HEADLINE: THE ASIAN CRISIS: THE DOMESTIC FALLOUT;
The Risks to America in Asia's Plummeting Markets

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23

 BODY:
Since he came to office President Clinton has repeated, time and again, that America's economic fortunes are tied to the spectacular growth of the powerhouses of the Pacific Rim. And the business world was far ahead of him, already building ventures from Kuala Lumpur to Hong Kong to New York.
But shared prosperity brings with it shared risk. And the question now is whether the financial earthquake that started somewhere under Thailand early this summer, and spread to Indonesia, Malaysia and Hong Kong, will end up here. 
 Some of the many possibilities being discussed on Wall Street and at the Treasury Department today were that the United States could become a safe haven for investors who now believe there is no place in Asia to hide -- not even Hong Kong, which today saw the biggest one-day market drop since the killings at Tiananmen Square in 1989.
But there is little question that the United States is at risk. Consider that in 1995, when Mexico plunged into a similar crisis after a currency devaluation late the previous year, America did about $100 billion in business across its southern border. That was a big figure -- big enough to spur President Clinton to bail out the Mexican economy. But it is dwarfed by United States trade with Asia, which last year was just shy of $300 billion, even without Japan.
Yet in Washington, there is no talk of a Mexico-pattern rescue for Southeast Asia, because the problems there vary greatly from country to country -- and in some places are barely understood at all.
"Mexico was relatively clean, one country with a diagnosable set of problems," a senior Administration official said recently.
But in Asia there is no such simplicity. Thailand suffers from a banking system built on a house of cards and a property market gone wild; Malaysia from trade and investment deficits; Indonesia from corruption and dubious accounting. But none of the quick fixes and austerity measures attempted over a long, hot summer of currency runs has succeeded in re-establishing confidence.
And now the crisis has hit Hong Kong -- the well-regulated, British-designed center of commerce that the rest of Asia was told to emulate.
It is Hong Kong's crisis that has alarmed the Clinton Administration as it finds itself struggling to douse the few flames that jumped the Pacific today, sending Wall Street stocks down more than 2 percent and many markets in Europe, 3 percent-plus. But American officials seemed to decide that anything they might say would only make a bad situation worse.
In his one public appearance today, Secretary of the Treasury Robert E. Rubin sidestepped a question about the markets by pointing to Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, who was sharing a platform, a joint appearance to press Congress into giving President Clinton new negotiating authority for trade accords.
"I will pass that question to the Secretary of State," Mr. Rubin said. "She is highly trained in the art of diplomacy -- talking a lot and not saying too much."
Nonetheless, American officials today were trying to think through a range of short- and long-term implications of the Asian markets' plunge.
The most obvious is the effect on exports. The first casualty of the Asian crisis is the cancellation or delay of scores of major public works projects, from dams and bridges in Indonesia, to a desperately needed light-rail project in Bangkok, to many elements of Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad's ambitious plan to turn Malaysia into the Silicon Valley of Southeast Asia.
American technology underlies many of those projects, and over the next few months major companies could be scaling back their profit estimates as big-ticket sales evaporate. That alone would not be so worrisome. But with Japan still in recession, and Europeans crawling their way out of double-digit unemployment, those projects were among the hottest tickets in the world.
Perhaps the bigger political risk in Washington is that the trade deficit with Asian nations is almost certain to rise, and rise sharply. Not only are their consumers becoming more frugal, but the wave after wave of currency devaluations are making Asian goods a lot cheaper. For the Clinton Administration, that is bound to cause a revival of political tensions, especially if the widening trade gap is combined with a slowing United States economy.
Harder to predict is the effect on the American stock and bond markets. While stocks were hurt today, bonds gained and the dollar rose against Asian currencies, suggesting that investors around the world were desperately seeking safety -- and found it here.
So the biggest impact indeed seems the political one. Underlying the Clinton Administration's drive to increase economic engagement with Asia was a sense that American influence through the region had been in decline. Washington's reaction so far has done nothing to reverse that view.
"There were a lot of Asians wondering why the Americans sat out during the emergency package for Thailand," said C. Fred Bergsten, president of the Institute for International Economics here, and a central figure in the first meetings that brought together heads of state from the nations that make up the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum, or APEC. "In their view, it is another test of Washington's commitment."
Today, the American representative to APEC, John S. Wolf, seemingly took note of Asians' ambivalent feelings when he told reporters: "Some are saying the United States and developed countries actually welcome the financial crisis now happening. Nothing could be more wrong."
But whether they are suspicious of the American reaction or not, the Asians are bound to be more cautious about opening their markets.
Many leaders in the region blame their moves toward openness, and the pressures to allow in even more foreign competition, for increasing the volatility of their currencies. While few subscribe to Prime Minister Mahathir's accusation that Southeast Asia was made a target for devaluation by a Jewish conspiracy, or at least by evil currency speculators, many say they share his suspicion that the West is perfectly happy to see the Asians, tigers and others, declawed.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 25, 1997, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
A front-page article and another in Business Day yesterday, and a chart showing the performance of stock markets around the world, misstated the German DAX 30 index. It closed on Thursday at 3,977.26 points, not 3,976.38. It was down 4.66 percent for the day, not 3.60 percent, and down 9.79 percent since Aug. 1, not 8.31 percent.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "One Market's Plunge Spreads Trouble Around the World"
PRELUDE -- The morning session in Japan and the first few hours of trading in Australia were unexceptional. Japanese markets close for lunch just as Hong Kong begins trading.
 
BLOODBATH -- Stocks in Hong Kong open much lower, rally briefly and then dive more than 10 percent further in just over an hour. Bargain hunters manage a rally to end the morning session.
 
THE FIRST CASUALTIES -- Hong Kong's early selloff pushes Australian and Japanese shares down sharply; later rallies fade when Hong Kong breaks for lunch and fears begin to mount that Hong Kong's afternoon session will bring another debacle. Waves of panic selling and bargain buying send stocks gyrating wildly in Hong Kong's afternoon session.
 
EUROPE REACTS -- Stocks in Europe begin trading just as Hong Kong's day ends and the final extent of its damage is known. Major markets open sharply lower or fall in their first minutes, and drift further down for most of their sessions.
 
ACROSS THE ATLANTIC -- American stocks react much the way Europe's did, but prices in Latin America are hit harder, as traders worry that economies there are vulnerable to the same pressures that have hammered Asia.

HEADLINE: THE ASIAN CRISIS: MARKET PLACE;
Thailand's Currency Flutters, And Wind Is Felt in the U.S.

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
Can the economic troubles of Thailand, a small country in Southeast Asia, really have begun the processes now causing currency turmoil through much of Asia and producing selloffs in nearly every stock market in the world?
Yes. 
 But the processes have been complicated, and have taken months to shake the confidence of international investors and the bull markets around the world. By yesterday, that confidence had plunged, and stock markets fell sharply. The selloff in the United States, which sent the Dow Jones industrial average down 2.3 percent, was the mildest among major markets. It was a selloff that began in Hong Kong, where the stock market has fallen 23 percent this week.
The effect of all the turmoil in Asia will almost certainly mean slower economic growth in that area and lower profits for some American and other multinational companies. And those Americans who invested in some mutual funds devoted to Asian markets have lost billions of dollars.
But until this week, most economists had thought the impacts -- both economic and financial -- would be minor. The selloffs, however, have raised the specter of a worldwide loss of investor confidence. Were that to happen, the economic impact could be much greater.
Most countries in Southeast Asia had chosen to tie their currencies to the dollar, with an exchange rate that is fixed or allowed to narrowly fluctuate. That had advantages for businesses, which could plan with some certainty, but it defied the fact that the economies were performing differently from the United States economy and each other.
Over time, Thailand -- the first of the countries to suffer -- found itself with a currency that was overvalued. Imports were flooding in as Thais bought foreign luxury goods, and exports stagnated. Some international speculators began to bet the currency would be devalued. They did that by borrowing the currency -- called the baht -- and selling baht for dollars or other currencies. They would profit if they could later repurchase the baht for less.
Thailand's responded with fury. It denounced speculators and took steps to punish them. It raised interest rates -- making it more expensive to borrow baht -- and prohibited some foreigners from possessing baht. That briefly strengthened the baht, and some speculators suffered substantial losses.
But in the meantime, many Thais, particularly business people, became worried. They had borrowed dollars to finance their businesses, rather than borrowing baht, because interest rates in dollars were lower. If the baht were to fall, they would be in trouble, since the dollars needed to repay loans would cost a lot more baht. So many Thais bought dollars to protect themselves. And that buying, coupled with that of international speculators, overwhelmed the Thai Government's defenses.
"When you have currencies under pressure, almost everyone becomes a speculator," Peter Allen, the head of emerging markets research at BankBoston, said yesterday.
That process has been repeated in several Asian countries, among them Malaysia, Indonesia and the Philippines. Now it has spread to Hong Kong, a darling of international investors even after China retook control on July 1. The Hong Kong dollar has been fixed to the American dollar since 1984, under a system known as a currency board. Hong Kong currency is issued not by the Government, but by three banks. For every Hong Kong dollar they issue, they must deposit an equivalent number of American dollars.
Hong Kong's interest rates have also been closer to American ones, and few people thought the currency was likely to succumb to pressure. But speculation it might nonetheless led to some of the same selling seen in other markets.
To keep the currency stable, the annual interest rate on money borrowed for one night rose to as high as 300 percent. That makes it very expensive to speculate against the currency, and yesterday, even as Hong Kong stocks plunged, the Hong Kong dollar rose a bit -- evidently as currency speculators retreated.
John Greenwood, the chief economist for GT Global, a mutual fund management company and a man named to the Order of the British Empire for his role in conceiving the Hong Kong currency system in 1984, said yesterday that he expected the Hong Kong currency to hold its value. But he noted that selling pressure had been greater than at any time since the Tiananmen Square killings in Beijing in 1989.
He also said that were high rates to continue for months -- even at 30 percent or so -- it would depress the Hong Kong economy.
It has taken months to persuade many investors that there was more to this crisis than currency values. When the baht cracked in July, Thai stocks rallied. (They have since fallen.) Numerous analysts opined that Thailand and other Asian countrieshad buoyant economies that would perhaps grow even stronger since they were now blessed with cheaper currencies, making their exports more competitive. Some investors who withdrew money from Asia moved it to Latin America, confident that emerging markets were the place to be.
But gradually, fear has set in that Asia, the strongest economic region in recent years, might be in trouble. That has set off alarms about growth elsewhere.
Against the backdrop of record-high stock markets around much of the world, the worries led to waves of selling yesterday, first in Asia, then in Europe, then in the Americas. Latin America was especially hit, but the United States got off relatively lightly. In fact, after strong rallies earlier this week on strong profits from companies like I.B.M. and Microsoft, major American stock indexes remain higher for the week even after yesterday's selloff.
For the American economy, the direct implications of the Asian turmoil are clearly negative, but have seemed likely to be mild. They will depress the profits of companies that sell things to the affected Asian countries. Relatively few Southeast Asian exports compete directly with American products, but those that do will likely be cheaper and thus do better. That could, of course, be good news for American consumers.
The stock market selloffs yesterday smacked of panic, and panic usually abates within a few days. In fact, a security traded on the American Stock Exchange, equivalent to a basket of Hong Kong stocks, ended yesterday 3 percent higher than the Hong Kong market had been, indicating some traders expected Hong Kong to at least partly recover today. The longer-term question will be whether the Asian turmoil means world growth is likely to slow significantly. Were that the case, the high level of stock prices that has prevailed here and abroad could be in serious danger.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 30, 1997, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
Articles on Oct. 21 and Oct. 24 about the Thai economy misstated one effect of the recent downturn there. Many Thai finance companies, but none of its banks, have collapsed recently.

HEADLINE: Success and the Black Magazine;
As Readers Prosper, Advertising Still Eludes Publishers

BYLINE: By ROBIN POGREBIN 

DATELINE: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., Oct. 24

 BODY:
As Edward Lewis tells the story, his wife was approached at a 1992 party by the cosmetics executive Leonard A. Lauder, chairman of the Estee Lauder Companies, who joked, "Ed Lewis never smiles."
"He would smile," she replied, "if you advertised in his magazine." 
 Whether her remark did the trick or not, the Lauder companies began advertising in Essence magazine soon afterward. More to the point, though, this tale gives some sense of the difficulty black magazines still confront in securing high-end advertising.
Although such hurdles have persisted throughout the 27 years since Mr. Lewis helped found Essence, a life-style magazine for black women, he has managed to build Essence Communications Inc. into a $100 million publishing business.
And today, at the American Magazine Conference here, Mr. Lewis was named chairman of the Magazine Publishers of America, making him the first black to head the 78-year-old trade group, which represents more than 700 magazines.
Mr. Lewis, 57, his company's chairman and chief executive, takes the helm of the publishers association at a time of both promise and frustration for black magazines. As blacks have become more educated and prosperous in recent years, mainstream magazines are paying increasing attention to them, and a number of new publications have come along to compete for that market. Yet black publishers say much of the advertising industry remains stubbornly resistant.
"We've come a long way," Mr. Lewis said in an interview at his Manhattan office, overlooking Times Square. "We've got a long way to go."
People in the industry give varying explanations for the obstacles. Black publishing executives say that media planners tend to be young whites who do not read or relate to black publications and that residual racism leads advertisers to assume that black readers do not have money to spend.
But advertising people say they can reach blacks better through television than through print media. They also say blacks have become a larger part of the general magazine audience, making it unnecessary to seek them in black publications.
"As African-Americans have become more mainstream and middle class, we do seem to assume we're reaching them through mainstream television and magazines," said Gene DeWitt, president of DeWitt Media, a media buying agency.
Black publishing executives say the election of Mr. Lewis sends a powerful, much-needed signal to the industry that minority readers matter.
"It's a tremendous statement and a tremendous opportunity for the magazine industry to take a hard look at itself," said Roy S. Johnson, an editor at large at Fortune magazine, who has been developing a magazine for blacks that Time Inc. hopes to produce jointly with Essence.
"No magazine should be published without people of color in its pages," he said, "whether it's a parents magazine, a business magazine or a travel magazine."
Donald D. Kummerfeld, president of the publishers group, emphasized that Mr. Lewis's appointment was not intended as a mere symbol. "He earned it just as much as every other chair," Mr. Kummerfeld said. "That being said, one of our goals is to see that our industry reflects the diversity of its readers."
Blacks' total earned income was $367 billion in 1996, up from an inflation-adjusted $243 billion in 1980, and black households are spending more than white ones on new cars, clothing and home furnishings, according to the latest edition of "The Buying Power of Black America," an annual report compiled by Target Market News, a Chicago research firm.
Spending by blacks on new appliances doubled, to $2.2 billion, from 1995 to 1996, and spending for furnishings rose from $8.3 billion, to $10.4 billion. The roughly 12 million black households spent $175 million on magazines last year, Target said.
As a result, mainstream magazines have been covering blacks more thoroughly, which might lead some black readers to feel less need for publications directed exclusively at them.
The fashion magazine Elle, for example, features a black model on its November cover. And Fortune's August issue on "new black power," profiling prominent blacks in business, was its second-best-selling cover of the year to date, after an issue that featured America's most admired companies.
But while Mr. Lewis concedes that such nibbles at his market keep Essence on its toes, he remains confident that black women will continue to need a magazine of their own. "Black women read other magazines," he said. "But they also want to see themselves."
Sure enough, established black magazines like Essence, Ebony and Black Enterprise all show ad page increases of 2 percent to 11 percent through September, although Essence's paid circulation declined one-tenth of a percent for the six months ended June 1997 and Ebony's fell 7.4 percent. (At Black Enterprise, which is published by Earl G. Graves Ltd., circulation was up 2.5 percent.)
Newer titles are also looking to get in on the action. These include Heart & Soul, a health and fitness magazine for black women published by Rodale Press, which publishes the successful Men's Health, among others; American Legacy, a quarterly black history and culture magazine jointly published by the American Heritage division of Forbes and RJR Communications, which is distributed in unconventional places like black churches and colleges; B.E.T. Weekend, a black entertainment and life-style magazine inserted into newspapers, published jointly by The Daily News in New York and Black Entertainment Television, which also publishes the black news magazine Emerge, and Black Child, a magazine for black parents, published by Interrace Publications in Atlanta.
Mr. Lewis, it would seem, should smile when he surveys this growing market, which he has done so much to nurture.
Essence, after all, has won several awards and built its circulation to one million. And while its second and third issues had only five ad pages each, the magazine expects to end this year with more than 1,000.
Mr. Lewis, who used to be known as Stone Face Lewis, does smile more these days, but he is not satisfied. "Some people will say, 'What are you whining about?' " he said. "But it's not good enough."
Along with his partner, Clarence O. Smith, the president of Essence, Mr. Lewis has big ideas for Essence Communications. "I want to be like Time Warner," Mr. Lewis said. "If Time Warner can employ over 30,000 people, I want Essence Communications to employ over 30,000 people."
With about 150 employees at Essence now, Mr. Lewis sounds like a dreamer. But he has already made some progress toward expanding the franchise. In 1992, Essence acquired the business magazine Income Opportunities from Davis Publishing. Last year it entered a joint venture to publish Latina, a magazine for Hispanic women, and it is considering teaming up with Time Inc. to produce Savoy, a black life-style magazine.
Essence has extended its brand name to a mail-order catalogue as well as an entertainment division that every year produces the nationally televised Essence awards at Madison Square Garden's theater and a four-day Essence music festival at the Superdome in New Orleans.
And, with its February issue, Essence plans to come out with a comprehensive redesign that will add several sections and increase beauty, fashion and home coverage; introduce a binding with a flat spine to allow more advertiser inserts and coupons, and make four-color ads available throughout the magazine. The magazine is also increasing its newsstand price in January to $2.75 from $2.50.
"We just cannot sit back and take our audience for granted," Mr. Lewis said. "We want to stay on top."
On one level, the general market has grown tougher, with more titles than ever vying for readers and ad dollars. But Essence and other black publications say they have an added burden: getting advertisers to understand them. "We always have to re-educate, retell our story," Mr. Lewis said. "The Glamours and the Vogues don't have to do that."
While black magazines have made significant progress in attracting automotive, tobacco and liquor advertisements, whole categories remain almost completely absent from their pages, like high-end fashion, travel and technology.
"Obviously we're not where we want to be," said John H. Johnson, publisher, chairman and chief executive of the Chicago-based Johnson Publishing Company, which publishes Ebony, Jet and Ebony Man. "None of us have done well in the fashion business with colognes and perfumes and designer clothes. Blacks wear them, but we so far haven't been able to convince advertisers that we do."
Despite the hurdles, Mr. Lewis has persevered, with a soft-spoken calm and courtly elegance that has won him friends in high places, like Bill Cosby and David N. Dinkins, the former Mayor of New York.
"You will not find a person anywhere that will find an unkind word to say about Ed Lewis," said Mr. Dinkins, one of several prominent blacks who joined Mr. Lewis in signing full-page newspaper ads on Aug. 27 condemning the treatment of Abner Louima, a Haitian who prosecutors say was tortured by police officers at a Brooklyn stationhouse.
Mr. Lewis spreads the credit around -- mainly to his partner, Mr. Smith, a former insurance salesman who helped found Essence in 1970. "He wants everything yesterday," Mr. Lewis said in characterizing their differences. "I can deal with tomorrow."
He also praises Essence's editor in chief of 16 years, Susan L. Taylor, saying she "gave Essence its soul."
"The definition of power is shared dependency," Mr. Lewis said.
The son of a beautician and a janitor who grew up in the South Bronx and became a New York All City fullback, Mr. Lewis went to the University of New Mexico on a football scholarship in 1958 -- one of five blacks out of 8,000 students. He majored in political science and international relations with a minor in Russian and Chinese history. After one unsuccessful year at Georgetown Law School, Mr. Lewis joined Citibank's executive training program and was fast on his way to becoming a loan officer when the entrepreneurial tug lured him away to start Essence.
He lives on the Upper West Side of Manhattan with his second wife, Carolyn Wright-Lewis, a speech pathologist with two grown daughters. If he doesn't walk to work, Mr. Lewis takes the subway or a car service and does not even bother trying to hail a taxi. "Just too many pass me by," Mr. Lewis said. "You can't imagine the frustration I feel."
One edge black magazines have is that prominent blacks make themselves available for in-depth interviews. Essence's cover article for October, for example, is a rare interview with the oldest daughter of Betty Shabazz, the widow of Malcolm X, who died from injuries in a fire set by her grandson. "We ask questions about their deepest thoughts and lives," said Ms. Taylor, the editor. "These are our people, and we care deeply about them."
While Essence might appear to be a black version of a mainstream women's magazine -- and includes conventional fare like beauty and fashion -- Mr. Lewis said it also addressed subjects of particular concern to black women, like single parenthood, child abuse, AIDS, abortion and welfare.
"We have one common denominator: that we are black," he said. "Because of what has happened in our history, we have always had to deal with these kinds of issues."

HEADLINE: As Turmoil Builds, Thai Leader Shuffles Cabinet

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 24

 BODY:
Thailand's political turmoil widened today, with the Prime Minister shuffling his Cabinet, naming a new Finance Minister and pledging to hold early elections.
The actions followed a week of political infighting, street demonstrations and demands for Prime Minister Chavalit Yongchaiyudh's resignation, even as the Thai currency continued to plummet and the economy continued to sour. 
 At the epicenter of Asia's economic crisis, the country that was hit first and hardest, Thailand seems unable to come to grips with its most pressing issues.
More than two months after being promised a $17 billion credit line by the International Monetary Fund -- the second largest, after Mexico's $40 billion bailout in 1994 -- Thailand has barely begun to formulate the economic restructuring that is required for the recovery program.
People are asking, as a Thai banker put it: "Who is setting economic policy today? Is there an economic policy?"
With prices rising, the stock market falling, tens of thousands of jobs being lost and half the country's financial institutions closed down, Thailand is concerned not with recovery but politics.
For the last week, leaders of the fractious six-party coalition Government have been wrestling behind closed doors over a Cabinet reorganization and struggling to find a replacement for the Finance Minister, who quit last week.
On Tuesday the Prime Minister was reported to have been dissuaded at the last moment by his top general from seizing more powers by declaring a state of emergency that would have sent the country's financial markets into further disarray.
Calls for Mr. Chavalit's ouster have gained momentum in the press, which has begun calling him a "madman," and among the demonstrators in the streets. Now, supporters of the Prime Minister are threatening to bus farmers into the city for counter-demonstrations that raise the possibility of a violent confrontation.
"The Prime Minister is trying to get away with not changing anything," said Montree Sornpaisarn, a leader of the anti-Chavalit demonstrations. "We think it's time for the Thai people to help their country."
In the midst of this tumult, Government action on the economic crisis has come to a virtual standstill.
"You start to wonder what is going to happen and when will something happen and how quickly will they move to actually do something," said Daniel King, an American political scientist who found himself out of work when the local bank where he was working shut down.
"The decision-makers seem unwilling and incapable of making decisions and carrying out the plans they have promised to implement," he said. "We are at a standstill, and there is not much to point to to say Thailand is complying with the I.M.F. program."
So far the Government has raised the sales tax and made plans for spending cuts that will halt a number of projects like highways and rail lines that are essential to further growth. But when it took the difficult step of raising fuel taxes last week to meet a budget target demanded by the I.M.F., it quickly rescinded it in the face of public resistance.
Economic analysts generally agree that with quick, effective action, Thailand, like other ailing nations in Southeast Asia, can recover and resume its growth in two or three years or less.
Without such action, they say, the pain will increase and recovery will take much longer.
"If the right measures are not taken, this could well be a five- to seven-year recovery," said Roy Ramos, an economist with Goldman Sachs in Singapore. "Part of the problem in Thailand was that there was a denial of the problem and procrastination. You can't solve a problem by denial."
The political uncertainty has itself become one of Thailand's foremost economic problems as investor confidence slips lower and foreign lenders close off their credit lines.
During the boom times, when Thailand's economy was growing at 8 percent a year, private companies accumulated some $73 billion in debt abroad, $18 billion of which is scheduled to come due by the end of the year.
On Wednesday the Political and Economic Risk Consultancy, a consulting company based in Hong Kong, warned of possible social unrest if Thailand's logjam is not broken.
"Economic problems are now so widespread that they are taking the Thai people into unknown territory and thus their response to painful new experiences cannot be easily predicted," it said.
"A clean sweep of the Government would do more than anything to guarantee stability. Indeed, it would be unwise to be optimistic about social harmony unless there is political change soon."
Both Moody's Investor Service and Standard and Poor's international credit rating agency have lowered Thailand's rating in the last few days. Their pessimistic assessments were based not on the country's economic fundamentals but on its ineffectual political leadership.
Standard and Poor's cited the country's patronage-based politics and its system of weak and fragmented governments that stymie the attempts of technocrats to put rigorous policies into effect.
Finance Minister Thanong Bidaya announced on Oct. 17 that he would resign after the Government retreated from the fuel tax increase. Several candidates were reported in the Thai press to have turned down the job before it was given today to Kosit Panpiemras, a banker, as part of the reorganization of the Cabinet.
The Prime Minister also said today that Parliament would debate a set of laws next month under a newly adopted Constitution that would allow a general election to be held as early as December.
The new Constitution is designed to change Thailand's system of vote-buying, which critics say drains the country's treasury and produces corrupt and ineffectual governments that spend much of their energy trying to earn back the huge amounts they spent in their campaigns.
In the last election, 10 months ago, according to a recent analysis, fully $800 million was spent buying votes.
Political analysts say another election -- and a new government -- may be the only way to get the country moving again. But if it is anything like the last one, they say, it could break the bank.

HEADLINE: U.S. Defends Weakened Rebuke to Iraqis

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24

 BODY:
The United States said today that despite the abstention of five countries on a Security Council resolution threatening new sanctions against Iraq, the vote sent a signal to Baghdad.
"We do regret the decision by France, Russia, China, Egypt and Kenya to abstain on this resolution," a State Department spokesman, Lee McClenny, said. "The bottom line is, the resolution passed." 
 The resolution, approved in a vote on Thursday, expressed the "firm intention" of the 15-member Security Council to ban the travel of Iraqi officials if they continue to hinder the work of United Nations weapons inspection teams.
Mr. McClenny said President Saddam Hussein of Iraq should understand the basic message: that the Security Council supports the inspection teams. "He should see clearly that if he continues to challenge that mandate, the Council intends to take further action," the spokesman said.
Economic sanctions were imposed after Iraq's defeat in the gulf war in 1991. Before these can be ended, United Nations monitors must confirm that Iraq has destroyed its major weapons systems.

HEADLINE: Fears of a Sale By Swiss Send Gold Plunging

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
Gold prices plunged to the lowest level in more than 12 years yesterday after a Swiss Government panel recommended that the country sell about half its gold reserves, raising fears that other countries would do the same and inundate the market.
Although the Swiss Government might sell less gold than the panel recommended and might not undertake any sale for some time, the prospect that such a financially conservative bastion as Switzerland would even contemplate an enormous sale unnerved gold traders. Switzerland's gold reserves total 2,600 tons, the fifth-largest stockpile in the world. 
 This was just the latest blow to gold, once the main hedge against inflation and uncertainty. In another powerful sign of gold's diminishing allure, there was little demand for it this week despite the financial turmoil in Southeast Asia that roiled global stock markets around the world.
"The reaction to the crisis in Asia was important," said William O'Neill, director of commodity research at Merrill Lynch & Company. "People did not go into gold, they went into bonds or currency."
 The spot price of gold in New York fell $14.65 an ounce yesterday, or 4.5 percent, to $309 an ounce. It was the lowest level since March 1985.
Several forces have combined to depress the price of gold, which is down 16 percent so far this year. Analysts said one reason for the decline was that the United States economy had shown little sign of inflation. Indeed, one reason why stock markets in the United States and many other places have been rallying until recently is the absence of inflationary pressure.
"In the old days, if you were worried about inflation you went to gold," said Douglas M. Cohen, an analyst at Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Company. "Now there are all sorts of hedges. It's tough to make the case that gold is the hedge that it once was."
 The end of Communism and the move to a single European currency have also detracted from the value of gold, thus recently many of the world's central banks have chosen to sell some of their gold reserves.
The last big drop in gold prices happened in July, when the central bank in Australia said that it had sold about two-thirds of its gold reserves over the previous six months. Belgium and a host of other countries have also hinted that they are considering selling some gold reserves.
 "For the last couple of years a lot of people have been questioning the value of gold; there was the feeling that a lot of central banks were losing their faith in gold," Mr. Cohen said. "This move today reinforces the view that gold is losing its place as a store of value."
 The Swiss Government panel's recommendations are a partial outgrowth of Switzerland's previously announced decision to consider restructuring its gold reserves to create a new fund that would benefit Holocaust victims and the disadvantaged.
The Swiss would profit immensely from a sale of gold, which has been carried on their books at an artificially low price for decades.
But the possible sale of up to 1,400 tons of its gold, about 45 million ounces, or 45 percent of Switzerland's total, was far more than anyone envisioned. Moreover, other central banks that have been retaining gold might feel pressured to unload gold before the price drops further.
"It's not the 1,400 tons that's significant; it's the sentiment," said Harry Bingham, the manager of institutional gold portfolios at Van Eck Associates, a mutual fund company. "Maybe other countries will see this and also want to sell."
 Still, there are those who remain bullish on gold, arguing that even in these times of relative political stability, the social and political environment could quickly shift and resurrect gold's allure.
 Mr. Bingham said if there was such a change, gold investors could find themselves suddenly wealthier, while others who have plowed money into other investments would be second-guessing themselves.
"You know the golden rule," Mr. Bingham said. "He who has the gold makes the rules. And to me, it's bullish for people who have gold. Paper doesn't have the intrinsic value gold does."

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Selloff"
Gold prices plummeted yesterday following the news that Switzerland might sell 45 million ounces of its reserves. Chart shows spot price for an ounce of gold, plotted daily for the months June through October 1997. (Source: Bloomberg Financial Markets)(pg. D2)

HEADLINE: Hong Kong Investors Look (Hard) for the Silver Lining

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, Oct. 24

 BODY:
Along Des Voeux Road, in front of dozens and dozens of flickering market monitors, a sustained sigh of relief issued from anxious Hong Kong investors today.
As the day wore on, a battered stock market seemed to regain some of its bearings and begin to move upward. After a devastating Thursday, when the market plunged more than 1,200 points, or 10.4 percent, investors rushed today to buy stocks that seemed like bargains, And at the end of trading, the benchmark Hang Seng index was up 718.04 points, or 6.9 percent, at 11,144.34. 
 Still, pessimism seemed interwoven with hope all along Des Voeux Road, a stretch containing more than 20 banks through the central business district.
"You can't tell what's going to happen, but I think there's a chance that it will go down some more," said Lok Lai Kong as he took a commanding position in front of monitor at the Bank of Communications. "I've lost a lot, a whole lot. It's a very serious damage for me.
"My wife says when I lose at mah-jongg I get all upset," added Mr. Lok, who is 66 and, he said, happily retired. "But when I lose in the stock market, I still feel fine -- even in a good mood. Anyway, how much can I lose?"
At another screen, investors punched in numbers of their favorite stocks. "I lost probably half of what I invested," Alan Au, a 31-year-old cosmetics wholesaler, said ruefully. "Right now I'm going to wait a bit. It'll probably go up a little, then I'll sell some of what I have and rearrange my portfolio by buying some better ones. The market will probably go up again, and then it can drop down to 8,000 -- that's a possibility."
Inside brokerage houses nearby, delight over the market's rise was tangible, but the focus was on the Hong Kong dollar. The Government's determination to maintain the currency's 14-year link to the American dollar has driven interest rates sharply higher and acted as a drag on stocks.
At the same time, the collapse of other currencies in Southeast Asia against the American currency, and by implication against the Hong Kong dollar, has made this newly minted piece of China a very expensive place.
"There is still currency tension in the region," said Pauline Gately, regional strategist for BZW Asia. "Until that dissipates, Hong Kong will not be truly out of the woods. After Korea and Taiwan, the only real strong currency is the Hong Kong dollar, and speculators decided to have a go at it."
But while the speculators have been successful in driving down the currencies of Thailand, Indonesia, Malaysia and other countries in the region, Ms. Gately said, they may have miscalculated this time.
"The speculators initiated this, but there's also genuine demand for the Hong Kong dollar," she said. "We are very much of the view that the currency will hold. Today, the market has rallied; it will encounter some selling again. But we will have a better feel of where we stand in a week or so."
Hong Kong officials have said they will stave off assaults on their currency despite the cost. And Hong Kong has the wherewithal to fight: At the end of last month, it was holding $88.1 billion in foreign-currency reserves, a hard-currency trove surpassed only by Japan's and by that of China, which has stored up $130.3 billion.
Hong Kong can use that money to buy its own currency, reducing the supply of Hong Kong dollars on the market and thereby making them more expensive.
Tung Chee-hwa, the city's chief executive -- after returning from a European trip, on which he sought to persuade leaders that China's new rule had not altered Hong Kong's way of life -- wasted no time today in throwing down the gauntlet to speculators.
"We will make sure they do not succeed in whatever they try to do," said Mr. Tung, who was appointed by China to administer Hong Kong, and took over nearly four months ago on the transfer of power from the British. "Let me emphasize to you the government's determination to maintain the linked exchange rate," he went on. "It has served us well. It will continue to be important for our future prosperity."
In fighting off attacks on the Hong Kong dollar, which is fixed at a rate around 7.75 to 1 to American currency, monetary officials here pushed up overnight money market rates last night to a range of 250 to 280 percent, from 6 percent early this week.
At the same time, Mr. Tung was seeking to allay investors' concerns about the stock market's volatility. "The market has fallen," he said, "but at a certain level it becomes a good buy and then there will be buyers in the market, and the market will start to rebound."
Even so, economists and business leaders here fear that the local economy will suffer from the high interest rates needed to sustain the Hong Kong dollar's value.
"People now believe that the peg will indeed stay in place, and the price for that is high interest rates," said Clive McDonnell, senior economist for North Asia at Societe Generale Crosby Securities. But he added: "There is a weakness in the economy caused by slower external accounts. We have adjusted our G.D.P. growth for '98 from 5.7 percent to 4.8 percent." G.D.P., or gross domestic product, is a broad gauge of a nation's economic growth.
Others were a great deal gloomier. "If the peg is not broken, interest rates will have to rise and economic development in Hong Kong could come to a screeching halt," said Jeff Malakoff, a member of the treasury management team at Honeywell Inc., which has operations here.
At Morgan Stanley Asia, Andy Xie, an economist for the greater China region, was not discouraged by the market's volatility. "The worst may be over," he said. "I think that the Hong Kong Monetary Authority is doing an outstanding job. The pressure on the currency will continue, but the worst has happened yesterday."
Still, he said, Hong Kong faces a painful period of readjustment. "The long-term outlook is that Hong Kong will go through some sort of restructuring process like other economies," he said. "Interest rates will remain higher than pre-crisis levels. But as the asset appreciation corrects, it will be good for Hong Kong."
On Des Voeux Road, however, concerns were immediate, and the potential benefits of this week's crisis were hard to see.
"I'm not very optimistic of the long-term development," said Ada Chan, who paused to look at a market monitor at the Star Internet Center. "I don't think there was anyone who didn't lose money. I think this is a good warning for small investors -- that they should be more cautious and not get caught up by all this."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Hong Kong Rebounds, But Not U.S. Stocks
Investors sent stocks sharply lower for a second day on Wall Street, despite a partial recovery in Hong Kong from the previous day's 10.4 percent drop. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 132.36 points, to 7,715.41, a drop of 1.7 percent atop Thursday's 2.3 percent fall. Many investors shifted into Treasury bonds, which rose for a second day. 
 After initially trading higher, stock markets were lower in Europe and elsewhere, too. Wall Street's gloomy reception to Hong Kong's rally could be bad news for Asia. Without the vote of confidence from America that Asia had been hoping for, the market turmoil that has been shaking the region for weeks, and that spread to Hong Kong and the rest of the world on Thursday, could resume. Page A1.
 
Thailand's political upheavals, an outgrowth of Southeast Asia's financial crisis, widened with the Prime Minister shuffling his Cabinet, naming a new finance minister and promising to hold early elections. A3.
 
President Supports China Ties
Even as investors focused on the problems in Southeast Asia and Hong Kong, President Clinton defended his policy of engagement with China as fundamental to America's economic and security interests, declaring the isolation of China to be "unworkable, counterproductive and potentially dangerous." The comments were meant to lay a foundation for next week's summit meeting with President Jiang Zemin of China. A6.
 
Boeing's Loss Exceeds Estimates
Boeing, struggling to keep up with the demand for its commercial airplanes, reported a big gain in revenue but suffered a larger-than-expected loss, largely because of a $1.6 billion pretax charge to cover production problems on the 747 and 737 jets. Boeing expects additional big write-offs before it fully recovers. D3.
 
School Internet Links Questioned
As volunteers in more than 40 states string up telephone wire and install computers with Internet access in schools today as part of the second annual Net Day, doubts are growing about the educational value of the public data network. Critics contend that the Internet is irrelevant for many American students who lack basic math and literacy skills. A1.
 
More Amtrak Uncertainty
The House of Representatives failed for a third day to take action that would provide new capital for Amtrak and amend labor rules in an effort to avert a strike at midnight next Tuesday. But legislation was introduced in the Senate to prevent a walkout, and agreements were reached to avoid possible disruptions to some commuter rail services. A9.
 
Panel Backs Aspirin Rival
An F.D.A. advisory panel gave its backing to Plavix, a new heart drug that its manufacturers -- Bristol-Myers Squibb and Sanofi -- call superior to aspirin. But even if Plavix wins F.D.A. approval, it is unclear whether the drug can successfully compete with aspirin, a doctor-recommended and cheaper therapy for heart disease. D15.
 
Milken Probation Prolonged
A Federal judge extended Michael Milken's probation a sixth time while regulators consider whether the former Drexel Burnham Lambert junk-bond financier is obeying a court-ordered ban from the securities industry. D14.
 
Nasdaq Short Positions Increase
In a possible sign of rising bearishness, the number of open positions on short sales on the Nasdaq stock market rose 7.1 percent in the month that ended on Oct. 15, the largest increase since October 1993. D14.
 
Hilton Extends ITT Offer
Despite its apparent defeat in a hostile takeover battle for ITT, Hilton Hotels extended its cash tender offer for 50.1 percent of the company's stock at $70 a share. D2.

HEADLINE: WALL STREET FAILS TO BUILD ON RALLY SEEN IN HONG KONG

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Hong Kong paved the way yesterday for a recovery from Thursday's global stock market rout, but Wall Street would not cooperate.
Apparently worried that the financial crisis in Southeast Asia could become worse before it becomes better, investors pounded the Dow Jones industrial average for the second consecutive day, dashing hopes that Hong Kong's rebound from its blackest trading day in eight years would spread to the United States. 
 Other major markets, which opened earlier than New York's exchanges, took their cue from Hong Kong. After stocks in the Chinese territory surged by nearly 7 percent, wiping out most of Thursday's 10 percent plunge, Japanese stocks bounced back and markets in Europe opened stronger. Hours later, when the Dow sprinted up almost 92 points in the morning, it seemed that Wall Street would join the euphoria.
But the American rally fizzled, and as stock prices moved lower, European markets fell with them. And the emerging markets in Latin America, the ones most vulnerable to the turmoil in Asia, fell even further, adding to their very sharp losses of Thursday. In the afternoon, the Dow's decline deepened, and it closed down 132.36 points, at 7,715.41. The Dow's drop over the last two days was the biggest since the end of March.
Wall Street's gloomy reception to Hong Kong's rally could be bad news for Asia. Without a vote of confidence from the United States, the market turmoil that has been roiling the region for weeks and spread to Hong Kong and the rest of the world on Thursday, could resume on Monday. Making matters worse, the political crisis in Thailand -- where the troubles began -- worsened yesterday. Page A3. And that boded ill for investors in Hong Kong, who were desperately trying to recoup some of their losses as the market turned back up. Page D1.
A further Asian decline might also mean that the United States and its allies, especially Japan, will be forced to take more decisive action to return calm to Asia.
"You haven't seen any statement out of the International Monetary Fund or the Treasury as yet that indicates that they see the situation as seriously as investors do," said Lawrence J. Brainard, global head of emerging-market research as Chase Securities. Thailand has already received a $17 billion rescue package from the I.M.F., but has been unable to carry it out because of all the market turbulence.
Uncertainty about the stock market's direction infected Wall Street just after the opening.
"I think its going to be very interesting how the U.S. responds today," Barton Biggs, global strategist at Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Company, said after the stock market opened yesterday morning. He quickly found out.
"It is fading fast," Mr. Biggs noted as the Dow began to give up its early gains. "I still think this is a big deal and an important event."
Two forces seemed to drive the American markets lower yesterday and take the steam out of the early rebound.
One was the fear among investors and analysts that although Hong Kong has managed, for now, to stem the tide of the financial crisis that has engulfed Thailand, Indonesia, Malaysia and the Philippines, they still have to consider the possibility that things can worsen. This is a big change in sentiment from just several days ago, when the assumption was that the Southeast Asian turmoil was a mere annoyance to the rest of the world and that Hong Kong, with its stronger corporate and financial underpinnings, was immune.
The second was that investors have begun to look more closely at the companies that might suffer if economic growth slows significantly in Asia, undercutting the demand for products made by American companies. Companies that have big stakes in Asia, including I.B.M., Coca-Cola and Texas Instruments, helped lead the market lower yesterday. Companies in the semiconductor business, like Applied Materials , which sells the machines to make the silicon wafers, also fell sharply as investors bet that the demand from Asia would decline.
What was worrying some people yesterday more than the American markets was Latin America. Just days ago, many analysts were confident that the spillover from Asia would not have a significant impact on Brazil, Mexico or Argentina, favorite territory for American investors.
Mr. Brainard of Chase Securities said he was worried the financial disturbances would spill over to those countries if Hong Kong could not defend its currency, which is pegged to the dollar. Those speculators, he said, are betting that the Hong Kong currency will have to fall just like the currencies of Singapore, Taiwan, Malaysia, Indonesia and Thailand.
The defense of the Hong Kong dollar has meant a surge in interest rates to attract investors and make such speculation expensive. The increase in rates, in turn, pushed stocks lower because the increases undermine the earnings of the financial and property companies that are the backbone of the Hong Kong economy. Overnight interest rates were at 20 percent yesterday, well below the spike to 300 percent on Thursday but far above the recent 5 percent to 6 percent level.
Mr. Brainard said it "isn't likely" that Hong Kong will lose its currency battle. "But it is being seen more as a problem in the markets," he said. "And if the Hong Kong dollar peg goes, there is no way other regions escape." The most likely target for a similar attack in Latin America would be Brazil, he said.
Abby Joseph Cohen, the co-chairwoman of the investment policy committee at Goldman, Sachs & Company, said that she thought the stock selling in the United States might be overdone. Investors, she said, are ignoring the positive implications of the Asian turmoil -- lower interest rates and less inflationary pressure as economic growth slows -- and are overestimating its impact on earnings.
For example, she said that American companies do more business in Mexico and Canada than in Asia and that a lot of the products sold there, like machinery for making computer chips, are needed by foreign chip makers to remain competitive. This means that sales will be less sensitive to an economic slowdown than investors think. So, she does not expect foreign-related earnings to go down. "They just won't go up as much," she said. "So the impact is less than expected."
Yesterday's drop in the Dow was equal to 1.7 percent, on top of Thursday's 2.3 percent slump. The broader Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks fell 9.05 points, or 1 percent, to 941.64.
New York was not the only market to throw cold water on hopes for an end to the international financial crisis. Despite Hong Kong's resurgence, other East Asian markets slumped, with Singapore off 1.9 percent, Taiwan down 1.4 percent, Malaysia off 2 percent, Indonesia down 0.8 percent and Thailand off 3.4 percent.
In other regions, Brazil's stock market fell 3 percent and Mexico's 2.7 percent. Britain's main market index, which was up more than 100 points, or 2.2 percent, before Wall Street opened, finished down 21 points, or 0.4 percent.
Other financial markets were calmer yesterday. The 30-year Treasury bond rose 1 6/32 , to a price 101 13/32 , and the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, dropped to 6.27 percent, from 6.31 percent on Thursday. Much of the rally, as on Thursday, came from overseas investors seeking a haven for their investments.
The bond market also benefited from a growing belief among investors that the Federal Reserve, fearful of aggravating all the recent financial convulsions, will refrain from raising its short-term interest-rate target when its policy-making committee meets on Nov. 12.
The dollar rose modestly against the German mark and was unchanged against the Japanese yen. In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 1.7730 marks, up from 1.7682 late on Thursday. It also was steady at 121.87 yen.
Gold stocks suffered sharp losses yesterday, helping to pull the markets lower, after a Swiss Government panel recommended that the country leave the gold standard and sell off up to half of its gold reserves. The announcement could accelerate the trend among the world's central banks to sell their gold deposits because they do not earn anything and gold's recent price performance has been miserable.
The spot price of gold in New York fell $14.65 an ounce, or 4.5 percent, yesterday, to $309 an ounce. It was the lowest level since March 1985.

HEADLINE: Religion Journal;
Orthodox Patriarch Reaches Out to U.S. and the World

BYLINE: By GUSTAV NIEBUHR 

 BODY:
Almost since the moment his plane landed in the United States last Sunday, Ecumenical Patriarch Bartholomew I, spiritual leader of the world's Eastern Orthodox Christians, has received a high measure of official acclaim.
In New York on Friday, he stood by as a portion of East 79th Street in Manhattan was named in his honor; the day before in Baltimore, that city's Mayor, Kurt Schmoke, paid him a tribute. And two days earlier, he received the highest honor of all, the Congressional Gold Medal. 
 Beyond the glitter and civic ceremonies, Patriarch Bartholomew's monthlong visit can be seen as primarily about two matters. On one hand, he is paying a pastoral call on Americans who belong to the Orthodox churches and archdioceses, of which the Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of America is the largest.
But the 57-year-old Patriarch is also showing he is determined to speak to a larger world, beyond the boundaries of Orthodox Christianity. Two years ago, he said that religious leaders needed "to take a visible place on the stage."
At a dinner given for him on Wednesday night by Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, the Patriarch said, "Part of our mission is to reach out beyond the borders of our faith tradition, as many of you reach out beyond the borders of your countries, in order to preach and to teach peace."
The Patriarch's status is a "first among equals" when it comes to the leaders of the self-governing Orthodox churches in Eastern Europe, Russia and the Middle East. But he also serves as Archbishop of Constantinople (modern-day Istanbul), and so plays a delicate and sometimes difficult role as leader of the tiny Christian minority in predominately Muslim Turkey. Since his enthronement in 1991, he has voiced a conviction that his patriarchate can act as a bridge for improving relations between Christians and Muslims.
But in Washington this week, the Patriarch worked to show an even broader range of concerns. During his visit to the United States Holocaust Museum on Monday, he called the Nazi genocide against Europe's Jews an "icon of evil," while saying that the museum itself was "an icon of human hope" -- significant statements, given the great importance the Orthodox place on icons as objects of religious teaching and faith.
At the museum, too, the Patriarch hailed the place of modern Israel in Jewish life: "We respect the role of Israel as a guarantor of the Jewish people's existence." And he described the Holocaust's victims as martyrs, whose memory should be eternal.
Later in the week, in a meeting with Vice President Al Gore, the Patriarch discussed his interest in environmental protection, a concern that has earned him the nickname "the Green Patriarch" in Europe. Next month, he will preside at a symposium on religion and the environment in Santa Barbara, Calif.
But it was during the dinner with Ms. Albright, and also in his remarks upon receiving the Congressional Gold Medal, that the Patriarch sought to spell out his vision of Orthodox Christianity as leading a spiritual renewal in Eastern Europe and perhaps elsewhere in the world.
To Ms. Albright, he said the Orthodox churches must play a key role, a spiritual one, in the reconstruction of Eastern Europe, after the collapse nearly a decade ago of Communist governments there.
"As Ecumenical Patriarch, we ask that you consider that working economies are only partial solutions," he said. "You, better than we, understand the onerous task of revitalizing economic infrastructures emaciated by failed social policies. But what of decimated cultures? What of religious institutions abused by secular powers for generations? How are we to rebuild the soul of a nation?"
"We must recognize that the spiritual needs of people are of equal importance to their material needs," he said.
In accepting the medal, the Patriarch said that although a fervent embrace of secular rationalism during the last two centuries had eroded "the spiritual bedrock of Western civilization," he believed that "the pendulum is swinging back" among many people, and that the Orthodox churches were gaining from this in converts.
"There is a great hunger for spirituality, there is a thirst for transcendent meaning," he said. "We believe that, as we enter the next millenium, religious values, religious feeling and religious faith are undergoing a massive revival."

HEADLINE: Taliban Agree to Enforce World Ban on Opium Trade

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Oct. 24

 BODY:
The director of the United Nations anti-narcotics organization said today that the militant Islamic movement that controls most of Afghanistan had agreed to enforce a ban on opium poppy production and smuggling with the help of international crime-fighting organizations.
The official, Under Secretary General Pino Arlacchi, said in an interview that the agreement with the Taliban, who seized power in Kabul in September 1996, had taken six months to negotiate. 
 Only last month Mr. Arlacchi, an Italian expert on the Mafia who this year became executive director of the United Nations International Drug Control Program, described himself as "very worried" that poppy production had increased since the Taliban took power.
But today he described the new agreement as "a major breakthrough," doubly important because it comes as the next season's crop is about to be sown. "We are talking about half the heroin in the world," he said.
Mr. Arlacchi, who is in charge of all United Nations crime-fighting operations based in Vienna, said that a memorandum submitted to his office in Kabul from Afghanistan this week "opened the door to direct monitoring of the ban" for the first time. He said that he would go to Afghanistan next month to ask for permission to put a surveillance network into 42 districts where poppies are grown.
The United Nations, using the BBC's foreign language services, plans to begin broadcasts in Pushto next week telling farmers of the ban. International monitors should be able to know within a matter of months whether the Taliban have indeed begun to eliminate or reduce crops.
The drug-control agency has devised a program that would introduce new crops that could substitute for opium poppies, extend irrigation systems, build a few factories -- including a woolen mill already in planning -- and pay for police training and enforcement. The cost would be about $25 million a year over 5 to 10 years
Mr. Arlacchi is discussing the program with donor nations here and New York and will meet American officials next week in Washington.
United Nations officials have been struggling for a year to devise policies for dealing with the Taliban movement, with agencies quarreling over how much Afghanistan's new rulers should be isolated because of their harsh Islamic strictures, particularly their repression of women.
But Mr. Arlacchi said today that for his agency, this was a political question beyond its competence. "We are dealing with drugs," he said, "and Afghanistan is in the central position on our map."
He said that he was prepared to discuss human rights with the Taliban, but that he was also bearing in mind "the human rights of eight million drug addicts in the world."
In September Mr. Arlacchi said that opium production in Afghanistan had increased 25 percent, to 2,800 tons, in the year that the Taliban had controlled at least two-thirds of the country, including 96 percent of its poppy-growing areas. About half the world's heroin is derived from Afghan opium, with most of the rest coming from Southeast Asia and Colombia.
The Taliban movement banned the production and consumption of marijuana and its derivative hashish, as well as heroin, several months ago, but left the question of poppies clouded. A spokesman for the Taliban said today in New York that this was in part because Islamic law says nothing to prohibit poppy cultivation.
On the other hand, coffeehouses where hashish was available have been closed, Afghan and United Nations officials said. Drug use is punishable with a range of sentences including execution.
In New York, Abdul Hakeem Mujahid, the Taliban's designated representative at the United Nations, where Afghanistan's seat is still held by the ousted government of President Burhanuddin Rabbani, said that his Government's cooperation was linked to promises from Mr. Arlacchi's agency that there would be help in creating new jobs and crops for the farmers in areas where poppy cultivation exists.
Calling poppy cultivation "a very ugly legacy of Communist government in Afghanistan," Mr. Mujahid said poor farmers argued that they were growing poppies for medicinal use or because there was little else to cultivate profitably. They had to be persuaded to desist both theologically and economically, he suggested.
"There is nothing written that poppy cultivation is prohibited," Mr. Mujahid said, "But when changed to drugs, this is a great sin, a great crime to Islam. There is a saying of Mohammed that everything that is intoxication is prohibited in Islam. These things are not only harmful to Western population. This is also harmful to our own people."
The memorandum from the Taliban to Mr. Arlacchi's agency, a copy of which was provided to The New York Times, asks that heroin laboratories in neighboring Pakistan, where Afghan opium is refined, also be shut down.

HEADLINE: Clinton Defends Engagement With China

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24

 BODY:
Declaring the isolation of China to be "unworkable, counterproductive and potentially dangerous," President Clinton today defended his policy of engagement with China as fundamental to America's economic and security interests.
The President's 25-minute address to a small group of Asia experts at Voice of America headquarters here was broadcast to a global radio audience estimated at 100 million, and was meant to lay a foundation for next week's summit meeting with President Jiang Zemin of China. It was the first time in his Presidency that Mr. Clinton has devoted an entire speech to a broad treatment of the relationship between America and China. 
 He said that even though he is having a high-profile meeting with Mr. Jiang -- the first Chinese state visit in a dozen years -- significant problems remained between Washington and Beijing. China stifles dissent, supplies weapons components to rogue states and does not adhere to international trading regimes, the President said. But the relationship with China is too important to base solely on points of friction, he asserted.
"As always, America must be prepared to live and flourish in a world in which we are at odds with China," he said. "But that is not the world we want. Our objective is not containment and conflict; it is cooperation. We will far better serve our interests, and our principles, if we work with a China that shares that objective with us."
The President touched all the bases of China policy without lingering very long on any one -- human rights, trade, environmental protection, Chinese political liberalization and American security interests in Asia.
The audience of diplomats, China scholars and Government officials interrupted the President with polite applause only twice, when he made his most forceful statements on American determination to call attention to continuing human rights abuses in China.
Mr. Clinton sought to inoculate himself against critics who claim that the United States should not act so cooperatively toward a repeat violator of press and religious freedoms, but should rather use its political and economic muscle to press Beijing toward more openness.
The President spoke of the profound economic changes under way in China and predicted that the growth of a market economy would bring with it greater political freedom.
"In the process, however, they have stifled political dissent to a degree and in ways that we believe are fundamentally wrong," he said.
"This approach has caused problems within China and in its relationship to the United States," he continued. "Chinese leaders believe it is necessary to hold the nation together to keep it growing, to keep moving toward its destiny. But it will become increasingly difficult to maintain the closed political system in an ever more open economy and society."
Despite these differences, the President insisted, the United States could not afford to contain or isolate Beijing, nor could it succeed in doing so because such an approach would embolden the enemies of freedom in China and give European and Asian business competitors a jump on the world's largest emerging market.
"A pragmatic policy of engagement is the best way to advance our fundamental interests and values," the President said.
Representative Nancy Pelosi, a California Democrat, criticized the President's speech as having glossed over Chinese human rights violations, however.
"President Clinton's China speech was masterful in its craftiness in whitewashing China's record," Ms. Pelosi said. "With this speech, President Clinton has tried to justify the failure of his trade policy and the failure of his human rights policy with a fiction of China's cooperation on proliferation of weapons of mass destruction."
Although the President's Washington audience consisted chiefly of professional China experts, he aimed his message at listeners in China and across the United States.
Evelyn Lieberman, director of Voice of America, said the speech was being broadcast into China in Mandarin and would be rebroadcast over the next several days. Foreign radio broadcasts into China are sometimes jammed.
The President spelled out six reasons it is in American interests to work with China on a range of issues, and said they would figure in next week's summit agenda. He maintained that policing the unpredictable post-cold-war world would be much simpler with China as a partner, that the security of American allies and trading partners in Asia depended on China's peaceful role in resolving disputes there, and that global efforts to curb the spread of weapons of mass destruction would fail unless China agreed to stop selling dangerous technology to unreliable nations.
In addition, he said China could be a crucial partner in stemming the regional and global flow of drugs, arms and aliens; that China represented the richest potential market for American goods at a time when American economic growth depends on the growth of exports, and that China had a large role to play in efforts to reduce energy consumption and protect the environment.
He closed by approvingly quoting Richard M. Nixon, who as President brought about the historic modern opening of China to the West. Even in 1967, before winning the Presidency, he said, Mr. Nixon recognized the futility of trying to isolate the world's most populous nation, warning that "there is no place on this small planet for a billion of its potentially most able people to live in angry isolation."
