HEADLINE: THE 1997 ELECTIONS;
In Final Round, Arguments Over Guns, Condoms and Cars

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from last night's debate among Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, State Senator James E. McGreevey, a Democrat, and Murray Sabrin, a Libertarian.
 
On AIDS and Condoms
 Should condoms be distributed in public schools? 
 SABRIN -- Here is a good example of how parental responsibility has been taken away from parents and put onto the schools. Parents are responsible for teaching their children values, to make sure that children have values that don't put them into situations where they have these problems. So what do we have to do in New Jersey? We have to have parents heavily involved in their children's education starting from day one. When that responsibility's not there, who takes over the burden? The burden should be placed, if you will, on the local communities.
McGREEVEY -- I do not think that schools should be distributing condoms. I do recognize, however, that there are significant non-educational problems that administrators and principals and teachers confront and there needs to be proper linkage between health departments and school. But part of this problem is also that we need to be going after behavioral change. We need to teach our students the different between right and wrong and that character counts. . . .
WHITMAN -- I believe that the decision to distribute condoms or not should be left up to the local school boards and the parents and teachers of our schools. We have a very comprehensive sex education that begins and ends with abstinence, because that is the only way to avoid an unwanted pregnancy or sexually transmitted disease. But we have to understand that there are kids that aren't going to get that message and to teach them everything else in between. But we need to work with the local districts to insure that we are providing that kind of education, which we do now. And we have a standard and a guide -- the first ever developed in this state -- for condoms in our classes.
 
On Auto Insurance
 Senator McGreevey is asked about the wisdom of his promise to roll back car insurance rates by 10 percent
McGREEVEY -- I'm going to do it. The insurance companies want to sue me. Make my day! My basic protection is that right now in the state of New Jersey, we spend $160 out of every $1,000 for fraud. Most states in the nation prosecute fraud; they don't pay for it. See the case in Essex County? Two unscrupulous health professionals bilked $52 million. They received a two-year suspension of license and a slap on the wrist. Frankly, if that happens during the McGreevey administration, they'll be prosecuted and, an individual, if indicted and convicted, ought to serve time. I believe New Jersey motorists should not be paying for fraud, and in addition, we need a public advocate to represent our interests. Right now, it's just the insurance companies and the Department of Insurance, and we've lost 12 times.
WHITMAN -- Well I'm always interested when the Senator speaks with such passion about going after fraud and talks about taking the professional licenses of those who engage in fraud. I agree. We wrote the bill. I signed it in June. He voted against it. We also went after the insurance companies. We have now increased the penalties to $25,000 each and every time they fail to report fraudulence. We've gotten rid of the most egregious benefits that insurance companies had under legislation that he sponsored. We're making a difference.
SABRIN -- I'll repeat what I said at the first debate. You can see that neither has the answer to the auto insurance mess in the state, which has been created over the past 20 years. Why aren't we trying freedom and deregulation? It works in every industry in the nation. Every country around the world is deregulated. What is this obsession with controlling the insurance industry? I don't understand it. It works in every other form of insurance -- homeowner's insurance, life insurance, people knocking on your door to get your business -- but not in auto insurance.
 
On Gun Control
SABRIN -- No, I would want the death penalty for someone who killed my family: that's the way I would feel. But we have the right to protect ourselves. That's a fundamental right; it's there in the Constitution; second amendment, the U.S. Constitution, and the New Jersey State Constitution. Protecting oneself is the most fundamental, natural activity that an individual can undertake. What we need is responsible gun ownership in this state. We can have instant-check that the National Rifle Association supports because that allows gun stores to determine who is eligible to get a gun if someone has a record. What we need, again, is personal responsibility. What does that mean? If you use a gun carelessly, you should be punished, civilly and criminally. It's very simple. Using a gun, a dangerous weapon, entails tremendous personal responsibility. And so what we need in this state is the right to carry it. . . .
McGREEVEY -- I supported and voted for the ban on assault weapons. I believe clearly that's where New Jersey ought to be. But it also draws a distinction between weapons that are illegal as opposed to weapons that are legal. We need to increase penalties -- punitive measures against those who illegally have arms, and draw that clear, strong distinction. It's not about punishing those who legally obtained through the permit process; it's about increasing penalties for those who illegally use arms.
WHITMAN I believe in the Second Amendment right to carry arms, but I also believe in, and I have signed legislation that increases the penalty for those who use illegal guns. And I must say, I'd be a little concerned living in a society where not only do we allow people to carry concealed guns, but we also make drug use legal. The combination is deadly.
 
On Big Government
 Mr. Sabrin was asked about his call to eliminate regulation and cut the size of state government.
SABRIN -- You ask the most important question in this election: What is the purpose of state government? I have gone to the State Constitution. The State Constitution says that we, the people, have the right to life, liberty and property. All the law emanating from the Legislature must be based on those premises. The government is micromanaging the auto insurance industry, giving us a $1 billion fee to protect our cars, and takes your car away next year if you don't pass inspection twice a year at a cost of $500. That's what's coming down the pike. We're talking about the government confiscating cars, overregulating land in our state, doing all the things that's costing our citizens millions and millions and millions of dollars. . . .
WHITMAN -- I think it's important to have as many voices as possible as part of this process and get as many people to vote as we possibly can. But those voices have to be responsible, and when Mr. Sabrin talks about us taking cars from people if they fail inspections next year, he is absolutely dead wrong. There's a real choice here: there's one person who believes in slash and burn of government and the other who believes in tax and spend. Then there is a third choice, and the third choice is someone who has a proven record of cutting taxes and controlling spending and seeing our economy rebound.
McGREEVEY -- I think the -- by the way, I like Murray -- I think the challenge here is making government work. On auto insurance, Governor Whitman's proposal is to reduce their coverage by 25 percent. Her own Republican Party refused that notion. This Republican Governor could get through $10 billion of debt, but didn't do anything on auto insurance reform for four years. And now the Governor recognizes it's a problem, after 12 rate increases and insurance companies' doubling their profits.

HEADLINE: THE 1997 ELECTIONS: THE CHALLENGER;
City's Troubles Are Hidden, Messinger Says

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
In a direct challenge to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's portrayal of a city on the upswing, Ruth W. Messinger says that New York's schools, economy and budget are threatened by dangerous if unrecognized problems. She said she would devote her first months as Mayor to uncovering and explaining the depth of the city's woes.
The Democratic mayoral candidate, in a 90-minute discussion with editors and reporters from The New York Times on Thursday, said Mr. Giuliani had papered over the extent of the city's problems, both because of his interest in winning re-election and because he wanted to use this campaign to position himself for higher office. Ms. Messinger said that she, by contrast, was prepared to "break eggs" to address problems in the city's economy and schools, no matter what the political cost. 
 "What I will do as Mayor, and I certainly will do in the first six months, is identify what are the biggest problems, what are worst challenges facing the city," Ms. Messinger said. "Spell out the consequences of not addressing those problems. And if that's rough on people -- you know, I won't do it with a dour face, I won't do it with a projection of doom, but I'll say to people, 'We have big problems, they have been covered up and none of you benefit from that.' "
For example, she noted that despite national economic prosperity, the city had suffered under the weight of an unemployment rate verging on 10 percent, that the school system has been chronically overcrowded and underfinanced and that the budget was dangerously dependent on Wall Street's boom.
Ms. Messinger repeatedly criticized the Republican Mayor for what she described as an attempt to win re-election without telling New Yorkers what he would do in a second term. She noted that Mr. Giuliani had, during this campaign, delivered speeches in Washington and Boston, and suggested that his real agenda was auditioning for the national Republican Party. Indeed, Mr. Giuliani's aides have said that the Mayor is hoping to use a strong showing to enhance his political future.
Although Ms. Messinger repeatedly assailed the Mayor for not offering details of what a second Giuliani term might be like, she, too, was often vague in sketching out the details of a Messinger City Hall. Ms. Messinger said again she would order all schools to be kept open until 6 P.M., would sweep from office nearly all of Mr. Giuliani's commissioners and would attempt to address the city's chronic unemployment.
Beyond that, she said she could not offer many details of how or when she would deal with the problems she listed in her interview. And she put the blame for that on Mr. Giuliani, saying that City Hall's reluctance to provide budgetary and staffing numbers about the city made it impossible for her to present the kind of detailed agenda that might normally have been offered by this point.
"Very clearly, I can't do as much as I would like, and as much as I feel that you and the public is entitled to, to say, 'I've figured out we can do this by then,' " she said. "Because I can't get the numbers."
Ms. Messinger made her remarks in response to an invitation from The Times to discuss what she would do as Mayor. Mr. Giuliani has not responded to a similar invitation.
Mr. Giuliani's campaign manager, Fran Reiter, said in response that Ms. Messinger was painting an unfairly bleak portrait of the Mayor and the city. "She's become the official scold of New York," Ms. Reiter said. "This campaign has been for six months negative on two fronts: negative in terms of what she has to say about her opponent -- that's been nonstop -- and being the purveyor of doom and gloom."
Through the interview, Ms. Messinger was earnest, though restrained. She discussed the city's problems in detail, employing the often technocratic language of someone who has been government for 20 years, which she has.
The interview was conducted after several opinion polls, including one in The Times, showed her trailing the Mayor by a sizable -- and possibly insurmountable -- margin. Ms. Messinger did not discuss her political standing, though at several points she seemed close to describing the election as something of a closed book.
In suggesting that Mr. Giuliani was playing to audiences outside this city, Ms. Messinger seemed to be reflecting the consensus in political circles that the Mayor was trying to use this campaign to position himself in national Republican politics.
She said Mr. Giuliani's "lack of vision, lack of plans," had hurt the typical New York City voter who, Ms. Messinger said, "suffers from a Mayor who seeks re-election and could win re-election without having told anybody what it is he is going to do in his second term. And with everybody in the city having reason to believe that what he will be most interested in his second term -- what some of us would say he's been most interested in his first term -- is himself and where it is he's going and when it is he's going to go there. "
Ms. Messinger devoted as much of her interview to discussing what she described as Mr. Giuliani's shortcomings and the problems facing him as she did her own plan. On specific matters, she criticized him for failing to sign legislation that would create an independent civilian board to review allegations of police abuse. She said he should add $2 million to the budgets of the city's soup kitchens. She bemoaned the condition of the services for children, but did not say what she might do differently.
Ms. Messinger said that Mr. Giuliani had gambled too much of the city's well-being on the success of Wall Street, which she said would inevitably end. "What on earth is this Mayor's plan for then?" she asked. "The Mayor is in a peak moment in the city's economy. He is tolerating a 9.3 percent unemployment rate and says it isn't a problem. And he says that what's happening in our schools is not a problem."
Ms. Messinger said she was prepared to deal with any potential economic downturn with cuts in spending -- she said again she would not raise taxes -- though she did not offer examples of how. "Am I prepared to look for cuts? Yes. Do I know the ins and outs of his budget, you know, better than many? Yes."
Mostly, though, she assailed Mr. Giuliani's personality. She described him as a "tough cowboy" who used the "Big Lie" technique to get his way. "I think the nasty, bully parts of his personality are devastatingly bad for this city," she said. "I think they have missed hundreds of opportunities to bring people together."
Asked how a typical family suffered because of Mr. Giuliani's personality, Ms. Messinger responded: "Under Rudy Giuliani, that family has missed lots of opportunities to negotiate out solutions that would be better for them in terms of state aid to education, to be fairly dramatic and direct. In terms of making the labor force more efficient and having a contract that begins to make the changes from which all future mayors will benefit.
"Because, in fact, telling everybody in the city that the way to get your way is to be a tough, mean, nasty person is quite dangerous for the model that I think works for the city. Do you need tough? Yes. Do you need mean? No."

INTERNATIONAL A3-6
 
Special American Aid To Fight Drugs in Colombia
The United States has agreed to send $50 million in equipment to help the Colombian military fight guerrillas involved in drug trafficking. Colombia is grappling with increasingly violent guerrillas who have loose alliances to drug traffickers. A1 

Taliban Agrees to Ban Poppies
The director of the United Nations anti-narcotics organization said that the Taliban, a militant Islamic movement that controls most of Afghanistan, had agreed to enforce a ban on opium poppy production and smuggling with the help of international crime-fighting organizations. The director of the drug control program called the accord a breakthrough as it came on the eve of the next sowing season for the crop, the key ingredient in heroin. A6
 
A Scholar's Den Closes
The British Library's domed Reading Room, used as a refuge and research facility by Karl Marx, Mohandas Gandhi and Virginia Woolf, is closing. The new library, described by Prince Charles as a "dim collection of brick sheds groping for significance," opens next month. A4
 
Clinton Defends China Policy
Speaking on the Voice of America, President Clinton defended his policy of engagement with China, saying that isolation of the Asian giant would be "counterproductive and potentially dangerous." Mr. Clinton, who will meet Jiang Zemin, his counterpart, next week in Washington, said that American interests like human rights would best be advanced by cooperation, not containment. A6
 
Small Steps in Thai Crisis
As the people of Thailand called for his resignation, Prime Minister Chavalit Yongchaiyudh shuffled his Cabinet and named a Finance Minister to replace the one that quit last week. Thailand is at the epicenter of a financial crisis that has shocked Asia with currency devaluations and harrowing declines in stock markets. With consumer prices rising and tens of thousands of jobs being lost, the press has taken to calling Mr. Chavalit a "madman" for focusing on fractious political infighting rather than confronting the crisis. A3
 
Kurdish Cease-Fire Ends
The Patriotic Union of Kurdistan said Turkish jets fired missiles and dropped incendiary bombs on positions 115 miles south of the Turkish-Iraqi border, killing five. The group said attacks by its rival, the Kurdistan Democratic Party, followed, ending a week-long cease-fire. (AP)
 
Woes Abound in Siberia
A dry summer in Russia's Far East has so depleted the water supply that reservoirs in Vladivostok are only 10 percent filled, the city's water director said. On top of that, workers, who have not been paid for eight months, are threatening to strike. The Pacific port city -- some 4,000 miles from Moscow -- also suffers from an energy crisis, with power cuts of up to 12 hours a day. (AP)
 
NATIONAL A7-9, 12
 
Senate Moves on Nominees After White House Push
Senate Republicans have started moving quickly to confirm a backlog of nominations for sub-Cabinet officers, ambassadors and judges after being pummeled for weeks by the White House over the slow pace in approving the nominees. A9
 
Sabotage Seen in Power Failure
A power failure that knocked out traffic lights and disrupted much of San Francisco on Thursday appears to have been a result of sabotage, the authorities said. A7
 
New Campaign Inquiry Opened
The Justice Department has opened a campaign finance inquiry into Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt's role in a decision to kill an Indian casino project opposed by a rival group of Democratic contributors who lobbied against the project. A8
 
Marv Albert Avoids Jail
The sportscaster Marv Albert will not have to serve any jail time for assaulting a woman in a hotel room tryst last February. Judge Benjamin N. A. Kendrick of Arlington County Circuit Court in Virginia deferred sentencing Mr. Albert and ruled that charges against him might be dismissed if he obeyed the law for a year and his therapist reported progress to the court in his continuing mental health counseling. A7
 
Campaign Bill Remains Stalled
The Senate again failed to end an impasse over campaign finance legislation that is blocking several other bills. Senate Democrats continued to filibuster a six-year $145 billion highway spending bill, underscoring their demand to schedule a debate and votes on a campaign finance bill for early next year. A8
 
Veterans' Nominee Withdrawn
President Clinton withdrew the nomination of Hershel Gober, the Deputy Secretary of Veterans' Affairs, to be the Department's Secretary. In confirmation hearings, the Senate Committee on Veterans' Affairs intended to explore the circumstances surrounding the exoneration of Mr. Gober after he was accused of sexual misconduct in 1993, a Congressional staff member said. A9
 
NEW YORK/REGION B1-6
 
City Pursues Crackdown In Child Neglect Cases
New York City has embraced an aggressive approach to protecting children, becoming one of only a handful of cities to vigorously prosecute a growing number of parents in neglect cases. But some judges and lawyers warn that the city often oversteps the line that separates poor parenting from minor crime, arresting parents guilty of little more than poverty and carelessness. A1

Messinger says that New York's schools, economy and budget are threatened by dangerous if unrecognized problems. In an interview with The New York Times, she said she would devote her first months as Mayor to uncovering and explaining the depth of the city's woes. A1
 
Panel Votes to Remove Judge
A state commission voted to remove Judge Lorin Duckman from the bench, saying the judge, who sparked a furor when a domestic-violence case he handled in Brooklyn ended in murder, had shown a "mean-spirited, bullying" bias against prosecutors and made disparaging remarks about blacks and women. Judge Duckman immediately said he would appeal the 7 to 4 ruling by the Commission on Judicial Conduct to the state's highest bench, the Court of Appeals, putting off for at least several months a final decision in the politically charged case. B1
 
Immigrant Freed From Prison
Facing criticism from members of Congress and advocacy groups, Federal officials eased their interpretation of a strict new immigration law and released a Dominican immigrant from Brooklyn who had spent 201 days in a Pennsylvania prison for a 23-year-old misdemeanor. B1

BUSINESS DAY D1-15
 
Wall Street Slips Again
Hong Kong paved the way for a recovery from Thursday's global stock-market rout, but Wall Street would not cooperate. Apparently worried that the financial crisis in Southeast Asia could become worse, investors pounded the Dow Jones industrial average for the second day in a row, dashing hopes that an earlier rebound in Hong Kong would spread to the United States. The Dow Jones industrial average closed down 132.36 points, at 7,715.41, a fall of 1.7 percent on top of Thursday's 2.3 percent slump. A1

SECTION: Section A; Page 10; Column 6; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 209 words

HEADLINE: Child Welfare Agency Needs More Workers;
Try Higher Salaries

 BODY:

To the Editor:
It is horrifying to read about children who have been abused or even murdered by family members while supposedly being monitored by New York City's child welfare agency (front page, Oct. 22). However, I think that the agency is being asked to do an almost impossible job. 
 Things have changed little since 1979, when I was a graduate student in social work doing my field placement in a foster care agency under contract with the city. The paid staff and I were asked to make visits to families in the most economically depressed areas of the city. These visits were terrifying; the worker is sent alone into frightening apartment buildings with broken elevators, forced to walk up dark stairwells and to enter apartments in which there is no way of knowing what one will face.
When I was a social-work student, many of the caseworkers were not long out of college, as still seems to be the case. They were paid low salaries and were overwhelmed by the tasks they were asked to perform. Needless to say, there was a great deal of staff turnover. If we as a society claim to care so much about our most vulnerable children, are we willing to put our money where our mouths are?
 
ELLEN S. DANIELS
New York, Oct. 22, 1997

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
LORAL SPACE SEEKS STAKE IN MEXICO CONCERN

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Loral Space and Communications Ltd. has offered to pay $692 million for a 75 percent stake in Mexico's state-owned satellite company, Satellites Mexicanos S.A. The company, which submitted the only bid, hopes to use Satmex's three satellites, whose signals cover Mexico, Central America and parts of North and South America, to increase its presence in the region. Satellite services, including television, radio, telephone and data transmission, are expected to boom in Latin America. Mexico's Communications and Transport Ministry is expected to take five working days before declaring a winner. Loral is based in New York.

Correction Appended

SECTION: Section B; Page 5; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 1069 words

HEADLINE: THE 1997 ELECTIONS;
Excerpts From Interview With Democratic Mayoral Candidate

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from an interview with Ruth W. Messinger conducted on Thursday by editors and reporters from The New York Times.
Q. Could you talk about, as specifically as you can, what the first six months of a Messinger administration would be like? What would you start to try to do, area by area? How would New York be different? 
 MESSINGER -- First of all, the appointments will be very different. I think that the city is in desperate need of skilled, knowledgeable commissioners in different agencies, at least some of them. I will put together an administration that pays real attention to how we do some of the things that I talked about in the speech this summer, how we modernize city government, how we address what it is that the work force in this city is doing for the city. You can't do every one of those agencies at once. But you can look for people who really have some demonstrated experience in my judgment. Some of those people, and I'm not saying at this moment, I know them by name, are in the next two echelons of some of those agencies.
Q. You know what steps you would like to take to improve the city's public schools. As mayor, wouldn't it be frustrating if the school system's bureaucracy and the community school boards blocked your ideas?
A. I don't envision that happening. Tough people don't survive 22 years in the government of this city without being tough. Tough people know how to get something done. I've got a whole bunch of things done as Borough President that people said I couldn't get done. I want to be mayor because I know there are some things that need doing. Several people have said to me, well, it would be easy for him Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to do the Police Department because of its hierarchical nature. Maybe that's true but I watched him take a fair amount of head banging to make some changes in the Police Department, much of it done by Bill Bratton. I can certainly look at the Police Department and see what they haven't yet done. They decided to leave substantial sinecures that are untouched. There are still many police officers working behind desks. There are still too many police officers in One Police Plaza. What changes are needed? And if you decide that, if you have a vision, which I do, if you really believe that it's worth everything, it's worth a second time to start turning the schools of this city around.
Q. How would you deal with principal tenure, the legal provision giving lifetime job security to most principals in New York City?
A. Challenge it in Albany. I would increase the authorities that principals have in their buildings. I think you cannot in fact hold a principal responsible for what happens in I.S. 172 if he does not have a set of discretionary money, if to some extent the custodian is still out of control, and if the school security people belong to someone else. Then you can comment all the time on what's wrong in the schools -- but you can't really in a legitimate way say, O.K., you failed. So it is a combination of saying here are the additional areas in which we are going to give you authority but as we move in those directions and change some of those regulations, then we're going to move to a four-year contract system.
Q. Would you tell us what policies you would use to curb child abuse? Would you comment on the level of child abuse and government's seeming inability to do anything? How would you balance the privacy of the family with the welfare of children? Would you take more children away, more foster care, more preventive care the way Mayor Dinkins tried? Do you throw in the towel?
A. No, we don't want to throw in the towel. I've been talking about it since I came into government because among the 6,000 things that elected officials become immediate experts on, this is work I've done. I have evaluated children whose parents were accused of abuse, of neglect. I've made decisions about moving kids from their homes. I've found foster and adopted homes. I've done it all.
First of all, it never has gone away. It never will go away. There will always be homes that are so severely dysfunctional for whatever set of reasons, exacerbated by economics but sometimes, as you know, entirely independent of economics, where children are the victims of physical or emotional neglect or serious abuse and brutality. It's very hard for people to wrap their brains around that and accept it. But can you run a very different child welfare agency than this city has been running under four names? That's how I decided that I'd been around so long -- the agency got its fourth name without any improvements. And the answer is yes.
Q. Which policies would you pursue?
A. First of all, let me just make a comment on the preventive stuff. We need to do a lot of preventive care and services. I believe that every kid in this city should have a place to go to from 3 to 6 P.M.
Q. Do you believe in family preservation?
A. Wait, let's take this one piece at a time.
Invest in preventive care, but do not imagine that if you provide more preventive care the number of cases of reported possible abuse or neglect will go down. You are not going to sort of save people by putting more kids in after-school care and you are probably going to run into some families -- good quality person in a beacon school, actually seeing a kid after school, seeing adults -- probably going to find some more instances of kids who are at risk that might have otherwise have escaped the system until something blew up in their faces.
Some family preservation, yes. You do some of it. One of the things that needs to be done in this city and this is by the way true in large numbers of agencies, is to get permission, which means negotiation with City Council, State Legislature and with unions, to try some very different approaches in some parts of the city. One of the really bad things about so-called agendas for reforms, whether it's Nick Scoppetta in child welfare or whomever you might in any agency is, O.K. we're going to do this this year. And all of a sudden we have a plan for doing it. Five boroughs, 400 neighborhoods, with a potential population of 8 million. That's where you run into every single logjam. I would take probably two districts and say let's figure out what happens if you do child welfare coterminous with the school district. . . .

HEADLINE: John Kennedy Jr., One Step Ahead of the Pack, Quietly Travels to Cuba

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

 BODY:
John F. Kennedy Jr., the editor of George magazine, has quietly traveled to Cuba on the 35th anniversary of the Cuban missile crisis, in which his father, the President, faced down the Soviet Premier, Nikita S. Khrushchev, in a nuclear confrontation. But the purpose of his visit was a mystery yesterday.
"He is there as a journalist," Nancy Haberman, a spokeswoman for George, said, insisting that she had no other details. Others close to Mr. Kennedy, including his cousin Robert F. Kennedy Jr., declined to talk about the visit or its significance. United States and Cuban officials also said they had no information. 
 It was thus unclear whether Mr. Kennedy went on his own or at the behest of Cuba's Government, whether an interview with President Fidel Castro had been arranged, or even whether the trip was intended to provide a scoop for George or to convey a larger significance on the anniversary of the crisis that had threatened nuclear war.
On Oct. 22, 1962, President Kennedy disclosed that the Soviet Union, trying to tip the strategic balance of power, had built nuclear missile bases in Cuba that could strike anywhere in the Americas. He ordered a naval blockade of Cuba and urged Khrushchev to recall the weapons and dismantle the bases.
Six days later, Khrushchev backed down, ordering ships carrying warheads to Cuba to turn back and agreeing to destroy the launch sites in return for a United States pledge of nonintervention in Cuban affairs. Soon afterward, Washington imposed an economic embargo against Cuba that still exists.
In Havana yesterday, journalists said Mr. Kennedy, accompanied by an aide, had arrived on Thursday and checked into the luxury Melia-Cohiba Hotel overlooking the Havana waterfront. After breakfast yesterday, he left by a back door and eluded reporters and photographers. There were unconfirmed reports that he had gone to Trinidad, on the south-central coast, with Cuban officials. Another report said he planned to leave Cuba today.
There was wide speculation that Mr. Kennedy had gone for an interview with Mr. Castro -- one that might mingle reflections on the missile crisis, an oft-expressed admiration for President Kennedy, as well as issues like human rights, Cuba's limited economic liberalization and the eventual succession of Mr. Castro's brother, Raul.
An interview with Mr. Castro could be a coup for George, founded by Mr. Kennedy in 1995 with a focus on political commentary. Mr. Kennedy, the editor in chief, does many of George's interviews.
Interviews with Mr. Castro are rare, but he spoke last year with Robert F. Kennedy Jr. and Michael Kennedy, sons of Robert F. Kennedy. They had been invited to Cuba with a group of environmental safety advocates; Mr. Castro at the time reflected on the missile crisis, the Bay of Pigs invasion and President Kennedy's assassination.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 32; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1414 words

HEADLINE: University Presses;
Noah's Passenger List

BYLINE: By Stefan Collini; Stefan Collini is a reader in intellectual history and English literature at Cambridge University.

 BODY:

THE PLATYPUS
 AND THE MERMAID
 And Other Figments
 of the Classifying Imagination.
 By Harriet Ritvo.
 Illustrated. 288 pp. Cambridge, Mass.:
 Harvard University Press. $29.95. 
 Thomas Bewick's "General History of Quadrupeds" was published in 1824, in an era when naturalists prided themselves on offering a far more systematic classification of the animal kingdom than their pre-Enlightenment predecessors had done. However, as Harriet Ritvo points out in this engaging, offbeat book, Bewick's history continued to exhibit some deeply traditional principles of organization. His entry on the cat, for example, began with the disclaimer that "to describe an animal so well known, might seem a superfluous task," before going on "to discuss its eyesight, its voice, its irritability, its gestation, its lack of affection for humans, its price in medieval Wales and its relationship to Dick Whittington."
Animals, like any other objects of knowledge, can be classified in various ways, depending on which characteristics are considered salient or defining. Though it may be hard for the modern reader to recognize it as such, Bewick's book is in principle one intelligible ordering of relevant information. By the early 19th century, it had in fact long been superseded among professional zoologists by other kinds of classification, in which certain fundamental anatomical features were used to determine which species any particular beast should be assigned to. But such a coolly clinical procedure did not necessarily satisfy all the needs that might be in play in understanding a particular creature's place in the scale of creation.
In 1829 the naturalist Edward Bennett denied that the domestic dog should be considered part of the same species as the wolf and other wild canines, but he had to acknowledge that its distinctiveness could not be maintained on grounds of physical characteristics: rather, he declared, "it is to the moral and intellectual qualities of the dog that we must look for those remarkable peculiarities which distinguish him."
The fact that neither Bewick nor Bennett was at what we might call the cutting edge of scientific taxonomy in their day is part of what recommends them to Ritvo's attention. For "The Platypus and the Mermaid" is a study of a wide range of classificatory practices in Britain in the 18th and 19th centuries, and Ritvo is particularly interested in the interplay between learned and popular writing. Hers is, therefore, far from a triumphalist, march-of-science narrative about how the 18th-century Linnaean system was displaced in the early 19th century by Cuvier's work in comparative anatomy, which was in turn challenged by the Darwinian denial of the fixity of species. Instead, she has assembled a collection of assumptions about the natural world, ranging from attempts at comprehensive zoological classification through a more demotic fascination with hybrids, crossbreeding, and "monsters," and on to the categories involved in those two very unscientific forms of relation to animals -- hunting them and eating them.
She begins with the first reports of the exotic fauna of Australia at the end of the 18th century because these creatures, especially the platypus and the kangaroo, were not only unfamiliar but actually threw doubt on the received principles of Linnaean classification; there was even some initial anxiety that the platypus might have been a naturalist's hoax, a duck's head having been grafted onto the body of a quadruped. But, as Ritvo hastens to point out, deciding what to do with this furry, wide-billed anomaly was only one of the more obvious puzzles that plagued all attempts to arrange a neat table of stable and distinct species.
Moreover, although the use of binomial Latin terms may have helped to give the impression of impersonal systematic order (as well as insuring that the naming of new species remained the province of the educated), there were often more directly practical interests at stake for various social groups, professional zoologists included. After all, what the "species" is to the laboratory, the "breed" is to the barnyard: stockbreeders had a major economic interest in operating with agreed categories that kept out any taint of the mongrel or the hybrid. And Ritvo is unfailingly alert to the yet more diffuse cultural resonances of the relation of man to beast. For example, being great meat-eaters was a defining characteristic of English identity in the 19th century, but there was meat and meat. It was taken as a further sign of the depravity of the French that they were proudly "hippophagique" ("they eat horses, don't they?"). And, of course, the English didn't eat dogs either, on the self-evident and therefore never stated social principle that one doesn't do that sort of thing to friends.
To prepare oneself for writing such a book as this, one has to have cultivated a long familiarity with works not usually regarded as being among the classics of the Western tradition, such as "Beeton's Book of Home Pets: Showing How to Rear and Manage, in Sickness and in Health, Birds, Poultry, Pigeons, Rabbits, Guinea Pigs, Dogs, Cats, Squirrels, Fancy Mice, Tortoises, Bees, Silkworms, Ponies, Donkeys, Goats, Inhabitants of the Aquarium, Etc." of the early 1800's or, later in the century, James Long's more succinctly titled "Book of the Pig." In her treatment of this arcana, Ritvo sustains a lightly sardonic note without ever ridiculing her sources, and the pleasures of her deft prose are supplemented by some tellingly bizarre illustrations. Judged by these characteristics, "The Platypus and the Mermaid" clearly belongs to a subset within the genus "scholarly monograph," perhaps even to a distinct species marked by its adaptation to a nonacademic environment (Opus Academicus Accessibilis). Readers worried about the debilitating effects of hybridity may be reassured by its impeccable pedigree: its author is a professor of history at M.I.T. who has already published widely on the interplay between scientific and popular understandings of the natural world in 19th-century Britain. (I wouldn't be surprised if she were a pet lover, too.)
The book's serious intellectual ambitions are less obvious than its surface charms. Ritvo offers no conclusions and for the most part she abstains from directive comment or even explicit argument. She seems to take quiet pleasure in the anomalies and instabilities that constantly manifest themselves in all schemes of classification, and of course in large parts of American academic culture today anything that can be said to "destabilize" categories is assumed to be a good thing.
The very few places at which she allows herself anything approaching a general claim raise more questions about the rationale for her enterprise than they settle. For instance, she writes, "The sea serpent, like the unicorn and especially the mermaid, embodied alternative modes of understanding the natural world," modes that signaled people's "reluctance to accept the structures imposed by self-constituted expertise." "Imposed" suggests she is unmasking the coerciveness that sustains scientific authority, and a similar frisson of ever-so-slightly-pleased-with-itself heterodoxy is present in the implication that a belief in unicorns and mermaids should be seen as one among other possible "modes of understanding the natural world."
And this takes us back to her title. It is clearly designed to be eye-catching (a characteristic that has perhaps been crossbred from the Opus Commercialis), and its juxtaposition of "platypus" with "mermaid" is presumably intended to be in some sense transgressive. Both, it implies, threw sizable monkey wrenches into the works of the taxonomies then dominant, suggesting that we should regard them as equally revealing of the limits, and hence limitations, of various worlds of discourse, including that which prided itself on being most "scientific." Yet the fact remains that platypuses, however troubling to Linnaean classification they initially seemed, were soon accounted for and assimilated into the accredited body of scientific knowledge. I have enjoyed Ritvo's entertaining and informative tour of both the highroads and the hedgerows of natural history, but should I regard myself as missing (or even resisting) her main point if I persist in thinking that only one of the two creatures in her title was a figment of anyone's imagination?

SECTION: Section 5; Page 6; Column 1; Travel Desk 

LENGTH: 2238 words

HEADLINE: FRUGAL TRAVELER;
Las Vegas on a Small Stake

BYLINE: By SUSAN SPANO 

 BODY:
WHILE waiting for my suitcase at McCarran International Airport in Las Vegas, I got to talking with three little old ladies from Long Island.
"I make out good at blackjack," said the first. 
 "I like slot poker," said the second.
"I'm here to watch the idiots," said the third.
It was after midnight on a Tuesday in September. Our plane from New York (not-so-lucky TWA Flight 777) had left two hours late, and it took 30 minutes for the luggage to arrive. Meanwhile, right there in the baggage claim area, quarter slot machines were binging and bonging -- sounds that do insidious things to the nervous system.
Briefly, I wondered what I was doing in Las Vegas, renowned for tackiness, vice, hangovers and more recently family-style casinos. The vaunted neon makes me mourn the damming of the Colorado River, and my idea of a good time at gambling tables is playing with someone else's money.
But last spring on a driving tour through the Southwest, I veered off the highway to try the $9.95 buffet at the MGM Grand Hotel. A friendly couple from New Jersey told me it would be a sin to leave town without a stroll up the Strip. So off we went, taking in the Statue of Liberty at New York-New York, a volcano erupting at the Mirage and a pirate ship under siege outside Treasure Island -- an amazing number of sights for such a short hike. I wanted to go back.
I doubted that I'd gamble much. As everyone knows, the odds are stacked in favor of the house. That's how casinos make money, luring crowds with spectacles, free drinks, budget buffets and cheap rooms.
Prices have risen lately, driven by economic prosperity and a building boom that brought the oasis in the Nevada desert huge, new luxury hotels like the MGM Grand, Mirage, Luxor and New York-New York (with two new properties, the Venetian and the Bellagio, due to open in the next two years). But according to the Las Vegas Convention and Visitors Authority, the average tourist who is in the city for two nights budgets over $500 for gambling, and only about $230 for accommodations. On a slow week, competition to fill the city's 103,000 hotel rooms remains heated, with prices at top-of-the-line places like the Mirage and Caesars Palace dropping from highs in the hundreds to lows of $59 to $69. Farther north on the Strip, the rate at the Sahara sometimes dips to $28.
These hotels are no fleabags. Many have spectacularly kitschy decorations, vast palm-fringed swimming pools, spas, shopping arcades, jousting tournaments, rare-animal collections and sound-and-light shows ( the one at Caesars Palace simulates the destruction of the island of Atlantis).
I have always wanted to see Atlantis, and love hotel rooms in all their unpredictable variety. So I bet that I could spend four nights in Las Vegas, including air fare, meals and accommodations, for about the same amount the average person drops at the gambling tables in two nights.
I started by checking packages organized by airlines and travel agencies, which run ads in newspapers for astoundingly low-priced Las Vegas sprees. Liberty Travel, for example, offered a deal that included round-trip air fare from New York, two nights at Palace Station and a discount-coupon booklet for $255 a person, double occupancy. Alas, I quickly found that the low-end deals last for just two nights and involve taking night flights -- meaning that on the first day, you arrive in Las Vegas late, and leave late on the third day after checking out of your hotel around noon. If you're traveling alone, the single supplement inflates the price by about a third.
So I put together my own package by hunting down an economy fare of $264 round trip from TWA, with night flights both ways. On the day I was scheduled to return to New York, I decided to stand by for a morning flight -- which is how I got home in time for dinner, at no extra charge.
Then I set about monitoring hotel rates, which fluctuate dramatically depending on demand. Once a week in late August and early September, I checked the price of the cheapest available room at nine hotels, including Treasure Island -- where, over the phone, the price ranged from $179 to $199 to $79, before bottoming at $49 while I was standing at the check-in counter. Admittedly, few travelers want to wait until the last minute to book accommodations. But price swings are a factor to consider when assessing packages, and the next time I pass through Las Vegas, I'm going to check the rate at Caesars Palace before bedding down in a Motel 6.
If I'd spent as much time learning basic blackjack strategy as I did tracking hotel rates, maybe I'd be a rich woman now. Still, the rate checking was worth it because I got a $28 room for my first night at the Sahara, which opened in 1952 on what is now the north end of the Strip. The next day I moved into a $30 room at Binion's Horseshoe on the Fremont Street mall downtown. For Day 3, I got a $69 room at the Mirage, on the central section of the Strip, with Treasure Island and Caesars Palace next door. On my last night, I stayed in a $59 room at the Monte Carlo, which opened in 1996 and has one of the most celebrated swimming-pool areas in town.
The rates were low because I avoided the weekend, and there was nothing much doing in town besides a moderate-size convention of the American Chemical Society, Wayne Newton in concert and a crop of expensive floor shows.
To economize, I decided not to see a show or rent a car -- even though Las Vegas is hardly a pedestrian-friendly town, with construction sites swallowing up sidewalks, sizzling hot pavement, heavy traffic and considerable distances between attractions. From the Sahara, it's over three miles to the Luxor and about the same distance to Fremont Street downtown. But a monorail connects the MGM Grand to Bally's, and a free tram runs between Treasure Island and the Mirage. For the most part, I relied on public buses ($1.30), tourist trolleys ($1.50) and taxis.
AT 1 A.M. it was a quick trip in a shuttle ($3.50) from the airport to the Sahara, which has recently been renovated but still looked vaguely grungy in the lurid glare of the slots. New carpeting lined the hall on the sixth floor of the Tunis Tower, though only one room along the corridor had new molding. My key card fit the lock there, and the room turned out to be a freshly decorated suite, somewhat Southwestern in style, with a bar, king bed, sitting area, two baths and bank of windows overlooking a parking garage. Maybe I got it for $28 because I was staying for only a night; maybe I was just lucky. Or maybe the weary, winsome approach I've been trying to cultivate with front-desk clerks finally paid off.
When I awoke the next morning, Las Vegas seemed like a top-notch place. The Sahara's domes, peaked windows, fake palms and colonnades evoked a cleaner, brighter Marrakesh than the one I visited last winter, and the large, lovely pool was shaded by a huge minaret. There was a heaping plate of lox with the bagels at the $2.99 breakfast buffet in the Sultan Room, and the casino offered free gambling lessons -- which is how I learned when to split a hand in blackjack, and that only suckers bet on the Big 6 and 8 at craps.
Across the street from the Sahara is an empty lot where the Strip's first hotel casino, the El Rancho, opened in 1941. Since then most of the action has moved south, with the exceptions of Circus-Circus, where I watched the free trapeze show above the gaming tables, and the Stratosphere, with a 1,149-foot tower surmounted by a roller coaster. It costs $6 to take the elevator to the top, but the view of the valley -- scouted by Jedediah Smith in 1826, crossed by the railroad in 1905 and put on the map by mobsters and movie stars after Nevada legalized casino gambling in 1931 -- is worth it. Carole Lombard died in a plane crash in the bone-dry Spring Mountains to the southwest, and across the valley Nellis Air Force Base stretches, home to the Stealth Fighter.
I arrived at Binion's Horseshoe (by taxi for about $8) in time to take a hot jog among the plasma centers north of downtown, followed by a dip in the hotel's rooftop pool, which was small but pleasant. So was my room on the second floor above the casino. It was decorated country-style, nicer than I'd expected, with drapes that matched the spread, a window air-conditioner, and a TV with an in-house channel for playing keno in bed.
The casino downstairs has western decor, a buffet and coffee shop. I was sad to learn that Binion's famous $2 steak dinner had been discontinued. So I bought myself a scotch and soda for $1.25 and sidled up to a craps table, where the action was so heated that the shooter's cigarette had burned down to the filter, unheeded, and the man next to me blithely told his buddy that he'd lost $1,300. When I asked an idle stickman if the Horseshoe gave lessons, he sneered at me. Clearly, this was no place for a greenhorn.
Pretty soon the neon signs of downtown blinked on, and even I was impressed to find the entire facade of Binion's decked in twinkling baby blue. Outside the hotel's front door lay the Fremont Street pedestrian mall, covered by a four-block-long canopy studded with 2.1 million bulbs, illuminated several times nightly during a free sound-and-light show called the "Fremont Street Experience." Down the block, the Golden Nugget was sponsoring performances by the Doveiko Aerialists from the Moscow Circus, and I stopped at the Golden Gate, Las Vegas's oldest hotel (dating from 1906), for a surprisingly big 99-cent shrimp cocktail. There was so much to see and do that I didn't get around to supper until 10. I've had better prime rib dinners than the one I ate in the coffee shop at the Lady Luck, about a block north of Freemont Street -- but never for $5.49.
The next morning I caught a crowded public bus down the Strip, taking a seat next to a lady from Texas who described what it felt like to win $25,000 at the slots. As I got off she wished me luck.
The Mirage was a tropical dream of a hotel with an aquarium behind the check-in counter, lush gardens in the center of the casino, an astonishing amoeba-shaped pool agitated by a waterfall and one of the more palatial rooms I've ever occupied. There I found two partly canopied double beds, a luxurious bath, a wide window with a view of the volcano, and my brother, John, who lives in Los Angeles. We'd planned to meet in Las Vegas before heading off for a weekend of camping in southern Utah.
While he snoozed by the pool, I toured the Secret Garden of Siegfried & Roy ($10), where the two magicians who headline at the Mirage keep the rare white tigers and lions they use in their act. After that, I strolled over to the Forum Shops at Caesars Palace to watch fire and water consume Atlantis and a statue of Bacchus come to life.
JOHN and I went back downtown for dinner, to glut ourselves at the popular $8.99 buffet at Main Street Station, which was better than any of the others I tried. After a while, though, all the buffets taste the same. And even the nicest hotel rooms lack distinguishing features. The one I moved to at the Monte Carlo the next day had two double beds, a TV, big bath and desert view, as did my brother's room next door. But because he arrived at the reception desk at just the right moment, his cost only $49, instead of the $59 I paid for mine.
We preferred the Mirage's swimming area to the pools at the Monte Carlo, which are noisy, crowded and a little like a water park. I was distressed to learn that even hotel guests have to pay $20 a day to use the Monte Carlo's well-equipped spa (since reduced to $14). But I liked the buffet ($6.49 at lunch, $8.49 at dinner), and the location: close to Hollywood (at the MGM Grand), Manhattan (at New York-New York), Camelot (at the Excalibur) and ancient Egypt (at the Luxor).
We saw it all, while John gambled and I equivocated. Finally, he thrust a dollar onto a table at a Big 6 wheel and told me to pick a number. Big 6 is an old carnival game, and a dumb way to try to make money. Just to be contrary, I chose the number with the toughest odds -- 40 to 1. The wheel went round, slowed, and then stopped on my number. So I went away with $40 extra in my wallet. Next time in Las Vegas, I think I'll do a little gambling.
 
The bottom line
My four-night Las Vegas trip cost $595, including round-trip air fare from Kennedy Airport on TWA, (800) 221-2000, accommodations, meals and admission fees. The average room cost $51 a night.
Most major car-rental chains have offices at McCarran International Airport. When I checked in September, a local firm, Savmor, (800) 634-6779 or (702) 736-1234, had economy cars for $149 a week, or $21 a day.
Information is available from the Las Vegas Convention and Visitors Authority, 3150 Paradise Road, Las Vegas, Nev. 89109; (702) 892-7575. SECTION: Section 11; Page 7; Column 1; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 1311 words

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Jamaica, Queens;
F.D.A. Project Taps Unusual Public-Private Alliance

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
WHEN it is completed in the fall of 1999, the new laboratory and office building for the Food and Drug Administration will look much like the others on the campus of York College in Jamaica, Queens.
The red brick and glass exterior will give no hints of the coalition of city, state and Federal agencies plus private companies that had to be forged to make the 260,000-square-foot, $85 million project a reality after years of studies and failed plans. Ground was broken on Oct. 14 in a temporary parking lot at the northeast corner of Liberty Avenue and 158th Street. 
 A state agency, the Dormitory Authority, controls the land under the building, which will be leased to a private developer, Hines Interests L.P. Private capital has been raised to finance construction of the combined building, a three-story laboratory and a five-story office building that will be connected by a glass atrium. But for tax reasons the building will be owned by a state agency, once again the Dormitory Authority.
Hines will develop the project and manage it for at least 20 years, with a Federal agency, the General Services Administration, paying the rent.
Officials involved say the reason it took most of 1990's to put the deal together was the unusual involvement of multiple government agencies, private companies like Hines and quasi-private organizations like the Greater Jamaica Development Corporation, which helped win community and political support for the project and is a very minor investor in it.
"This was not a typical government construction project," said Donal E. Farley, a retired senior vice chancellor of the City University who acts as a consultant on real estate matters. "You had a lot of agencies, the private sector, a very complicated deal -- and everybody had a lawyer."
He said that because of the unusual nature of the undertaking, the lawyers spent a lot of time trying to anticipate possible problems. "There were a lot of 'what-ifs' that were raised," Mr. Farley said. " 'What if somebody goes bankrupt? Who gets the property?' Finally enough pressure was applied and the issues got settled."
One reason for the unusual alliance was to take advantage of private developers' proven ability to bring in projects on time and within budget, said F. Carlisle Towery, president of Greater Jamaica Development. He said delays in the construction and finishing of the federally owned building in Jamaica that houses offices of Social Security and other agencies had left local officials skeptical about all-government projects.
"The Federal building took nine years to build when it should have taken three," he said. Greater Jamaica helped push the F.D.A. project, which will bring about 350 jobs to the area, although at least at first, most will not be held by local residents.
"I have 27 months to finish the project and the clock started running in August," said Peter J. Davoren, vice president and general manager of the New York office of the Turner Construction Company, the general contractor. "At the end of that time, I have to have an operating building."
He said the project was being built on a so-called fast-track basis, which means construction starts before all the design drawings and specifications have been completed. Since a developer has to borrow to pay for construction and gets no rent until the building is occupied, the faster a construction company can work, the more likely it will be chosen to do the work.
The F.D.A.'s current location in the Sunset Park area of Brooklyn is a throwback to the early years of the century, when most of the food, drugs and other materials falling under its jurisdiction came in by ship. Being close to the waterfront made it convenient to collect samples for analysis in the agency's laboratories.
TODAY the Brooklyn waterfront is largely deserted and most of the items that require the agency's attention come in by air to Kennedy International Airport. With many of the F.D.A.'s workers living on Long Island, the Jamaica location will be much more convenient than Brooklyn, since a major terminal of the Long Island Rail Road is only a few blocks away, Mr. Towery said.
In addition, a light rail line along the median of the Van Wyck Expressway to the airport -- which is not fully authorized but is widely anticipated -- should make it easier for F.D.A. employees to travel from the Jamaica office to a branch at Kennedy.
Because F.D.A. officials said they would like their new location to be on or near a college campus, Greater Jamaica made a deal with York to set aside the land, which was once the site of a large Brooklyn Union Gas tank. And it actively worked politically and organizationally to win the project for the area.
"We assembled a team to bid on the project," Mr. Towery said. "We sought out Hines and Gruzen Samton to be the architects." He said the architectural firm was chosen because it had designed much of York College and the Federal building, which is nearby.
"When you are working in places like Jamaica, you have to realize that you are in the boroughs, not Manhattan," said Peter Samton, one of the principals of the firm. He said the use of a red brick facade would help the F.D.A. building blend in with others on the campus and in the neighborhood.
Gruzen Samton is designing the building in association with HLW Ltd., an architectural firm specializing in laboratories. "They will do the labs and we will do all the outside, the office and the atrium," Mr. Samton said.
The Greater Jamaica-Hines group, one of three finalists on the project, was selected by the G.S.A. in June. Under the terms of the deal, Hines will pay $297,000 a year in ground rent (with a 15 percent escalation every five years) to CUNY, which will have to develop other parking to replace the lot that is being lost. The 250 remaining spaces at the site will be reserved for F.D.A. employees and visitors.
Hines has floated a 20-year private placement bond issue of $83 million to pay for construction and professional fees and will be repaid through lease payments starting at $8.5 million a year, which is to cover payment of debt and fees for management of the building.
BECAUSE the building is on what is, ultimately, city-owned land and is deeded to the Dormitory Authority, it is exempt from city taxes, Mr. Farley explained. "Exemption from city real estate taxes was critical to this site," he said. "If the government is paying a market rental and there are no real estate taxes, that means you can move more money into development."
Jeff Spiritos, the Hines vice president closest to the project, said there was never any plan to use public financing, despite the public nature of the ownership and tenants. "The F.D.A. put out a set of specifications that was five inches thick, and it was up to the developer to figure a way to finance, build and operate it at a price lower than what Congress authorized," he said.
As the operator of the building, Hines will provide maintenance, cleaning, engineering and most other services. One that it will not is security. "This will be a highly secure building and the government is providing its own security," Mr. Spiritos said.
Meeting the requirements of the various government agencies, while preserving the flexibility and economics of the private developer, were the reason it took several years to pull the F.D.A. project together, Mr. Farley said. "It was the first time most of the participants worked with each other," he said.
Along the way, the developers, architects and local backers grew comfortable with the mind-numbing acronyms so beloved of government officials. They learned that a S.F.O. is a "solicitation for offer," which is an invitation to bid on a project. Similarly the last bid is a B.A.F.O. (pronounced baf-o), standing for "best and final offer."

SECTION: Section 2; Page 26; Column 4; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 1222 words

HEADLINE: FILM;
From a Vanished Country, a Viewable Cold-War Archive

BYLINE: By KEN SHULMAN 

DATELINE: AMHERST, Mass.

 BODY:
THESE MEN WERE decidedly not the victors. Instead of striding, they shuffled into an auditorium on the campus of the University of Massachusetts as if they were the bewildered colonels of a vanquished army. In fact, they were producers, directors, actors and screenwriters who, as employees of Deutsche Film AG, the East German state film studio, had become virtually obsolete seven years ago with the unification of Germany.
"You must try and understand, it was such a wonderful thing for us to be able to make films," said Wolfgang Kolhaase, the author of more than 20 screenplays produced in East Germany. Mr. Kolhaase, one of the few studio employees who has found steady employment in the West since 1990, had come here earlier this month to take part in a conference on East German film and, more specifically, a Deutsche Film AG archive established by the university. 
 "Of course we weren't as well paid as our colleagues in the West," he continued. "But money wasn't the primary objective. It didn't have the same meaning for us as it did in Hollywood. We made films as an attempt to define a society where justice and not money was the guiding principle. Yes, of course there were problems, and there was censorship. But show me a country where they give you money to make a film and don't pose some conditions on its content."
Between 1946 and 1990, Deutsche Film AG, which is also known by the acronym DEFA, produced 750 feature films, 200 children's films and more than 3,000 documentaries.
"The DEFA archive is a collection of unknown films from a country that stopped existing in 1990," said Barton Byg, a professor of Germanic languages and literature at the university who was responsible for bringing the East German films here. "It is an important part of German cultural history -- and, as I become increasingly aware, of cold-war history. Of course there are plenty of halfhearted attempts to put the best face on East Germany. But even the ideologically overburdened clunkers earn a begrudging respect because DEFA was a very technically accomplished studio."
Beginning with its first feature, the 1946 film noir "Die Morder Sind Unter Uns" ("The Murderers Are Among Us"), the studio in East Berlin worked to establish a tradition of antifascism, and it tried to use that tradition to claim legitimacy both for itself and for East Germany.
"Antifascism has always been a main theme in East German cinema," said Ralf Schenk, a representative of Progress Film-Verleih, a Berlin company that owns the rights to the Deutsche Film AG films and has given the archive to the university on extended loan. "In West Germany, this theme disappears in the 1960's, with the appearance of the New Wave. Certainly there were difficult truths to come to grips with in both countries. But it was even more difficult to deal with the remaking of society in East Germany than it was in West Germany."
The Deutsche Film AG productions included several movies that were acclaimed internationally. One, "Jakob der Lugner" ("Jacob the Liar"), directed by Frank Beyer, received an Oscar nomination for best foreign film in 1974. Another, "Die Frau und der Fremde" ("The Woman and the Foreigner"), directed by Rainer Simon, won the top prize at the Berlin Film Festival (a West German event) in 1985.
Many well-known actors, writers and directors, including Bertolt Brecht and Armin Mueller-Stahl, worked in the East German film industry. And the movies made by Deutsche Film AG were certainly not all high art or heavy-handed propaganda.
THERE WERE COMEDIES, musicals and operas. Between 1965 and 1983, the East German studio even produced 14 westerns. Shot on location in Yugoslavia, Czechoslovakia, Romania, Bulgaria, the Soviet Union and Cuba, and usually starring a hulking former physical-education instructor named Gojko Mitic, these so-called Indianerfilme are as clumsy and predictable as many of Hollywood's cowboy films. There is one notable distinction: in East German westerns, the American Indians are always the good guys.
The archive has been established by the University of Massachusetts to give scholars and commercial distributors access to the East German films. Still, few people are expecting Hollywood distributors to rush to Amherst. Many American filmgoers may be familiar with West German directors like Werner Fassbinder and Wim Wenders, and many have viewed numerous Russian films and movies from former Soviet bloc countries like Poland, Hungary and Czechoslovakia. But the films of East Germany are almost wholly unknown in the West.
"I think the obscurity of East Germany film was really a marketing problem," said Dr. Byg. "Poland and Czechoslovakia and Hungary did not have a West Poland or a West Hungary in whose shadow they stood. East German cinema wasn't recognized as a national cinema because it had a sort of schizophrenic identity. And the DEFA people really weren't very good at figuring out where their export market might be."
In the West, East Germany was synonymous with gloom, intellectual conformity and unrelenting boredom, and Dr. Byg and his colleagues are aware that interest in East Germany has waned even further after unification. Some of the harshest words about East Germany and its culture, of course, have come from West Germans.
In 1992, the director Volker Schlondorff ("The Tin Drum") dismissed the history of Deutsche Film AG as abysmal. "I've had more interesting discussions with architects and engineers than with DEFA scriptwriters," he wrote in a journal article entitled "Was Stinkt Hier" ("What Stinks Here").
The name Deutsche Film AG was actually not struck from the record until 1992, when the Compagnie Immobiliere Phenix, a German-based subsidiary of a French company, the Compagnie Generale des Eaux, purchased the studio from the Treuhandanstalt, a German agency assigned to privatize state-run companies. With that purchase, thousands of people lost their jobs.
For some East German film professionals, the loss of a forum for analyzing the problems of their vanished country was more traumatic than unemployment. "We still wanted to shoot films about Stalinism and reckon with our own past," said Michael Gwisdeck, an actor. "Naturally, no one wants to see this sort of thing at the movies anymore. And no one wants to finance it."
The conference here opened with a screening of "Die Morder Sind Unter Uns," and also included showings of films by leading directors like Mr. Beyer, Mr. Simon, Konrad Wolf and Heiner Carow. Attendance at the screenings was strong, and the response to many of the films was enthusiastic. But while Deutsche Film AG seems to have found a niche in North America, at least among students and scholars, the studio's former employees are struggling to reinvent themselves in a world where their ideas and values are considered as worthless as their old country's currency.
"We all need time to digest the new situation, to fully grasp the new realities in Germany and in the world," said Mr. Kolhaase, who since 1990 has written and directed a film, completed two screenplays and worked in the theater in the unified Germany. "One tends to understand these things more quickly in the mind than in the heart. And for a filmmaker, this is a problem, because a good film must always come from the heart."

LENGTH: 1351 words

HEADLINE: In Mexico, the Prices Are Right, in Dollars or Pesos

BYLINE: By VERNE G. KOPYTOFF 

DATELINE: ROSARITO, Mexico

 BODY:
THE distinction between Mexico and the United States can seem unclear along parts of the coastal highway in Baja California, given the proliferation of billboards in English that advertise housing developments with "Models Open." Paying for a home can be just as disorienting, with prices in dollars, not pesos.
Thousands of American retirees and weekend vacationers, lured by the low cost of living and the spectacular views of sunburnt hillsides and rugged seashore, own homes here in Rosarito, a town of 13,000, located 20 miles south of San Diego. The local real estate agents aim at Americans for much of their business, hence the brochures that list home amenities like "breakfast bar," "Jacuzzi tub," and "spacious pantries." 
 Sales to Americans are just starting to recover from Mexico's economic and political turmoil of the last few years, which left many development projects under construction looking deserted. The country's reputation for beautiful whitewashed villages and glorious beaches was supplanted in the minds of many potential buyers by worrisome reports of drug trafficking and corruption.
But most veteran homeowners like Donald R. Thompson, a retired sales manager for a publishing company, only gloat about their decision to move to Mexico. As ocean swells crashed on the beach just a few dozen yards from his second-story balcony, Mr. Thompson told of his weekly games of golf on a nearby course, frequent games of tennis and the exorbitant cost of buying a similar home on the beach in California.
"It's heaven here," said Mr. Thompson, 75, who moved from San Diego to the Club Marena development in Rosarito four years ago. "I wouldn't live anywhere else. I have everything I need here."
"People who haven't been here talk about crime and all of that," he added. "But it's probably safer here than in the United States, and the people are just wonderful."
Mr. Thompson's three-bedroom condominium apartment, which he shares with his wife, Julie, is in an 11-story tower that overlooks a lawn, gym and swimming pool. The 2,800-square-foot apartment, which he bought for $315,000, features red tile floors, arched doorways and a dining area with a domed ceiling. It has conveniences like a dishwasher that are typical of a middle-class home in the United States.
"There's no way I could afford a place like this in California, if one so close to the shore existed," said Mr. Thompson, who, when he lived in San Diego, could afford only a small condominium three miles from the beach.
Club Marena, which was opened in 1990 by a Mexican developer, Jamie Garcia, has expanded to four buildings from one. Prices of the 96 units range from $240,000 for a 1,400-square-foot apartment to $500,000 for one couple's 4,800-square-foot custom-built penthouse. Vacancies are rare.
EXPERTS say housing costs in Mexico are 30 to 40 percent cheaper than for a comparable home in the United States, and that property taxes are about half those in California. So it is no surprise that Americans make up nearly 90 percent of Club Marena's occupants.
Most owners use their homes only on weekends or vacations. But about 10 are full-time residents, many of whom drive 45 minutes once a week across the border to San Diego to shop at a mall, see a movie in English or attend a concert.
With so many Americans in northern Baja California, some living in luxury with maids and cooks, others in trailers on dusty lots not far from slum neighborhoods, the area's traditional rural atmosphere has become enmeshed with California's beach culture. One restaurant operating from a roadside shack in Rosarito specializes in "surfing tacos."
Mexican real estate laws have not been similarly Americanized, however, and buyers from north of the border may find the regulations unfamiliar. That fact, plus lax research, has led some Americans to be swindled out of their money by buying property from someone who did not own it.
One difference is that real estate agents in Mexico are unlicensed and not required to have any professional training. Second, foreigners who buy a house within 31 miles of the coast and 62 miles of the border are forbidden from holding title to their property. Instead, the property title must be held by a Mexican bank and placed in a trust called a "fideicomiso," with the home buyer designated as the beneficiary.
The arrangement costs several thousand dollars to initiate and several hundred dollars in annual fees, and must be renewed every 50 years. Though the process seems intricate, experts say foreign home buyers in Mexico have the same property rights as if they were in the United States and, contrary to what some fear, the Mexican Government will not one day appropriate their land.
"It's not that an American can't own property," said Dennis John Peyton, a lawyer who helps Americans buy property in Mexico and the author of "How to Buy Real Estate in Mexico" (Law Mexico Publishing, 1994). "They might not be able to hold title, but they have all the rights to enjoy the property and to sell it whenever they want."
One new development that may make buying a home more familiar to Americans is the availability of financing from an American mortgage company. For example, the Metrociti Mortgage Company, in Sherman Oaks, Calif., is offering a 25-year mortgage in Mexico with an interest rate of 11 percent to 12 percent, 3 to 4 percentage points higher than for a home in the United States. The mortgage interest on a personal residence is considered tax-deductible by the Internal Revenue Service.
In the past, American mortgage companies refused to offer mortgages in Mexico because of the potential complications of foreclosing on property across an international border. As a result, home buyers had to pay in cash or take out a loan in Mexico.
"The North American Free Trade Agreement legitimized doing business in Mexico," said Tim Kruger, director of Metrociti Mortgage. "We can be more confident about our mortgages, because Nafta made it more certain that our Government would get involved if there were problems."
Real estate experts in Mexico predict that the housing market will continue its slow recovery from the peso devaluation of 1994, when the value of the peso was cut in half, and the subsequent political scandals. Virtually all development has been halted since the troubles began. Recently the peso has been worth around 13 cents in American money.
While the prices of some homes have declined or can be bargained down as a result, others are said to be pegged to the dollar and do not fluctuate. Americans, suffering from their own recession and apprehensive about Mexico's future, have until recently been unwilling to buy.
"Mexico is in the process of becoming a democratic nation," said Bo Wallsten, president and co-owner of the Century 21 real estate company in Mexico City. "We're only in Year 10. We'll have a lot of hiccups along the way."
BEFORE buying property in Mexico, some Americans take organized trips to popular retirement areas with companies that offer seminars explaining the country's real estate procedures, immigration law and medical care system. Destinations include Cabo San Lucas, on the southern tip of the Baja Peninsula; Puerto Vallarta, on the Pacific coast, and Lake Chapala, Mexico's largest lake, located inland near Guadalajara.
Loujean LaMalfa, the president of Prince LaMalfa International, a company in Petaluma, Calif., that offers tours, said she advises potential buyers to do their research, look out for disreputable real estate agents and be understanding of Mexico's relaxed pace of business and abundance of poverty.
No matter what some people say, Ms. LaMalfa added, the cost of living comfortably in Mexico is not negligible. She said a couple who rent a home, enjoy regular nights on the town and employ a housekeeper can expect to spend $2,000 a month.
"Telling people that they can live in Mexico for $400 a month is doing them a real disservice," Ms. LaMalfa said. "You can do that, but it depends on whether you want to live without electricity."
