SECTION: Section 14CN; Page 17; Column 1; Connecticut Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1449 words

HEADLINE: A Hartford Arena Becomes a Draw

BYLINE: By R. L. FELSON 

 BODY:
IT is a warm autumnal evening, with a harvest moon aglow, as Fleetwood Mac opens its reunion tour before a crowd of 20,000 fans. Outside the concert, rows of white, stretch limousines idle as their passengers -- including many corporate executives in expensive box seats -- enjoy the show. Up on the lawn, nearly 13,000 younger fans sway and holler exclamations of joy with the band's every song.
In the music industry, the kickoff of Fleetwood Mac's national tour, after 15 years off stage, is a big event, and this could be New York, Los Angeles or Chicago. But it's Hartford, once an unlikely venue for major league concerts. More specifically, it's the Meadows Music Theater, a $31 million concert amphitheater financed in part by the state of Connecticut. 
 The three-year-old amphitheater, pushed by former Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr., and other state officials, not only has brought new night life to a city that often seems deserted after business hours, but also has given Connecticut music fans a chance to see popular music acts that they once had to drive out of state to hear. "These sorts of amazing things happen in primary markets, not secondary markets like Hartford," said Jim Koplik, the president of the Meadows, who at 48, will mark 30 years as a rock concert promoter in Connecticut next year.
Because bands over the past decade increasingly have turned to playing outdoors during the summer, many big-name acts had bypassed Connecticut, including the Hartford Civic Center and the New Haven Coliseum, to play nearby outdoor venues like Great Woods, in southeastern Massachusetts.
Moreover, because the amphitheater includes a heating system and a set of retractable walls that enclose the 6,900 reserved seats, the Meadows can operate yearround, making it the second most expensive amphitheater ever built. The world's first indoor-outdoor concert theater is the Blockbuster-Sony Entertainment Center in Camden, N.J.
Since its opening the summer of 1995, marquee artists including Hootie and the Blowfish, Michael Bolton, James Taylor, Crosby, Stills & Nash, the Allman Brothers, Santana, Alice Cooper, Courtney Love, Sting, Jimmy Buffet, Dave Matthews and David Bowie have played the Meadows.
In the last year, Mr. Koplik has managed to lure several nationally touring bands to the Meadows to rehearse their act. He has been able to draw bands to Hartford for rehearsals in part because the costs of hotels and other expenses for bands and their stage crews are so much lower than in cities like New York or Boston, and because the amphitheater, unlike other multi-purpose concert halls, does not double as a hockey rink or basketball court or circus venue.
Fleetwood Mac, for example, was scheduled to open its 37-city tour at Great Woods, Mass., but Mr. Koplik offered them the Meadows for rehearsals for free if they opened in Hartford. The move earned Hartford national media attention when the band launched its big comeback tour from the capital city.
Other bands, including David Bowie, Aerosmith and AC/DC also have used the amphitheater as a rehearsal hall. Yes, which opened its North American tour at the Meadows Oct. 17 was the most recent band to rehearse at the amphitheater. Because the Meadows offers bands one of the largest stages on the East Coast, coupled with easy load-in access and reasonable stagehand costs, some bands, like Aerosmith, will rehearse at the Meadows even if their tours don't open there.
Built in the city's industrial North Meadows about a mile north of downtown, the site is easy for fans to get to and get home from, situated just off Interstate 91 and close to Interstate 84. As a result, the amphitheater has been a relatively easy sell for residents who live within a 60-minute radius of Hartford, from New Haven and New London to the south, Waterbury to the west and Springfield, Mass., to the north.
While most outdoor amphitheaters are often built in rural areas so they don't bother neighbors, the Meadows has caused virtually no noise problems because its location is far enough from residential neighborhoods. Its proximity to downtown Hartford was actually a selling point when the project was first floated by state officials, as a potential boon to revitalize Hartford's night life. But that promise has yet to fully be realized.
Robb Hankins, the executive director of the Greater Hartford Arts Council and a leading advocate of leveraging the arts for the city's economic benefit, said the Meadows remains a dream in the making. "To have people like Tina Turner eight blocks from my office on a regular basis is like a dream come true. And those of us in arts and entertainment are delighted the Meadows is here. We just want it to do more and be more," said Mr. Hankins, who was largely responsible for creating the city's downtown arts and entertainment district as a way to capitalize on the variety of such venues in Hartford.
The challenge, said Mr. Hankins, is that the Meadows is a mile north of the arts and entertainment district. With a highway overpass, parking lots and industrial areas for pedestrians to contend with, that distance is apparently far enough to discourage many Meadows fans from spending time before or after the concert at downtown restaurants.
A shuttle bus between downtown and the Meadows ran as an experiment during the first season, but that service no longer is available, yet Mr. Hankins said ways need to be discovered to better connect the Meadows to downtown.
Mr. Koplik, a Stamford resident who now spends most of his time at the Meadows, says he has expressed a willingness to sit down with downtown leaders to discuss how better to make the Meadows work for the downtown.
Nevertheless, hotels report an increase in business as a result of the Meadows, not only from some out-of-town fans but also from the bands and stage crews, said Marjorie Morrissey, executive director of Business for Downtown Hartford, a trade group representing downtown restaurants, retailers and the service industry. And she said that while the hoped-for economic impact from the Meadows has taken a while, with every year more and more people connect Hartford with the Meadows.
As more premiere artists play the Meadows, Ms. Morrissey said, Hartford will continue to benefit with good public relations. Lately, the Meadows has had to weather a barrage of bad publicity in connection with ethical violations in which state officials and employees, including Gov. John G. Rowland, received an estimated $10,000 in free concert tickets from the Meadows and its lobbyist, violating a law limiting gifts from lobbyists to $50 a year.
The $30 million amphitheater received about $20 million in state financing, including about $10 million from the Connecticut Development Authority under a relatively new formula called tax-increment financing, in which the state uses sales and ticket tax revenues from the amphitheater to pay off the bonds. Roy Breward, the deputy director of the Development Authority, said the Meadows has been making its payments on time and is up to date.
The theater was developed by Mr. Koplik, who was president of Metropolitan Entertainment in New Jersey, and the Nederlander Organization of Chicago, a theatrical giant.
Earlier this year, radio giant SCF Broadcasting Inc., purchased the Meadows, although Mr. Koplik continues to run the amphitheater. One major difference, Mr. Koplik said, is that unlike past seasons, this year he has been at every concert to respond to fans' complaints. As a result, he said SFX has invested about $1 million in improvements to the site this past season, including the addition of new state-of-the-art video screens and projection system for fans on the lawn to see the stage better. Mr. Koplik also has added new speakers into the corners of the enclosed part of the amphitheater, where fans complained of poor acoustics.
In addition, he has begun to open up the site to the public for special events as a sign of his willingness to play a greater role in the community. When Hartford's Superintendent of Schools, Patricia A. Daniel welcomed back 4,500 teachers late last summer, Mr. Koplik, who is married to a teacher, allowed the school system to use the Meadows at cost.
He has also opened the Meadows up for college graduation ceremonies and other children's programs. "It's good for the community, and it's good for us, and we've only just begun," said Mr. Koplik.
Paul Shipman, an aide to Hartford's Mayor Mike Peters, said, "It's certainly helped put Hartford on the map as an entertainment venue and a place where people can come to see top notch entertainment in the region."

HEADLINE: CRITIC'S VIEW;
Where a Democracy and Its Money Have No Place

BYLINE: By EDWARD ROTHSTEIN 

 BODY:
EARLIER THIS YEAR, JANE ALEXANDER, THE departing chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts, wearily spoke of recurring Congressional attempts to "drive a stake in the heart of Federal funding for the arts." She called these exorcistic rites a "nearly debilitating annual Sturm und Drang that threatens to suck the life out of all arts advocates."
It is too soon to say if the annual Sturm and Drang will achieve its threatened goal, but here is a working critic's confession: if this perpetual drama actually reaches its final wrenching cadences, it will be a relief. Andres Serrano's urine-soaked crucifix, Robert Mapplethorpe's penile photographs, Jesse Helms's outrage and invocations of family values -- all will become quaint memories. So will endowment reports like the one released on Oct. 15 that accuses the arts of the sin of elitism. 
 Finally, we will be able to pay attention to the real problem -- something that might be called the "ideology of democracy." In this vision of the world, not only are all people created equal but so are all ideas and all cultures. Even art -- an essentially undemocratic achievement by extraordinarily gifted individuals -- is thrust into a marketplace marked by clamorous demands for democratic distribution. How can a national agency act as a patron in such an atmosphere? It can't. And it shouldn't. R.I.P.
Before the grave is dug, it might be worth reviewing the all-too-familiar N.E.A. debate. The endowment began in 1965 as part of the same Great Society enterprise that declared war on poverty; that utopian spirit still characterizes its defense. N.E.A. supporters point out that all great nations help finance the arts -- France spends $32 a person and Germany $27 -- but the annual costs of the endowment have been no more than 38 cents per capita. That small amount, though, has large repercussions.
 
Endowment Money Talks, But Interpretations Differ
According to the endowment, each N.E.A. dollar inspires $11 more in matching grants. Since its founding, the number of orchestras has quadrupled; there are eight times as many theaters; annual audiences for the arts exceed those of all sports events combined. The arts also create $37 billion in economic activity and support 1.3 million jobs. Finally, less than 40 of the 110,000 grants ever given by the N.E.A. have been controversial.
The organization's opponents see a very different picture. The controversial grants, with their provocative sexual, political or religious imagery, are viewed as just extreme examples of the N.E.A. helping to pull the fringe closer to the mainstream. Endowment-inspired matching grants are part of the problem, not solution: they further institutionalize the N.E.A.'s attitudes.
And if the endowment has helped increase the quantity of art, it is debatable whether the quality has improved. Economic benefits are also beside the point: if the goal is fiscal health, there are more efficient methods. Countries like France and Germany hardly offer a model for American patronage; they are too different in character and history. The Government should get out of the business of art criticism.
Underlying these arguments, though, is a more fundamental issue. In the political arena, where deals are made and budgets determined, the N.E.A. is debated with little understanding of what art is all about or what the function of a patron is; among politicians and, indeed, within the endowment, major decisions are being influenced by the ideology of democracy.
That ideology begins with one of the great liberal ideas that defined this country: equality is not something attained or purchased or inherited. It is simply possessed, universally, at birth. Failures to realize this ideal have done nothing to weaken its strength: when we stand before the law as citizens, we are supposed to stand equally.
But as de Tocqueville realized, such a revolutionary idea could not be applied in the political realm without also resonating in all other aspects of American life. In fact, it has now become the defining aspect of American culture. We are so loath to make distinctions (except to correct earlier distinctions) that we now doubt whether any are worthwhile or even possible. We ask democracy to be the moral, spiritual and esthetic compass by which our culture evolves.
The problem is that art is incompatible with this ideology. It is engaged in constant acts of discrimination. Moreover, the ability to create it is no more distributed according to democratic principles than is the ability to play basketball like Michael Jordan or chess like Gary Kasparov. There are differences between us at birth that the civil order must ignore but the esthetic order is beholden to. Even the evaluation of art is guided by such undemocratic gauges as cultivated taste and extensive experience.
 
Can Democratic Ideals Be Used to Judge Art?
So there is a tension at the very heart of the N.E.A.: How can a national agency in a democracy make decisions that are, in their very essence, anti-democratic?
This was an issue raised during the initial debates about whether a Federal arts agency should even be established. Initially, many major arts institutions were opposed to a Federal arts program. In 1953, a survey by the American Symphony Orchestra League, the service organization for American orchestras, showed that 99 percent of orchestra board members opposed Federal aid. Aside from the leaders of community orchestras, members of the league remained lukewarm on Federal aid even into the 1960's. Orchestras and the fine arts, many organizations argued, could only be sullied by the interference of politicians who were neither trained nor inclined to make proper decisions.
The skepticism did not disappear once the N.E.A. was established. Who, after all, would be given the power to make judgments about grants? By what right would anybody's tastes, values and standards prevail over anybody else's? The way such elite activities were reconciled with democratic aspirations was to create an institutional hybrid: the main decision-making was seemingly removed from the realm of democratic politics and ceded to professionals. An elite jury of peers would evaluate each application.
This created a new style of artistic patronage. The panel system rejected the idea that we are all equal in judging art, but still turned the judging of art into a "democratic" process. A larger bureaucracy was required to administer the panel system, to assess results "objectively" and to justify the judgments to those holding the purse strings.
The panel system also strengthened the ideology of democracy within the N.E.A. The composition of panels became politically important. Panels were treated as if they should be representative bodies, their members speaking for different constituencies.
While politics has always been a handmaiden to patronage -- older models of arts support by court and church involved notorious quantities of infighting and favoritism -- the emphasis on accountability created a new kind of bureaucratic politics. Artistic patronage was thrust into the public marketplace, to be buffeted about by conflicting claims. Forget individual taste; the demand was for representation.
During the last two decades this demand has become even more fervent as democratic ideology has taken root in the art world itself. The very idea of artistic quality has become open to question. Many artists have become preoccupied with making ideological statements. And advocates of multiculturalism have questioned the priority of Western standards and styles.
In such a landscape, what sort of patron of the arts has the N.E.A. become? It takes equitable distribution as a principle of its patronage. It is preoccupied with the size of audiences. It focuses on insuring equal participation by different interest groups. It retains a notion of "excellence" but makes that idea contingent on the opinions of its constituencies. And nothing can be excluded. The endowment boasts that it "reaches Americans of every race, class, ethnicity and geographic region" and "supports community festivals, rural chamber music, art exhibitions in libraries and town halls, lawn concerts."
The N.E.A. has tended to treat financial support of the arts as if the money had to be distributed according to various formulas of representation -- calculating, to a tenth of a percentage point, funds distributed to each state and ethnic group. Its judging panels in recent years have been created using something resembling an ethnic quota: about a third have consistently been "minorities" -- American Indians, Asians, blacks or Hispanics -- and about 48 percent have been women.
The result is that the N.E.A. has ended up becoming a multicultural clearing house. When the agency was criticized recently for a grant to the California Indian Basket Weavers Association, Ms. Alexander defended "this world-renowned form of traditional art mastered by Native Americans." No other distinctions were necessary.
As a consequence, there appears to be no central vision, simply the clamor of political forces. This is evident in the recent revisions of grant categories, established not according to discipline, like theater or music, but according to principles, like Access, Heritage or Preservation. Such categories give more emphasis to the political benefits of support than to the arts themselves.
 
If the N.E.A. Is Not Elitist, Why Is It Needed?
So without a homogeneous culture, without an education system that creates a deep understanding of artistic traditions, without a realization that art is more than entertainment, public patronage becomes a market phenomenon, responding to conflicting demands, competing bids, promises of influence. We have a democratic society; we demand democratic arts.
It is astonishing how thoroughly this idea has been accepted in Washington, without any inkling that it might conflict with the very essence of traditional patronage of the arts or artistic accomplishment. Newt Gingrich and the Republicans thought they were making an incisive criticism of the N.E.A. when they called it "elitist." The agency's allies responded with outrage at the supposed insult. On Oct. 15, the endowment went a step further in its report, "American Canvas, an Arts Legacy for Our Communities," blaming arts institutions for being elitist. Each group thought the word a slur rather than a matter of pride. But if the N.E.A. is not elitist, what do we need it for?
Attempts by Republicans to create a test of artistic "decency" also ended up revealing an esthetic vacuum. The arts were treated as if their function was to communicate proper "values" to the public. Washington liberals took a similarly vulgar view, focusing on their own versions of "values" and treating art as a form of social therapy doled out to interest groups. As much as the right's opposition, the left's defense has tended to piety and religious fervor.
Even the courts have got into the act. When the endowment's "decency" test for determining the financing of artworks was struck down earlier this year, the court argued that the Government could not deny a work support because of ideas or point of view. This was hailed as a triumph for free speech. But if a patron cannot decide whether or not to financially support a work because of its ideas or point of view, on what grounds can it decide? Form? Style?
So the ideology of democracy leaves us with a vision of the arts that is pure pork barrel. At this moment, there are few Congressional Democrats or Republicans with any deep understanding of cultural life apart from television or movies. There is nothing to temper the ideology of democracy, only opinion to support it. And this, of course, affects the kind of "art" being created. One criterion for the authenticity of democratic art is that it stir "controversy": controversy means that it is noticed by the most people and justifies its cost. Immediate sensation becomes important. So do practical benefits and notions of "relevance."
Paradoxically, though, the ideology of democracy may suggest a means for developing a national artistic culture. It is not to be found in democracy itself but in the intellectual, religious and esthetic traditions that led to its development. If those traditions were really at the center of the N.E.A., there might be some chance for national patronage; they might encourage a more healthy artistic diversity, free from democratic demands.
 
There Is a Model For an Arts Paradise
Prime examples of institutions that have offered such alternatives are the great museums -- like the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Here many esthetic universes coexist, with each culture's most elite and extraordinary objects on display. But they are housed in an enterprise unmistakably based on Western traditions of knowledge and judgment. The museum is made possible by combining Western-style scholarship with multicultural expertise. The Met could evolve in that fashion because it didn't have to answer to democratic constituencies, only to its curators, who shared common goals.
A contemporary public patron like the N.E.A. could have similar ideals, but that would mean declaring independence from democratic ideology and being ready to withstand the righteous outrage that would follow. It may be that at this moment of cultural and political fragmentation, a public patron could best serve the public by educating it in art's undemocratic character, focusing on the cultivation of educated eyes and ears. This would turn the patron into a conservator rather than a supporter of new works -- a role with risks and restrictions, but with far fewer than democratic dilettantism. The more effective grants of the current N.E.A. could then be built upon.
Optimism, though, may be uncalled for. The sad aspect of modern American culture is that we created a National Endowment for the Arts we deserve. The even sadder aspect is that the way things stand now, what we really deserve is no N.E.A. at all.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 4; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 2044 words

HEADLINE: SUNDAY VIEW;
'Side Show' Asks, What Is Normal?

BYLINE: By Vincent Canby 

 BODY:
IF YOU HAVE EVER SEEN "Freaks," Tod Browning's macabre 1932 horror-film classic, you have seen the Hilton sisters -- Daisy and Violet, Siamese twins. With their unexceptional features, carefully waved hair and eyebrows fashionably plucked, they are almost pretty in the low-key way of two girls next door. Yet their heads are a little too large for their compact bodies and, more important, they are joined at the hip.
The sisters were on display for much of their lives, that is, from the instant they were born in England in 1908 through their show business careers in this country in the 1920's and into the 1940's. When, finally, vaudeville no longer called and interest in such oddities of nature declined, they settled near Charlotte, N.C., where they worked in a supermarket. They died in 1969. 
 In the film, they don't do much. They are impassive presences, nonactors who have been told where to stand and what to look at, but they are in many scenes. They are members of the chorus of sideshow "freaks" who bear witness to, and take terrible revenge on, the circus's beautiful aerialist who marries the sideshow's midget for his money. "Freaks" is still a disturbing film, as it observes, with an existential detachment, the fierce, brutal "otherness" of a community of people who feel forever estranged from the so-called normal world.
Taking the story of the Hilton sisters as their inspiration, Bill Russell, who wrote the book and lyrics, Henry Krieger, the composer, and Robert Longbottom, the director and choreographer, have conceived the astonishingly effective new musical called "Side Show," now at the Richard Rodgers Theater.
In spite of its smart, melodic, often funny words and music, its idealization of Daisy and Violet as Broadway beauties of real talent, and its simplification of circumstances, "Side Show" is almost as disturbing as "Freaks." There is no violence here, but the twins, condemned to live in a world of "normals," are denied the satisfactions of the only lives they have been taught are worth living.
In this respect "Side Show" recalls "The Elephant Man," the 1980 David Lynch film about John Merrick, the turn-of-the-century London working-class lad who was grossly deformed at birth by neurofibromatosis. The sorrowful thing about Merrick is that he denies his rage at his condition. He suppresses his roaring ego to accept the values of the fussily genteel upper middle class, which briefly celebrates him only because he is so horribly different.
This may be heroism, but it's of a kind that strikes most of us as inconceivable -- unbearable, really. It also represents a terrible surrender, not unlike the sort expected of the victim of Stalin's Moscow trials in Arthur Koestler's "Darkness at Noon." It demands faith in a faith that is not one's own. Which is why "Side Show" is so haunting. Even as you wonder -- as I do -- whether Siamese twins are a significant metaphor for the human condition, you have the suspicion that you are seeking a way to avoid facing questions too primal to answer honestly. What would it be like to be chained to a mirror image that sustains, comforts and infuriates you and that, in fact, is not you?
In the case of Daisy and Violet in "Side Show," played with uncanny precision and immense heart by, respectively, Emily Skinner and Alice Ripley, we are also put into the position of voyeurs. We're like the rude reporters who interview the twins from time to time within the show. As the sisters try desperately to demonstrate how normal they are, in the darkest recesses of our minds we are speculating about how they go about the most commonplace of daily functions; visions of their possible sex lives rattle our imaginations.
"Side Show" trades on this in its eerie prologue: the so-called "cannibal king," the bearded lady, the geek who bites the heads off chickens, the fat woman, the reptile man and all the other bizarre midway attractions silently come onto the stage to take their places in bleachers facing the audience, then taunt us as they issue their invitation in a mocking anthem titled "Come Look at the Freaks." From that moment on, the audience is always a bit on the defensive, while being deliciously conned by the show's expertise.
In outline the tale is more sentimental than it plays: the sisters, discovered in the carnival, are transformed into first-rate performing talents, moving first to vaudeville, where they become headliners, and then to stardom in what looks to be the Ziegfeld Follies. Yet even when they reach the top, their aspirations to achieve normal lives are thwarted.
Their mentors are two ambitious but essentially decent, ordinary guys, Terry Connor (Jeff McCarthy), a talent scout for the Orpheum circuit, and Buddy Foster (Hugh Panaro), a young sideshow usher who has the gift to teach the flat-footed, tone-deaf Hiltons how to become dancing, singing sensations.
As Daisy loves the go-getting Terry, the far less assertive Violet falls for Buddy. One of these would-be suitors, though intrigued by a twin, knows himself well enough to realize he can't carry through with anything as serious as a marriage. The second fellow, though fond of but not sexually aroused by the other twin, is ready to marry her just for the boost the publicity would give his career.
If "Side Show" depended on narrative, it would be deadly. Instead, with most of the dialogue sung, it is propelled and given emotional heft by Mr. Krieger's bright, inventive score (he is the composer of "Dreamgirls") and Mr. Russell's lyrics. The latter often have something of the intelligence, purity and wit you might have recognized in the work of Betty Comden and Adolph Green in the revival of "On the Town" in Central Park last summer.
THEN, TOO, THERE ARE THE contributions of Mr. Longbottom, as director and choreographer, who, I assume, also conceived (or, at least, realized) the show's overall concept. "Side Show," gorgeously designed by Robin Wagner, moves out of darkness into light and back again with often breathtaking effect. It looks lean, though it can suddenly erupt into a hilarious, elaborately dressed production number like "We Share Everything."
This number, which has an Ancient Egypt motif, introduces Daisy and Violet to the Orpheum circuit: the twins make their entrance from a double sarcophagus, seemingly inspired by Tutankhamen's, wearing short, spangly blue gowns and black wigs that recall Louise Brooks's trademark bob. Sample lyrics: "Two songbirds/ Zero friction/ No strong words/ Dainty diction/ Harmony is what we always sing/ We're so happy/ We share everything."
In support are eight male dancers. They
are scantily clad as generic pharoahs (and apparently none too at ease in their crazy get-ups) as they back up the cheery, conjoined temptresses with intricate dance patterns punctuated by furious though muted (for the vaudeville trade) bumps and grinds.
The lyrics are designed to tickle naughty funny bones, but the notion of the sisters sharing everything, a theme sounded time and again throughout the show, will soon return like a fatal boomerang in another duet, the lovely, double-edged "I Will Never Leave You."
Ms. Skinner and Ms. Ripley are an amazement. They not only look alike, as costumed by Gregg Barnes and lighted by Brian MacDevitt, but without any sort of harness, they also move, walk and, most spectacularly, dance together with the ease of creatures that a befuddled old God forgot to untie. Each clearly defines her own personality, and they sing with the zest of Broadway sweethearts.
Mr. McCarthy and Mr. Panaro are very good in roles that don't always seem consistent. It is difficult to believe that Mr. McCarthy's Terry, introduced as an easygoing ladies' man, would ever come on to Daisy as strongly as he does at first if, as it turns out, he is so put off by her singular attachment to her sister. As written, Mr. Panaro's Buddy also appears to change character halfway through.
The show's strongest supporting character is Jake, beautifully played and sung by Norm Lewis, though Jake is also the show's most glaring anachronism. He is the black sideshow worker who triples as the "cannibal king," the assistant to the sideshow's boss and the twins' protector and confidant, the only man capable of loving Violet for herself. Though the time of the show is the late 1920's and early 30's, he is seen socializing with the sisters in New York as well as at the Texas centennial celebration in San Antonio, which ends the show.
THIS IS DRAMATIC license and it pays off. Mr. Lewis has a big baritone and a stage personality that turn "The Devil You Know" and "You Should Be Loved" into two of the show's most affecting moments. Also to be noted is Ken Jennings, who plays the Boss, the rummy, vicious slob who has found his corner in life as the supreme ruler of a small band of society's rejects.
"Side Show" has its own original mind but it never pushes too hard. It doesn't alienate the audience, though as often as we're moved we are kept at a cool distance. It is less Brechtian than old-fashioned Broadway informed by a sharp, contemporary sensibility. Not in a long time has a new season begun with such promise.
 
'The American Clock'
This year the Signature Theater Company, which each season devotes its schedule to the work of a single playwright, is honoring Arthur Miller, and about time, too. The initial presentation is "The American Clock," now playing in the company's fine new space at 555 West 42d Street.
With the determination of the obsessive master he is, Mr. Miller has been tinkering with "The American Clock" ever since its premiere at the Harold Clurman Theater in New York early in 1980 and the productions that followed, each being an attempt to fix the problems of the earlier one. I may have been one of the few people who liked the production at the Clurman, and suspected that the play's problems were also the reason it was so moving. Now I'm not so sure.
"The American Clock" is a consideration of the awful economic, social and psychological dislocations caused by the Great Depression, based on material from Studs Terkel's book "Hard Times" and integrated with Mr. Miller's recollections of his own family's experiences.
There was always a difficulty in mixing the clearly documentary vignettes with Mr. Miller's personal stories. The vignettes, being far more vivid, exact and immediately significant, overwhelm the short scenes of the Baum (read Miller) family, which, at best, seem like notes for a play yet to be written.
That difficulty continues in the would-be jubilant production at the Signature, directed by James Houghton, the company's artistic chief, and labeled "a vaudeville," inspired by Peter Wood's hugely popular London staging in 1986. This "American Clock" is an attempt to do epic theater, and though a lively three-piece band and a cast of 15 have a high old time playing, singing and dancing dozens of irresistible period songs, the piece still bogs down in the family interludes, which, though often intriguingly idiosyncratic, never have time to gather dramatic momentum.
The designer, E. David Cosier, makes good use of the Signature's large new stage, the floor and side walls painted to look like a deconstructed American flag, the back wall painted to represent the big, fair sky that always hangs over an ideal America. The members of the cast, on stage from start to finish, come forward as needed to perform in an area defined by a huge wooden picture frame.
The play looks great and is performed by some splendid actors, among them Lewis J. Stadlen, as Mr. Miller's father, and Patrick Husted, who portrays Theodore K. Quinn, a marvelous, cranky, passionate American who resigned as president of General Electric after one day because he disliked the direction in which big business was headed.
Characters such as Quinn draw you into "The American Clock," not the whore who wants to know more about Engels and who sounds like an inspiration from a playwright's notebook.
 
SIDE SHOW -- A fascinating mix of old-fashioned Broadway and a sharp, contemporary sensibility.
 
THE AMERICAN CLOCK -- This would-be jubilant reworking of vintage Arthur Miller finally bogs down.

HEADLINE: Beyond 50 and Blazing Trails on the Frontier

BYLINE: By CAROLYN BATTISTA 

 BODY:
ONE afternoon Carole Bobruff and Dale Callahan were at their kitchen table, talking about health care, money, entertainment, relationships and a sprightly fellow named Otto. Most mornings they're in a studio at radio station WSUB-AM in Groton, talking about such matters -- and more -- with listeners in a dozen states.
The Mystic residents are hosts of "Senior Focus," a radio show for those they call "seasoned citizens." The show, which began in 1990 with local, once-a-week broadcasts, has been syndicated since February. Now on the air Monday through Friday, it's a success with listeners and with advertisers. "I think that's because it's something that hasn't been done before," said Ms. Bobruff. She doesn't know of any other prime-time radio talk show "that's targeted to the needs of the 50-plus audience and reflects the tremendous diversity of our interests." There's certainly no other show where Otto -- a character that she created -- gets to speak his seasoned mind. 
 On the air, Ms. Bobruff, who's 62, uses the name Carole Marks. She and Mr. Callahan, who's 59, chat with each other, callers and guests (including politicians, doctors and a milkman). They aim to inform as well as entertain. "Now that we're living so much longer, we need information to get through the next 20 or 30 years," said Ms. Bobruff.
The two also hope to open some eyes to the needs, contributions and power of older people. "We're on a frontier, but people don't know it," Ms. Bobruff said. For one thing, Mr. Callahan said, advertisers are just beginning to recognize the growing market of people over 50. "They're still concentrating on people 24-45, but they're suddenly realizing that they may be targeting the wrong market. It's economics," he said.
Senior Focus is "a fight against agism -- and that's a fight that has to be fought," added Ms. Bobruff. On the show the character Otto (played by an actor) often observes that Americans treasure old things, not old people. "We have to turn our society around a little bit," said Ms. Bobruff.
The hour-long show is syndicated through Talk America II, a radio talk show network based in Canton, Mass. Besides reaching WSUB audiences in Connecticut, Rhode Island and Long Island, the show is sent via satellite to stations in Arkansas, California, Florida, Idaho, Massachusetts, Michigan, Mississippi, Nevada and Texas. Broadcasts are live, not taped, with guests interviewed in the studio or by phone.
Much -- but not all -- has changed since 1990, when Ms. Bobruff, who'd been the director of a volunteer program staffed by older people, decided that a radio show could help older people be better informed and less isolated. She'd never done any radio work before, but she plunged into the tasks that she still carries out -- researching topics, scheduling interviews, writing scripts and selling advertisements. "I've never been afraid to take a risk," said Ms. Bobruff, who went to college in her 40's. Mr. Callahan, who'd never been involved in radio either, gamely became the show's producer. "We were together, and she needed some help," he explained. His past experience included selling insurance and cars.
In 1995, he became a co-host. He says that his sales background helps him to put people at ease, "so we can talk." Ms. Bobruff says, "It's valuable to have a male point of view."
Mr. Callahan reads three or four newspapers daily, to stay informed on varied issues and perspectives. Ms. Bobruff finds the Internet useful. The two share in the show's national and local advertising revenues. In Groton, Ms. Bobruff said, Senior Focus draws more local advertising than the Rush Limbaugh show.
Since syndication, Senior Focus has had more guests with national appeal. The hosts frequently mention toll-free numbers -- like that of a national insurance association, for instance -- so that listeners anywhere can get information on particular topics. This summer they introduced Otto, a character who has apparently lived for centuries. "He's the ultimate senior citizen," said Ms. Bobruff. "He's seen it all. He can comment."
Recent topics on the show have ranged from the workings of the weather to the discovery of the genes linked to macular degeneration, a visual impairment. Guests have included Connecticut's attorney general, Richard Blumenthal, who discussed the state's settlement with tobacco companies; the artist Peter Max, who talked about his work, and Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, who talked about his proposal to support training for medical students in gerontology.
It wasn't easy, Ms. Bobruff said, to persuade Jack LaLanne, the long-time promoter of physical fitness, to be interviewed at 9 A.M., Connecticut time. That's 6 A.M., California time -- and that's when Mr. LaLanne, a Californian who's 83, is into his daily workout. Nor was the 9 A.M. slot so good for the milkman who still makes daily deliveries. He was more tired than talkative, recalled Mr. Callahan, because he'd been up and working since 2 A.M.
The hosts said they especially enjoyed their interviews with older entertainers, including Steve Allen and cabaret singers like Julie Wilson and Margaret Whiting. "Lots of them are working," said Mr. Callahan. "They still sound good." Ms. Bobruff calls Mr. Allen, who's 76, "a mentor." He's given them advice and allowed them to use some of his music.
Senior Focus gets calls from people of varied ages. "We have lots of younger listeners," said Ms. Bobruff, adding that often younger people call because they're concerned about their parents.
Calls from different areas reveal regional differences, like more conservatism in the interior of the country. But more often they indicate common concerns. The hosts say that, everywhere, people who once served their country are distressed by cuts in military retirement benefits. And everywhere, said Ms. Bobruff, older people are concerned about "health, health and health." They're also worried about finances.
She and Mr. Callahan see plenty to be done. "If I could accomplish one thing through the show," said Ms. Bobruff, "it would be to try to work through the political system to get premiums for long-term care, and for home health care, completely tax deductible." That, she says, would make the expensive premiums more feasible for more people.
More attention should be paid, the hosts say, to problems like drinking and depression in the older population. Recently they informed listeners about a nation-wide depression-screening program.
They'd like to look at how much older people are helping their adult children these days. With downsizing and other changes in the workplace, Ms. Bobruff said, "It's so much harder for your children to become secure. You worry; you care, you're going to help out."
Mr. Callahan said, "There should be more talk about relationships between older people. People say, 'It's all over.' It's not true." He turned to Ms. Bobruff with a big smile. "Maybe," he said, "Otto can advise on personal relationships."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The character known only as Otto, left, offers his views of the day to Carole Bobruff and Dale Callahan on "Senior Focus." (Thomas McDonald for The New York Times)

LENGTH: 2140 words

HEADLINE: Gilded Age Estates Hold a Key to Open-Space Efforts

BYLINE: By JOY ALTER HUBEL 

 BODY:
JUST off Jericho Turnpike in Cold Spring Hills, past a development of ranch houses, the medieval turrets of the Oheka Castle spring into view. That a 123-room chateau stands blocks from the shopping centers on Route 25 may be unusual.
Oheka is one example among hundreds of lavish country estates that have shaped Long Island history. And while many of the estates have yielded to subdivision and development, a number have been restored, converted to other uses or are in the process of refurbishment, preserving a tone and style that dates to many decades ago. 
 "Many people think of Newport, R.I., as the showcase for the nation's richest and most aristocratic families, but it is actually Long Island that boasts the most concentrated assortment of architecturally and historically noteworthy mansions in the country," said Robert B. MacKay, director of the Society for the Preservation of Long Island Antiquities.
"These surviving estates are among the principal amenities of Long Island, and are one of the few remaining ways for us to protect the region's open spaces."
He added: "This region has undergone so much excess development that now people are concerned with preserving what is left of their environment and quality of life."
To promote preservation of the grand estates, the society, in association with W. W. Norton & Company, has published a 560-page guide, "Long Island Country Houses and Their Architects, 1860-1940," edited by Mr. MacKay and Anthony Baker and Carol Traynor, who are historians.
The book documents through essays and photographs the Gilded Age, when many millionaires could not spend their money -- or build their country homes -- flamboyantly enough.
"In the years between the Civil War and World War II," Mr. MacKay said, "over 1,000 Long Island country residences were built by some of the nation's richest financiers and industrialists, including the Vanderbilts, the Astors, the Morgans, the Whitneys and the du Ponts, who were drawn to Long Island because of its proximity to New York City and its abundance of woodlands, waterways and open spaces."
Many estates were designed to recreate the world of the European aristocracy. The rich modeled their homes after Italian villas, English manor houses and Celtic castles and commissioned the greatest architects and landscapers of the period, including MacKim, Mead & White; Delano & Aldrich, and the Olmsted brothers, designers of Central Park.
The most lavish country houses boasted amenities like private golf courses, polo fields, tennis courts, stables and boathouses.
Today little remains of that Gatsby-like world. Nevertheless that way of life has strongly influenced how Long Islanders live. Much like those tycoons, commuters strive to escape the pressures of work to the serenity of country, the vigor of sport and the company of friends, albeit on a different scale.
The estates, Mr. MacKay said, represent not only the architectural past, but also social and cultural roots.
The Town Historian of Glen Cove, Dan Russell, credited a new capitalist attitude for stanching the tide of estate destruction. "Twenty years ago," Mr. Russell said, "these estates were looked upon as white elephants owned by evil Robber Barons. Yet now we realize they represent tremendous social history. They describe a past that will never come again, a way of building that is superior to anything we have now, and a capitalistic heritage that is not so much about Robber Barons but heroic entrepreneurs."
Unfortunately the sentiment turned too late for many estates. About half have been lost, to the Depression, income taxes and rising land values and labor costs.
Many were divided to satisfy inheritance claims. Parts were sold to builders who subdivided sprawling terrain for smaller houses and condos.
Burrwood, an estate originally owned by Walter Jennings, an oil magnate, that sat on a bluff overlooking Cold Spring Harbor, was leveled in 1994. A builder, John Kean, subdivided the estate into single-family houses.
"In the 70's," Mr. MacKay said, "when demolition of these estates peaked, we didn't see private ownership as a solution for saving them. And yet in the 80's and 90's we have seen some people step forward to take on bigger ones."
One example is the purchase by George Campbell, an engineer and builder, of the 45-room Fort Hill estate in Lloyd Harbor in 1992. That same year Ronald O. Perleman, the financier, bought The Creeks, the estate of Alfonso Ossorio, the artist, in Wainscott.
Not long ago, the chief executive of Computer Associates, Charles Wang, bought the Youngs homestead in Cove Neck. It had previously been owned by P. James Roosevelt, first cousin twice removed of Theodore Roosevelt.
The vitality of estate ownership and restoration is being driven, in part, by prosperity, Mr. MacKay said, adding: "In fact it appears we are on the verge of a new country-house era. Flying over Long Island one can see a number of huge houses going up, the size of which we have not seen since before World War II."
The decision, however, to restore an existing mansion rather build a new one is not necessarily economical. An engineer who restores Gold Coast mansions, Bud Woodworth of Woodworth Associates, said a typical restoration would cost $100 to $150 a square foot.
Where individuals have not taken over estates, creative re-uses have often filled the gaps. More than 84 estates have been modified, for activities like schools, colleges, country clubs, nursing homes and conference retreats.
Sometimes the modifications harm an estate, as in the case of Oheka, according to Joan Cergol, a spokesman for the catering operation there. For a short period, Oheka was a retreat for sanitation workers and then, for several decades, it was a military school that eventually went broke. By 1980, when Gary Melius, a builder, bought it, each room was waist high in school supplies.
On the other hand a number of institutions have restored or preserved buildings to within inches of their glory. The Webb Institute for Naval Architecture in Glen Cove maintained the Jacobean-style estate that Herbert L. Pratt, a founder of the Standard Oil Company, built in 1912 in its original condition, including its carved wainscotting, molded plaster ceilings and water views.
The Phipps estate in Old Westbury Gardens and Coe Hall at Planting Fields in Oyster Bay are equally well restored. The former mansions offer good views of what life can be like on endless acres of gardens, woodlands and rolling hills and in rooms larger than many single-family dwellings.
Similar examples of successful restorations include Rynwood, once the estate of Sir Samuel Agar Salvage, a textile manufacturer, and Winfield, F. W. Woolworth's manor house in Glen Cove. Banfi Importers Inc. bought Rynwood in Old Brookville in 1979 from the estate of F. W. Luncy, the Sheepshead Bay restarateur. The wine importer restored Rynwood as a corporate headquarters.
The Pall Corporation, which leased Winfield Hall from Martin Carey, brother of ex-Gov. Hugh L. Carey, spent millions to restore the estate with its original gilt ceilings, a music room lined with intricate wood screens and a huge marble stairway. But now Pall, which used Winfield as a corporate retreat, is trying to retire its 99-year lease.
A 158-acred Muttontown estate owned by George S. Brewster is a recent rescue effprt. The Hoffman Foundation, set up by Maximillian Edwin Woffman , a foreign-car importer, and his wife Marion, bought it in 1995 from the Resolution Trust Company, which took it over from its former owner, Robert Meyer, who went bankrupt. The foundation plans to maintain the site as a preserve, a wildlife museum and an educational center.
The house will take five years to restore, beginning with the replacement of 99 windows with the original antique glass. The foundation, which bought the mansion, the farm complex and 158 acres for $8.1 million, won the mansion in an auction, triumphing over a number of builders.
Readaptations, although widely applauded as ways to save estates from unsympathetic development, sometimes run afoul of the community. Most estates exist in incorporated villages that are zoned for residential use, and communities are fearful of activity that is anything but residential.
Mayor Thomas R. Suozzi of Glen Cove said he was aware of the difficulty in reusing estates and was trying to encourage such projects for several estates in Glen Cove, including the modernization of Winfield.
"The challenge of these estates is to find a creative use for them that will preserve their historic integrity, generate the funds necessary to keep them going, while at the same time satisfy their neighbors, who don't want their quality of life sacrificed," Mr. Suozzi said.
Some neighbors of Oheka contended that the catering business attracted too much traffic and noise to their streets. Mr. Melius, who is leasing the building from a Japanese company, is asking the town to give the estate the status of a Special Historic Overlay District. The Huntington Town Board approved that classification last year, after the town had rejected Mr. Melius's request for a variance.
If Mr. Melius succeeds under the new ordinance, he could proceed with his plan for a luxury spa. The application includes 19 self-imposed restrictions, including 8 traffic-related conditions, that he worked out with the Cold Spring Hills Civic Association.
Banfi, too, made an appeal, to the Old Brookville Zoning Board for reclassification when it changed Rynwood to offices in 1979.The request met with little resistance, said Robert Whiting, estate and vineyard manager of the 127-acre property.
That experience may suggest that Long Island communities are becoming more aggressive in preserving history and making the zoning adjustments to do so.
Heritage tourism is an increasingly profitable part of the travel industry, according to the Travel Industry Association, which says visitors to historic sites spent an average of $688 last year, compared with $425 for all other types of travelers in the United States.
Towns are adding legislation to preserve landmarks. About 25 of the 99 incorporated villages have ordinances to foster preservation of their historic sites. A property-tax law passed in June could increase that number.
"At present, when you improve your property you are assessed at a higher tax rate," Kathie Ridley, a lawyer for the Preservation League of New York State, said. "This acts as a disincentive to preservation."
The new law provides a property-tax exemption to owners of historic homes who preserve the historic characters of their properties. It allows individuals to defer their tax increases for five years and then pay the increases at yearly 20 percent installments for the next five years.
"This new bill," Ms. Ridley said, "is an enabler. It enables individuals to make use of these tax advantages, which is good for everyone in the community. It will add to the tax revenues of the towns and help historic homeowners afford the improvements necessary to preserve these landmarks."
 
Many Preserved Estates Find Uses in Glen Cove
 The following is a partial listing of mansions in Glen Cove:
Killenworth -- Constructed circa 1912 by the architectural firm of Trowbridge and Ackerman for George du Pont Pratt, son of the Standard Oil magnate Charles Pratt; now owned and used by the Russian Mission to the United Nations.
 Elsinor -- Built before 1873, it was the home of Samuel Latham Mitchill Barlow, a wealthy railroad lawyer and art collector. The estate was acquired by E. R. Ladew, owner of the Ladew Leather Belting factory in Glen Cove in the early 1900's.
The Manor -- Constructed in 1910, it was the estate of John and Ruth Pratt and designed by Charles Adam Platt; it is now the Harrison Conference Center.
Pembroke -- Built by Joseph Raphael Delamar, who made millions in gold and silver mining. After Delamar's death in 1918, it was acquired by Marcus Loew, operator of a national chain of movie theaters and one of the founders of MGM Studios.
Cobble Court -- Constructed in 1927 for Louis and Kate Luckenbach. It has a commanding view of Long Island Sound. It is privately owned.
Poplar Hill -- Built in 1917 for Frederick B. Pratt, son of Charles Pratt; designed by William and Jeffery Platt, son of Charles Platt. It is now the Glengariff Nursing Home.
Webb Institute -- Constructed in 1912 for Herbert L. Pratt by the architect James Brite and the landscape architect James Leal Greenleaf. It is now owned by the Webb Institute for Naval Architecture.
Powell House -- Built in 1946 for Francis and Florence Pratt Powell. It is still privately owned.
Bucknall House -- Constructed in the late 19th century for H. W. J. Bucknall.

HEADLINE: Long Island Q&A: Gerard T. Breitner;
Setting the Right Course for Retirement

BYLINE: By SUSAN KONIG 

 BODY:
"AMERICANS have fallen in love with mutual funds, but beware," cautioned Gerard T. Breitner, president of Excomp Asset Management, a Manhattan-based financial planning concern that uses mutual funds exclusively to create investment portfolios.
Over the past five years, Mr. Breitner said, thousands of mutual funds have come to the marketplace, giving investors much more choice. Yet, selecting from all of these funds can be confusing, he cautioned, and investors need to know what is in these funds, and if there are hidden fees, to avoid investment disasters. 
 Mr. Breitner founded Excomp in 1982. The company currently oversees $60 million in client assets. He is also the host of "The Mutual Fund Report," a four-year-old radio show that airs Mondays at 7 P.M. on Long Island's WGBB (1240 AM), where he interviews top mutual fund managers and answers listener questions live on the air.
Mr. Breitner has worked in the financial services industry since 1974. He earned a bachelor's degree from St. John's University and a master's in financial services from the American College. He is a certified financial planner, a chartered financial consultant and a member of the Estate Planning Council of New York.
He and his wife, JoAnn, live in Rockville Centre. They have one daughter.
Q. You say the mutual fund industry is booming partly because people aren't prepared for retirement?
A. There are some major changes happening in our society today. Baby boomers are shifting from being consumers to being savers and investors. I think they hear the footsteps of retirement off on the horizon, and it's creating a dramatic change in the way they spend their money. Therefore, there's a tremendous flow of money into mutual funds, and a slow-down in the shopping binges they went on in the 1970's and 80's, and the real-estate explosion that occurred when they bought their homes.
However, there have been two studies -- one by Fidelity Funds, the other by Scudder -- which say that most baby boomers' goals for retirement are on a collision course with what they're actually saving and investing. They view retirement as playing on the golf course, spending time with the grandchildren, living half the year in Florida and half the year here. But saving for retirement is something you've got to do all along.
Q. Should people start saving for retirement as soon as they enter the work force?
A. Yes. One of the biggest secrets to a successful retirement is to start saving early. Another is to invest well. But saving early can even make up for investment mistakes.
Q. Is this a realistic expectation when people are faced with high living expenses, caring for children and elderly parents, etc.?
A. There are lots of temptations not to save-- putting the kids through college, keeping up with the Joneses, etc., and I don't pretend to have the answer for each individual case. But I think people need to pay themselves first. They need a strategy. They need to make sure they're taking care of their 401k plans and saving a little on top of that. If you want to spend the rest, then that's O.K. But pay yourself first.
Q. You say the notion of retirement has changed dramatically from just a generation ago?
A. Most people are going to spend a third of their life in retirement. We used to view this as sitting in our rocking chairs. Now, people consider retirement a very active part of life, a transitional phase where they've got more time to do the things they like. And that takes money. It's funny; I have clients in their early 80's who still play singles tennis. I don't ever remember seeing anything like that before.
Q. How does one go about creating a portfolio for a comfortable retirement?
A. You need to set specific goals and have a specific plan. It's not just a question of saving; you need to know what you're saving for and whether you're accumulating enough. You need checks and balances to know where you're going. People can do this on their own. More often than not, though, I think you need help from someone who can be objective, a professional who knows how to deal with taxes, inflation, etc.
Q. Are you a proponent of asset allocation?
A. Asset allocation and diversification are wonderful tools to help reduce the risk of investing. There are 8,000 mutual funds out there. Sometimes, people own 10 or 12 funds and think they are diversified when, in fact, a lot of the funds own some of the same kinds of holdings. You really need to what kinds of things are in the funds and who the manager is. Have an eyeball-to-eyeball meeting with the manager, see if he or she is focused on and passionate about what they do. Since a lot of funds are similar, statistically, you're likely to do better with a fund manager who loves what he is doing.
Q. What advice do you have for investors trying to select mutual funds?
A. You have to be wary of what I call "rear-view mirror investing." If you want to drive to a particular destination and you only look in the rear-view mirror, you're not going to have much success. And, I think using past performance as the main tool to make your investment decisions is just as futile.
It's important to take a forward perspective. Look at what's happening in the economy, make an assessment as to what Alan Greenspan and the Federal Reserve might be doing. Then ask yourself, "What kinds of funds do I want to own based on what's happening in the economy in the next 6 to 12 months?"
Q. Is investing in mutual funds -- or the stock market in general -- too risky for some people?
A. The bigger risk is not being invested, particularly for the long-term. I consider 65-year-olds as still having a long-term horizon, based on the fact that their life expectancy is probably another 20 to 25 years. The biggest risk is being too conservative, because inflation really annihilates conservative investments like CD's and bonds.
Q. You're somewhat skeptical of major mutual fund families. Why?
A. There are 8,000 mutual funds, and a good fund family might have 60 or 80 choices. If you restrict yourself to one particular fund, you're really only using about 1 percent of the choices that are available to you. And, you're not choosing from the best 1 percent; you're choosing from the 1 percent that has a particular brand or fund name on it. Each fund has a couple of good choices. The rest become mediocre, and some are downright "dogs." So, to the extent that you're moving around within one particular fund family, you're going to wind up with mediocre performance in your portfolio.
Q. Why do you prefer mutual funds over high-performing individual stocks?
A. There are a number of reasons. Funds today allow you to diversify more effectively than individual stocks, international funds and real-estate securities. Secondly, and equally as important, a mutual fund, being broad-based and diversified, will tend to be less volatile and risky than individual stocks or bonds. Since the market's been good, people are kind of lulled into a sense that there's no risk involved in being an investor. But, we've seen much more volatility in 1997 than in the two years previous. We stress to our clients that they need to have a specific strategy so that, when periods of volatility and down markets occur, they won't lose sight of the long-term picture, panic and make some bad investment decisions.
And, it's not just investors who panic -- the professionals can too -- which is why it's important to have a definitive strategy from the very start.
Q. What strategy do you recommend?
A. We take a three-pronged approach: we use a buy and hold strategy, a market-timing strategy and a sector rotation strategy, which means investing in different sectors of the market, i.e., utilities, technology, bonds, etc. We combine them to try and get the benefits of each without the down sides.
Q. You don't put a lot of client investments into bonds. Why?
A. I look at portfolios as being like daisies. The core funds -- the funds you want to hold for three to five years -- are the center of the daisy. The "petals" are other groups of funds you're using to try and add some performance over the short-term -- to add some zip in good markets and some stability in bad ones. I see bonds as being out on the petals, rather than in the core, because I believe they have as much risk as stocks but nowhere near as much of the upside.
Q. Why do you prefer "no-load" funds?
A. The world is global today. It's moving very fast. Commissions kind of stick people's feet in concrete; they prevent them from being proactive with their portfolios. No-load funds allow you to move about fairly freely.
Q. What are the greatest concerns of your clients?
A. Clients don't have a good sense of what risk is all about. We've done studies on human behavior and investing, and most people aren't necessarily rational about their portfolios from a risk standpoint.
If people are given a choice between something that's a sure gain or a chance to win more, overwhelmingly, they choose the sure gain. But, when given a choice between paying a traffic fine or gambling on being assessed a much greater fine, they usually take the chance of paying the higher fine. Risk aversion seems to apply only in the gain dimension; in the loss dimension, most people aren't risk-takers. Statistically, people view losses as being 2 to 2 1/2 times more painful than gains are pleasurable.
Investing isn't necessarily trying to get the greatest of gains. I think it's about taking the least amount of risk, while trying to have your portfolio and investments help you achieve your financial goals. They need a strategy to figure out the least amount of risk they can take for their plan to be effective.

HEADLINE: Off-Year Elections Handicap Challengers

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
TAD SCHARFENBERG, Democratic candidate for Suffolk County District Attorney, called a news conference this month to outline his 10-point plan to change the prosecutor's office.
Mr. Scharfenberg detailed his plan and attacked the incumbent, James M. Catterson Jr., a Republican, as an out-of-control bully so fearsome that would-be contributors to Mr. Scharfenberg's campaign had been scared off. "He is the most despised elected official in county history because of his abuses of power," Mr. Scharfenberg said. 
 Two reporters, and no cameras, were on hand. Little news resulted.
As a lackluster campaign season winds up, candidates for Long Island offices, including Nassau County Executive and the District Attorneys in Suffolk and Nassau, are again resigned to paying for advertising on television and radio and in print for a yawning public in an off-year election.
Once again candidates who spend the most are making their impression, while those with limited resources struggle to avoid virtual anonymity or the ignominy of having their image cast in negative advertising.
In the top Nassau race County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta, a Republican, has been expecting to raise more than $3 million in his campaign for a third term. The Democratic challenger, Supervisor Lewis J. Yevoli of Oyster Bay, said he hoped to raise $225,000.
By the end of last month Mr. Gulotta had spent more than $700,000 on television advertising. The frequency of his ads has picked up as the election nears. "For every one I have," Mr. Yevoli said, "he will have 30."
In one ad on cable television in Nassau and on broadcast television in New York City, Mr. Gulotta speaks about his record as a tax cutter. "Working together," he says, "we've cut and frozen general county property taxes for five years in a row. This year we are cutting taxes again."
Mr. Yevoli pointed out that the ad did not mention questions raised this month by State Comptroller H. Carl McCall about $100 million in revenues in Mr. Gulotta's proposed $2 billion budget for next year. The projection, which enabled Mr. Gulotta to propose a small property-tax cut for 1998, includes $16 million for the county's anticipated share from a yet-to-be approved nationwide settlement in the tobacco case.
The ad also does not mention that in 1991, in a period of fiscal crisis, Mr. Gulotta proposed a 25 percent property-tax increase for 1992.
Mr. Yevoli said an attack on Mr. Gulotta's budgetary tomfoolery was a cornerstone of his campaign. He said the county had a current budget deficit of up to $50 million that would grow larger next year under Mr. Gulotta's proposal.
He also said Mr. Gulotta should be blamed for an increase in county debt from $1.1 billion to $2.5 billion during his years in office. "There is nothing that has happened in that 10-year period that can justify a more than doubling of county debt, nothing," said Mr. Yevoli. But he said that without additional advertising it was "difficult to get people to focus on something like the Nassau County budget and county debt when they are struggling to survive and have mortgages to pay."
Mr. Yevoli said he was swamped by Mr. Gulotta's advertising. "No matter when you turn the television on," he said, "there's a Gulotta commercial. You can't go down a street in Nassau without seeing a Gulotta sign. Every Nassau County bus has a Gulotta sign on it, every rail trestle. It's like Big Brother."
"It's not exactly a level playing field. It's gotten to the point where you have to say, 'Hey, come on, that's not what it's all about.' "
Mr. Gulotta's campaign said Mr. Yevoli was complaining because he was being outmatched by a better candidate. "The real reason Tom Gulotta's opponent is having a tough time running for county executive is that Tom Gulotta is a widely popular county executive who has cut taxes, cut crime and created jobs," said the campaign director, Michael E. Marr.
Mr. Gulotta is also the candidate of one of the most powerful Republican organizations in the country, and is running in a county where Republicans hold a 3-to-2 enrollment advantage among registered voters.
One ad was doing more than giving Mr. Yevoli the name and face recognition that he had gained by shaking an estimated 40,000 hands at railroad stations, shopping centers and local events. Entitled "Cheesy" by Mr. Gulotta's campaign, the ad depicts Mr. Yevoli as a tax raiser and big spender of tax money for questionable purposes and his own enrichment.
"Lew Yevoli knows exactly what to do with your money," the narrator says. "Spend it."
The ad says Mr. Yevoli "voted to spend $175,000 on a cheese museum," voted 66 times to raise his own pay, voted 25 times to raise taxes and "even voted for the largest tax increase in New York history."
The presentation features a photograph of Mr. Yevoli that makes him appear ratty and disreputable. "Cheese museums, big pay raises, huge tax increase, that's Lew Yevoli," the narrator ends.
The ad offers no time frame and does not make clear that Mr. Yevoli cast his vote for a cheese museum in Rome, upstate, in 1988, when Mr. Yevoli was an assemblyman. The museum was a so-called member item that Assembly members routinely approve.
Nearly all the votes that the ad refers to were made when Mr. Yevoli was in the Assembly. The votes he was said to have cast for tax increases and higher salaries could not be confirmed.
Another Gulotta ad based on "Jeopardy" warns, "Lew Yevoli puts Nassau's taxpayers in jeopardy," and shows a photograph of Mr. Yevoli.
Experts in political advertising say negative ads use rivals' photos to create unpleasant associations.
Mr. Yevoli's more limited ad campaign began in the summer with a scattering of ads on cable television on the Island and on broadcast stations in New York City. It focused on the disparity between financing for the two campaigns.
"Don't let Tom Gulotta and the G.O.P. bosses buy this election," it said.
Mr. Yevoli said last week that Mr. Gulotta's campaign had been enriched by contributions from "anyone who has done work for the county," including consultants and contractors, adding, "There is also not a county commissioner who has not made a contribution."
"The man has $3 million to spend on the election," Mr. Yevoli said. "It's obscene. What it says is that you can't even consider running for the highest office in this county unless you have a million bucks to spend."
The executive director of Common Cause in New York State, Rachel Leon, said such disparities between incumbents and challengers were typical. "It's all too familiar," Ms. Leon said. "It's what we are seeing at the state and national level, this incredible incumbent advantage. It is really unfortunate that it comes down to how much money you have."
Ms. Leon said the need for large sums to challenge incumbents meant that challengers faced "an uphill battle unless they are bought out by special interests or are independently wealthy."
In Suffolk, Mr. Scharfenberg started a negative campaign last week that urged voters to "end the Catterson reign of terror."
"I'm putting all my money into radio and TV," he said.
But with hopes of raising a total of $50,000 for his campaign, Mr. Scharfenberg has little to spend.
Mr. Catterson, a widely recognized figure, is running with all the advantages that a Republican incumbent enjoys in a heavily Republican county.
The Suffolk Republican Committee, which is financing the campaign, expects to spend more than $300,000 on the effort, according to a spokesman, Alan F. Eysen. "The party has always strongly supported him," Mr. Eysen said. "We would be foolish not to give all our support to the person at the top of the ticket."
In the absence of stiff competition, Mr. Catterson's ads have ignored the challenger's allegations of abuse and concentrated on portraying Mr. Catterson as a proven crime fighter.
"District Attorney James Catterson," says a 30-second ad that shows a close-up of Mr. Catterson on the job. "Tough. Honest. Doing the job of fighting drugs and keeping criminals behind bars."
Mr. Scharfenberg's ad paints a different picture. "First he said that he would not prosecute every man who belts his wife across the face," says the ad, showing an unflattering photo of Mr. Catterson and referring to a comment that he made in his campaign four years ago.
The ad also says Mr. Catterson "threatened to haul county officials in front of a grand jury if they didn't end the car-lease scandal investigation." That refers in part to allegations by four former and current county officials that Mr. Catterson had threatened them with subpoenas. Mr. Catterson has denied those contentions.
The ad suggests that the District Attorney should investigate Mr. Catterson. "The problem is he is the district attorney," it continues, showing another unflattering photo of Mr. Catterson.
The ad cuts to a photo of Mr. Scharfenberg and ends: "End the Catterson reign of terror by electing Tad Scharfenberg Suffolk D.A."
Mr. Scharfenberg's campaign began running a radio ad last week with virtually the same text. "These ads are hard hitting and they are the truth," he said. "And with Catterson the truth is enough."
The prosecutor's race in Nassau has been mild by comparison, in fact nearly invisible. The Democratic challenger, Jon S. Kaiman, a defense lawyer, said he planned no radio or television ads.
"It's a low-finance campaign," Mr. Kaiman said. "Basically it's a grass-roots effort. We're going door to door and to train stations. It's not a year when people are particularly interested in politics. The economy is good. Crime is down. People are not angry."
The incumbent, Denis Dillon, a Republican, plans to spend $25,000 on radio and television ads. The ads depict a highly professional prosecutor whose office has one of the highest conviction rates in the country. There is no reference to Mr. Kaiman.
Mr. Dillon is seeking a seventh term.
Mr. Kaiman, who said he would raise far less than $25,000, added that he appreciated the restraint that Mr. Dillon had shown in his spending on advertising. "At least," Mr. Kaiman said, "to his credit he is not going to spend a million to try to shape some image just for the sake of it."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Tad Sharfenberg, a Democrat, left, is opposing James M. Catterson Jr., Suffolk County District Attorney, Republican. (Steve Berman for The New York Times)(pg. 6)
