HEADLINE: Will Huskies Embrace Big Time Football?

BYLINE: By JACK CAVANAUGH 

 BODY:
CAN a state that has embraced the University of Connecticut's successful men's and women's basketball teams with a passion develop a similar mania for a bigtime football team on a campus football crowds of 10,000 are a struggle?
It will be at least a few years before that can be determined. But barring unexpected opposition from the state legislature, the university appears on the verge of building a new football stadium on the Storrs campus that will accommodate a Husky team that will, by 2003, be playing the likes of Miami and Syracuse as a full-fledged member of the Big East football conference. 
 With the backing of Gov. John G. Rowland, the university's trustees, by a vote of 16 to 1, has approved an upgrade of the football program from I-AA to I-A and recommended that a 35,000-seat stadium be built on campus and not in Hartford, as the House Speaker Thomas Ritter and some others had suggested. Mr. Rowland has said he would call for a one-day special session of the legislature in November to authorize bonding for the stadium, which is expected to cost about $106 million. If that is approved, as expected, construction would begin next year and the stadium would be ready for play by the start of the 2000 season.
Why a move to bigtime college football by a school where the sport traditionally has stirred little interest and has cost the university more than $2 million a year in losses? Certainly it is not because of a winning tradition; UConn football has had only two winning seasons in the last six years. And it is not because of larger crowds at the 16,200-seat Memorial Stadium, which has been filled to capacity only once in 35 years.
Primarily, UConn is making the move to Division I-A (the highest level of collegiate football) to protect the Division I-A status of its basketball teams. A secondary reason appears to be to attract more national attention to the university, something that basketball accomplished to an extraordinary degree in the 1990's.
"There is a reconstructuring of the National Collegiate Athletic Association currently going on," said the university president, Philip E. Austin, in an interview, "and in order to continue playing in the Big East Conference in basketball, we may have to also play at the top level in football. And the UConn basketball program must be protected." Lew Perkins, the university's athletic director since 1990, has been hinting for years that basketball's status might be jeoparized if football were not upgraded. Mr. Perkins, who previously was the athletic director at two Division I-A schools, Maryland and Wichita State, has warned that schools in some major sports conferences, like the Big East, might form a "super tier" exclusive of the N.C.A.A. If that happened, Mr. Perkins has said, schools that are Division I-A in only one major sport, as is UConn, could be left out.
"All kinds of things can happen," he said. "Whoever would have thought that the Southwest Conference, one of the strongest in the country, would have gone out of business and that Brigham Young University would win a national championship and then find itself without a conference?"
Not everyone shares Mr. Perkins or Dr. Austin's fears that a football upgrade is needed. "The argument that if we don't go Division I-A in football we will be kicked out of the Big East in basketball is bogus," said Allen M. Ward, a professor emeritus of history at the university.
Apparently Villanova University shares Dr. Ward's sentiments. Like UConn, Villanova is a member of the Big East basketball conference but in football plays in the I-AA Atlantic 10 Conference. Also like UConn Villanova was invited to join the Big East football conference by Dec. 31 at the latest. But the school, a major football power before it de-emphasized the sport in the 1950's, announced earlier this month that it had declined the invitation. Its Wildcats were unbeaten through the first six games of this season and ranked No. 1 in the latest poll of Division I-AA football teams.
What makes the UConn move all the more surprising to some observers is the expense. During at least the first few years of its existence in I-A, the program would cost approximately $2 million more than the current $2.2 million-a-year football losses, according to a projection by Roy Kramer, the commissioner of the Southeastern Conference who, at the university's request, drew up an implementation plan for the upgrade.
The increased cost is attributable to an additional 22 football scholarships (from the current 63 to 85), the addition of three more coaches and a variety of support services, including improved practice fields and weight rooms. But according to the Kramer report, the costs can then be expected to decline each year and that UConn, "with some degree of success on the field, can develop adequate revenue streams within 8 to 10 years to cover the overall cost of a Division I-A program."
Dr. Austin conceded that the UConn football program would continue to lose money, at a rate of about $2 million a year in his estimation, after it moves up to Division I-A. "But after five or six years, we believe that we would show a profit," he said.
And in the long run, it can sometimes cost a school less to fund a Division I-A football team than one at the Division I-AA level. Temple University, for example, has managed to avoid losing money on football in recent years, according to the athletic director, Dave O'Brien, even though the Owls have not posted a winning record since 1990 and have been averaging less than 10,000 people at home games, all of which are played off campus at Veterans Stadium or at Franklin Field in Philadelphia.
"We still break even -- even with all of those empty seats -- because of revenue sharing from the Big East and money from the N.C.A.A., along with money from television and corporate sponsors," Mr. O'Brien said.
But Temple has a long tradition in Division I-A football, marked by many successful seasons in years gone by.
Invariably, schools moving up to Division I-A have been extremely successful on the field in Division I-AA, have had strong followings and already have stadiums that seat at least 30,000, the minimum capacity for a Division I-A school.
For example, Marshall University of Huntington, W. Va., which was elevated to I-A this year, averaged 22,000 spectators last season when it won its second Division I-AA national championship (the first was in 1992). Marshall also had finished as runnerup in 1987, 1991, 1993 and 1995. Connecticut, by comparison, has never qualified for the national playoffs.
That raises the question of whether a Division-I UConn can really draw spectators to Storrs, 22 miles east of Hartford and a two-hour drive from lower Fairfield County. Even Dr. Austin conceded that "football has not been very big historically in New England." And Mr. Perkins, the athletic director, noted that the state is not renown as an incubator of football talent. "We definitely would have to recruit all over the country," Mr. Perkins said.
The UConn athletic department has had strong support for the move to I-A from Lewis Rome, a prominent alumnus, former state legislator and chairman of the university's board of trustees when that body recommended the upgraded. And Harry Hartley, Mr. Austin's predecessor as the university president and an ardent supporter of UConn varsity sports programs, also favored the upgrade.
Dr. Austin acknowledges the opposition of some, including some faculty members, within the UConn community. "Some academic purists do not find the argument that we upgrade to Division I-A in football persuasive," he said. But he said he felt that, in addition to generating "more excitment" among students and alumni, the elevation to Division I-A would create more interest in the university around the country.
"That has happened with basketball, and I'm sure football would make us even better known," Dr. Hartley said. "We would be able to attract the very best in students."
But opposition at Storrs remains strong. "We go into this with a lot of serious handicaps," said Peter Barth, a professor of economics who previously taught at Ohio State, which represents the quintessence of big-time collegiate football.
"First, the university has no football tradition. Second, we've never gone to a national tournament in the sport. Third, it will be a very hard sell to fans, and, fourth, it is not a good business proposal and could be a drag on the entire athletic program. Costs are going to rise substantially, and there could be a lot of losing seasons, particularly at the start."
Professor Barth and some other faculty members also expressed fears that standards might be lowered in order to field a competitive Division I-A football team.
"A critical question here is whether you're going to protect academic programs and not lower standards for football players," said Bruce M. Stave, the chairman of the university's history department. "It's imperative that we not adopt a 'football culture' that could lead to a way of life that we're not proud of. It has to be a clean program and one that we constantly keep an eye on. People have to realize that, above all, this is an academic institution."
Allan Ward, the history professor, said he felt that if a vote were taken among UConn faculty members on the move to Division I-A, "I think they'd vote against it."
"I think the idea is dreadful, and that we have a situation here where the tail is wagging the dog," Dr. Ward said. "By moving into big-time football, you focus the wrong kind of attention on the university and you attract people to the school for the wrong reason. And spending more and more money on football is hard to justify when we've had cutbacks in faculty."
Jason Jakubowski, the editor of the Daily Campus, the student newspaper, said he thought that most students favored the move to Division I-A. "I know some people have reservations about it," said Mr. Jakubowski, a junior from New Britain. "But I think that the national exposure will benefit the university. More quality students will apply for admission. And I don't think the university will allow standards to be lowered for football players."

LENGTH: 1505 words

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/Red Bank, N.J.;
Reborn Downtown, Century-Old Homes

BYLINE: By JANICE FIORAVANTE 

 BODY:
BETTY THOMPSON is a member of Red Bank's Borough Council, the charter school committee and the school superintendent's partnership committee. "This is a positive, engagement-type community," she said.
Red Bank hugs the Navesink River, separating it from Middletown. Its success in revitalizing its downtown business district in the last seven years has encouraged residents to tackle new challenges. 
 "If you present an idea here that has any merit and adequate advocacy, Mayor McKenna and the council will put 100 percent support behind it," said Tracy Challenger, executive director of RiverCenter, a public-private business alliance that has been instrumental in the Monmouth County town's rebirth.
In January 1994, there were 45 vacancies on the main shopping avenue, Broad Street. "Today, there are three," Ms. Challenger said. Rents have climbed to $14 to $20 a square foot a year from $8 to $10 five years ago.
The downtown has several small districts within a five-block area, Ms. Challenger said, including an antiques district; an arts corridor with galleries and theaters; waterfront parks and hotels, and shopping, restaurants and "little Wall Street," which includes branch offices of Merrill Lynch, Dean Witter and Fahnestock now and will add Smith Barney in January.
Red Bankers are now focusing on challenges like education. "Over the past four to five years, Red Bank schools have not kept pace with the retail renaissance," said J. Michael Rush, Superintendent of Schools. Dr. Rush took over as head of schools in January to address declining test scores.
Red Bank Regional High School has students from Little Silver and Shrewsbury as well as Red Bank, but the former towns' eighth-grade students score in the 90th to 95th percentile in statewide tests, while Red Bank's scores are in the 50th percentile.
The Red Bank school district has classes from pre-kindergarten through eighth grade in two schools. The primary school goes from pre-kindergarten through the third grade and the middle school from the fourth through eighth grades. Of the fewer than 900 students who attend, 60 percent are black, 15 percent Hispanic and the rest white or Asian.
"It's only October and parents are already reporting dramatic changes in attitude and discipline since Dr. Rush has taken over," Mayor Edward J. McKenna Jr. said. "His new team of administrators and new principals for each school have made even the charter school committee want to wait and see what happens with the changes he's implementing."
Dr. Rush has started several programs, including teacher retraining, an adopt-a-class partnership with business and afterschool programs to improve basic skills for grades one to six. "I want business owners to come and talk to students about economic empowerment," he said.
Students here are also served by the St. James elementary school and Red Bank Catholic High. St. James enrolls 560 students in pre-kindergarten to grade eight, with tuition at $2,200 a year. Red Bank Catholic High, with 800 students, costs $4,695 a year. Of last year's graduates, 83 percent went to four-year and 15 percent to two-year colleges. "Our parochial schools draw from 20 communities," said Maureen Hintelmann, director of admissions at the high school and principal of the elementary school. "Of its 560 students, fewer than 150 are from Red Bank."
OF Red Bank Regional High School's 1,050 students, 40 percent come from Red Bank. "We're a magnet school for performing arts and receive students from about 18 other districts," said the principal, Robert Nogueira. Its class of 1997 included 202 graduates, 88 percent of whom went on to college. The performing arts program has classes in dance, drama, creative writing, voice, piano, commercial art and photography.
Jeffrey MacPherson, a real estate agent and lifelong resident of Red Bank, said he was not surprised at how many people come back to Red Bank after college to buy a home and to start a career, partly because of the downtown's revival.
"House prices range from $60,000 for a three-bedroom, one-and-a-half-bath Colonial in town to $1 million for a four-bedroom house on the river," said Mr. MacPherson, who is with Murphy Realty/Better Homes & Gardens. "Most of our houses are 100-year-old three-to-four bedroom, one-family Victorians and Colonials." Only 8 percent of the homes are multifamily, with most of those two-family.
The condominium/town-house developments are renovations and conversions of high-rise apartment houses on the riverbank or garden apartments. "However, Tower Hill is an example of relatively new building with a Mediterrean-type theme from the 1980's containing 60 two- and three- bedroom multilevel condo units with fireplaces," Mr. MacPherson said. There are no co-op apartments.
An early conversion project, The Bluffs on the River, started out as historic Victorian houses on Front Street, according to Patricia Small, a broker at the William H. Hintelmann agency. "These condos are very special, with such architectural features as wooden floors and mouldings, cathedral ceilings and brickwork and a widow's walk, as well as panoramic views of the Navesink," she said. The two- , three- and four-bedroom units range from $375,000 to more than $500,000.
Another former apartment house on the river is now a retirement community called the Navesink House.
"It's an extended-care facility where a one-bedroom apartment goes for $80,000 and long-term care is available on the premises," Mr. MacPherson said. "It's gorgeous, with a great banquet hall, and was renovated 10 years ago."
He added, "There's an influx of out-of-towners, college students and older families that has meant a very competitive rental market." Monmouth University is 15 minutes away.
Both Mr. MacPherson and Geoff Brothers of Brothers Commercial Realty described the mixed-use buildings downtown as popular among renters. Downtown buildings tend to have retail space on the ground floor, office space on the second and residential rentals on the third. "People like to be right downtown -- there's a vibrancy and community feeling," Mr. Brothers said.
Deborah Marks was born and raised in Red Bank and came back after four years away to live and start her own business, DD Business Forms. "It's been exciting to be here and see the changes," she said. "And it's continuing." She cited a microbrewery based in Princeton called Triumph that is gutting a storage building in Red Bank and a customer of hers who just opened a new theater, the Royale.
But many other residents explain their love of Red Bank by starting with, "I came from New York City. . . ."
Ara Hovnanian said that Red Bank attracted New Yorkers because of "its suburban beauty while being a little walking downtown city." Mr. Hovnanian is president of K. Hovnanian Enterprises Inc., the largest homebuilder in the state, with headquarters on the Navesink River. "And while we've been located here for 20 years, none of our building goes on here," he said. "There is virtually no land in Red Bank to build on -- the just-closed Woolworth's is about the biggest available space."
MS. MARKS described Red Bank as a city without the city. "Ten minutes away is the closest beach, Sea Bright, and there are beautiful parks along the river," he said. The 2.3-acre Marine Park is the site of RiverFest, a three-day jazz, blues and food festival every June and one of many special events that help bring 500,000 visitors to town each year.
Perhaps jazz and Red Bank are inevitable. Count Basie was born and raised here -- as William James Basie at 229 Mechanics Street. Basie remembered his hometown when he recorded the "Red Bank Boogie." He was honored after his death in 1984 with the renaming of the old Carlton Theater, now the 1,400-seat Count Basie Theater. The New Jersey Symphony as well as dance and theater groups and popular performers like Steve Winwood perform there.
The theater, the park festival and the renewed downtown all draw visitors, but Red Bank's riverfront location has been its ticket to growth since the 1600's. Farmers had access to New York markets via sloops and schooners, with steamboats helping to bring residents and commerce between the 1830's and 1850's. By the 1860's, the Raritan and Delaware Bay Railroad helped further expansion, sparking the town's industrial boom.
The Galleria, a minimall in an old factory building, includes one of the town's first coffeehouses, The House of Coffee, as well as a dance studio called Steppin' Out and such stores as Makin' Good Scents, with scented candles, oils and potpourri, and restaurants like 2 Senza, serving Italian food and wines.
Evening entertainment, like jazz at the Downtown Cafe or comedy shows at the Internet Cafe, in addition to the theaters, restaurants and shops make Red Bank a destination for people in the region. "People drive a half hour to come here for entertainment," Ms. Challenger said. "It's fun to be part of the rebirth," Mrs. Thompson. added

ROLL 'EM: Kevin Smith, a local independent filmmaker, not only shot his most recent movie, "Chasing Amy," in Red Bank; his production company, View Eskew, is on Broad Street. Now Mr. Smith is setting up his own film institute to help students make movies. He is following in the tradition of Daniel B. Dorn, who in the 1920's made films for Fox Movietone News and started his own production company in Red Bank. Red Bank has been a mecca for photographers, among them Charles Foxwell and Andrew Coleman, whose prints from the early 1900's of the town and its populace are owned by Daniel W. Dorn Jr., grandson of Daniel B. and owner of Dorn's photoshop in Red Bank. The book "Images of America: Red Bank" by Randall Gabrielan tells its story through such photos.

HEADLINE: A 'New' Kennedy Airport Takes Wing

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
THE INTERNATIONAL ARRIVALS BUILDING, heart of the Terminal City complex at John F. Kennedy International Airport, whose swooping entry arch ushered New York into the jet age, is about to turn 40. And a special event is planned for its anniversary year.
It's going to be demolished.
Replacing it will be the $1.2 billion, 16-gate International Air Terminal, or Terminal 4, which is to be completed in 2001. Although a ceremonial groundbreaking is planned next month, the ground outside the old terminal has already been broken wide open, as crews dig utility trenches and sink foundations. The rhythmic pounding of pile drivers on the construction site is so loud that only the roar of the Concorde drowns them out. 
 Travelers will not have to wait three years, however, to find a thoroughly contemporary terminal at Kennedy Airport. The $435 million, 11-gate Terminal 1 is to open in seven months where the Eastern Airlines terminal stood. It is the first new passenger building in 27 years, since British Airways (then BOAC) opened Terminal 7.
The British Airways terminal itself is undergoing a $143 million renovation that began last month.
All told, some $2.7 billion will be invested at Kennedy Airport in the next five years, said the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, on top of $2.6 billion that has been spent since 1990. Much of the money to date has gone into realigned roadways and new utilities. Though vital, this is not as obvious as a new passenger terminal.
"One thing that is not too well understood is that J.F.K. is undergoing a complete reconstruction from the ground up," said Barry Abramowitz, general manager of Port Authority's aviation capital program. "At the end, we will have produced a brand-new Kennedy Airport."
It will certainly take that kind of effort to mitigate Kennedy's reputation among travelers as one of the least welcoming airports in the world. The sense of hopelessness deepened in 1990 when the ambitious plan known as J.F.K. 2000, which called for an enormous central terminal, was scuttled, leaving as its legacy a $21 million baggage-handling system known as the "tunnel to nowhere."
What has permitted the current wave of construction and renovation is an infusion of private investment, which the Port Authority said accounts for 47 percent of all capital spending at Kennedy between 1990 and 2002.
"The idea of privatization is catching on," said John A. Cavanagh, chief operating officer of Morse Diesel International, the construction manager for all three terminal projects, which are largely financed with private money.
Terminal 1 is being developed by a consortium of four foreign-flag carriers: Air France, Japan Airlines, Korean Air and Lufthansa German Airlines. Terminal 4 is being developed by Schiphol U.S.A., a subsidiary of the Dutch company that runs Schiphol, the Amsterdam airport; LCOR, a New York-based real estate concern that produced the master plan for the relocation of Amtrak's Penn Station operations into the General Post Office and the investment banking house of Lehman Brothers.
Like any privately owned commercial buildings, Terminals 1 and 4 will be competing aggressively for tenants; in this case, airlines.
While their developers emphasize differences, the buildings have numerous common elements. For example, shopping malls and food courts are the order of the day. Since international travelers have to arrive earlier than ever to clear security, they can spend hours at an airport. That is an attractive captive audience.
Both new terminals adhere to an understated esthetic that is gradually replacing the World's Fair variety of the original Terminal City, where architects outdid one another with eye-catching three-dimensional billboards. The new style -- call it Airfoil Modern -- is characterized by rooflines as gently bowed as the top of an aircraft's wing and silvery surfaces as smooth as a fuselage skin.
Both designs emphasize direct routes from check-in to boarding, via retail areas. Glass walls allow passengers to see the aircraft, orient themselves quickly and chart their paths without need of complex signage.
Even in its raw structural state, Terminal 1 is striking. Its check-in hall, almost long enough to fit three 747's head to tail, is covered by a canopy of curving, branching steel members 50 feet overhead. Check-in counters are clustered in islands, rather than being arrayed as a solid wall, lending a sense of permeability to the space.
William Nicholas Bodouva & Associates are the architects of Terminal 1. Terminal 4 was designed by TAMS Consultants, Skidmore, Owings & Merrill and Ove Arup & Partners. The Terminal 7 renovation is by Corgan Associates and Ove Arup.
British Airways is investing $100 million in the Terminal 7 renovation, financed through the sale of bonds by the New York City Industrial Development Agency, and the Port Authority is spending $43 million on related roadway work. Key features are expanded check-in and retail areas, new lounges and a new parking decks.
Other projects at Kennedy include a $46 million boomerang-shaped parking garage, with 1,430 short-term spaces, across from Terminal 1 and the Delta Airlines terminals. It is scheduled to be completed next May, in time for the opening of Terminal 1.
New roadways have been completed in front of the American Airlines terminals. Pedestrian islands are sheltered under aluminum canopies on tapered concrete columns. This covered network not only affords protection from the elements but also delineates a clear walkway to the buildings.
Most of the infrastructure has also been redone, said Charles G. Seliga, acting general manager of Kennedy. "But nobody sees it," he said. "It's underground." The utility systems and roadways were designed to handle 15 million passengers a year, Mr. Abramowitz said, and staggered under the demands of 31 million. The new systems are meant to serve 45 million passengers a year.
Four new cargo centers, ranging in cost from $16 million to $100 million, are being built around the airport by Korean Air, United Airlines, Northwest Airlines and Air Express International. Almost inconspicuously from the passengers' viewpoint, some 1.7 million tons of cargo, worth about $94 billion, passes through Kennedy each year.
All four cargo buildings were financed through the sale of bonds, totaling $202 million, by the Industrial Development Agency, administered by the New York City Economic Development Corporation.
"The Port Authority's attention has been focused on making air cargo grow at Newark," said Charles Millard, president of the corporation. "This has required the city to make sure air cargo gets the attention it deserves and has not received from the Port Authority at J.F.K."
Fighting words, to be sure, but merely the latest in a half century of tense relations between the City of New York, which owns the 4,930-acre property (one-third the size of Manhattan), and the Port Authority, which holds a long-term lease. In 1947, a financially strapped city government ceded control of Idlewild airfield to the authority, which was in a stronger position to develop it. The original 50-year lease would have expired this year but was extended to 2015.
At the dedication in 1948, Mayor William O'Dwyer happily contemplated the day when the city would regain control and he could "thank the Port Authority for the present of this finished airport."
Now, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is proposing a city-state authority that would take over Kennedy no later than 2015.
"The Mayor strongly believes that the city has been shortchanged for quite a long time," said Randy L. Levine, the Deputy Mayor for Economic Development. "The lease is unfair. We're in litigation. The airports have not been run the way they should be run. We could do a better job."
Robert E. Boyle, executive director of the authority, said in response: "Obviously the Port Authority disagrees with the Mayor on who is best suited to run the airports. As far as the lease goes, we are still ready, willing and able to sit down with the city and strike a new deal."
Complaints by New York City officials that the Port Authority favors Newark are as old as the O'Dwyer administration and as fresh as the opening last year of Newark's International Arrivals Facility and its monorail, which is eventually to be extended to the Northeast Corridor rail line.
But Mark O. Hatfield Jr., director of communications for the authority, said Newark was rebuilt first in part because it was older. He also noted that a new light-rail link between Kennedy and the Howard Beach subway station might be open in four years, about the time that the Newark connection is running. An elevated line from Kennedy along the median strip of the Van Wyck Expressway to the Jamaica rail and subway station may be finished in 2002.
The light-rail system will make a loop around the central terminal area, passing directly through Terminal 4, the International Air Terminal, which will be constructed over and around the rail line.
"We have the famous choo-choo train coming right into our building," exulted Hans Mohrmann, president and chief executive of Schiphol U.S.A.
Schiphol U.S.A. is a subsidiary of N. V. Luchthaven Schiphol, which developed, runs and manages the Amsterdam airport. It has a 40 percent interest in J.F.K. International Air Terminal, a limited liability company formed last year to develop Terminal 4.
A 40 percent interest is held by a subsidiary of LCOR, formerly Linpro, which has developed some 13 million square feet of office space, including the Federal building at 290 Broadway in lower Manhattan and the 101 Hudson Street tower in Jersey City. The other 20 percent is held by a subsidiary of Lehman Brothers Holdings.
The developers have subleased a 165-acre site from the Port Authority and taken over management of the arrivals hall and flanking departure gates, from which 50 international carriers operate. (The flanking structures were once formally designated the Foreign-Flag Airline Wing Buildings but the whole complex is now commonly called the International Arrivals Building.)
In the existing wings, check-in, ticketing, baggage handling, security and waiting areas are repeated every several hundred feet. "The I.A.B. is actually six smaller terminals, which is terribly inefficient," said Ted D. Kleiner, program director for redevelopment at Kennedy Airport.
WITH 1.5 million square feet of space, the new building will actually be slightly smaller than the existing structure. But the essential functions will be shared by the airlines, making for greater efficiency. Tenants that sign up for the longest leases, 10 to 15 years, will get preference in the allocation of check-in counters and boarding gates.
Beyond the check-in hall in the headhouse, as the main part of the terminal is called, will be a 1,000-foot-long shopping mall and food court, with design elements like a clock tower or topiary to conjure the neighborhoods and landmarks of New York.
The east concourse will have six gates and the west concourse 10 gates. The structure can be expanded incrementally to as many as 37 gates as the market demand warrants, said Kurt M. Eichler, executive vice president and principal of LCOR.
Construction is being financed through the sale of $934 million in bonds by the Port Authority, together with investment earnings of $125 million and developer equity of $15 million. In addition, the Port Authority is reinvesting $124 million of the terminal rental into the project.
"There were constraints in terms of amortization because of the underlying city lease," Mr. Eichler said. Bonds that are due to mature between the years 2017 and 2025 will be subject to a special mandatory redemption in 2015 if the city has not renewed the Port Authority's overall lease.
With the existing building in operation, construction will begin on the new headhouse and west concourse. Six months later, a temporary arrivals hall will be built and demolition will begin on the arch. A year later, the west concourse will open. A year later, construction will begin on the east concourse. Seven months later, the headhouse will be finished and demolition will begin on the wing buildings. Eleven months later, the east concourse will be complete and all 16 new gates will be open.
"We've made the commitment that we'll never have less than 10 gates in continuous operation," Mr. Eichler said.
Developers are generally loath to discuss potential tenants publicly until they have been landed, and the Schiphol-LCOR team is no exception. But the bond prospectus notes that the developers have had discussions with United Airlines, which gave up its own building, Terminal 9, in the 1980's and now operates from Terminals 6 and 7.
The prospectus also notes that the departure of four airlines for Terminal 1 should open up capacity that would attract many carriers now in congested quarters elsewhere. Their departure will also open space in which to shift other tenants, making it easier to stage construction of the new building around the existing terminal.
Frustration is what drove Air France, Japan Airlines, Korean Air and Lufthansa to an apparently unprecedented collaboration -- carriers from four different nations building on the soil of a fifth.
Even as they chafed in their aging quarters, they had opposed an enormous central terminal as unwieldy and exorbitant. But when that plan was abandoned, so was hope.
"There was no relief or development in sight," said Dieter Bergt of Lufthansa. There was, however, an opportunity: the 36-acre site of the Eastern Airlines terminal.
The airlines formed a limited partnership, Terminal One Group Association. Its general partner is Terminal One Management, in which the airlines have equal shares. Mr. Bergt is chief executive. The executive director Arthur F. McMahon, who formerly managed the Trans World Airlines and British Airways terminals.
The partnership holds a sublease on the property through 2015 from the Port Authority. It is renewable through 2024 if the city extends the authority's lease. However, Mr. McMahon said, the partnership has a separate agreement with the city, also running through 2024, should the authority's overall lease be terminated. Financing came from the sale in 1994 of $435 million in bonds by the Industrial Development Agency.
Terminal 1 has 635,000 square feet of space. The check-in hall has four islands for use by each of the airlines. Beyond that is a two-level rotunda that will be used as the food court. There are eight gates on the south concourse, three on the west, including the Concorde's position, which will be visible from the Van Wyck Expressway.
There is room in the terminal for approximately seven more airlines, Mr. McMahon said, depending on the size of their operations. Tenants will be courted with the idea that the terminal has been constructed by the very companies who use it. "What was brought to the design and functionality of the building is decades of first-hand experience," Mr. Bergt said. "This has been built by airlines for airlines."
Next July 31, two months after Terminal 1 opens, will come the 50th anniversary of the dedication of New York International Airport by President Harry S. Truman and Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York.
"For too long now the existing facilities for air transportation in this area have been saturated," Dewey said, in a sentiment that has outlived the days of the Constellation.
Truman said the airport "will be the front door to the United Nations." But before he could finish his speech, a formation of F-80 jets screamed overhead to begin an hourlong aerial show of 900 fighters, bombers and transports -- the largest peacetime display of American air might.
Like everyone else, Truman called the airport "Idlewild," after a golf course that had stood on the site. Perhaps the only person who abjured that designation was Austin J. Tobin, executive director of the Port Authority. According to a new history of the authority, "Perpetual Motion," Tobin admonished staff members by saying: "It's neither idle nor wild!"
Neither was it much of an airport at first, with a ragtag collection of Quonset huts that The New York Times called "one of the worst terminal buildings in the world." Passengers at Idlewild suffered "physical, mental and emotional indignities which were barely acceptable in the days of the covered wagon," The Times said.
AN astonishing transformation occurred in 1957 with the opening of the International Arrivals Building. Designed in a spare modernist style by Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, it sparkled like a new Park Avenue office tower and worked as efficiently as a supermarket, with conveyor belts at the customs inspection stations. Travelers were greeted by a 40-foot Alexander Calder mobile. ("What we kept from the old building was of course the Calder," Mr. Mohrmann said.)
After that came the "unit" terminals of the big American-flag carriers: United and Eastern in 1959, American and Pan American in 1960, Northwest and Trans World in 1962, National in 1969. They were arrayed around a landscaped oval with a fountain, a reflecting pool, three chapels and a see-through heating and cooling plant.
Each was distinctive. The sinuous T.W.A. Flight Center, by Eero Saarinen & Associates, is the best known; indeed, it is an official landmark. Its upraised, intersecting concrete vaults make it look like a giant concrete bird that has glided to a landing.
Equally arresting was the Pan Am Worldport, by Tippetts-Abbett-McCarthy-Stratton (predecessors to TAMS), with its elliptical concrete and steel canopy suspended on a network of cables over a glass drum. The National Airlines Sundrome, by I. M. Pei & Partners, had an intricate facade of faceted glass mullions, while the American terminal, by Kahn & Jacobs, had a 317-foot-long stained-glass wall by Robert Sowers.
Idlewild was sensational, recalled Mr. Bergt, who was first stationed in New York for Lufthansa from 1957 to 1972. "After the unit terminals opened, one after the other," he said, "with the fountain, the flower beds, the churches and synagogue, people who came here from Europe and overseas couldn't believe it. This was the model airport."
When the arrivals building opened, Gov. W. Averell Harriman said he hoped the runways could handle moon-bound rocket traffic. But that did not turn out to be the problem. Rather, it was the arrival in 1970 of 400-seat jumbo jets that gravely overtaxed the structure.
"The building for the next 40 years will have to be radically different," said Marilyn Jordan Taylor, a partner at Skidmore, Owings & Merrill. She believes this is the first time that a Skidmore-designed icon will be replaced by another Skidmore building.
Having departed on her first overseas voyage as a young girl from the international building, Ms. Taylor allowed that she may feel a twinge of sadness when it comes down. But her regret will be tempered.
"I'm so tired of seeing my city's primary international airport rated the lowest," Ms. Taylor said, "that it stiffens me to say it's clearly time to move on."

HEADLINE: IN PERSON;
Giving Commercials Their Best Shot

BYLINE: By DEBRA GALANT 

 BODY:
TO David Fitzgerald, New Jersey suburbia essentially breaks down into two basic types: Norman Rockwell and Edward Scissorhands.
Montclair and Tenafly are classic Norman Rockwell towns, with stately colonials on shade-dappled yards, places that evoke a memory of a time when childhood was safe and unhurried. Clifton and Cedar Grove will serve as your basic Edward Scissorhands towns, slightly menacing places where 1960's split-levels gleam unshaded under the midday sun and where the foliage forms perfect geometric shapes. 
 "Norman Rockwell was always the standard for commercials," Mr. Fitzgerald, who scouts locations for television, explains. But lately, that has changed. The Edward Scissorhands towns have been more in vogue. Then there are your gritty urban locations: Newark, Jersey City, Hoboken. And your rural ones, places like Oldwick and Lebanon. Of course, you never know about those rural locations. The way new suburbs spring up these days, last year's great cornfield could be this year's new Edward Scissorhands town.
Whatever. Wherever. New Jersey can, and does, provide the backdrop for almost any scene a film or television director could want. Last year, 69 feature films, 240 commercials and numerous other film projects were shot on location here, contributing $48.2 million to the state's economy, according to the New Jersey Motion Picture and Television Commission.
It's people like David Fitzgerald who find these backdrops. Mr. Fitzgerald, 41, has been scouting locations in the New York area for 15 years. Like many fellow scouts, he fell into his profession accidentally. A painter with a master's degree in fine arts, Mr. Fitzgerald received a call one day from an old friend who had gone to film school and was now working as a location scout. "I was working in an art gallery," Mr. Fitzgerald recalls. "He was making more money."
Experienced location scouts command about $500 a day plus expenses. Beginners earn $200 to $300. At least 100 location scouts work steadily in the New York metropolitan area; Mr. Fitzgerald is one of about 30 who concentrate exclusively on commercials.
It doesn't take a whole lot to get set up in the location scouting business. A sturdy camera, a reliable car, a good set of maps, a beeper, a cellular phone and a few contacts will start you off. But it's up to the location scout to develop a vast database of houses of every architectural style and feel, with occupants willing to put their lives on hold for a few days -- in other words, to create the visual equivalent of a great Rolodex.
And it's up to the location scout to learn which towns are film-friendly and which aren't, and to keep up with changes in local ordinances regarding location shooting.
"A lot of the job is clearance," Mr. Fitzgerald says. "Who will allow you to film, which locations have been film-friendly in the past."
Like most scouts working in the area, Mr. Fitzgerald found himself spending a lot of time in Montclair, a town with a strong collection of houses built in the late 19th century. Mr. Fitzgerald, who was brought up in Manhattan and then moved to Brooklyn, grew to like Montclair so much that he decided to move his own family there in 1995. He and his wife, Naomi Rand, a college professor and writer, chose a yellow Victorian built in 1892, with a glassed-in front porch and a 30-by-30-foot living room -- with an eye toward show business.
"I thought it would work for commercials," he says. "And it does." The house has provided the setting for four commercials, including a Corestates Bank spot currently being broadcast. To avoid the resentment of other residents on his small private street, he has arranged for the production companies to pay the neighbors for parking in their driveways. And after the latest commercial was filmed, Mr. Fitzgerald bought them each a bottle of wine.
With all their trailers and equipment, their habit of tying up traffic and hogging parking spaces, film crews have a way of wearing out their welcome in even the most film-friendly towns. So places like Tenafly and Montclair, which have provided the scenery for more than their share of commercials and movies, are beginning to become restrictive. After a number of film shoots in one of Montclair's tonier neighborhoods last year, irate neighbors pressed the town to pass an ordinance limiting production to three days a year at any single location. Anything more -- say, the day-after-day production required in shooting a feature film -- requires a variance.
When certain towns begin to recede as film towns, others emerge to take their place. Lately, Maplewood has begun to provide some of the Norman Rockwell sets needed by the film business. As word spreads among scouts, Maplewood will begin to get the reputation as a film-friendly town and draw more business, Mr. Fitzgerald explains.
Then there's the magic circle to consider. If a film is shot within a 25-mile radius of Columbus Circle in Manhattan, the production company doesn't have to pay for travel time for the union crew. A scout who wants to be asked again is attentive to that geographic requirement.
IT usually doesn't take much to persuade homeowners to put up with all the chaos involved in a film shoot. For $1,800 to $2,000 a day -- not to mention the flattery of having your house chosen to be on television! or in the movies! -- most homeowners are quite willing to put up with the cameras, cables and caterers that come with job. Farmers, too, are often eager for both the money and the attention. Although some farmers are "sort of old and crotchety and don't want to be bothered," Mr. Fitzgerald says, many enjoy the Hollywood-style intrusion and therefore are called again and again, he says.
Still, part of his job is reminding the property owner what that $2,000 pays for: the right to completely turn your house (or farm or whatever) upside down for a day. "When they come in, they might move furniture," Mr. Fitzgerald recently warned a Montclair homeowner, whose house was being considered for a spot featuring a major brand of sports equipment. To make a real location fit the director's vision, crews may refit light fixtures or replace window treatments. To prepare for a shoot that could scratch a floor, a false floor might be laid down over it. "It's sort of like an invading army," Mr. Fitzgerald says.
That army needs a lot of room, and one of the challenges of Mr. Fitzgerald's job is to find houses big enough to hold all the crew and equipment, but small enough that they won't look like mansions: "big houses that don't read as wealthy as they are." Another challenge is to find offices, shopping districts and schools that can accommodate all the disruption that inevitably comes with a film crew.
After all the logistical requirements have been met, Mr. Fitzgerald can consider the artistic side of his job. "You have to have a sense of what a director will be looking for," he says. "To be willing to understand the director's vision." And there's not a lot of time.
Location scouts usually have two or three days to bring back 10 or 15 possible locations for a commercial shoot. That translates into about 20,000 miles a year on Mr. Fitzgerald's leased 1995 Camry.
On one job last year, for a Three Musketeers candy bar commercial, Mr. Fitzgerald was asked to find an Italian social hall, the kind of place where the Godfather would hang out. The director suggested he watch the movie "Goodfellas" to get the idea.
"I immediately thought of sort of funky places," Mr. Fitzgerald says. First, he got the name of an actual Italian social club in Jersey City from the New Jersey Film Commission. He also visited the Elks' Lodge in Hoboken, as well as the back room of a Hoboken bar with old wooden booths and a tin ceiling. He tried some places in Little Italy in Manhattan, including at least one with Chianti bottles and checkered tablecloths.
But as is so often the case, the director wound up liking a location a little classier than the one he originally described, and the commercial was shot at another Hoboken location provided by Mr. Fitzgerald: the back room of Frankie and Johnny's, an old-fashioned restaurant and bar with classic turn-of-the-century details.
And then there's the hard part of the job, informing people that their kitchens won't be the setting for next spring's Maxwell House commercial after all. "Some people take it very personally," Mr. Fitzgerald says. "People who haven't been approached numerous times. They get excited, and they start assuming it's going to happen."
In that case, Mr. Fitzgerald tries to let them down easy, just as a director would after auditioning, say, an actress who reads well but is just too short for the job. "You say: 'It's not about your house, but they wanted a bigger space," he says. Or: "They wanted whiter walls."

HEADLINE: ROAD AND RAIL;
Some Foresee Revival, Some Ruin Along a Proposed Light-Rail Line

BYLINE: By BILL KENT 

 BODY:
Twice a day, from the front window of his dry cleaning shop, Louis Fisher can see Conrail freight trains moving slowly down a single track through downtown Riverside.
"Every time I look at that track, I try to see the light rail on it," Mr. Fisher said. "Light rail is the future of this town, my business and my family." 
 Mr. Fisher, a Riverside native, has watched his town suffer steady economic decline. Then, in January, he heard of New Jersey Transit's proposal to run light-rail commuter trains on a Conrail track linking Trenton and Camden, making at least 15 stops. The first phase of a plan that would ultimately extend to Glassboro and Rowan University in Gloucester County, the $450 million project had the potential, in Mr. Fisher's words, to "do for Riverside what Hi-Speed Line did for Haddonfield."
The Hi-Speed Line, a 45-mile commuter train administered by the Delaware River Port Authority Transportation Company, whisks 41,300 commuters daily through Camden County between Lindenwold and Philadelphia. The line, which opened in 1966, was bitterly opposed by some Haddonfield residents, who feared it would increase crime and decrease property values in one of the richest municipalities in South Jersey. In fact, the Hi-Speed Line has had no identifiable effect on crime, and residential property prices have remained consistently among the region's highest.
In March, Mr. Fisher moved his business from Mount Laurel, Burlington County, to Riverside, where he still lives. "I'm counting on light rail to make people and businesses want to come back to Riverside," Mr. Fisher said. "There's already talk of all kinds of new things planned for downtown. I can't believe anybody would want to fight this."
Since it was announced last November, the proposed Southern New Jersey Light Rail Transit System has had the support of most elected officials whose municipalities would be served by it. Advocates of the elderly and the disabled (who tend to have less difficulty boarding trains than buses) and commuters irritated by the slow pace of existing New Jersey Transit buses in the Delaware waterfront towns have also endorsed it. The light-rail system is considered crucial to a regional Route 130 Corridor revitalization program. It would provide quieter, potentially less polluting transportation to the E-Center, the state aquarium and the Rutgers University campus in Camden, as well to a food distribution center under construction in Florence Township that is to employ 2,500 workers.
Yet the system has strong opponents who say the plan is too expensive, would serve too few residents, might be less efficient than buses and would so decrease the quality of life that they would have to move.
Jim Gross of Riverton, who teaches elementary school in Pemberton Township, said the system would not serve people who live or work along Route 295 in Burlington and Camden Counties.
"We need money spent on alleviating transporation in this region right now," he said, "and instead here comes New Jersey Transit telling us that they're going to spend $450 million so people along the waterfront can get to Camden."
Tom Wood of Pennsauken, whose house backs up to the track New Jersey Transit wants to use, said he would move if the light rail link were established. Increases in noise, pollution from diesel-powered light rail engines and invasions of privacy are "only part of the reason," he said. "The major reason is that I grew up in Haddonfield." That town, he said, benefited more from its school system and historic buildings than from mass transit.
Phyllis R. Elston, New Jersey Transit's community affairs director for the project, dismissed opponents of light rail "as people who just don't have all the facts." Although final approvals are still necessary, she said, money for the project has already been allocated from state gas tax revenues. "So no taxpayer is going to be burdened by this," she said.
"Light rail engines are quieter than buses, less polluting than buses, safer than buses in that they can stop faster and can run in all weather conditions," she said. In addition, "mass transit brings jobs and people to a region, and both are absolutely necessary to revitalize a community." She said the first light-rail trains could be running in four years.
The Democratic gubernatorial candidate, James E. McGreevy, has promised to thwart the project if elected. The town of Delanco also opposes it. A survey of Palmyra residents showed slightly more than half the respondents opposed to the train. And although light rail has been enthusiastically endorsed in Camden, where a light-rail maintenance yard is projected to bring 150 new jobs, Camden Country freeholders have withheld their support.
John Laverty of Riverton, a fast-food restaurant developer who is a member of the Burlington County Citizens Transporation Advisory Council, noted that only three years ago, another proposed South Jersey light-rail link connecting Camden with Moorestown and Mount Holly was defeated. "If South Jersey keeps saying no, North Jersey will take the money and spend it elsewhere," he said. "Light rail might not be everything everybody wants, but without it, things are only going to get worse."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: STUYVESANT COVE;
Park to Grow on the Ashes of the Riverwalk Plan

BYLINE: By BERNARD STAMLER 

 BODY:
Efforts to revive a desolate stretch of shore on the East River, between 18th and 23d Streets, have themselves been revived.
The redevelopment effort, began in the early 1980's as Riverwalk, a proposed development of luxury apartment towers, marinas, a hotel and offices, has metamorphosed into Stuyvesant Cove, a riverfront park. 
 After Riverwalk was officially scratched in 1992 as a result of fierce neighborhood opposition, talks among city and state politicians and community board members dragged along until last week, when the city's Economic Development Corporation announced a plan for what people seem to agree is better.
"It's proof of what we can accomplish under this mayor," Charles Millard, the president of the E.D.C., said, adding that previous administrations had been unable to field "a team" like his to work on projects like this one and other waterfront developments like Pier A at the Battery, now under reconstruction. "We put together the plan and the money for it," he said of Stuyvesant Cove.
But the new park -- whose financing will come from state, city and federal sources -- is also a pet project of Assemblyman Steven Sanders, a Manhattan Democrat who was a leading opponent of Riverwalk.
While praising Mayor Giuliani for cooperating and helping the project, Mr. Sanders said that , "all of the initial work was begun under the Dinkins administration" and that members of Community Board 6 did yeoman's work in putting the idea together over the last several years. "It's really the cooperation of all the local elected officials that's made it possible," he said, mentioning himself and Councilman Andrew S. Eristoff and State Senator Roy M. Goodman, both of whom are Republicans.
Unlike Riverwalk, which would have cut off neighborhood residents from the water, the new park is specifically designed to be "environmentally appropriate," according to E.D.C. plans, and to promote access to now-unused shoreland next to the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive.
To accomplish those goals and to maximize the park's size, the northbound service road of the F.D.R. Drive will be moved to the west side of the elevated highway, so that the park will begin at the highway's eastern edge. Avenue C will in effect be extended to 23rd Street as a two-way boulevard from its present end at 18th Street, with crossing points at both ends and at 20th Street, and a southbound exit from the Waterside apartment complex just north of the park, to be opened for the first time. Currently, the onlyexit is at 34th Street.
Present plans call for the planting of marsh grass along the waterline and for the building of bicycle and walking paths, Mr. Millard said.
Construction of the park is scheduled to begin early next year, once the rebuilding of the F.D.R. Drive is completed in the area. BERNARD STAMLER

HEADLINE: SPENDING IT;
Joy in Mudville: The Resale Value of Minor League Teams

BYLINE: By ROY FURCHGOTT 

 BODY:
THE Quad City River Bandits, a minor league baseball team in Davenport Iowa, are not exactly the stuff of legend. The clubhouse is so small that players have to take turns dressing. The stadium, which seats 5,100, has one men's and one women's restroom (and a 50-cent beer night). And in April the team had among the worst records in baseball -- 3 wins, 15 losses.
And yet, Richard M. Holtzman, the River Bandits' owner, turned the team into the stuff that baseball dreams are made of with two words: for sale. 
 Many a fan has fantasized about owning a team. Maybe the attraction is rubbing elbows with celebrity owners like the comedian Bill Murray or the singer Jimmy Buffett. Maybe it is the desire to have stationery with the "Lansing Lugnuts" letterhead, or a fond regard for the atmosphere of the movie "Bull Durham." Maybe it is the opportunity to watch future major leaguers, or even the hope of big cash returns.
Investors tempted to make any of those dreams a reality can shop for one of the six to eight minor league teams that are sold each year. But team owners warn that would-be baseball moguls should take a long look before stepping up to the plate.
"It's possible to make money, and it's also possible to lose a lot very quickly," said Mike Veeck, owner of five minor league teams, including the St. Paul Saints of the independent Northern League.
Many team owners have done well on their investments, not necessarily because of ticket sales but because resale values have skyrocketed. "A team that cost $350,000 just 10 years ago costs $8 million today," said Robert D. Richmond of Scottsdale, Ariz., president of the Class A Northwest League, who also owns and brokers minor league teams.
Prices for independent league teams that are not affiliated with major league clubs can run as low as $25,000, for example, in the North Atlantic Baseball League, based in Southampton, N.Y. Prices increase with each step up the league ladder, from rookie league to classes A, AA, and AAA, the step just below the majors. The AAA teams have asking prices of up to $12 million, still low when compared with a major league team like the Los Angeles Dodgers, which is close to selling for $350 million.
Howard J. Darwin, owner of the Class AAA Ottawa Lynx, put the club on the block in August, asking $10 million. He paid $5 million for it as an expansion club in 1993.
Mr. Darwin said the team had been profitable, sometimes making more than $2 million a year, but that much of those profits were passed back to the city of Ottawa, which built the team's new stadium.
At first blush, the economics of the minor leagues seem sweet. Although few teams make TV money, they receive income from tickets, concessions, advertising and team merchandise, while their big-league affiliates underwrite many expenses. The major league teams, which need the minors to develop players, pay all players, managers, coaches and trainers at 156 minor league clubs -- as well as meal allowances, some hotel rooms and spring training.
But a recent agreement shifts more costs to the minors. Next season, they will pay the costs for more than 200 umpires, the cost of uniforms and half the cost of balls and bats. As in the previous contract, the minors also pay for travel and for running the stadium.
Stadium lease deals are the key to profits, and the cause of owner headaches. The major leagues set stadium standards and minor league owners must persuade stadium landlords, usually municipalities, to make improvements. That can lead to friction.
"The current Mayor of Davenport and I are not on each other's Christmas list," said Mr. Holtzman, who said he was selling his team because Davenport would not make an estimated $6 million of stadium improvements required by the league. Without improvements, Mr. Holtzman must sell, move or get a league waiver to play in the stadium. Failing that, the league president can force a sale of the team -- though as a practical matter, that has not happened since the stadium standards were introduced in 1990.
Teams are rarely listed publicly for sale; rather, they sell via brokers or blind ads in sports journals. Owners don't want to anger fans by openly offering to sell a team that could move if sold. The governing body for the minors, the National Association of Professional Baseball Leagues in St. Petersburg, Fla., stays out of the trading, but will help buyers find brokers.
Mr. Richmond, as a broker, advises that, "If you want to get the right management and work hard, and you would be satisfied with a 5 to 8 percent return on your investment, then O.K., we can do it."
Plenty buy anyway, including Mr. Veeck, who grew up around baseball. His grandfather, William Louis Veeck Sr., was president of the Chicago Cubs; his father, Bill Veeck, owned several teams, including the Cleveland Indians and the Chicago White Sox. (Perhaps following the example of his father, who was known for innovations, the younger Mr. Veeck ran a promotion in which an enormous Chia pet was doused with gasoline and set on fire.)
The young Mr. Veeck said it was a good year when a team made $200,000. Yet when he compares his least profitable team, the Butte Copper Kings in Montana, with his most profitable, "Butte lost money and I love them as dearly as St. Paul," he said.
IF money is to be made, it's in the long run. Joe J. Buzas, 79, of Salt Lake City, the owner of the Class AA New Britain Rock Cats in Connecticut and the Class AAA Salt Lake Buzz, says he has owned 83 teams in 52 years. "I've become a multimillionaire managing minor league baseball teams." he said.
Mr. Buzas was a minor-league player and had a brief stint in the majors -- "a cup of coffee," he calls it -- with the New York Yankees in 1945. "I didn't want to get off the stage, so I became an owner," he said.
Mr. Buzas said that any well-run AAA team should make $1 million a year, but that he has made his real money buying and selling. He bought the Class AA Reading Phillies in Pennsylvania in 1977 for $1. "I sold it nine years later for $1,000,001," he said.
Some owners, like Mr. Veeck, have a fanatical love of the game. "At the end of the day, no matter how rotten the day is, my office is a ball field," he says.
Others warn that it is easier to watch from the bleachers. "Being an owner makes it harder to enjoy a game," Mr. Holtzman said. "You are concerned if all of the light bulbs are working, if the hot dogs are warm, if the other fans are having a great time. It's a disadvantage."

HEADLINE: EARNING IT;
How to Keep the Best Workers Working at Their Best

BYLINE: By TINA KELLEY 

 BODY:
ALMOST every office has one: the recent M.B.A. with fire in her belly, the weekend-working overachiever who regularly finishes his daily list of things to do, the people who take on the workplace equivalent of ironing boxer shorts. Managers love them, unions distrust them and co-workers merely roll their eyes, knowing that on an island of perfectionists, the average Joe is doomed.
For a manager, such overworkers are priceless, and that is part of the problem. They cannot possibly be paid what they are worth, so how do companies keep them happy, keep them from slowing down and, most of all, keep them? 
 There are a variety of opinions on the care and feeding of overachievers, and every good manager has a solution. It is not a topic that lends itself easily to management-in-a-box answers, but this much is obvious: When merit pay is not affordable, or when work rules discourage action above and beyond the job description, the best managers have found other ways to motivate the best workers to do their best work.
Edward Lazear, a professor of economics and human resources at the Stanford Graduate School of Business, thinks the rewards must be broken down by the type of worker. He says managerial workers want promotions most of all, while wage earners generally produce best for the promise of more money. (Thus, piecework can be more attractive for them than hourly wages.) Younger workers are more likely to crave training and visibility; more established workers desire autonomy and freedom.
Professor Lazear advises bosses to set objective goals. "It's good to have managers try to commit to absolute standards, so everybody can be rewarded if they exceed a particular standard," he said. "But you've got to convince everyone that the standard is not going to move based on what happens this year -- because workers know if they goldbrick this year, the standards won't be higher next year."
Comparing workers with one another can damage morale, he said. "In school, you remember when the teacher would tell you that you could do something for extra credit? The question is: Is there really such a thing as extra credit? If everyone does extra credit and you're graded on a curve, and if you didn't do it and everyone else did, you're below average in the class."
Workplaces with overachievers can be tough for average people, but a good place to have stock options. Consider Microsoft, where working has been compared to drinking out of a firehose because there is just so much to do, said Julie Bick, 32, who retired as a millionaire after five years at the software giant in Redmond, Wash., and wrote the current best seller, "All I Really Need to Know in Business I Learned at Microsoft" (Pocket Books).
A company that hires so many whiz kids is wise to offer stock options, she said, recalling how her secretary at Microsoft, when asked to make copies of a marketing plan, came back instead with insightful suggestions on how to improve it, based on her reading of PC Week.
"It was just beautiful," Ms. Bick said. "The magic of stock options is if you have a star working for you, in most companies you'd want to keep him in your fiefdom. But with options, you'd say, 'This guy's smart, but he could be promoted to another group and do better there, and therefore my stock options will go up.' " Nobody is held back.
SOMETHING as simple as a cup of coffee can be a great incentive, too. When Charlotte Guyman, a general manager with MSNBC, the joint venture between Microsoft and NBC, took over a new group for Microsoft several years ago, she found herself managing 100 people in several departments, with pockets of rivalry, tight deadlines and many new hires. She knew she needed to keep communication flowing, create a strong team and get the best work out of everyone.
She decided to have monthly meetings, which in itself would not win her any management awards. But she added an incentive, based on her frequent midafternoon visits to the company espresso machine: the Char-Latte awards.
She chose winners based on nominations from her team, honoring those who had "produced great results, shown real fine teamwork or removed barriers to doing the right thing," said Ms. Guyman, who at 41, after 10 years at the company, just received a carrot of her own: a Microsoft Achievement Award, an eight-week sabbatical.
"People thought it was very fun," she said. "They'd get a gift certificate to go get a latte, attached to a bunch of helium balloons, in the meeting. It was very public, and people would send E-mail that said, 'Wow, that really felt good.'
"Sometimes people who get rewarded are the most vocal, but I found out about good stuff being done by people who were not high profile. It's pretty easy to lose touch for managers, especially when they have a lot of people below them. This was a good way for people to get recognized, even if they're not in personal contact with their manager."
The accent is on the personal, Ms. Bick said. "One year Microsoft gave out 500 identical plaques that said, 'For Your Individual Achievement.' People just thought it was ridiculous. They used them as doorstops," she said. "But if you get a congratulatory E-mail from Bill Gates, that's worth a lot."
Other employers have been able to direct employee performance with variable pay scales that reward specific extra efforts, said Marc John Wallace, a consultant at the Center for Workforce Effectiveness, a management consulting firm in Northbrook, Ill. This can work in union shops, too.
"A common pitfall is putting in a plan with unrealistic goals," he warned. "Then the incentive to work harder and overachieve is gone. The assumption is that there will be some kind of reward for extra effort, but if the goals aren't met, there's a feeling of helplessness, of not being able to achieve the goal, so why waste time trying?"
But for another breed of employees, a seemingly impossible goal can be the best incentive. "Giving people real big opportunities and problems, that's often highly motivating for someone who's a high achiever," Ms. Guyman said. "Some people like recognition or respect or money or power or control or promotion. Some may be motivated by time off or by a new challenge. Figuring that out is a pretty critical key."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Charlotte Guyman, left, created awards -- based on her love for espresso -- to recognize Microsoft workers like Linda McGee. (Dan Lamont for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS;
A Nobel Winner Wears Several Fund Hats

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY MIDDLETON 

 BODY:
MYRON SCHOLES, the Stanford professor emeritus who recently won the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science for research into pricing options, is also a mutual fund investor. In fact, he sits on the boards of three fund complexes, helping them cut costs and improve operations. Along with his fellow Nobel winner, Robert C. Merton of the Harvard Business School, he is also a principal of Long Term Capital Management, a $6 billion hedge fund that invests principally in fixed-income securities and derivatives on them. He spoke last week from his office in Connecticut. TIMOTHY MIDDLETON
 
 Q. How did you get involved in the fund business? 
 A. I was involved with Wells Fargo Bank as a consultant in the late 1960's and early 1970's, when I suggested to them that they develop a product that has become known as index funds. That was how I initially got started thinking about investment products, doing research over the years that led me to understand, study and teach about mutual fund performance. So when Benham Group asked me to join their board of directors when they had a vacancy in 1981, I accepted the position.
Q. You invented index funds?
A. Yes, actually it was Fischer Black and me. That was in 1968. We called it passive investment, and it later became known as indexing. Of course, it was a long time before it really caught on as a viable product. I remember that in 1987, Vanguard funds only had about $500 million invested in index funds, and now it must be $60 billion to $70 billion.
Q. So you invented it but did not collect any of the huge funds that have subsequently flowed in?
A. Sometimes the early bird gets the worm, but sometimes the early bird gets frozen to death.
Q. Benham has since been acquired by American Century Funds. Do you remain on the board?
A. Yes, I'm on the board of all the Benham funds.
Q. And the other boards you sit on?
A. About 1983 or 1984, two former students of mine from the University of Chicago, Rex Sinquefield and David Booth, formed a mutual fund complex called Dimensional Fund Advisers, or DFA, to offer index-fund-like products. So I became a member of their board. Then around 1992 another former student, Doug Breeden, asked me to join the board of Smith Breeden & Company, which operates the Smith Breeden funds. Students ask you to be on their boards of directors sometimes. So I'm a director for three fund complexes.
Q. As a director, what interests you most about funds?
A. No. 1 is portfolio performance, No. 2 is transactions costs and No. 3 is customer service. In every case, I'm interested in seeing how these areas can be optimized.
Q. Can you give an example?
A. I got interested in customer service many years ago. As a director you get reports on customer service, and there's always a tendency to measure inputs, and not necessarily to measure outputs. What I mean is, you get a lot of statistics, like how many calls the fund company received and how long it takes to answer them, but you don't get at how the customer feels about the call. So trying to figure out ways to measure the output -- satisfaction -- is something I was interested in because as a board member I felt responsible for shareholders receiving the quality of service that was being paid for.
Q. Can you be more specific?
A. Well, that's proprietary and somewhat confidential. I can only say we try to figure out what the major factors are that the customer wants, then figure out the measures that will support that, as opposed to just starting out with a bunch of measures.
Q. You have mentioned indexing and a focus on cost control, and of course index funds are famous for being economical to operate. So does that mean you're not interested in actively managed mutual funds?
A. My career in academic research has not been involved with active management of securities. I've tried to understand risk-and-return relationships; also the pricing of derivative securities.
Q. Hence, the famous Black-Scholes model for pricing options?
A. Yes, I'm famous for a way to price an array of securities without having to know the expected returns of the underlying securities. That's what interests me.
Q. Do you invest in any of the funds you serve as a director?
A. I invest in some of the money market funds at Benham and also a small-cap index fund from DFA.
Q. Indexing isn't supposed to be as good as active management with small stocks, is it?
A. I think DFA has been very successful in providing index-like products in smaller stocks, not only for U.S. stocks, but they've also accomplished it for international indices as well. Active management doesn't just involve potential benefits; it also involves additional costs.
Q. What do you receive from the fund complexes for your services?
A. Directors' fees.
Q. Can you tell me what they are?
A. Well, approximately $80,000 to $100,000 a year.
Q. Do you have advice for investors?
A. My view is that one should diversify broadly across different fund investments. However, it's tough for investors to try to pick the appropriate risk level that they should manage their funds at. Having a personal adviser would be helpful.
Q. What are you going to do with your half-million-dollar prize money?
A. Actually, the standard answer to that is that part of it is going to go to the United States Government, in the form of taxes. And then people tell me it's expensive to take one's family to Sweden. So I haven't given a great deal of thought to it. However, as you know I manage money through my own firm here, so it's most likely I'll invest it here.
Q. Congratulations on winning the prize.
A. Thank you very much.
