HEADLINE: China Leader, on Milestone Visit, Might Not Always Follow Script

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Oct. 25

 BODY:
When President Jiang Zemin of China wants to impress someone, he often breaks into song.
At dinner with the Philippine President, Fidel Ramos, in Manila last year, Mr. Jiang surprised his host by showing that he knew the words, in English, to "Love Me Tender." The two men sang a duet. Then Mr. Jiang sang "Swanee River" solo, saying afterward that it was his favorite tune. 
 Mr. Jiang, 71, lacks the charisma and authoritative manner that might be expected of a man who stands at the helm of the world's most populous nation and its fastest-growing economy. In most public settings, he appears stiff and awkward, and prefers to follow a script.
But his penchant for unexpectedly displaying his artistic talents -- Mr. Jiang also likes to play piano and recite poetry -- points to an unpredictable, wacky side as well.
Mr. Jiang sets out on Sunday on his first state visit to the United States, a week-long trip that begins in Hawaii. Billed as a milestone in United States-China relations, and the most important visit by a Chinese leader since Deng Xiaoping went to America in 1979, the trip is also a chance for Mr. Jiang to introduce himself on the world stage now that he has consolidated power.
When Mr. Jiang was named general secretary of the Communist Party in June 1989, the common view in Beijing was that he was a political lightweight and he would be lucky to last three years in the post.
In 1997, he passed his eight-year mark, and succeeded Deng as China's paramount leader when the patriarch died in February. Mr. Jiang then presided over a smooth transition from British rule in Hong Kong and called a Communist Party Congress that, mostly, went his way.
During those eight years, Mr. Jiang has successfully isolated and controlled several potential rivals, including a former President, Yang Shangkun, and his brother, Yang Baibing, who were building a powerful faction in the army.
Yet for all his successful political maneuvering, and good luck this year, Mr. Jiang is not regarded by Chinese officials as particularly able or insightful, nor is he as deeply knowledgeable about economic matters as his predecessor, Zhao Ziyang.
Mr. Jiang is often wooden in official gatherings. When he first met President Clinton at a conference in Seattle in 1993, he used up most of the allotted 60 minutes for their meeting by reading a prepared text.
By limiting himself to restating positions that have already been worked out, Mr. Jiang suggests an unwillingness or a lack of authority to make decisions. Some Chinese officials say his eagerness to sing and play piano in both public and private settings reflects a desire to show off and compensate for his political shortcomings.
"Jiang has a deep desire to make everyone like him," said a Shanghai official who served under Mr. Jiang when he was Mayor of Shanghai in the 1980's.
Mr. Jiang does, however, rely on a trusted group of advisers. First among them is Zeng Qinghong, often called Mr. Jiang's "eyes and ears" for his role of collecting political gossip and swiftly identifying any anti-Jiang moves by rival leaders.
It is hard, many Chinese officials argue, to identify anything that Mr. Jiang believes in or stands for. He likes to recite sections of the Gettysburg Address and Declaration of Independence in English, yet here too he has appeared more interested in showing off his knowledge of such texts than in expressing any serious opinion about them.
Born near Shanghai to an educated family, Mr. Jiang was taken into the care of an uncle who was later said to have died as a "revolutionary martyr" with the Communist army, where a network of revolutionary veterans later proved instrumental in promoting Mr. Jiang's career.
As an engineering student in Shanghai just prior to the Communist-led revolution in 1949, Mr. Jiang was exposed to popular Western music, taking a particular liking to Benny Goodman.
After the Communist takeover, Mr. Jiang first worked in mid-level management jobs at a soap factory in Shanghai, a sign that he was unlikely to have played a significant role in the Communist underground, which generally rewarded its volunteers with important jobs after the revolution was won.
Mr. Jiang won the chance to study in Moscow at the Stalin Automobile Factory for a year, and then spent years as a mid-level official in the machine-building industry. He was not purged during the Cultural Revolution, a badge of honor for many reformist officials once they were reinstated to power.
Wang Daohan, a comrade of Mr. Jiang's stepfather, helped Mr. Jiang win the prestigious job of Mayor of Shanghai in 1985, where Mr. Jiang mastered the art of tending to the elder men who ruled China and who traditionally came to Shanghai for part of the winter.
One defining moment in Mr. Jiang's career came in the middle of the two-month period in 1989 when, as in Tiananmen Square, student-led demonstrations filled the streets of Shanghai, where he had become municipal party chief. His test came from a liberal newspaper called the World Economic Herald.
Led by a gutsy editor, the newspaper published a special issue that was sympathetic to student demonstrators, effectively thumbing its nose at Mr. Jiang without technically breaking any rules. Mr. Jiang dithered for several days, seeking guidance from his superiors in Beijing, and finally ordering the newspaper closed, a move apparently intended to demonstrate his toughness to Deng.
When many writers and university professors spoke out against the newspaper's closing, Mr. Jiang telephoned several of them to ask that they "understand my position," implying that he was simply following orders, said a former Shanghai official.
Then he dispatched a trusted aide to reopen the newspaper under a new editor, telling associates that he actually supported its right to publish, with the right supervision. As it turned out, journalists at the newspaper refused to go along with the new management, and attempts to revive it were abandoned.
"That was the essence of Jiang," said a Chinese journalist in Beijing. "Closing it, opening it, trying to seem tough to one side, and compromising to the other."
Mr. Jiang's once-in-a-career chance came soon thereafter, as an intense power struggle erupted in Beijing between Deng and Zhao Ziyang, who was then head of the Communist Party, over how to cope with the widening demonstrations. When Mr. Zhao was fired and placed under house arrest, it was widely expected that his job would go to one of the next men in the Party hierarchy, Prime Minister Li Peng or the Security Service boss, Qiao Shi.
To the amazement of virtually everyone, Deng and his fellow elders settled on Mr. Jiang, clearly a compromise candidate, and a weak-looking one. When he moved to Beijing, Mr. Jiang was said to have been unable to bring more than a few aides with him, leaving him ill-equipped to conduct the fierce political infighting that goes on in Zhongnanhai, the secluded compound where senior leaders live and work.
In his early years at the helm of the Communist Party, Mr. Jiang operated in the shadow of Deng, and many of Beijing's political cognoscenti believed he would fall swiftly after Deng's death. The two leaders previously chosen by Deng to succeed him, Hu Yaobang and Zhao Ziyang, were each sacked.
Mr. Jiang was fortunate that Deng survived eight years, giving the new leader time to expand his power base. He added the title of President in 1993. Eventually, Mr. Jiang promoted so many colleagues from Shanghai to high posts that Beijing leaders began to complain that a "Shanghai faction" was wielding too much influence.
By the time Deng died last February, Mr. Jiang was apparently ready. As he prepared for the Communist Party Congress last month, he recognized that he needed some kind of decisive political move at the Congress, to prevent it from being themeless.
Until this year, the leadership seemed unable to make any difficult decisions about how to handle the biggest obstacle to economic reform, the elephantine state sector. But this year Mr. Jiang pushed through just that, with a broad plan to shed state control over medium and large enterprises by selling them.
At the same gathering, Mr. Jiang was also able to outmaneuver Mr. Qiao, one of his main rivals, forcing him to step down from the party's Central Committee.
Mr. Jiang's wife, Wang Yeping, is retired from her position at an electrical engineering research center in Shanghai, and appears in public rarely. Their two sons, work in Shanghai, one at the Shanghai Metallurgical Research Institute and the other at a computer software company.
These days, a staple of Communist Party political culture is the site visit, where a national leader goes to a factory or university or hospital, and local officials in charge offer special arrangements, knowing that a career can be made or broken in a few seconds with the word of a senior official. When Mr. Jiang goes for a visit, many work sites know how to prepare.
"Everyone knows you need three things to make a successful Jiang visit," said the Chinese journalist. "One is to let him show off his English or Russian; second is to make him sing, preferably with a pretty young woman; third is to let him play the piano. If you have all those three, he will be very happy."

HEADLINE: THE 1997 ELECTIONS: THE CHALLENGER -- Campaign Journal;
Heroic, or Just Quixotic, Messinger Tilts in Populist Tradition

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr.

 BODY:
Quiet heroism was in the air the other night at Holy Apostles Church in Chelsea. Its congregation has not only fed 3.3 million meals to homeless people in the last 15 years, with the help of thousands of contributors and volunteers, but it rebuilt the 154-year-old Episcopal church after a ruinous fire in 1990.
The main speaker at a reception celebrating those achievements, held in the luminous white nave of the little church, was Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President, a politician almost as down on her luck, politically speaking, as the men, women and children the church looks after. 
 You would not have known it from the fierce rallying cry that she issued, a cry that carried echoes of Bryan and Truman and Humphrey and all the other Democratic tribunes of the dispossessed; a cry of a kind seldom heard in the party of Bill Clinton; seldom heard, for that matter, in a city and a state where Roosevelt and Lehman and their followers once made "liberal" a shining accolade, not an epithet, and only episodically heard in the campaign of Ms. Messinger, the Democratic nominee for mayor, as she struggles to find a strategy to save herself from burial by landslide.
Never mind. That night, Ms. Messinger gave them the old-time religion, fierce and undiluted.
"What does it say about this city," she demanded, "that two years from the end of the century, more and more people need to turn to resources like the Holy Apostles Soup Kitchen? In the richest city in the richest country on earth, how can it be that every month, 73,000 people are turned away from pantries and soup kitchens unfed, 45,000 of them children, when it would only cost the municipal government $2 million, in a budget of more than 30 billion, to insure that no one would be turned away? And the money is not found?"
Those questions, based on statistics her opponent would challenge, crystallized Ms. Messinger's campaign against Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.
As did her comment notable for its insistent moralism in a time of political pragmatism: "When some people are doing so well, it is wrong for others to go hungry and have no place to live."
Hers is the hardest kind of campaign -- a "yes, but" campaign against a popular incumbent, an attempt to make the case that while things are better for most people, they are not better for all. That, she says, is unacceptable.
At its best, the campaign blooms with outrage, though it lacks specifics. She seldom talks about where she will find the additional dollars she promises to spend, neither proposing cuts in program A to finance program B nor advocating tax hikes.
Ms. Messinger does not argue with statistics that show crime dropping precipitously over the last four years, on Mr. Giuliani's watch; she contends that the improvement has been bought, in part, at a cost of increased police brutality, and rejects as "hogwash" the contention that you can't have one without the other.
She does not belittle the Mayor's efforts to curb the growth of gangs through the use of sophisticated police methods; she contends that they are not enough, and that young people must be given alternative outlets for the steam of adolescence. She accuses the Mayor of eliminating after-school programs for 280,000 students, something she describes as folly.
She does not question the prosperity that has been generated by the boom in Wall Street; she contends that it must be more evenly distributed.
"This city's best-kept secret is the people who've been downsized, squeezed out of jobs," she said at another campaign event last week, a "town meeting" in the social hall of St. Mark's Episcopal Church in Jackson Heights, Queens. "Unemployment in this city is almost 10 percent, twice the national average.
"It's not enough to put your thumbs in your suspenders and say, 'Wall Street's doing great; executives are getting six-figure bonuses.' It's not enough to give tax breaks to the corporations. How about small businesses?"
That burst of populism drew applause from the audience, a modest one of about 65, including a dozen officeholders and party officials. Small as it was, it was one of the better crowds of Ms. Messinger's campaign, which has had trouble generating excitement. One reason was evident that evening: the sole camera present was for Korean television, rendering the event invisible on television in the city.
The strain of playing catch-up is starting to show in Ms. Messinger's entourage. People blame her problems on the news organizations. They rail against prominent Democrats like Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan and former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, calling them "sell-outs" who have done little to help her. But the candidate keeps plugging away, like Sisyphus, at her daunting mission.
"I know the style has changed, even in New York," she said in a conversation in her campaign van. "The people who set the political style -- who are they? -- they say it's not productive, dangerous, you risk your political neck when you talk about the government making a difference for people who need help. It's not fashionable to talk about putting roofs over poor people's heads."
She knows Mr. Giuliani is a formidable opponent, though she derides him as an autocrat who lacks the capacity to negotiate. She concedes that it is "very hard to get any response" to some of her main campaign themes.
"People see the signs of prosperity," she said, "so they think I must be exaggerating when I talk about unemployment. The ones who are hurting think it must be their own fault they aren't part of the boom. Giuliani has people feeling good."
The words spill out with passion, and the ideas are laced with statistics and anecdotes. She is a better speaker than Mr. Giuliani, when she is on form, and she talks earnestly and easily with voters about their problems. But she is not the Mayor, she is not on television, and she lacks the magnetism -- the money of a Rockefeller, the looks of a Kennedy -- to offset those handicaps.
Ms. Messinger's No. 1 priority is education, she says. Not coincidentally, it is also among the electorate's prime concerns, according to polls by The New York Times and others. She is frustrated that employers have not rallied to her, because "they know," she said, "that the jobs of the future will require what city schools are not delivering."
"Our schools are in gross distress," she told the group in Queens, and she blamed it on the man she calls "Rudy." (He describes her, coolly, as "my opponent.") The Mayor, she said, had cut $6 billion for education from the projected budget of the Board of Education, although Mr. Giuliani has called the Board's budget requests bloated. Ms. Messinger promised, like so many before her, to rebuild battered school buildings, reduce class sizes to a maximum of 25 and make sure students can read.
That part of her message, unlike the others, appears to be getting across. The latest Times poll shows her leading Mr. Giuliani among parents and, by a slightly larger margin, among parents with children in the public schools. More than two-thirds of all respondents said the Mayor was paying too little attention to the schools.
But whether that is enough to persuade voters to abandon a popular mayor is another question.

HEADLINE: THE 1997 ELECTIONS;
In Their Own Words

 BODY:

RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI
At a news conference at Sylvia's, a restaurant in Harlem, when asked if former Mayor David N. Dinkins had the power to reinvigorate Ruth W. Messinger's candidacy:

RUTH W. MESSINGER

He thinks he has so many other options coming down the road. He's positioning himself for those options with the national Republican Party. Now, you think he'll pay more attention to our schools in the next four years? Ridiculous. You think he'll pay more attention to the unemployment? Why should he?"

HEADLINE: PRO FOOTBALL;
Meet the Occasionally Gentle Giants: The Two Sides of Four Linebackers

BYLINE: By BILL PENNINGTON

 BODY:
Jessie Armstead says football almost gave him an identity crisis. Writing is one of his hobbies.
Corey Miller says fatherhood is his most important job. He watches "Barney." 
 Scott Galyon teaches school in the off season. He wonders why people don't return his smile more often in line at the grocery store.
Corey Widmer plays classical piano daily, though he wishes his left hand were more adroit. "Something like Chopin is tough on me," he said recently.
Tame bunch, these Giants linebackers.
And when they're not pursuing their other interests, they're out chasing quarterbacks and running backs hoping to slam them into the ground, delivering a blow with such force that perhaps the football, or even a helmet, might spurt free.
In the modern world of pro football, even linebackers, the traditional standard-bearers of the game's malevolent underpinnings, have all their teeth and most of their marbles. So it's no surprise that the Giants linebackers, at the center of a resurgent Giants defense, embrace the two-faced concept of their lives as well as any in the National Football League.
"It's a brutal world out there on the field," Miller said last week as the Giants prepared for today's game with the visiting Cincinnati Bengals. "But that doesn't mean you have to be an animal off it."
So Widmer heads for his piano to calm down, where he composes his own music. "My melodies can be somber, with a classical type of tone," he said after a recent practice, standing beside the locker where he piled the pads and other armor of his job. "It relaxes me. I'm going to go into a recording studio and record some of it. Because in my head when I play my music on the piano, I can hear the whole symphony -- the woodwinds, the trombones, the flutes, the strings."
Armstead, the star of the group who is having a Pro Bowl-caliber season, has been known to head for a different keyboard in his spare time.
"I was editor of my high school newspaper," Armstead said. "And in college at Miami, I had an English teacher who pushed me to write some articles that ended up published down there.
"She said to write what touches you. I wrote about when I tore up my knee. She liked what I did and asked me to write some more. I enjoy it."
Galyon went back to his hometown of Seymour, Tenn., last winter and taught economics in the high school there. "I used N.F.L. contracts and the salary cap as examples for some lessons," he said. "People back home are pretty fascinated with that. And, they want to know what it's like living in New York."
In Seymour, which Galyon said has one traffic light, he explained to friends that things are a little more frantic in his new neighborhood.
"It's just a shame everyone is so busy up here," he said. "People are nice, but I'll be in the grocery store and I'll make eye contact with someone and say: 'How ya doing?' And they'll look away, down at their feet.
"I'm sure they're thinking, 'What's wrong with that guy?' But back home, that's what everybody does."
This group of Giants linebackers inherits a grand heritage, one that dates from Sam Huff and carries forward to Lawrence Taylor. Their reputations are not highly developed, since Giants fans don't simultaneously visualize them and their jersey numbers as they once did Taylor and his No. 56, Harry Carson and his No. 53, Carl Banks and his No. 58.
But Miller as the steadfast strongside linebacker, Widmer as the ferocious, yet cerebral, middle linebacker, Armstead as the freelancing playmaker at weakside linebacker and Galyon as the pass-defending specialist in the team's nickel defense are an underrated group coming of age within an underrated Giants defense.
And they are an overachieving crew, too. Miller and Galyon were each picked in the sixth round of the N.F.L. draft, Widmer in the seventh and Armstead in the eighth. Players drafted that late are not projected to be starters, let alone stars.
Indeed, Widmer was selected as a defensive lineman. Miller was told on draft day by Bill Parcells, the Giants coach at the time, that he would be converted to a tight end. Armstead was asked to move his skills to strong safety as recently as three years ago. Galyon, until two months ago, was thought of primarily as a special teams player.
Armstead, who celebrates his 27th birthday today, has always had the best football pedigree of the bunch. Coming out of Dallas, he was considered the best high school linebacker in the nation. When he got to Miami, he was nicknamed Superman.
"That's until some Kryptonite got me in the knee," Armstead said. During his sophomore season, Armstead had major reconstructive knee surgery. He was never highly rated by pro scouts again. Not just because of his knee, but also because he was listed at 6 feet 1 inch and 220 pounds.
"I've been told I was too small all my life," Armstead said. "Even in high school, they said I was too small. When I got to the pros, they said I didn't have a position. It was enough to give a man an identity crisis."
But Armstead, who can rarely be found without a smile on his face, had an answer. "The Jessie regimen," he said. "Eat, lift, run. Then do it again."
And now, with his weight up to 240 pounds and his speed in the open field still intact, Armstead is terrorizing offenses. He leads the Giants in tackles, just as he led them last season.
Giants coaches continually refer to Armstead's sharp football instincts. "What that means," said the team's linebackers coach, Mike Haluchak, "is he has a sense for where the ball is going to be on the field. And he knows the best angle to get there."
Armstead may have been a natural linebacker, but Widmer, 28, and Miller, who turned 29 yesterday, learned on the job as Giants. Widmer had been a defensive tackle at Montana State, and Miller was a defensive end at South Carolina. But since each is asked to fend off blockers and defend the run in the Giants' current 4-3 base defense, a certain in-the-trenches mentality has been helpful.
"I've always liked smash-mouth football," Widmer said. "But you can't get too crazy. They're going to pass, and then what will you do? You've got to keep your head."
Though an emotional player who can often be seen screaming at opponents and teammates, Widmer has the most placid off-the-field interests. Besides the piano, he flies gliders at home in Montana. "It's a great place to fly because if you encounter any problems, you just land in somebody's backyard," he said.
Widmer also comes from a family of artists and avid players of the real-estate market in his hometown of Bozeman, Mont.
"My mom convinced me to buy my first duplex when I was 20 years old," Widmer said. "Bought it for $35,000, sold it for $95,000. I've since bought five more."
Miller has a physique like Samson and is one of the few players in the Giants' locker room who played on the last Giants playoff team in 1993, but he is one of the least heralded players of the Giants' surprising 1997 season.
"Strongside linebacker is not a position where you make a lot of plays," Haluchak said. "Corey's job is to control the tight end, and sometimes take on linemen and fullbacks. He makes the ball go where we want it to go and then others make the tackles. But he's outstanding at his job."
Miller accepts the grunt work with good humor. "I'll do all the work," he said last week, laughing. "And let the other guys go to the Pro Bowl and sit there sipping mai tais."
Miller is talkative with reporters, which got him in trouble with the staff of the former Giants Coach Dan Reeves. "I have to be myself," he said. "And pro athletes can do a lot of good and influence a lot of people with what they say."
Miller, who grew up in the small town of Pageland, S.C., also speaks often at church groups, telling his story. "I don't sugarcoat it," he said. "I tell them that as a teen-ager I'd go to school drunk. My cousin and I used to break into stores and steal stuff. Just for kicks, we'd head into the better neighborhoods and beat up white kids, get involved in all sorts of racial stuff.
"Thank God for my parents; they instilled a Christian ethic and kept me from going too far over the edge. God took someone like me and turned me around. And now I know that the most important job I have is being a good father. It's hard but rewarding work." Miller and his wife, Lisa, have two sons, C. J. and Christian.
Galyon is in his second year out of the University of Tennessee. In passing situations, he enters the game with an extra defensive back while Widmer and Miller leave.
Fox called Galyon "a pleasant surprise."
Galyon also has a flair for the dramatic. His first N.F.L. tackle was on Emmitt Smith, whom he stopped for no gain on a third-and-1 last season.
Against Detroit last week, Galyon charged into the Lions' backfield on Detroit's first running play and pulled Barry Sanders down for a 4-yard loss.
"I'll tell you what I like about these guys," Fox said. "The characteristics you need to play this game have nothing to do with how you're built or how fast you run on the track. It's a tough game, and you need people of high character. That's what these guys have, and that's what makes them unique."
Well, that's not all that makes them unique. With the writing, the religion, the music and the teaching skills, they would make for entertaining guests at a dinner party.
Just don't invite them over for an enlightening Sunday brunch. It would interfere with their day jobs.

HEADLINE: In the Region/Westchester;
In County's North, a Land Rush for Building Lots

BYLINE: By MARY McALEER VIZARD 

 BODY:
THE booming economy, combined with low interest rates and a pent-up demand for new construction, has created a land rush in Westchester, with some areas experiencing strong double-digit increases in sales in the last year.
The activity is concentrated in the northern reaches of the county, where sizable building lots are still available. "In the southern part of the county, they're out of land," said Ebie Wood, a regional manager for Houlihan/Lawrence. "People there are buying existing properties and knocking them down. That doesn't show up as a land sale, but that's essentially what it is." 
 In Pound Ridge, one of Westchester's most rural northern towns, land sales have almost doubled this year. And that number is expected to go higher before the year's end, according to Ms. Wood.
"There have been 22 sales in Pound Ridge so far this year," Ms. Wood said. "And there are two more pending, and four are in negotiation." That is up from 12 sales in all of 1996 and 6 in 1995.
Sales have also jumped, although not so dramatically, across the northeast quadrant of the county. In an area that includes Armonk, Chappaqua, Somers, Bedford, Pound Ridge, Lewisboro and North Salem, there have been 76 sales so far this year, with 23 pending, according to Ms. Wood. Last year, in the same area, there were 73.
Ms. Wood and other brokers say that the people buying land range from wealthy individuals looking for large properties on which to build a single-family home to developers primarily interested in building lots, preferably with all their approvals already in place.
"The big builders are back and they don't want to battle the local people or raise the ire of the community," said Stuart R. Scamberg, a lawyer who represents property owners. He said he had noticed increased activity in the last few years. "There are more applications pending and we spend more time in front of municipal boards, that's for sure," he said.
Mr. Scamberg said he had also noticed some other trends. "For one thing, land around golf courses is extremely hot," he said. "And high-end single building lots, selling for $500,000, are in demand. These are mostly bought by wealthy individuals. There seems to be a great deal of money around."
Of the large builders, the most active in the county is Toll Brothers of Huntingdon Valley, Pa. It entered the county in 1993, has completed five single-family communities and is now building six more. "We continue to see opportunity in Westchester," said Robert Parahus, a vice president. "We're under contract to buy 63 building lots in Cortlandt Manor."
Toll Brothers evaluates each property on "whether or not we can make money with it," Mr. Parahus said, adding, "We need to be able to develop a substantial number of homes to be able to come out with a profit." The average home built by Toll Brothers in Westchester sells for $500,000, Mr. Parahus said.
In general, land prices have come down since the boom years of the late 1980's. "At the height of the market, building lots of an acre or more were selling for $300,000," said Patrick Browne, a broker with Preferred Realty Better Homes and Gardens, in Cross River. "Now builders won't pay more than $100,000 to $150,000 for a lot."
That is because properties are often more strictly zoned now, allowing for less development. "And they are subject to more stringent environmental regulations, especially for land in the New York City watershed," Mr. Browne added.
Last year, Gilbert Johnson, a local builder, purchased six building lots in Pound Ridge, paying approximately $100,000 per two-acre lot. "There were multiple bidders so I had to pay the going rate," Mr. Johnson said.
The property had some of its approvals but not all. "I had to spend an additional $12,000 to get the remaining approvals," Mr. Johnson said, "and another $130,000 improving the land and getting it in shape to build on it."
A lot of the remaining land is difficult to build on, requiring fill, blasting and other costly operations. "The easier land has already been developed," Mr. Johnson said. "Every builder has to factor in additional costs. There's always going to be a Murphy's Law part of the property. You just don't know which one it will be."
Mr. Johnson, who had previous experience buying land in Pound Ridge in the early 1980's, added: "Nobody can expect the appreciation we saw in the late 1980's. You can't flip properties and make money like you could then."
John Ciardullo, a developer, learned this the hard way. He bought 100 acres in Waccabuc in 1985 for $900,000. "A few years later, it was worth $3 million," Mr. Ciardullo said. He didn't sell, however, hoping to develop it, and he wound up spending an additional $3.5 million for legal and consulting fees over a 10-year period completing environmental impact statements.
ALTHOUGH he now has all of his approvals and is preparing the property for 21 homes, Mr. Ciardullo said, "I will never do anything again involving Seqra," referring to the State Environmental Quality Review Act, which places stringent controls on development in watershed areas.
Such economic factors have forced the smaller players out of the market, according to Mr. Scamberg. "After the stock market collapse of 1987, the small players left and most have never returned," he said "Only the big player can afford to remain."
The current building boom is a reflection of the strength of the overall housing market in Westchester, which for the last few years has experienced record sales. "The inventory of resales had to be cleared out before we'd see this amount of interest in land on the part of builders," Mr. Browne said.
It also reflects confidence in the long-term health of the economy. "The low interest rates definitely help," Ms. Wood said. "But building a house is a long-tern project. To do it, you have to believe that the economy is strong long-term."
Certain sociological factors have also played a role, according to Ms. Wood. "The northern part of the county has become more desirable to buyers due to life style changes, which allow more people to work from home," she said. "The commute into midtown Manhattan isn't as wildly important as it once was."

HEADLINE: MARIJUANA AND PRO BASKETBALL -- A special report.;
N.B.A.'s Uncontrolled Substance.

BYLINE: By SELENA ROBERTS

 BODY:
Contrary to the wholesome image marketed by the National Basketball Association, 60 to 70 percent of its 350-plus players smoke marijuana and drink excessively, according to conversations with more than two dozen players, former players, agents and basketball executives.
"If they tested for pot, there would be no league," said Richard Dumas, the former Phoenix Suns guard who was banned from the league for drug and alcohol use and is now playing in Europe. "Weed is something guys grow up doing, and there's no reason for them to stop. Because almost everyone does it, no one wants to test for it. They're afraid to." 
 Two decades ago, the league nearly collapsed under a perception that its athletes were high on cocaine. Now, many people are saying the N.B.A.'s 14-year-old drug policy is so antiquated and ineffective that it protects players despite behavior that is illegal and commonplace. Under the collective bargaining agreement, the league, which begins its new season in five days, allows mandatory drug testing of rookies only, does not list marijuana as a prohibited substance, and prevents teams from testing veterans for cocaine and heroin except under rare circumstances.
"The policy is ridiculous," said Karl Malone, Utah's All-Star forward and last year's most valuable player. "Marijuana is not tested for, and yet that is the big thing guys are getting in trouble with in the league. It's terrible. What you're saying to the young kids playing in college is this: Smoke all the pot you want to, because it won't be detected until you are picked up by the cops and it's all over the newspapers."
Malone could have been talking about any of three players who were involved in marijuana cases over the summer: Philadelphia's Allen Iverson, Portland's Isaiah Rider and Toronto's Marcus Camby. A possession charge against Iverson was dropped in a plea bargain, Rider pleaded no contest on a possession charge stemming from the previous summer, and Camby agreed to do community service to avoid prosecution on a possession charge. The publicity has tarnished the polished product that Commissioner David Stern has pushed into living rooms around the globe.
According to many of the players interviewed, when the games end, the night is just beginning. Marijuana, drinking and clubs are part of a post-game party scene in almost every N.B.A. city. Cocaine, once the bane of pro basketball, has fallen out of favor, but a fast-paced life style has been thriving in a league that is increasingly richer and younger. More exotic drugs are available, including MDMA, an amphetamine also known as ecstasy or the love drug because it supposedly enhances sex.
Six years ago, the sport was stunned with the revelation that Magic Johnson had tested positive for H.I.V., prompting a graphic and painful discussion of sexual promiscuity. Now, the case of Marv Albert, the league's respected voice on network television, is only the latest evidence that the party life style associated with the game is spinning out of control. Aside from problems with marijuana, N.B.A. players have been written up in police reports on almost 20 occasions in the last year for accusations ranging from driving under the influence of alcohol to domestic violence.
Although there are no formal statistics on marijuana use in the N.B.A., many people interviewed placed the figure between 60 and 70 percent of players. One agent suggested the number was even higher.
"No one can really know, but it wouldn't surprise me if it was close to 70 percent," said Robert Pack, the Dallas point guard. "I haven't seen 70 percent of guys do it, but everyone knows guys who do. I think most of the ones who do smoke marijuana try to keep it hidden."
"You don't follow guys home, but just from what you hear, I think it's closer to 70 percent," said Derek Harper, the Orlando Magic point guard. "It's scary, because you don't know when guys are using it. You don't know if guys are under the influence while they're playing or what the case is."
Stern admitted in a recent interview that he has "serious questions concerning drinking and marijuana," and that perhaps too much attention was paid to economic issues in the last collective bargaining agreement, signed more than a year ago. If the owners decide to reopen the agreement in July, the league will propose tightening the drug policy, Stern said, by suggesting some degree of private testing that might allow the union to supervise it, and that would include marijuana. But the National Basketball Players Association has historically resisted mandatory testing and budged only a little in 1988 by agreeing to rookie testing.
"I think the union has a balancing act," Stern said. "I think anyone representing someone is fair in saying, 'Don't discriminate by asking us to take oaths and allegiances that you don't place on other people.' Saying, 'Are or have you been a member of the pot-smoking party,' is a series of words that raises a sense of witch hunting.
"But on the other hand, we do have a group of people, including players, who collectively work hard and obey the law. You have to ask yourself what additional obligations come to people in those positions. I think we and the union sort of disagree as to where you draw the line."
 
League Image Vs. Star Power
Will either side compromise? If there is enough solidarity among players who do not want an updated policy, how does a league, bankrolled by its stars, reel in the freedom it has given them in past negotiations?
"I've often heard it from players that they suspect people in management are using drugs," said Billy Hunter, the executive director of the players association. If tougher drug testing were applied to all league employees, other workers would resist just like the players, he said.
"If there is a marijuana problem, it's one reflective of society," Hunter said. "The conflict comes in because you have states around the country that are looking to legalize it. We intend to take a reasonable and prudent stance on this issue. We have a concern about player image and the success of the league. We don't want to undermine it or destroy it. But I don't intend to impose on our players more than what is imposed on people in society."
But do N.B.A. players mirror society? The average player's salary is $2.2 million, affording a life of stardom, wealth and power that can lead to a feeling of invincibility. Some players have appeared out of control, and alcohol has been a problem.
"Alcohol is a much larger problem than marijuana or the designer drugs," said the Knicks' Buck Williams, who was union president during the last collective bargaining negotiations.
Said Dennis Scott, who was traded to Dallas from Orlando during the summer: "After a game, especially if a guy has had a bad night, I've seen players drink until they pass out in their chair. If they're lucky, someone is watching their back, ready to haul them back to their hotel room."
One theory to explain widespread alcohol abuse is the increasing number of players who leave college early or bypass college to join the league without any real experience in adult society. Others believe drinking problems are associated with the pressure of trying to be a star.
In any event, players are vulnerable to the post-game party scene that frequently takes place in the clubs.
"If you do go out, the temptation will be there," Pack said. "The party atmosphere is a real lure. People you don't know want to be your best friend. It's about making the right decisions. If you expose yourself to the clubs, temptation is there waiting for you."
 
Few Offenders Are Caught
 Dumas, who was suspended after testing positive for cocaine as a rookie in 1991, was tossed out again in 1995 because he violated a clause in his contract that prohibited him from consuming alcohol.
"It's a life style that's very, very fast, and some guys don't have a grip on it," he said. "You go out to a club and you start drinking. And then some guy says, 'Hey try this.' You might be so drunk, you'll say yes."
Chances are, you will not be caught. Dumas and Roy Tarpley are the only players in the 1990's to have been barred from the league under the current policy -- which means either the league is a model in creating a drug-free zone or usage is going undetected.
Under the drug policy, teams have little opportunity to find out whether a veteran player, who might represent a huge salary investment, is using drugs. Suspicious behavior by a player -- missing flights, acting erratically, arriving at a game sleep-deprived and glassy-eyed -- is not enough reason to test him. There has to be definitive proof of drug use, such as a witness who is willing to come forward by name. Any evidence has to be presented to an arbitrator, who decides whether there should be a test.
"In all of the years I've been a general manager -- 11 years since 1986 -- I have never had a player tested," said John Nash, the Nets' General Manager. "Not that I didn't have suspicions. But I didn't have enough evidence to test a player."
This is by design, said the players association's Hunter, who is not willing to bend on this issue.
"You could have a problem player on your team, and all of the sudden he becomes a player who is under suspicion," Hunter said. "If you take action based on that suspicion, with nothing to substantiate it, it's not constitutional. I would never agree to anything like that. It's too ripe for abuse. It gives management a stick to abuse players who may not have a drug problem. They could use that as subterfuge to get to the guy because of other conduct. Testing based on suspicion is a way to control or monitor players they don't like."
The N.B.A. is a player's league, built on the marketability of the individual. Games are billed as Patrick Ewing versus Shaquille O'Neal. And this kind of star power, some people contend, is the reason mandatory drug-testing will never come to pass.
"I think it's like, be careful who you test because it might show up in some guys you don't want it to show up in," Malone said. "If I were smoking marijuana and I was tested, there should be a penalty.
"I think, if nothing else, fans have a right to know if a player is on drugs because they are paying to see them perform to the best of their ability. You should know if a player has a drug problem, but you have no way of knowing because that is unconstitutional? Give me a break. To me, if you don't want to be held to a standard, don't come into this league. If you don't want to be tested, what are you afraid of?"
Testing could also help some players who might not be able to recognize a dangerous health condition. Who knows whether Reggie Lewis of the Boston Celtics would be alive today if the league had a screening process? In July 1993, his death was officially attributed to heart damage caused by a virus. But a Wall Street Journal report in 1995 contended that Lewis had signs of heart damage consistent with cocaine use. League officials disputed the report, which undermined the perception that the N.B.A. had eradicated cocaine use by its players.
"It's not as widespread as marijuana, but cocaine is still there," Dumas said. "It's something guys have learned to keep very quiet and very low-key."
Cocaine became an N.B.A. problem after a series of arrests in the late 1970's and early 80's. That unsavory image led the union leaders Quinn Buckner, Bob Lanier and Junior Bridgeman, in concert with the league, to implement what was then considered the toughest drug policy in sports. Beginning in 1984, the policy called for an immediate ban of any player convicted of, or pleading guilty to, a crime involving cocaine or heroin. That rule still applies.
A player who believes he has a problem can come forward and receive treatment. A second request for help carries a suspension with pay, and a third leads to a suspension without pay. In the infancy of the policy, Lewis Lloyd, Mitchell Wiggins, Micheal Ray Richardson and Duane Washington were barred for cocaine use. By 1988, cocaine seemed like a designer drug that had fallen out of style.
 
Running Afoul Of the Law
 Fair or not, one name inevitably surfaces as an example of players behaving badly: Allen Iverson. On the night of Aug. 3, Iverson and two friends were pulled over by the police for traveling 93 m.p.h. on Interstate 64 in Virginia. The state trooper smelled marijuana, and soon discovered a .45-caliber pistol on the floor mat, along with marijuana cigarettes. Iverson and his friends were arrested. Iverson said the gun was his, and on Oct. 6, he pleaded no contest to a charge of carrying a concealed weapon. The marijuana charge was dropped, but as part of the plea bargain, he must undergo monthly drug testing for two years.
The league is attempting to hold players responsible for their legal behavior. This past month Stern handed down a one-game suspension for Iverson, and at the same time assessed a two-game suspension for Rider, as a way of saying enough is enough.The commissioner did not base his sanctions on the drug policy but on his power to discipline players for conduct detrimental to the league.
The subject of marijuana was raised in the last round of collective bargaining, part of an unsuccessful effort by the league to update the drug policy.
"They didn't have any substantial evidence to base a more complete program on," Buck Williams said. "We didn't want the N.B.A. to go on a witch hunt."
Deputy Commissioner Russ Granik said the league is not seeking a strictly punitive solution and is willing to expose people who work for the league to the same testing as players. "We were assured by the union that they would work to come up with a more up-to-date, comprehensive policy," Granik said. "They basically have refused to make any amendments."
And why shouldn't they refuse?
"As far as use, it's bad in the league, but I think half of America might smoke marijuana, whether you want to believe that or not," said Toronto guard Damon Stoudamire. "So I think to single out players, because of a couple of players who had incidents -- no, I don't think that's the way to go."
Other people counter that widespread marijuana use is just another symptom of a troubled league, where some players continue to push the limits of what is legal in a party-till-you-drop routine.
"As long as you perform," Dumas said, "no one is going to ask questions."
Stern disputes that notion and said the league is concerned about the physical effects of marijuana.
"There is the issue of muscle deterioration that could come with the retention of substances like marijuana in the body, and concerns about the recovery time of injuries that might be lengthened by marijuana," Stern said. "I'm not saying it's a problem. But it's an issue that we'd like to address. Beyond that, there is an opportunity for athletes to lead as examples."
A player getting high and drunk in a strip club or a hotel room is not the image the league wants drifting into the public eye.
"Playing in this league carries with it a responsibility," Malone said. "I worry about the image of this league all the time. I want to leave this league in as good or better shape than when I came. If every other guy took that approach, it would be better than picking up a paycheck and saying, 'I'm going to do what I want to because of who I am.'
"We talk about the N.B.A. not doing enough, but the responsibility has to fall on each individual. Still, everyone has to police it, from the league office to the union. You have to have cops in society. You hope you don't ever have to use them, but you have too many knuckleheads out there, too many guys doing crazy things without realizing the consequences."

CORRECTION-DATE: November 2, 1997, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
A sports article last Sunday about marijuana use in the National Basketball Association referred incorrectly to the plea made by Isaiah Rider of Portland to a charge of marijuana possession. He pleaded not guilty to the charge, not no contest. He was found guilty and fined $500, and is appealing.

HEADLINE: Children's Museum Finds Support

BYLINE: By MARY CUMMINGS 

 BODY:
THE Children's Museum of the East End does not have a space of its own. But if the seven women who thought up the idea in April 1996 and organized a pilot exhibition that opens today at Guild Hall in East Hampton have their way, it will.
"It has really been an exciting project," the principal designer of the show, Jo Ann Secor, said about the effort to establish a home. "And a whirlwind." 
 Ms. Secor, director of museum services for Lee H. Skolnick Architecture + Design in Manhattan, said that she and her husband, Lee Skolnick, the architect, had been pressed into service shortly after the director of Guild Hall, Henry Korn, had offered space to the fledgling institution and invited the committee to try out the museum idea with an exhibition that would run simultaneously with "The Moran Family Legacy" from today to Jan 11. With the East Hampton Library as co-sponsor, the exhibition features paintings by Thomas Moran, whose family was at the center of East Hampton cultural life at the turn of the century.
Ms. Secor said that Mr. Korn, who knew of the firm's work for children's museums elsewhere, introduced the couple to the committee, starting the process that led to the show, "Time and Place/Light and Space."
Mr. Skolnick and Ms. Secor, who have two school-age children, were eager to help despite a schedule that includes work for children's museums in Alabama, Florida and West Virginia.
With a house in North Haven, Ms. Secor and Mr. Skolnick were in a position to understand the committee of seven mothers of young children who live year-round in the Hamptons.
A statement by the committee said that families on the East End could feel isolated and that for all its natural beauty and rich heritage, the area lacks an inviting place for children to explore the wonders around them.
The members -- Beatrice Alda, Janet Jennings, Jorie Latham, Jaqui Leader, Jacqui Leader, Bridget LeRoy, Lucie Muhlfeld and Kari Lyn Sabin -- agreed at an initial meeting to create "a safe and fun place where young children and adults can learn together through interactive exhibits and activities."
After the group sought volunteers, Ms. Secor said, a result was an "almost 100 percent" volunteer effort, including work by carpenters andartists, as well as materials donated by merchants.
In the Hamptons, where social divisions are skewed by the presence of a super-rich summer colony and distrust can run deep between locals and newcomers, year-round residents and weekenders, suppliers of services and those they serve, the broad-based support that the committee has enlisted attests to the determination and social skills of its members.
"The committee is extraordinary," Ms. Secor said. "It's made up of very talented people. It's one thing to have the enthusiasm, another to actually apply it, put the vision down on paper and develop the program."
The committee members have a tradition of civic activity. Ms. Alda, daughter of Alan Alda, is project director. She is a trustee for a foundation that aids children at risk of problems.
Ms. Jennings, a painter, has worked with children in arts programs. Ms. Latham is a performer in schools, and Ms. Leader runs a children's theater workshop and directs the East End Special Players, a theatrical troupe with retarded people.
Ms. LeRoy is a writer and a co-founder of The East Hampton Independent and a sister paper in Southampton. Ms. Muhlfeld, a freelance fund-raiser, has taught dance, and Ms. Sabin has been a partner with her husband, Andrew, in the South Fork Natural History Society.
Using Moran, his family and the East Hampton artists' colony as a springboard, Ms. Secor said, the designers devised ideas to incorporatethe images and themes from that exhibition in their exploration of the East End in Moran's time and now.
One Moran landscape, "A Midsummer Day, East Hampton, Long Island," from 1903), was enlarged for "Time and Place." Behind "discovery doors" are sections of text on in East Hampton around 1903. A child who opens a cutout for the cow, for example, will learn, "Every house had a cow."
In accordance with current ideas on encouraging children to think creatively, the exhibit seeks to be interactive, hands-on and multimedia. Children will fish in a make-believe pond with magnetized rods. As they "shop" at a farm stand they will pick up pointers on plants, economics and the advantages of a shopping list. And when they dig into the costume bin to dress up in 19th-century clothing, Ms. Secor said, they will find out that "people were quite decorated 100 years ago, as opposed to today."
"It's a temporary installation," Ms. Secor said. "But we did design it so the entire thing could be packed up and stored for reinstallation at another time."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Volunteers installing a mural at Guild Hall, where a Children's Museum of the East End exhibition is on view. (Lois Raimondo for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Treasury Bills and Notes Scheduled for Auction During the Week

 BODY:
The Treasury's schedule of financing this week included today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and two-year and five-year notes being auctioned tomorrow and Wednesday.
By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.98 percent and the six-month bill was 5.10 percent. In when-issued trading, the two-year note was offered at a price to yield 5.75 percent and the five-year note at 5.90 percent.

HEADLINE: Who Can Afford Him?;
Stephen King Goes in Search of a New Publisher

BYLINE: By DOREEN CARVAJAL 

 BODY:
The horror. The horror. Superstar storyteller and scaremeister Stephen King is abandoning Viking, his publisher of 18 years, fleeing what seemed like a contented and placid literary relationship that spanned 44 titles from "The Dead Zone" to "Desperation."
With a strange mixture of anticipation and cold dread, a few major publishers are considering Mr. King, like classmates warily circling Carrie at the high school prom. They are pondering whether to pounce on his newly completed manuscript, "Bag of Bones," a 1,000-page novel about an author who develops writer's block after the death of his wife. 
 In fact, a handful of top New York-based publishing houses are rushing to put proposals together to land Mr. King. But many executives in the running say privately that the rare contest for a superstar author will be a test of the industry's resolve to rein in astronomical advances in a particularly bleak sales climate.
"This is really a reality check for all those people who have been saying that the business is out of control and the advances are going through the roof," said one top publishing executive participating in discussions. "We'll see how many people are going to go out there and pay a ridiculous amount of money."
By most reports, the new tome is vintage King, a gripping tale from an author so beloved that a recent trade industry survey indicated that readers would like to be marooned on a desert island with their first choice of a Bible or their second choice of a King horror novel.
But several publishing executives involved in the talks fear that even another best seller from Mr. King will almost certainly lose money in a conventional publishing deal given the asking price of more than $17 million for a "Bag of Bones."
"It's pretty impossible to make money at that level," said Paul Fedorko, the publisher at William Morrow, which is trying to piece together a proposal that would include deals with other divisions of Morrow's parent, the Hearst Corporation. "But if you can put something else together then it's worthwhile to be in business with Stephen King."
Publishers are also weighing whether the sizable advance is better spent by spreading such a sum among up-and-coming authors rather than using it for a brand name whose net sales appear to have leveled at just over a million. At times, the rhetoric coming from New York publishing houses has the distinct ring of a major league franchise owner mulling whether to put a top athlete on waivers.
"Do you want to have one superstar with a lot of utility infielders around him or do you want to have nine All Stars on the field?" said a top publisher who considered making a bid. "We're fed up. I just feel that we're doing all this work for a poor bottom line.
"I realize that life isn't fair, but it ought to be tolerable," the publisher continued. "I have no problem with building up a superstar author where everybody makes money. But to be forced to pay top dollar so you basically can make no money?"
Mr. King's work has been a staple on best-seller lists since "The Dead Zone" was published in 1979. But even best-sellerhood is a relative concept: 20 of the author's books have made The New York Times best-seller list, for instance -- but newer books tend to spend less time there.
Mr. King became a literary free agent earlier this month after negotiations for a new book deal reached an impasse with Viking, where he had long been considered the undisputed pillar of the publishing house, both under his own name and his pen name, Richard Bachman.
But recently, Mr. King was forced to share the rarefied air of superstar status after Viking's corporate parent, the British media conglomerate Pearson P.L.C., acquired the Putnam Berkley Group early this year and created Penguin Putnam Inc. That brought into the same luxury stable the author Tom Clancy, whose sales record far outstripped Mr. King's. In 1996, according to Publishers Weekly, Mr. Clancy sold more than 2.4 million copies of "Executive Orders" while Mr. King sold 1.5 million of his books.
In the top echelon of the publishing industry, the conventional wisdom is that Mr. King was bolting Penguin Putnam because he was irked that Mr. Clancy negotiated a more lucrative deal. In August, Penguin Putnam announced a complex new deal with Mr. Clancy that includes a partnership to develop on-line games and the publication of two novels.
Penguin Putnam officials declined to reveal the total cost, but publishing executives estimate that Mr. Clancy could earn more than $20 million for each book, which does not include money spent on the on-line ventures, bringing the estimated total of the deal to nearly $100 million. In his last deal with Penguin, Mr. King earned almost $16 million for each book based on a four-book sale for $63.5 million.
The bottom line for Penguin Putnam is apparently the view that Mr. Clancy sells so many books that he will earn a profit even with a sizable advance.
Mr. King, who lives in Maine, was unavailable for comment. His lawyer and agent of 10 years, Arthur B. Greene, said the author was traveling in Australia.
Mr. Greene said that Mr. King decided to sever ties with Penguin Putnam after reaching an "impasse," which he declined to describe. "There were aspects that he wasn't satisfied with. He became a bit stale," Mr. Greene said, adding that he was referring to the author's treatment and growth.
Mr. Greene said he had "no idea" how much Tom Clancy made on his contract with Penguin Putnam and that Mr. King was simply searching for a "new enduring relationship." Mr. Greene also declined to elaborate in detail about what Mr. King is hunting for, but he said, "it's the publishing strategy principally and, of course, financial considerations."
Mr. King's spurned publisher, Penguin Putnam, is saying little publicly while keenly watching the actions of its rivals. Although Mr. Greene said that Mr. King's relationship with Penguin Putnam is over, Marilyn Ducksworth, a senior vice president for the company, said gamely that, "as far as we're concerned we are still in negotiations."
But despite that belief, several publishing companies started receiving query letters from Mr. King's attorney last week when many of their top executives were away at the Frankfurt Book Fair.
"After being published for more than 20 years by one company, Stephen King has decided to make a change," the letter stated. "We're contacting a small group of publishers and are indicating to them that Mr. King is looking to establish another longstanding relationship, which will be artistically and financially beneficial to all parties."
The news was so surprising that one publisher thought it was a joke.
"Here's a guy who has been a success," said Mr. Fedorko, the publisher at Morrow. "What happened? What is going on here? Is this a scam of some sort? Frankly, I thought it was a friend kidding me."
The query letter from Mr. King's attorney set a Wednesday deadline for submission of proposals, but that deadline was eventually extended and several publishers met with the lawyer late last week.
The letter did not specify the asking price for "Bag of Bones," but in meetings it became clear to participants that the focus of Mr. King's search for a new publisher was not a literary issue, but simply business -- with an asking price of more than $17 million.
Mr. King was not present at any of the meetings, a fact that some publishers found troubling because typically authors participate in significant negotiations. Several said that Mr. King's lawyer listened sympathetically to their concerns that it would be difficult to make money on Mr. King at his present sales levels. But they were told that the author expected a new publisher to make greater efforts than Viking to increase sales.
"There was an air of unreality to the meeting," said one publisher, who said he left feeling like the imprisoned character in the Stephen King book "Misery," which was made into a film in 1990 about a writer tortured by a psychotic outraged over a plot twist.
And so that leaves publishers playing out the standard tension scenes of any horror movie as they warily pass each other in Manhattan restaurants. Will a competitor take the plunge and pay Mr. King an enormous advance?
"What's interesting about this is to see whether all this talk about a recession in the book business has had some impact," said one of the players.
"All it takes," he added, "is one."

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Technology Stocks Hit By Variety Of Problems

BYLINE: BY DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
Technology stocks, the perennial leaders of the current bull market, are under fire.
Since mid-April, when the stock market began surging out of a sharp decline, technology issues had been leaders of the pack, helping lift the broader market to record after record high. 
 But for the last two weeks, the share prices of technology companies have been plunging on everything from fears that earnings growth could be decelerating at home to worries about economic turmoil abroad.
The strength of technology -- now considered a bellwether sector -- is critical because the market is at an impasse. Yet several analysts interviewed over the weekend suggested that mounting problems in the once high-flying technology sector could spell further trouble for a market already seething with anxiety.
Last week, the Dow Jones industrial average rose as high as 8,060.44 on Tuesday, before plummeting 345.03 points, or 4.3 percent, over the next three days. The fall was triggered by a currency crisis that began in Thailand earlier in the year, but quickly spread across Southeast Asia and into Hong Kong, where stock prices plunged 18 percent in the week.
And with an Asian financial crisis threatening to further disrupt world markets this week, some analysts are nervous that a weakening technology sector might precipitate a steep fall in the broad market here.
"The reality is the market has placed a great burden on technology companies to perform above the bar because prices have been bid up so high," said Charles Federman, chairman of Broadview Associates, a technology banker in Fort Lee, N.J. "The companies are fundamentally sound, but their growth rates can't keep up with their stock prices. So I think we're going to see a raft of earnings disappointments."
To be sure, many analysts say that third quarter earnings growth in the sector has been robust, and the fundamentals of many of technology companies remain sound.
Yet slowly but surely, questions are arising. Is the technology industry headed for a slump? Personal computer sales growth appears to be slowing, and overcapacity in the industry has led to a sharp drop in the prices of computers and memory chips. In fact, an entire legion of big name companies -- from Intel to Silicon Graphics -- have issued warnings about slowing earnings prospects.
"The deterioration has been coming for a long time," said Fred Hickey, an independent analyst who publishes The High-Tech Strategist, a newsletter. "The investors are finally beginning to connect the dots."
Among Mr. Hickey's concerns are price pressures, declining growth rates and the rapidly souring prospects of doing business in Asia, which many companies had looked to as a potential growth vehicle.
These concerns helped undermine a rally early Friday, as the United States stock markets attempted to follow the lead of European and Hong Kong exchanges, which had rebounded earlier that day from a steep fall on Thursday.
When the wreckage was overturned, technology issues had taken a beating, partly because Intel said it would postpone opening a $1.3 billion plant because of weakening demand for its computer chips.
"Intel is one of the bellwethers of technology, so when investors see that kind of change, they get concerned," said Gus Richard, an analyst at Hambrecht & Quist in San Francisco. "Semiconductor companies tend to move in herds. If one starts spending, they all start spending; and if one stops spending they all stop."
Mr. Richard said that although the downturn in Asia is not a direct threat to the broad technology sector, semiconductor capital equipment makers would be hurt by turmoil in the Pacific Rim, which accounts for about 40 percent of their business. If Asian companies in the computer chip pipeline suffer, demand for American products could also suffer.
As a result, the Philadelphia Semiconductor Index -- one of this year's best performers -- plunged 5.2 percent on Friday, and is down 16.7 percent in a month. A broader technology measure, the Pacific Stock Exchange Technology Index, also took a beating, dropping 2.5 percent.
Technology stocks tend to be volatile, largely because their high share prices, analysts said. And so if earnings disappoint, or sentiment shifts, those stocks get hammered.
Also, the same kind of momentum investing that helped push the value of the technology sector up to $1.5 trillion -- or 13 percent of the US stock market -- can just as quickly reverse course when the news turns sour.
One question is: just how strong are the companies. While some analysts, like Roger McNamee at Integral Capital Partners in San Francisco, argue that technology companies are resilient and that the recent selloff creates "a massive buying opportunity," others aren't too sure.
"There are manic bulls out there," Mr. Hickey said. "If there is one company doing well, they'll say everything's fine. The fact is: when you have p/e's in the 50's, you can't have decelerating growth rates."
Indeed, Mr. Hickey and others believe the industry's wounds are being masked by the performances of a handful of high-profile companies, such as Dell and Microsoft. Many other computer companies, from Acer to Gateway, are facing weakening prospects, they say, partly because of the introduction of more inexpensive personal computers.
But Charles Hill, director of research at First Call Inc., which tracks earnings reports, suggests that the threat of technology, one of the pillars of this bull market, tumbling over is a little premature.
Third-quarter earnings are up an average of 14 percent for the bigger companies, thus far, and smaller companies are up even more. The problem is: many of these firms are not keeping pace with expectations.
"The difference for technology this time is we're only meeting expectations, while we were beating them in the first and second quarter," he said.

LENGTH: 1151 words

HEADLINE: Station Weighs Local Appeal Against Ready-Made Programs

BYLINE: By DEBORAH SHAPLEY 

DATELINE: READING, Pa.

 BODY:
Maybe it is the barking of the ownerless dogs penned in the county humane society across the street. Maybe it is the lingering scare from the explosion at the neighboring gas processing plant, which sent a brick through the station manager's window.
There are plenty of reasons why the staff of Reading Broadcasting Inc. has been tense behind the tidy white facade of WTVE-TV Channel 51 on North 11th Street. The station, like many of the nation's small, independent commercial broadcasters, has become an economically endangered species, thanks in part to the 1996 Telecommunications Act. 
 WTVE must attract more viewers or face stagnation.
For the small UHF station, time is literally money. Air time is its currency. Its owners are constantly preoccupied with the question of how much of this time they must sell to the producers of canned programming and how much of it they can afford to keep for locally produced or otherwise distinctive fare that has special attraction in their area.
The former brings in steady revenue at little cost but also offers little growth potential. The latter is the key to growth -- but, without the access to deep pockets that chain ownership gives to their rivals, WTVE's owners can ill afford to spend too much of the station's air time on these offerings.
The results of this weekly balancing act can be read in the station's weekly program guide.
Until last year, WTVE broadcast HSN Inc.'s Home Shopping Network for 22 hours a day. But, said Peter Bowman of BIA Media Inc., a consulting firm in Chantilly, Va., "Historically, the key to broadcast success has been localism."
So WTVE's owners decided to change the mix. Now about 75 percent of the station's 168-hour weekly broadcast time is sold to distributors of canned programming and infomercials. The station obtains some vintage situation comedies like "The Adventures of Dobie Gillis" for free in exchange for commercial time.
On a recent Sunday, for instance, Reading viewers who clicked away from network affiliates in Harrisburg (50 miles west) and Philadelphia (40 miles southeast) could start the day with WTVE's "Bethany Hour" and "Love of God," then watch "Woods and Wetlands" and "North American Fish and Game."
After that, the station's 1,200-kilowatt tower atop nearby Mount Penn sent out seven hours of marketing pitches for such items as exercise equipment or spray to cover bald spots, followed by two hours of "My Mom's a Werewolf." At 6 P.M., it was time for Sunday's single local show, "La Tarde Alegre."
The sale of 120 hours of air time a week to program distributors brings the station three-quarters of its annual revenue of more than $1 million.
The buyers are Master Media Enterprises Inc. of Fort Mill, S.C., which distributes the Sunday religious fare; Baer Media of Southaven, Miss., which distributes the outdoors programs, and the Paxson Communications Corporation, which delivers WTVE's viewers 15 hours of infomercials a day, and, finally, purveyors of local infomercials.
With that revenue, the station pays the salaries of its 30-person staff (30 percent of its overhead), its electric bill (15 percent of its expenses) and the remaining payments under an arrangement that brought it out of bankruptcy in 1985.
For Mike Parker, the station's de facto owner, who wants to build the station's identity as an appealing local broadcaster in touch with its community, the high point of the Sunday schedule comes with "La Tarde Alegre," a one-hour Hispanic community affairs show produced in WTVE's studio by a Hispanic businessman who also finds advertisers for the show.
At other times during the week, the station broadcasts videotaped events like the Saturday games of the Hershey Bears ice hockey team, with ad time sold to local merchants like the owners of Jack O'Reilly's Tuxedos. Other locally produced shows include "Healthbeat" and "Elderly Update."
"These get us away from the image of just being watched by people by the telephone with their credit cards," said the station's program manager, Dan Bendetti, who is also its local advertising salesman.
Mr. Parker said he thought local programming would set WTVE apart from its larger rivals. And, thanks to a Supreme Court decision last March requiring that cable companies carry most local broadcasters' signals, WTVE's signal now reaches more than a million households, he said.
Mr. Parker obtained 25 percent of the station in 1993 when it emerged from bankruptcy and now has a 33 percent stake. A turnaround specialist, Mr. Parker recently sold WHRC-TV Channel 46 in Boston to Paxson.
The 1996 Telecommunications Act set off a wave of broadcast mergers and buyouts by lifting the limit on the number of stations a single entity can own. Now an owner may have any number of properties so long as its total national audience does not exceed 35 percent. Radio and television acquisitions reached a record $25.4 billion last year.
But despite Congress's stated intention -- to unleash market forces and increase the diversity of voices the public hears -- the number of television station owners has declined. "The independent commercial station will go the way of the corner store when Wal-Mart moves to town," Mr. Bowman said.
"There are 76 fewer TV broadcasters today than just before the Telecom Act was enacted," Mr. Bowman added. The number of owners dropped by 16 percent between January 1996 and mid-October of this year, to 395. The exit of smaller, poorer stations may be inevitable, he said. But, he added, "The merger wave increases the stratification of have-not stations at the bottom."
Some stations in Harrisburg, at the western edge of WTVE's broadcast signal, have benefited from the trend. This city's 584,000 households constituted little more than a television backwater until 1995, when a unit of Clear Channel Communications Inc. paid $30 million for a Harrisburg UHF station. The Allbritton Communications Company, a subsidiary of the privately owned Perpetual Corporation, paid $113 million for another in 1996. The Tribune Broadcasting Company, the nation's fourth-largest chain, bought a UHF station in nearby York.
That has not yet happened in Reading.
But, even while fighting a challenge to the station's license by the Adams Communications Corporation of Chicago, WTVE's owners are planning to pay $1.5 million for a new signal tower that could reach tens of thousands more households in the Philadelphia area.
With a unique identity and more potential viewers, Mr. Parker wants to be one of the first local stations to broadcast digital signals.
Then would he sell to a chain?
"I have a responsibility to my shareholders to maximize market value," Mr. Parker said. "But the same economics that apply to a sale apply to operating a good station. As the revenue goes up, the quality of local programming can go up, and the more valuable the asset is."

Deficit Falls to $22.6 Billion As Tax Revenues Surge
President Clinton will announce today that the Federal budget deficit for the just-completed fiscal year fell to $22.6 billion, its lowest level in decades, largely as a result of strong economic growth that has created a surge in Federal tax revenues. The Administration started the year expecting a deficit of $128 billion. 
 With the nation's fiscal condition improving so rapidly, Republicans in Congress are already talking openly about the deficit being wiped out, and are debating how best to spend any surpluses. Page A1.
 
Deal for Mortgage Company
National Australia Bank Ltd. plans to acquire Homeside Inc., a home mortgage company based in Florida, in a deal valued at more than $1 billion. A14.
 
Secret Sale of I.B.M. Computers
Defying the United States, a Russian nuclear weapons laboratory secretly acquired 16 advanced I.B.M. computers late last year, using Moscow-based middlemen. A Federal grand jury is examining whether I.B.M. violated laws governing the sale of computers to nuclear weapons installations. A1.

Charting Operating System Limits
At its core, the Justice Department's clash with Microsoft over the Internet Explorer Web browswer involves a single but not-so-simple question: What belongs in a computer's basic operating system? D5.

Out of His Own Pocket
The mantle of world's richest man seems to be resting easier these days on the shoulders of William H. Gates. Upgrading from coach, the chairman of Microsoft bought himself a $21 million private jet. D9.
 
Rap Artists Doubling Up
In a sign that rap music is moving further toward the mainstream, increasing numbers of performers are releasing double-disk sets. The trend is lending a lift to overall music industry sales. D11.
 
Advertisers Reappraise
Marketers of everything from cars to cleaning products changed advertising agencies late last week, affecting accounts with nearly $200 million in billings. D13.
 
Trawling for the Evening News
At a time when television news teams routinely scrabble for plum items, CBS is seeking to exploit the informal connection between print journalism and broadcast news. It has offered substantial fees to newspaper reporters who feed it usable -- and exclusive -- items. Iver Peterson: Broadcasting. D11.
 
A Church on the Electronic Frontier
Bishop Jacques Gaillot has turned a deserted parish deep in the Sahara into an on-line sanctuary, creating the first cyberspace diocese. Edward Rothstein: Technology. D6.
 
Computer Game to Debut, Finally
Riven, the sequel to the best-selling computer game ever, will hit stores this week. Although it cost millions to develop and will be a year late, its makers hope it can build on the phenomenal success of its genre-busting predecessor, Myst. D5.
 
Environmentalism in Cyberspace
El Nino and the intense smog in Southeast Asia have pushed environmental issues to the front of the news. For anyone seeking to more than the headlines, the Web offers a wealth of information. Taking In the Sites. D6.
