HEADLINE: An Indefensible Treaty

BYLINE: By Jack Kemp; Jack Kemp is a co-chairman of the Alexis de Tocqueville Institution and a co-director of Empower America.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Imagine a nuclear arms reduction treaty in which three nuclear powers -- say, Russia, France and China -- committed to no specific reductions while other nations disarmed. It seems absurd.
Now imagine negotiating a global climate change treaty to reduce carbon emissions, but with no specific commitments from 3 of the 10 biggest carbon producers, and without even a clear global target. It seems equally absurd. 
 Clearly this is the view of the Senate, which in late July passed a resolution by a 95 to 0 vote stating that the United States should not sign any climate change agreement unless it "mandates new specific scheduled commitments to limit or reduce greenhouse emissions for developing countries and would not result in serious harm to the economy."
Frankly, even if these conditions are met, the President should sign no treaty. Whether humans are influencing the climate is unknown. Despite the mantra from the Clinton Administration that the science is settled, it is not. The May issue of Science magazine made this clear. So too did the Heidelberg Appeal, a petition signed by hundreds of distinguished scientists urging against precipitous action.
Bert Bolin, who directed the United Nations scientific report on the issue, disagrees with President Clinton's and Vice President Gore's belief that climate change is causing more violent and unpredictable weather. This year, even the Sierra Club's conservation director, Bruce Hamilton, admitted, "If you look at the science, it's all over the board."
But even if you buy the premise behind global warming, this treaty is indefensible. A "global" warming treaty is no such thing if it omits developing nations where most growth in emissions will take place. This includes China, Brazil, Mexico, South Korea and other developing nations, which are expected to produce 60 percent of global carbon emissions in the next few decades. In fact, China is expected to become the biggest carbon producer on the planet.
By failing to include developing nations, we are working against the very purpose of a treaty intended to address the worrisome potential problems of global warming.
Yet the Clinton Administration seems to be pursuing just such an agreement in the negotiations leading up to December's international global climate change meeting in Kyoto, Japan.
In his recent speech outlining his position, the President said the "United States will not assume binding obligations unless key developing nations meaningfully participate in this effort." But what does "key" mean? Does the President intend to sign a treaty that does not include other nations, say, China, Brazil or Mexico? If so, he should say so.
Moreover, with the December treaty deadline fast approaching, our Government has not conducted its own thorough analyses of the treaty's impact on the American economy nor has it embraced any of the many macroeconomic studies already produced.
How can such far-reaching policy be negotiated without a thorough examination of the treaty's effects on the economy, American workers and communities? How can we find solutions that protect workers and communities without first identifying specific global goals? How can we protect ourselves from economic upheaval without honest public analysis of the economic impact associated with the lower carbon emission plan that would be imposed? We have hard work to do before we make hasty agreements.
As Bill Cunningham, a spokesman for the A.F.L.-C.I.O., noted in a statement delivered last March:
"Let there be no mistake, whatever happens with respect to greenhouse, it will be working people who finally pay most of the cost. Whatever taxes governments raise, whatever regulation they impose, whatever measures business introduces -- it will be working people who finally must implement the changes and pay much of the cost."
Taking time to act intelligently will serve us all better than trying to live with a flawed agreement.

LENGTH: 440 words

HEADLINE: Smart Rules for Health Plans

 BODY:
The "bill of rights" for patients that was tentatively approved last week by a Presidential commission would, if adopted by Congress, build in sensible consumer protections without strangling health plans with innovation-killing rules. There are important holes in the commission's work, but on the whole its draft is promising.
The rise of managed care has brought innovative coverage and a surprisingly swift deceleration of health care inflation. But managed care imposes obstacles to choosing doctors and treatments and can reward plans that skimp on care. The insecurity surrounding managed care has triggered calls for Government action, and Congress is inundated with ill-conceived bills that would dictate how health plans treat patients. President Clinton deftly cut off the rush to legislate by appointing the commission, which will reconvene in November to adopt a final report. 
 The draft requires disclosure of key information -- such as the number of times surgeons have performed specific operations and their outcomes -- so that consumers can judge which plans are best. The draft also guarantees consumers the right to appeal to an external authority their plan's decision to deny care for a treatment that the patient believes was covered by the plan's contract. The commission's focus is exactly right. Patients can feel secure about their health plan only if they have enough information and a right to appeal denials of promised benefits.
The commission's report is also interesting for what it does not say. On the positive side, it does not delve into specific mandates, like restrictions on the right to hire and fire doctors, that would raise costs and crimp flexibility. Anything that raises medical costs leads employers -- which cover most non-elderly Americans -- to drop health coverage entirely. On the negative side, the plan does not say how to implement any of its recommendations.
The plan also sidesteps the crucial component of a consumer-friendly health care system: choice. The best way to achieve choice is to require that employers give employees a choice of health plans. Only when consumers can drop one plan for another will their needs drive what health plans do, rather than the other way around. The commission need not fear that employers will drop coverage when faced with a mandate to offer choices. In fact, the evidence is clear that employers save money on premiums when they set up competition among employee health plans.
Of course the biggest hole in the commission's plan is not of its doing. Nothing in a bill of rights can cover 40 million uninsured Americans.

HEADLINE: Carl Feiss, a Pioneer of Urban Preservation, Dies at 90

BYLINE: By ROBERT McG. THOMAS Jr. 

 BODY:
Carl Feiss, a visionary architect and pioneering urban planner who helped transform the science of clearing slums into the art of historic preservation, died on Oct. 10 at a retirement home in Gainesville, Fla. He was 90 and had played an important role in historic restorations in Charleston, S.C., Savannah, Ga.. Annapolis, Md., Alexandria, Va., and scores of other cities in the United States and abroad.
Mr. Feiss was one of the first of the professional planners who emerged in the 1930's to elevate what had been a grab bag of activities by civil engineers and other municipal officials into a distinct discipline. In the forefront of his field almost from the beginning, he ended his career teaching a new generation of planners at the University of Florida. 
 Mr. Feiss, whose father was a men's clothing manufacturer, grew up in an artistic Cleveland household. (Mr. Feiss was a lifelong painter.) He earned a degree in architecture from the University of Pennsylvania, spent three years teaching at the Cranbrook Academy of Art in Bloomfield Hills, Mich., and then obtained one of the first master's degrees in urban planning offered by the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
Within a year of receiving his degree, in 1938 at age 31, he had been made the director of the housing and planning division of the Columbia University School of Architecture. He had also become deeply involved in zoning and other planning issues in New York City.
Although he was so devoted to public construction projects that he once suggested that the much-maligned form might someday produce an American Parthenon, from the start Mr. Feiss was a planner with a difference. He advocated low-density, low-cost development of vacant land and tangled with New York's master builder, Robert Moses, over grandiose plans to build expensive public housing on the rubble of cleared slums.
He then spent five years in Denver, where he ran the city's planning commission, established an urban planning department at the University of Denver and helped found the Denver Art Museum. Mr. Feiss went to Washington in 1950 as the chief planner for slum clearance for the forerunner of the Department of Housing and Urban Development and had an epiphany.
At a time when urban renewal generally meant bulldozing neighborhoods to make way for modern steel-and-concrete structures, Mr. Feiss decided that for all their rundown condition, many buildings being swept away were architectural or historic gems whose restoration could be the basis for renewal of an invaluable municipal heritage.
He left his post in Washington in 1955 and became an independent consultant. He led the campaign that produced the Federal Historic Preservation Act of 1966 and a National Register of Historic Places, and was a sought-after expert on the complexities of historic preservation.
Mr. Feiss, whose clients included state, county and city agencies from Connecticut to Bogota, Colombia, hardly invented the notion of preserving and restoring rundown neighborhoods of architectural or historic significance. The idea, long the province of the docent class, generated almost too much support: at a time when the bulldoze-and-build approach offered the advantage of straightforward simplicity, the trick of historic preservation was to get an assortment of often squabbling civic groups, public agencies, elected officials and private businesses to work together.
Mr. Feiss, who wrote and lectured widely on the subject and all but invented the methodology of preservation, was a master at coordinating an intricate array of tasks: creating an inventory of worthy buildings, mapping district lines, obtaining necessary zoning and other legislation, creating and enacting economic revitalization plans and arranging creative financing.
Success did not occur overnight. He spent seven years working on the Savannah project, for example.
His spirit, determination and attention to detail were not limited to his professional life. On visits to the great James River plantations of Virginia, he would pinch a bit of the ancient boxwoods, then plant them at his home in the Cleveland Park section of Washington, where he would proudly identify each bush by the plantation it was from.
He is survived by his wife, Alleen, of Falls Church, Va.; two daughters, Alison Kriviskey of Falls Church and Caroline Feiss of Seattle; a sister, Gertrude Feiss of New York City, and two grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Christine Whitman for Governor

 BODY:
For most of this year, the New Jersey gubernatorial race sputtered along with little drama. Early surveys showed Gov. Christine Todd Whitman ahead, helped by the state's improved economy, the drop in crime and welfare rolls and, not least, her record of cutting taxes as she promised four years ago. Lately, James McGreevey, a State Senator and the Mayor of Woodbridge, has gained, hammering the Governor over school standards, soaring property taxes and auto insurance rates. Mrs. Whitman, a rising star in the Republican firmament a few years ago, is fighting back hard in a tight race that is drawing national attention.
Today we endorse Mrs. Whitman for re-election, though the choice was not easy. Mrs. Whitman is an impressive politician with an excellent command of issues. But her 30 percent income-tax cut, which we opposed, has damaged the state's fiscal health because it was largely financed by a raid on the state pension systems. Mrs. Whitman compounded the error this year with a $2.7 billion bond issue to keep the pension system solvent. On the other hand, the Governor has compiled a solid record on the environment and education issues. Her approach to helping people on welfare find work has been humane. She has championed abortion rights, affirmative action and other causes of the moderate wing of the Republican Party. If she wins, she can help her party get beyond its punitive agenda in Washington. 
 There is much to like about Mr. McGreevey, a little-known but energetic politician who came from behind to win the Democratic primary in September. Contrasting his own working-class background with that of the patrician Governor, he has attacked Mrs. Whitman's fiscal policies, called for higher school standards and demanded action to lower New Jersey's car insurance rates, the nation's highest. But Mr. McGreevey has failed to offer a coherent explanation of how he would meet his promises. He cannot escape having voted in the State Legislature for Mrs. Whitman's tax cut, and he has not said where he would get the money to pay for upgrading schools as well as the state aid that would help local districts cut property taxes.
Like many Republicans, Mrs. Whitman entered office promising to bring sensible business practices to government. Her privatization schemes have largely fizzled, but the Governor bargained hard with state unions and in general kept the cost of government under control. The impact of her worst mistakes, the tax and pension schemes, was mitigated by economic good times.
One of the trickiest problems tackled by Mrs. Whitman has been the state's response to State Supreme Court rulings demanding more spending for poor students. The issue has tormented New Jersey governors for over two decades as the state's highest court repeatedly demanded parity in spending between rich and poor districts. Mrs. Whitman's approach has been to argue for moving away from arbitrary spending levels, toward education standards and accountability. The court found merit to her argument but still insisted on more money for impoverished districts. The Governor and the Legislature found the funds, and they now must follow through on their promise to achieve the high standards they say they want.
Like some politicians, Mrs. Whitman is most distinguished by the enemies she has made. The Republican right wing has reviled her for the sin of favoring affirmative action, abortion rights and equal treatment of homosexuals. In backing Senator Bob Dole last year, she warned the party not to turn its back on moderates. In the battles on Capitol Hill over welfare and Medicaid spending, Mrs. Whitman has played a visible role, demanding that Republican Congressional leaders support programs that help the urban centers of the North. The Governor turns aside questions about running for higher office if she wins re-election, a sensible position given her current political troubles. But we hope that with a victory at home, she will not hesitate to demand humane national policies on education, the environment, race and treatment of the poor.

HEADLINE: Study Predicts Food Gap for Poor Countries

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

 BODY:
A survey of what people will be eating -- and feeding their animals -- into the first two decades of the next century finds that problems from rising consumer demands to falling water tables could create huge food gaps in the poorest countries despite their economic growth.
Imports of meat and cereals are likely to rise in countries that once were largely self-sufficient, benefiting exporting nations like the United States, Australia and Argentina but making the cost of feeding families in developing nations higher, says the survey, which was done by a unit of the World Bank. 
 A report on the survey published yesterday, "The World Food Situation: Recent Developments, Emerging Issues and Long-Term Prospects," says that improvements in living standards in a world growing by 80 million people a year put pressure on food stocks at a time when there are no prospects of another green revolution to guarantee increased agricultural yields.
The report says that increases in yields of major cereal crops, including wheat, rice and corn, are expected to slow in the next 25 years, following already slower growth since 1982.
Stepped-up grain production is reaching the limit of what it is possible to produce, especially in Asia, the study found. In the richer countries, especially in Europe, opposition to genetically altered foodstuffs slows research, hurting poorer countries that need larger crops most.
The demand for meat, mostly poultry and beef, is rising everywhere, the report says, but is growing fastest in developing countries. In 1993, poorer countries accounted for 47 percent of the world's meat demand. By 2020, these countries could be consuming 63 percent of meat products.
Given such consumption changes, huge questions loom over China and India, which together have almost half the world's people.
Better living standards and changing tastes that come with urbanization could strain the world's food supplies on a still unpredictable scale, the report's researchers concluded.
The report was prepared by the International Food Policy Research Institute in Washington for the Consultative Group on International Agricultural Research at the World Bank.

HEADLINE: THE 1997 ELECTIONS;
McGreevey Lists Priorities: Schools, a Master Plan and Economic Development

DATELINE: EDISON, N.J., Oct. 23

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from an interview with James E. McGreevey conducted today by editors and reporters from The New York Times.
Q. How would the first state budget, if you are elected, reflect your values? What would be the top three areas where you would seek to increase spending, and then as a follow-up, what would be the areas that you would protect from spending cuts? 
 McGREEVEY There are three broad areas that I think are of essential concern to New Jersey. And how we do it and how we plan for it.
One is the state master plan. Tom Kean developed a master plan, which is basically collecting dust on a shelf. No teeth, no implementation. And the reason why, every mayor has a master plan required by state law to know where there's housing or where there's industrial development and where there's commercial development.
My concern is -- as a state -- is that we've had these tremendous cities in the state of New Jersey and people left our cities and they continue to move out and out and out and out. And by contrast you can drive 60 miles outside of London and still see green hills. Because it's how we approach, we have a disposal-driven mentality. . . .
Secondly, of major concern is education is a critical concern. And we all know the litany. We spend more money than any state in the nation on education, but only a small percentage of that gets in the classroom. Fifty percent more to administrative costs. The standards stink. We don't teach our kids the difference between right and wrong. We don't have school-based performance standards. We don't have a mentoring program. Our students are spending only 42 percent studying core academic subjects. . . .
Q. Let's say, take three state agencies. What would be the agency in state government that you would protect from budget cuts?
A. We were talking about education. We were talking about planning and also talking about economic development. And in terms of the state budget per se -- can I -- I'd like to go back to education for a second and talk about how we spend those dollars.
What I would do, not just in terms of dollars, but in terms of education, I think we need an education blueprint in the state of New Jersey. A specific model of where we want to be. A specific model of what education will look like in the state of New Jersey, between birth and between whether it's secondary school, community college or university training. And that includes an outline of how we're going to spend our resources, what the standards are going to look like and where we're going to put our money. And we know we spend about $12 billion a year on education. But it's also about how we spend that money and what are those standards. . . .
None of this is easy in the sense of developing consensus. I mean, I tore down a town hall in Woodbridge and I had 12 town meetings all throughout Woodbridge to build a consensus. None of this is going to be easy. . . .
We have to spend less on administration. I mean that has to happen. But we have to develop consensus about how that's going to accomplish -- you know -- the obvious cases are the egregious, you know, the buyouts, the quarter of a million dollars of sick time, and how we're going to reduce 50 percent -- we're 50 percent above the national average in administrative costs; how we're going to get more money in the classrooms; what the classroom day is going to look like.
Q. Are you outlining a series of town meetings over nine months?
A. Yes. I would do with people to develop consensus on -- but it, I mean, it's on different focuses. It's on primary, I mean pre-pre-k, primary, secondary and then post-secondary in terms of technical training and univer---- we have excellent universities. That question is more just a question of affordability.
Q. What percentage of your time in the first nine months would you devote to developing this consensus?
A. On education? I would say 20 percent.
Q. Where do you think you'd spend the other 80 percent?
A. In addition to the budget itself, I think another approximately 25 percent of my time would be working with the business community and the labor community in targeting economic development and job opportunities and beginning to develop a rational plan for attracting specific job growth and job industries to the state of New Jersey.
And lastly, the remaining of my time is working with mayors and municipalities, in improving the excellence of municipal government. You know, as Mayor I recognize the limitations that mayors have. But municipal government is the level of government which most directly deals with individual citizens and providing for excellence and also insuring the greatest return for our tax dollar.
Q. Mr. McGreevey, you had said in interviews and on the campaign trail that the tax crisis facing New Jersey residents today is a property tax crisis. And you have talked about, if elected, creating a commission which would then make recommendations on changing the tax structure in New Jersey. What would you ask this commission to look at?
A. The long-term goal is to obviously reduce the reliance on property taxes. Long-term goal.
Short-term goal is to undo the damage that Governor Whitman has wrought on the citizens of the state. And that is the substantial reduction of state aid funding to school districts and municipalities.
The state share has dropped from 42 percent to 37 percent. Middle-class property-tax payers across the state are getting hammered. I would dedicate up to 50 percent of increased revenues to targeting specific for school district property tax relief.
Q. On your auto insurance plan, and we have discussed this, that on your brochure it suggests that you support changes in how auto insurance rates are determined based on geography, based on where you live in New Jersey. And Governor Whitman has strongly suggested that you're telling different audiences in New Jersey different things about your position on this issue, which would lower rates for some urban drivers. However, there's some belief it would increase rates for some suburban drivers.
A. Yes. I would not end demographic rating.
Q. You would not end demographic----
A. Rating or geographic rating. It's not a matter of pitting urban drivers versus suburban drivers. It's a matter of having a governor on the side of the driver as opposed to the insurance company.
The Governor granted 12 discretionary rate increases over the four increases that were automatically given.
The Governor abolished the Public Advocate. Literally, there is no one in the room to represent our interest. It's the insurance companies and the department of insurance. Governor Kean, Governor Byrne, Governor Florio: all had a public advocate to represent our interest. It was this Governor who abolished the Public Advocate. Literally, no one speaks for the public. This system is wholly out of kilter.

HEADLINE: U.S. Lowers Goals on China After Glitches in Early Talks

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER and DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26

 BODY:
When President Jiang Zemin meets President Clinton on Wednesday in the first state visit of a Chinese leader in a dozen years, there is likely to be a nuclear agreement and possibly one to provide American assistance to clear China's air pollution from its coal-fired power plants.
There will be talk of a new age of economic cooperation, greased by at least $4 billion or more in freshly signed deals, more than half with Boeing. 
 Naturally there will also be plenty of food and plenty of champagne. And the White House will declare, as its top officials have been saying for weeks now, that the main accomplishment of this summit meeting is that it is happening at all.
But that declaration is making a virtue of necessity, senior Administration officials privately admit, because the months of frenzied pre-summit negotiations between Chinese and American officials have produced significantly less than once hoped.
The agreement to get China to reduce its dangerous exports of nuclear expertise will be the substantive centerpiece of Wednesday's meeting, and it will clear the way for billions of dollars in sales of American nuclear power plants to a country whose economic ambitions outstrip its electrical capacity. China has also promised to stop selling anti-ship cruise missiles to Iran, reducing threats to American naval ships in the Persian Gulf and helping to mute Republican criticism of Mr. Jiang's visit.
But the once-feverish discussions about getting China to open its markets to foreign competition, especially with state-owned enterprises that are attempting a perilous transition to private ownership, have all but stalled -- and with it, China's hopes that this summit meeting would speed its entry into the World Trade Organization.
In other areas, progress will be at best incremental, senior officials say, and the main importance of this meeting is to provide a new beginning for what they concede has been the single most badly handled foreign policy of Mr. Clinton's Presidency.
In a speech on Friday, Mr. Clinton reiterated the need for broad engagement with China -- "expanding areas of cooperation, dealing forthrightly with our differences" in order to "advance fundamental American interests and values."
But his defense of this visit by Mr. Jiang seemed passionless, and his critics are bound to argue that Mr. Clinton will not get enough in return for ending America's diplomatic quarantine of China after the 1989 military crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrations in Tiananmen Square.
Representative Christopher H. Smith, a Republican of New Jersey, who will hold hearings on Tuesday on Chinese human-rights abuses, said the summit meeting itself "should never have happened without preconditions on human rights."
"We don't want nice-sounding words and sound-bites," he added. "We want meaningful action for the victims of this dictatorship, which understands only power."
There are already concerns about the 71-year-old Mr. Jiang's reaction to the sight of protesters. He says his host, Mr. Clinton, should "handle these events." Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said today on NBC's "Meet the Press" that demonstrations were an example of democracy at work, that the Chinese had dictated their own itinerary, and that Mr. Jiang should not expect "a totally fuzzy time."
The biggest accomplishment of this summit meeting is expected to be a written pledge from China to phase out its nuclear assistance to Iran, even though there is no international obligation to do so.
In return, Mr. Clinton will lift a 12-year American ban on sales to China of nuclear technology for civilian power, which Beijing wants to buy and Westinghouse and ABB Combustion Engineering Nuclear Systems desperately want to sell.
Samuel R. Berger, Mr. Clinton's national security adviser, insists that sales of power plants "are the cart, but assurances to end nuclear cooperation with Iran is the horse."
"This is not in the first instance about whether we sell civilian nuclear power to China," he said. "It's about nonproliferation."
But many in Congress question the Administration's willingness to crack down on China for the sale of dangerous materiel to Pakistan and Iran. The issue has become highly politicized; Republicans have accused Mr. Clinton of downplaying alleged Chinese violations of past pledges to stop dangerous exports.
So Mr. Clinton has made security issues like proliferation and restraining North Korea important justifications for deepening American "engagement" with China at the highest level, and for his refusal to allow American policy toward China to rise or fall on human rights.
For the American business community, however, the power plants are the horse. To them, the nuclear sanction is another example of how Washington drives China into the arms of French, Russian and Canadian businesses. America's allies long ago came to terms with post-Tiananmen China, noting that China has possessed nuclear weapons for three decades. And Westinghouse and ABB Combustion Engineering have spent months documenting to lawmakers how sanctions have already cost the United States $16 billion in lost sales.
"Clearly, the Chinese have the capability to build power reactors on their own and get help from others," said R. Ian Butterfield, director of government affairs at Westinghouse, which is ready to swoop as soon as Mr. Clinton signs the waiver. "What they are looking for now is advanced technology, and they are making it clear that they want to standardize on one nuclear-power technology for the country."
Far more business is at stake during this visit, he argues. If China's economy keeps expanding rapidly, the country will need $60 billion in new reactors over the next 15 years, and American companies think the vast majority of that business can be theirs.
But the cost will be high: China wants extensive nuclear power technology transfer, just as it has obtained knowledge from Boeing about building sophisticated aircraft. And it wants assurances that the United States will be a reliable supplier, no matter what the Congressional mood.
Early this year, Mr. Clinton's aides were betting that the meeting's centerpiece would be China's impending entry into the World Trade Organization, a sign of the country's economic arrival. The unspoken part of the deal was that Washington would end the annual Congressional debate over "most favored nation" trade status for China.
But months of negotiations have produced little but doubts over whether Mr. Jiang is truly willing to make the sacrifices to join the W.T.O. -- summit or no summit.
China has missed several deadlines to produce a timetable for dismantling layers of protection and subsidies for China's inefficient state enterprises, which employ nearly two-thirds of the urban population.
After his trip to China last month,Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin reported to President Clinton that Mr. Jiang has considered the political impact of the economic dislocations of joining the W.T.O. -- and was aware that opening markets too fast could worsen the pain. "He is quite realistic about the challenges of making this work," Mr. Rubin concluded.
The economic crisis unfolding in Asia may further slow that opening, especially if Mr. Jiang concludes that a battered Hong Kong will not prove to be a cash cow, helping to pay for the privatization of Chinese enterprises. The first stock offering in two of those companies, including the huge China National Aviation Corporation, were indefinitely postponed over the weekend.
China's rethinking of when to enter the W.T.O. is understandable. Investors poured $42 billion into the country last year, roughly 40 percent of global investment in developing nations. Its growth is double digit and even without Hong Kong, it now has foreign currency reserves of an astounding $130 billion. Because Congress has consistently extended "most-favored nation" status to China, the Chinese are enjoying all the biggest benefits of joining the W.T.O. -- low tariffs for exports -- without any of the responsibilties of membership.
"The Chinese know that they only get into the W.T.O. one way -- on commercially acceptable terms," said Charlene Barshefsky, the United States trade representative. But some experts wonder if the American position is shortsighted.
"I think the U.S. side made a mistake and should have recalibrated its approach," said Nicholas R. Lardy, a senior fellow at Brookings Institution, who argues that it is better to get China inside the tent, preventing it from backtracking on past liberalizations. "Unless there is a change in policy there is a risk that China stays out indefinitely."
At every meeting, the Americans ask that dissidents like Wang Dan and Wei Jingsheng be granted medical parole. They also want Red Cross visits to Chinese prisons and an institutionalized "dialogue" on human rights, an end to religious repression in Tibet and elsewhere, and continued freedoms in Hong Kong. The Chinese respond, almost ritually, that these are purely internal affairs.

HEADLINE: THE 1997 ELECTIONS;
In Their Own Words

 BODY:

RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI
On being endorsed by the editorial boards of The New York Times, Newsday and The Daily News yesterday, as he walked down Broadway. 
 "I'm always surprised when you get endorsements. I'm very happy we got them. Actually, the last time I didn't have The Times and the Newsday endorsement. The News endorsed me the last time that I ran, but The Times and Newsday did not. We feel that the administration has worked very hard, and we were very proud that we were able to obtain those endorsements. But ultimately it's Nov. 4 that counts. Endorsements, polls. The election starts on Nov. 4 at 0-0, and it's our job to try to get as many people out to the polls as possible. That's what we'll be working at for the next 10 days."
 
RUTH W. MESSINGER
In brief remarks outside Zabar's, while campaigning on Broadway on the Upper West Side yesterday.
"Friends, I pledge to you, in the spirit of the West Side, in the spirit of the borough of Manhattan, an administration true to the principles of my colleagues who just spoke, true to the work that Barney Frank has done in Congress for many years, a city in which we will grow the economy and create jobs for New Yorkers, a city in which we will fight to stop police brutality, a city in which we will invest in our children and their teachers and their principals, so that everybody is learning. And I pledge to you a city in which we all work together, in which the new mayor is plenty tough, but is not mean, does not bully, does not divide and prosecute and persecute. I love representing this neighborhood, I look forward to representing the entire city."

HEADLINE: THE 1997 ELECTIONS: THE DEMOCRAT;
McGreevey Says Education Plan Would Be His Legacy as Governor

BYLINE: By BRETT PULLEY 

DATELINE: EDISON, N.J., Oct. 23

 BODY:
Detailing how he would spend much of his time as governor, James E. McGreevey, the Democratic gubernatorial candidate, said today that his focus in a first term would be on public education, economic development and carrying out a master plan for growth in the state.
In an hourlong interview with reporters and editors at The New York Times's printing plant here, Mr. McGreevey offered his most specific breakdown to date of what his priorities would be if he were to win the election on Nov. 4, and said that education would consume a great deal of his time. 
 "I think we need an education blueprint in the state of New Jersey," Mr. McGreevey said. "A specific model of where we want to be. A specific model of what education will look like in the state of New Jersey, between birth and between whether it's secondary school, community college or university training."
If he were successful in his bid to unseat the state's Republican Governor, Christine Todd Whitman, Mr. McGreevey said he would spend his first nine months in office holding town meetings and trying to build a consensus on education among parents, teachers and administrators. The focus of those meetings, he said, would be how resources should be used and what curriculum standards should be required. Education alone, he estimated, would dominate 20 percent of his time in office during a first term.
Mr. McGreevey said he would cut administrative spending in schools and try to get more of those dollars into classrooms. And he referred to curriculum standards used in other parts of the country -- like a Harvard University model used in Massachusetts schools and a University of Chicago model used in Chicago schools -- as examples that New Jersey should follow.
"I can say now that I'd scrap this Governor's standards," Mr. McGreevey said.
During the first year of his term, Mr. McGreevey said, he would not change the way education is financed. He said he felt that the State Supreme Court's recent mandate to give more money to poorer districts had achieved parity on an interim basis and that he would not propose any changes in spending until the final three years of a first term.
"What I need to grapple with is to insure that the money that's being spent now is spent wisely and appropriately," he said. "This isn't about telling everybody what they want to hear," he said in response to the fact that not all school districts are happy with the current spending plan. "For now, it stays the same."
Mr. McGreevey, a State Senator who is also the Mayor of Woodbridge, has been able to draw almost even with the Governor in public opinion polls largely through his unrelenting focus on the state's high auto insurance costs and property taxes. Yet while he continued to reiterate his plans to force a reduction in auto insurance rates and relieve property taxes with more state assistance to municipalities, he made it clear during the interview that he would like the betterment of education to be his ultimate legacy.
Relaxed and seeming to enjoy the fierce final days of the campaign, Mr. McGreevey was at times playful, yet constantly concerned about the image he was projecting during the interview. He anxiously joked about his syntax. "Is this verbatim, this transcript?" he asked, pointing to the tape recorder in front of him. And at one point, after inadvertently slouching back in his chair, he admonished a photographer: "Don't take my picture while I'm lying all the way back here," he said. "I look too relaxed."
Mr. McGreevey referred often to the policies and programs of other states' governors -- most of them Republicans -- to illustrate how he would also govern. He cited New York's Governor, George E. Pataki, as an example of someone who had successfully used union labor for state projects.
He said he would follow the examples of North Carolina's Governor, James B. Hunt Jr., and Indiana's former Governor, Evan Bayh, who focused on specific industries for growth in their states. And he pointed to the former Governor of Massachusetts, William F. Weld, who had successfully spurned development on the environmentally hazardous industrial tracts known as brownfields.
Often referring to his tenure as Mayor of Woodbridge, Mr. McGreevey said he would draw from that experience to take on the far more formidable challenges of running the state. For example, he said, his experience in bringing together knowledgeable people to redraw Woodbridge's garbage collection routes would lend itself to the task of revamping the state's public school system.
"It's about bringing people into the process," he said. "In terms of education, I want to bring in the best minds for educational excellence."
He said that his priorities in education were primary and secondary schools, but that he was also committed to spending $57 million on an urban-based, early childhood education program and that he also wanted to keep tuition costs down at state colleges and universities.
Mr. McGreevey linked his proposed educational initiatives to his economic development plan. He said he would choose the biotechnology, telecommunications and plastics industries for growth in the state, and he would then plan school curriculums to address the specific skills required of jobs in those industries.
And even though Mrs. Whitman's first term is concluding with the economy's moving at a healthy pace and with the state's unemployment rate at its lowest in years, Mr. McGreevey continued his assault on the Governor's economic development record, contending that most of the 190,000 jobs that had been created under her watch were low-paying, service-oriented positions and that she did not have an "overarching plan" for growth and development. "This Governor doesn't have a game plan," he asserted.
Mr. McGreevey said that he would adopt a master plan created under Thomas H. Kean, the former Republican Governor, as a guide in developing a long-term outlook on how the state should evolve. "One of the first things that I'd like to do is that we need to have a plan, and I think the master plan provides that, as to where New Jersey is going," he said. "Whether it's residential development, whether it's investment in infrastructure, whether it's targeting economic development to our cities, whether it's housing. There needs to be a plan."
Mr. McGreevey said he would seek to offer commercial tax abatements to provide for business development around the state's ports in Newark, Elizabeth and Camden. The state, he said, should be "aggressively" using the ports as a point of distribution and assembly for products going in and out of the country. "We're talking about a $20 billion economic engine where we're taking products in from around the world and sending them out," he said. "We ought to be putting them together or taking them apart."
Mr. McGreevey continued his well-seasoned attacks on the Governor for using a bond sale to balance the budget and to address pension liabilities, even though he similarly took on debt to balance the Woodbridge municipal budget when he became Mayor. The difference, he insisted, was that he inherited a fiscal problem, but the Governor created one by borrowing from the pension plan in previous years. "The Governor caused the harm, then cured the harm, then wants to get praise for the cure," Mr. McGreevey said.
Mr. McGreevey, a 40-year-old native of central New Jersey's working-class suburbs, contrasted his upbringing with Mrs. Whitman's affluent background. "The fundamental difference between the Governor and I is where we come from," he said.
Holding a State Senate seat and mayoral post simultaneously throughout most of the 1990's has kept Mr. McGreevey in a perpetual state of campaigning, and he waxed romantic during the interview about his affection for the political stump.
"No where else in life would I have had the chance to meet so many people with so many different experiences," he said. "If you love people, if you love life, it's a great opportunity." A professed workaholic who is separated from his wife, Mr. McGreevey said that the only significant other in his life these days is "the undecided voter."

HEADLINE: THE AD CAMPAIGN;
A Potential Rival Is Depicted as 'From the Left'

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:

PRODUCER -- Russo, Marsh and Raper, Sacramento, Calif.
 
ON THE SCREEN -- The advertisement, a parody of the introduction to "Crossfire," the CNN political debate program, begins with a blurry picture of Geraldine A. Ferraro, who serves as a commentator on the show. Over music reminiscent of the "Crossfire" theme, an announcer introduces Ms. Ferraro, as the words "From The Left," appear on the screen. The announcer's words appear as he speaks about Ms. Ferraro's congressional voting record on taxes, welfare and balancing the budget. A picture of Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato then appears, beside which are the words "On Our Side." As the announcer touts Mr. D'Amato's record, the words appear on the screen. 

THE TEXT -- "Next, in the crossfire, from the left: Geraldine Ferraro. Ferraro voted repeatedly for higher taxes on New Yorkers. She supported more welfare and opposed workfare. She even voted against the balanced budget amendment. And on our side: Al D'Amato. D'Amato voted repeatedly to cut our taxes. He led the fight for workfare, not welfare. And he co-sponsored the balanced budget amendment. From the left, it's Geraldine Ferraro. And on our side, it's Al D'Amato."
 
ACCURACY -- The ad exaggerates Ms. Ferraro's positions on raising taxes. In 1981, Ms. Ferraro voted against a measure to cut income tax rates by 25 percent across the board, part of President Ronald Reagan's landmark package of tax and spending cuts. In 1984, she voted for the adoption of a conference committee report on a bill to raise $50 billion in new taxes. But the bill, which also included spending cuts and was intended to reduce the deficit by $63 billion over four years, was also supported by President Reagan, who signed it. Mr. D'Amato opposed it.
 
On welfare, Ms. Ferraro frequently assailed the Reagan Administration's welfare cuts, which she contended were too harsh and provided no mechanism to move people from welfare to self sufficiency. She voted in 1979 for a bill that would establish a national minimum welfare benefit. The same year, she voted against an amendment to a bill that would have allowed states to establish work requirements for welfare recipients.
On the budget, Ms. Ferraro did join 167 other Democrats and 20 Republicans who in 1982 voted down a proposed amendment to the United States Constitution that would have required a balanced budget. Those who opposed the measure contended that it could tie the hands of the Government and damage its ability to stimulate the economy during slow periods.
 
SCORECARD -- Deftly playing on her role as the more liberal commentator on "Crossfire," Mr. D'Amato's ad effectively uses Ms. Ferraro's high-profile position to portray her as a public figure still proud to be known ideologically as "from the left." And it concentrates on two pocketbook issues important to many voters in an era of shrinking government: taxes and welfare spending.
But the ad's contentions about Ms. Ferraro's positions are presented with no context and could ring somewhat hollow for viewers, many of whom will recall that her last policy-making job was more than a dozen years ago. RANDY KENNEDY

HEADLINE: THE 1997 ELECTIONS: THE MAYOR;
Experts Call Giuliani's Term One of Modest Achievement

SERIES: RACE FOR CITY HALL: The Incumbent's Record

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
The most devastating charge Rudolph W. Giuliani made against David N. Dinkins in 1993 was that Mr. Dinkins had allowed city government to slip from his control. Mr. Giuliani then spent about 18 hours a day for the next four years making sure that no one ever accused him of the same thing. And no one has.
Measured against the recent standards of New York City history, in fact, the city's 107th Mayor has exercised the most muscular use of government power in many years, combining good fortune and limitless self-confidence to banish the gloomy hesitancy that so long hung over City Hall. 
 By improving the effectiveness of the Police Department -- the most conspicuous agency of the city government -- Mr. Giuliani was able to persuade many New Yorkers that a host of seemingly intractable urban ills, from murder and organized crime to panhandling, could actually be tamed.
Not all of the city's 40 percent reduction in overall crime can be traced directly to him, but through force of will and communications bravado, Mr. Giuliani translated the dry statistics into a tangible feeling of security for a broad swath of the city.
No one was more surprised by the magnitude of the year-after-year crime drops than the Mayor, whose innovations in policing were enhanced by an unexpectedly strong trend toward civil order in cities around the country.
But New York's predominance in reducing crime became the perfect symbol for Mr. Giuliani's striking success in converting national trends into personal accomplishments, making the office of mayor seem far more potent than it actually is.
His timing, in that sense, has been unerring: he began his well-known quality-of-life campaign just as business improvement districts were having their greatest impact cleaning up the city's most visited commercial areas, and just when years of planning to rebuild Times Square were coming to fruition. The reductions in crime, coming as the national recession ended and Wall Street profits began to boom, led to substantial improvements in business and tourism against a backdrop of a suddenly alluring Manhattan. As New York's sense of its own capability began to return, the Mayor was there to act as its shepherd, just as he led the parade when the Yankees won the World Series last year.
But an examination of the Mayor's record in the world beyond law enforcement shows that it often falls short of his assertion that he has turned the city around. In area after area -- long-term balancing of the budget, municipal workers' productivity, reshaping the school system, moving people from welfare to meaningful, full-time work, reducing homelessness, improving race relations -- Mr. Giuliani's performance has not matched his self-appraisals.
Many impartial experts in urban affairs say that Mr. Giuliani's real achievement is considerably more modest than a full-scale renaissance of New York City. They view him as having achieved greater efficiency rather than a true transformation of local government, as having restored an impression of order to the governance of New York rather than meaningful, lasting discipline in such areas as city spending or police behavior. Those, in and of themselves, are not inconsiderable accomplishments for someone in office less than four years, but they are not as all encompassing as the Mayor claims.
Peter C. Goldmark Jr., the departing president of the Rockefeller Foundation and a prominent local government official for many years, called the reduction in crime "a towering achievement" that has fundamentally changed the prevailing opinion of New York City. But he gave Mr. Giuliani much lower marks on education and race relations, and said the administration had made no lasting changes to the way the city spends money or builds.
"If I were putting him in the gallery of mayors alongside the six I've known, I'd put him in the lone ranger category," said Mr. Goldmark, who was chief of staff to former Mayor John V. Lindsay, the last Republican Mayor before Mr. Giuliani. "He hasn't built any broad alliances, or brought in any large portions of population. He is a battler who has taken on enemies when they presented themselves, but he has not fundamentally changed the way the city operates."
William B. Eimicke, director of the program on politics and public policy at Columbia University, said that only two basic issues had received the Mayor's full attention: public safety and fiscal policy. Mr. Eimicke argued that this narrow focus made Mr. Giuliani a good mayor, because he had followed through on the areas he said were important to him, but not a great mayor, because he had failed to expand his vision beyond its core.
"Those were good priorities, and he mapped out that course and stuck to it," said Mr. Eimicke, an authority on urban innovation around the country. "But the job of mayor is more than that. Other mayors have gone beyond that core and found ways to be more creative and deliver services better. The question for the next four years is, will he become a reinvention mayor and go beyond just being good? Can he really be great? The jury is out on that."
Mr. Giuliani can be merciless to a commissioner whose department is performing poorly, but outside the tightly closed doors of his inner circle, he is loath to acknowledge blemishes on his record. In an interview last week, he rebutted every criticism leveled at him, maintaining that New York's turnaround was not only virtually complete but also greater than any other city's. Where critics see deficiencies, he sees accomplishments overlooked.
"A lot of what we've done is ignored, because it doesn't fit somebody's classical model, but it's quite significant, quite a significant turnaround," he said between campaign appearances. "I don't know of any city that's had the kind of turnaround that we've had in the last three years. Not just in crime, but in the delivery of services, the mood of the people. We used to be a city where no one wanted to come to, and now you can't get a hotel room."
His biggest accomplishment, he said, has been ridding the city of a sense of helplessness and restoring hope. "People used to say the city was unmanageable, that it couldn't be run, that it was ungovernable," he said. "Now people believe the city can have success."
 
The Vision
Innovation In Limited Doses
Mr. Giuliani ran on a platform of rethinking and reinventing government, and even now argues that his law-enforcement techniques and workfare program constitute the country's greatest urban innovations. But unlike other mayors in Chicago, Philadelphia or Houston to whom he is often compared, Mr. Giuliani has neither fundamentally changed the city's relationships with the unions representing its workers, whose wages remain the city's biggest expenditure, nor achieved the extensive program of privatization he once promised.
In his first year in office, the Mayor put a few small road and park contracts up for bidding, but the effort halted after he decided not to further challenge the municipal unions, most of which have endorsed him for re-election. His plan to sell three city hospitals stalled in the face of legal and political opposition.
Mr. Giuliani has reduced the size of the work force and the rate of growth in city spending, while cutting taxes slightly for businesses and instituting an atmosphere of retrenchment at City Hall, all moves that have been received warmly by the financial community. But without exception, the outside government agencies and private companies that monitor the budget have warned that these actions have not gone nearly far enough. The city's bond rating, which declined under Mr. Giuliani, has not risen amid all the talk of a renaissance, and spending has continued to grow.
Though some city functions are now more efficient, other agencies with budgets that were cut are simply doing less with less. Polls show that most residents, for example, do not share his opinion that the city is now cleaner than ever.
"Giuliani has been good for New York's image, but he hasn't really tried to change the political culture of the city like they have in Houston or Indianapolis," said Joel Kotkin, a senior fellow at the Pepperdine Institute for Public Policy in Malibu, Calif., who writes frequently on the country's mayors. "It's harder in New York because of the power of the public employee unions, but he's really been disappointing when it comes to pushing thoroughgoing civic reforms."
Nor has Mr. Giuliani always lived up to his inaugural image as a clean-cut reformer. The practice of rewarding friends and political allies with jobs has hardly ceased despite the Mayor's insistence that he does not engage in patronage, and two of his closest allies and advisers have been allowed to build up lucrative practices lobbying city agencies. As in most administrations, the quality of the Mayor's appointments has been mixed, with a few acclaimed commissioners and many more who have remained anonymous, mostly because of Mr. Giuliani's policy of being the spokesman for anything good that happens within the city.
 
The Message
A Willingness To Confront
 Much of the Mayor's surging popularity is due to his intuitive understanding of the fears and desires of the city's middle class, his most reliable voting bloc, and of the business community.
He forged a new style of politics for a city accustomed to years of paternalism from its leaders, angering traditional liberals by making social benefits much harder to get, while defying his fellow Republicans with his constant promotion of the rights of immigrants. The mixture has not proved popular among many black residents and has done little to heal the city's racial rifts, but it has brought together a pragmatic coalition of recent immigrants, ethnic whites, Jews, and many Hispanics in an assertion of power rooted in the boroughs beyond Manhattan.
He seemed to immediately grasp the symbolic effect of ignoring prominent black critics like the Rev. Al Sharpton, long a critic of the white establishment, after a police incident at a Harlem mosque two weeks after he took over from the city's first black Mayor. He knew that his very visible willfulness in pursuing squeegee men and graffiti writers would buy him the reputation he needed for future confrontations.
Earlier this year, the Mayor was able to benefit from that reputation, along with some quick and dramatic action, to emerge without serious political damage from a case involving charges of serious police abuse in Brooklyn. Although black and Hispanic New Yorkers have long complained that the crackdown on crime has led to increased police harassment, the Mayor's base seemed unconcerned, and polls show that his support among blacks has risen substantially from 1993.
"That rebuilding of confidence was his greatest accomplishment," said Fred Siegel, a professor of history at Cooper Union whose new book, "The Future Once Happened Here," casts a skeptical eye on the accomplishments and failures of Mr. Giuliani and other big-city mayors. "He brought to an end that whole evacuation mentality of the middle class that you used to hear at dinner parties in the early 90's."
The Mayor was two years ahead of the national mood on welfare reform, and never fails to remind middle-class audiences that he created the country's largest workfare program. As a result, the number of people on welfare in New York City has declined to 780,000, a decrease of 320,000, saving $700 million to date. But the city's program, criticized for its lack of dignity by religious groups, has made little effort to find real jobs for those on welfare, and the city has not tried to track what happened to those who left the rolls. The Mayor said his goal is not to find "meaningful jobs," but to make people less dependent on government.
Similarly, the Mayor knew exactly what the business community wanted to see and hear after its dissatisfaction with former Mayor David N. Dinkins: tax cuts, fewer regulations, an open door. The tax cuts, 82 percent of which have gone to businesses, have been small, but along with the effort to drive organized crime out of the private garbage-hauling industry and from wholesale markets, they have helped send a message that the city is a better place in which to do business.
"When we now talk to businesses about coming to New York, crime is no longer on the list of concerns," said Kathryn S. Wylde, president of the New York City Investment Fund, a private group established to funnel corporate funds into job creation and development in neighborhoods around the city. "I think the consensus in the business community is he deserves credit for convincing people that he is a tight fiscal manager, and that he has focused on issues of serious concern for folks who are watching the economy of the city."
While the city's economy has gained notable strength in recent months, the unemployment rate, at 9.3 percent, is nearly twice the national average. And while the city's economy is creating jobs at a quicker pace than at any time this decade, New York City still has not gained back all the private sector jobs it lost during the recession of the late 1980's.
 
The Technique
Dogged Leadership, At Times, to a Fault
The one area where polls show the Mayor badly misjudged the public mood was in his treatment of the school system. Mr. Giuliani slashed the requested budget of the Board of Education for his first two years in office by $1.2 billion, chasing Schools Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines out of town with withering attacks. Only in his final year, facing widespread public criticism as buildings crumbled and students were packed into hallways, did he join forces with a new Chancellor and begin putting money back into the schools.
The Mayor acknowledges that the performance of the schools has not measured up to his hopes, which he said is understandable because he still does not have direct control over the system.
The downside of his well-known eagerness to demonstrate control and accept accountability has been the peremptory, sometimes abusive treatment given to those who displeased him, including Mr. Cortines and former Police Commissioner William J. Bratton. The administration's reluctance to discuss anything but its own successes has led to a large number of lawsuits from other public officials, civic groups, and journalists whose requests for information have been rejected.
Still, the Mayor's techniques have been effective, particularly because polls have shown that city residents want their mayor to be an aggressive manager and a tireless cheerleader, and Mr. Giuliani has unquestionably filled the bill. City residents never expected crime to fall so far, and having enjoyed the benefits, New Yorkers seem inclined to give the Mayor a great deal of maneuvering room on everything else.
"Giuliani is a shining example of the advantages of diminished expectations," Mr. Kotkin said. "People are used to being disappointed by government. With Giuliani, at least they can say, 'Hey, this guy did something.' "
 
Race for City Hall
Future articles will examine the specifics of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's record on certain issues, and Ruth W. Messinger's record as Manhattan Borough President and as a Councilwoman.

HEADLINE: FEDERAL DEFICIT AT LOWEST POINT IN TWO DECADES

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26

 BODY:
President Clinton will announce on Monday that the Federal budget deficit has fallen to $22.6 billion, the lowest since the early 1970's, largely because of strong economic growth that brought a surge in tax revenue, Administration officials said today.
The figure, covering the Government fiscal year that ended Sept. 30, was within the range predicted by economists and Congressional analysts in recent weeks. It capped a year in which the economy drove down the deficit at a stunning rate, even before the balanced-budget agreement, reached by the White House and Congress this summer, took effect. 
 The Administration had started the year expecting a deficit of $128 billion, and as recently as late summer, both the Administration and the Congressional Budget Office were predicting a deficit of $34 billion to $36 billion.
In dollar terms, the deficit has not been so low since 1974, when it was $6.1 billion. As a percentage of the nation's economic output, the deficit now stands at less than three-tenths of 1 percent, equaling or perhaps slightly lower than in 1970, the year after the Government last had a budget surplus.
Mr. Clinton will announce the figure, which is based on the Treasury Department's final calculations of the Government's expenditures and tax receipts for the year, when he delivers a speech on the economy to the Democratic Leadership Council in Washington, Administration officials said.
As an economic matter, analysts said, the deficit is now so low that it almost does not matter whether it is eliminated. It is far below that of any other big industrialized nation, and is one reason the United States has enjoyed a combination of steady growth, low inflation, low unemployment and heavy business investment in new technology, economists said.
But the deficit's political symbolism remains important, not least to Mr. Clinton. His aides have long said they hope to make the nation's restored fiscal health one of his most powerful legacies. And with a shrinking deficit, the annual budget process, so long focused on partisan fights over spending cuts and tax increases, are undergoing an abrupt twist.
Republicans in Congress are already talking openly about the deficit being wiped out well in advance of the 2002 deadline set in the balanced-budget accord, and are debating how best to spend any surpluses. While some Republicans want to pay down the national debt, which continues to grow, others are eager to use any surpluses for annual tax cuts or to increase spending on politically attractive projects like roads and bridges.
Administration officials have been more cautious, saying that the deficit is likely to increase again next year, partly because of tax cuts, and that there is no assurance the budget will be balanced before 2002. Yet even within the White House, an effort is under way to determine how best to allocate any surpluses, and how an improving budget picture would influence problems like the long-term solvency of Social Security.
But economists and budget analysts said it was far from certain that the good fiscal news would continue unabated, even if the economy continued to grow at a healthy pace.
Some of the deficit's fall since 1992 -- when it peaked, in dollar terms, at $290.4 billion -- can be attributed to painful steps taken in Washington, particularly the tax increases of 1990 under the Bush Administration and of 1993 under Mr. Clinton. But much of the reduction in the last few years resulted from an economy that grew faster than expected -- and that generated tax revenues at a pace surprising even for such an elevated rate of growth.
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, told the House Budget Committee this month that "much of the fiscal improvement of recent years is less the result of a return to the prudent attitudes and actions of earlier generations than the emergence of benevolent forces" -- among them the end of the cold war and the ensuing drop in military spending, the economy's recent ability to grow without inflation, and the breathtaking rise in stock prices.
Economists inside and outside the Government said it seemed likely, in fact, that the surging stock market deserves a good portion of the credit for the surprisingly fast decline in the deficit. They said a substantial portion of the unexpectedly high tax revenues appears to be coming from capital gains, as investors cash in on rapidly rising share prices.
Some gains, they said, may be coming from people who are being paid with stock options or with bonuses that are linked directly or indirectly to the performance of their companies' stock prices.
"The area of uncertainty is, to some extent, how long will this surge in the stock market go on," June O'Neill, the director of the Congressional Budget Office, said several weeks ago.
For all the progress in reducing the deficit, it is also a matter of debate among members of Congress and among economists whether it is fair to say that the budget is approaching balance. That is because the Government's accounting allows it to include the surplus of Social Security tax revenues over outlays -- a surplus that for 1996 was $66 billion -- in its deficit calculations, even though Social Security is technically not considered to be part of the Federal budget.

HEADLINE: Legal Bills Soar in Fund-Raising Inquiries

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26

 BODY:
When Dan Denning went to work for the National Policy Forum, a defunct Republican think tank, little did he imagine that three years later he would be hauled before two Congressional investigative committees and a grand jury. After all, he was just a mid-level financial officer, he said, who did nothing more than persuade lawyers to approve bank loans for the organization.
But today, the Forum, which was closely aligned with the Republican National Committee, is under scrutiny as a conduit for possibly illegal campaign donations, and Mr. Denning's knowledge of its inner workings is of great interest to Congressional and Justice Department investigators. 
 Although he says he has always played by the rules, Mr. Denning did not want to face the inquiries without a lawyer. Now, he says, his life has been turned upside down. He has $20,000 in legal bills and has had to take out a home equity loan.
"I could understand if I had my hand in the cookie jar," said Mr. Denning, now an officer at the Heritage Foundation, a conservative research group. "But I've tried to live my life by the rules. And when something like this happens, you have to get a lawyer. You've got no choice."
Mr. Denning is not alone. The number of people drawn into the campaign finance inquiry, both central figures and ordinary people with useful information, has grown into the hundreds, according to Richard Hertling, a spokesman for the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee, who said it was impossible to come up with a precise figure. Multiple investigations, by Congress, the Justice Department and various Government agencies, may make this the most costly political inquiry in recent times -- and a veritable bonanza for a small group of lawyers expert in the campaign finance law.
The scope is enormous: the Justice Department has a 120-person group calling witnesses, and Attorney General Janet Reno said recently that it had issued 500 subpoenas to date. Two Congressional committees with $10 million budgets have called 370 witnesses for depositions and issued over 700 subpoenas. A grand jury has been convened in Washington. The Central Intelligence Agency and the Federal Election Commission have their own questions.
The highest legal bills are those of the Democratic National Committee, at $9.7 million by the end of this year. About $5.2 million has gone to lawyers -- mainly Debevoise & Plimpton, the party's outside counsel -- who represent former officials, and the rest for the production of documents. The committee has had to hire 34 people to review the 800,000 documents sought.
The Republican National Committee, meanwhile, has spent $1.2 million on outside lawyers since the investigations began.
While most people facing questions have to pay out of their own pockets, both parties are footing the bills for their top employees.
This has prompted Steve Grossman, the Democratic chairman, to complain that so much lawyering is "a clear Republican stategy to paralyze us."
"If they can cause the D.N.C. to spend so much time dealing with hearings," Mr. Grossman said, "it will take so much financial and human resources that the Republicans can pick up all the marbles in the 1997 and 1998 races."
The Republicans, in turn, have their own spin. Michael Madigan, the Senate investigating committee's chief counsel, said, "If the D.N.C. is paying for you and you are an ex-employee, you are less inclined to say something that might be harmful to them when they are paying for you."
The Democratic committee's deep pockets do not extend to the White House or Clinton-Gore re-election employees, even though President Clinton said last August that he would "do everything I can" to raise money for the legal bills of members of the White House staff. The President will pay for his own campaign finance-related legal expenses from a $2.5 million defense fund established to take care of bills from the Whitewater investigation and other personal matters. Harold M. Ickes, the former deputy White House chief of staff, is paying his $200,000 legal bills from his own pocket and Dick Morris, the former Clinton political adviser, gets his legal work for free, from a friend who calculates the cost at $200,000.
"The legal bills are dramatic and substantial," said Robert Bauer, a Washington lawyer retained by the Democratic Party. "Legal representation for these kinds of things is extraordinarily time consuming. And then there are the aftershocks. These are other groups and individuals who are not immediately involved in the process, but fear they may be. They are suddenly more focused on seeking legal help."
The Justice Department will reimburse Government employees if it determines it is in the interest of the United States to do so. Sheila N. Heslin, a former National Security Council employee who tried to keep Roger Tamraz, a pipeline entrepreneur who donated $300,000, out of the White House, has made such a request.
"Ms. Heslin is a prime example of someone who did the right thing," said her lawyer, Richard Janis. "And now the Government is telling her she has to pay her own legal bills while others, including a top D.N.C. official who tried to pressure her, are getting legal support from their political organizations."
Ms. Heslin could have been accompanied before the Senate Committee by a Justice Department lawyer, but since Justice is also investigating the matters she is testifying about, she declined because of the conflict of interest, Mr. Janis added.
Ms. Heslin, currently unemployed, faces bills in the "tens of thousands of dollars," Mr. Janis said. "Sheila Heslin had no prior experience dealing with such matters. She was interviewed by the F.B.I., the C.I.A., Justice and the Senate committee on matters relating to classified information. She was required to be vigilant to avoid unintentional disclosure of classified information and her testimony was not helpful to a number of people. It is understandable she sought legal assistance."
In some cases, it is unclear who is paying the legal bills. A Washington lawyer, Reid Weingarten, would not disclose how much he is being paid or by whom for his two clients: Charlie Trie, the Little Rock, Ark., restaurateur who raised questionable cash for President Clinton's legal defense fund that was later returned, and Pauline Kanchanalak, the international consultant whose $253,000 in donations to the Democrats was also returned.
When Haley Barbour, the former Republican Party chairman and former head of the National Policy Forum, appeared before the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee, he was accompanied by six lawyers, courtesy of the Republican National Committee. The committee has spent the better part of its $1.2 million in legal fees on Mr. Barbour, who is also the subject of a grand jury investigation.
The inquiry focuses on a loan obtained by the Forum from a Hong Kong businessman that helped the Republican Party, as well as on donations, later returned because they were illegal, from the businessman's company to the Republican Party.
Then there are the Buddhist nuns who appeared in ceremonial garb before the Senate committee to testify about a fund-raising event by Vice President Al Gore at their Los Angeles temple. The nuns have spent "six figures plus," according to their lawyer, Brian Sun, to respond to Senate subpoenas, depositions and requests for documents. The nuns' legal bills are paid by the Temple.
Mr. Sun said his other client, Johnny Chung, the Taiwanese-American businessman who visited the White House more than 50 times during the 1995-96 campaign, was also facing six-figure legal bills, although Mr. Sun would not say whether Mr. Chung or someone else is paying.
"It's as though someone has stuck a hand in your pocket and will continue to stick you up until they are satisfied," said Mr. Denning, the former Forum financial officer. "The Senate Committee has got millions and the Justice Department has more attorneys than God. They don't think about the cost to the average citizen of putting them through this process."
Mr. Madigan, the Senate committee's chief Republican counsel, defended the process. "For this committee to do its job," he said, "it needs to get information. And it has the authority to obtain that information. A number of the people we interviewed had no need for a lawyer in the first place. They were witnesses and not the target of anything. All they were being asked is to state the facts. But many came with lawyers."
Some of those subpoenaed worked for nonprofit organizations that are going back to donors to cover their legal bills.
Peter Flaherty, head of Citizens for Reform, a nonprofit group that ran ads supporting Republicans, said that his legal bills were $100,000 and that he had gotten the money by appealing to conservative donors on First Amendment grounds. "Money for lawyers is the hardest money to raise and we're lucky our donors are willing to put it up," Mr. Flaherty said.
One leading figure who has escaped legal bills is Mr. Tamraz, the pipeline promoter who elbowed his way into the White House. He appeared at his depositions and as a witness without counsel. According to Senate lawyers, Mr. Tamraz showed up for an initial interview with a lawyer who, once he started objecting and telling Mr. Tamraz not to speak, was never seen again.
