HEADLINE: THE 1997 ELECTIONS: THE CAMPAIGNING;
Giuliani Goes After Voters In Messinger's Stronghold

BYLINE: By NORIMITSU ONISHI 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani began the last week of campaigning yesterday with a foray into the heart of Ruth W. Messinger's base on the Upper West Side, even as he warned his supporters across the city not to grow overconfident. Meanwhile, Ms. Messinger, trailing in the polls and short on money, insisted that the mayoral race was not over and pleaded for votes in four boroughs.
Mr. Giuliani, buoyed by the editorial-page endorsements of three of the city's daily newspapers yesterday, marched down Broadway between 86th and 80th Streets, throwing himself into receptive sidewalk crowds, getting spontaneous applause at Ollie's restaurant and making brief stops at two of the neighborhood's culinary citadels, H&H Bagels and Zabar's. 
 The move into the heart of Ms. Messinger's neighborhood reflected the growing confidence of the Mayor, who had spent the previous week shoring up his base of support in the more conservative white ethnic neighborhoods outside Manhattan. Its symbolism was not lost on either candidate, even though the Mayor took pains to deflect attention from it.
"I've lived on the Upper West Side for 11 years of my life," the Mayor said, referring to a period in the 1970's, "so it wasn't as if I felt that I was going some place I hadn't been before. I've been there many times as Mayor. I was there as a candidate last time. I campaigned on the Upper West Side both times I ran for Mayor. So, no, it wasn't intended to have anything to do with the opposition. It's intended to say to the people of the Upper West Side: I want your vote."
Ms. Messinger, who also stumped on the Upper West Side, played down the Mayor's appearance in her political redoubt, saying, "There's room for both of us on the West Side."
Later, walking through a street fair on Broadway between 96th and 110th Streets, she added, "There are two people who told me they saw him in Zabar's and told him to leave the West Side." (In fact, Mr. Giuliani entered the store, saw that access was hindered by the crowds near the cash registers and quickly left.)
Joined by Representative Barney Frank, Democrat of Massachusetts, Ms. Messinger told listeners in the neighborhood that "in the spirit of the West Side" she pledged "a city in which we all work together, in which the new mayor is plenty tough, but is not mean, does not bully, does not divide and prosecute and persecute."
Ms. Messinger began the day by campaigning in the mostly Jewish section of Midwood, Brooklyn, along Avenue J. Later, she stopped at the Caraville Restaurant on Avenue M, greeting diners and waiters. And she attended morning services at the Convent Avenue Baptist Church in Harlem, where she was acknowledged by the pastor but did not speak. She attended the annual brunch of the Benjamin Franklin Democratic Club in Riverdale, the Bronx, with Representative Charles E. Schumer of Brooklyn, Public Advocate Mark Green and others.
In those appearances, and later in Queens, Ms. Messinger seemed to be appealing to her listeners not to abandon hope. "The best way that you counter the polls," she told the Bronx club members, "every single one of you, is to understand that this election doesn't happen for another nine days, that you can in fact each call 10 people every night, tell them who you're voting for."
Mr. Giuliani's warm reception in a famously liberal district was the latest vivid reminder of how much his Democratic rival has to overcome a week before Election Day. Last week, polls showed Ms. Messinger still struggling to gain citywide name recognition; campaign finance records showed her with $46,343 remaining, compared with the Mayor's $1.6 million, to finance crucial voter drives in the race's last days.
Except for a few negative comments, including from one man who followed the Mayor's entourage while comparing him to a dictator, Mr. Giuliani encountered mostly well-wishers, like Bill Priest, 55, a registered Democrat who has lived on the Upper West Side almost all his life and works in publishing.
"I got to say good luck to you," said Mr. Priest, shaking the Mayor's hand. He said he will be voting for a Republican for the first time next week.
"He's done a very good job," Mr. Priest said. "He's not everybody's friend all the time. At times, people dislike him. But the whole picture -- he's done a fantastic job."
Also yesterday, Mr. Giuliani, in appearances in Bensonhurst and East New York, Brooklyn, played down his lead in the polls in an apparent effort to make sure that his supporters do not become complacent. Later, about 1,000 Hasidic men showed up in a cold rain to hear Mr. Giuliani talk for five minutes in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, showcasing his support in a community known to turn out at the polls in force.
The Messinger campaign suffered a setback yesterday when the editorial boards of The New York Times, The Daily News and Newsday endorsed the Mayor. The New York Post gives Mr. Giuliani the nod in today's editions.
"I think that it is very bad for the future of this city when relatively thoughtful people are willing to endorse a mayor who has not told them what he will do in his second term," Ms. Messinger said, "who has not promised to serve out his second term, and who has managed to pretend that the schools are fine because he dribbled a little bit of money back on them, that rising unemployment is a sign of economic health."

A Chinese Leader in U.S. For First Meeting Since '85
President Jiang Zemin of China arrived in Honolulu to begin the first state visit by a Chinese leader in 17 years. In a simple gesture laden with historical significance, he dropped a necklace of Hawaiian flowers at Pearl Harbor. Mr. Jiang is scheduled to meet President Clinton in Washington on Wednesday and to visit seven cities in seven days. A1

A Russian nuclear weapons laboratory has evaded American export rules and secretly acquired 16 advanced I.B.M. computers, Russian and American officials say. Despite threats by Marxist rebels, more Colombians than expected turned out in cities to vote in regional elections, while many in villages stayed home. Isolated skirmishes were reported. A3

Angola promised to pull its troops out of neighboring Congo Republic after a threat by the United States to cut off aid, diplomats said. The Coming Food Gap
Problems like falling water tables and rising consumer demand could create huge food gaps in coming years in the world's poorest countries, a study found. The report, prepared by a Washington group, says that improved living standards and population growth are expected to put pressure on food stocks at a time when big increases in agricultural yields appear unlikely. HEADLINE: When (and Why) Dad Has the Babies

BYLINE: By NATALIE ANGIER 

 BODY:
MANY working mothers will attest to this: When a woman does the laundry and cooking, she gets clean clothes and food on the table. When a man does the housework, he gets a standing ovation. A good mother is natural, a good father divine.
And so it is that the male sea horse has long been viewed with awe, as a kind of submarine saint. Not only does he look like a Gothic hallucination, with his horse's head, anteater's snout and spiraling dragon's tail; he also behaves like a fantasy. As scientists discovered many decades ago, the male sea horse is the one that becomes pregnant, carries the young in his belly and gives birth. He is such a flamboyant specimen of devotion, such an exemplary parent, that the female sea horse is easily forgotten. How does that deadbeat mom spend her time, anyway? 
 Doing most of the work, it turns out, but behind the scenes and without making a fuss. In results that shatter a staple of sea horse lore, Dr. Heather Masonjones of Amherst College in Massachusetts has determined that despite appearances, the female sea horse contributes more effort and energy to the welfare of her young than the male does, and that, therefore, sea horses are not quite the procreational iconoclasts they were assumed to be. Dr. Masonjones has found that although the male does carry the gestating embryos in a brood pouch, he does not transfer nourishment to them through a placenta-like organ, as had been thought; instead, the embryos feed off nutrients in the egg -- food they had received beforehand from their hard-working mother. Dad operates essentially like an incubator -- a great guy, yes, but not a martyr to his children.
Dr. Masonjones studies dwarf sea horses, one of about 35 species of the fish found worldwide, and though she suspects her findings are applicable to other types of sea horse, she has yet to prove it. Her new results are part of her recently completed doctoral dissertation and are now being submitted for publication. She presented some of the work at a recent meeting of the Animal Behavior Society at the University of Maryland.
In tandem with being less motherly than legend has it, male sea horses turn out to be less brotherly as well. Scientists had thought that given the considerable commitment of male sea horses to child care, sex roles would be swapped in toto, and the males would sit back peacefully while the females thrashed it out with one another over the right to mate with them. But as Dr. Amanda Vincent of McGill University in Montreal, and Dr. Masonjones have shown, some of the old verities of the animal kingdom apply: put a few females together with a male, and not much happens. Put two or more bachelor males in with a female, and the males go at it, interlocking their tails, extending their lower jaws and snouts, and jabbing at each other as they might at food. It is an odd, mannered, viscous performance, the Jets and the Sharks by way of molasses, but the surliness is clear. "You can hear them snapping at each other," Dr. Masonjones said. "It sounds like the snapping of fingers."
The latest insights into one of nature's most eccentric specimens demonstrate once again the danger of making simplistic, overarching assumptions about reproductive behavior and the ever-shifting dialectic between male and female. And though the results strip some of the sentimental gauze from the male's reputation, they enhance the sea horse's status as one of the most compelling and complex creatures, gilled or otherwise. Sea horses are fish, but they are not cold fish; they are great romantics. In a world where infidelity is almost universal, sea horses pair up and seem to be unerringly faithful to their mates, reaffirming their bond each day through elaborate courtship rituals. They are great pretenders, able to blend in with their surroundings so convincingly that they are nearly impossible to investigate. Dr. Vincent, considered the world's leading expert on sea horses, is one of the few people to study them in their native habitats, and even laboratory investigations of the creature are rare.
Sea horses may be too ethereal for their own good. Nobody knows how many sea horses swim the world's waters, and few countries bother regulating or tracking them. Dr. Vincent estimated that in the last five years, sea horse populations have plunged by 15 percent to 50 percent, depending on the species. The animals are harvested by the tens of thousands for use in traditional Chinese medicine, and demand for them has surged along with the boom in the Chinese economy. Sea horses are also gathered to supply the aquarium trade, although they fare poorly in captivity. They are sold as "curiosities," made into key rings, paperweights and mobiles. Their marine habitats are threatened by agricultural runoff, sewage, overfishing, boat traffic and a variety of other human activities.
"We need to put the brakes on now, before there's a catastrophic collapse," Dr. Vincent said. "You can't afford to lose 50 percent of a population in five years." She and a global network of activists and scientists are struggling to devise an amalgam of solutions to ease the pressure on sea horses. They are working to establish small-scale aquaculture programs in places like the Philippines and Vietnam, where the fish would be reared for trade rather than plundered from the wild; they are consulting with practitioners of Chinese medicine to learn how sea horse extracts are used, and what ingredients might serve as substitutes; and they are lobbying for the enactment of regulations to monitor and control the international trade in sea horses.
In September, the Australian Government responded by announcing that it would regard the family of fishes that includes sea horses, pipefishes and sea dragons as a form of wildlife. "They're the first marine fishes in Australia to be considered wildlife, rather than just food," Dr. Vincent said. "That means exports of them will be controlled and documented."
Sea horses may be poorly understood, but they have been known, and exploited, since antiquity. They are pictured on Greek vases, for they were thought to be the offspring of the stallions that carried the god Poseidon's chariot across the waves. The Roman naturalist Pliny wrote that ashes of sea horse could cure baldness, impotence and rashes. By the 18th century, scientists realized that sea horses are fish, though highly modified ones. Unlike most fish, they wear their bones on the outside, as an exoskeletal armor that offers considerable protection against predation. Their genus nomenclature, Hippocampus -- hippo meaning horse, and campus, worm -- was used to name the sea horse-shaped structure in the brain responsible for memory.
Sea horses range in size from half an inch to more than a foot in length, and they are found in coastal waters throughout the world, congregating in sea grasses, mangrove swamps and coral reefs. Like chameleons, sea horses can change color to match their surroundings, going from drab to psychedelic in a matter of moments, and they can even grow skin filaments to better mimic algae or coral. The camouflage is both defensive and offensive. Sea horses are ambush hunters, wrapping their tails around a strand of seaweed and waiting for a small crustacean or other live prey to swim by, at which point they lunge forward and suck the meal in through their trunk-like snouts.
In love, sea horses are thoroughbreds. Once they have chosen a partner, they have eyes for no other. A married sea horse of either sex cannot be persuaded to cheat on its mate even when presented with a tankful of willing singles. The pair reaffirm their bond each morning through a courtship ritual of quivering, tail-wrapping, and dancing round and round a blade of sea grass like figurines on a music box. The female roams farther afield than the male, ever on the lookout for better feeding grounds. She needs the calories to generate a clutch of eggs. And when her eggs are ripe, the tango begins. She approaches her mate and raises her head upward in a slow arc. He quivers in response. She nods more emphatically, and he nods in refrain. Facing each other swan-style, they entwine their tails and rise upward in the water. They disengage and do it again, 5, 10, 50 times, for hours and hours. "They're trying to line their bodies up perfectly," said Dr. Masonjones, "so the female can insert her ovipositer into the male's brood pouch."
Eventually, their bodies harmonize, and she transfers her eggs into his womb. As she does so, the male releases a burst of sperm from a cloacal opening above the pouch, fertilizing the eggs internally. Here Hippocampus stands alone. In many species of fish, males tend to the eggs and even brood live embryos in their mouths, but nowhere else in the animal kingdom is fertilization known to occur within the male's body. The eggs seeded, a sphincter muscle snaps the brood pouch shut, and a membranous seal forms behind it.
Throughout the 10 or 12 days of gestation, the fluid within the pouch is completely insulated from the external environment, its salinity and oxygen maintained at constant levels. Placenta-like epithelial tissue extends from the pouch lining to surround each embryo. That tissue was thought to permit the transfer of calories from the father's bloodstream to the young, but Dr. Masonjones has concluded that the placenta serves mainly as a waste-removal and gas-exchange system.
Her experiments with dwarf sea horses, which are about two inches long, show that all the protein, fats and carbohydrates needed to feed the infants are derived from the meat of the mother's eggs. The role of the brood pouch, she says, is to act as a safe and predictable haven, a shelter from the fickle seas, so that the young need not devote egg energy to regulating salt and oxygen concentrations, but instead can spend it all on getting bigger faster. "At this point, it doesn't look like there are many energetic costs of brooding to the male," Dr. Masonjones said.
Once the two dozen or so fry are sufficiently baked, the father goes into labor, which can last up to two days. Eventually the seal is broken, the pouch reopens, and a stream of fully developed, but very tiny, sea horses comes trotting out. Now they are on their own and must begin hunting immediately. Most die of starvation.
There is no respite for the parents either. While the father was brooding, the mother was feasting, and making a new batch of rich, yolky eggs. The day after the male gives birth, his mate returns with the new clutch of ova to be fertilized and incubated. Throughout the seven-month breeding period, the male sea horse may become pregnant a dozen times, giving birth to more than 300 young.
It is because the partners must be in perfect procreative synchrony, the mother ready with new eggs at exactly the moment when the father's pouch is open for business, that infidelity, nature's favorite ploy, becomes almost impossible. There is nothing to do but stay true, and start each morning with a twirl through the grass.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Heather Masonjones, who studies the behavior of sea horses, with her subjects in her lab at Amherst College. (Fred LeBlanc for The New York Times)(pg. F7)
 
Chart/Drawings: "Male and Pregnant"
The sea horse has long been a favorite of feminists because, almost unique among animals, it is the male of the species who gives birth to the young. Now researchers who study the elusive creatures have discovered their method of reproduction may actually be in the male's best interest: because females do not have to bear the young, they can produce more eggs for the male to fertilize.
In mating, the female expels eggs into the male's pouch, where they are fertilized. The bright red eggs impart a glow to the male's pouch.
The dwarf Sea horses shown here, Hippocampus Zostrae, can reach 2 inches in length, and other species can grow to 14 inches.
Sea horses have elborate courtship rituals. Here, they entwine their tails and "promenade" through the water.
After 10 days the babies emerge from the male's pouch. They grow to adulthood in about three months.

HEADLINE: Male Chromosome Is Not a Genetic Wasteland, After All

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS WADE 

 BODY:
WHY the Y chromosome? The question can now be answered, after the discovery of almost all of its genes and the emergence of a pattern that explains how the Y chromosome evolved.
The new findings may also help toward understanding the sources of male infertility, the cause of half the childlessness that affects some 10 percent of American couples. Defects on the Y chromosome affect only men, who have an X and Y chromosome in each cell of their bodies, while women have two X's. 
 Chromosomes, visible under the microscope as puffy X-shaped blobs, are nature's answer to the hard disk drive: they are high-density genetic storage devices organized along random access principles. The 70,000 human genes are packed into 23 pairs of chromosomes but are distributed, as far as anyone can tell, with no rhyme or reason as to which chromosome a gene is assigned to.
The one exception is the Y chromosome, which has very few genes on its main body, apart from the male-determining gene that switches the fetus away from the default human condition of femaleness.
It is strange that this bastion of maleness should be a wasteland, genetically speaking. Until recently, only eight genes had been found on it, compared with the several thousand packed into each of the other 45 chromosomes, including the Y's counterpart, the X chromosome.
Believing there must be something more in this desolate genetic terrain, two biologists at the Whitehead Institute in Cambridge, Mass., Dr. Bruce T. Lahn and Dr. David C. Page, made a thorough search of the Y chromosome and have now turned up 12 more genes. That makes 20 known genes on the main body of the Y, which they believe is close to the full inventory.
Knowing roughly what these genes do, the Whitehead scientists have been able to reconstruct the likely history of how the Y chromosome got to be the way it is. Their findings and theory are reported in the current issue of the journal Science.
In the beginning, when devising two sexes, nature needed to insure that the male-determining gene did not sneak into the female's genome or gene set. That is a tougher chaperoning problem than it may sound, because a principal way of creating genetic variety between generations is for pairs of chromosomes to line up and promiscuously trade fragments of genetic material before creating egg and sperm cells. This wholesale shuffling of the genetic deck is called recombination and is a principal reason that children differ from their parents.
To confine the male-determining gene to the male line, the chromosome containing it started not to recombine with its counterpart, except at the very tips, where it has the same few genes as the X chromosome.
But recombination is the genome's tonic for healthy living and all-round fitness. Genes that do not recombine eventually cease to provide useful service to an organism trying to survive in a changing environment. And useless genes tend to get lost. So the Y's decision not to recombine with the X meant that most of its genes became unfit and over the course of millions of years were driven into extinction. The Y has visibly shrunk to just a cut-down version of its sister chromosome.
The Whitehead biologists find that the 20 genes left on the Y fall into two classes. One class has counterpart genes on the X chromosome. Both the X and Y versions of these genes are switched on in many different tissues of the body and play housekeeping roles in the cell's economy. These nine genes are presumably the sole survivors of the Y chromosome's original full complement of genes.
The second class of Y genes are switched on just in the testis and are presumably involved in the manufacture of sperm. Dr. Page views them as male fitness genes, and has reason to believe that over the course of evolution they jumped onto the Y from other chromosomes.
One of these male fitness genes, which has been studied earlier in Dr. Page's laboratory, turns out to be missing in certain men who produce no sperm. The DAZ gene, as it is called (short for "deleted in azoospermia"), seems to be descended from a gene called DAZL (for "DAZ-like") which is found on chromosome No. 3. The DAZL gene, Dr. Page believes, must have copied itself onto the Y chromosome some 30 million to 40 million years ago, since only in old world monkeys, and not in animals that split away earlier from the primate lineage, is DAZ found on the Y chromosome.
The other testis-specific genes probably also hitchhiked their way onto the Y chromosome, Dr. Page suggests. Although the chromosome offers an unstable and hostile environment for most genes, it is evidently a sanctuary for male fitness genes. Once they have landed on the Y, these genes produce extra copies of themselves. DAZ, like the other 10 Y genes of its class, exists as a family of multiple copies. The reason for the amplification is unknown.
The two classes, housekeeping and male fitness genes, account for all the known genes on the main body of the Y chromosome and thus explain the one part of the genome where gene content seems to have a rational basis.
"It's a lovely piece of work," said Dr. Huntington F. Willard, an expert on the X chromosome at Case Western Reserve University in Cleveland. "This is the first glimpse we have had that the human genome was thrown together with some forethought."
Dr. Page, who has been studying the Y chromosome for 15 years, described the diminutive chromosome as "a part of the genome I have cared deeply about for some time" and said it was "exciting to find a little pocket of the genome that makes some sense."
Besides male infertility, Dr. Page's findings are also relevant to Turner's syndrome, a condition in women who have only one X chromosome. In normal women, with two X's in each cell, one X chromosome's genes are permanently switched off so as to give women the same dose of X-based genes as men. Dr. Page has found that there is an exception to this rule: the X-based genes that are the counterparts to the housekeeping genes of the Y. The housekeeping genes remain switched on in both X's so as to equal the male cell's dose from its X and Y chromosomes.
This suggests, though it has yet to be proved, that the abnormalities seen in Turner's syndrome may arise because the single X chromosome produces only half the needed dose of the various housekeeping genes. The odd collection of symptoms found in Turner's syndrome -- short stature, webbing of the neck, infertility and a narrowing of the aorta -- may each be caused by insufficient quantities of a different gene. Once these genes are identified, it may be possible to devise drugs that make them more active.

GRAPHIC: Chart/Graph: "The Logic of the Y Chromosome"
Diagram of the Y chromosome shows its two classes of genes. The X-homologous genes (labelled black), so called because they have close counterparts on the X chromosome, are general housekeeping genes, switched on in many cells. The other class (gray), which includes the male-determining gene SRY, is switched on only in the testis. Third line shows result when given genes are deleted. (Source: Science)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Stocks' Free Fall Sends Dollar Down Sharply Against Mark

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar had its biggest drop against the German mark in two and a half months yesterday and lost its early gains to end flat against the Japanese yen after the stock market's plunge.
The dollar dropped sharply against the mark in late afternoon trading after the Dow Jones industrial average plummeted more than 550 points for its biggest point loss ever, automatically shutting trading on stock markets in the United States. 
 The United States currency was higher against the yen during most of the session as traders sought the dollar as a safe haven from weak Asian currencies, but it lost all its gains after Wall Street's free fall.
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 1.7495 marks, down from 1.7730 late Friday, its sharpest drop since mid-August. The dollar was also trading at 121.88 yen, compared with 121.87 yen on Friday, after peaking at 122.29 earlier in the day.
The dollar also tumbled to a three-month low versus the British pound after Britain reiterated that it would not join Europe's planned common currency in 1999. The pound was quoted at $1.6595, up from $1.6335; it was its highest level since late July.
The dollar did rise sharply versus the Mexican peso as financial worries about emerging markets spilled into Latin America. The dollar hit an intraday high of 8.6500 pesos, its strongest since the peso's devaluation in December 1994, which preceded a deep economic slump in Mexico. The dollar settled at 8.4000 pesos, up from 7.8700 late Friday.
Tim Stewart, a global currency strategist at Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover, said he expected currency traders to move cautiously until stock markets begin to stabilize.
"Most people have had a pretty good year in the currency markets," he said. "It's not a period in the next few weeks to be brave."
While the dollar is often viewed as a haven for investors during times of financial turmoil, many investors yesterday turned to the mark and the Swiss franc. The mark rose strongly against the yen, which also contributed to the dollar's decline against the German currency.
The dollar also dropped sharply against the Swiss currency, to 1.4499, down from 1.4706 late Friday.

LENGTH: 292 words

HEADLINE: Next Asian 'Domino' Won't Be China

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Financial turmoil in Southeast Asia has surely tainted the Asian economic miracle. Yet there is no reason to expect that all Asian countries will meet the same fate. Gregory Fossedal (Op-Ed, Oct. 24) says China may be the "biggest devaluation domino of all" because its currency is overvalued. But he fails to recognize fundamental differences between China and those Southeast Asian countries. 
 First, most Southeast Asian countries suffered huge trade deficits as a result of currency overvaluation. The Chinese currency is not overvalued. The current exchange rate is 8.28 yuan to the dollar. If purchasing-power parity is used, the exchange rate would be about 1.7 yuan to the dollar. China has enjoyed a trade surplus for the past three years, evidence that its currency is not overvalued and its exports are not "becoming less competitive."
Second, most Southeast Asian countries (except Singapore) have relatively meager foreign exchange reserves. But China has a reserve of $132 billion, the second highest in the world next to Japan.
Third, although China incurred foreign debt of $110 billion, 80 percent of this is long-term debt that need not be paid back in the short term. And most of its loans from the World Bank are for the improvement of infrastructure, not for "luxury" projects.
Finally, the Chinese inflation rate has fallen precipitously since last year, allowing China's central bank to lower interest rates. These factors suggest that China will avoid the domino effect. A stable currency and a steadily growing economy will facilitate China's economic and political reform.
 
CHU-YUAN CHENG
Muncie, Ind., Oct. 26, 1997
 
The writer is a professor of economics at Ball State University.

HEADLINE: Home Resales Set Record in September

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27

 BODY:
Sales of previously owned homes inched higher by two-tenths of a percent in September, setting a record, the National Association of Realtors said today. The gains came entirely in the Northeast.
Existing homes sold at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 4.32 million units, up from a revised 4.31 million in August. It was the highest level since the trade group began tracking sales in 1968. Most economists had expected a drop of about 1.2 percent. 
 Strong economic growth and plentiful jobs are giving Americans the wherewithal to buy homes, and mortgage rates are near the low point for the year. The Department of Housing and Urban Development said last week that the nation's home ownership rate rose to a record 66 percent in the July-September quarter.
The median price of an existing home -- meaning half sold for more and half for less -- was $125,600 in September, up 6.6 percent from last year.
By region, sales jumped 11.7 percent in the Northeast, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 670,000. They were unchanged in the South at 1.64 million. They fell 2.8 percent in the Midwest, to 1.09 million, and dropped 4.1 percent in the West, to 940,000.

HEADLINE: HORSE SHOW;
Gem Twist, U.S. Star, To Take His Final Bows

BYLINE: By ROBIN FINN 

 BODY:
Because he hated his heels to touch the fences he was bred to scale, he gained a reputation as a perfectionist who did not suffer human fools lightly, no small feat for a mere horse.
But Gem Twist, the New Jersey-born Pegasus who will experience the ultimate equine retirement bash this week during the National Horse Show's four-day stint starting tomorrow at Madison Square Garden, was no mere horse. He was a patriot, the pride and joy of the United States Equestrian Team, which had labored for years under the stigma that European horses were superior to homegrown. When his owner, Michael Golden, once pondered a foreign nation's seven-figure offer for Gem Twist, a veteran American rider informed him he had better plan on relocating to that nation, too, if he ever had the gall to export this horse. 
 Gem Twist, an Olympic medalist, a tenacious 10-year veteran of the international Grand Prix circuit, and a riveting peacock in the show ring, where he amassed more money, and more honors, than any of his contemporaries, became a legend in his town with his ability to fly without wings. And his owner's, trainer's and riders' lives were touched and changed (painfully on occasion) by the 18-year-old champion who will, unknown to him, take his final public bows Saturday afternoon at the Garden.
"People used to tell me he was the horse of a lifetime," said Greg Best, the Flemington, N.J., native who won everything from 1987's rookie of the year title to two Olympic silver medals aboard Gem Twist until he splintered his shoulder in a career-stopping fall at Devon, Pa., in 1992.
"But now I realize he was the horse of a hundred, thousand lifetimes," he said. "Gem gave me a vehicle for launching a career; the phase of my life that was spent with him exceeds comparison." Best, 33, is traveling from Waipuckurau, New Zealand, where he runs his own horse business, to celebrate Gem Twist's career. "It's going to be emotional, for sure, to be there at the Garden with him for the last time. He was always the hometown boy there, and I was the hometown boy who got to go along for the ride."
The silvery gelding won 40 major events, accumulated more than $800,000 in prize money, attracted purchase offers of $2.5 million, and is the only superstar to win the American Grandprix Association's horse of the year award three times. Gem Twist is also the only jumper to claim the A.G.A.'s championship for three different riders: Best in 1987, Leslie Burr Howard in 1993, and Laura Chapot, the daughter of Gem Twist's original owner and lifelong trainer, Frank Chapot, in 1995.
Not bad for an aloof, mottled gray gelding purchased as an unproven 3-year-old with great bloodlines but no guarantees for future greatness by an astute businessman and very amateur horseman, Golden, who got both more and less than he bargained for when he chose Icey Twist as his first horse. ("It sounds corny, but I changed his name because I had this gut feeling he was going to be my rare jewel, a Gem," Golden said.)
Since Golden, president of the Whippany, N.J.,-based Stephen Gould Corporation, had never bought a horse before, he had no inkling that he was getting the deal of the century on the horse of the century when he shelled out $12,000 for Gem Twist. Nor did Frank Chapot, the six-time Olympian whose favorite U.S.E.T. mount, Good Twist, was Gem's father, have any idea what he was giving up when he sold the rambunctious youngster to Golden.
"I wasn't enough of a genius to see what kind of future he was going to have; if I'd known, I would have charged $2 million," said Chapot, whose Chado Farm in Neshianic Station, N.J., will serve as Gem Twist's retirement home after serving as his headquarters throughout his career.
Once Golden took possession of Gem Twist and began riding him under the watchful eye of his instructor, Arlene Orr, it did not take long to realize the horse was simply too much horse for the owner. "Let's just say that whenever we went into the arena, everybody else automatically cleared the ring," said Golden.
Golden and Gem Twist parted company, at least as a jumping team, the day his steed tackled a two-foot-high combination jump in the schooling ring as if it were a six-foot monolith on the Grand Prix circuit. Golden was already dangling from the saddle when the horse decided to take off straight toward a parked tractor, and in the instant that he envisioned himself as a broken-limbed hood ornament, Golden bailed out. For good. Gem Twist went back to Chapot for further training, and when Chapot decided the horse's radical jumping style was having the same effect on his back as a trip to a bad chiropractor, Greg Best, then a Penn economics major with a weekend minor in exercising jumpers, got the call that changed his life.
"It was one of those rides where Frank just told me to get up there and see if I could stay on," said Best, who wound up staying aboard for six years. "He was a creative horse, and charismatic in his own way: he seemed to like to get himself into awkward situations and then figure a way out of them." Best and Gem Twist made the definitive Grand Prix debut in 1987: the 8-year-old jumper took horse of the year honors and the rider was the rookie of the year. A silver medal at the Pan American Games followed, and then the rookie duo surprised the horse world by dashing through a jumpoff to a silver medal for show jumping at the Seoul Olympics in 1988, where the United States also collected a team silver. It was in Seoul where Gem Twist unveiled the crowd-pleasing post-leap bucking that, along with his determination never to touch a jump, became a signature.
After Best's unfortunate tumble in September 1992, Leslie Burr Howard replaced him as Gem Twist's rider, and though it took the new pairing 18 months to win a Grand Prix, the veteran rider kept Gem Twist safe enough in the 1992 standings to secure his third horse of the year title.
"He was such a smart, clever horse, and though he seemed ordinary in the schooling area, when he went in the ring, puffed himself up, grew two hands taller," Howard said. "It was like an actor going onto the stage."
The improved teamwork of Gem Twist and Howard in 1993 yielded that year's A.G.A. Championship, and when Chapot, still Gem Twist's trainer, looked for a horse to take his daughter, Laura, through her Grand Prix initiation season in 1995, he put her aboard the most reliable mount he could find. Gem Twist, older and wiser and snowy white at 16, not only carried another newcomer to rookie of the year honors, but also won the A.G.A. championship, a repeat of his double coup with Best in 1987. The horse had, as his owner puts it, "come full circle. Frank was the first person to ever ride Gem, and now Laura will be the last."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gem Twist, Greg Best up, winning a silver medal at the 1988 Olympics in South Korea. The gelding will be retired Saturday at the Garden. (Tish Quirk)

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Down to the sea in marketing: three big new campaigns for the cruise line industry.

BYLINE: By Edwin McDowell 

 BODY:
CRUISE line advertising is still a long way from reaching saturation levels, but it has been growing steadily for several years and shows every sign of continuing to set records.
Early this month, for example, the Cruise Lines Industry Association, a trade group, began an $8 million yearlong campaign called "You haven't lived until you cruise." Norwegian Cruise Lines recently rolled out an ad campaign primarily aimed at travel agents that will cost nearly $1 million this quarter. (It will follow up with a national consumer ad campaign in January.) And Royal Caribbean International is spending $5 million for sole sponsorship of the halftime show during the Super Bowl, to be held in San Diego on Jan. 25. 
 The Royal Caribbean ads will be aimed in large part at extolling the pleasures of cruising on any of Royal Caribbean's 12 ships or on any of the 5 ships of Celebrity Cruises, which Royal Caribbean acquired last summer.
"The challenge is to be seen as a global provider of vacation options, not just these two little cruise lines in Miami," said Mark Kammerer, director of marketing for Royal Caribbean. "Next year, our joint revenues will exceed $1.5 billion."
The ads for Royal Caribbean are being created by McKinney & Silver, a unit of the CKS Group in Raleigh, N.C. Celebrity is handled by Harris Drury Cohen, an agency in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., that is also working on the Cruise Lines Industry Association campaign.
Discounting concerns that the price it paid for the Super Bowl sponsorship is akin to putting all of Royal Caribbean's advertising eggs in one basket, Art Sbarsky, Celebrity's senior vice president of marketing, said that at least 85 percent of the millions who watch the halftime show on television have never gone on a cruise.
Expanding on Mr. Kammerer's theme, Mr. Sbarsky said: "If we were just a cruise line, our sponsorship wouldn't make economic sense. But we're a huge vacation company." Seeing a backdrop of Super Bowl spectators basking in the San Diego sun in midwinter, he said, is likely to make those millions of television viewers think about vacations. If the ads do their job, that will translate into cruise vacations with Royal Caribbean or Celebrity.
Sponsorship of the San Diego Super Bowl provides another benefit to Royal Caribbean. "The following year the Super Bowl will be played in Miami, our backyard, " Mr. Kammerer said, "and we have the option for that halftime show.'
The previous campaign for Norwegian Cruise Lines -- "It's different out here" -- created by the Omnicom Group's Goodby, Silverstein & Partners in San Francisco, won awards from the advertising industry. But the ads raised eyebrows in the cruise industry for their sensual imagery, and drew criticism from Bob Dickinson, the president of Carnival Cruises, the industry giant. Ads that emphasize glamour rather than value, he said, "send messages that 'I need a $50,000 wardrobe' or that 'I need my breasts augmented or my teeth capped' to go on this cruise line or that."
Norwegian's new ads take a much different tack.
Created by Young & Rubicam Chicago, which won the account three months ago, the ads in the trade press are intended both to build the Norwegian Cruise Line brand and to differentiate it from other cruise lines and land-based vacations. Its general theme, the "Norwegian Way," highlights the tradition of Norwegian seafaring excellence.
Thus one ad, with an Old World globe adorned by wooden Viking ships, asks: "O.K., so Norwegians discovered all the world's sea routes. But what have they done for you lately?" The facing page says: "New routes. New ports. New itineraries."
Another ad shows a partly opened can of sardines on one page, dancing and dining passengers on the other page. "Ask any Norwegian," the headline says. "It's not the size of the vessel. It's the space per passenger."
A plaque depicted in another ad, obviously aimed at the spate of megaships that cruise lines have added recently, describes the Norwegian Way thus: "We believe a ship should be a ship, not a floating mall. Authentic, romantic, civilized. Long on choices, not on lines."
It should be noted, however, that the cruise line's Norway, at 1,035 feet, remains the longest cruise ship afloat. But Nina Cohen, vice president of marketing for Norwegian Cruise Lines, said what other Norway loyalists maintain -- that the classic lines and generous amounts of wood used in construction of the ship (which was built in 1960 as the S.S. France) give it an unexpected intimacy.
Beyond that, she noted that while the company has been Norwegian since it began, "The Norwegianness has never been used as a raison d'etre."
"In fact," she continued, "we called ourselves N.C.L. Now we're breaking out." The company is doing so not just in its ads, but by changing the name of three ships: the Seaward, to Norwegian Sea; Dreamward, to Norwegian Dream, and Windward, to Norwegian Wind.
"The ads are whimsical, tongue in cheek and relevant," Ms. Cohen added. "How can you not love them?"

HEADLINE: Christmas Fades As Retail's Rescuer;
Stores Look to Rest of Year As December Sales Flatten

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
For weeks, retail executives have been making grand predictions about the imminent holiday. It is going to be smashing, they say, citing all the new toys, themed baby clothes, home decorations and eager shoppers dying to buy it all.
The holiday they are speaking so fondly about is not Christmas, though, but Halloween. 
 When the subject turns to the December selling season, traditionally a shopping blowout, everyone is less chatty. This Christmas will be decent, retail experts agree, but probably not fantastic.
It is no coincidence that retailers are keeping expectations low for the Christmas season, even when all the consumer surveys and economic indicators suggest that Americans have plenty of money to spend for the holidays. That is because Christmas is slowly shedding its role as the annual rescuer of American retailers, the sure-thing season that makes up for a year's worth of mistakes.
Indeed, sales of general merchandise, apparel and furniture in November and December fell to 23.9 percent of annual sales in 1996 from 25.4 percent in 1988, Commerce Department figures show. That adds up to a huge $9.5 billion that shifted away from the holiday season or evaporated altogether. This is anathema in the retail business, where the holiday season has long been counted on to cover a multitude of shortcomings.
The one sector of the retail industry that has enjoyed better trends -- luxury goods -- may also hit a speed bump this Christmas if days like yesterday, when the Dow Jones industrial average plummeted 554.26 points, continue. An embattled yen and serious trouble on the Hong Kong stock market have resulted in declining sales of expensive shoes, handbags and liquors by Japanese tourists. And the people who have profited mightily from gains in the stock market here may not be running so quickly to Neiman Marcus and Tiffany this season.
To be sure, the holiday-season quarter remains essential for shopping malls and traditional retailers -- representing up to 40 percent of annual sales for some merchants and nearly half of the annual profits for most retailers. But just as they have watched more competition enter their market over the last decade, now they are also watching several other industries lap up shoppers' dollars, even at Christmas.
"People just don't spend money on Christmas the way they once did," said Peter N. Schaeffer, a retail analyst at Dillon Read. "It all goes back to Americans working more hours and harder than ever before and spending money differently. They are making the abode more comfortable. They are buying sport utility vehicles. And if I spend $200 on my kid's hockey equipment, I am going to buy him less at Christmas. It's that simple."
As sales of items like clothing have flattened, sales of airline tickets, restaurant meals and services have risen, appealing to overtaxed consumers who prefer the quick thrill of a nice meal or a pleasurable vacation to another shirt, compact disk or tie.
"It hit me on one Christmas Eve when I was standing in Nordstrom and I thought, 'This is nuts,' " said Katy Khakpour, a receptionist who lives in Seattle. "I'm spending Christmas Eve racing around trying to find last-minute gifts, and this is not what this celebration is supposed to be."
For the last few years, Ms. Khakpour and her sister and mother have opted not to shop the day after Thanksgiving, traditionally the busiest shopping day of the year, treating themselves instead to high tea at the Four Seasons Hotel. And they have stopped exchanging gifts. "We know as adults that if we need anything throughout the year, we can get it," she said.
As a result of these trends, traditional retailers and mall developers have had to work harder to make the rest of the year count more. Retailers as varied as Wal-Mart Stores Inc., the Zale Corporation and the Dayton Hudson Corporation have looked to marginal holidays like Halloween and Mother's Day for new selling opportunities. Others have tried hard to build customer loyalty with packages similar to airline mileage programs that they hope will translate into added sales year round. For example, frequent shoppers can join a club at Neiman Marcus and with multiple purchases can earn points for later discounts or perks like lunches with celebrities.
"Retailers are up against the same situation that supermarkets are in," said Therese Byrne, editor of Retail Maxims, a newsletter on retail issues, who has studied seasonal selling cycles for two years. "You need people in the stores at least once a week."
So where are the dollars going that once flowed to traditional retailers?
One area of the economy that appears to have taken market share from retailers is travel. Passenger revenue on domestic airlines has increased nearly 29 percent since 1990, according to the Air Transport Association of America, and hotel occupancy rates have hit record highs over the last year. Dozens of luxury resorts sold out for the holiday season months ago.
Often, families may choose to go on a trip rather than buy a dozen presents. "I spend much more time getting away," said Amy Wells, 22, an insurance company receptionist in Portsmouth, N.H. "Travel is the biggest and best gift of all."
Some retail sales also appear to be shifting to restaurants. Inflation-adjusted sales in American restaurants grew to $320 billion last year from $200 billion in 1987, fueled by the success of chain restaurants like the Outback Steakhouse, the Olive Garden and the Cheesecake Factory -- places that appeal to children as well as adults and offer reasonably good food, served fast.
The urge to get away from it all -- whether it is a week in St. Barts or two hours at the Olive Garden -- underscores the shifting needs of the American family, where time-pressed dual-income parents are looking for ways to relax.
Retail experts said that gift certificates for services like day spas or tuitions for ballet school or camp -- areas that are hard to measure in dollar terms -- were now often given as gifts. What is more, savings for college and investments for the future have also pulled at the nation's longest purse strings: those of baby boomers.
"For baby boomers," Ms. Byrne said, "everything they have has to be the best, and that extends to their kids. That doesn't mean they are going to buy them things. It is ultimately about getting them into activities and preparing them for the future."
"People are into experiences," she added. "The last thing they need is the aggravation of a mall."
That seemed to ring true for Ellen Cooper Klyce, who lives in Memphis and has three school-age children. "I'm trying to simplify and not have so much stuff in my life," Ms. Klyce said.
"In our family, we also give promises in a coupon book redeemable by the end of the next year," she said. "So I may give a coupon book with promises not to nag, or to give an encouraging word or to buy an ice cream sundae."
The smartest retailers have attuned themselves to the shifting values and spending habits of Americans and have worked to get them into stores the rest of the year.
Consider Zales Jewelers. Not so long ago, aside from selling engagement rings, jewelers had only Christmas to look forward to. With less traffic in malls at Christmas, though, Zales began aggressively pursuing shoppers during other holidays.
"We are here to do business all year round," said Robert J. DiNicola, Zale's chief executive. While the retailer may once have simply hoped for the best on Mother's Day, it now devotes 20 to 25 percent of its second-quarter marketing budget to the holiday.
It has a similar strategy for Valentine's Day, using advertising, signs outside the store and pure salesmanship to convince people that a bracelet or watch is a year-round gift. "We want our associates to drag them into the stores," he said.
As a result, 78 percent of the company's profits now come in the fourth quarter, down from 95 percent a few years ago. The company expects fourth-quarter profits to represent 60 percent of the entire year within the next few years.
Zales is not the only one trying to convince Americans that there is more to celebrate than Christmas. Discount and department stores have become obsessed with Halloween. This year, stores like Wal-Mart and Target devoted large sections of their stores to displaying everything from home decorations to adult costumes to bibs that say "My first Halloween."
"Halloween is now a very major sales event," said Douglas A. Scovanner, chief financial officer at Dayton Hudson. "Same-store sales last year at Target in October increased 9 percent, due in no small part to Halloween."
Jeffrey Edelman, a retail analyst at Deutsche Morgan Grenfell, said he expected Dayton Hudson's fourth-quarter earnings to represent 45 percent of the year's total, compared with 54 percent last year.
Even at Toys "R" Us, the mother of all holiday retailers, efforts have been made in recent years to beef up the rest of the year.
"The holiday season is getting a little less of the overall holiday business," said Michael Goldstein, the chief executive of Toys "R" Us. The company recently put a 52-page advertising insert in Sunday newspapers, trying to drum up early business. "Six years ago, we never would have done that," he said. The company has also added gift registries to try to make the store a destination for new mothers and parents shopping for a child's birthday party. Such things "help us through the rest of the year," he said.
Mall developers have even joined in the game. Seven of the country's largest developers now offer a Visa card that consumers can use to shop in 500 malls nationwide and receive 2 percent rebates on every purchase, said Adrienne Davis-Brody, senior vice president for marketing at the Wells Park Group, a developer. Shoppers who get the card also get benefits like free parking, gift wrapping and the use of a photocopy or fax machine in the mall.
Even retailers who still make more than 80 percent of their sales during the holidays are faced with a stronger need to lift profits the rest of the year through greater control over expenses, reduced inventory levels or clever programs that give incentives to shoppers in the middle of July.
"If you are not making your profit line the first three quarters," said Bruce Van Kleeck, vice president of the National Retail Federation, "you are running a great risk during the fourth quarter to make your overall goal. Ten years ago, you stood a greater chance of doing so. You can't take your eye off the business at any point in the year these days, because if you do, you are heading for a real problem."

SECTION: Section A; Page 22; Column 1; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: The Plunging Dow

 BODY:
There are three salient facts to keep in mind before sizing up yesterday's scary 554-point drop of the Dow Jones industrial stock average. Its drop of 7 percent was much smaller than the 22 percent, 508-point drop on Oct. 19, 1987. The economy can absorb shocks better today than 10 years ago, because inflation is lower, employment is higher and, most important, banks are financially sturdier. The Federal Reserve Board, under its current chairman, Alan Greenspan, reacted correctly in 1987 to keep the economy rolling on an even keel, and will have to do so again today.
The 13 percent fall in the Dow from its August peak of around 8,200 should be put in perspective. Mr. Greenspan warned investors of "irrational exuberance" last December when the Dow was under 7,000. Now that it has dropped back down to about 7,160, it is still high -- relative to corporate earnings -- by historical standards and still above the levels that worried Mr. Greenspan late last year. What will happen when the stock and financial markets open today is anybody's guess. Millions of Americans have experienced only sunny days in the market, and it is difficult to predict how they will react to a severe downturn. 
 But there is reason to believe that a resilient economy and Federal Reserve intervention can prevent avalanche selling on Wall Street from burying jobs and income on Main Street. The "lost" wealth, measured from the Dow's peak, might lead some investors to cut back spending, but the Fed has the tools to offset that problem by nudging interest rates lower as needed. Stock crashes create problems for banks, securities firms and mutual funds that are hit by a rush of investors redeeming shares and demanding cash. But the Fed has the luxury of working with a banking system that is flush with reserves and the leeway to pump money into an economy that is almost inflation-free.
True, there is the worrisome image of Japan, where stock and real estate markets crashed, dragging the economy along with them for most of the 1990's. But Japan's banks were buried in bad loans, and its central bank reacted slowly and ineptly.
Last week's turmoil in Hong Kong and financial capitals in Southeast Asia probably frightened investors on Wall Street enough to spark self-fulfilling waves of selling. But Southeast Asia has a limited impact on the American economy, and if the American stock market had not been spooked by Hong Kong it would almost inevitably have been spooked by something else. There remains a danger that currency disruption and stock market crashes will spread from Asia to other regions, but such contagion, given that scared foreign investors will likely pour their money into the United States as a safe haven, ought to pose a limited danger here. The economy's vital signs are strong, which reflects many years of solid monetary and fiscal policies that should now serve Americans well.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: THE MARKET PLUNGE: THE IMPACT;
Consumers Likely to Keep On Spending Unless . . .

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
Judging by the initial reaction, yesterday's 554-point plunge in the Dow Jones industrial average, despite all the scary reminders of 1987, seems unlikely to have much impact on people's spending -- as long as stock prices do not plunge much further.
"I am assuming the market is going to revive on Tuesday," said Madeline Hochstein, president of DYG Inc., a public opinion polling firm. "Another 500-point drop over the next couple of days, and you enter a different ball game. People would start pulling back on their spending." 
 Her views, repeated in a dozen interviews with economists and pollsters, demonstrated a vast change over the last decade in the prism through which Americans -- at least the 40 percent of the population holding stocks -- view reversals in the market.
In 1987, many people saw the October crash as their worst fears come true, a repeat of what had happened to their parents in October 1929, and the Depression it soon ushered in. The selloff this month, in contrast, draws comparisons not with 1929, but 1987. That crash was damaging -- real estate prices fell, for example, and Wall Street firms went through huge cutbacks. But there was no immediate recession, and stocks soon embarked on the long bull market that has lasted until now.
"The 1987 experience taught people, rather traumatically, that things can go wrong," Ms. Hochstein said. "Now we have been through 10 years of learning that things can go wrong; you can have a recession, you can be downsized, and still you can survive, even quite nicely."
The stock market's spectacular rise this year -- the Dow average was up 28.1 percent from January to its peak in August -- has clearly had a "wealth effect," many economists say, contributing to the nation's strong economic growth mainly through spending on luxury cars, travel, home remodeling, sales of appliances and computers, and investment in new machinery.
Yesterday's market shock did not seem sufficient to shake that spending, in part because interest rates have fallen even as the Dow industrials declined 11.2 percent over the last four trading days, including yesterday's 7.18 percent drop.
"One offsets the other," said David F. Seiders, chief economist for the National Association of Home Builders. The 30-year mortgage rate, now down to 7.3 percent from 8.2 percent last April, is likely to drop to 7 percent shortly, Mr. Seiders said, based on what has occurred in the last few days. "At this point, I am not much worried," he added, "as long as stock prices don't fall much further."
The rule of thumb among economists for measuring the effect on spending of a stock market selloff is this: For every dollar that an investor loses in portfolio value, he or she spends three cents less over the next year or two.
Chris Varvares of Macroeconomic Advisers Inc. in St. Louis calculates that stock prices are down roughly 15 percent since August, shrinking stock wealth by $1.6 trillion. "At three cents to the dollar, that comes to roughly $50 billion in spending cutbacks over the next two years," he said -- only a small fraction of the nation's income over that period.
Still, the selloff over the last four trading days is worrisome to Henry Kaufman, an economist and money manager, in a way the 1987 crash never was. While the Dow has lost only 11.2 percent -- half the drop on the day of the crash in 1987 -- the American stock market is responding to global turmoil beyond its control. The 1987 crash initiated the turmoil that brought down stock prices elsewhere in the world, but a decade later the Dow is plunging in response to the Asian financial crisis.
"We have little historical precedent to guide us in this situation," Mr. Kaufman said. "The problem is in the Far East, not here. That is new for Americans, and much of what happens next in the United States could depend on what happens next in Japan. That country has not had a stock market rally at all this year, and further deterioration in response to the Southeast Asia turmoil could spread fresh trouble to the United States."
Not surprisingly, after the market shut down yesterday, many Wall Street analysts tried to put the best light on what had happened. Mr. Kaufman, for example, noted that rising stock prices had added more than $5 trillion to household wealth since 1995, and very little of that has been lost, so far.
Stephen S. Roach, chief economist at Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Company, offered similar comfort. "When you wake up on Tuesday," he said, "you have to think that if you put $1,000 into stock at the end of 1994, you still have $2,000 left."
And then, whistling past the graveyard perhaps, Mr. Roach said: "Remember, in 1987, the worst meltdown we had ever seen since the Depression, turned out to be the greatest buying opportunity in our lifetime."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Thrive as a Haven From Stocks

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Supported by a flight to safety from plunging stocks around the world and the first trading halt on Wall Street since the 1987 crash, Treasury securities surged yesterday and pushed yields down to 20-month lows.
The rout in stock prices overshadowed factors that in other circumstances might have caused bond prices to fall. 
 Potentially strong economic data due this week -- including information on consumer confidence, the quarterly employment-cost index, home sales and third-quarter economic growth -- coupled with a fresh supply of Treasury debt had been expected to put pressure on bond prices.
But yesterday the main focus in all the financial markets suddenly became falling stocks and a 554.25-point drop in the Dow Jones industrial average, which caused trading to halt in American stock markets.
"The stock market got a reality check," said Robert Pugliese, senior vice president and director of fixed income at J. W. Charles Securities, in Boca Raton, Fla. "Normally, the fixed-income market does not focus on equities. But when you least expect it to happen to the market that can hurt the most people at one time, that's when it happens."
Investors and traders pouring money into the safe haven of Treasury bonds helped the benchmark 30-year issue rally 126/32 to a price of 1036/32 . Its yield, which falls when prices rise, declined to 6.14 percent from 6.27 percent on Friday -- the lowest yield since 6.09 percent on Feb. 14, 1996.
Traders said that the 30-year bond got a big lift late in the afternoon, after a 350-point decline in the Dow average led to the first-ever use of a half-hour trading halt, one of the "circuit breaker" mechanisms devised in the aftermath of the 1987 crash to limit market volatility.
On reopening, the Dow average quickly fell another 200 points, which led to the declaration of an hourlong halt that ended the session because only a half-hour of trading remained.
"When the stock market reopened, the bond raced up two points before tapering off a bit," said Jack Ablin, executive vice president and head of fixed income at Barnett Capital Advisors. He said the reason bonds tapered off reflected the impact of the second circuit breaker, which meant "no other money could leave" on the stock market.
This week the Government will be selling $26 billion of new two- and five-year notes. Such Treasury auctions by themselves can cause prices to drop by raising the prospect of a supply glut. But the surge in demand for Treasuries from fund managers and foreign investors seeking the safety of United States debt securities diminished that possibility.
In when-issued trading ahead of today's two-year note auction, the securities were offered at a price to yield 5.55 percent, down from 5.75 percent on Friday. Tomorrow's five-year notes were offered at a price to yield 5.69 percent, down from 5.90 percent on Friday.
Traders said yesterday's weekly Treasury auction of new three-month and six-month bills went well, as the short end of the Treasury market benefited the most from the selloff in stocks. The discount rate for a three-month bill was 4.97 percent, up a hundredth of a percentage point from last week; the rate for a six-month bill was 5.08 percent, down from 5.15 percent.
Despite the bond rally, traders had mixed views on what the stock market turmoil could signify for bonds in coming weeks and months.
Sung Won Sohn, senior vice president and chief economist at the Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis, said the flight to safety from Asia would help the bond market for a while. "Eventually, however, the Asian countries will need cash to defend their currencies and shore up weakened balance sheets," he said. "U.S. securities will be sold and interest rates will be higher than otherwise would be the case."

HEADLINE: In Miami, a Romance, However Brief, With the Marlins

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO 

DATELINE: MIAMI, Oct. 27

 BODY:
The home of the new World Series champions woke up today giddy from celebrations that did not even begin until the early morning hours, its euphoria tempered neither by the workday nor the uncertainty over the possible sale of its winning team.
Nowhere in South Florida was the Marlins' 11th-inning victory over the Cleveland Indians early Monday sweeter than in the city of Homestead, which built a $12 million spring training stadium for the Indians for the 1993 season, only to be abandoned by the team after Hurricane Andrew devastated the city in 1992. The Indians, citing "an act of God," got out of a two-year contract and went on to train in Winter Haven in Central Florida, while the Homestead stadium was repaired but has yet to attract a tenant. 
 "We got a double victory out of this -- we got to see the Marlins win, and we got to see the Indians lose," Mayor Tad DeMilly of Homestead said today.
After the destruction caused by Hurricane Andrew, Mayor DeMilly said, "for these guys to come in and kick us in the shins created a long-lasting negative impression." He added, "I don't care if they'd played Little Leaguers, we would have supported the Little Leaguers."
Emotions seemed to run as deep elsewhere in South Florida, where thousands of fans poured out in the streets from sports bars and home parties shortly after midnight on Monday to dance on top of cars and honk horns, to yell "MAAARLINS!" until they were hoarse and to slap one another silly.
At Pro Player Stadium, where the Marlins gave South Florida its first professional sports championship since the Miami Dolphins won the Super Bowl in 1974, Eddie Russo, 27, remained in his seat for a half-hour after the game, letting the tears flow.
"With all the ebb and flow of the game, my body and mind just couldn't handle it anymore," said Mr. Russo, a resident of Parkland, a Fort Lauderdale suburb. "This is big."
In Coconut Grove in Miami, South Beach in Miami Beach and the Las Olas Boulevard area in Fort Lauderdale, fans wearing fish-shaped hats and Halloween masks protruded from windows and sun roofs in car caravans going nowhere as traffic jammed within minutes after the game. In the Little Havana section of Miami, revelers came with conga drums and pots and pans, creating an impromptu carnival.
Xavier Cortada, a 33-year-old painter, said he had not seen such spontaneous euphoria since 1980, when 125,000 Cuban refugees arrived at Florida's shores in the Mariel boatlift and Cubans here thought that the fall of Fidel Castro's Government was imminent.
Cuba has not changed politically, but it produced the World Series' most valuable player, Livan Hernandez, who defected in 1995 while traveling in Mexico with the island's national baseball team and is now the toast of both Cuba and Florida.
Paint on cars read "Go Fish" or, in one case, "Go Pescados." Debbie Cohen, 38, and Tom Murphy, 49, a married couple visiting from Long Island, were swept up in the frenzy after watching the game in a Coconut Grove restaurant.
"Everywhere you go in Florida, everybody is so psyched," said Ms. Cohen, a Yankees fan. "We had to root for the Marlins."
The Convention and Visitors Bureau of Greater Miami and Greater Fort Lauderdale estimated that the series generated more than $50 million in economic benefits for the local economy.
Parades are planned on Tuesday in both Miami and Fort Lauderdale. The Marlins will hold a rally in the evening at Pro Player Stadium.
But the nagging question of the future of the team hung over the festivities. The team's owner, H. Wayne Huizenga, announced in June that he would sell the Marlins, although he vowed to consider only investors who would keep the team in South Florida. He says the Marlins are losing $30 million a year and he has lobbied for a new publicly financed, more intimate stadium that would be only for baseball and would have a retractable dome.
The current stadium was built for the Miami Dolphins football team. While its size allowed about 67,000 fans to attend each World Series game there, many consider it too large for baseball.
Mr. Huizenga's spokesman, Stan Smith, said today that the owner had not changed his mind about selling. But in recent interviews, Mr. Huizenga has indicated that he is reconsidering. Early this morning, in the champagne-sprayed Marlins locker room, Mr. Huizenga shouted to anyone within earshot: "It doesn't get better than this, does it?"
Mayor Joe Carollo of Miami and his main opponent in the November election, Xavier Suarez, have both said they support public financing for a new stadium in Miami, although they disagree on a location.
But even some feverish Marlin fans were not enthusiastic today about the prospect of more public spending to insure the long-term future of the franchise.
"There are more important things for the public to pay, like education," said Jose Suarez, 43, an electrician from Miami. "How come a man with so much money can claim losses? He can pay for a stadium."
But today was no day for weighty issues. The mood was exemplified by Aldrin Gomez, 28, a jai alai announcer in Hialeah whose jeans dropped to his knees as he ran to an intersection in Little Havana with arms raised. In his underwear, surrounded by a throng laughing at him, he laughed along and pulled his pants up.
"Maybe I lost weight" watching the game, he said. Asked about the fate of the team, he said he would support a plan to finance a stadium with taxpayers' money but brushed off any more questions. "We're not worrying about that right now," he said, running off for another victory lap in drooping pants.

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN WASHINGTON: SIDE TRIPS;
In Chinese Politics, Too, All Photo Ops Are Local

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27

 BODY:
When President Nixon went to China in 1972, one of his main goals was to be photographed in the country's most illustrious settings: on the Great Wall, at the Forbidden City, even in Mao Zedong's private bedroom.
The same is true for Jiang Zemin, as he visits the United States this week. 
 Just as Mr. Nixon's overriding intention as a politician in 1972, an election year, was to enhance his prestige at home by basking in the exotica and stateliness of a China visit, Mr. Jiang's main purpose in coming to the United States is to look good back home in the year he is solidifying his position as China's foremost leader.
When asked, Chinese diplomats insist that Mr. Jiang's trip is intended to develop better relations with the United States in a quest to make the world a safer place. But in the reality of politics, domestic concerns come first, and for the Chinese that means promoting Mr. Jiang's image in the place he cares about most.
Chinese television audiences will doubtless be fed images of Mr. Jiang's visit for weeks and months to come. Well-known backdrops of Washington and New York are likely to appear stately, while hula dancers in Hawaii and the colonial dress of Williamsburg may look strange and mysterious to the Chinese.
But Mr. Jiang is not as much concerned about the impression he makes on the typical Chinese citizen as on members of the political and bureaucratic elite, whose allegiance and respect he needs to govern effectively. Chinese leaders are not elected by popular vote, but public opinion, hard as it can be to gauge, affects the elite and how they work.
In China, where centuries of tradition have made symbol and ritual far more important to politics than they are in the United States, images of the nation's leader on a foreign visit take on added significance.
For Mr. Jiang, there may be no more politically weighty photographs than those of him in America, meeting well-known figures and touring famous places.
"This trip is extremely important to Jiang," said Liu Junnian, a political scientist at the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences. "America is still by far the most important country to China. Having meetings there is automatically significant, and it also makes Jiang look stronger by going there."
Indeed, Mr. Jiang's trip is probably more valuable politically to the Chinese side than to their American counterparts.
While each leader may have diplomatic objectives in the summit meeting on Wednesday, that is only one day of seven that Mr. Jiang is spending in the United States, and for the Chinese each day and each city offers some valuable images of America.
American negotiators preparing for the visit have said they were perplexed by the way their Chinese counterparts seemed extremely particular about the details of protocol and symbol that often seemed hard to understand. But Chinese negotiators are likely under pressure to please their superiors, who care most about how the trip looks back in China, not here.
The benchmark for Mr. Jiang's visit, without question, is the trip to America by Deng Xiaoping in 1979. That trip, while also freighted with heavy geopolitical significance -- China's plans to invade Vietnam and how the Soviet Union would react -- is best remembered in China for the way it certified Deng's emergence as China's foremost leader.
Deng's trip came just a month after he had consolidated his power at a key Central Committee meeting, endorsing a major advance in economic reform, then concentrated in farming. It also approved Deng's plan to open China to far more contact with the United States.
Yet Deng's goal, and his success, was to show Chinese viewers two things above all: that his leadership of China was unquestioned internationally and that he was as capable in foreign affairs as in domestic ones.
Similarly, this year's trip comes shortly after Mr. Jiang's own success at a Communist Party Congress, where he established himself as China's current leader. His trip is likewise intended to show that he is both firmly in charge of his nation and capable of conducting foreign affairs.
A complicating factor for Mr. Jiang is that the bureaucratic elite in Beijing whom he is most trying to impress will inevitably compare his trip with Deng's. And Deng's great success, winning over millions of Americans with a well-timed doffing of a cowboy hat, may be hard to top.
American negotiators urged Mr. Jiang to visit Chicago, to signify the growing trade and economic cooperation China has with the Midwest, particularly in climbing grain sales to China.
Yet the Chinese turned down that option, choosing instead to visit several sites of historical significance, from Pearl Harbor to colonial Williamsburg to Philadelphia and its Independence Hall.
"Chinese people have always respected American history," Mr. Jiang told reporters in Beijing. "I want to understand even more about America."
Mr. Jiang, an engineer who is China's first top leader to graduate from a university, apparently also wanted to draw attention to his taste for academia. Besides visiting a former professor in Philadelphia, he is also scheduled to visit Drexel University, his son's alma mater, and to deliver a major policy address at Harvard University.
Anticipating major demonstrations in Boston, American officials suggested choosing another city. But Mr. Jiang apparently was adamant that he wanted to speak at Harvard.
"He has his own personal political agenda," said Harry Harding, a China scholar at George Washington University. "This is a way of ratifying his position."
