HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN WASHINGTON: PROTESTS;
Soapbox Is Crowded, And Lather Is Richer

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27

 BODY:
A group calling itself Project Democracy in China had hoped to assemble Chinese dissidents in Lafayette Park across from the White House to protest the visit this week of China's President, Jiang Zemin. The problem was that so many people were applying at the park to protest the visit that the Parks Service had to turn the group away.
"There's an amazing breadth of opposition," said William Schroeder, a spokesman for the group, which now plans to hold daily protests in a corner of the Capitol grounds. "And they've all taken this occasion to come together in one place." 
 China has always had its enemies in the United States, from exiled dissidents to ideological warriors in search of a new Evil Empire.
But Mr. Jiang's visit has galvanized them like nothing since the Tiananmen Square massacre of democracy demonstrators in 1989.
Everywhere from college campuses to Congress, China's critics are a a growing group. They have disparate politics and concerns, with the A.F.L.-C.I.O. railing against prison labor, the Family Research Council against religious persecution, the Sierra Club against China's choking pollution. There are few issues in America today that unite the likes of Richard Gere and Oliver L. North.
All, with varying degrees of vehemence, oppose the Clinton Administration's policy of engaging China diplomatically and economically, especially in its emphasis on billion-dollar business deals.
"I think there's an increasing awareness of the broad spectrum of threat Communist China poses to the American workers, to our environment, to the human rights ideals this country has stood for for more than two centuries," said Mr. North, the former National Security Council aide involved in the Iran-contra affair, who is a talk-show host. "And I think it's been slow in coming."
Despite an admonishment from Mr. Jiang to keep unruly protesters under control and out of sight, the demonstrations are likely to punctuate the official proceedings, ruffling a visit that both Mr. Jiang and the Clinton Administration hope to use to smooth relations.
On Sunday nine protesters were arrested near the White House. A Chinese group plans to follow Mr. Jiang around the East Coast in minivans decorated to look like jails. Tibetans will converge at the Chinese Embassy on Tuesday and at a "stateless dinner" on Wednesday.
Today the Catholic Alliance, an offshoot of the Christian Coalition, held a vigil to focus attention on China's repression of religion. It was a small group, if spirited.
Chastising the President along with business executives, the Rev. Rob Schenck of the National Clergy Council prayed for help against companies "who choose to profit at the expense of those who lose the most sacred right of all."
While the Chinese remain adamant that the White House protect Mr. Jiang, the Administration itself may well be the focus of much anger.
As Senator John Ashcroft, Republican of Missouri, put it: "Betraying our country's heritage of leadership in defense of freedom and a stable international environment is not the way to establish a relationship with China." He was responding to the President's defense of "a pragmatic policy of engagement."
Today 11 Republican Senators, including Mr. Ashcroft, sent Mr. Clinton a letter opposing a tentative agreement that would clear the way for the sale of billions of dollars' worth of American nuclear power plants to China in exchange for its pledges not to export Chinese nuclear expertise.
Although that agreement is supposed to be a centerpiece of the visit, the Senators warned that "China has made and broken nonproliferation commitments for over a decade."
While Mr. Clinton promised as a candidate in 1992 not to coddle China's dictators, he later agreed to separate renewal of China's trade status from its record on human rights. Now that approach is entrenched in policy.
In Congress, Republicans have seen China as an issue on which to attack Mr. Clinton's stewardship of foreign policy. Critics of China and its policies have received an enormous boost from the religious right, which in recent years has rallied strong support on behalf of religious freedom, championing the cases of those jailed or persecuted for practicing their faith.
Few of China's critics call for cutting off relations, but most say the Administration must use its leverage to force Mr. Jiang to respect human rights. "This is the time to engage them," said Gary L. Bauer, president of the Family Research Council, "but to engage them with American values and moral principles."

SECTION: Section A; Page 14; Column 1; Foreign Desk

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN WASHINGTON: TRADE;
U.S. Business Ties to China Are Far Richer Than Any Diplomatic Links

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27

 BODY:
Early this summer, the president of Intel Corporation, Craig Barrett, went to see the former mechanical engineer who now runs China, Jiang Zemin.
Behind the high walls of the Zhongnanhai compound, where China's leaders live, the two men talked for an hour about the power of the Pentium II, Intel's newest chip. 
 They talked about the potential of "Webcasting" -- or broadcasting via the World Wide Web. It was a technology that Mr. Jiang said he welcomed in China, somewhat to his guest's surprise, and Mr. Barrett said the talk left him with new insights about the pragmatic mind-set of the former factory engineers who are now in charge.
It was, in a way, a presummit summit meeting, and the fact that such talks have become more commonplace illustrates a central truth about the American-Chinese relationship: While the two Governments have kept each other at bay during most of the 1990's, the American business community has developed a web of relationships -- including some with the Chinese Government's top officials -- that is far richer and deeper than anything diplomacy has yet accomplished.
So this week, Mr. Jiang will be spending considerably more time with American businesses -- from I.B.M. to AT&T to Hughes and even the New York Stock Exchange -- than he will with President Clinton and official Washington.
As a result, one subtext of the summit conference that begins Wednesday is an effort to find a way for American foreign policy to catch up to the corporate foreign policies of Intel and Microsoft, Westinghouse and Boeing. "In many senses," Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin told American executives in Beijing last month, "you have invested in this relationship more fully than we have in Washington."
But much like Washington's interactions with Beijing, corporate America's have been a mix of success stories and daunting setbacks. To talk to American executives in China is to hear tales of executives in hot water for crossing swords with the wrong provincial governor while others were feted on yachts sailing through the Three Gorges. And here in Washington, companies with big stakes in China have often been on the opposite sides of major battles.
Just last year, Boeing pressed for permanent renewal of China's trading privileges at the same time that its neighboring corporate superpower, Microsoft, successfully pressed the Administration to threaten to impose $1 billion in sanctions against Chinese goods if Beijing failed to stop the piracy of software, videotapes and music. In that battle, Mr. Jiang backed down, finally convinced that a reputation for piracy could chill foreign investment.
With increasing frequency, American companies are in a tug of war with Beijing over its insistence that investments are tied to extensive transfers of technology -- often to develop industries that will compete with foreign firms. Chrysler backed out of a major car deal several years ago rather than turn over too much technology to Chinese automakers.
McDonnell Douglas, now part of Boeing, and its Chinese partners are being investigated by a grand jury in Washington in connection with the diversion of equipment for fabricating the skins of aircraft to a military site. (The diversion was detected and stopped before the equipment was put into use.)
American companies also must steer clear of the human-rights practices that often tar China's reputation in the United States -- for example, making sure not to use the products of prison labor and not to deal with subcontractors who do.
Such conflicts will go unmentioned during Mr. Jiang's visit. But even the U.S.-China Business Council, the chief lobbying group for smoother relations with Washington, notes that in the past two years Chinese leaders have tilted laws and new regulations "to the advantage of domestic firms" and to the disadvantage of foreigners.
So to the many crosscurrents of Wednesday's summit meeting, add one more: Just as the diplomatic relationship between Washington and Beijing is finally speeding up, the corporate relationship shows signs of chilling.
American investment in China actually declined last year by 7 percent, and the number of contracts signed -- the rough equivalent of looking at the numbers of shares traded on a stock exchange -- fell by 28 percent.
That reluctance to pour in more money will almost certainly be accentuated now that Hong Kong's stock market has taken a beating, and growth throughout Southeast Asia looks like it could be slow for several years.
"You are going to be hearing a lot of happy talk for the next few days," the chief executive of a major company doing extensive business in China said this weekend. "But the truth is that the same chief executives who will be toasting Jiang at the state dinner know enough about China that they will probably be cutting back their presence for a while."
If Washington and corporate America seem once again out of sync, the explanation may be that they are focused on two very different Chinas. Washington still focuses on managing China's interactions with the rest of the world -- as an arms proliferator, a potential threat to Taiwan, a growing diplomatic force in Asia. But the American business community is focused on China's internal changes -- the pace at which it privatizes its state-run enterprises and its willingness to lift the many restrictions that keep foreigners from competing directly for the hearts of Chinese consumers.
"The truth of the matter is that we still cannot sell directly to the Chinese people," Vaughn A. Koshkarian, who heads Ford's operations in China. Everywhere else in the world, Mr. Koshkarian notes, Ford keeps extensive records about who buys its cars. In China's case, it must sell to Government-affiliated distributors. Exasperated, Ford's executives in China once sent the company's interns out into the streets of Beijing for days at a time, recording the location of every Lincoln Town Car so that Ford could begin to communicate with the actual owners.
But the real lesson that American business brings back to Washington is this one: Government-to-government agreements are nice, but what works on the back streets of Shanghai and Xian is a conspicuous display of political power.
Procter & Gamble has flourished where other foreign consumer-product companies have failed, its competitors say with a mix of envy and anger, in part because its chief business partner in China happens to be one of Hong Kong's most powerful billionaires, a man with excellent connections in Beijing. During his tour of China, a diplomat told Mr. Rubin about a lawyer who had a remarkable string of victories in the Chinese courts, even in suits against local companies.
"I asked him, 'How do you do that?' " the diplomat said.
"He said it's easy: He just invites some very powerful people in Beijing to come sit in the front row."
But for all their complaints, American executives have found that the Chinese no longer reflexively react to every American call for change with a call for America to get its nose out of China's "internal affairs."
The dispute over piracy has resulted in the closing of more than 50 factories that were churning out counterfeit copies of "The Lion King" and Windows 95. .
Another sign that China is willing to listen to American economic suggestions -- as opposed to its advice about human rights -- came at the end of Mr. Rubin's trip to Beijing.
The Treasury Secretary told Zhu Rhonji, China's economic czar, that he was flattered by the fact that China keeps its $130 billion in foreign currency reserves in the form of Treasury bonds. But, Mr. Rubin asked, should not some of that money be spent on new power plants and other essentials that could ease China's industrial transition?
It might seem like a conversation between financial policy wonks, but something else was at work. "A few years ago the Chinese probably would have told us that this was their business, not ours," one of Mr. Rubin's aides said later. "Instead, they said, 'Could we run over those numbers again?' "

HEADLINE: THE 1997 ELECTIONS: SCHOOLS;
Schools Under Giuliani: Raging at System, Then Nurturing It

SERIES: RACE FOR CITY HALL: The incumbent's record.

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG 

 BODY:
When it comes to New York City's public schools, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's term can be divided into two parts.
During his first three years in office, the Mayor railed against the girth of the Board of Education's central administration, pared $1.3 billion from the board's projected spending, and branded the board's decision to squirrel away $100 million in a reserve fund an "absolute tragedy." 
 Then, over the past year or so, Mr. Giuliani has permitted the Schools Chancellor to create $100,000-a-year jobs for a half-dozen new aides, added more than $200 million worth of programs to the schools' budget, and hailed the board's retention of a $156 million surplus as "good management."
What accounts for the difference?
The Mayor says the answer is simple: Since October 1995, he has had, in Rudy Crew, a Chancellor whom he can trust to spend the city's money wisely. He did not feel the same about Dr. Crew's independent predecessor, Ramon C. Cortines, whom Mr. Giuliani berated, on an almost daily basis, until he announced his resignation in the spring of 1995.
"This is a partnership based on shared principles," Mr. Giuliani said in an interview last week. "Rudy Crew is getting it done."
But critics fear that Mr. Giuliani's recent nod to the system's enormous needs -- he added money for reading instruction, textbooks, art teachers and computers this year -- is motivated as much by election-year politics as by a desire to help improve a troubled system.
And as evidence, they point to the most significant education initiative of the Mayor's first 32 months in office: a plan to transfer more than 1,000 public-school children to parochial and other private schools.
It was, the Mayor acknowledged then, hardly a vote of confidence in public education in New York. And that sentiment, even if the Mayor does not give voice to it these days, still concerns parents and teachers.
"I think he is really at the beginning of putting his mark on the school system, in any positive way," said Sandra Feldman, the president of the city's teachers union, the United Federation of Teachers, which has not endorsed a mayoral candidate this year. "What will be his education legacy is yet to be determined."
So far, his major accomplishments have been political. Last year, the Mayor reluctantly set aside his demand that the Board of Education be dissolved and that he be given direct control of the school system. His turnabout -- whether motivated by his confidence in Dr. Crew, as the Mayor contended, or by the lukewarm support in Albany for mayoral control, as his critics suggested -- helped pave the way for the passage of a sweeping new law.
The law stripped hiring powers from the city's 32 community school boards, many of them seen as bastions of corruption, patronage and ineffectiveness. Those powers were transferred to the district superintendents who now report directly to the Chancellor.
"I played a card that I had developed, which is, I compromised," Mr. Giuliani said. "So I was able to play that card and get for him the power that I always thought should belong ultimately in a mayor."
The roots of that compromise can be traced to October 1995, when Mr. Giuliani ended his two-year feud with the independent Board of Education (the Mayor appoints only two of its seven members) by agreeing to support Dr. Crew, a compromise candidate, as the next Chancellor.
Since then, the Mayor's hold on the charismatic Chancellor and the board majority has been so firm and steady that Dr. Crew has been perceived as his Chancellor. The Mayor devoted an entire campaign advertisement to encouraging parents to "thank another Rudy."
Arthur Levine, the president of Teachers College at Columbia University, said that supporting Dr. Crew was "the Mayor's biggest accomplishment."
 The rapport between Dr. Crew and the Mayor stands in stark contrast to the sniping that dominated the relationship between Mr. Giuliani and Mr. Cortines. Once a week, Dr. Crew meets with the Mayor, seeking his counsel on every significant decision.
Dr. Crew's loyalty to the Mayor is so strong that the Chancellor declined, in an interview, to characterize the budget cuts that preceded his arrival as harmful to the system -- even though schools had to gut programs in art, music, physical education, guidance and after-school sports.
Thus far, the Mayor has not used his heightened political control of the system to effect much change. By most yardsticks, the system looks much as it did at the end of the term of Mayor David N. Dinkins.
The city's portion of per-pupil spending, having been slashed by 11 percent during the first two years of the Giuliani administration, has increased this year to about the same level -- when adjusted for inflation -- as it was when Mr. Giuliani took office: about $3,400 per student, according to the Independent Budget Office, a city unit that provides nonpartisan budget data to elected officials and the public.
Mr. Giuliani boasts of creating seats for 80,011 students during his administration, half of them in trailers, but that is only slightly higher than the number of students who entered the growing system over that period. The system, in a debt inherited from the Koch and Dinkins administrations, still has 87,000 more students than its classrooms were built to accommodate.
Then there is the central administration.
Under Mr. Giuliani's persistent prodding, Mr. Cortines contended that he had winnowed nearly 2,000 full- and part-time jobs from the board's central headquarters, reducing its ranks from 5,630 in February 1994 to 3,738 in June 1995 through layoffs and attrition.
But that was not enough to satisfy Mr. Giuliani. In an interview in March 1996, six months after Dr. Crew's arrival, the Mayor called on the Chancellor to pare another 2,000 jobs from the central administration.
So far, Dr. Crew has come up short. A spokeswoman for the Chancellor, Karen Crowe, said he had eliminated 243 full- and part-time administrative positions, mostly through attrition. Dr. Crew has also created more than a half-dozen new high-ranking jobs, including one overseeing a special district for failing schools, three in the division of instruction, one to oversee parent relations and two in public relations.
Mr. Giuliani lodged no protest.
The Mayor, like the Chancellor, has taken some credit for a rise in students' scores on reading tests administered last spring. But the upward trend is a fledgling one. On a state test last spring, 69 percent of third graders were found to be reading at or above the state minimum standard, the first increase since Mr. Giuliani became Mayor.
On a city test in April, 49.3 percent of third graders were found to be reading at or above their grade level -- an increase of 2.6 percentage points over the previous spring. But because it was only the second year those tests were given, long-term comparisons are impossible.
Despite the rise in scores, parents' displeasure persists. In a New York Times poll released last week, 76 percent of respondents said they were not satisfied with the quality of the city's public schools. And in two celebrated instances last month, parent groups, using the threat of a lawsuit, prevailed on the system to add an extra teacher to their elementary schools because they thought class sizes were too large.
But parents' qualms about the public schools do not appear to have had much impact on Mr. Giuliani's strong political standing, in part, perhaps, because over the past year the Mayor has introduced a flurry of education initiatives.
He gave elementary schools $125 million to add reading teachers, reading workbooks and after-school reading tutorials. He spent $22 million to provide new computers and printers to intermediate schools. And he gave the system about $55 million, about $50 per pupil, to begin replacing textbooks, many of which dated from the Kennedy Administration.
Roscoe C. Brown Jr., the former president of Bronx Community College and an informal adviser to Mr. Dinkins on education, said he was reluctant to give Mr. Giuliani credit for restoring money "in the context of the fairly Draconian cuts that occurred before."
"If you give it back more recently than you took it away," Dr. Brown said, "then it appears a positive outcome."
Given that the reading program, among others, has been financed only for this year, the depth of Mr. Giuliani's new commitment to the system will be gauged by whether he continues to invest in it.
"Four years has not been a lot of time to turn this ship around," said Seymour C. Fliegel, a senior fellow at the Center for Educational Innovation, a conservative policy group that advises the Mayor on education.
"I give him the benefit of the doubt," Mr. Fliegel said. "Let's see what happens in the next four years."
 
Race for City Hall
Future articles will examine Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's record on social services and the city's budget and economy and Ruth W. Messinger's record as Manhattan Borough President and as Councilwoman.

HEADLINE: THE MARKET PLUNGE: THE POLICY MAKERS;
Washington Tries to Reassure Investors After Plunge: A Muted Response Is Coordinated by Officials

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration sought today to reassure investors after the stock market's plunge, but shied away from addressing the challenges that economic policy makers will face if the market decline continues.
And just as he did a decade ago on Oct. 19, 1987 -- the day the Dow Jones industrial average fell 508 points -- Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve and the official in Washington with the greatest potential influence on the markets, remained silent. But attention turned to whether Mr. Greenspan, who had been hinting recently that interest rates might have to rise to help contain any threat of higher inflation, instead might be driven to reduce rates to reassure investors. 
 A spokesman for the central bank said Mr. Greenspan, who is scheduled to testify to Congress on Wednesday, had been busy monitoring the situation, but declined to provide any details.
"Clearly, he no longer has to worry about 'irrational exuberance,' " said Ed Yardeni, an economist at Deutsche Morgan Grenfell, citing Mr. Greenspan's comment last year about the possibility that the market had become overheated. "Now he needs to calm some irrational hysteria. I think he will do just that by suggesting that the Fed may lower interest rates if necessary."
The market plunge today, of 7.2 percent in the Dow Jones industrial average, was far more moderate than in 1987, when the Dow fell 22.6 percent on a single day. Unlike the 1987 crash, this drop did not leave financial firms scrambling to cover debts. But Mr. Greenspan, analysts said, will face a major challenge if the market continues to fall on Tuesday. Further sharp declines in stock prices would create increasing pressure on the Federal Reserve to repeat the statement it made the morning after the market crash in 1987, when it reassured investors by promising to inject money into the financial system to avert the risks of cascading defaults among brokerage houses and banks.
But any move to loosen monetary policy would push interest rates down at a time when the central bank has been worried about a potential outbreak of inflation and has been leaning, instead, toward raising short-term rates. A crucial indicator that may provide a clue to inflationary pressures, the employment cost index, is to be released Tuesday.
Whatever the indicator shows, Mr. Greenspan, analysts said, will have to balance the short-term need to help stabilize the markets against the potential long-term risk of overstimulating the economy.
Meanwhile, Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin sought to reassure the public. He said the nation's fundamental economic situation remained strong, and he and other officials said there appeared to have been no big problems on Wall Street that might have set off alarm bells about the financial system's basic ability to handle a market decline. "Our consultations indicate that the payment and settlement systems and other market mechanisms are working effectively," Mr. Rubin said.
Another part of the calculation facing American officials tonight was whether to revisit their arms-length approach to the financial crisis in Southeast Asia, where the run on the markets began.
When the International Monetary Fund bailed out Thailand this summer, with a $17.2 billion aid package, the United States was part of the discussions but not a contributor of cash. The thinking in the Administration at the time was that the financial crisis was a regional problem that should be first addressed by Japan and other major economic powers in the Asia, just as the United States took the lead when Mexico collapsed.
But Clinton Administration officials have gradually been rethinking that strategy as the crisis has deepened and resonated around the world. Over the weekend, Mr. Rubin suggested that the United States might take a more active role, through the I.M.F. and other international institutions. Others in the Administration have said internally that the United States needed to make a significant contribution to the Asian bailouts to reassure investors in the region.
Now all those decisions must be made in a different context: Stopping the cycle of selloffs that began in Asia and then circled the globe.
Mr. Greenspan and other policy makers in Washington have long been concerned about the possibility of a plunge in the market and its possible effects on the United States economy and in other markets around the world. Mr. Greenspan issued his latest warning about the sustainability of the bull market less than three weeks ago.
Moreover, Mr. Greenspan's view of the Fed's role in a financial crisis was forged during the 1987 market crash. Mr. Greenspan had then been leading the Fed for just 10 weeks, and won wide praise for his public commitment to provide whatever liquidity the financial system needed.
But Mr. Greenspan has been careful to avoid drawing exact parallels between the situation then and current economic conditions. Moreover, the Fed chairman noted in one speech, that while there was not any large-scale, lasting disruption to the economy after the market fell in 1987, no one can be sure in today's circumstances just how much consumers and businesses might alter their behavior in the event of a sustained market downturn.
The muted response in Washington to today's plunge on Wall Street was coordinated through a working group of senior officials including Mr. Rubin; Mr. Greenspan; Arthur Levitt, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission; Brooksley Born, the chairman of the Commodities Futures Trading Commission, and other regulators and economic policy advisers.
Mr. Rubin briefed President Clinton on the market activity during the afternoon, White House officials said. Paradoxically, the market began plunging in earnest even as Mr. Clinton was delivering a speech in which he announced that the Federal budget deficit had fallen to $22.6 billion in the year ended Sept. 30, its lowest level since the early 1970's.
Indeed, in many ways, the juxtaposition of Mr. Clinton's announcement about the deficit and the market selloff served to emphasize the differences between today's economy and the conditions prevailing when the market fell off a cliff in 1987.
Not only has the budget deficit been tamed, but interest rates are far lower than they were 10 years ago and have been heading lower. Inflation has so far remained dormant, despite low unemployment and steady growth. While the Fed had been raising interest rates prior to the 1987 crash, the central bank this year, while wary that inflation could again take root, has remained on the sidelines since a quarter-point increase in the Federal funds target rate, to 5.5 percent, in March.
"The risks of problems in one part of the world spreading to others does make life more complicated," said L. Douglas Lee, the chief economist in Washington of the HSBC Corporation. "But you always have to return to the fundamental economic situation, and in the U.S. our economy is fundamentally quite healthy."

HEADLINE: Billing Problem Leads to Losses For Big H.M.O.

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
Oxford Health Plans, the big New York area health plan that has been invoked as an industry model for its ability to keep costs down while satisfying patients, said yesterday that it had been losing money because it fell behind in sending bills to customers and underestimated how much it owed doctors and hospitals.
Because of the problems, the company faced the choice of whether to raise premiums more than expected -- perhaps angering the corporate customers with which it contracts -- or to take a big writeoff. 
 It chose the latter, deciding against any changes that would affect plan members. But the move startled investors, and they jettisoned their holdings of its stock yesterday.
The shares of Oxford fell $42.875, or 62.4 percent, to $25.875, in Nasdaq trading, making its stock the biggest decliner on a day when stocks in general plunged by about 7 percent. The market value of Oxford, whose 49 million shares traded made it by far the day's most active issue, plummeted by more than $3 billion, ending the day at slightly more than $2 billion.
Oxford's announcement was only the latest in a string of disastrous financial reports in the managed health care industry, as Aetna, Cigna and other companies said that higher costs would reduce their profits, too. Some economists have begun to question whether, over the longer term, health maintenance organizations can deliver on their promise of keeping health costs under control.
"Oxford joined the long list of H.M.O.'s that lost control over costs," said Kenneth S. Abramowitz, an analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company.
Oxford said it would report a loss of 83 cents to 88 cents a share for the third quarter, in contrast to analyst forecasts for earnings of 47 cents a share, according to I.B.E.S. International.
Much of the loss will be caused by a charge against earnings of $47 million to $53 million to increase reserves, as revenue for the quarter comes in an estimated $111 million less than expected.
Stephen F. Wiggins, chairman of Oxford, said that the company had belatedly discovered that many customers were not paying premiums, often because the company was late in sending bills during eight months from September 1996 to last May. Customers balked when Oxford tried to collect the back payments.
Oxford acknowledged earlier this year that it had fallen behind by hundreds of millions of dollars in payments to hospitals and doctors as it struggled with a new computer system that was intended to help it handle a rapid expansion. With incomplete information in its computers, it had to advance money to doctors and hospitals without verifying that they were obeying Oxford's cost-saving rules.
Oxford, which is based in Norwalk, Conn., is the biggest health maintenance organization in the New York area, with 1.9 million members, up from 1.4 million in 1996.
While Oxford recruited 109,000 new members to its plans from July through September, that expansion slightly trailed company expectations. And some employers with Oxford plans refused to pay the late-arriving bills and dropped the company as an insurer for their workers.
Analysts said the rapid expansion of Oxford was a big reason for its troubles. "When you add 500,000 members a year, it's hard to keep up," Mr. Abramowitz said. He said that Oxford's main rivals in New York, the United Healthcare Corporation, Foundation Health Systems and Aetna, would be the biggest beneficiaries of the company's problems, possibly adding new members at a faster pace.
Compounding Oxford's difficulties was the very feature of its plans that had helped fuel their rapid growth. The plans' liberal rules, compared with other H.M.O.'s, permit many members to go to any doctor or hospital, if they pay more for the privilege. If they choose physicians who are not in Oxford's network, the H.M.O. has little control over how many tests and other services those doctors perform.
"Once you open up all kinds of choice, you've taken away one of the effective tools to control costs that a managed-care organization has," Dr. Henry Simmons, president of the National Coalition on Health Care, said.
Mr. Abramowitz said that while the H.M.O. business in general had grown more difficult, free-choice insurance like Oxford's "is even more difficult, and when you switch information systems, it's extra difficult."
"A company can only digest so much change at one time," he said.
Mr. Wiggins said that Oxford still would make incremental technology changes, but that most problems had been "cleaned up now." He said Oxford would add "about half a percent" to spending on administration next year in an effort to insure that there are no similar problems.
"The important thing," he added, "is we're the same company we were on Friday, except our market value has dropped by half. We still have a very strong enrollment. We are now in our fourth month of on-time billings."
One analyst, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Oxford had a credibility problem because it had repeatedly said earlier this year that its problems had been solved. Still, if the company succeeds now in improving its customer services and in promptly paying doctors and hospitals, the worst could be over.
Analysts noted that most big H.M.O.'s have had problems recently. Aetna and Cigna said earlier this month that higher medical costs were cutting earnings. United Healthcare, Humana and Pacificare have also reported disappointing earnings in the last two years.
Some health care economists said those problems indicated that managed care might be losing its ability to keep costs contained. "The H.M.O. industry has lost a lot of clout," said Uwe E. Reinhardt, an economist at Princeton University.
He said H.M.O.'s had greatly expanded their networks of doctors to attract members. "The wider the network, the less leverage the H.M.O. has over the individual doctor and hospital" to restrain expensive practices, Mr. Reinhardt said.
Dr. Simmons, of the health care coalition, said, "Managed care alone can't possibly fix the total problem of rising costs, falling insurance coverage and serious problems of quality of care."
The coalition, a group of 87 employers, unions, and religious and consumer organizations, published research last week that contended that the slowdown in health costs of recent years was only a temporary blip.
Oxford and other H.M.O.'s have already said that they will raise premiums by 4 percent for 1998.
Analysts, including many who had been enthusiastic supporters of Oxford, said that it would take time for the company to cure its ills. "This will clearly linger through the 1998 earnings results," said Roberta Walter, a health care analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company.
Mr. Wiggins, Oxford's chairman, said that as the holder of about three million company shares, he was "the big loser" in the stock price slide. He said that recent stock sales by company insiders, including himself, were made to raise money for taxes on stock options they had to exercise.
"I know it will take a while to rebuild investor confidence," he added.

HEADLINE: THE MARKET PLUNGE: THE ASIAN CRISIS;
Hong Kong's Slide Goes Deeper

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, Tuesday, Oct. 28

 BODY:
Hong Kong stocks plunged further today, with the benchmark Hang Seng index ending the morning trading session down 1,621.8 points, or 15.45 percent.
Following Monday's sharp drop on Wall Street, the Hong Kong market today fell more than 12 percent at the opening. Scarcely an hour later, the Hang Seng sank like a stone past 9,000, a level not seen since 1988 and what many market analysts had regarded as a psychological barrier. 
 As Hong Kong stocks plunged this morning, Tung Chee-hwa, the man chosen by Beijing to run Hong Kong under Chinese rule, called a crisis meeting of his Cabinet. Afterward, he appeared unconcerned about the plunge, telling reporters that "our fundamentals are strong, that is the most important thing."
The turmoil on Hong Kong's exchange was mirrored throughout Asia this morning, with markets from New Zealand to Tokyo, Manila to Singapore all sharply lower.
The selloffs were accelerated by the overnight plunge on Wall Street.
"Today's crash is the direct consequence of the U.S. market selloff," said John M. Mulcahy, a managing director at Indosuez W. I. Carr, a brokerage firm here.
But even as the market here plummeted, Mr. Mulcahy said that it was uncertain where the damage would end. "All is contingent on what happens on Wall Street overnight," he said, referring to trading later today in New York.
Across Hong Kong, crowds of people gathered in front of market monitors watching the devastation, most murmuring quietly to one another. Some, however, said that some of the stocks seemed cheap. "I'm feeling really good," said Fung Wan, a 66-year-old retired cabbie who was hanging out at the Nang Yang Commercial Bank in front of a market monitor. "I didn't buy when the prices were really high. I'm here to buy cheap stocks."
So far this month, the Hong Kong market has lost 30 percent of its value as institutional investors and small shareholders alike have fled the turmoil created by the Government's dogged defense of the Hong Kong dollar.
Hong Kong's market collapse has deepened the spreading economic and currency crisis in Southeast Asia that was brought on by reckless public spending, declining exports and widespread corruption. And while Hong Kong suffers none of the economic maladies of its neighbors, it is the last in the group whose currency is bonded to the United States dollar.
Last week, convinced that the Hong Kong dollar was overvalued and could be brought down, speculators attacked the currency with a fury. But Hong Kong fought back with equal ferocity to maintain the rate of about 7.75 to 1 that it has fixed against the United States dollar. The moves raised overnight borrowing rates radically and, according to BZW Asia Ltd., required spending $8 billion last Wednesday and Friday to buy Hong Kong dollars.
In the face of this defense, Hong Kong stocks, many of them property companies that are adversely affected by climbing interest rates, went into free fall. They sank 10.4 percent on Thursday, their worst performance in eight years, before surging back by 6.9 percent on Friday as investors bet the worst was over. It was not.
But not all economists were as distressed as small investors who saw their holdings being savaged. "This is a necessary adjustment that Hong Kong has to go through," said Jan Lee, the chief economist of the economic research department of the Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation. "We expect further higher rates."
Despite the plummeting stock market, the Hong Kong Government on Monday reiterated its vow to defend its currency. The hard-line stand has had the desired effect. Virtually no one here expects the link to be ruptured.

HEADLINE: Oklahoma Case Highlights How Economic Burden of Jury Duty Affects Panel's Makeup

BYLINE: By JO THOMAS 

DATELINE: DENVER, Oct. 27

 BODY:
An auto mechanic told Judge Richard P. Matsch of Federal District Court here that he did not think he could make ends meet if he was chosen to sit on the jury for the second Oklahoma City bombing trial.
Each juror, under a fee set by Congress and last adjusted in 1990, will be paid $5 an hour, or $200 a week. But day care alone for the man's two children costs $168 a week, he said. His employer will pay his salary for only four days of jury duty; the trial could last months. 
 "We know financial hardship is something that's involved in a lengthy trial," Judge Matsch told the man sympathetically, "and we're not making light of it at all."
Had the man, the judge asked, tried to negotiate with his employer? Yes, the man replied, but it was all up in the air. His parents would try to help him out.
"Good," the judge said. "We appreciate that."
The search for 12 jurors and 6 alternates to hear the trial of Terry L. Nichols is now in its fifth week and Larry A. Mackey, the lead prosecutor, said tonight that opening arguments would probably be next Monday. But as the selection has unfolded, it has offered a detailed look at an issue that has long concerned legal scholars and professionals: the financial burden of jury duty and its effect on the makeup of a jury that is asked to work for less than the Federal minimum wage, now $5.15 an hour.
"It's the single biggest impediment remaining to recruiting jurors from a cross section of the community," said Jeffrey Abramson, a visiting professor of government at Harvard University and the author of "We the Jury" (Basic Books, 1994).
Several people in the pool of potential jurors for the Nichols trial are retired; others said their employers would make up the difference between their salaries and their jury pay, which will rise to $50 a day if the trial lasts beyond a month. But some said their financial obligations would make it difficult to serve.
Judge Matsch excused a heavy-equipment operator who feared bankruptcy. He also excused a woman who makes her living cleaning houses while caring for her grandchildren and a daughter seriously ill with leukemia. But he urged others to do everything they could to serve.
"We don't put jury service out for volunteers or say that only the people who are retired or don't have a job or don't have anything better to do should serve on juries," he told one prospect. "Obviously, that would not serve the constitutional function of the jury, which is to have a cross section of the community."
Mr. Nichols, 42, is charged with murder and conspiracy in the bombing that killed 168 people on April 19, 1995. His co-defendant, Timothy J. McVeigh, was convicted on identical charges in June, in a trial that lasted 11 weeks. Mr. McVeigh has been sentenced to death.
To cope with the economic burden of a long trial, some prospective jurors here said that they could draw on their savings, move in with their parents or send their children to neighbors for day care. One woman, whose husband was forced by degenerative spine disease to retire without a pension, told the judge she holds down four part-time jobs: mending baseball uniforms, working as a seamstress for a sporting goods store, teaching reading and baby-sitting.
To serve on the jury, she said, she could quit the baby-sitting job, but "I would have to sew after I got off and I would, you know -- it would be putting in probably 18-hour days, 16-hour days." She said she thought the school system where she teaches would continue to pay her. If not, she said, she could use her sick leave.
"So it's doable?" the judge asked her. It was, she said.
The effort that the jurors here are being asked to make is unusual but not unique. The latest figures on the Federal Court system show that 108 criminal trials lasted more than 20 days in the year ending Sept. 30, 1996. Most of the 7,202 criminal trials in that year lasted one to three days.
This year's Congressional appropriation for the fees of Federal jurors, including those on grand juries, was $67 million. The appropriation for lawyers appointed to represent indigents was $325 million; the lawyers, including those serving Mr. Nichols, receive $125 an hour.
"Jurors don't have a lobby," said Seth Andersen, director of the Hunter Center for Judicial Selection at the American Judicature Society, a national nonprofit organization based in Chicago that has long advocated judicial reform.
"Juror pay in the Federal system and in each state system has to be set by statute," he added. "Who would lobby the legislature or lobby Congress to increase jury pay? No one really does it."
Jerome Shestack, president of the American Bar Association, said the organization advocated "reasonable compensation" for jurors, but "the standards are fairly vague."
Traditionally, jury service is seen as "a civic virtue," Mr. Shestack said.
The notion that pay is not important is "O.K. for one or three days," but not for several months, he said.
G. Marc Whitehead, a lawyer with the firm of McDermott, Will & Emery in Chicago, who heads the Jury Initiative Task Force at the American Bar Association, said the issue of pay was reducing diversity on juries because people of modest means could not afford to serve.
"How can you ask a divorced mother with three children at home, or an entrepreneur, to make this huge sacrifice on the part of society, without some reasonable measure of compensation?" Mr. Whitehead asked.
In state trials, jury pay is often even lower, and varies widely. California pays jurors $5 a day; Arizona pays $12. A campaign to improve a wide range of conditions for jurors in New York State, led by the state's Chief Judge, Judith S. Kaye, resulted in legislation that raised jury compensation from $15 a day to $27.50 this year and to $40 next year.
Yet in most jurisdictions, "the legislators just don't see it," said Tom Munsterman, director of the Center for Jury Studies of the National Center for State Courts in Williamsburg, Va. "Who speaks for the jurors? No one."

HEADLINE: THE 1997 ELECTIONS: THE CANDIDATES;
In New Jersey, Rivals Stump At Schools And a Stable

BYLINE: By BRETT PULLEY 

DATELINE: ALDINE, N.J., Oct. 27

 BODY:
Slogging along the edge of a muddy pasture today, in cowboy boots and jeans, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman waved her baseball cap to cajole a stubborn herd of 88 Holstein cattle into their daily ritual of moving down the middle of the road and crossing over into their milking stables.
But herding the cattle in this Salem County town seemed a cinch compared with wooing recalcitrant undecided voters in southern New Jersey. The Governor herself stayed smack in the middle of the road -- making an appeal to moderate voters on the Howard Stern radio program in the morning and touching on conservative themes about personal responsibility to Gloucester County high school students in the afternoon. 
 The Governor's Democratic opponent, James E. McGreevey, addressed a group of Union County high school students on the subject of race, and attended an afternoon rally in Trenton with two dozen Democratic mayors, who joined him to criticize the Governor for the continued rise in property taxes.
Mr. McGreevey, who has repeatedly assailed Mrs. Whitman for borrowing $2.75 billion to balance her budget and shore up the state's pension plan, asserted that the day's precipitous drop in the stock market had underscored the "precarious nature" of Mrs. Whitman's financial policy. "The Governor has held the taxpayers of the state of New Jersey ransom to the market," Mr. McGreevey said.
Although the state's investment in the stock market is a long-term proposition, Mrs. Whitman's fiscal policy and her moderate social positions have caused many in the right wing of her party to take a tepid view of her candidacy. In an attempt to excite her party's base, the Governor campaigned with Terry Branstad, the Governor of Iowa.
"I think the conservative wing of the party will be relieved and feel a lot better when they see people like Terry Branstad, who's a conservative," said Lyn Nofziger, a consultant to Mrs. Whitman. Mr. Nofziger said that other more conservative Republicans, like Jack Kemp and Dan Quayle, are expected to join Mrs. Whitman on the campaign trail.
At Paulsboro High School in Gloucester County, Mrs. Whitman alluded to news accounts of violence involving suburban teen-agers. "We have to have a discussion in this state about personal responsibility," she said. "Every time you make a decision, there are consequences."
Earlier in the morning, she spoke with Mr. Stern on the telephone, and her voice was hoarse because she is battling a cold. "It's very sexy," the typically provocative Mr. Stern said of the Governor's raspy voice. "It's husky. I like it."
And while the unpredictable radio announcer said he supported the Governor because she "didn't buckle under to the right wing of her party," Mrs. Whitman was careful not to let the radio interview move so far left that it might offend conservative voters. When Mr. Stern commended her for sticking to her support of abortion rights, she responded, "What I wish we could get the discussion on is how to keep young women from getting pregnant in the first place when they don't want the baby or can't take care of the baby."
Mr. McGreevey's proposal to reduce auto insurance premiums received a boost today when Ralph Nader, the noted consumer activist, compared it to a plan passed by California voters in 1988, which he said has saved drivers in that state billions of dollars.
At the same time, Mr. McGreevey released a television advertisement that accused Mrs. Whitman of being too close to auto insurance companies. The 30-second spot says Governor is "secretly" allowing an insurance company to raise its premiums in exchange for a donation to the Republican Party. Officials in the Whitman camp quickly dismissed the advertisement as false.
During the evening, Mr. McGreevey attended a fund-raiser in Bayonne, and was a featured speaker at a formal dinner at the new performing arts center in Newark.
Republican officials hope that Mrs. Whitman's focus in south New Jersey will result in a much stronger showing than she had four years ago, when Jim Florio, who was then Governor, dominated his native region. Jack Collins, the Speaker of the State Assembly, said that internal public opinion polls showed the Governor leading Mr. McGreevey in many southern election districts.
As she campaigned in Aldine, Mrs. Whitman was joined once again by the football legend Jim Brown, who at times attracted more attention than she did, as farmers hustled over to shake his hand, and boys crowded around for autographs.
As residents gathered around bales of hay serving as chairs, Mrs. Whitman discussed her agriculture and small-business initiatives, and spoke with reverence of the people who make their living as farmers. "You have my utmost respect," she said.

HEADLINE: THE MARKET PLUNGE: THE STREET;
Horror and Pain, but Oddly, Some Relief

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
Many emotions swept over Wall Street yesterday: horror, panic, pain. But for a lot of market gurus, the strongest feeling was of relief.
That may sound odd on a day when stocks fell farther and faster than they have in a decade, with the Dow Jones industrial average plunging a record 554.26 points. 
 But as traders and investors watched the lines on their computer screens head steadily south, one thought seems to have flashed across a lot of minds: It's about time.
Not that anyone was celebrating the losses that millions of Americans will see in their mutual funds and brokerage accounts, not even the pessimists who had been held up to public ridicule for being bearish. "Sure, the champagne bottle's open, but we have very mixed emotions about this," said James B. Stack, editor of Investech Market Analyst, a newsletter in Whitefish, Mont., that had been predicting the bull market's demise.
But even some optimists almost welcomed the market's setback, which clipped more than 7 percent off the Dow yesterday and left it down about 13 percent since August. "It's almost good to have it out of the way," said Arnold Kaufman, editor of Standard & Poor's Outlook newsletter. "It sort of relieves some of the pressure."
Of course, that assumes that yesterday's drop does not turn into a rout, as it did in 1987, when the Dow fell more than 20 percent in a single day. Whether that occurs has as much to do with investors in Detroit and Duluth and Denver as it does with the financial crisis in Malaysia and Thailand and Hong Kong.
For a decade, American investors have learned that every market retreat is an opportunity to buy, because stocks always seem to recover from their dips. And that is what has made some on Wall Street so nervous.
Why? Before yesterday, the stock market had completed its longest stretch ever without the sort of decline that Wall Street calls a correction, meaning a drop of 10 percent from a peak. In this case, that peak occurred Aug. 6; the rally that preceded it lasted seven years, or twice as long as the next best period in financial history, way back in the early 1960's.
Historically, such setbacks occurred every 18 months or so. So even while stocks soared on a strong economy, low inflation and great earnings, there has been an undercurrent of anxiety on the Street.
By many traditional measures -- compared with companies' earnings, or the value of their assets -- stock prices were extremely high. For example, the stocks in the Dow Jones industrial average have been trading for about 25 times their earnings; historically, that number is more like 16 times, according to data from the Leuthold Group in Minneapolis.
And companies were paying out extraordinarily meager sums to their shareholders in the form of dividends. These dividends amounted to just 1.7 percent of prices -- the dividend yield, in Wall Street's parlance. Historically, stocks have yielded an average of 3.7 percent.
But these high valuations have persisted for ages, and investors who bailed out because of them have been left in the dust. Indeed, some seers said that the market and the economy had entered a new age in which the old rules were null and void.
So part of the relief on Wall Street stems from the feeling that 300 years of financial history has not been overturned. "Valuations do matter in the end," said William E. Rhodes, a vice president for investment strategy at Merrill Lynch. "You always hear, 'It's different this time,' and the situation is different -- but that doesn't mean the rules change."
Some on Wall Street were also worried about less concrete, more anecdotal evidence that stocks had moved too far, too fast: the wave of corporate takeovers paid for with stock, which seemed more attractive than cold cash; the rise of mutual fund managers as media stars; stories about people taking out second mortgages to gamble in the market, and, of course, stock tips offered by everyone from New York taxi drivers to Montana fishing guides.
Of course, the catalyst for the sharp drop yesterday was not valuations or economic fundamentals, but plunging markets in Southeast Asia. These markets have been in trouble for weeks, but until recently -- and particularly until Hong Kong cracked -- American investors pretty much ignored the possibility that what happened overseas could have implications at home.
To many market seers, those implications have now been absorbed, and then some, by investors. "I can't believe the fortunes of D.L.J. are too grossly affected by Hong Kong, but the stock is down 10 percent," said Laszlo Birinyi, a market strategist in Greenwich, Conn., referring to the Wall Street firm of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.
"Financial crises actually tend to be good times to buy," he added.
Moreover, there are those on Wall Street who see a silver lining, although a costly one, in yesterday's plunge. "Some people have been buying stocks because they believe stocks never go down," said Roger Ibbotson, chairman of Ibbotson Associates, which analyzes long-term returns. "The occasional shake-out teaches a lesson too many people have been forgetting."

HEADLINE: THE MARKET PLUNGE: THE INVESTORS;
For Many Market Players, Panic Is for the Other Guy

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
When the great bull market began to teeter yesterday, Esther Curtis was out shopping for groceries.
Ms. Curtis, who is retired and lives in Columbus, Ohio, is an avid investor but not a frightened one. She remembers Oct. 19, 1987, and that strengthened her resolve to ignore any wild swings.
"I'm just holding tight here," Ms. Curtis said in a telephone interview. "I've been in it long enough not to panic. The economy's doing well and the companies are doing well, so I just have the faith." 
 Ms. Curtis is not alone. Traders and investors may well be worried that one of the mightiest bull markets of all time could be stumbling, but while mutual fund companies did say there were some redemptions, almost no one actually admitted feeling panic.
Indeed, the resilience of individual investors, who have rushed into the market since the 1987 market crash, has buoyed stocks repeatedly when there have been dips. Over the last dozen years, Americans have doubled the percentage of household financial assets invested in stocks, pouring money into employers' 401(k) plans and mutual funds in an effort to insure their futures. Wall Street has benefited heavily from the trend, and that may have tempered reactions yesterday at the exchanges.
"It wasn't that bad," said Steve Simmons, a floor trader at the New York Stock Exchange. "The only time it got a little edgy was when it was down 500. All in all, people are kind of laughing it off. It's been a fantastic year. It's kind of like we got in today, got beat by the better team, but tomorrow is another day."
Outside the exchange, a curious crowd had gathered. Harold and Nicola Schlicht, honeymooners from Germany, were on a boat to Ellis Island when the public address system suggested that tourists head for Wall Street. "They said it could be an interesting spot to go today," Mr. Schlicht said. "They said it might be historic." The Schlichts got to Wall Street, though, only to find that the market had closed early. "We're going to go back tomorrow," he said. "And we'll have to line up."
Many pros were unfazed by the plunge. "It was long overdue," said Blane Barbour, an investment banker in Manhattan. "I'm not a pessimist. The market has to stabilize."
And Jerry Hill, an account manager for Tandem Computers who was taking a break on Wall Street, said: "I'm not thinking it's the same thing as '87. The market is always subject to the fear factor, the psychology thing. But the truth is it's the only game in town. The last time, in '87, I hit the panic button and I sold. This time I just don't see enough indicators to make me panic. I personally think this is an overreaction to what is happening in Hong Kong."
By all accounts, trading was orderly. In fact, even though a lot of shares were sold, no one was admitting to doing the selling. Few people were surprised that someone was, though, given the market's long bout of exuberance. And almost everyone interviewed said the selloff presented a buying opportunity.
People talked about a market rocked by events oceans away, in Hong Kong, Japan, Europe and Thailand, and many investors, large and small, called their brokers and looked up various Internet sites to check their holdings. But smaller investors are not yet fleeing.
"It's foolish to sell at this point," said Sue Zane Williams, a retired public school teacher in Honolulu. "Why take a loss? It'll probably come back up."
Some Wall Street analysts have voiced fears that a big plunge would cause panic among many of the 25 million first-time investors who have come into the market since 1990. But in Times Square, a crumbling market was tourist fodder. People craned their necks to catch a glimpse of the huge television set on which CNBC labeled the action "Monday's Selloff," with some gawkers even training video cameras on the towering screen.
Mutual fund investors, meanwhile, made tentative steps to hedge their bets. At fund companies, calling volume was up modestly, but few reported large redemptions.
At Fidelity Investments, where phone traffic was heavy over the weekend, investors made "slight redemptions" from stock funds, said Andy Trincia, a spokesman. Much of the money, he said, was moved into taxable fixed-income funds or money market accounts.
The Vanguard Group, in Valley Forge, Pa., saw the year's first large exodus from equity funds. "There is a little bit sharper and clearer evidence that people want to move to a safe haven," said Brian Mattes, a vice president. But he added, "For every one of those, there appears to be someone who's saying this is a buying opportunity."
Despite all the calls, some analysts say many investors will not respond until they digest the day's news.
"The real volume will be seen tomorrow," said Eric Kobren, who publishes Fidelity Insight, a fund newsletter. "Individual investors continue to be the cushioning agent of the market, while it's the professional money managers who are quicker to pull the trigger and sell."
On-line brokers were in the thick of the activity. Trade-Well Discount Investing, a Manhattan service that allows investors to buy and sell over the Internet, reported that the number of on-line trades doubled to about 150 from a normal day of 75 trades.
But there was no shortage of experts offering this message: relax -- this is not the beginning of a bear market.
"I don't see this as a sign that the American economy is going to shrivel up," said Merton H. Miller, a University of Chicago professor who won the Nobel award in economics in 1990.
Lavonne Raney, 81, of Columbus, Ohio, said she had been here before. "I've lived through many of these," she said. "I was a little girl when the 1929 crash came."
Ms. Raney survived 1929, and she survived 1987, and that is why she believes she is going to survive 1997.
On Wall Street, though, it was undeniably a tense day. "When there was no bounce after the market reopened after the first trading halt, people were wondering whether the market would make it to the closing bell," said one floor trader who refused to be identified. "So instead of being a leisurely jog to 4 o'clock, it became a sprint. The real test tomorrow is: Do mom and pop have the intestinal fortitude to withstand this kind of bloodletting?"
Some show more faith than others. On their annual vacation to New York City, Susan Garbuio and her husband, William Nern, decided there were bargains to be had.
"We were having lunch and we heard that the market went down," said Ms. Garbuio, so they dropped off their packages at their hotel and went straight to a Charles Schwab office to buy stock.
But David Gilden, of Las Vegas, Nev., said, "I'm still in shock." Mr. Gilden, a retired marketing executive who has invested in stocks for more than 30 years, sold some of his mutual fund shares because they were down more than 6 percent, and he may sell more tomorrow. But he plans to hold onto most of the cash, which he socked into a money market fund. And he expects the market to fall further.
"Maybe if it was just the U.S., it would come back," he said. "But you're talking about the whole world."

HEADLINE: THE MARKET PLUNGE: THE SELLOFF;
STOCKS FALL 554 POINTS, OFF 7%, FORCING SUSPENSION IN TRADING

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
A worldwide plunge in stock prices erased more than 7 percent from the Dow Jones industrial average yesterday and forced the New York Stock Exchange to halt trading. The only other interruptions like this came after the wounding of President Ronald Reagan and the assassination of President John F. Kennedy.
No one knew just how far the market might have fallen had not market rules -- adopted in the wake of a stock market crash 10 years ago -- required the exchange and other American stock markets to close at 3:30 P.M., half an hour before the scheduled 4 P.M. closing bell. 
 The tumble further unnerved Asian markets as trading resumed there. After the midday break today, Hong Kong stocks were down more than 12 percent -- the sharpest fall since 1989.
In Tokyo, the Nikkei index of 225 issues closed today down 725.97 points, or 4.26 percent, at 16,312.39. Other markets in Asia were sharply lower in morning trading.
The overnight fall on Wall Street raised concerns among investors in Asian markets that a prolonged downturn in the United States stock markets would reduce consumer demand for Asian exports. Traders also feared that the global selloff had not yet hit bottom.
As Hong Kong stocks plunged this morning, Tung Chee-hwa, the chief executive of Hong Kong, called a crisis meeting of his Cabinet. Afterward, he said he considered the plunge to be temporary, telling reporters that "our fundamentals are strong, that is the most important thing." Page D25.
Yesterday, the Dow average ended down 554.26 points, or 7.2 percent, at 7,161.15, the worst day in a decade and the 12th worst ever. The drop was, however, only about a third as large as the 22.6 percent, 508-point drop on Oct. 19, 1987.
The latest plunge has been somewhat of a surprise to most American equity analysts. They had been closely watching the Federal Reserve Board and the economic statistics for any sign of rising inflation and of a Fed inclination to raise interest rates. There is little sign of danger on those fronts.
Instead, "The fear is of profit deflation emanating from Asia," said Doug Cliggott, the chief equity strategist at J. P. Morgan. Since July, several Asian currencies have fallen sharply, and more recently stock markets have followed. It appears that much of Asia, the world's fastest-growing region for much of this decade, is likely to see little if any economic growth in the near future. There is a risk that prices of many goods will fall as countries compete for dwindling export markets.
For much of the summer and early fall, even as Asian problems were growing, the American and European stock markets remained relatively strong. "Many market professionals thought the stock market was overvalued, but the market kept going up and the momentum kept them in," said Robert Barbera, the chief economist for Hoenig & Company. "Now they know it is overvalued and not going up anymore."
The Asian problems clearly threaten the profits of many multinational companies, but the reaction to them has also driven many investors into United States Treasury securities, as the safest investment around, and helped drive interest rates down.
That means, Mr. Barbera noted, that American investors may be feeling poorer with lower stock prices, but they will also be enjoying lower mortgage interest rates.
Since the Dow peaked on Aug. 6 at 8,259.31, it has fallen 13.3 percent. This is the first time since 1990 that the Dow has suffered a drop of at least 10 percent, based on daily closes. In the 1990 drop, which came as the country entered a brief recession and as Iraq invaded Kuwait, temporarily driving up oil prices, the Dow fell 21.2 percent in less than three months.
Yesterday's drop was considerably less severe than the worst loss of the 1929 crash, a 12.8 percent decline on Oct. 28, 1929 -- 68 years ago almost to the day.
Within the stock market yesterday, the fall was relatively orderly, in sharp contrast to the 1987 plunge. Traders said there was selling from nearly all types of traders, whether individual or institutional, domestic or foreign. Big Board volume was 685.5 million shares, the largest ever, but only a little above the previous session. Although it no doubt would have been higher had the market not closed early, so far the market has not seen the explosive growth in volume seen in the 1987 crash.
Both the New York Stock Exchange and the Nasdaq stock market said their systems worked well. It appeared that most people who wanted to trade -- at least before the markets closed early -- were able to. In 1987, that was not the case. "The panic of 1987, which I think was fed by the fact that phones were not being answered and people could not find out what prices were, was absent here," said Frank Zarb, the president of the National Association of Securities Dealers, which runs Nasdaq.
Yesterday represented the first real test for so-called circuit breakers, added after 1987 in an effort to insure that prices would not plunge without reason and to give the public a chance to assess lower prices and consider buying stocks at cheap prices.
The Big Board's rule calls for a half-hour trading halt when the Dow falls 350 points and another hour if the loss widens to 550 points. With the first milestone hit, trading was halted at 2:35 P.M. Some had worried that it would be difficult to reopen after such a halt, possibly because of an imbalance of orders that came in during the break. That proved not to be the case -- only two Big Board stocks experienced any significant reopening delay -- but there was no relief from the downward pressure.
The market had halted with the Dow at 7,361.04. By 3:17, only 12 minutes after the market had reopened, the Dow was down another 100 points, and by 3:30 it had fallen a total of 550 points, and a few more by the time the closing order could be executed. Under the circuit breaker rules, the market could have reopened after a one-hour halt, but because the halt came after 3 P.M., the market closed for the day.
The most important test of the circuit breakers will come this morning when the market reopens.
The Dow ended the day yesterday down more than most market indexes, although the selling was widespread. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks fell 6.9 percent, the Nasdaq composite lost 7.0 percent and the Russell 2,000 index of smaller stocks was off 6.1 percent. Earlier in the day, all those indexes had been off significantly more than the Dow, which contains only 30 stocks.
It was possible that some selling in the Dow stocks came as the market neared the circuit breakers, with traders knowing that if the Dow stocks fell even a little more, all stocks would stop trading .
It appeared there was substantial selling of stock programs, or groups of stocks sold simultaneously by one trader. That may indicate use of some strategies known as "dynamic hedging," which call for traders to limit losses by selling as prices fall. The best-known form of program trading, called "index arbitrage," is now effectively banned when the market has a big move.
In 1929, the Big Board never closed early, although there were shortened trading hours and even market holidays, supposedly to catch up with paperwork. The only times in recent years when the Big Board has closed early due to concerns about prices were in 1963, when trading was halted in the aftermath of the assassination of President Kennedy, and in 1981, following the attempted assassination of President Reagan.
The slide in American stock prices has mirrored declines around the world that began with last week's sharp falls in Hong Kong. Nearly every market, from Britain to Brazil and from Australia to Austria, has fallen sharply.
But last week it was the United States that was doing relatively better, and thus helping to slow the worldwide selling. Yesterday the American market performed far worse than other major markets, although not as badly as Latin American markets, which were open at the same time as New York and could witness the carnage in that market.
European markets fell between 2 percent and 4 percent yesterday, and then the United States fell even more. By the end of the day in New York, only one of the S.& P. 500 stocks gained for the day. Apple Computer rose 19 cents to $16.75, apparently on speculation that Steve Jobs, its co-founder, would agree to be chief executive again.

"ERASING PAPER WEALTH"
Yesterday's market decline wiped out billions of dollars in market capitalization around the world. Owners of most stocks are now poorer -- on paper -- than they were yesterday. But the bull market's gains before yesterday mean that most investors still own stocks worth more than they paid for them, and so have not yet lost any money they invested, but only forgone some profits.

HEADLINE: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW YORK CITY;
Bulk Discount Approved For Buses and Subways

 BODY:
The Metropolitan Transportation Authority gave final approval yesterday to a bulk discount that will effectively cut the bus and subway fare to $1.36, from $1.50, in January.
The 9 percent discount, equivalent to getting 11 trips for the price of 10, will be offered to Metrocard customers who put at least $15 on their cards. 
 Several speakers at yesterday's M.T.A. board meeting, however, said the authority should be doing even more for riders because its revenues are running about $100 million ahead of schedule this year.
Between increased ridership, higher tax revenue from New York's economic boom and lower-than-expected expenses, the authority could have an extra $160 million by the end of the year, the City Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, said.
Mr. Vallone asked the authority to roll the fare back to its 1995 level of $1.25. Jonathan Sigall, a staff planner for the Permanent Citizens Advisory Council to the M.T.A., urged the board to consider offering monthly passes. And an aide to Representative Jerrold L. Nadler, a Democrat representing parts of Manhattan and Brooklyn, asked the board to provide free rides for children and the elderly.
