HEADLINE: NEW YORK CITY MARATHON: SPECIAL PREVIEW SECTION;
Marathon Is Staged As Outdoor Theater

BYLINE: By JERE LONGMAN

 BODY:
AS SHE entered Central Park for a training run before the 1996 New York City Marathon, Tegla Loroupe of Kenya was spotted by a homeless man, who sat up from a bench and called out to the two-time winner, "Are you that runner, that Tegla?"
"I wasn't expecting that," Loroupe said. "But that is why I love New York, the people." 
 Where else but New York will someone yell out of a window as the four-hour marathoners reach the halfway point, "You can all stop now, we have a winner."
And what other city would cheer, "Come on, Sister," for a hairy-legged man wearing a habit and running as a billboard for Blue Nun wine?
"I don't want to sound religious, but marathon day is almost the best day for humanity," said Phyllis Marchand, the deputy mayor of Princeton, N.J., who will be running her 14th New York City Marathon on Sunday.
"The diversity and pulling together of people is something that I think is extraordinary. You see police interacting, you see Hasidic Jews working with African-Americans, who are working with the Latino community. I wish every day could be marathon day."
There is nothing quite like the organized chaos of the New York City Marathon, which winds its way through the city's five boroughs for 26.2 miles in a procession that is equal parts race, fitness celebration, street festival and sociological statement.
The race is singular in many ways, from the size of the field (30,463 entrants as of late September) to the embrace of the crowd (an estimated 2 million spectators line the streets from Fourth Avenue in Brooklyn to the finish line in Central Park).
Gina Martinelli, a physical therapist from Havertown, Pa., would like to run a marathon in as many states as possible. She has run four marathons thus far, from Anchorage, Alaska, to Boston, and now she will attempt New York.
"I want to be able to say I accomplished the biggest marathon in the world," Martinelli said.
This year's field, which is approximately one-third local, one-third national and one-third international in makeup, includes runners from every state but North Dakota, and from 95 countries ranging from Albania to Zimbabwe.
A woman from Iran will compete among the recreational runners this year, and another from Algeria and China. And among Sunday's marathoners will be 1,592 administrators, 1,400 attorneys, 1,275 teachers, 72 hairdressers and 55 bartenders.
"You can look at the professions and it pretty much reflects what's going on in this country," said Marchand, the deputy mayor of Princeton. "Last year, or the year before, I looked under politicians, and there were 2 women and 4 men; there were probably more, but they didn't want to own up to it."
In its 28th running, the New York City Marathon is facing growing competition for top runners from other fall marathons in Chicago and Japan.
Todd Williams, America's top 10,000-meter runner, decided to make his marathon debut on Oct. 19 in Chicago, where the course was flatter and faster and the financial incentives were more enticing. Fatuma Roba of Ethiopia, the 1996 Olympic champion, will run her fall marathon in Fukuoka, Japan.
New York has received criticism for not catering enough to top American marathoners. Some runners and agents say that New York's prize structure is not big enough or deep enough, noting that its first-place prize of $50,000 is $25,000 less than Boston awarded in April.
Dave D'Alessandro, a top executive with the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company and the man credited with revitalizing the Boston Marathon, has accused New York of losing its focus and diminishing its international aura, calling the event "overwhelming."
Allan Steinfeld, race director of the New York City Marathon, takes sharp issue with these criticisms. The prize money doubles for Americans who finish among the top five, he notes. Boston requires qualifying times for entry, which makes it different from New York, where 10,562 runners entered this year are competing in their first marathon. Finishing is important to them, not winning.
"We have an open race; it's a people's event," Steinfeld said. "At the same time, we will match our elite athletes and their fame and fortune against any marathon. When something happens in New York, it is national and international news."
New York has faithfully maintained the ideals of the race's founder, Fred Lebow, which is to put on an international marathon that reflects an international city, Steinfeld said.
Even though the race is now being shown nationally on ESPN2 instead of its parent company, ABC, Steinfeld said the marathon will reach 300 million households worldwide in 75 to 100 countries. (In New York, the race will be televised on WPIX, Channel 11.) The yearly local economic impact is $100 million, Steinfeld said.
"It's more of an international race than any marathon in the world," he said.
Among the elite runners, Loroupe owns the fastest women's time in the world this year: 2 hours 22 minutes 7 seconds. German Silva, a two-time winner from Mexico, is returning in hopes of a third title.
"If you win New York, you are recognized everywhere," Silva said. "I love the environment, the hotels where everybody is speaking different languages, the neighborhoods. When I won, I couldn't pay for a meal."
Mark Coogan, a 1996 Olympian from Boulder, Colo., is the top American contender in this year's field. Born in Manhasset, N.Y., Coogan will be running his first marathon in New York City. As a high school runner, he kept a poster in his room showing the arm-raised ecstasy of Rod Dixon of New Zealand, the 1983 winner, and the crumpled agony of Geoff Smith of Britain, who was passed after 26 miles and lost by 9 seconds.
"If you're a marathoner, New York is one you should try," Coogan said. "I've been watching tapes of previous races. I get nervous watching people line up on the bridge, the crowds, the boats. I've been to the race the last three years, and your heart starts going fast, and you tell yourself, 'Why am I not doing this?' "
Is there a more compelling scene in all of sports than the start on the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, with 30,000 runners squeezing through the start like corpuscles through an artery, beginning a 26-mile journey that others might consider impossible or crazy?
"It's exciting to see the city in the distance," said Leslie Buckland, a 68-year-old adventurer from Manhattan who reached 24,500 feet on Mt. Everest last May and who will run his 22d New York City Marathon.
"It's rather like running to a castle in medieval days. You tell yourself, 'I'm going to storm the ramparts of Elsinore,' and then you start running. Every time I do the last 100 yards, I'm weeping. How many people in their lives have thousands and thousands of people cheering for them?"
At 16 miles, the runners come off the Queensboro Bridge and are greeted by a wall of sound along First Avenue. Always runners are warned not to be seduced by the siren call of the crowds with 10 miles remaining. Almost always, they succumb to the cheering.
It is the hospitality here and in the ethnic neighborhoods, especially, that makes the race what it is and that dispels, for an afternoon anyway, any notion of New York as a dangerous, forbidding, uncaring city.
No one who has run the race can fail to be moved by the bands playing, the children slapping hands as the runners pass, the volunteers handing out water, candy, slices of orange and unfailing encouragement.
"When you run through New York, it seems like you run through so many different communities and so many thought processes," said Keith Brantly, a 1996 Olympian who finished fifth in New York in 1993.
Susan Wilson, a native of Manhattan who lives in Princeton, has run everywhere from London to Hanoi, and at 67, she will attempt her first marathon. New York seemed to be the natural place.
"I remember learning how to roller skate in Central Park," Wilson said. "When I started running 15 years ago, I started around the reservoir. It is sort of my backyard.
"I'm looking at this as a one-shot deal, with my fingers crossed. There's nothing like the crowds they're going to have. You'll see people at their best. I think it will be a transcendent experience."

According to information provided by the entrants, the quintessential New York City marathoner would be male, married and thirtysomething, with a graduate degree and a New York address. Even though applicants could choose from 71 professions - including bartender (55 entrants), filmmaker (90), retired (318), security guard (40) and unemployed (71) - the most prevalent occupation was "other" (7,839).
 
"Years and People to Remember"
1970
The first marathon is a multiple-lap run through Central Park, with 127 starters and 55 finishers. The winner is Gary Muhrcke, a New York City firefighter.
 
1976
The marathon visits all five boroughs for the first time, and Bill Rodgers scores the first of his four consecutive victories. The marathon and its new champion become instant stars.
 
1983
In a steady rain, Rod Dixon, above, closes a large hap and passes Geoff Smith at the 26-mile mark on his way to a dramatic nine-second victory.
 
1988
Grete Waitz, left, remains the race's most-loved and most-decorated champion. In 1988, the Norwegian captures her ninth and last title - after having won eight from 1978-86 and setting three world records along with way. In 1992, when she ran with the race director Fred Lebow as he battled cancer, it seemed as if the cheers of "Grete, Grete" had never stopped.
 
1994
German Silva of Mexico wins the first of his two titles despite making a wrong turn into Central Park seventenths of a mile from the finish.
 
1996
Giacomo Leone, who wasn't chosen for the Italian Olympic team, surprises everyone with his closing speed and joins past Italian winners like Orlando Pizzolato and Gianni Poli. Anuta Catuna of Romania is the women's champion.

HEADLINE: SIPS;
Am I a Little Tipsy, or Did That Martini Glass Just Grow?

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GRIMES 

 BODY:
THE martini has just been supersized. In one fell swoop, the standard 6-ounce glass has ballooned to 10 ounces at restaurants like Ben Benson's and Smith & Wollensky in Manhattan, where the steaks used to be the biggest thing on the menu. The king of drinks now joins the one-pound muffin, the triple bacon cheeseburger and the Lincoln Town Car as a potent symbol of America the Huge.
Ten ounces. That's a long way to the bottom of the glass. The big-gulp martini may be the first cocktail that requires channel markers and a lifeguard. It certainly changes the complexion of the three-martini lunch, which will now have to be regarded as a suicide pact rather than as a meal. 
 It also makes William Powell as Nick Charles look like a sissy. Close scrutiny of "The Thin Man" movies shows that the wicked martini of the 1930's came attired in a dainty curved glass, a four-ouncer by the look of it, that would be appropriate for a late-afternoon sweet sherry. No wonder he was always trying to catch up on his drinking -- he was sipping from a thimble. Myrna Loy, as Nora Charles, knocks back five martinis in a row at the beginning of the movie, and it looked pretty audacious at the time. Now we know she was just trying to get a decent-sized drink.
Ignore economic irrelevancies like interest rates, the Dow Jones industrial average and housing starts. The martini just went up four ounces. The recovery is official. WILLIAM GRIMES

HEADLINE: Reform Social Security

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Contrary to Peter Passell's Oct. 23 Economic Scene column on Social Security, I don't propose to "limit reforms to tucks and trims that would delay the day of reckoning for perhaps an extra decade." What I and others propose is to choose among several options to bring the program into balance for the 75-year period for which actuarial estimates are usually made. 
 These options include extending coverage, increasing taxation of benefits, improving the accuracy of cost-of-living adjustments, increasing the contribution rate (less than a third of 1 percent) and reducing benefits for those retiring in the future by 3 percent to 6 percent.
The need for even these modest tax increases and benefit cuts could be greatly reduced by changing the policy of investing Social Security money only in low-yield government bonds and instead allowing partial investment in equities. These are not "tucks and trims." They would maintain Social Security in long-term balance without diverting money into a new system of individual accounts that do nothing to help Social Security's financing.
 
ROBERT M. BALL
Alexandria, Va., Oct. 27, 1997
The writer, Social Security Commissioner from 1962 to 1973, was a member of the Social Security Advisory Council, 1994-96.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Non-Panic of '97

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

 BODY:
This was not It.
In July, just as the stock market was reaching its peak, I donned my sandwich boards and wrote: "You're going to see a correction one of these days that will curl your hair, followed by a year in the doldrums before the next recovery. . . . Repent! The end is near." 
 Greed being what it is, I didn't dump much after my own jeremiad, which is why nobody can hate me after the babyboomers' babybust and bounceback.
But this was not a hair-curler. Instead, it was the shakeout of nervous professionals who were looking for some outside event to justify a rush to lock in the year's profits.
Turmoil in the Asian markets, reflecting incipient deflation there, was the cathartic our traders were waiting for. America's small investor, however, was not suckered by all the globalony. When market averages backed 10 to 15 percent off their highs, the little guy resisted all chicken-littling. Only the market, not the sky, was falling.
What explains the Non-Panic of '97?
It was not Robert Rubin standing on the steps of the Treasury saying "the fundamental economy is strong." Such pronouncements by government officials smack of "prosperity is just around the corner"; they reassure nobody.
One reason for the non-panic was that the media, which love anniversaries, have been reminding us for weeks of the 22 percent market break of '87, compared with which Gray Monday's drop of 7 percent was not so terrible. "Selloff" was the preferred term of commentators; few used the scarier term "crash."
A better reason is that the fundament is strong. Inflation and unemployment are down, and growth and profits are up.
Global domino effect? A worry but not a panicker; any drop in demand for our exports to Asia is not going to put much of a crimp in our huge national product. And Asian investors aren't crazy; they'll look for safe havens, of which there are no safer than U.S. stocks and bonds.
That's why this week's market turmoil is not It. Like Californians after a mild quake, we can say, "But this wasn't the Big One."
There is a good message in all the bouncing down and up, however, to be directed to the new-age, new-paradigm new-economists who waltz hand in hand with Goldilocks and Rosie Scenario.
That message is: There are other ways to go besides up. Just as the fluctuating nature of the stock market has not been fundamentally altered by the end of the cold war or the beginning of the globalized computer age, economies will stumble and recover as they have in the past.
Just as markets breathe, economies breathe. That natural inhaling and exhaling, contraction and expansion, means that the business cycle has not been steamrollered into permanent flatness. Someday we will have a recession.
A market drop may not trigger a recession, but a recession always harms the stock market. Reduced profits reduce tax revenues and increase the budget deficit.
Now to the big lesson we can draw from the market's wake-up call. President Clinton proudly pointed to the shrinking of our deficit to the lowest in decades. His economists see the deficit in the fiscal year that ended last month to be $22 billion.
But in February of this year, the Office of Management and Budget was predicting a deficit of $125 billion. It was off by $100 billion, plus change, not because of any spending restraint but because an economic boom produced greater revenues.
If we can be that wrong on the downside, we can be that wrong on the upside. As recession follows prosperity (as night follows day, and as market shakeouts follow run-ups), then all the optimistic budget agreements on which we base our spending and taxing will be knocked into a cocked hat.
The message this week is that markets have a downside, and that it is wise to keep a little cash on the side. Economies also have a downside, and it would be wise for our political leaders to treat as hogwash the predictions of the new-era economists that the only way is up.
Hand me those sandwich boards. As I was saying about a market break before a real recession, Repent! The end is near.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Britain Is No Model On Job Creation

 BODY:

To the Editor:
A news analysis on the decision by Germany's central bank to raise short-term interest rates (Business Day, Oct. 23) suggests that European countries are becoming less competitive because of social welfare policies and says that Britain has promoted job creation through labor market flexibility. 
 According to the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, productivity growth in European countries has consistently been faster than in the United States. Since 1979, productivity in France and Germany has increased by 48.8 percent and 54.9 percent, respectively. This compares with an increase of just 13.8 percent in the United States.
While Britain does have significantly lower unemployment than most European countries, it has not achieved this through job growth. According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, Britain actually lost 70,000 jobs from 1989 to 1996. Job growth in France and Germany was extremely slow, but at least there was growth.
The decline in Britain's unemployment rate was because many workers became so discouraged that they gave up looking for work and were therefore no longer counted in the unemployment data.
 
DEAN BAKER
Washington, Oct. 24, 1997
 
The writer is an economist at the Economic Policy Institute.

HEADLINE: THE 1997 ELECTIONS;
In Their Own Words

 BODY:

RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI
During a visit yesterday to Maria Hernandez Park in Bushwick, Brooklyn, the Mayor commented on the plunge in stock prices on Wall Street on Monday. 
 "The city is a lot more stable today than it was 4 years ago, or 10 years ago. The general reserve of the City of New York is five times what it was in 1987, two and a half times what it was in 1993. In other words, we're saving $500 million now. We used to save only $200 million and $100 million. Through welfare reform, again for which there's a lot of political criticism, we saved over $650 million. So the city is in a lot more stable position than it was in a few years ago. We've cut the work force by 24,000 city-funded; over all by 36,000. So the margin of what the city could now absorb is much greater than it was back then."
 
RUTH W. MESSINGER
To students at Long Island University in Brooklyn yesterday.
"The ups and downs on Wall Street have shown that it's not good for the city to have so many of our eggs in that basket -- that what the city needs to do is encourage new kinds of businesses to grow. We definitely need to encourage businesses to grow because we are living right now with an unemployment rate in the City of New York which is much too high. When I say much too high, I mean it is higher than that of almost every other city in the country, every other large city in the country. And I mean that what is most troubling is that our unemployment rate now is 9.3 percent, is just about twice the national average. So whatever is happening nationally that has allowed the economy to grow, jobs to be created and unemployment to go down is not happening here."

HEADLINE: Dollar Finishes Lower in a Broad Slump

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar tumbled to a five-month low against the Swiss franc and a four-month low versus the German mark yesterday despite a powerful rebound in United States stocks.
The dollar also finished lower against the Japanese yen and other European currencies despite rebounding slightly in volatile trading after stocks recovered from their big losses on Monday. 
 The dollar was unable to recoup all of its early losses yesterday, however, because trading was lighter in North America than overseas, where most of the damage to the dollar occurred before the United States stock market opened, said Christopher Low, a senior economist at HSBC Securities.
Traders turned to the European currencies as havens instead of the dollar because those countries' economies are seen as being less dependent on Asia, where a financial crisis had led to the global drop in stocks in the last week.
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 1.4223 Swiss francs, down from 1.4499 late Monday, to reach its lowest point since May 30. It also settled at 1.7368 marks, down from 1.7495, and its lowest level since June 26.
The dollar traded at 120.47 yen, down from 121.87. It also remained weak against the British pound after dropping to a three-month low on Monday when the British Government said it would not quickly join Europe's planned common currency. Yesterday, the pound sold for $1.6711, up from $1.6595.

HEADLINE: Fed Is Expected to Postpone Discussion of Higher Rates

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28

 BODY:
Even after the sharp rebound today in stock prices, analysts said that turmoil in the markets would force the Federal Reserve Board to postpone consideration of raising interest rates until next year, and that it could diminish any risk of the economy's overheating.
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, is scheduled to lay out his view of the economy to a Congressional committee on Wednesday morning. Economists said he would almost certainly avoid making any comments that might unnerve the markets, especially in the wake of the rout on Monday that erased 7.2 percent from the Dow Jones industrial average. 
 In Congressional testimony three weeks ago, Mr. Greenspan warned that the bull market might not be sustainable, and he suggested that further declines in the already low unemployment rate could cause inflation. His comments led investors to conclude that the Fed might raise rates as soon as its next policy meeting, on Nov. 12, if unemployment fell more and growth remained strong.
But because Wall Street bounced back so strongly today -- and because the financial system had no apparent problem weathering the plunge on Monday -- analysts said Mr. Greenspan was unlikely to make any explicit promise to loosen monetary policy to reassure investors.
"The market turmoil has obviated the need for any Fed tightening in the near term," said James F. O'Sullivan, an economist at J. P. Morgan & Company. "If anything, it's the chairman's role to calm the markets rather than giving them anything to worry about."
The analysts said they expected Mr. Greenspan to emphasize the message that the Clinton Administration stressed in the last two days: the economy and the financial system remain fundamentally sound. Speaking in Chicago this morning at about the time that the Dow Jones industrial average was shooting back into positive territory for the day, President Clinton said the economy was "as strong and vibrant as it has been in a generation."
Mr. Greenspan will be able to point to statistics released today suggesting that the risks of inflation are not rising substantially. The Labor Department reported wages are not rising at a rate that greatly increases the danger of inflation. The Conference Board, a business group, said the high levels of consumer confidence that had helped drive growth had begun to ebb even before the Monday stock rout rattled investors.
Economists said the Federal Reserve might also have pared its growth projections to account for the troubles afflicting Asia. The United States sends about a third of its exports to Asia, and the weakened economies there, combined with a strong dollar, are expected to reduce demand for American goods enough to trim economic growth in the United States for the rest of this year and into the next.
The devaluation of many Asian currencies will also depress the price in dollars of goods imported from that region, helping restrain inflation in the United States, economists said.
"Economic growth is in the process of slowing down," said Sung Won Sohn, the chief economist for the Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis. "The stock market correction is going to make the slowdown a bit more pronounced, especially because the balance of trade will deteriorate as a result of the Asian currency meltdown."
Mr. Sohn said that Mr. Greenspan's concerns about the tight labor market were unlikely to have dissipated, and that the economy might not slow enough to avert the outbreak of wage and price pressures early next year.
"I don't think we should eliminate the possibility of a Fed tightening in February if financial market conditions stabilize," he said.
Even in the absence of market turmoil, the economic reports issued today would probably have strengthened the case for the Fed's holding interest rates steady for at least a month or two.
The Labor Department's Employment Cost Index, a broad measure of changes in wages and benefits, rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in the third quarter, the same increase shown in the previous quarter. The figure matched the expectations of analysts and suggested that wages were not rising rapidly enough to set off inflation alarms.
Wages and salaries rose nine-tenths of 1 percent in the third quarter, compared with eight-tenths in the second quarter, but benefit increases slowed to four-tenths of 1 percent from six-tenths.
The Conference Board said its consumer confidence index fell to 123.3 this month from 130.2 in September. Because much of the economy's strength this year has come from the willingness of consumers to spend and accrue additional debt, any reduction in their optimism could translate into less spending and a reduction in growth to a rate less likely to set off inflation. But whether the stock market's gyrations will further erode consumer confidence is an open question.
"It's too early to determine whether the October decline signals the beginning of a downward trend in consumer confidence or whether it's simply a temporary blip in a still-strong upward pattern," said Lynn Franco, the associate director of the Conference Board's Consumer Research Center.

HEADLINE: After First Sinking With Asia, Europe Recovers With U.S.

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Oct. 28

 BODY:
European stock markets recovered in part from early selloffs today, lifted at the end of their trading sessions by an upturn on Wall Street.
Faced with another overnight rout on Asian markets, European markets plunged at the opening. In London, Europe's biggest market, the Financial Times Stock Exchange index of 100 leading shares fell as much as 9 percent in the morning. 
 In Frankfurt, the DAX index of 30 leading stocks plummeted 400 points, or 13 percent, in the first 30 minutes of trading. Stocks in France, Switzerland and other markets also fell sharply.
"The volume was extraordinary; we nearly had a record high," said Reta Francioni, a member of the Frankfurt stock exchange's executive board. "But it was a correction, not a crash. We had orderly markets."
The markets later steadied and then recovered some lost ground as United States stocks, which open in the last hour to two hours of European trading, began to climb.
The Financial Times index closed just 1.76 percent, or 85.3 points, lower. The DAX ended the session off 8.04 percent, or 311.90 points, but the loss was further cut in after-hours electronic trading, with the DAX index ending down 5.83 percent, or 225.70. French and Swiss stocks recovered from slumps of as much as 10 percent. The Paris CAC-40 index closed down 118.31, or 4.27 percent, while the Swiss market index closed down 253.8, or 4.59 percent.
As European markets steadied today, economists contended that the turmoil in Asian markets should not significantly change the basic economic outlook for Europe.
Though Europe's inchoate economic recovery has been driven primarily by exports, many experts argue that exports to Southeast Asia do not account for enough of the total to make a big dent in the growth prospects for countries like Germany and France.
Kermit Schoenholtz, chief economist for Salomon Brothers, said the turmoil in Hong Kong and the panic in world stock markets had not changed the fundamental prospects for strong economic growth in Europe's biggest countries next year.
"Personally, I believe that growth in core Europe in 1998 will be the fastest since 1990," Mr. Schoenholtz said today. "It will probably exceed the growth rate of the United States for the first time in several years."
To be sure, there were plenty of signs of panic, particularly in the emerging markets of Central and Eastern Europe. Russian stock markets, which have climbed faster than those of any other country in the world and have tripled the last 12 months, were shut down for several hours today as panic set in. Brokers said prices plunged at least 20 percent in over-the-counter trading.
Currencies in Eastern and Central Europe lost value against the dollar amid speculation that Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic might follow the path of Southeast Asia.
But some experts doubted Central and Eastern Europe would fall. "In Eastern Europe, the financial systems are in better shape," said Stuart Parkinson at Deutsche Morgan Grenfell in London.

HEADLINE: Wall Street Sneezes and the Russians Catch a Chill

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Oct. 28

 BODY:
During Soviet days, a stock-market plunge in the West would have been cause for rejoicing in the Kremlin.
But with a pro-capitalist Government, a fledging stock market and a crying need for Western financing, the new Russia is increasingly integrated into the world economy. So much so that Monday's stock plunge in New York sent shock waves through Russia's capital, prompting a frantic effort by top Yeltsin aides to head off the panic selling of stocks and Government bonds. 
 Even so, the Kremlin's effort failed to stop the precipitous fall in the stock market here, as shares fell about 40 per cent from their August high.
Economists also warned that unease over emerging markets has already hurt the federal Government, which has sold bonds internationally and domestically to help finance the budget deficit. Local governments hungry for capital have also been hurt. The result could be still more painful retrenchments in government spending.
"The Russian economy fully felt itself to be a part of the world economic system," observed Sergei Dubinin, chairman of the Central Bank.
This is by no means the equivalent of Black Tuesday, the day in 1994 when the ruble collapsed and the panic that ensued affected everyone. The average Russian, however, owns no stocks, mutual funds or Government bonds.
But like stock markets in the West, the Russian stock exchange had been on an ascending track, tripling over the past 18 months. Foreign investors have not been the only ones snapping up the stocks. Increasingly, Russian companies and the Russian business elite have also been getting into the act.
While brokers here have boasted that the Russian stock market was the hottest in the world, there have been increasing indications that the bull market was turning into a Russian bear.
Last week, the Russian stock market took a hit as the economic turmoil in Southeast Asia began to sour foreign investors on all emerging markets, despite the dissimilarities between the Russian and Southeast Asian economies.
Monday's plunge on the New York Stock Exchange sent the market here into a tailspin. The leading shares in the Russian market lost 19 per cent of their value today.
Peter Kizenko, the chief of equity trading in Moscow for ING Barings estimated that stocks in general were down about 40 per cent from their high in early August. "Russia is cheap once again," quipped Mr. Kizenko, who added that he expected the market to recover.
But not everybody was laughing. The Russian Government halted trading for several hours today in a vain effort to halt the slide. The Central Bank bought up rubles to stabilize the Russian currency.
Central Bank officials also sought to boost the slumping market for Russian treasury bonds. The once sky-high interest rates of the treasury bills have declined considerably this year and the Russian Government is not eager to assume the huge costs of paying higher interest rates to attract buyers.
Top Central Bank officials bluntly warned Russian banks and companies -- which depend heavily on Government connections and good will -- not to abandon the treasury bill market.
Sergei Aleksashenko, first deputy chairman of the Central Bank, said it would take "traditional and uncustomary measures to support the stability of the state bond market."
"Those Russian companies that blindly copy foreign investors' actions may lose their capital," he added sternly.
But the effects were already being felt abroad. Charles Blitzer, chief economist for emerging markets at the London office of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said the interest rate for Russian Eurobonds had already shot up.
The rising cost of borrowing, he noted, will mean "less foreign borrowing and will slow down economic growth." After a long period of economic decline and stagnation, Russian economists have hoped that the economy would begin to grow in 1998.
Still, Mr. Blitzer and most other economists stress that Russia's change of fortune has little to do with economic developments within Russia -- and everything to do with the global capital markets. Investors have sought safer assets because of anxiety over soaring stock prices in the United States this year and troubled Asian economies.
"What is going on in terms of Russia is not a market vote on that country," he said. "Nothing fundamental has happened in Russia."
That thought, at least, was some consolation to Russian politicians, who tried to put on a brave face.
"We aren't behind an Iron Curtain, so we have to take our share of both the good and the bad," First Deputy Prime Minister Anatoly B. Chubais said today during a visit to London. "The crisis will weaken the weakest and strengthen the strongest."

HEADLINE: Impasse Remaining, Senate Ends Effort on Highway Bill

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28

 BODY:
The Senate today abandoned its efforts to pass a six-year highway financing bill after supporters of a campaign finance overhaul once again blocked the popular $145 billion highway measure from being brought toward a final vote.
In a day of increasing brinksmanship across the Capitol, Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader, pronounced the highway measure "apparently dead for the year." In an effort to press the Democrats by blaming them for denying money for new roads, bridges and public transit projects across the nation, Mr. Lott also said he would not agree to the simple six-month extension the House favored. 
 Raising the stakes in the campaign finance standoff, Mr. Lott also said he would keep from the Senate floor trade legislation avidly sought by President Clinton unless Democrats agreed to separate that issue from the campaign finance controversy and to provide a significant number of votes to break an expected filibuster.
The threats capped another day in which Congress, no longer united by the spring's common drive to approve a balanced budget agreement, remained nearly stymied by partisan standoffs. Besides campaign finance, legislators were stuck over a contested House seat, discontent over legislation to store nuclear waste in Nevada and the inability of the White House and Congress to reach agreement on several controversies snagging major spending bills.
The Federal highway program expired on Sept. 30, and states have been using reserve money to keep as many as 1,900 construction programs going. But the Senate's Democrats, joined by a handful of Republicans, have been bottling up all but essential spending bills in their effort to secure a commitment to an early vote on campaign finance legislation next year.
Today, for the fourth time in several days, 45 Democrats, joined by 3 Republicans, prevented consideration of the full six-year highway bill. Senate Republicans fell 8 votes short of the 60 needed to stop a filibuster against the highway construction program.
After the vote, Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the minority leader, said Democrats would allow a simple six-month extension of the highway and bridge construction financing to move forward.
But Mr. Lott said he would not agree to a six-month program.
"I think it is unfortunate," he said. "The Democrats continue to play games with campaign finance reform."
The National Governors' Association sent a plea to Senate leaders that the legislation be extended for a short term, saying a lapse of financing for several months would "have disastrous affects on many states' transportation programs."
With just weeks remaining in the Congressional session, the legislative slowdown has threatened to engulf Mr. Clinton's faltering bid for "fast track" authority to negotiate free-trade deals that Congress can approve or disapprove but not amend. Mr. Clinton considers such authority a cornerstone of his economic program and his definition as a New Democrat.
"For the life of me," the President said in a speech this week, "I can't figure out why anybody in the wide world believes it will create jobs for us to stay out of markets that other people are in when we can win the competitive wars."
The trade authority is bitterly opposed by organized labor and by many of the President's fellow Democrats, particularly in the House where the Democratic leader, Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, is leading the opposition.
Until now, House Republicans have refused to schedule action on the trade measure until Mr. Clinton can promise them 70 Democratic votes. They have argued that they do not want to risk an embarrassing defeat on free trade.
"I'm perfectly willing to put it on the floor tomorrow," said Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the House majority leader. "But I'm not willing to put it on the floor and have it lose, so we've got to get the votes together."
A dozen Democratic supporters of the trade measure met with Speaker Newt Gingrich today to urge him to push forward with a vote. They said many wavering Democratic lawmakers simply would not make up their minds until they were forced to, because they hoped that they could avoid taking sides between Mr. Clinton and organized labor.
"It's time to burn the ship so that there's no retreat," said Representative James P. Moran, Democrat of Virginia.
After his meeting with the Democrats, Mr. Gingrich went to the White House to consult with the President . Barry Toiv, a spokesman for Mr. Clinton, said tonight that the two leaders discussed strategy on how to propel the trade measure forward but did not set a timetable for a vote.
Because of the lack of Democratic support in the House, the White House has looked to the Senate to begin the trade debate, in hopes that it will muster the 60 votes needed to break an expected filibuster by Senator Byron L. Dorgan, Democrat of North Dakota, and give momentum to the bill.
But today Mr. Daschle said Democrats would stand firm in their vow to block virtually all Senate action as a tool in their effort to win a commitment to a renewed campaign finance debate early next year, including the trade measure.
"I just happen to disagree with the White House about the urgency of this legislation,' he said before catching himself and insisting that he had no disagreement with the White House on the trade bill.
Mr. Daschle went on to say the President and his aides had not asked Senate Democrats to exempt the trade legislation from their strategy of gridlock "because they understand the unanimity and the depth of feeling that our caucus has on campaign reform."
The Senate did manage today to give final passage to a $13.8 billion spending measure that increases money for national parks and retains the National Endowment for the Arts. But White House officials said Mr. Clinton could veto the bill because of various timber provisions affecting Northwestern forests.
"We are mulling it over," said Lawrence Haas, a spokesman for the Office of Management and Budget.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Lose Their Haven Status as Stocks Recover

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities declined sharply yesterday, once again zigging as the stock market zagged.
The Dow Jones industrial average surged 337.17, to 7,498.32, overcoming more than half of Monday's 554-point loss, and with that rebound investor demand for government securities as a safe haven dried up. 
 Bond traders began refocusing their attention on the concerns that were in place before stocks plunged. Rate fears top that list of concerns.
Market participants have again started demanding higher yields to compensate for any risk that strong economic data could cause the Fed to step in and raise short-term rates to keep inflation contained -- a move that would cause bond prices to tumble.
The price of the 30-year bond dropped 2 4/32, to 101 9/32, pushing its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, up to 6.28 percent from 6.14 percent on Monday. Yesterday's decline erased about two-thirds of the gains made over the last three days.
Volume yesterday was the highest ever, according to Maureen Mooney, an analyst with GovPx, a bond pricing service, surpassing the $139.4 billion record set on March 26, a day after the Fed raised short-term rates. Late yesterday the volume of Treasuries bought and sold was well over $148 billion and climbing, with $150 billion within sight.
Despite the heavy trading, analysts said yesterday's Treasury auction of $15 billion of new two-year notes was only mediocre. The notes were auctioned at a price to yield 5.720 percent, the lowest since 5.662 percent on Nov. 19, 1996. The market's recent surge did not allow dealers to set up properly for the auction. Often dealers will raise yields ahead of an auction to insure good demand, so that the securities will move quickly to investors and away from the shelves of dealers.
Today the Treasury will auction $11 billion of new five-year notes. In when-issued trading yesterday, dealers were offering the note at a price to yield 5.88 percent, up from 5.69 percent on Monday.
Maury N. Harris, chief economist at Paine Webber Inc., said, "The 30-year Treasury bond yield should return to around 6.30 percent."
The release of the Employment Cost Index for the third quarter yesterday, showing a rise of eight-tenths of 1 percent from the second quarter, was within expectations and reinforced the view that inflation pressures remained under control.
Still, traders will be awaiting today's testimony by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, before the Joint Economic Committee for any clue to Fed intentions about interest rates or mention of the recent turmoil in the stock market.
Amy Ary, chief fixed-income analyst with Thomson Research in Boston, expects that today will probably bring more losses to the bond market, unless there is another drop in the Asian and European stock markets. "But given how well the U.S. recovered," she said, "it would be unlikely to see overseas markets deteriorate further."

HEADLINE: Japanese Stocks Bounce Back Day After Trading Was Curbed

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Wednesday, Oct. 29

 BODY:
Japan's long-suffering stock market enjoyed a rebound this morning, sharing in some of the relief Wall Street experienced yesterday.
The Nikkei stock average rose 3.46 percent, gaining 564.93 to close at 16,877.62 in the morning session. Large exporters, led by Honda, Toyota, and Canon, paced the climb. 
 The gain, however, left the average short of where it was trading before the recent plunge and still below the psychologically important 17,000 point level.
On Tuesday, the Nikkei had plunged 4.26 percent, as investors panicked on concerns that a prolonged downturn in the American stock markets would reduce consumer demand in Japanese exporters' biggest foreign market.
For the first time since the Persian Gulf war of 1991, the Tokyo Stock Exchange imposed some limitations on trading on Tuesday. The exchange does not apply circuit breakers in the spot market, although they are used in some cases in the futures market. But to stanch Tuesday's bleeding, officials took the unusual steps of narrowing the price increments at which shares trade and doubling the interval between the postings of share prices.
The immediate cause of Tuesday's selloff here was Wall Street's slide on Monday, and Government officials and business leaders rushed to reassure investors that the American economy was fundamentally sound. But many analysts brushed aside their words as irrelevant to the long-term outlook for Tokyo stocks, which are weighed down by the dismal state of Japan's own economy.
The influence of the fall in American stock prices on the Japanese market is light, because so many stocks have already fallen so far that it's not possible for them to go lower, said Norimitsu Otsubo, senior analyst at Wako Research.
Indeed, so many shares are trading below 200 yen (about $1.65), including those of such household names as Kanebo and NKK, that the Japanese press has dubbed them "chewing gum" stocks because about the only thing you could buy if you cashed one in is a pack of gum, which sells for around 100 yen.
Even if today's rebound on Wall Street is sustained, few analysts here expect the Nikkei to follow suit. "The correction in Japan will continue," said Yasushi Suzuki, manager of investment and information services at Nomura Securities Inc. "The economic slowdown here is continuing."

HEADLINE: Hong Kong Follows U.S., Staging a Strong Rebound

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, Wednesday, Oct. 29

 BODY:
Stocks rebounded early here today on relief after Wall Street's explosive rally on Tuesday.
Other Asian markets were also sharply higher at midday. 
 Hong Kong's chief stock index, the Hang Seng, surged more than 17 percent in the first three minutes of trading before settling back. At the midday recess in trading, the index was up 1,512.42 points, or 16.69 percent, at 10,572.31 points. The rally was led by shares of real estate and financial services companies.
Asia took its cue this morning from the revival of American stocks, much as Latin America did on Tuesday. Mexico's chief market index roared back 7.2 percent, Brazil's rebounded by 6.4 percent and Argentina's gained 6 percent.
Despite today's early surge in Hong Kong, there is no sign that the crisis that has gripped the market here since last week has passed.
On Tuesday in Hong Kong, the epicenter of Asia's market turmoil, stocks plunged 13.7 percent, more than double the previous session's descent. It was the biggest decline in points ever and the biggest percentage drop since 1989. Since August, the selloff has erased nearly a third of the Hang Seng's value.
"We're dead; we're dead," people repeatedly moaned on Tuesday as they punched stock codes into terminals at Kincheng Bank in the dense streets of Causeway Bay and stared in disbelief at the numbers that popped up.
Chan Yuk Shui, a 65-year-old retired businessman, groped for a metaphor to describe his anguish and settled on the Shanghai crustaceans that are bound in twine and boiled alive as a seasonal treat. "We've all become hairy crabs; we're all tied down," Mr. Chan lamented. "What can we do? We can't go jumping off buildings." Around him, other retirees prepared to camp out at the market terminals. "We came here early in the morning to 'work,' " one said. "We're going to stay here until the market closes. We thought we could make some money for our retirement funds, but we've lost everything."
At computer terminals scattered throughout Hong Kong on Tuesday, crowds were packed two and three deep as investors watched their portfolios shrink.
Many saw their life's efforts shredded before their eyes.
For here, playing the stock market has become an obsession, an activity that resembles less the careful reasoning of the conference room than the frenzied betting of the race track.
"There's a kind of casino mentality," said Diahann L. Brown, a vice president at Thornton Management (Asia) Ltd. "I would say it really became so this year. But I would say you saw a new kind of investor who came into the market this year, secretaries, hairdressers, people not earning lots on the market."
The market debacle has cast a cloud over Hong Kong's economy and shaken public faith in the leadership installed by Beijing. On Tuesday, Tung Chee-hwa, the shipping magnate appointed to administer the territory when China took control in July, summoned officials for an emergency meeting and afterward sought to reassure investors.
"The market still goes up and down," he told reporters. "What has happened this morning was a reaction of what happened around the world, particularly in New York, and from our side we don't see any panic. The fundamentals here are very good, the economy is going well in Hong Kong and the economy in China is going very well."
For much of the Hong Kong population, though, those words rang hollow. Most analysts agree that the Hong Kong economy is sound; the problem is not inflation or weak consumer demand but the Hong Kong Government's determination to defend the Hong Kong dollar at all costs, a policy that has pushed up interest rates and depressed stocks.
The dogged defense of the currency has not only eroded small investors' nest eggs; it has also thrown into question their hopes of buying a home. Fully half of Hong Kong's citizens live in subsidized Government apartments, but Mr. Tung has said he wants 70 percent of the population to own their homes by early in the next century. That will be harder to accomplish if investors' savings evaporate and mortgage rates go up, as they have been doing lately.
On the other hand, some analysts see a silver lining in the current turmoil -- sky-high housing prices might become more affordable. "What is happening in the stock market definitely has some impact on the property market," said Swavi Cheng, a broker who was waiting for customers at the Centaline Property Agency. "We're seeing fewer speculators in the market. A lot of them have money tied up in the stock market."
Nonetheless, she said, "end-users are still coming to us to look at flats; they're hoping prices will come down as more pressure is put on the market."
The question of where the Hong Kong market, and indeed all the markets in Asia, will go next continues to evoke a mixture of concern and confusion among economists and analysts here.
"I'm not quite sure I can offer any sensible insight," Miron Mushkat, the chief economist for the Asia-Pacific region for Lehman Brothers, said on Tuesday.
"There was some bargain hunting last Friday," when the market climbed more than 700 points in an effort to regain some of the ground lost last week, he said, adding, however, that "others saw this happening and sold."
"The market is trying to find a level that is consistent with economic and financial realities," he said. "No one can fully understand what these realities are."
Richard Margolis, a senior vice president at Merrill Lynch & Compnay, said that despite the mayhem visited on the Hong Kong market, the regulatory and oversight mechanisms put in place after the crash of 1987 would insure that Hong Kong weathered the current crisis.
"So far what we've had this time is asset values taking a pretty severe whacking," he said. "But institutionally, Hong Kong is rock solid, which is a sign that the lessons of the past have been learned. The infrastructures of the marketplace and the supervision and regulation have changed all out of recognition. And again, China has done what anybody would have asked, which is nothing. Which is to say, this is for Hong Kong to sort out by itself."
Even so, Mr. Margolis conceded, "we'll have to go through a difficult period for a year or two, but we've lived through this in the past; we'll live through this one."

HEADLINE: Commercial Real Estate;
Exploiting the Fame of Times Square

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
On the fringes of Times Square, at 48th Street and Seventh Avenue, there is a rooftop billboard that most passers-by find more confusing than promotional. It displays the number 999 in large figures; below that is the word "pharmaceutical" and four Chinese characters across the bottom.
The company that is paying as much as $25,000 a month to lease the sign is a Chinese company whose name is 999 Pharmaceutical. But anyone with an urge to try some 999 products is bound for frustration. None are sold in this country. 
 So why a sign advertising an unobtainable brand's name to people who can't read the message?
"There are very few venues that are global, but one of them is Times Square," said Wei-Tai Kwok, managing director of Dae Advertising, the San Francisco agency that developed and arranged to place the sign. "With all the tourists coming to Times Square and taking pictures, the sign is a way to target the global customer. They are not trying to promote individual products."
Other advertising executives, and real estate specialists, say the sign is an indication of the growing recognition of Times Square's value as a tourist mecca and a place the whole world looks to on New Year's Eve, when the ball drops on the top of the building at One Times Square to signal the arrival of the new year.
Jeffrey Katz, the president of Sherwood Equities, was one of the first to recognize the sharply increasing value of signs in a Times Square that is being transformed from a seedy home to pornography to a glittery entertainment zone with new cinemas and stages and names like Disney and Warner Brothers. Mr. Katz owns the building at the north end of the intersection of Broadway and Seventh Avenue, known as 2 Times Square, and the adjacent 1600 Broadway.
He was also an investor in One Times Square at the south end, recognizing that while the narrow tower was no longer suitable as an office building, it was wonderfully placed as a support structure for signs. The building, which had been purchased by Lehman Brothers a few years ago for $27.5 million, was sold this summer to some German investors known as the Jamestown Group for $110 million, an astounding $1,000 a square foot.
Mr. Katz arranged to lease the first four floors to Warner Brothers for a studio store, like the one on 57th Street. When the renovation is ready, Warner's Bugs Bunny and Daffy Duck will be positioned to battle it out with Mickey and Minnie Mouse at the Disney store diagonally across the street.
Mr. Katz echoed Mr. Kwok's comments about the appeal of the location, where 20 million visitors a year take pictures with signs in the backdrop. "The theme is there are very few global formats," he said. "There are no global magazines or television. But Times Square is a global image format."
Although 999 Pharmaceutical is not a big name in the United States, Mr. Kwok pointed out that some Japanese companies, like Sony, that are household names today were little known when Sony put up a sign in Times Square in the early 1960's.
Mr. Katz said Akio Morita, then a top executive of Sony, arranged to put a sign on 1600 Broadway, which towered over the building in front of it. "They stayed there until I poured the 15th floor of 2 Times Square," Mr. Katz said. Sony withdrew after that, because the newer building obscured the sight line from the main part of the square.
Now that the economic value of signs has been recognized -- the ones on One Times Square are estimated to produce $7 million in annual net income -- building owners are in the sign business, renting out space and paying the sign companies a fee.
As recently as 10 years ago, executives say, the sign companies would go to the owner of a rundown building and offer to rent the roof for a modest sum, perhaps $100,000 a year. The owner was happy to get the income, but the sign companies could sometimes lease the signs for four or five times as much.
Now that the value of signs has been realized, some latecomers are getting into the game. One of the few buildings in the area that has gone unadorned except for a movie marquee is 1500 Broadway, between 43d and 44th Streets. But now the framework is being erected for a giant video screen on the seventh floor setback of the building.
"The sign is being built by Rainbowvision and will resemble the Panasonic and Concorde signs," said Orna Shulman, executive vice president of Intertech Corporation, which bought the building in 1995. She said additional signs are being planned for the setback roof and over the doors to the office building.
"The building should have signs and it will," she said. "The effect will be quite fantastic."

HEADLINE: THE 1997 ELECTIONS: THE ISSUES;
320,000 Have Left Welfare, but Where Do They Go From Here?

SERIES: RACE FOR CITY HALL: The incumbent's record.

BYLINE: By RACHEL L. SWARNS 

 BODY:
In the bleak days of the recession, when Rudolph W. Giuliani first seized the reins of New York City, hundreds of grizzled men nested on the busy streets, dozens of homeless families slept in government offices and 1.1 million people eked out a living on welfare, the highest number since the Great Depression.
Mr. Giuliani promised to put the jobless to work, to take the homeless off the streets and to profoundly reshape the social contract between the city and its poor by offering a helping hand from government only to those willing to help themselves. 
 Four years later, there are 320,000 fewer people on the welfare rolls. Nearly 200,000 welfare recipients have swept streets and cleaned parks in what has become the nation's largest workfare program. The homeless men and women who begged for pennies have greatly decreased, at least in the busy center of town, and some shelters now require work in exchange for beds.
Mr. Giuliani touts these changes, particularly the overhaul of welfare, as "the most important thing we have done." And some policy experts call it one of New York City's most dramatic social transformations.
"It is an enormous change," said Fred Siegel, a senior fellow at the Progressive Policy Institute in Washington. "In the Dinkins years, there was no attempt to come to grips with the cost of dependency to the city, and the cost of dependency to the people caught in it."
But much that was promised has yet to be delivered.
For while Mr. Giuliani revolutionized social policy by eliminating New Yorkers' relatively easy access to benefits, his critics say he has failed to move the jobless into real jobs and the homeless into permanent housing, steps that would enable the poor to complete the journey from dependency to self-sufficiency.
Mr. Giuliani, who has not created a successful job placement program, has moved only a tiny proportion of all workfare participants into permanent jobs, according to data that the city reports to the state.
And while he often points to the declining welfare rolls as proof that people are finding work, the Mayor has chosen not to track what happens to those who lose their government checks.
Meanwhile, dozens of homeless families still sleep on the floors of government offices each night, and thousands more have been turned away. In 1994, the city rejected only three families seeking emergency shelter, city statistics show. In 1997, the number was 7,747, under a new city program intended to weed out families whom the Mayor contends are not really homeless.
Homeless adults have been swept from Manhattan's busy streets, but their numbers in city shelters have surged by 15 percent over the last two years, to 7,119 on an average night. It is the first increase since 1990 and it results, in part, from the city's failure to develop enough affordable, permanent housing.
"They have made considerable progress, but they still have a long way to go," said William J. Grinker, a former commissioner of the city's Human Resources Administration who advised Mr. Giuliani on social issues during the 1993 mayoral campaign.
"It's one thing to create a workfare program, but it's another thing to get people into real work," Mr. Grinker said. "And in terms of a comprehensive employment strategy, in terms of strategies to reduce long-term homelessness, I haven't seen that kind of planning yet."
Mr. Giuliani's aides say the city is moving in that direction. After reducing city spending on housing programs for homeless adults, the administration now hopes to get state money to create new permanent housing. Mr. Giuliani also plans to spend $7.5 million on a new program that will reward contract agencies that help workfare participants find and keep jobs. And the city hopes to expand its role as a quasi-employment agency, screening and training welfare recipients for work in big companies like Macy's.
"I think you will see an expansion of these programs," said Anthony P. Coles, a senior adviser to the Mayor.
But Mr. Giuliani and Mr. Coles also say the decline in the welfare rolls and the creation of the nation's largest workfare program are tremendous accomplishments in and of themselves.
"I think that's as big a change in thinking as the reduction in crime," Mr. Giuliani said in an interview last week. "And I think it has as much of an impact. What I see us doing is re-establishing the centrality of work as an important experience in people's lives."
Mr. Giuliani, who slashed spending on child welfare during the first two years of his term, also claims credit for altering the long-beleaguered child welfare system.
After a series of blunders by city child welfare workers contributed to the beating death of 6-year-old Elisa Izquierdo in 1995, Mr. Giuliani created New York City's first stand-alone agency for children, the Administration for Children's Services. And he appointed Nicholas Scoppetta, a well-regarded former prosecutor and an advocate for children, to lead it in January 1996.
Since then, Mr. Scoppetta has hired 1,000 new caseworkers, pushed the average caseload down from 20 to 14 per worker and expanded employee training to 10 months from 4 weeks. And he has won high marks for an ambitious and detailed plan to transform the city's management of endangered children.
But change has come slowly. A court-ordered panel of child welfare specialists, which assessed the agency between July 1996 and March 1997, found an agency in grave disarray. In the panel's most recent report, issued last week, 43 percent of the abused and neglected children who were left in their homes under the watch of city caseworkers were found to have been mistreated again by their caretakers. And caseworkers closed 30 percent of their investigations prematurely, leaving children unnecessarily endangered, the panel found.
The number of children in foster care, which had been declining, surged to 11,158 in 1997, a 40 percent increase over 1995, as caseworkers pulled children from troubled homes more aggressively. Unprepared for the deluge, city officials found themselves short of beds and sometimes forced to house children overnight in city offices.
This summer, Mr. Scoppetta managed to win financing for new beds in group homes, many of which had closed in previous years because of city and state budget cuts. And he said his agency was improving.
"It's a better agency today than it was," Mr. Scoppetta said. "It's going to take some years before we reap the benefits of this investment."
But policy experts warn that the coming years will pose even greater challenges as thousands of welfare recipients lose their benefits under new state and federal laws. Many experts in social services fear this situation will strain the child welfare system and homeless shelters. By the end of next year, for instance, 179,000 single adults on welfare will lose their benefits under state law.
Will New York City have a successful job placement program by then? Will there be enough jobs in the private sector? Will the ranks of the homeless swell and will there be places for them go?
"It's an enormous task," said Liz Krueger, the associate director of the Community Food Resource Center, a non-profit group that acts as an advocate for the poor. "Right now, we're not ready."
Future articles will examine Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's record on the city's budget and economy and Ruth W. Messinger's record as Manhattan Borough President and as Councilwoman.

HEADLINE: This Time, a Market Slump Would Differ in Its Effects

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
For a long string of years, most New Yorkers did not need to think much about Wall Street and the stock market as prices climbed with seemingly inexorable stability.
But the tumult of the last week has brought it all back into focus -- both how much the industry remains a force in the New York economy and how much it remains a mystery. On Monday, there were people facing co-op boards with suddenly heightened timidity because their net worth had declined by 20 percent, and home buyers, shopping for mortgages, who watched interest rates seesaw with the stock market. 
 The city has changed since its last market crucible in 1987 and so has the market. With prices plummeting one day and soaring the next, the market's role in the city economy is unquestionably back on the minds of residents and politicians no matter what happens next. The era of complacency is over.
Economists and securities industry officials say that New York is the stock market's unquestioned national capital as much as a decade ago but that what the city draws from the relationship is not the same.
The city, in short, has fewer jobs and more money. It is less a captive of the industry's employment rhythms and more a slave to its profits. That means the impact of a downturn in the market, or even a period of prolonged turmoil, would take a much different form than it did in 1987.
Mass layoffs in New York would probably be less likely than in 1987, for example, because the job base has increasingly been shifted out of New York -- to the nation, the world and the rest of the region. The kinds of jobs that the industry has added in the city in recent years, especially the high-technology positions required to run the increasingly elaborate and automated trading systems, are also considered more stable, given the dominance of computer trading.
Other parts of the local economy are also healthier than they were a decade ago. Because there has been little new commercial office construction, there is no vast pool of space that would drag the economy down, as was the case after the 1987 crash. State and local governments have also become more efficient, economists say, and thus less likely to drag down the economy through layoffs.
"The city is in a much better position to weather a storm," said Rae Rosen, a senior economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. "It's not that it wouldn't be painful, but that we're simply in a better position to withstand it."
Countering the story on jobs, however, is the much harder to predict question of Wall Street's money. The impact of a decline in bonuses and salaries would ripple through the economy with more force than it ever did in the past. Industry salaries accounted for 12.8 percent of the total private sector payroll in the city in 1987. Today, Wall Street salaries are sharply higher than a decade ago. And even though there are slightly fewer securities jobs in the city, those that remain account for 17.8 percent of the money earned in the city's private-sector economy.
"The key contribution of Wall Street now is the income and the earnings -- that's a shift from what happened in the 1980's," said John L. Wieting, the New York Regional Commissioner for the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. "Then it was a major force in job growth."
That flow of bonuses and salaries affects everything from residential real estate to car sales, and while few experts were predicting any change in the flow of that money, there were a few anecdotal signs that at least a period of momentary monetary caution may have arrived.
One media analyst for Bear Stearns, who was looking in the $900,000 range for a six-room apartment on the Upper West Side on Monday morning, called his real state broker that afternoon and said he wanted to downscale.
Barbara Corcoran, the chairwoman of the Corcoran Group, said the analyst told her he had decided to keep his purchase at about $500,000. "He was very clear on what he wanted in the morning and by afternoon, he had reassessed," she said. "It was a direct response to the market."
Kevin J. Pallonetti, 30, who owns an electronic parts distributorship in Great Neck, N.Y., and is in contract to buy a town house with his wife, said he called his mortgage broker six times on Monday morning. His hunch was that interest rates would drop and that if he moved quickly he could lock in a lower rate for his mortgage. Mr. Pallonetti is still waiting, betting rates will go lower.
The securities industry's role in the region has changed. A decade ago, for example, New York State had about 38 percent of all the nation's jobs in the industry. Today, it has about 28 percent. Total employment in the industry in New York City -- about 154,000 jobs as of September, according to the Federal figures -- is slightly lower than a decade ago, though it is up sharply from the bottom of 129,000 jobs in 1991.
But employment elsewhere has soared. Securities jobs in New Jersey, for example, have doubled in the last 10 years, to nearly 33,000.
Industry experts said they believed Wall Street has also deliberately changed in part to try to avoid the thousands of layoffs that occurred in the early 1990's.
"Nobody wants to work in an environment where you're vulnerable to those kinds of swings, and no institution wants to lay off," said Rocco J. Maggiotto, chairman of the securities industry practice at Coopers & Lybrand. "Most major firms made significant investments in back office functions so that their cost of executing trades was significantly reduced. If another downturn did occur, they would not need layoffs."

HEADLINE: What to Make of Wave That Started Over There;
U.S. Businesses Can Shrug Off Asian Tumult

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
When currencies and stocks in Hong Kong -- or Thailand or Indonesia -- take a tumble, must America feel their pain?
Sure, the deepening financial woes in Asia and, more particularly, the spread of the problem to Hong Kong, China's monument to global capitalism, clearly prompted the big drop Monday on Wall Street. 
 "Irrational exuberance gave way to irrational gloom," said Bruce Steinberg, chief economist at Merrill Lynch.
But for all the increasing interconnectedness of global markets, many observers say that the linkage between Asia's economic prospects and the profitability of American companies is not strong enough to justify the trillion-dollar loss in stock values in a week.
"All of us have been guilty of exaggerating the importance of Asia as the driving force behind the world economy," argued Peter Kenen, an economist at Princeton University.
Indeed, the rebound yesterday on Wall Street, in which the Dow Jones industrial average rose 337 points, appeared to reflect some serious second thoughts about just how the dire the situation for American business really is.
While Asia's problems, to some extent, will cause a number of big American corporations to face lower exports, more import competition and diminished returns on foreign investments, the size of those changes simply does not justify a fundamental shift in outlook. In fact, some countervailing forces work to keep the American economy on the prosperity track.
Hard times in Asia "will likely impede U.S. growth only modestly," concluded Abby Joseph Cohen, the market strategist at Goldman, Sachs who has been bullish for much of the 1990's. "At the same time, the inflation and interest rate backdrop has become more favorable."
John Maynard Keynes compared the stock market to a beauty pageant in which the winner is not the woman the majority thinks is most attractive but the woman most people think that others will find most attractive. From this perspective, it should hardly be a surprise that fears that a collapse of the currencies in Southeast Asia would lead to a selloff of American stocks proved to be a self-fulfilling prophecy.
That said, virtually all analysts agree that in the long run the price of stocks turns on the more tangible question of expected earnings per share down the road. And while Asia's economic predicament is, on balance, bad news for globally minded American enterprises, it hardly presents a serious obstacle to continuing growth in profits for corporate America.
Start with import competition. The sharp depreciation of Southeast Asian currencies in the last three months is already beginning to show up as an increase in Asia's volume of exports. But Southeast Asia largely competes in world markets with low-wage countries like Brazil, China and Mexico -- not with California, Michigan and Texas.
Albert Fishlow, a senior fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations, notes that some American companies stand to reap a windfall from Asian currency depreciation, since the prices of imported components for their own products -- computer memory chips, for example -- are likely to fall in coming months. Others American companies will benefit because they use Southeast Asia as an export platform to Europe, Japan and North America. "While local sales by foreign subsidiaries may be hit by recession in Asia, increased exports could more than offset the loss," he said.
Recession in Southeast Asia means these countries will buy fewer 747's from Boeing, fewer videos from Disney and fewer bushels of soybeans from Illinois. But once again, the magnitude has not been put into perspective. American exports to the countries in the deepest trouble -- Thailand, Indonesia, Malaysia, Hong Kong and the Philippines -- amounted to just $30 billion in the first eight months of this year, less collectively than exports to Canada, Japan or the European Community individually.
And some of the nation's largest consumer products companies say the turmoil in the Asian markets will have little effect on their businesses.
The companies, including Procter & Gamble, Gillette and Colgate-Palmolive, say Asia represents less than 10 percent of their sales, which minimizes their vulnerability to wild market swings and declines in consumer demands that might follow currency devaluations.
To Colgate, for example, Southeast Asia, including Hong Kong, Malaysia and Singapore, represents just "5 percent of our sales, and the populations of those countries represent a small portion of all the countries we serve," said Robert A. Murray, a Colgate spokesman. A number of companies questioned said they had also taken actions in the currency markets to hedge against the risk of wide fluctuations.
Moreover, the $8 trillion United States economy is so substantial and diversified that weakness in any region of the world is not enough to divert it significantly from its path. "Slow growth in Japan since 1991 has hardly put the brakes on Wall Street or the American economy," Mr. Fishlow said.
If the potential for collateral damage from a recession in Southeast Asia has been exaggerated, the potential for indirect gains has been all but ignored. One reason American business has enjoyed seven fat years is that growth in much of the world has been tepid. For while slow growth abroad dulls America's export performance, it also prevents the sorts of production bottlenecks that lead to inflation -- and recession.
World commodity prices, measured in dollars, are virtually unchanged from 1990 levels. In the last year, crude oil prices have actually fallen by 20 percent, rubber prices by 32 percent and timber prices by 27 percent. Moreover, with both Japan and Europe running in slow motion, America's huge appetite for manufactured goods has been easily satisfied by foreign producers. And with growing excess production capacity in Southeast Asia as well, more signs point to deflation than to inflation.
By the same token, economic trauma in Asia reduces the likelihood that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates anytime soon. With Hong Kong's once rock-solid currency under pressure, Latin America deeply worried about contagion and stock markets around the world still on edge, the Fed will be in no mood to tighten money. "They aren't going to add fuel to the fire," Mr. Steinberg of Merrill Lynch said.
None of this guarantees that investors will ignore all that has happened in the last week, say "never mind" and simply pump Wall Street back to record highs, the way they did relatively quickly after the crash of 1987. It does suggest, though, that Asia's trauma will hardly be felt by most Americans. "Globalization matters," Mr. Kenen concluded, "but less than people think."
