HEADLINE: UAL and T.W.A. Report Improvements in Earnings

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Oct. 28

 BODY:
The UAL Corporation and Trans World Airlines Inc. reported improved third-quarter earnings today, capping a robust quarter for the airline industry as more travelers paid higher fares and the companies cut costs.
Earnings at UAL, the parent of Chicago-based United Airlines, rose 5.3 percent, aided by a surge in September travel and lower fuel costs. St. Louis-based Trans World Airlines reported its first profitable quarter since the crash of Flight 800 in July 1996, as the company flew smaller planes and cut operating costs. 
 The third quarter is typically the most profitable period for airlines as travel increases for summer vacations. The airlines also received a lift from a 5 percent increase in business fares at the beginning of September.
"We are encouraged by September's revenue strength, and unless the recent stock market volatility and uncertainty disrupts the general economy, we expect this strength to continue into the fourth quarter," said Gerald Greenwald, chairman and chief executive of UAL.
Earlier this month, the AMR Corporation, the parent of American Airlines; Continental Airlines Inc. and the Northwest Airlines Corporation all posted profit gains of 13 percent to 15 percent, while profits soared 52 percent at the Southwest Airlines Company and 72 percent at US Airways Group Inc. Earnings at Delta Air Lines Inc. rose 6.8 percent. All exceeded analysts' estimates.
Using pro-forma calculations to reflect employee stock-option plan distributions, UAL's profit before special items rose to $499 million, or $3.75 a share, up from $474 million, or $3.58 a share, a year earlier.
The results beat analysts' expectations of $3.68 a share. The company's shares rose $1.375, to $87.50, on the New York Stock Exchange today.
A gain of $235 million, reflecting the sale of Apollo Travel Services to Galileo International, resulted in net income in the latest quarter of $734 million, or $5.52 a fully distributed share. A year earlier, charges of $38 million resulted in net income of $437 million, or $3.29 a share.
The company, majority-owned by its employees, says fully distributed earnings are the best measure of its results.
Revenue rose 3.3 percent, to $4.64 billion, from $4.49 billion.
T.W.A. reported third-quarter profit from operations of $13.3 million, or 17 cents a share, in contrast to a loss of $6.9 million, or 24 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Per-share amounts reflect the payment of preferred stock dividends. Revenue fell 9.4 percent, to $908.4 million, from $1 billion a year earlier.
After charges of $6.99 million in the most recent quarter and $7.42 million a year earlier, T.W.A. had net income of $2.42 million, or 4 cents a share, in contrast to a loss of $18.2 million, or 40 cents a share, a year earlier. T.W.A.'s shares rose 37.5cents, to $7.3125.

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN WASHINGTON: THE CHINESE-AMERICANS;
Pride and Censure Mix With a Dash of Apathy

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28

 BODY:
If President Jiang Zemin of China studies the official receptions here this week and the disparate throngs protesting or quietly watching beyond, he will be able to sample a range of Chinese-American concerns as wide as China itself.
Kung-Lee Wang, an economist and business consultant who co-founded the influential Committee of 100 Chinese-American leaders, says he will be at the reception for President Jiang on Wednesday because he yearns to see a fuller opening of China's vast economic and cultural marketplace to America. 
 "We are not there," Mr. Wang warned. "The Europeans and the Japanese are there." Counseling creative patience on human rights matters, he said, "I would not let that one issue become the veto issue."
But half a block from Mr. Jiang's meeting with Mr. Wang and 30 other local Chinese-American leaders at Blair House, vocal dissidents will mass in Lafayette Park to focus on human rights, not economic opportunity, as the prime issue of the China leader's visit with President Clinton.
"We have been stripped of our nationality and forced to become stateless international refugees," Liu Binyan, a celebrated victim of Beijing's intolerance, said on the eve of a protest that will echo with the grievances of the brutal crackdown on the Tiananmen Square democracy protest eight years ago.
Daphne Kwok is one Chinese-American activist who will be studiously ignoring human rights and economic issues as her focal point. "I'm monitoring how the visit may or may not play into the campaign finance issue," said Ms. Kwok, devoted in her role as director of the Organization of Chinese Americans.
She says her group has 10,000 members and a sense of absolute outrage at the "systematic stereotyping" of Asian-American citizens in the investigations into alleged political fund-raising abuses by foreign-born donors.
"This is the real issue for Chinese-Americans," she said. "Here we are in 1997 with a major feeling, tolerated among the American public, that it is O.K. to make fun and stereotype Americans who have Chinese features."
Darting somewhere between Blair House and the park protest will be Norman Fu, United States correspondent for China Times, a Taiwan newspaper, taking notes as a reporter fascinated by President Jiang's presence here as "a paradoxical figure" who has had a classical education but a "callous" rise to power.
"What is no less interesting is my impression that there may be more Americans than Chinese-Americans opposed to his visit because of the human rights issue."
Beyond these individuals, the mood among the 1.7 million Americans of Chinese ancestry about President Jiang's arrival can be found ranging from the blase to the prideful.
"I'm kind of ambivalent," said Wu-Lang Lee, a Federal economist unstirred by the media drumbeat.
"It's a routine matter to me," said Mr. Lee, a Taiwan-born American who cares deeply about the security of Taiwan but expects President Clinton to win no great reassurances in that regard.
And pride? Shu-Ping Chan, a community relations specialist with the government of Maryland, insisted: "Listen, even among my friends who work for the Taiwan Government I'm finding political differences put aside. There's a bit of lingering pride that the Chinese Government is being recognized as a coequal. This is a chance for China to shine -- that's what I'm sensing."
Studying these facets and more, American scholars like Marshall Bouton, vice president of the Asia Society, find Chinese-Americans feeling "whipsawed," as he put it, by the Chinese leader's visit. There is a distinct sense of welcome, but wariness, too, that the visit might somehow redound negatively on them by feeding controversies like the foreign-money campaign inquiry.
"The visit is and ought to be a very welcome development in putting U.S-China relations back on an even keel after the very traumatic Tiananmen events," Mr. Bouton said. "Many in the community felt the trauma personally. But there was also that sort of shudder, if you will, at the tendency in our history for the Chinese community to be victimized when state relations turn sour."
Just a mile from all the toasting and protesting about President Jiang, Duane Wang, Shanghai-born and an American for four decades, intends to stay busy all week at his lumberyard in Washington's Chinatown.
"It all depends on where you're from and when you got here," was his summary of Chinese-American views. "I speak as an American. I find the visit a good thing because China is a very old country, and since Nixon opened it up, it has changed tremendously, even in human rights."
"Think of it this way: if it hadn't been opened up, there would have been no Tiananmen Square," said Mr. Wang, his faith in time and China strong. "President Jiang will learn. He will find out our system is good, and he will go home with a different attitude."
Others are not so sure.
"Personally, I think business will be foremost with President Clinton in the visit, not human rights, and I don't agree with that," said the Rev. Samuel Yau, pastor of the Chinese Christian Church of Greater Washington, which serves 350 Americans from China, Taiwan and Hong Kong in nearby Silver Spring, Md.
Mr. Yau finds no special discussion or protest this week among his hard-working parishioners. He speaks of the campaign inquiry issue not as an outraged Chinese-American, but as as an American with faith in the political system. "I don't worry about the fund-raising charges," he said. "The system is very much stable in our country."
G. Greg Chen, a worker here in the Mayor's office, earns his living tracking and celebrating the grand disparity of views about China within Chinatown, but also fathoming the relative ignorance of non-Chinese Americans about his birthplace. He hopes the visit will ease both the simplistic "Communist dragon" image of China and local anxiety over racist stereotyping.
"We have lots of people contributing to their new country," Mr. Chen said. "You cannot treat Asian-Americans this way."

HEADLINE: So Far, a New Crop of Investors Refuse to Budge

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Oct. 28

 BODY:
Nearly panicking as the stock market dived after today's opening bell, Jan Balou, a saleswoman in her 40's, dashed to the Michigan Avenue bus, and headed for her Charles Schwab brokerage office, ready to unload her investments.
Feeling frantic, she asked almost everyone on the bus -- and later on the sidewalk -- if Wall Street, long the toast of the town, was now just toast. She found not a Chicken Little in the bunch. 
 So, after all that, Ms. Balou decided to buy more stocks.
"Everybody else said, 'I'm hanging in,' " she said, "so I'm going to hang in, too."
For all the fretting about whether the new crop of investors could withstand a major downturn without scurrying back to their savings passbooks, the ordinary Joes and Janes like Ms. Balou refused to fold their cards today after Monday's Wall Street plunge.
Only time will tell, of course, whether that will turn out to be a smart move.
After watching the market drop more than 7 percent on Monday, and then sink lower this morning, 49-year-old Dalia Ratner said to herself, "Hmm, looks like a good day to buy more stocks."
Judging from dozens of interviews in Atlanta and Boston, in Los Angeles and Denver, in Chicago and Hicksville, N.Y., investors generally remain strongly bullish, and well schooled about the dynamics of the market.
With almost everybody and her sister invested in Wall Street, the stock market seems to have become a new national pastime, as people break the ice by talking about the Dow, instead of the ball game.
Indeed, old cliches like "playing them one at a time," and "giving 110 percent," seem to have given way to, "the underlying fundamentals are excellent," and "great buying opportunity."
Investors like Andrew Jaramillo, 27, who runs a flower market in Los Angles, were shrewdly looking for bargains today. As he stood in front of a stock quote computer, his biggest disappointment, in fact, was that the market did not stay down for a longer period.
"This morning we were going to buy Dell Computer at $70, but we just couldn't get on the phone," he said. "By the time we got on, it was already $86."
 Craig Holm, a 43-year-old health consultant from Philadelphia, sat in the Second Street Cafe in Brooklyn, analyzing the stock market and global politics, sounding a bit like Louis Rukeyser.
"Even if the Far East economies stumble," said Mr. Holm, "our economy is still strong" enough to ward off a terrible plunge in the market.
Dave Elliott, a Chicago construction worker in a hard hat, broke into a broad smile at the news that the market had soared today.
"I don't play the market, I invest for the long term," said Mr. Elliott, who checks his mutual fund on the Internet. "But it's nice to hear it's coming back."
And plenty of investors, especially the more prosperous ones, noted that the market has been so good for so long, that to pout about a downturn would sound a bit like a spoiled child.
Joy Cash, a 62-year-old psychotherapist in Denver, said she lost thousands of dollars in retirement funds on Monday, about the same amount she had made so far this year.
Some people were thrilled to see the market take a tumble on Monday.
Figuring that the stock market could not soar forever, Larry Williamson, 41, recently bought a boatload of puts, which make money when the market falls.
"I feel great, man, just great," he said early this morning, in a position to reap thousands of dollars. If the market recovers completely, of course, he is out of luck.
For all the talk about high finances in the go-go 90's, there still are many Americans who do not have a dime riding on the crap tables of Wall Street, and harbor a little resentment over any tears shed for the investors, especially the ones in fancy threads.
"When you live from check to check, like a lot of us, you don't have anything to put on the stock market," said Cecilia Moon, 40, who lives in a basement apartment in Chicago and checks parking meters for a living.
"A lot of these big-shot investors have been riding the gravy train," Ms. Moon said. "And then, if they lost a little, they'll get to write it off on their taxes."
Others without investments were happy to be free of the anxieties of the stock market.
"When something fluctuates so much, it makes me nervous," said John Obih, 45, who operates a roadside yard sale under a tent in Los Angeles.
"If you go to a store, you see the money. If you go to a house, you see it standing up," he added. "In the stock market, it is only a piece of paper. There is nothing to show for your money."
Inside the chapel at St. Paul's Bookstore in Chicago, visitors write down their worries, asking others to pray for them.
The list is usually full of concerns for sick children, a sense of loneliness or despair, a crisis in faith. In the last two days, plenty of people have been asking for prayers for the stock market.
Sister Tracey Duggs, a 25-year-old Roman Catholic nun at the store, who has taken a vow of poverty, said there are bigger concerns in life than the Dow Jones industrial average. But she is not beyond empathizing with some secular worries.
"My dad," she said, with a hint of concern, "likes to dabble in the market."
These market worries seem like small potatoes to David Wald, a retired lawyer, who remembers the stock market crash of 1929. He even saw a bright side to the market jitters.
"This is fun, you know, creating some action, stirring people up," he said, noting the buzz caused by the market's gyrations. "And what do I care, I'm 81 years old. What do I need money for?"
When Mr. Wald mentioned that he had long ago learned "an important secret about investing," several younger men and women drew near the oracle, listening for sage advice.
"Never listen to anybody," he declared. "They don't know what they're talking about."

HEADLINE: Debating Whether Crisis Had to Be

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28

 BODY:
The financial tumult that built speed in Southeast Asia and then repeatedly raced around the globe raises a question that few finance ministries around the world want to address: Could someone -- maybe the United States, maybe Japan -- have taken the lead early enough to stop a selloff from becoming a crisis?
Months ago, American officials, led by Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, decided that there would be no Mexican-style bailout of the ailing Asian markets. After all, it is not in America's backyard. Financial turmoil in Asia is unlikely to affect the American economy significantly. Besides, the prescription for economic recovery is not clear. And most important, there is the risk that any quick fix by the United States might do more harm than good. 
 If the world became dependent on the world's economic superpower to bail countries out of every financial crisis, Mr. Rubin has said repeatedly, that might simply open the door to even more crises in the future.
In the last few weeks, however, American officials have begun to edge toward more active involvement, spurred by signs that a "contagion effect" from Asian markets to the rest of the world was taking hold. Today, at the Treasury and the White House, officials said there was discussion of taking a more public role in the International Monetary Fund's impending bailout of Indonesia -- including American participation in emergency back-up financing in case the I.M.F.'s program proves insufficient. It is the clearest evidence yet that the Administration is concerned that its influence in Asia could be harmed if Washington fails to take a more active role.
And while they will not discuss it publicly, American officials appear poised to act more forcefully. But late today, they were clearly hoping the market's rebound would make that unnecessary. "We feel a lot smarter this afternoon," one Administration official said, with an eye to Wall Street's 337-point rebound, "than we did this time yesterday."
But Mr. Rubin's calculations -- a weighing of the short-term benefits of calming world markets against the long-term costs of making America the world's financial savior of last resort -- are hardly over.
Indeed, in some ways the financial problems in Asia are now significantly larger. And American officials say they know they face the financial corollary of the Powell Doctrine during the Persian Gulf war: If the United States decides to shore up investor confidence, it may have to do so with such overwhelming force that the opposition would be overwhelmed.
"Rubin's facing an excrutiating choice," said Jeffrey Garten, a former Under Secretary of Commerce and author of a book about emerging markets. "If we can make it through this period without American intervention, it will force the economies of Southeast Asia to make very fundamental reforms. That is clearly the preferable course. But if we can't make it through, my guess is that other options have to be very much alive."
The Administration is benefiting from one of the realities of economic diplomacy: Unlike nuclear arms talks or negotiations in Bosnia, financial crises are considered so arcane that they produce little Congressional sniping -- as long as no taxpayer dollars are at risk.
"I wouldn't be inclined at this time to be critical of Secretary Rubin or anybody else for what they did or didn't do," the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, said today. "I don't know what I would have expected."
At the heart of the Administration's strategy, officials said, are two guiding principles.
The first is that no country should receive help from the I.M.F. or other international institutions without first agreeing to comprehensive changes. Among those are painful austerity measures and actions that assure that banks that made bad loans or investors who made bad decisions "take a haircut" -- that is, lose substantial sums. Otherwise, calling in the I.M.F. will seem like an easy out to countries that overspend, overborrow and overbuild.
The second guideline has been to dispel the Mexico effect: make it clear that the United States is not in the business of providing direct help to countries that get in trouble.
"Our strategy has been to be activist and concerned," one senior Administration official said today, "but to know where the line is."
The question, on Wall Street and to a lesser degree in Washington, is whether that line should have moved as the crisis deepened.
"The official approach so far has been too little, too late," said John Lipsky, the chief economist at Chase Manhattan Bank. "The initial policy line in Thailand -- urging countries to adjust their policies, working with the I.M.F. and the World Bank -- was appropriate at the time." But that strategy, he said, should have been revisited "once it became clear that it was not halting a further spiraling of the Asian crisis."
Both Mr. Lipsky and C. Fred Bergsten, the director of the Institute for International Economics, say the key turning point came on Oct. 17, when Taiwan -- apparently under little or no pressure from speculators -- devalued its currency so that its goods would be competitive with those of Indonesia and Thailand.
"That was a moment the U.S. and other major economies needed to exercise some influence," Mr. Bergsten said. The next week, the speculators turned to Hong Kong -- Taiwan's most direct trade competitor.
Administration officials say they do not remember any high-level discussion of intervention, public or private, after Taiwan's sudden decision to devalue its currency. It is unclear whether the United States would have had the influence to reverse that decision, even if it had tried. But Treasury officials reject the suggestion that the Administration has been too timid in its statements.
Meanwhile, some in the Administration have been critical of the International Monetary Fund for what American officials say has amounted to mindless cheerleading for Thailand and other Asian nations, repeatedly declaring that stability was just around the corner.
But while today's resurgence in the American market may calm Asia, some critics remain convinced that the Clinton Administration could have acted more forcefully without turning itself into a bailout specialist. "This was not an issue of money, it was one of clarity of policy," Mr. Lipsky said. "There were moments where more could have been done."

HEADLINE: MARKET PLACE -- STOCKS RALLY ON RECORD VOLUME AS SMALL INVESTORS TAKE LEAD;
Wall Street Sets the Tone

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
Panic on Wall Street spread around the world, but was halted yesterday where it had been the most intense just a day earlier -- in America. For better or worse, the United States is now setting the tone for world stock markets.
Whether the buyers or the sellers yesterday will ultimately prove to have been the wiser investors will not be known for some time. But it is clear that the impact on world markets was intensified by American stock market rules that were aimed at minimizing market swings. Those rules may have helped bring in buyers yesterday, but the cost to world markets was significant. 
 First came the panic. Most world stock markets plunged further and faster early yesterday than they had at any time in recent years. The cause clearly was alarm over the previous day's declines in New York. Because rules had cut off trading on Monday after the Dow Jones industrial average fell 550 points, there was no way to determine just how far prices would have plunged in New York if stocks had been allowed to trade freely.
Then came the turnaround yesterday. Prices opened lower in New York, but rebounded after less than an hour. European markets that were still open turned on a dime, bouncing back from their deepest losses earlier in the day. It was not that there was suddenly better news on the prospects for European companies and economies. It was the reassurance provided by the largest and most important stock market.
And who had turned around that market? No data are available on who really buys and sells stocks. But computers that monitor trading can reach some conclusions. And those computers, reports Laszlo Birinyi of Birinyi Associates, a market research firm, indicate that it was smaller orders, of fewer than 10,000 shares, that provided all of the market's power. The bigger orders were generally negative for most of the day. Virtually all the bigger orders came from institutional investors, like pension funds and mutual funds. Some of the smaller ones did too, of course. But many of them came from ordinary investors.
Economic theory may assert that investors weigh each stock and then pick the most attractive one, but in practice money managers often follow the herd. They buy things that are going up, and they sell things that are going down, in each case assuming that there are likely to be good reasons for the moves, even if they are not immediately obvious. For now, it appears that Main Street was more willing to believe the old trend -- of prices that rise year after year -- than the new one that manifested itself in the last week.
Last week, when a plunge in Hong Kong set off international alarms, the New York market was a bastion of relative strength. Early in the week, American shares rose despite Asian weakness. And even on Thursday and Friday, when prices fell sharply in this country, the declines were not as great as in most foreign markets.
But on Monday, New York did worse than most markets and was forced to close early when a so-called circuit breaker kicked in after the Dow Jones industrial average had fallen 550 points, or about 7 percent. An earlier circuit breaker had resulted in a half-hour break after the Dow fell 350 points. There are just 30 stocks in the Dow, but the thousands of stocks in all American markets are barred from trading after those 30 plunge the requisite amounts. The data indicate that both large and small orders put downward pressure on the market on Monday.
The rally yesterday can be cited as evidence that circuit breakers work. After American investors had the night to think it over, enough of them were willing to invest to halt the fall in prices not long after the market opened for trading. It appears that individual American investors were less upset than were the professionals who manage their money. Some bought, and fewer sold than mutual fund managers may have expected.
But the intensity of the overseas selling between the time the United States market closed early on Monday and the time it reopened yesterday indicates that those who designed the circuit breakers were wrong in one respect: The market reaction to the closing was not minimized by the fact that it was caused by an existing rule rather than by fearful exchange officials or politicians.
"We were very aware that ad hoc acts of closing the market could cause panic," said Robert Glauber, who was executive director of the Brady Commission, a Government body that studied the 1987 crash and recommended that circuit breakers be put into place. "Circuit breakers were put in place so no one would think anyone had pushed the panic button."
But somebody obviously thought just that, and the results were awesome. Hong Kong, which had started the panic last week by falling 23 percent in four days, fell 13.7 percent yesterday, after Monday's close on Wall Street. Australia was down by 1O percent, New Zealand by 12 percent. Japan fell only 4 percent, but that reflected extraordinary controls that limited how much individual stocks could fall and kept many of them from trading at all. In Europe, Germany and France had each lost more than 10 percent, and Britain more than 7 percent, by the time New York opened.
European markets had mild recoveries earlier in the morning, before 6 A.M. New York time, when the stock index futures on the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks, which trade overnight, recovered a bit. But then those futures fell back in the overnight session to the maximum decline allowed, and European markets resumed their drop.
Another factor of international money management is that managers who need to raise cash sometimes choose to sell their most liquid investments -- that is, the ones that can most easily and quickly be unloaded. Liquidity has always been a major strength of the American market, but it vanished for a time on Monday under conditions that made it possible to believe it would not return. That fact could have led some money managers to sell foreign stocks in lieu of American ones they really wanted to sell.
History does not allow trial runs, or controlled tests with placebos given to half the investors. So it will never be known if foreign markets would have suffered as much had the American market been allowed to find its own level on Monday, rather than be closed.
Mr. Glauber, who is now a lecturer at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University, remains a believer in circuit breakers. But he says they never should have been used this week. "The original design of circuit breakers from the Brady Commission was as strong medicine for a market in distress," he said. "The market was not in distress and it did not need the medicine. I think circuit breakers should be set wider so they trigger only in a disorderly market."
When the circuit breakers were originally adopted, they called for a halt when the Dow Jones industrial average had fallen 250 points, and another at 400 points. Those limits amounted to falls of about 12 percent and 20 percent. But on Monday, even though the limits had since been raised to 350 and 550 points, they amounted to only about 4 percent and 7 percent. And, in fact, trading was orderly as the Dow neared that 550-point threshold. Mr. Glauber said the limits should be set at about 10 percent for the first halt, and 15 percent for the second one.
Circuit breakers in the American stock market are, by the way, one-way things. At 3:17 P.M. yesterday, the Dow was up 350 points. If melt-ups worried the rule makers at the Big Board as much as meltdowns do, that would have halted trading for half an hour. Instead, it continued, and prices soon fell back a bit. The Dow ended the day up 337.17 points, or 4.7 percent.
For now, the panic seems to have ended. But the probability is that it would have been less intense, and perhaps would not have been so widespread, if the American rules had been different. Circuit breakers, as they worked on Monday, saved some American investors from making sales at levels that were destined to seem cheap the next day. But they seem to have stimulated a lot more such selling in foreign markets. On balance, they may well have done more harm than good.

HEADLINE: Steady Retirement Money Is Foundation for Rebound

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
Monday's stock market plunge may have unnerved some investors, but it did not spook people who save for retirement in 401(k) plans. At least that was what large employers, mutual funds and plan administrators said yesterday.
To be sure, service centers were flooded with calls, but most people were simply checking the value of their accounts. 
 Few people moved money from one investment account to another, casting doubt on a frequently expressed concern on Wall Street -- that novice investors would bolt at the first sign of a downturn.
If they did bolt, it would create quite a ripple. The number of people with 401(k) plans has doubled in a decade, to the point that one worker in five has a 401(k) or similar plan. And fully a quarter of this money is in stock funds.
At the General Electric Company, which has 200,000 people in its 401(k) plan, just 800 moved money from one investment option to another, said Charles E. Welch, a benefits executive. While that was five or six times normal, he said, it still came to just one G.E. worker in 250.
At the General Motors Corporation, where 282,000 salaried and hourly workers have $19 billion in retirement plans, "we did not see a mad dash to sell out," said Tony Simonetti, a spokeswoman.
Fidelity Investment Company, the mutual fund unit of the FMR Corporation, said that its automated system for 401(k) plans received a record 250,000 calls on Monday, up from 150,000 on a typical weekday. The number of callers who wanted to speak to an operator almost doubled, to 78,000, on Monday, said Bob Reynolds, president of Fidelity Institutional Retirement Group.
Rowena Itchon, a spokeswoman for T. Rowe Price, the third-largest mutual fund company in the 401(k) business, said that yesterday morning "we saw modest redemptions out of equity funds into money market funds and some fixed-income funds, but by the end of the day we saw quite a bit of money moving into equity funds."
TIAA-CREF, the largest private retirement fund, with two million participants, also said few people moved money. Calling volume, it said, was 25 percent above normal.
"Some people moved into equities and some out, but not enough that you could draw any inference," said Claire Sheahan, a spokeswoman. "Our participants seem to have gotten the message through our investor education programs that retirement saving is for long-term investors."
Many workers were apparently as nonchalant as Howard Stutz, a public relations executive in Las Vegas, Nev. "I didn't even call to check my balance," said Mr. Stutz, whose clients include several big gambling halls. "I am in a 401(k) for the long haul, so I am just going to leave it. The economy is good, and so I am not that worried."
About 24 million workers participate in 401(k) plans and similar retirement savings plans for nonprofit and government workers, double the number in 1987, when the Dow Jones industrial average lost nearly a quarter of its value in a day.
Last year workers had $810 billion in 401(k) plans, up from $155 billion a decade earlier, according to Access Research Inc., a Stamford, Conn., company that tracks 401(k)'s.
Workers and their employers contributed $69.3 billion to 401(k) plans in 1993, the latest year for which detailed figures were available, according to the Employee Benefits Research Institute, a Washington nonprofit group whose estimates are regarded as authoritative. The trend in 401(k) contributions as tracked by the institute suggests that workers now add to their 401(k) plans at the rate of nearly $2 billion a week, or $100 billion a year.
The inaction by participants Monday and yesterday came even though workers are far more exposed to swings in the stock market today than when the market had its last sizable downturn.
Last year 26 percent of 401(k) money was in diversified stock funds, up from 10 percent in 1990, Access Research estimated, while stable-value funds like guaranteed investment contracts had fallen to 20 percent from 32 percent in 1990.
For long-term investors, stocks have historically provided bigger returns than bonds and much bigger returns than savings accounts and money market funds.
The emphasis on equities in retirement plans is even more pronounced in the new money going in. Last year 59 percent of 401(k) contributions went into stock funds and 11 percent into the stock of the employee's company, Access Research estimated.
What would it take to scare Mr. Stutz out of his nonchalance?
"If the market had gone down again today followed by another drastic drop tomorrow, I am sure the calls would have started going to our portfolio manager to ask him what this means," Mr. Stutz said. "But a one-day drop like yesterday, I figure that goes with the territory."
Jeff Croyle of Kwasha Lipton Group, the benefits consulting arm of the accounting firm Coopers & Lybrand, agreed. "The herd mentality would kick in after a couple of days" of sharp drops, he said.

HEADLINE: Amid Day-After Jitters, Opportunity Beckons

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
Yesterday morning, shortly before the stock exchanges' 9:30 start of trading, Daniel K. Cantor seemed remarkably assured for a man who had lost millions of dollars the previous day.
The overnight news from Hong Kong, a flash point in the recent global market slide, was unnerving, down more than 13 percent. Tokyo and the other Asian markets were all heading down sharply, and the gloom was spreading to the European markets for another day. 
 It looked grim. But Mr. Cantor, who manages a $330 million mutual fund, the Stein Roe Growth and Income Fund, that lost 6 percent of its value on Monday, shrugged off both that battering and the cascading declines overseas. In the continuing drop, he saw bargains. "It's the sort of opportunity we've been waiting for," he said, expressing a view shared by many other eager investors yesterday.
When the New York market opened sharply lower, so much the better, he figured. At a few minutes after 10 A.M., Mr. Cantor bought 5,000 shares of Citicorp, when it was trading around $118. The shares closed at $127.50, up $4.1875 on the day, bolstering the assets of a fund that represents mainly the savings of individual investors and puts their money into the blue-chip household names of corporate America.
For a day at least, Mr. Cantor's view of financial reality prevailed. Investors as diverse as major corporations, like I.B.M., and individuals like Robert Baird of Denver said that they were untroubled by the previous week's market slide. The recent bad news, they said, was really good news -- justification for a daylong share-shopping spree. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 337.17 points, or 4.71 percent, while the Nasdaq rose 4.43 percent and the American Stock Exchange advanced 1.49 percent.
For Wall Street's professional stock traders, the day began in deep anxiety and ended in relief -- though not triumphant optimism that the market's decline had been permanently reversed.
At 5 A.M., Robert M. Murphy awoke at his home in Colts Neck, N.J., and a half-hour later was driving to his job on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange. Mr. Murphy is president of Robb, Peck & McCooey, a so-called specialist firm. Specialists are designated by the stock exchange to make a market -- standing ready to buy and sell specified stocks, if needed to keep the market operating and orderly. Mr. Murphy's firm handles the shares of 200 different companies, including Philip Morris and Eastman Kodak.
By 6:30 A.M., Mr. Murphy had arrived at the exchange and met with his colleagues at the firm, all of whom, he said, were "pretty much in shell shock." Given the overnight slide in the Asian stock markets and a trend of declines that continued in Europe, he felt certain the market here would open lower.
"My stomach tells me I'm going to have to put on the helmet and get back in the foxhole," he said. "It could be a pretty tough day."
His worries were shared by the hundreds of traders, sitting in row after row, in Smith Barney's cavernous stock trading room on the third floor of 390 Greenwich Street. As the market opened, Robert E. Moore, a managing director on the trading floor, spoke of the possibility that the Dow industrials could fall more than 300 points to the 6,800 range.
Before the opening, there was talk about the essential strength of the American economy -- the steady growth, robust corporate profits and low inflation. It was all true, but none of that had prodded the stock market higher recently.
The Smith Barney traders realized that the market would open lower in a knee-jerk response to the foreign markets. The real test, they said, would come later in the day, if a second wave of selling developed. Or a rally.
The answer came quickly. Shortly after the opening, the Dow Jones was indeed down 105 points. But then came glimmers of a rally -- a surge of orders from mutual fund managers, like Mr. Cantor, and reports that corporations were ready to step in and buy back their own shares. The financial news wires reported that I.B.M. said it would spend as much as $3.5 billion for its shares.
Just after 10 A.M., the tide had turned. "It has all the marks of a good rally," one relieved Smith Barney trader declared.
In Denver, Mr. Baird, a 36-year-old vice president at Samsonite, was smarting from Monday's selloff on Wall Street. His personal portfolio -- composed mainly of well-known companies, including Citicorp, General Electric, Motorola and Microsoft -- had lost $150,000 in a single day. Like the professional fund managers, he was thinking of buying. But, first, he wanted the market to drop further.
Had the Dow average declined an additional 300 points yesterday, Mr. Baird said, "I would have added to my positions in my core stocks."
Mr. Baird spoke to his broker at midday, but decided not to buy into yesterday's rally. He will watch the market closely for the next couple of weeks. "If it drops more, then I'm going to buy," he said.
In general, he believes in the soundness of the nation's economy. The market's recent slide did not tempt him to sell. "Our economy looks very healthy and corporate earnings reports are still showing some good gains," Mr. Baird said. "I'm sure the market will rebound."
The stock market has long served as kind of fun-house mirror of economic sentiment, exaggerating both optimism and pessimism. Big market moves do have an impact on consumer spending and corporate investment. Yet to have any sizable economic effect, the shift, up or down, must be large and lasting.
Economists estimate, for example, that for every dollar that a person loses in portfolio value, he or she spends 3 cents less during the next year or two. Corporate investment, economists calculate, falls a percentage point or two in a year if the market drops by 10 percent.
"The linkage is real, but it's not huge, unless the market really falls off a cliff and stays there," said David Wyss, chief economist of Standard & Poor's DRI, a research firm in Lexington, Mass.
Yet it is globalization of the financial markets that has changed markedly in the years that Mr. Wyss, who is 52, has studied the links between the stock market and the economy. Yesterday, he was in his suburban Boston office at 7:30 A.M., anxiously monitoring the overnight activity in foreign markets on a pair of computer terminals, especially after the alarming drop abroad, as in Hong Kong's Hang Seng index.
"Years ago, people used to think Hang Seng was a surfing term," he said. "Now, you've really got to pay attention to international markets."
In Silicon Valley, the spreading falloff in global markets, before yesterday's rebound in the United States, was viewed as evidence of the fast-moving globalization aided by information technology.
Roger McNamee, general partner of Integral Capital Partners in Menlo Park, Calif., noted that the information age had linked the world's far-flung economies more tightly and opened markets. Yet the accelerated flow of information and capital, he says, also carried the risk that the forces enhancing economic growth could also transmit trouble more quickly. "This is the flip side of the information economy," said Mr. McNamee, a truly mobile investor who always carries a pager, cellular phone and notebook computer.
Mr. McNamee's firm both invests venture capital in high-technology start-ups and manages a fund of more than $600 million invested in public companies. And yesterday afternoon, after the markets recovered some of their recently lost ground, he was feeling cautiously confident. The share prices of high-technology companies are notoriously volatile, prompting the Silicon Valley quip that investors in these start-ups should be given neck braces along with their shares.
Even if further large drops occur, Mr. McNamee said, he did not expect a rerun of the aftermath of the 1987 crash. In 1988, he noted, fewer than a dozen technology companies could sell new shares to the public, compared with the hundreds of new public offerings annually seen in the last couple of years.
"The total scale of the high-tech economy is so much greater than it used to be," Mr. McNamee said, "and there are so many more solid small companies than there used to be, so things shouldn't dry up."
In Dallas, Frederick E. Rowe, a money manager, used local terms to make the case for taking the market's gyrations in stride.
"Investors are like those cattle," he told a real estate developer and potential investor who had driven an hour and a half to Dallas from his ranch. "Maybe they heard a cricket. Maybe they heard thunder. Maybe a mountain lion. Maybe they thought they saw a mountain lion. Maybe they heard something about the Thai baht. One of them start moving. Then the others start moving. They stampede. Then they stop."
By lunchtime yesterday, a hectic morning for Mr. Rowe had calmed considerably. The flow of phone calls from worried investors, heavy early in the morning as stocks kept falling, tapered off as they rebounded and gained. "It will be all right in the long term," he assured a caller.
For Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, yesterday was a test -- one when the best strategy may be silence, but also one when the Administration had to be ready to act should a market drop prove far worse.
Mr. Rubin started his day with a 7:45 A.M. strategy session with Erskine Bowles, the White House chief of staff. The issue: how President Clinton should handle the market's drop when he spoke in Chicago.
During the meeting, Mr. Clinton tried to reach Mr. Rubin at the Treasury, looking for exactly that guidance. By then, a brief set of suggested comments was being faxed to him in Chicago.
After talking with Mr. Rubin around 9 A.M. -- and getting briefed on the wreckage in the Hong Kong market overnight -- the President took his cue. Making clear the contrast between America and Asia without ever explicitly comparing the two, Mr. Clinton described American businesses and banks as "healthy and sound," adding that with "new jobs being created every day, our economy is continuing to grow steady and strong."
"The effort," one Administration official said, "was to refocus investors on the economy, not the market."

HEADLINE: THE 1997 ELECTIONS: THE CANDIDATES;
Ministers Back McGreevey; Whitman Stumps With Kemp

BYLINE: By JENNIFER PRESTON 

DATELINE: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 28

 BODY:
More than two dozen black ministers gathered here today to announce their endorsement of the Democratic gubernatorial candidate, James E. McGreevey, a week after the head of the Black Ministers Council threw his support behind Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's re-election bid.
The church leaders, representing hundreds of black churches across the state, said they were concerned that there may be confusion among blacks that the executive director of the Black Ministers Council was speaking for all of them. 
 "The Republicans like to pretend that African-Americans are coming out for Whitman, but I would tell Jim McGreevey not to worry because, as Elijah told the king, 'There is another army, the army of God standing behind, and there are more with us than are with him,' " said the Rev. John Ragin, the pastor of St. Luke's A.M.E. Church in Newark, and the president of the New Jersey A.M.E. Conference. "Jim, hold on to God's army."
As Mr. McGreevey welcomed the endorsement and then spent much of the day courting elderly voters in Ocean County, Governor Whitman continued her bus tour of the state, now in its fourth day.
Mrs. Whitman shook hands with commuters in the Bergen County town of Waldwick, spoke at a luncheon for small-business owners in Jamesburg, in Middlesex County, and toured the laboratories of one of the state's largest employers, the communications giant Lucent Technologies in Monmouth County.
With Jack Kemp, last year's Republican vice presidential candidate, at her side, Mrs. Whitman also toured Perth Amboy's downtown business district. Shoppers there pay lower sales taxes and business owners receive tax incentives under a state program that is similar to a redevelopment initiative that Mr. Kemp is credited with introducing during his days as secretary of the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development.
"I'm just here as an Abraham Lincoln Republican," Mr. Kemp said, when asked if he thought his visit would help the Governor attract the more conservative wing of the state's Republican Party.
"I don't think the Republican Party can survive unless we have a strategy to save America's cities."
As Mrs. Whitman strolled down Smith Street, crowds gathered and walked alongside her. But while local residents waved placards that read, "Latinos and Whitman," Mayor Joseph Vas, a Democrat who had been expected to campaign with the Governor today, was notably absent.
When asked about the Mayor's apparent change of heart, Mrs. Whitman said that Mr. Vas had endorsed her at an earlier event, and she could not expect to "necessarily get two or three bites of the apple."
The endorsement of Mr. McGreevey today by the black ministers is expected to help bolster his campaign for black votes.
The pastors vowed not only to urge members of their congregations to vote for Mr. McGreevey, but also to help take church members to the polls.
"We are sure that you are going to create and provide an atmosphere that is inclusive," said the Rev. Calvin McKinney, the president of the New Jersey General Baptist Convention, which represents 430 churches.
Mr. McGreevey promised to work closely with the ministers, if elected. "I make a fundamental sacred communitment: to work with the pastors to rebuild our cities, to join in partnership," he said.
The Rev. Reginald T. Jackson, the executive director of the Black Ministers Council, pointed out that there had been disagreement in the past among church leaders over endorsements of political candidates. He said that he stood firmly by his decision to offer his personal endorsement of Mrs. Whitman.
Mr. McGreevey also campaigned at senior centers and retirement villages in Ocean County, where he called for the full restoration of a state program that provides home health care services. The program allows recipients, who are not eligible for Medicaid, to receive some subsidized health care services at home. The Whitman administration has not accepted any new enrollments for the program for more than a year.
"It was intended to provide home health care services to the elderly and to the disabled," Mr. McGreevey said at the Lacey Community Hall in Lacey. "The basic concept is that we can care for our elderly at home for the same cost we pay for a nursing home. For the past two years, there has been a deliberate effort to eliminate the home care expansion program."
Mr. McGreevey also criticized the Governor for trying to reduce the number of senior citizens who would be eligible for the state's subsidized prescription.

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

 BODY:

INTERNATIONAL A3-18
 
China's President Wades Into American Culture
Emulating his predecessor, Deng Xiaoping, President Jiang Zemin donned a gift hat in America. He was given a three-cornered colonial-style hat and wore it enthusiastically on a brief visit to Williamsburg, where he met an actor dressed as Thomas Jefferson, whom the Chinese leader frequently quotes. Deng got his ten-gallon hat at an outing to a rodeo in Texas in 1979. A18 

President Clinton and Jiang Zemin agreed to establish a round-the-clock telephone line between Washington and Beijing as a concrete sign of warming relations between the two powers. A18
 
U.S. Troops May Stay in Bosnia
The Clinton Administration has resolved to leave some American troops in Bosnia after their current mission ends next June, senior Administration officials and Western diplomats said. How many would stay, and what they would do, remains to be determined, they said, noting that the President has yet to sign off on the proposal. A3
 
U.N. to Probe Scottish Courts
United Nations Secretary General Kofi Annan plans to name two experts to inspect the Scottish legal system, hoping to defuse Libya's criticism that two of its citizens wanted for trial in the 1988 bombing of Pan Am flight 103 would not receive a fair trial there. Libya's leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, has argued for the trial being held in a third country, or at the International Court of Justice in the Hague. A5
 
Time Out in Israeli Conflict
One day after leaders of the Conservative and Reform movements in Israel vowed to pursue legal action against the Orthodox rabbinate, they agreed to a grace period to mediate the dispute. They object to the Orthodox establishment's exclusive rights to perform conversions to Judaism in Israel and to serve on religious councils. A Government committee will try to find a compromise. A7
 
Coup Defused In Zambia
The Zambian Government said that a coup attempt that lasted a mere three hours had been suppressed without bloodshed and that a handful of military officers had been arrested. Such news from relatively stable southern Africa surprised many observers, especially as Zambia had withstood troubles even though it shares borders with Congo and Angola, both riven by civil wars. A11
 
Spanish Socialists Convicted
Spain's Supreme Court convicted two senior officials of the Socialist Party for their role in a campaign finance scandal that helped defeat the Government of former Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez last year. Court officials said Sen. Josep Maria Sala was sentenced to three years in prison, and Carlos Navarro, a former congressman, to 11 years. Six other individuals were also found guilty in the Filesa case, named for the company that was reportedly set up to funnel funds to the party. Those convicted plan to appeal. (Reuters)
 
NATIONAL A20-24
 
Congress Moves to Limit Some Computer Exports
Congress is moving to tighten controls over the export of high performance American computers to Russia and China, prompting strong opposition from the White House and computer manufacturers and talk of a possible veto. A22
 
Youth Drug Use Surveyed
The country's largest survey of adolescent drug use shows that while the popularity of marijuana and other drugs appears to be leveling off among older high school students, more of their younger brothers and sisters are trying drugs. A20
 
Rules Sought on Airline Data
The Federal Aviation Administration will soon propose a rule under which airlines that voluntarily provide detailed data on routine operations would be given immunity from prosecution for minor violations that the data reveal, the Administrator of the agency, Jane Garvey, said. Ms. Garvey said that a second rule, which would follow soon, would seek to make the data immune to the Freedom of Information Act, and off-limits to plaintiffs' lawyers who sue airlines after plane crashes. A24
 
New Plane Crash Guidelines
A task force on how to assist families of plane crash victims will recommend today that airlines and travel agents be required to ask people who buy tickets for the name and phone number of someone to call in an emergency. The task force will also recommend extending the 30-day period after a crash during which it is illegal for airline insurance companies and lawyers looking for clients to speak with bereaved families. It will also recommend that reporters confine themselves to certain areas at crash scenes, and avoid approaching family members except in designated areas. A24
 
A Tax Defines Virginia Race
James S. Gilmore 3d, the Republican candidate for governor in Virginia, has vaulted to a lead in three major statewide polls after months of running even with his Democratic opponent, Donald S. Beyer, the two-term Lieutenant Governor. Mr. Gilmore's advantage is built in part on his pledge to eliminate the state's car tax. A20
 
Senate Drops Highway Bill
The Senate abandoned its efforts to pass a six-year, $145 billion highway financing bill after supporters of campaign finance overhaul blocked a fourth effort to advance the popular legislation toward a final floor vote. A22
 
Councilman Faces Scrutiny
Los Angeles City Councilman Mike Hernandez has been facing increasing pressure to resign since his arrest on cocaine possession charges two months ago. Constituents have organized a recall movement; last week two of Mr. Hernandez's council colleagues called for his resignation, and on Monday, Mayor Richard J. Riordan also said he should resign "in the best interests of his constituents and the city." A20
 
NEW YORK/REGION B1-10
 
State Health Officials Track H.I.V. Carrier
Nushawn J. Williams, the man accused of infecting nine women and girls in Chautauqua County with H.I.V., has said that he had sex with dozens of women in New York City this year, state health officials said, raising the possibility that he has, directly or indirectly, exposed hundreds of people to AIDS. B8
 
Mayor Expands Drug Stings
Returning to his pledge to make fighting drugs a priority in a second term, Mayor Giuliani announced the expansion of sting operations in New York City parks that for the first time involve undercover police officers selling marijuana to buyers, and then arresting them. B1
 
Work Starts at Ellis Island
Preservationists worried that Congress is ignoring the decay of the long-neglected south side of Ellis Island have raised $50,000 to shore up one of the 24 buildings, saying they hope the work, which began recently, will shame the Federal Government into paying for emergency repairs to the rest of the site. Up to 24 buildings are at risk from rot and rust, but could be preserved with a $3 million investment, advocates said. B3

College Faces Antitrust Case
A Federal appeals court has reinstated an antitrust action charging Hamilton College with monopolizing the market for student housing in Clinton, N.Y., by requiring all students to live on campus. The outcome of the case could affect a number of colleges trying to close fraternity houses. B11
 
BUSINESS DAY D1-28
 
U.S. Stocks in Big Rally
Main Street rode in to rescue Wall Street as America's amateur investors rushed to buy stocks, halting the global financial free fall that began last week. The Dow Jones industrial average soared 4.7 percent, the greatest gain in more than a decade and the sixth-largest ever. A1

HEADLINE: War on Auto Tax Is Giving G.O.P. an Edge in Virginia

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY

DATELINE: ALEXANDRIA, Va., Oct. 28

 BODY:
Kathy Smith has a 9-month-old daughter and a 2-year-old Toyota Camry. As she sees it, the $300 state car tax she paid to the Alexandria city government this year, came at her child's expense.
"That's worth almost one month of day care," said Ms. Smith, who works for Alexandria's Department of Human Services. "You buy a car, you pay the sales tax. You shouldn't have to pay anything additional." 
 James S. Gilmore 3d, the Republican candidate for governor in Virginia, agrees and has made eliminating the car tax on the first $20,000 of book value the cornerstone of his campaign.
It appears that his stand could win him the election next Tuesday.
After months of running even with his Democratic opponent, Donald S. Beyer, the two-term Lieutenant Governor, Mr. Gilmore has vaulted to a lead in three major statewide polls. A survey published by The Washington Post last week showed Mr. Gilmore with a seven-point lead. In a Roanoke College poll released on Monday, Mr. Gilmore led by 12 points, and in a poll released today by Virginia Commonwealth University in Richmond, Mr. Gilmore led by 8 points.
In all three polls, Mr. Gilmore's lead exceeded the statistical margin of error.
Political analysts around the state say that voters like Ms. Smith are the reason Mr. Gilmore has jumped ahead. In a campaign in which both candidates have emphasized putting into effect new education programs as their chief objective, many voters in the final days have focused, instead, on a tax that costs some car owners as much as $1,000 a year. Each local government sets its own car tax rate. Mr. Gilmore has calculated that if his plan is approved, 90 percent of Virginia car owners would no longer pay the tax by the end of a five-year phase-in period. The state would reimburse municipalities for the lost revenue.
"Our poll shows that anyone who is voting on a tax issue is going to vote for Gilmore," said Robert S. Holsworth, a professor of political science at Virginia Commonwealth University. "Beyer has an advantage on the education platforms, but he has never been able to elevate his education plank to the same level Gilmore has with the car tax."
Mr. Beyer at first criticized the Gilmore tax plan, contending it would cost the state $1 billion a year, damaging educational programs in state public schools. Mr. Gilmore said projections of economic growth would more than compensate for the tax cut.
When voters began responding to Mr. Gilmore's plan enthusiastically, Mr. Beyer proposed a tax plan of his own, giving car owners a modest tax credit, up to $250, to help offset what they pay for the car tax.
The polling results show that Mr. Gilmore's approach has begun swaying many voters. But more than that, Mr. Holsworth said, it has become an issue that represents to many voters a major position change by Mr. Beyer, who has been plagued by other late-campaign problems.
In a debate televised around the state earlier this month, Mr. Beyer accused Mr. Gilmore, the state's former Attorney General, of offering plea agreements to 35 defendants after the state had abolished parole and adopted tougher sentencing guidelines. The next day, Mr. Gilmore proved Mr. Beyer incorrect with evidence that he only offered nine such deals, forcing Mr. Beyer to apologize and admit he was wrong.
Two weeks later, former Gov. L. Douglas Wilder, a Democrat who became the first black ever elected as a governor in the United States, announced that he would endorse neither candidate. It was a stinging rebuke for Mr. Beyer, who served his first term under Mr. Wilder, and it could persuade many black voters to stay home on Election Day.
Mr. Gilmore said in an interview that Mr. Beyer's failure to win Mr. Wilder's support was "a devastating blow." But more reflective of his surge in the polls, he added, was a growing belief by voters that his economic plan makes more sense than Mr. Beyer's.
Mr. Beyer continues to be unpersuaded, even with mounting evidence that he is even slipping in the traditional Democratic stronghold of Northern Virginia, where Mr. Beyer's family owns a successful car dealership.
Speaking at a high school in Norfolk, Mr. Beyer acknowledged today that his slip in the polls was mainly linked to Mr. Gilmore's salesmanship on the car tax. Mr. Beyer agreed that advocating its elimination had "political sex appeal," but he argued that "it is the wrong thing to do."
"I know people hate the car tax," he said. "They hate to write the check. I'm a car dealer; I know. Most people hate the Federal income tax, too."
Mr. Beyer said he would continue to emphasize that using so much state money to offset the tax would hurt schools, calling that "the central message of my campaign."
"If people hear that message," he added, "I'll win."

(Clement Britt/The Richmond Times Dispatch); At right, Donald S. Beyer, the Democrat, played basketball yesterday at the Salvation Army Boy's Club in Richmond. (Joe Mahoney/The Richmond Times Dispatch)

SECTION: Section A; Page 31; Column 2; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 795 words

HEADLINE: Conspiracy Overload

BYLINE: By P. J. O'Rourke; P. J. O'Rourke, the international affairs desk chief for Rolling Stone magazine, is the author most recently of "Age and Guile Beat Youth, Innocence and a Bad Haircut."

 BODY:
Some of my politically conservative compeers have been telling wild tales about the Clinton Administration. They see vast conspiracies in the small-time chicanery of Whitewater, Castle Grande and the Madison Guaranty Savings and Loan. They view the shabby, provincial Rose Law Firm as a super-villain cabal worth a new Batman film. They experience fits of credulity about drug smuggling at the airport in Mena, Ark., and an adolescent Bill Clinton's K.G.B. contacts. They monger gossip about the President and his wife participating in what may be politely termed a rich and varied social life, and they claim that webs of hidden influence are spun from such extramaritalities.
I'm a right-wing nut myself -- believing in flat tax, Second Amendment rights, God and other things liberals find incredible. But I do not believe Vince Foster was kidnapped by space aliens or murdered by a jealousy-maddened Ruth Bader Ginsburg or whatever the latest canard is. More likely Mr. Foster came to Washington with people he thought were friends, hated the place, was having personal problems and then discovered that he was to be left holding a large bag of Whitewater effluvium. In the matter of his own death, poor Mr. Foster had what a prosecutor (special or otherwise) would call "motive, means and opportunity." 
 I don't understand why conservatives resort to the fabulous to discredit such a less-than-fabulous Administration. The reality of the Clinton Presidency is damning enough. The energy would be better spent attacking Mr. Clinton's political principles -- if and when he shows any.
Maybe this is the problem. Mr. Clinton is so elusive that conservatives are driven to romance by frustration. Here is a man who no one disputes is untrustworthy but whom everyone agrees to like. A man of dubious courage and character who defeats not one but two war heroes. A man who beats Republicans by running as one. A man who is able to use arguments from the right, the left and indeed from thin air (i.e., global warming) to further a political agenda that seems to consist of nothing but making everything more political.
Conspiracy theories are the traditional consolation of the powerless, and conservatives feel powerless watching President Clinton benefit from the cold war victory and the free market success won by conservative ideas. He is a cheerleader who thinks he carried the ball, a cheerleader for the other side at that. In the past we've seen powerless conservatives create McCarthyism, the John Birch Society and water fluoridation hysteria just as we've seen powerless liberals create Psychology, Sociology, Anthropology and Political Science. Now it's the conservatives' turn to play the fools again.
Conspiracy theories are also the consolation of the stupid. Bill Clinton as President of the United States is a perplexing phenomenon. A conspiracy might explain it. Contrary to certain appearances, liberals do not have a monopoly on thickheadedness. When a stupid person espouses a conspiracy theory, he is saying, "The world is so stupid that, given some special information, even I can understand it."
But although all conservatives are exasperated with Bill Clinton and some are stupid, too, the best reason for conservatives to pull the longbow about the Presidency is to get attention. The public is not listening to the substantive points conservatives are making -- about sloppy foreign policy, entitlement burdens, military unpreparedness, tyrannical regulatory powers and other fundamental issues. In a time of no international threats and a prospering economy (check today's Hang Seng closing to make sure these things are still true), the public doesn't care about political principles. With giddy insouciance Americans support family values legislation, then go out and act like the cast of "Melrose Place." They vote for tax cuts, they vote for benefit increases, and they often don't vote at all. An entire New Jersey gubernatorial race is being fought on the issue of car insurance rates.
If it makes conservatives feel better, nobody is listening to Bill Clinton, either. Watch him desperately trying for a "place in history" -- one week it's as welfare reform maestro, the next week as race relations adept, then ecology maven, education cognoscente, etc. He may come back in a hundred years to find that his historical place is "whatshisname with two terms between Bush pere and Bush fils."
I think Bill Clinton and the conservative bunko merchants should go on one of those daytime television shows. The President could confess that he did everything of which he's accused. The conservative pundits could admit that they made up every allegation. All concerned could hug and cry. And maybe somebody would tune in.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Continues Its Tumble Against Mark and Swiss Franc

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar, continuing its pattern of recent days, tumbled yesterday against major European currencies but rose against the Japanese yen.
The United States currency fell to its second consecutive five-month low against the Swiss franc and dropped to a four-month low against the German mark for a second day. Traders considered traditionally safe European currencies a haven for their money amid continued uncertainty about the course of world financial markets. 
 The dollar fell to a three-month low against the British pound for a third consecutive session. The pound has been strengthened by the British Government's announcement on Monday that it would not join the European common currency immediately when it is introduced next year. The pound fetched $1.6717, up from $1.6711.
The yen also struggled yesterday against European currencies, which indirectly helped the dollar strengthen against the Japanese currency.
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 1.4093 Swiss francs, down from 1.4223 late Tuesday and its lowest level since May 21. It fell to 1.7293 marks from 1.7368, a level not seen since June 26.
The two European currencies are "appealing places to park funds in the short term," said Lisa Finstrom, a currency analyst at Smith Barney.
Contributing to the dollar's slump against European currencies was Congressional testimony from the Federal Reserve's chairman, Alan Greenspan, that left traders confident that the Fed would not raise interest rates soon. Mr. Greenspan said recent market gyrations could have a long-run benefit for the American economy by helping it slow to a more sustainable pace, suggesting that the Fed would not raise rates to cool inflationary pressure.
Higher interest rates generally raise demand for a country's currency. Many traders believe Germany's central bank will raise interest rates before the Fed does, and the Bank of England has already raised rates four times this year.
The dollar rallied to 120.78 yen, up from 120.47.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday included 5.7880 French francs, down from 5.8257, and 1,695 Italian lire, down from 1,702.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Crude Oil Prices Up Sharply As Iraq Bans U.S. Officials

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Crude oil futures prices rose yesterday after Iraq barred Americans from a team overseeing dismantling of some of its weapons, a move that could lead to a complete ban on Iraqi oil exports. Heating oil and unleaded gasoline also jumped.
On other markets, copper futures prices rose as rebounding world stock prices prompted optimism that Asian economies could bounce back, lifting demand for the metal in the construction industry. 
 Crude oil and its products jumped after the leader of Iraq, Saddam Hussein, ordered 10 American members of the United Nations weapons inspections team expelled from the country within a week, contending that Washington had impeded Iraqi sovereignty.
The action came in response to a United Nations resolution, passed late last week with urging from the Clinton Administration, that threatened to impose travel restrictions on Iraqi officials if they did not cooperate with inspection teams.
Iraq is required to eliminate its weapons of mass destruction before the United Nations will lift the oil embargo it imposed after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in 1990.
An exception to the embargo allows Iraq to export slightly more than $2 billion in oil every six months to pay for food and medicine. The oil amounts to about a million barrels a day, or 1.6 percent of global output.
Some investors were betting that the United Nations would cut the flow of oil from Iraq. But prices retreated from the day's highs on the expectation that even if exports were stopped, other countries would move to fill the void, said Gerald E. Samuels, an analyst at ARB Oil Inc.
Crude oil for December delivery on the New York Mercantile Exchange rose 25 cents, to $20.71 a barrel, after rising as high as $20.95. November heating oil rose 0.67 cent, to 57.19 cents a gallon; November unleaded gasoline rose 1.21 cents, to 60.09 cents a gallon.
Copper futures prices followed world stock market prices higher on the New York Mercantile Exchange, amid easing concerns about a weak world economy that could reduce demand for the metal in everything from cars to electronics and plumbing. December copper rose 0.55 cent, to 91.05 cents a pound.

HEADLINE: 2 U.S. Reports Add to Evidence of Minimal Inflation

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29

 BODY:
Orders for long-lasting goods fell in September for the first time in three months, the Commerce Department said today in a report that suggested that American industrial activity might be slowing.
In another report that pointed to noninflationary economic growth, the Federal Reserve Board said its regional survey of the country showed steady prices and infrequent wage pressures. 
 The two reports coincided with testimony to Congress by the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, who asserted that the economy was continuing to expand with no sign of accelerating inflation.
Mr. Greenspan's testimony and the economic data contributed to gains in the stock and bond markets, which viewed them as evidence that the Fed was unlikely to raise interest rates anytime soon. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 8.35 points to 7,506.67, adding to its record comeback rally of 337.17 points, or 7.2 percent, on Tuesday. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond, a harbinger of interest rate trends, eased to 6.20 percent from 6.28 percent.
The Commerce Department data showed orders for durable goods fell six-tenths of a percent, to $185.73 billion, after rising a revised 2.8 percent in August, to a record $186.81 billion. In its previous reading on durable goods on Oct. 2, the Government reported that August orders rose 2.7 percent, to $186.55 billion.
The September drop was led by declines in orders for aircraft, motor vehicles and parts, and electronic equipment. Before the report, analysts had expected orders to show a drop of four-tenths of a percent.
When the often-volatile category of transportation equipment is excluded, durable goods orders rose two-tenths of a percent last month. Excluding military hardware, orders decreased three-tenths of a percent.
Unfilled orders, a gauge of pent-up demand, increased one-tenth of a percent in September after rising 1.1 percent in August. Shipments of goods, a gauge of current demand, rose 2.1 percent last month after decreasing 1.3 percent in August.
Despite the decline, economists cautioned against reading too much into one month's factory report because orders for durable goods tend to vary widely from month to month.
The Fed's regional economic report, known as the beige book, said prices remained stable partly because competition and customer resistance made it difficult for producers to raise prices.
Most of the 12 Fed district banks contributing to the report characterized growth in their regions as moderate to strong, while retail sales and auto sales were weaker. Labor demand was high, with hiring difficulties reported by employers seeking workers skilled in high technologies.
Residential construction and sales have been uneven, although commercial construction continued to grow, the report said. Bank lending was mixed.
The Fed's regional report is published eight times a year, just before the policy-setting Federal Open Market Committee meets. The latest edition was compiled by the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta, using information collected before Oct. 20.
The report will help form the basis for discussion on interest rate targets at the Nov. 12 meeting of the committee. Most economists expect the panel to refrain from changing the Federal funds target rate on overnight loans between banks.

GRAPHIC: Chart/Map: "Economy Tempers in Places, but Remains Vigorous"
A roundup of regional economic conditions in recent months for the Federal Reserve's 12 districts, according to the beige book report issued by the Fed yesterday.
 
Minneapolis -- Earnings, tax receipts and sales all inc-reased, while prices, for the moment, held steady. While wages did not rise, em-ployers used other incentives to attract workers in a tight labor market.
 
Chicago -- Prices held steady; retailers attributed a slow pace in sales to warm weather, also cited for increases in new-home sales and construction. Manufacturing activity and new orders were strong.
 
Cleveland -- Business activity continued to expand amid extremely low levels of unem-ployment and small wage and price increases.
 
Boston -- Retailers, manufacturers and insurance companies reported steady expansion in revenues; labor markets cited 3% to 5% increases in wages and salaries.
 
New York -- Growth appeared to moderate. Manufacturing accelerated, retail sales slowed, and prices and loan demand held steady.
 
Philadelphia -- Manufacturers saw gains in orders and shipments, but retailers, car dealers and bankers all reported drops in activity.
 
Richmond -- Manufacturing output increased, labor markets tightened, and commercial real estate was robust; home sales slowed.
 
Atlanta -- Retail sales increased modestly, as did commercial construc-tion; wage pressure was seen in fewer industries than in previous months.
 
St. Louis -- The economy continued to surge, with increased sales and an increasing tightness in the labor market.
 
Kansas City -- Labor markets remained tight, with intensifying wage increases. Retail prices held steady, sales dipped slightly, and construction lessened somewhat.
 
Dallas -- Prices rose, and retail sales were slower than expected, although construction and demand for services grew. Many industries reported continued difficulty hiring.
 
San Francisco -- Indications of rapid growth continued, including increases in manufacturing activity and demand for residential and commercial construction; retailers reported moderate gains.
