HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Fed Chief's Remarks Spur Rally in Bonds

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury securities rallied yesterday after Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, told a Congressional committee that despite a tight labor market, "growth appears to have remained robust and inflation low, and even falling."
Still, Mr. Greenspan told the Joint Economic Committee that the Fed could not take a complacent view of inflation. "It is terribly important for us to make sure that this recovery continues and continues in a solid way," he said, adding that an onset of inflation would be "the greatest threat to it at the moment." 
 His comments were a relief to bond market participants, who now expect no rate increase when the Fed's Open Market Committee, the panel that sets interest rate policy, meets on Nov. 12.
The 30-year Treasury bond gained 15/32 points to a price of 10212/32 , pushing its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, down to 6.20 percent, from 6.28 percent on Tuesday.
Also bolstering Treasuries yesterday, analysts said, was a flight to quality fueled by a plunge in Brazil's stock market and by rumors of rising tensions between North and South Korea.
Another factor was a report that new orders for durable goods fell six-tenths of 1 percent in September, primarily because of a decline in civilian aircraft orders.
Despite the slippage, said Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, durable goods orders continue to demonstrate resiliency. Discussing the recent turmoil in world equity markets and its economic effects, Mr. Fine forecast that American exports would fall, while imports would rise, widening the trade deficit and acting "as a drag on economic momentum."
In auction activity yesterday, traders said the sale of the five-year Treasury note was disappointing. The notes sold at a higher price than expected to yield 5.83 percent.
The Treasury said yesterday that its quarterly refunding next week would include $14 billion of new three-year notes; $11 billion of 10-year notes (actually the issuance of more of the 6.125 percent coupon first auctioned on Aug. 8), and $10 billion of new 30-year bonds. Analysts said this would be the smallest quarterly refunding with a long bond since May 1993.
In when-issued trading ahead of next week's auctions, dealers began offering the securities at prices to yield 5.69 percent for a three-year note; 5.90 percent for the reopened 10-year note and 6.17 percent for the 30-year bond.

HEADLINE: Waiters Settle Suit With Chinatown Restaurant

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN 

 BODY:
In what Asian-American labor groups are calling a big victory, Chinatown's largest restaurant has agreed to pay more than $1.1 million to 58 workers who said they had been cheated out of tips and wages, officials said yesterday.
The Attorney General's office filed a lawsuit in January that charged Jing Fong restaurant with cheating workers out of more than $1.5 million in tips and wages since 1993 by illegally controlling the distribution of tips and withholding some of them. The Asian-American Legal Defense and Education Fund had filed a lawsuit against Jing Fong in Federal District Court seeking $500,000 on behalf of workers who said the restaurant had failed to pay overtime and violated minimum-wage laws. 
 Yesterday's settlement between Jing Fong and the Attorney General's office and the legal defense fund is not the first between Chinatown workers and their employers. But it is the biggest, and perhaps the most important, in Chinatown, an area of sharp labor conflict.
"We have to treat the workers with dignity, with respect, we have to pay them the wages they're entitled to, and if they don't, we're going to be here," Attorney General Dennis C. Vacco said in front of the restaurant on Elizabeth Street.
Hugh H. Mo, an attorney representing Jing Fong's owners, said that too much was being made of the settlement, in which Jing Fong admits no wrongdoing. "Jing Fong is not a slave-labor scam," he said. "We would've preferred to litigate this in a court of law. But we are mindful of the fact that restaurants play a crucial role in the Chinese-American economy and Jing Fong is concerned about the continuing bloodletting from this case."
Jing Fong is Chinatown's largest restaurant and seats more than 1,000 in a dining area that seems as big as an ocean liner. On weekends, the place teems with people speaking Cantonese to waiters pushing dim sum carts.
But some waiters and busboys said they were paid as little as $65 to $100 a week for working 60 or more hours -- a workweek that should have earned them $213 a week at the minimum wage, plus overtime and tips. When one waiter, Sheng Gang Deng, complained publicly to managers in 1995, he was fired, according to the Attorney General's office.
Under the settlement announced yesterday, the restaurant's owners are expected to pay the employees in installments over the next 32 months. Mr. Deng will be rehired -- with a guarantee that he will not be discriminated against. In addition, managers will no longer control the collection and distribution of tips, which, according to state law, is supposed to be controlled by the waiters.
Peter Kwong, director of Hunter College's Asian-American studies program, said a garment manufacturer had settled a labor lawsuit for $91,000 in 1991, but the latest settlement would have a larger impact.
"This puts employers on notice that you better pay attention to some of the very, very basic labor conditions," Mr. Kwong said.

HEADLINE: Perot Set to Re-Enter Political Scene

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: DALLAS, Oct. 28

 BODY:
Ross Perot said he thought of going up to Washington to "bang on some doors" to try to get a campaign finance bill passed, but concluded it would be a waste of time.
"Facts and testimony don't mean anything there," Mr. Perot added, rolling his eyes and professing mock shock that such legislation was currently stymied in Congress. "It's who's paid off who that means everything." 
 The bipartisan campaign finance hearings in Washington are a joke anyway, he said.
"This is like having Willie Sutton and Jesse James investigate one another for bank robbery," Mr. Perot snapped. And over all, he concluded, the nation is in a "Lawrence Welk mode," lethargically ignoring its real problems.
But lest anyone think that Mr. Perot, the two-time Presidential candidate, has grown pessimistic about his role in the nation's public life, watch for him this weekend in Kansas City, Mo. That is the site of a national meeting of the Reform Party, the movement that he founded and bankrolled and whose Presidential nomination he accepted last year -- and might just accept again, if the call comes.
"I will sweep the streets, I'll sleep under a bridge," Mr. Perot said last week on "Larry King Live" on CNN, echoing almost exactly the language he used in 1996 when asked if he would run for the White House. "I'll do anything that I can do constructively to help this country."
For nearly a year, since garnering 8.5 percent of the Presidential vote, the normally loquacious Mr. Perot has been curiously silent, and even some of his supporters have been wondering why he has seemed all but invisible as Congress has taken up campaign reform, an issue that is arguably the centerpiece of Mr. Perot's eclectic set of prescriptions for the nation's ills.
"I must say, a lot of us have wondered about this, about why he has not been more involved and more vocal," said Anne Merkl, chairwoman of the Reform Party of Georgia. "Whatever his reasons are, I'd like to know why, and maybe he'll come forth with that this weekend."
In fact, over the last few days, Mr. Perot has begun speaking out, first on the Larry King show, his time-honored vehicle for getting his message out (his Oct. 20 appearance was his first this year), then in a lengthy interview in his office here. And now he will speak this Saturday night at the Kansas City meeting, which Reform Party officials describe as the "founding convention" of the party. (Obviously, the party was around last year, with Mr. Perot as its nominee, but the meeting now -- with delegations from all 50 states -- is intended to create a formal national committee, a set of party rules and a general declaration of principles.)
Just what the party's impact will be in elections in 1998 or 2000 is unclear, but Mr. Perot, using a series of military analogies, said the whole point of the exercise was to "get organized, get in position, be prepared and wait for the opportunity.
"You need the opportunity," he said in an interview in his office here, adorned with Frederic Remington busts and Norman Rockwell pictures. That opportunity could be a scandal "that gets the American people so totally disgusted" that they demand a new party, or it could be an economic calamity, or it might even be a war, he said, adding, simply, "It will come."
Many of those who have observed Mr. Perot over the years say the reasons for his apparent self-imposed exile from the public fray were obvious.
"Perot was convinced after the '96 election that he was badly overexposed, and needed some quiet time away from the cameras," said Larry J. Sabato, a professor of government at the University of Virginia who is in frequent contact with Reform Party members. "By and large, to many people's surprise, he stayed out of the limelight for about a year."
Moreover, even among those who dearly want campaign finance reform, there is a strong sense that Mr. Perot is not likely to have much effect on the discussions in Washington.
"Clearly, this issue crystallized with Perot's candidacy in '92, and resonated to a lesser extent in the '96 election," said Charles Lewis, executive director of the Center for Public Integrity, a nonprofit research group in Washington. "But it's not clear to me that Ross Perot or anything short of the Second Coming would have any impact on these politicians here in Washington. They are determined to maintain the status quo."
Mr. Perot acknowledged that some people were claiming he had, in his words, "gone underground," but he bitterly rejected the characterization.
"Let's look at the record," he said in the interview here. "How many times have I been invited on Larry King? Once. How many times have I appeared? Once. How many times have I been invited on 'Meet the Press'? Once."
Mr. Perot also noted that he had repeatedly sought this year to buy half-hour blocks of prime-time television on the major networks for "infomercials" about campaign finance and other topics. He is correct about that, but the networks have routinely turned down the requests, generally by saying that they do not make such large chunks of time available, especially for "issue oriented" advertising.
In any event, Mr. Perot is back, and he said he was unlikely to fade away because he saw no prospect that either major party would tackle campaign reform issues or long-range fiscal crises like Social Security, Medicaid or Medicare.
"You don't want to know how many key Republicans and Democrats have sat down right where you are and said, What would it take to get you guys to go away or to join us?" Mr. Perot said. "I've said 100 times, the way you get this organization to go away is to do all these things you talk about but never do."
Russell J. Verney, the chairman of the Reform Party national organizing committee, said the party would be fielding all kinds of candidates in elections next year, though he emphasized that the major goal at this point was less to rack up victories than to influence the debate and step up pressure for the party's agenda.
"The bold ideas in American public policy debate have never come from established political parties," Mr. Verney said. "The bold ideas like abolition of slavery, women's right to vote, child labor laws, antitrust laws, progressive taxation and reducing the deficit have all come from third party efforts."
Mr. Perot scoffed at recent reports about squabbles within the Reform Party, perhaps most noticeably a split in Illinois that has two factions claiming to represent the party.
"It's a group of five people, maybe," he said of party dissidents, some of whom he said were working for the "dirty tricks teams" of the two major parties. "They're like mosquitoes at a picnic. You can't let it ruin the picnic."
And of the influence of money in politics today, Mr. Perot said, "Tammany Hall looks pristine compared to this. Louisiana politics in the 30's, when Huey Long was in, looks like it was controlled by the Boy Scouts and Girl Scouts."

HEADLINE: Senate Approves New F.C.C. Chairman

BYLINE: Dow Jones 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29

 BODY:
The Senate gave approval today to President Clinton's choice to fill the top post at the Federal Communications Commission, but lawmakers vowed to keep a close eye on the agency as it continues pressing for competition in the telecommunications industry.
In a 99-to-1 vote, the Senate confirmed William E. Kennard as chairman of the agency. Mr. Kennard, 40, the general counsel for the F.C.C., replaces Reed E. Hundt. 
 The vote follows months of rancorous debate on Capitol Hill over the pace of deregulation under last year's sweeping telecommunications legislation. Lawmakers worry that their vision of competition is being clouded by mergers, higher rates for consumers and new regulations.
Senator Conrad Burns, Republican of Montana, voted against the nominee, saying he feared that the F.C.C. would allow higher calling rates for rural telephone users.
Late on Tuesday, the Senate had cleared three other nominees for the five-member commission: Michael Powell, chief of staff at the Justice Department's antitrust division; Harold Furchtgott-Roth, an economist with the House Commerce Committee, and Gloria Tristani, a New Mexico state utilities regulator.
Several senators had expressed concerns about the nomination of Mr. Kennard, including Jesse Helms, the Republican from North Carolina, who questioned an F.C.C. decision to pull the construction permit of a radio station in Asheville, N.C. But Mr. Helms said his fears were allayed after meeting with Mr. Kennard earlier this month.

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN WASHINGTON: THE POLITICS;
A Chinese Visitor Comes Between Longtime California Allies

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29

 BODY:
One woos. The other attacks.
One danced with Jiang Zemin, now China's President, when he was Mayor of Shanghai in the 1980's. The other protested in Tiananmen Square in Beijing in 1991 in memory of pro-democracy demonstrators killed by soldiers two years earlier. 
 Senator Dianne Feinstein and Representative Nancy Pelosi are both hard-charging Democrats from San Francisco whose politics suggest that they should be on the same side of the most important strategic challenge of the Clinton Presidency: how to deal with China.
Instead -- as the state visit of Mr. Jiang illustrates -- the two lawmakers represent polar ends of the debate over what to do about a nuclear power with a three-million-man army, an abysmal human rights record, one-fourth the world's population and the fastest growing economy in the world.
For Ms. Feinstein, 64, whose husband has invested tens of millions of dollars in China on behalf of his clients, the answer is to make friends with the Chinese to build a strong bilateral partnership, make money for American corporations and perhaps change China's bad behavior along the way.
In Ms. Feinstein's view, Mr. Jiang's problem with America is that he is not given enough respect. "I always felt he was underestimated," she said. "This is really the first Chinese leader with a higher education. He can be austere, as Chinese leaders are, or very jovial."
For Ms. Pelosi, 57, the key to dealing with China is to deprive the country of its preferential trade benefits until it no longer tortures political prisoners, uses prison labor, forces women to have abortions and restricts freedom of speech and religion. Honoring Mr. Jiang with a state visit represents the worst kind of pandering to the interests of American business, she said.
"It is shameful for the United States to give a state dinner and a 21-gun salute to the leader of a regime that crushed dissent in Tiananmen Square," Ms. Pelosi said. "It's the best welcome money can buy. I call the state dinner the 'ultimate coffee.' "
The two women's activities surrounding the state visit underscore their differences.
Ms. Feinstein is so close to Mr. Jiang (he calls her Dianne; she sometimes calls him Zemin) that she visited him in Beijing four weeks ago to suggest ways to make the state visit a success. Distressed that Mr. Jiang was only getting a lukewarm welcome on Capitol Hill, Ms. Feinstein organized a reception for him with her fellow senators at Blair House, the Presidential guest house across from the White House.
"I would very much like to invite you to meet the President of the People's Republic of China," her invitation read, reminding her colleagues that she has known him for years and advising them that "it is best to be on time."
Several Senators, including Joseph Biden of Delaware, ranking Democrat on the Foreign Relations Committee, were displeased that Ms. Feinstein organized such an important foreign policy event -- particularly without consulting more senior colleagues on the committee, Senate staffers said. Of the 70 senators invited, only about half have accepted.
At a coffee on Tuesday for Chinese dissidents and former political prisoners organized by Senator Jesse Helms, the North Carolina Republican who is chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee and a longtime China-basher, the two women's different approaches were on display.
Ms. Pelosi said it was an honor to be in the same room with the dissidents, whom she called the "true heirs to Thomas Jefferson." Ms. Feinstein reminded the former political prisoner Harry Wu that she was instrumental in persuading Mr. Jiang to release him, Mr. Wu said.
"I told her Jiang Zemin was the criminal responsible for the persecution," Mr. Wu said he told her. "I do not appreciate that he does a favor for me by releasing me from prison."
While Ms. Feinstein attended the state dinner at the White House tonight with her husband, Richard C. Blum, Ms. Pelosi was at the alternative "stateless dinner" organized by activists for Tibet at a hotel nearby.
While Mr. Clinton was meeting with Mr. Jiang at the White House today, Ms. Pelosi spoke against the Chinese Government -- and the state visit -- at the human rights rally in Lafayette Park across the street.
In a political environment in which almost any dispute between two women is still called a catfight, both lawmakers claim to be friends. Their San Francisco residences are only two miles apart. Just last week, Ms. Pelosi led a delegation of nine Democrats to Ms. Feinstein's office to urge her to run for Governor.
"There isn't anything like a catfight," Ms. Pelosi said. "We don't have that word in our vocabulary. We agree on a thousand issues. We just have a disagreement on this one."
Ms. Feinstein said: "I want the same things Nancy wants, but I believe we can get there a different way. But I just don't happen to believe it is productive to humiliate China. I don't believe pushing their backs against the wall drives change."

HEADLINE: THE MARKET TURMOIL: THE REGULATORS;
Rethinking Circuit Breakers After Monday's Big Plunge

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29

 BODY:
The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, Arthur Levitt Jr., said today that trading may have been needlessly halted during Monday's market slide and that changes may be needed in the braking devices, known as circuit breakers.
"There have been concerns raised in two areas: about the level at which the current circuit breakers are triggered and whether they unnecessarily disrupt trading," Mr. Levitt told a Senate securities subcommittee. "These are legitimate concerns that should be addressed." 
 He suggested that the circuit breakers be redesigned to kick in when the Dow Jones industrial average drops by a certain percentage rather than a certain number of points.
Circuit breakers, adopted in the wake of the 1987 crash, now call for trading to be halted when the Dow drops 350 points and again if it falls 200 points more. The system's creators intended it to give investors time to make level-headed decisions instead of selling in panic.
Although the exchanges raised these trigger points, from 250 points and 150 points more, in July 1996 and February 1997, because of the market's long rise, many believe that the triggers were not needed on Monday -- and may well have aggravated the market drop. Unlike the 1987 experience, trading this week was orderly and investors at least had accurate price information on which to base decisions.
"It isn't medicine that should be administered for a head cold," said Robert Glauber, a Harvard University professor who was staff director of the commission headed by Nicholas Brady that recommended circuit breakers after the 1987 crash.
Mr. Glauber has suggested that the trigger points be increased, automatically reset by formula each year and applied at the same time to all markets in this country so none would be open when another is closed. He suggested that trading should not be halted until a decline had reached 12 percent, or about 900 points at the current level of the Dow, and be stopped a second time only when the decline reached 20 percent, or about 1,500 points.
Mr. Glauber also complained about the "collar" that curtails certain types of program trades whenever the Dow moves 50 points in either direction, something that occurs about four times each week. But he defended the principle of circuit breakers against complaints by other conference participants that, among other things, trading halts may aggravate, rather than mitigate, market declines and pose particular problems for mutual funds in the daily pricing of their portfolios.
James B. Rogers Jr., a New York investor and former colleague of George Soros, the billionaire financier and philanthropist, was one of the most vociferous objectors to circuit breakers. He called for their abolition, saying they add to investor uncertainty, give professionals extra advantage and will eventually drive business from exchanges subject to them, to overseas markets.
These "absurd" restraints, Mr. Rogers held, were designed to protect the ability of the Wall Street establishment to make sure payments continued to flow, "to help the Merrill Lynches of the world" and not the small investor.
In a paper he presented on circuit breakers, Lawrence Harris of the University of Southern California, said that evidence was scant that trading halts, price limits, collars, margins and transactions affected market volatility.
E. Gerald Corrigan, a senior Goldman, Sachs & Company official who in 1987 was a chief market troubleshooter in his capacity as president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, suggested "some rethinking" of circuit breakers today in a wide-ranging discussion of changes of the last decade. He said that Wall Street institutions, the markets and the nation's economic policy were all considerably stronger than in 1987 and that the potential for financial disaster has diminished.
"The risk of a major market meltdown with systemic impact is not zero, but in the current circumstances it is greatly exaggerated by some," Mr. Corrigan said. At the same time, he added "such an event, were it to occur, could be more difficult to contain than in the past."
He dismissed a commonly expressed concern that the public had become fanatical stock market participants by noting that household holdings of equities are in line with those of the 1950's and 1960's, with a greater share in mutual funds but less in individual stocks.
Mr. Brady, a former Treasury Secretary and a panelist today, called the greatest risk to the financial system its "plumbing and wiring" for insuring liquidity but he also fretted about highly leveraged derivatives that he said "are not worth what they cost" in additional risk.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Circuit Breakers at a Glance"
After the 1987 stock market crash, the New York Stock Exchange adopted new rules, often called circuit breakers, intended to slow a market fall. The criteria for invoking them were set in index points, not in percentage terms; the huge rise in the market since then has made them much more prone to trip than was originally intended.
 Here are the current rules for stocks, how often they have been invoked, and what the criteria would be if they were to be adjusted in proportion to today's market (based on Dow closes yesterday and in October 1988, when the rules were adopted). Additional rules covering futures are omitted.
 
50-POINT RULE
 When the Dow Jones industrial average rises or falls 50 points from the previous day's close, index arbitrage orders (computer program trades based on the stocks in an index like the S.&P. 500) cannot be executed at prices that would move the market further from the previous close.
 
INVOKED -- In recent years, very frequently; in 1997 almost daily.
 
IF ADJUSTED -- Would be invoked at a 175-point move in the Dow.
 
350-POINT BREAKER
 When the Dow falls 350 points (originally 250 points), trading in all stocks is halted for 30 minutes.
 
INVOKED -- Just once, at 2:35 P.M. on Oct. 27, 1997.
 
IF ADJUSTED -- 875-point fall in the Dow.
 
550-POINT BREAKER
 When the Dow falls 550 points (originally 400 points), trading in all stocks is halted for one hour.
 
INVOKED -- Just once, on 3:30 P.M. on Oct. 27, 1997; it had the effect of ending trading for the day.
 
IF ADJUSTED -- 1,400-point fall in the Dow.
 
(Sources: Associated Press; Reuters)

HEADLINE: MARATHON;
The American Standard-Bearer Is Mark Coogan

BYLINE: By JERE LONGMAN 

 BODY:
Mark Coogan's final weekend of training before Sunday's New York City Marathon was complicated by the small interruption of 30 inches of snow dropping on the running trails of Boulder, Colo.
As an autumn storm pounded the Rockies, Coogan did interval training last Friday in snow that blew sideways in a blinding wind. On Saturday, he had to tunnel out of his driveway with a snow shovel. He is the top American in a race where runners from the United States have been buried under an avalanche of international winners since Alberto Salazar's victory in 1982. 
 "It made my back tighten a little, but it didn't mess me up," Coogan said of the shoveling.
According to a preliminary forecast, Sunday in New York looks to be showery with temperatures in the mid-to-upper 50's. Not bad conditions for a marathon. Anyway, for his first attempt at New York, Coogan figures inclement conditions are to his advantage. A native of Manhasset, N.Y., he grew up in Attleboro, Mass., outside Boston. He is accustomed to wind, rain, cold, snow and potholed streets that can interrupt a stride and wrench an ankle.
"It doesn't bug me as much as the next guy," Coogan said. "I can run well in organized chaos."
At 31, the holder of an economics degree from the University of Maryland, Coogan possesses a rare completeness for an American distance runner. He has run a sub-four-minute mile and competed in the Olympics as a marathoner. His personal best of 2 hours 13 minutes 5 seconds came with a second-place finish at the 1996 Olympic marathon trials. The Olympics themselves were not such a pleasant experience. Coogan finished 41st in Atlanta on a hilly, humid, draining course.
"I thought I was in awesome shape," Coogan said. "At 16 or 17 miles, I went from the lead pack to struggling on my own, feeling sorry for myself. But the heat and dehydration won't be a problem in New York."
Unlike others who jumped right back into marathoning, Coogan has not run a 26.2-mile race since Atlanta some 15 months ago. He is rested, healthy and fit for New York, having put in 10 weeks of training above 100 miles and 5 weeks above 120 miles.
Several weeks ago, on a nine-and-a-half-mile course at 6,000 feet, Coogan completed the loop in 47 minutes. This was a big confidence boost, given that his time was comparable to Kenyans who have trained in Boulder, such as Lameck Aguta, the 1997 Boston Marathon champion, and Sammy Lelei, the second-fastest marathoner ever.
 Persistent hill workouts have prepared Coogan's legs for those final three rolling miles of Central Park, which can make a champion or break a contender.
"You want to be racing those last three or four miles, not surviving," Coogan said.
In September, during a 120-mile training week, Coogan was the top American finisher at the Philadelphia half-marathon in 1:03:02. That time was particularly encouraging, given that he defeated Jerry Lawson by more than two minutes and, a month later, Lawson set an American record for a loop course in 2:09:35 at the Chicago Marathon.
"I feel really good; this is definitely the best shape I've been in," Coogan said. "I've been focused all year."
He may have been expected to join Lawson in Chicago and skip New York. New Balance, the shoe company that represents Coogan, is offering $1 million this year to the runner who breaks Bob Kempainen's American record of 2:08:47, set at the 1994 Boston Marathon. It is an enticing carrot to dangle.
Chicago's course is flatter and easier than New York's. But it wasn't money he was after, Coogan said, it was the chance to prove himself in New York, to feel the energy of a city where two million people line the course on race day. As a high school runner, he kept a poster in his bedroom that showed the exultation of Rod Dixon winning the 1983 New York City Marathon and the despair of Geoff Smith, who had been caught and passed after 26 miles.
"Boston, New York, the Olympics, those are my big three," Coogan said. "I want to feel the energy, the hype of the largest single-day spectator event, the heart-pounding good time. Bill Rodgers, Salazar, all the great ones have run New York."
Coogan has been training with the 1988 winner, Steve Jones, and with such other New York veterans as Mark Plaatjes and Arturo Barrios. They have given him pointers: run patiently, don't panic if your legs and feet feel strange as you run over the Queensboro Bridge, don't let the cheering on First Avenue shift you into overdrive with 10 miles left. He has also watched videotapes of previous races, observing how Kempainen smartly ran the tangents to finish second in 1993.
A victory for Coogan would mean a doubling in prize money from $50,000 to $100,000 because he is an American, and it would quadruple the respect that American marathoners now receive in a sport dominated by Africans, Mexicans, Spaniards, Koreans and Japanese. He chafes at the criticism of Frank Shorter, the 1972 Olympic champion, who believes that Americans run too frequently for road-race money and don't preserve their legs for major races.
"In Kenya, the average yearly income is $500," Coogan said. "If you win a $10,000 race, that's 20 years of income. If I make $10,000, it's four months' income. I have to race more; I've got a daughter, a mortgage. Running is like a full-time job on a part-time salary."
Once, marathoners ran at a sustained pace; now, with Africans at the forefront, runners go out hard and "the one who dies the least wins," he said.
Coogan added: "Look at the years Billy Rodgers won New York in the 70's. How many Kenyan runners were there? Or Ethiopians? Probably zero. Now the whole world is running. That's the difference. If an American wins New York, maybe it will get people off our backs."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mark Coogan, who ran the marathon in the Atlanta Olympics, hopes to be the first American since Alberto Salazar to win the New York City Marathon. (Matthew Stockman/Allsport)

HEADLINE: THE MARKET TURMOIL;
Excerpts From Greenspan's Testimony

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from testimony yesterday by Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, before the Joint Economic Committee of Congress: 
 Mr. Chairman and committee members, we meet against the background of considerable turbulence in world financial markets. . . .
We need to assess these developments against the backdrop of a continuing impressive performance of the American economy in recent months. Growth appears to have remained robust and inflation low, and even falling, despite an ever-tightening labor market. . . .
Even after the sharp rebound around the world in the past 24 hours, declines in stock markets in the United States and elsewhere have left investors less wealthy than they were a week ago and businesses facing higher equity cost of capital. Yet, provided the decline in financial markets does not cumulate, it is quite conceivable that a few years hence, we will look back at this episode, as we now look back at the 1987 crash, as a salutary event in terms of its implications for the macroeconomy.
The 1987 crash occurred at a time when the American economy was operating with a significant degree of inflationary excess that the fall in market values arguably neutralized. Today's economy, as I have been suggesting of late, has been drawing down unused labor resources at an unsustainable pace, spurred in part by a substantial wealth effect on demand. The market's net retrenchment of recent days will tend to damp that impetus, a development that should help to prolong our six-and-a-half-year business expansion.
As I have testified previously, much of the stock price gain since early 1995 seems to have reflected upward revisions of long-term earnings expectations, which were implying a continuing indefinite rise in profit margins from already high levels. I suspect we are experiencing some scaling back of the projected gains in foreign affiliate earnings, and investors probably are revisiting expectations of domestic earnings growth. Still, the foundation for good business performance remains solid. . . .
There is much that is encouraging in the recent performance of the American economy, but, as I have often mentioned before, fundamental change comes slowly and we need to evaluate the prospective balance of supply and demand for various productive resources in deciding policy. . . .
The underlying technology-based structure of the international financial system has enabled us to improve materially the efficiency of the flows of capital and payment systems. That improvement, however, has also enhanced the ability of the financial system to transmit problems in one part of the globe to another quite rapidly. The recent turmoil is a case in point. . . .
The shifts in perceived future investment risks led to sharp declines in stock markets across Asia, often on top of earlier declines or lackluster performances. To date, the direct impact of these developments on the American economy has been modest, but it can be expected not to be negligible. . . .
Particularly troublesome over the past several months has been the so-called contagion effect of weakness in one economy spreading to others as investors perceive, rightly or wrongly, similar vulnerabilities. Even economies, such as Hong Kong, with formidable stocks of international reserves, balanced external accounts and relatively robust financial systems, have experienced severe pressures in recent days. One can debate whether the recent turbulence in Latin American asset values reflect contagion effects from Asia, the influence of developments in U.S. financial markets or home-grown causes. Whatever the answer, and the answer may be all of the above, this phenomenon illustrates the interdependencies in today's world economy and financial system. . . .
The financial disturbances that have afflicted a number of currencies in Asia do not at this point, as I indicated earlier, threaten prosperity in this country, but we need to work closely with their leaders and the international financial community to assure that their situations stabilize. It is in the interest of the United States and other nations around the world to encourage appropriate policy adjustments and where required, provide temporary financial assistance.

HEADLINE: THE MARKET TURMOIL: THE POLICY MAKER;
Greenspan Sees A Silver Lining In Stock Unrest

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, broke his silence today over the turmoil in the stock market and proclaimed it not such a bad thing after all.
Speaking to a Congressional committee -- and to investors around the world who were hanging on his every phrase -- Mr. Greenspan said the plunge in markets, even though apparently short lived, could diminish the risks of an outbreak in inflation by venting some steam from an economy that has been threatening to overheat. 
 The stock market rallied sharply on his statements but fell back later in the day. The Dow Jones industrial average closed with a gain of 8.35 points, at 7,506.67. Page D1.
Mr. Greenspan suggested that the harrowing 7.2 percent fall and 4.7 percent rebound in stock prices on Monday and Tuesday could provide consumers with a needed reality check. Consumers have been driving the economy's strong growth by spending freely and amassing considerable new debt, partly because the market's breathtaking rise over the last few years had left them feeling well off even if they were not cashing in their investment gains.
Moreover, Mr. Greenspan said the economy would also be slowed slightly by the economic problems plaguing Asia, where the market turmoil originated. Exports to that region could decline, he said, and imports from Asia would cost less. That would help restrain inflation in the United States because the plunging value of Asian currencies has made goods from that part of the world less expensive if bought in dollars.
As the policy maker most able to influence markets in the United States and abroad, Mr. Greenspan clearly intended to help calm investors' frazzled nerves by providing an upbeat assessment of the wild swings of the last few days.
Although he had dropped a broad hint in Congressional testimony three weeks ago that the current combination of strong growth and low unemployment could soon begin pushing wages and prices higher and require the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates, he avoided any suggestion today that he saw imminent danger from inflation.
Mr. Greenspan has in many ways been the stock market's pre-eminent bear since he asked last December whether investors were suffering from "irrational exuberance." So it was perhaps not surprising that he would emphasize the positive today, two days after the Dow average tumbled 554 points and markets around the world trembled.
He even drew a parallel to the aftermath of the 1987 market crash, which is now widely viewed as having done little economic damage while providing a marvelous stock-buying opportunity for investors.
"Even after the sharp rebound around the world in the past 24 hours, declines in markets in the United States and elsewhere have left investors less wealthy than they were a week ago and businesses facing higher equity cost of capital," Mr. Greenspan said. "Yet, provided the decline in financial markets does not cumulate, it is quite conceivable that a few years hence, we will look back at this episode, as we now look back at the 1987 crash, as a salutary event in terms of its implications for the economy."
The strong economy has been pushing unemployment steadily lower, increasing the odds that wages will begin rising in a way that could push up inflation, he said. The strong demand for goods and services, he said, is caused partly by a "substantial wealth effect," a reference to a belief among consumers that they can spend more because their investments are doing so well.
"The market's net retrenchment of recent days will tend to damp that impetus, a development that should help to prolong our six-and-a-half-year business expansion," Mr. Greenspan said.
Asked whether stocks were now priced more realistically, Mr. Greenspan, who had said several times this year that investors seemed to have a very optimistic view of future corporate earnings, replied that valuations were now "less out of line" than they had been.
Mr. Greenspan, in two hours of testimony before Congress's Joint Economic Committee, said the economy's performance in recent months had been "impressive."
"Growth appears to have remained robust and inflation low, and even falling, despite an ever-tightening labor market," he said.
He attributed the stock market's problems to the troubles afflicting the Asian economies and markets, and on the likelihood that profits of American companies operating in that region would be hurt. But he said that if the Asian markets had not caused American investors to begin reassessing how long the remarkable bull market could last, something else would have.
Mr. Greenspan reiterated his belief that productivity growth was picking up, giving the economy greater capacity to expand without inflation. But he stressed that gains in productivity -- output of a worker in an hour -- were not sufficient to erase his concerns that continued declines in unemployment from the current 4.9 percent rate would eventually create inflationary increases in wages and prices.
Short-term interest rates set by the central bank are high by historical standards when adjusted for inflation, he said. But these relatively high rates have shown no signs of restricting activity in rate-sensitive areas of the economy like housing and therefore should not be considered terribly tight, he added.
The Federal Reserve has left its Federal funds target rate at 5.5 percent since March, but declining inflation since has pushed up the inflation-adjusted "real" rate to about 3.3 percent this year from 2.8 percent. For the last three decades the real Federal funds rate has averaged about 2 percent.
On problems overseas, Mr. Greenspan said it was in the national interest to provide temporary financial assistance to nations like those in Asia that are struggling economically. His statement appeared intended to buttress a growing consensus within the Clinton Administration that the United States should provide more support to Asia to help settle the financial markets.
Mr. Greenspan's testimony supported a widespread view on Wall Street that the Federal Reserve was almost certain to leave interest rates unchanged at its next meeting on Nov. 12, and probably at the following meeting on Dec. 16.
However, the Fed could be caught in an uncomfortable situation if economic statistics over the next week and a half show the economy growing at a rapid pace and unemployment declining sharply. The Government's first estimate of growth in third-quarter gross domestic product will be issued on Friday. The unemployment report for October will be released a week later.
But a report from the Labor Department on Tuesday showed few signs that wage increases were accelerating, and a summary of conditions around the country released by the Fed today concluded that prices and wages were relatively stable.
Even if new economic reports showed some tentative evidence of inflation, analysts said, the Fed would err on the side of keeping the markets calm and avoid raising rates at least until early next year.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Remarks by Greenspan Soothe Shaken Markets
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, tried to calm nervous financial markets by suggesting that the recent turmoil in stocks was a healthy reality check that had lowered prices and could help repress inflation.
Mr. Greenspan's assessment during Congressional testimony was well received in the markets, which viewed it as powerful evidence that the Fed would not raise interest rates at a November meeting. Page A1. 

Bonds rallied on Mr. Greenspan's remarks, pushing the 30-year Treasury yield down to 6.20 percent from 6.28. D8.
 
Business Agreements With China
At the summit meeting in Washington, China agreed to buy $3 billion worth of aircraft from Boeing and to make concessions that clear the way for American companies to bid on commercial nuclear power contracts in China that are potentially worth $60 billion. A1.
 
Waste Management Chief Quits
The chief executive of Waste Management, Ronald T. LeMay, quit, the second chief to leave the troubled trash hauling company in nine months. Mr. LeMay will return to Sprint, which he left in July. D4.
 
Silicon Graphics in Shake-Up
Silicon Graphics said that its chairman and chief executive, Edward R. McCracken, would step down as chief executive as soon as a successor could be found. The company, which had surprised Wall Street by announcing a widening of its quarterly loss, also said it would cut 700 to 1,000 jobs. D6.
 
Reports Show Growth Easing
More evidence of steady or slower growth emerged when the Commerce Department said orders for durable goods fell in September for the first time in three months, and a Fed regional survey showed no sign of inflationary price or wage pressures. D4.
 
Two Regional Retailers to Join
Proffitts, a regional department store company, said it would buy Carson Pirie Scott, another retailer, for about $790 million, creating the fourth-largest department store chain. Carson stock soared. D2.
 
Viacom Operating Profit Falls
Viacom's quarterly profit from continuing operations slid 83 percent as problems at the Blockbuster video chain offset higher earnings at the MTV and Nickelodeon cable channels. Analysts had predicted a loss, though only after the company had warned them that their expectations were too high. D11.
 
New Approach to Fighting Fraud
Federal regulators are turning up the heat on some of Wall Street's biggest firms, which process the trades of smaller operations, in an effort to prevent some small firms from defrauding investors who trade in the stocks of tiny companies. D6.
 
PNC Seen Buying Stake in Broker
PNC Bank is buying 4.9 percent of Friedman, Billings, Ramsey, an institutional brokerage firm, for about $45 million, people involved with the negotiations said. The firm is also arranging to sell a further 17.3 percent of its stock in an initial public offering. D6.
 
Columbia/HCA Earnings Fall
Columbia/HCA Healthcare said that its earnings had dropped significantly in the third quarter, in the wake of a widespread criminal investigation of some of the company's business practices. D4.
 
Mercedes Moves to Fix Problem
Mercedes-Benz said that it would spend $57 million a year to install electronic equipment on its new A-class subcompact cars to correct a design problem that caused one of the cars to flip during a sharp turn in a test. D7.

HEADLINE: THE 1997 ELECTIONS: THE FACTS;
Both Sides Manipulate Data to Fit

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

 BODY:
In last night's final debate of the mayoral campaign, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Ruth W. Messinger showed off the wiles of political oratory, the timeless art of trying to pummel an opponent with facts that have been stripped of their contexts, nuances and caveats.
Ms. Messinger, for example, proclaimed twice in the debate that Mr. Giuliani had cut $6 billion from education, as she has said repeatedly during the campaign. She left the impression that the budget for the Board of Education is now $6 billion less than it was when Mr. Giuliani became Mayor. In truth, education spending has increased during the Mayor's tenure. 
 The $6 billion refers to requests by the Board of Education for new money that Mr. Giuliani rejected, rather than a cut in money already allocated. About $4.7 billion of the money would have been used for school construction and repairs over several years. The board had said it wanted the money to respond to many needs, including soaring enrollment. Ms. Messinger has argued that in spurning the request, the Mayor showed he did not care about the public schools.
Mr. Giuliani said, early in his tenure, that the board was doing a poor job of managing the school system, so new money might have been wasted. Either way, the $6 billion is a cut in the projected growth of spending, not in money that the city had already distributed.
The Mayor responded to Ms. Messinger's attack last night by saying that spending per pupil was now at the highest level ever. But that does not take inflation into account. A study by the city's Independent Budget Office found that overall spending per pupil by the Board of Education has actually declined over the last decade when adjusted for inflation, largely because spending has not kept pace with enrollment, which has been increasing by nearly 20,000 students a year.
Mr. Giuliani said he had added 88,000 classroom seats to the school system during his tenure, and promised to add more in a second term. But the Mayor's aides have acknowledged that many of the new seats added over the last four years were planned under his predecessor, Mayor David N. Dinkins.
In discussing the economy, Ms. Messinger said, "60 percent of the jobs that have been created in this city have gone to people who live outside this city." She was apparently basing that statement on an August report by City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi. But her assertion is not supported by the report, which says that while suburban residents got more jobs in one period -- the first half of 1997 -- city residents generally have received more jobs during the rest of the Mayor's tenure.
Toward the end of the debate, Ms. Messinger said Mr. Giuliani's re-election campaign had refused to return $1 million in illegal campaign contributions until the city's Campaign Finance Board threatened sanctions. While the Mayor's campaign has returned that money, it gave back much of it before the board said it would impose penalties.

HEADLINE: PRO BASKETBALL;
Female Refs Say They Owe Their Jobs to Their Ability

BYLINE: By MIKE WISE 

 BODY:
First, there was Commissioner David Stern sending accusations at the players association's executive director, Billy Hunter. Then there were two female officials on the cusp of making history.
Only labor peace and gender equity were at stake yesterday in the National Basketball Association. 
 While Stern and Hunter engaged in a skirmish over the concerns of marijuana use in the league, Violet Palmer and Dee Kantner granted the only interviews they plan to during their careers as officials.
The two women were mostly candid about their appointment by the N.B.A. to referee games during the 1997-98 season. Their assignments over the weekend will mark the first time female referees have officiated in America's four major professional sports leagues.
"I'm not worried about a pat on the behind," Kantner said, laughing. "As long it's in the context of the game, those things don't bother me."
Ask about curbing the behavior of irascible players like Charles Barkley, Dennis Rodman and Anthony Mason, Palmer added, "We'll treat them like any other players."
"Confrontation is part of being a referee," she said. "If they cross a line, they'll be assessed a technical foul."
Kantner, 37, and Palmer, 33, have worked preseason games for the last two years for the N.B.A. Both have extensive officiating experience and both shot down the notion they were merely politically correct pawns for the league.
"I think I speak for Dee when I say that we were selected on our ability," Palmer said.
Kantner labeled reports of sexism and criticism by current players "sensationalism," and insisted she had had nothing but positive responses to her work so far. "Now, I'm not Pollyanna in thinking that nothing is going to happen, but I haven't had a problem to date that I've been concerned about."
To accept the positions, Kantner resigned her job as a sales engineer in North Carolina and Palmer resigned her position as a recreation director in Southern California. In keeping with the secrecy policy involving officials, neither the league nor the women would disclose where they will work their first games this weekend.
They were guarded regarding their roles in breaking another barrier in American sport, preferring instead to view themselves as two qualified individuals intent on working at the game's highest level.
"I don't think Violet or I could ever say we would be trailblazers when we started out," Kantner said. "We're both a little awed by the attention. But if one of the after-effects of this is that it helps open up more doors, we're both all for it."
Meanwhile, in an early afternoon conference call, Stern warned of the potentially contentious give-and-take that may take place between the owners and the players over the next year. But in the end, the commissioner said, the two sides would eventually break bread together with the intent of preserving labor peace.
Given yesterday's skirmish, they have a long way to go.
Within hours after Stern criticized the players association for its refusal to address the league's concern over marijuana use, Hunter fired off a scathing statement aimed at Stern's "misrepresentation of the issue."
Stern was responding to an article in The New York Times last Sunday regarding use of marijuana by players, with some estimates as high as 70 percent. The league's current drug policy includes testing for cocaine and heroin, but it does not include marijuana.
Saying the players association was only interested in discussing the issue if economic concessions were involved, Stern said he was puzzled at Hunter's apathy.
"This was not about punishment and exclusion," Stern said. "We're dumbfounded by the approach. We'd like to cut down the use of marijuana, educate and identify the problem. But apparently Mr. Hunter has a different agenda."
In his statement, however, Hunter outlined the highlights of the league's most recent proposal to the players, a 41-page document that he said includes punishment and exclusion. Accusing Stern of trying "to sway public opinion and to gain an edge in upcoming collective bargaining negotiations," Hunter disputed the commissioner's position.
According to Hunter, the most recent proposal calls for a five-game suspension if a player tests positive, pleads guilty or is convicted of a marijuana offense. The N.B.A. seeks an automatic six-month suspension in the event of a second offense. If a player distributes marijuana, the league calls for a lifetime ban.
"To accuse us of stonewalling is false and self-serving," Hunter said in the statement. "If the commissioner is really interested in advising and educating our players, then we invite him to engage in more than rhetoric."
More propaganda will spew forth from both sides over the next few months, all of which may have serious ramifications on the prospective re-opening of the collective bargaining agreement in April. The owners have the right to open the agreement and begin negotiating a new one.

HEADLINE: THE MARKET TURMOIL: THE TRADING;
Stocks Mixed As Volatility Seems to Ease

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
A day after one of the biggest stock market rallies in history, and two days after one of the biggest selloffs, Wall Street calmed down a bit yesterday, ending with mixed results despite continued heavy trading volume.
In fact, it was the first time in a week that the stock market did not rise or fall sharply, a hint that the economic turbulence that has rattled markets from Thailand to Tokyo, and all the way to New York, might be subsiding, and that investor fears might have eased somewhat. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average gained a scant 8.35 points, to close at 7,506.67. Broader indexes were mixed. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 2.69 points, to 919.16, while the Russell 2000 index of smaller company issues had solid gains.
Trading activity, however, was extremely heavy on the New York Stock Exchange, where more than 777 million shares traded hands. It was the second-busiest day in history, after the 1.2 billion shares traded Tuesday, testing the technology might of Wall Street brokerage firms and exchanges, and causing delays at many discount brokerage firms.
And today, Asian markets resumed their slide, hurt in part by a drop in the December futures contract for the Standard & Poor's 500 index, which trades around the clock. Still, in afternoon trading the losses were much less severe than those earlier this week.
In late afternoon trading in Toyko, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 452.44 points, or 2.68 percent, at 16,404.60. The Nikkei surged 3.34 percent yesterday. Hong Kong's main stock index was down 6.7 percent at the midday break in trading today. Hong Kong stocks rose 18.82 percent yesterday.
Yesterday's gains around the world gave some investors hope that the economic crisis that is gripping much of Southeast Asia will not topple the bull markets in other, more prosperous, regions.
Investors might have also been soothed yesterday by remarks from Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, who told Congress that the economy continues to perform impressively. He added that the recent stock market selloff might later come to be viewed as a "salutary event," if it helps keep the economy in balance with more modest growth.
Some of the world's stock markets, however, continue to be clouded by uncertainty about whether the crisis in Southeast Asia might spread to other parts of the globe. Yesterday, several markets in Latin America continued to slide; in Brazil, the main stock index was down 6 percent, and in Argentina, one of the main indexes fell 3.5 percent.
And despite the rebound in the United States, the Dow is still down 7 percent in a week, and analysts said it would be some time before investors felt confident enough to bid prices up to the level they were at in August, when the Dow reached its peak of 8,259.31.
Some lingering uncertainty was evident yesterday, analysts said, as the Dow and other major indexes, though ending close to where they started the day, fluctuated wildly. Early in the day, the Dow was up 120 points; but by midafternoon it had fallen into losing territory, before closing with the slight gain.
"It's almost as though we've had a violent storm, and investors are just coming up from their storm shelters," said Hugh Johnson, a market analyst at the First Albany Corporation. "There's still a great deal of uncertainty about what the past week has meant."
Through all the recent turmoil, though, financial advisers and analysts continue to reassure investors that the American economy is healthy, corporate profits are strong, inflation is not a threat and interest rates are stable.
In fact, almost immediately after Monday's 554-point plunge in the Dow -- a drop that forced the Big Board to halt trading twice -- Wall Street analysts were mobilizing to contain what some feared could turn into a panic.
Abby Joseph Cohen, the bullish strategist at Goldman, Sachs & Company, announced that the firm was increasing its exposure to stocks. "Recent stock price declines have been more of a market event than an economic event," she said.
Others, like Edward Kerschner, the chief investment strategist at Paine Webber, insist that the troubles in Asia are not going to cut sharply into corporate profits in the United States and that investors should focus on their long-term objectives.
Mr. Kerschner contends that there is little risk in the United States market, and that the currency and economic crisis in Southeast Asia will not have a "material impact on corporate profits," because Asia does not account for a large enough share of United States profits.
Indeed, few people on Wall Street say that they think a crisis is at hand. There is some disagreement about how much of an impact the problems in Asia might have on American companies, but few see the end of the great bull run.
And other analysts said they had a sense, from Main Street and Wall Street, that the huge bout of selling that saw the Dow lose 900 points in four sessions through Monday, had subsided.
"The panic is over for now," said Eric Miller, chief investment strategist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. "But instead of a broad upsweep, we might just see a stutter-step market."
Following that pattern, technology stocks sold off on Monday, rocketed ahead of the pack on Tuesday, and then surrendered again to heavy selling yesterday.
Many small stocks gained yesterday, however. The market's flat performance might have obscured the fact that the buying was actually broader than it was on Tuesday, when the Dow leaped 337 points. Nearly two stocks gained for every one that lost ground on the Big Board, and smaller investors, like Donald Kelley, a retired engineer, jumped back into the market.
"I took a heck of a beating on Monday," said the 65-year-old Mr. Kelley, who lives in Florissant, Mo. "But I recouped half of it Tuesday."
The gyrations notwithstanding, Mr. Kelley -- who says he lost his job about six years ago -- has never looked back. "I was an engineer until they downsized me," he said. "I wasn't happy at the time, but they did me a favor because it gave me more time to watch my investments."
