PUB-DATE: October 30, 1997

SECTION: Section A; Page 20; Column 1; Foreign Desk 

LENGTH: 3866 words

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN WASHINGTON;
Clinton and Jiang in Their Own Words: Sharing a Broad Agenda

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from a joint news conference today by President Clinton and President Jiang Zemin of China, as transcribed by the Federal News Service, a private transcription company. Mr. Jiang's remarks are through an interpreter unless otherwise indicated.
 
OPENING STATEMENTS
MR. CLINTON: Good afternoon. Mr. President, let me again say how pleased we are to welcome the leader of a great people with a remarkable civilization, history and culture, a people now with its focus on the future. Your visit gives us the opportunity and the responsibility to build a future that is more secure, more peaceful, more prosperous for both our people. To that end, I am pleased that we have agreed to regular summit meetings. I look forward to visiting China next year. . . . 
 We also have agreed to high-level dialogues between our Cabinet officials on a full range of security matters. And we will connect a presidential hot line to make it easier for us to confer at a moment's notice.
China and the United States share a profound interest in a stable, prosperous, open Asia. We've worked well together in convincing North Korea to end its dangerous nuclear program. Today President Jiang and I agreed we will urge Pyongyang to take part in four-party peace talks with South Korea. We also agreed to strengthen contacts between our militaries, including through a maritime agreement, to decrease the chances of miscalculation and increase America's ties to a new generation of China's military leaders.
A key to Asia's stability is a peaceful and prosperous relationship between the People's Republic of China and Taiwan. I reiterated America's long-standing commitment to a one-China policy. . . .
I told President Jiang that we hoped the People's Republic and Taiwan would resume a constructive cross-strait dialogue and expand cross-strait exchanges. Ultimately, the relationship between the P.R.C. and Taiwan is for the Chinese themselves to determine, peacefully.
President Jiang and I agreed that the United States and China share a strong interest in stopping the spread of weapons of mass destruction and other sophisticated weaponry in unstable regions and rogue states; notably, Iran. I welcome the steps China has taken and the clear assurances it has given today to help prevent the proliferation of nuclear weapons and related technology.
On the basis of these steps and assurances, I agreed to move ahead with the U.S.-China agreement for cooperation concerning the peaceful uses of nuclear energy. It will allow our companies to apply for licenses to sell equipment to Chinese nuclear power plants subject to U.S. monitoring. . . .
In both China and the United States, trade has been a critical catalyst for growth. China is the fastest-growing market in the world for our goods and services. Tomorrow, Boeing will sign a contract for the largest sale of airplanes to China in history: 50 jets valued at $3 billion. This contract will support tens of thousands of American jobs and provide China with a modern fleet of passenger planes.
Still, access to China's market remains restricted for many American goods and services. Just as China can compete freely and fairly in America, so our goods and services should be able to compete freely and fairly in China. The United States will do everything possible to bring China into the World Trade Organization as soon as possible, provided China improves access to its market. . . .
This is a broad agenda in which China and the United States share important interests that we can best advance by working together. But we also have fundamental differences, especially concerning human rights and religious freedom. I am convinced the best way to address them is directly and personally, as we did yesterday and today, and as we will continue to do until this issue is no longer before us. . . .
MR. JIANG: Ladies and gentlemen, a while ago I had an in-depth exchange of views with President Clinton on China-U.S. relations and of international and regional issues of mutual interest. The meeting was constructive and fruitful. President Clinton and I have agreed on identifying the goals for the development of a China-U.S. relationship oriented toward the 21st century. The two sides believe that efforts to realize this goal will promote the fundamental interests of the two peoples and the noble cause of world peace and development.
We both agree that our two countries share extensive common interests in important matters bearing on the survival and development of mankind, such as peace and development, economic cooperation and trade, the prevention of the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction, and environment protection. Both sides are of the view that it is imperative to handle China-U.S. relations and properly address our differences in accordance with the principles of mutual respect, noninterference in each other's internal affairs, equality and mutual benefit; and seeking common ground, while putting aside differences. . . .
 
QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS
Q. President Jiang, for the past few years you have reiterated once and again that we need to take a long-term perspective and we should view China-U.S. relations from the perspective of the 21st century. Therefore, Mr. President, what measures will the Chinese Government make, and how can a sound and stable relationship between China and the United States be brought into the 21st century?
MR. JIANG: Your question reminded me of the first meeting that President Clinton and I had in Seattle when we agreed that we need to work to bring a world of prosperity, stability and peace into the 21st century.
The meeting that I had with President Clinton during my current trip to the United States was the fifth one that we had with one another. However, my visit is the first by a Chinese head of state to the United States in 12 years. And this shows that both sides are working together in taking many specific measures to achieve this goal. . . . There are a lot of works from ancient Chinese literature and culture describing the view that one should scale a great height in order to have a grander sight. And the development of modern science and technology also told us that if you have a greater height, you can see farther into the long distance. . . .
Q. We are told that you have asked even last night for the release of some political dissidents and the Chinese have not done so. Is it acceptable for China to refuse even such a modest gesture?
MR. CLINTON: Well, first of all, we had a long discussion about human rights. We discussed a lot of issues related to human rights, every conceivable aspect of it. And we have profound disagreements there. But that does not mean that this visit should not have occurred or that we don't have a big interest in continuing to work together.
After all, this interest that we have in working with China relates to the fact that we have common values and common interests related to preserving peace, to growing the economy, to stopping the spread of dangerous weapons. We have an agreement to fight narco-trafficking. We have an agreement to work together on the terrific environmental challenges we face right across the board. And so I think that you have to see this meeting in the context of that. But you shouldn't in any way minimize the steep differences that still remain between us over that issue.
Q. I'm with the People's Daily. I have a question for your Excellency, President Jiang Zemin. Why is the Taiwan issue the core issue in China-U.S. relations?
MR. JIANG: The three Sino-U.S. joint communiques all covered the question of Taiwan because this question is involving the sovereignty of the People's Republic of China. The late Mr. Deng Xiaoping proposed the system of "one country, two systems" for the settlement of the Taiwan question and for the accomplishment of peaceful reunification of China, and this is the only correct policy.
However, we also are saying that we do not commit to renounce the use of force, but this is not directed at the compatriots in Taiwan but rather at the external forces attempting to interfere in China's internal affairs and at those who are attempting to achieve separation of the country or the independence of Taiwan.
I am very happy that I discussed this issue in clear-cut terms with President Clinton during my current trip, as we have done in our previous meetings. And I believe the joint statement that the two sides are going to release will also carry explicit explanations on the Taiwan issue.
Q. Mr. President -- a question actually for both Presidents. The shootings in Tiananmen Square were a turning point in U.S.-Chinese relations and caused many Americans to view China as a repressive country that crushes human rights. President Jiang, do you have an you have any regrets about Tiananmen? And, President Clinton, are you prepared to lift any of the Tiananmen sanctions? And if not, why not?
MR. JIANG: The political disturbance that occurred at the turn of spring and summer in 1989 seriously disrupted social stability and jeopardized state security. Therefore, the Chinese Government had to take necessary measures according to law to quickly resolve the matter to insure that our country enjoys stability and that our reform and opening up proceed smoothly. The Communist Party of China and the Chinese Government have long drawn the correct conclusion on this political disturbance. And facts have also proved that if a country with an over 1.2 billion population does not enjoy social and political stability, it cannot possibly have the situation of reform and opening up that we are having today. . . .
MR. CLINTON: To answer your question, first on the general point, I think it should be obvious to everyone that we have a very different view of the meaning of the events at Tiananmen Square. I believe that what happened and the aftermath and the continuing reluctance to tolerate political dissent has kept China from politically developing the level of support in the rest of the world that otherwise would have been developed. I also believe, as I said in my opening statement, that over the long-run, the societies of the 21st century that will do best will be those that are drawing their stability from their differences; that out of this whole harmony of different views there is a coherence of loyalty to the nation. Because everyone has their say, it enables people to accept, for example, the results of the elections that they don't agree with. And so we have a different view.
The depth of the view in the United States, I think, is nowhere better exemplified than in the so-called Tiananmen sanctions. We are the only nation the world, as far as I know, that still has sanctions on the books as a result of the events of eight years ago.
Now, you ask a specific question. Our agreement on nuclear proliferation issues allows me to lift the sanction on peaceful nuclear cooperation. It is the right thing to do for America. This is a good agreement. It furthers our national security interests. China is to be complimented for participating in it. And the decision is the right one.
The other sanctions, which cover a range of issues, from OPIC loans to crime control equipment and many things in between, under our law have to be reviewed on a case-by-case basis. So as a result of our meeting today, the only Tiananmen Square sanction which is being lifted is the one on peaceful nuclear cooperation, and it is a good thing for America, a good thing for China. And I applaud the Chinese side for the work they have done with us on this specific nuclear issue. It's a substantial step forward for us.
MR. JIANG: I would like to speak a few words in addition to this question. Our two countries have different geographical locations, and we are also thousands of miles apart geographically. We also have different historic and cultural traditions, different level of economic development and different values. Therefore, I believe it is just natural for our two countries to hold different views on some issues.
Now people in the world are standing at the turn of the century, when we're going to bring in the 21st century, and science and technology have developed significantly as compared with, for instance, the period when Newton lived. And I also believe that the world we are living in is a rich and diverse one; and therefore, the concepts on democracy, on human rights and on freedoms are relative and specific ones, and they are to be determined by the specific national situation of different countries. And I am also strongly of the view that, on such issues as the human rights issue, discussion can be held on the basis of noninterference in the internal affairs of a country. And it goes without saying that, as for the general rules universally abided by in the world, China also abides by these rules. . . .
Naturally, I am also aware that, in the United States, different views can be expressed, and this is a reflection of democracy. And therefore I would like to quote a Chinese saying which goes, "Seeing it once is better than hearing about it 100 times." I have also got my real understanding about this during my current trip. However, I don't believe this will have any negative impact on our efforts to approach each other.
MR. CLINTON: Let me -- I just have to say one other thing. First of all, the United States recognizes that on so many issues China is on the right side of history. And we welcome it. But on this issue we believe the policy of the government is on the wrong side of history. There is, after all, now a universal declaration of human rights.
The second point I'd like to make is that I can only speak from our experience. And America has problems of its own which I have frankly acknowledged. But in our country I think it would amaze many of our Chinese guests to see some of the things that have been written and said about me -- -- my family -- -- our Government, our policies. . . .
And yet after all this time I'm still standing here, and our country is stronger than it was before those words were uttered six years ago. . . .
Q. Mr. President, I have a question for both President Jiang and President Clinton.
President Clinton, you stated your position with regard to Taiwan, that this is a question for the Chinese people to resolve. But we all understand you have brokered peace in Bosnia, in the Middle East. Do you see any role for the United States to play in the securing of a permanent peaceful environment in the Taiwan Strait? . . .
My question to President Jiang is about the cross-strait dialogue. President Clinton said that he has urged President Jiang to resume the interrupted dialogue. I wonder if President Jiang will respond positively and take some measures to resume the dialogue as soon as possible.
MR. CLINTON: Well, first of all, I think the most important thing the United States can do to facilitate a peaceful resolution of the differences is to adhere strictly to the one-China policy we have agreed on; to make it clear that within the context of that one-China policy, as articulated in the communiques and our own laws, we will maintain friendly, open relations with the people of Taiwan and China, but that we understand that this issue has to be resolved and resolved peacefully, and that if it is resolved in a satisfactory way, consistent with statements made in the past, then Asia will be stronger and more stable and more prosperous. That is good for the United States, and our own relations with China will move onto another stage of success.
I think the more we can encourage that, the better off we are. But I think in the end, since so much investment and contact has gone on in the last few years between Taiwan and China, I think the Chinese people know how to resolve this when the time is right. And we just have to keep saying we hope the time will be right as soon as possible. Sooner is better than later. . . .
MR. JIANG: To answer your question in rather brief terms, all in all, our policy is one of peaceful reunification and one-country/two-systems. And as for more detailed elaboration on that, a few years ago, I made my eight-point proposal along that line, and at the just-concluded 15th national congress of the Chinese Communist Party, I also delivered a report which gave a rather comprehensive elaboration on this. Therefore, I will not repeat them here. . . .
Q. Mr. President, could you elaborate a little bit more on your decision to approve these reactor -- or to permit reactor sales? It's certainly something that raised concerns by some members of Congress. And also, could you just describe what kind of commitments you've received from China? Are they actually written?
MR. CLINTON: Well, let me say, first of all, I am completely convinced that the agreements we have reached are sufficiently specific and clear that the requirements of the law will be met and that the national security of the United States will be advanced, and that we will have greater success in our global efforts to keep nuclear technology and other dangerous weapons from falling into the wrong hands, as a result of the agreement we have made with China. . . .
Q. Mr. President, the United States and China are inevitably big powers in the Pacific. Are you comfortable with the size of America's military presence in Asia? I'd also like to ask President Jiang if he would view a reduction of American troops in the region as a step towards improving relations.
MR. CLINTON: The question you ask of me, the answer is simple. It's yes. I believe that our presence in the Pacific, where everyone knows we have no territorial or other destructive ambitions, is a stabilizing factor. And it will lead us to greater partnerships in meeting common security threats in the years ahead. . . .
Q. . . . Yesterday Beijing has announced its invitation for Russian President Boris Yeltsin to visit Beijing. And today the heads of state of China and the United States have announced here in the United States to establish a constructive and strategic partnership between China and the United States. Therefore, I would like to have your comment -- the two Presidents -- your perception concerning the triangular relationship between China, the United States and Russia.
MR. JIANG: I don't see much contradiction in this aspect, for I am coming here to the United States this time at the invitation of President Clinton for what is our fifth meeting with one another, and therefore, we are already old friends. And so am I with President Yeltsin with Russia. And I still remember that in the spring of 1995, the three of us met in Moscow. Therefore, I don't see much contradiction in this regard. And we should all commit ourselves to building a peaceful and beautiful new century.
MR. CLINTON: During the cold war, we were all three suspicious of each other and we tried to play each other off against the other. So when Russia fought with China -- argued with China, we were very happy.
Today we must look to the future. Russia has a strong democracy. Its economy is coming back. We are working with Russia in Bosnia and in other places around the world. In land mass, it is the largest country in the world; it is a rich country. It is a European country and an Asian country. And both China and the United States should have good relations with Russia, and then the three of us should work together on matters of common concern. This is not the cold war. We need to be looking to the future and a different set of relations.
Q. Mr. President, and Mr. President, I wonder if you specifically had a chance to raise the cases of the two leading political dissidents in China -- Wang Dan and Wei Jingsheng -- with President Jiang and ask for their release?
And to President Jiang, why not simply release these political prisoners? And also, why not allow greater religious freedom in Tibet, which has become such an emotional issue here in the United States as well?
MR. CLINTON: First, as Mr. Berger I think has already told you, my answer to that question is, I discussed every aspect of this issue in great detail.
MR. JIANG: To be frank with you, President Clinton discussed all these relevant issues with me. And I just want to state here that I am the President of the People's Republic of China, not the chief judge of the Supreme Court of China. And as for the issues such as the one concerning Wei Jingsheng, this involves China's criminal law and will be resolved gradually according to the legal procedure by the court of China.
As for the issue concerning religion in Tibet, in China people have the freedom to exercise their different religious beliefs. However, on this question I believe religious freedom in Tibet and the evaluation of criminal law are issues within different framework. . . .
Q. My question is for President Clinton. In China, sometimes we are confused by American policy to China. We know there are sections in Congress which are friendly to China. So, as President, how do you coordinate the unbalance to have a unified policy to China? Is there any elements to damage effective Sino-U.S. relationship?
MR. CLINTON: Well, let me say -- make a general point first. It is very important that we understand each other so that if we have a difference, it's a real difference and not a misunderstanding. Therefore, in dealing with the United States, unless there is some clear signal to the contrary, you should assume that a statement by the president, the vice president, the secretary of State, the secretary of Defense, the secretary of the Treasury, the National Security Adviser, the Trade Ambassador -- the people in our direct line of authority, they represent our policy.
We need the support of important people in Congress, and much of the leadership does support this administration's China policy. But I think it would be a mistake to think that the United States has no unified China policy because individuals or groups in the Congress disagree with it. We do have a lot of disagreement; we have had for eight years now -- ever since 1989. Until we resolve all these issues, in that sense our relations will never be fully normal, but we have to keep pushing forward. . . .
Q. My question is for President Jiang. . . . Officials in the delegation have suggested that the protesters who have protested Chinese policies in Tibet, are in many cases, young people, students who have been misguided and misinformed by a Hollywood-led campaign. Sir, if that is so, and if we take to heart your old Chinese saying that "seeing once is worth hearing a hundred times," would you be willing to invite either a senior delegation from the United States Congress or a group of international journalists to travel to Tibet and to see for themselves?
(Interpreter, in Chinese, says "travel to China" instead of "travel to Tibet," and members of audience say "to Tibet.")
MR. JIANG: I do indeed -- would like to welcome more people to go to Tibet and see with their own eyes.

PUB-DATE: October 30, 1997

SECTION: Section B; Page 10; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 1227 words

HEADLINE: THE 1997 ELECTIONS: THE ISSUES;
Mayor Has Helped Stabilize the Budget, but Avoided a Promised Overhaul

SERIES: RACE FOR CITY HALL: The Incumbent's Record

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

 BODY:
When Rudolph W. Giuliani was a candidate in 1993, he pledged to take a scalpel to New York City's budget, cutting spending, taxes and the work force, all in a crusade to end chronic deficits and rouse a local economy that had been thrashed by the recession. He vowed, in short, to administer a dose of hard-nosed fiscal conservatism to one of the most expansive governments in the nation.
Four years later, the city's economy is rebounding from its prolonged slump and its budget is sturdier than at any time in nearly a decade. Throughout his re-election campaign, Mr. Giuliani has said that his policies helped lead to a net gain of more than 170,000 private-sector jobs in the city. He says he guided municipal finances through a difficult period of retrenchment without harming essential services or laying off city workers. 
 Mr. Giuliani notes often that he pushed through cuts in taxes on hotel rooms, commercial rents, small-business earnings, the sale of some clothing, and co-ops and condominiums. And he speaks of his efforts to reduce what he terms another kind of tax: the extra costs that businesses have had to shoulder because the garbage hauling industry, the Fulton Fish Market and other wholesale markets were long dominated by organized crime. His administration has helped to break up these cartels.
Yet, despite all that, the Mayor has not always achieved his goals. Though he has trimmed some programs, the city's spending has actually increased. In his first year, he pushed through an aggressive plan to cut the budget and the city work force, but since then, he has scaled back, arguing that the city could take only so much austerity.
In general, he has shied away from the far-reaching overhaul of the budget that he promised, failing to cure many of the city's long-term financial ills, including the persistent budget gaps that he had said he would eliminate.
The current budget is stable because soaring profits on Wall Street have sent a torrent of taxes into the city treasury, but that good fortune has masked the city's continuing inability to deal with a longstanding problem: its expenses are rising faster than its revenues.
Mr. Giuliani has cut the number of city employees paid for with city revenues by about 20,000, to roughly 200,000, largely through an innovative severance program. But that is less than the reduction of 35,000 that he promised as a candidate four years ago. He has not shown much stomach for paring labor costs, the largest component of the budget, by adopting the kind of privatization and productivity measures that he once supported and that other cities have embraced -- initiatives that would have forced a politically exacting confrontation with the powerful municipal unions.
While the economy has improved, the net gain in private-sector jobs has still not made up for a drop of 342,000 private-sector jobs in the recession that began in the late 1980's. Most other large cities recovered the jobs they lost in the recession years ago. And over the last year, New York City's unemployment rate has remained at more than 9 percent, nearly double the national average and among the highest rates of any major city in the country.
"There are still fundamental weaknesses throughout New York City's economy," said Robert A. Kurtter, a senior vice president at Moody's Investors Service, a leading bond-rating concern.
Mr. Giuliani maintains that the city was in such bad fiscal condition when he became Mayor that he could not accomplish all he wanted in just one term. He said he gets carping from both sides, some saying he cut too much, destroying the city's social fabric, while others say he cut too little and is letting the government stay a drag on the local economy.
"You've got to live in the world of the realistic," Mr. Giuliani said in an interview. He later added: "I understand, the monitors always want more. But I have to be ultimately responsible for balancing the budget of the city. Which means how much can you do this year, without threatening public safety, schools, health."
While Mr. Giuliani takes credit for the growth in private-sector jobs during his tenure, few economists believe that a mayor has much direct impact on the local economy, which is more tied to national and, increasingly, international trends. For example, the city has been steadily losing manufacturing jobs in recent decades as factories decamp for places with cheaper labor, transportation and other costs, and it would be extremely difficult for any mayor to forestall that.
But some economists praise Mr. Giuliani for improving the business climate by working to reduce crime, lowering business taxes, cracking down on organized crime and seeking to make his administration more receptive to the concerns of business than its predecessors.
"The things that do come under his control that have been drag on the economy in the past, he has lessened them," said Rae D. Rosen, a senior economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
Using what power he has to preserve and generate jobs in private industries, the Mayor has handed out more than $650 million in tax breaks and other incentives to big corporations that threaten to leave the city. He defends the policy as clearly to the city's benefit, saying that the companies receiving the inducements give far more back in taxes. But his critics deride the spending as wasteful and say Mr. Giuliani should have concentrated more on helping medium-size and small businesses.
The Mayor has much more control over the city's own spending, and he can shape the budget to minimize the effect of economic downturns or benefit from upswings. Mr. Giuliani often contends, for example, that if the city's spending had increased at the same rate over the last four years that it did during the administration of Mayor David N. Dinkins, all the extra taxes generated by Wall Street in the last year would have been spent and there would not have been a $1.4 billion surplus at the end of 1997 fiscal year in June.
And he says that after pushing through three austere budgets, he remained disciplined and did not sharply increase city spending when tax revenues from Wall Street began soaring last year -- though he did allocate more money for some programs, particularly at the Board of Education, trying to bolster his record on education, which Democrats had repeatedly attacked.
By some gauges, the Mayor has not made much progress in solving the city's financial problems. The city's long-term debt has risen during his term; nearly 20 percent of the city budget now goes toward paying off principal and interest. And the city's bond rating is still low.
Some experts say that despite Mr. Giuliani's assertions that the city's fiscal health has improved, large budget gaps projected for comong fiscal years underscore how the Mayor has not brought about the sweeping reforms he vowed.
"He gave up on reinventing government," said Raymond D. Horton, president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a watchdog group financed by businesses. "He has basically frozen the existing way of doing things. That doesn't mean that he hasn't done some good things with respect to some services. But as to his general approach to re-engineering or restructuring government, he has been very much in the tradition of his predecessors."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Williams Rates Best in the A.L. For Outfielders

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
While the Yankees' center fielder emerged yesterday as the top-ranked outfielder in the American League, the center fielder of the archrival Baltimore Orioles emerged as one of the top rank of free agents the Yankees covet.
The annual ranking statistics that were released yesterday show that Bernie Williams is No. 1, ahead of Ken Griffey Jr., the player many consider baseball's best. A day earlier, the Yankees registered their interest in the sixth-ranked outfielder, Brady Anderson. 
 Bob Watson, the Yankees' general manager, declined to comment on the team's initial pursuit of Anderson, but Jeff Borris, who represents him, confirmed that the Yankees were one of many teams to call since Anderson declared his free agency Monday.
Economic competition for Anderson would mark the start of a third successive off season of free-agent battles between the Orioles and the Yankees. Two winters ago, the teams played a game of can-you-top-this as the signing of a free agent by one team prompted the signing of another free agent by the other team. Last winter, the Orioles signed the Yankees' Jimmy Key, and then the Yankees signed the Orioles' David Wells.
Adding Anderson to their lineup would not only give the Yankees a potent leadoff hitter, which they have lacked, but it would also deprive the Orioles of a player who has been integral to their recent success. To join the Yankees, though, Anderson would have to move to left field, at least as long as Williams is around.
"We didn't talk about Bernie or where Brady would play," Borris said. "He likes center field; he'd prefer center. But I don't think he'd have any problem playing left."
Borris said he was surprised that Anderson has reached this juncture with the Orioles.
"Baltimore has made several offers since August a year ago, but nothing came close to reflecting the current market," Borris said by telephone from his office in Beverly Hills, Calif.
Borris recalled that the Orioles signed Cal Ripken Jr. and Mike Mussina to contract extensions early in the season, and he said he expected that Anderson would be next. But it never happened. The Orioles last offered about $5.5 million a year for four years, but Anderson reportedly wanted closer to $8 million a year.
However, his production this year plunged. In 1996, he hit 50 home runs and drove in 110 runs. This year he hit 18 home runs and knocked in 73 runs.
The Yankees, meanwhile, didn't need the news of Williams's place in the rankings because they already face a difficult task in signing him to a multiyear contract and to keep him from becoming a free agent after next season. Williams has risen steadily in the rankings, from seventh to fourth a year ago, then to No. 1 this year.
With the rankings by positions based on two years worth of five offensive statistics, Williams had a 5.4 average rank in those categories to a 6.0 average for Griffey. Williams ranked 10th in home runs among 84 outfielders to first for Griffey, but Griffey was hurt by his being 13th in batting average to 5th for Williams and 12th in on-base percentage to 6th for Williams.
Mariano Rivera, the Yankees' closer, was No. 1 among American League relief pitchers. Seattle had two top-ranked players, shortstop Alex Rodriguez and designated hitter Edgar Martinez. Other A.L. players ranked No. 1 were catcher Ivan Rodriguez of Texas, first baseman Frank Thomas of Chicago, second baseman Chuck Knoblauch of Minnesota, third baseman Matt Williams of Cleveland and the starting pitcher Pat Hentgen of Toronto.
Andy Pettitte placed second to Hentgen, and Derek Jeter was third behind Rodriguez and Jay Bell of Kansas City.
Top-ranked players in the National League were Jeff Bagwell of Houston at first, Craig Biggio of Houston at second, Barry Larkin of Cincinnati at shortstop, Ken Caminiti of San Diego at third, Barry Bonds of San Francisco in the outfield, Mike Piazza of Los Angeles at catcher, John Smoltz of Atlanta the starting pitcher and Trevor Hoffman of San Diego the relief pitcher.
 
INSIDE PITCH
TIM RAINES, whose contract option was not exercised by the Yankees, was one of 14 players who filed for free agency yesterday. Others joining him were DENNIS ECKERSLEY of St. Louis, HAROLD BAINES of Baltimore, CHILI DAVIS of Kansas City, OREL HERSHISER of Cleveland and JOSE VIZCAINO of San Francisco.

SECTION: Section B; Page 1; Column 2; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 3508 words

HEADLINE: THE 1997 ELECTIONS: PROFILE -- Politics as Lifelong Passion;
McGreevey of New Jersey Is a Relentless Competitor

SERIES: RACE FOR GOVERNOR: The Democrat -- Second of three profiles.

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

 BODY:
He used to shed his suits on weekends, strap a canoe to his car and head to the Delaware River, where a gentle landscape and the company of friends distracted James Edward McGreevey, ever so briefly, from his ambitions.
But even on the river, Mr. McGreevey could not allow himself to float. If there were two canoes, friends recall, he would insist on racing for hours at a stretch. He would study the route like a textbook, craning his neck to assess every bend as his fellow canoers fought the urge to toss him overboard. 
 "Jim would be all worked up, shouting, looking down the river far enough to know when we would really need to push," said James Kennedy, a close friend of Mr. McGreevey's. "I can remember my arms burning like crazy and me thinking, 'Why are we doing this?' "
He no longer makes time for canoeing, but Mr. McGreevey, the Democratic gubernatorial candidate in New Jersey, continues to approach every project -- and he makes sure there are always several lined up -- with manic energy and a will to conquer. The people who know him best say these qualities, combined with his "hey, guys" schmoozy personality, explain why he has never lost an election -- he is a state senator and the Mayor of Woodbridge -- and never faces a day without a plan.
His critics say the source of Mr. McGreevey's energy is implacable political ambition that makes him seem eerily hollow at times. They say that while Mr. McGreevey can charm and connect with people from all social strata, he lacks convictions and a coherent vision.
"I couldn't tell you what his guiding political philosophy is, and I don't think he could, either," said David Bixel, Mr. McGreevey's history teacher at St. Joseph's High School in Metuchen, who has followed his student's career. "I would have to say at this juncture he seems more guided by his ambition."
But friends and family members say Mr. McGreevey is driven by a lifelong devotion to public service that overshadows every other aspect of his life. It is why he collected three academic degrees in seven years, became a state official at 28 and began running for office at 32, they say. Mr. McGreevey himself says it was his preoccupation with politics that sent his wife, Kari, back to her native Canada with their daughter in 1995, after four years of marriage.
"I know no one who gets such personal satisfaction from his career choice as Jim does," said James Burns, a lawyer who grew up around the corner from Mr. McGreevey in Carteret. "It's not driven by greed or any of the things that would otherwise motivate people. Jim is driven by a very internal, personal thing."
Mr. McGreevey's father, a former drill instructor in the Marines, taught his young son a mantra that stuck: Plan your work and work your plan. With those words in mind, Mr. McGreevey mapped out a route that included law school, a stint in the Middlesex County prosecutor's office and two years as a staff lawyer for the Assembly Democrats in Trenton, where he made sure people remembered his name.
"McGreevey would be all over the legislative chamber, making friends and shaking hands," said Alan Karcher, who hired Mr. McGreevey to work in his office when he was Speaker of the Assembly in 1983. "He was ubiquitous."
Mr. McGreevey was also eager to advance, snatching up an offer to run the New Jersey Parole Board when he was 28. Two years later, in 1987, he became a lobbyist for Merck & Company, focusing on state regulatory issues for the pharmaceutical company. Mr. McGreevey says he took the job not so much to influence policy as to gain insights into corporate culture.
"Merck taught me some very valuable, lasting lessons, lessons that can be transferred to the public sector," he said in an interview. "Principled objectives. Clarity of expectations."
Encouraged by politicians he had befriended earlier in his career, Mr. McGreevey ran for the State Assembly in 1989. But when it came time for re-election, voters were angry about Gov. Jim Florio's $2.8 billion tax increase, and Mr. McGreevey, whose legislative district had been redrawn, would have faced a veteran Democrat in the primary. He relinquished his Assembly seat and ran for mayor in Woodbridge instead.
The race pitted Mr. McGreevey against Mayor Joseph DeMarino, who had helped introduce Mr. McGreevey to politics in Middlesex County and even invited him for weekends at his vacation home in the Poconos. Mr. DeMarino had been indicted on bribery charges in early 1991, and Mr. McGreevey decided to run against him in the primary. When Mr. DeMarino lost the primary, he declared himself an independent and stayed in the race. Mr. McGreevey won the general election as well. His detractors describe his challenging Mr. DeMarino, who was acquitted before Election Day, as a betrayal.
"It was a bloodbath that brought McGreevey to power," said Robert F. Gawroniak, a former Democratic councilman in Woodbridge. "He didn't have any loyalty to the people who helped him in the beginning."
Others say Mr. McGreevey was courageous to challenge a popular and powerful mayor, driven by a desire to end mismanagement and waste in Woodbridge, the fifth largest town in New Jersey. Many residents say he has succeeded, using the management skills he learned at Merck to make the town government more productive and efficient, even as he has continued seeking other offices. (Mr. McGreevey ran for the State Senate in 1993 and began planning his gubernatorial campaign in 1996.)
"I think he is a good, straightforward, honest politician," said Anthony Smith, 56, a resident of Woodbridge for 18 years. "He's a go-getter who wants to straighten things out."
 
Short Hair and Long Hours
The Dutiful Son, The Good Student
To anyone who will listen, Mr. McGreevey says he wants nothing more than to help working-class people like his own parents, Jack and Veronica McGreevey, who moved from Jersey City to a small split-level house in Carteret when their only son was 3. Growing up within earshot of the New Jersey Turnpike, Mr. McGreevey watched his father work doggedly as a traveling salesman for a trucking company. Carteret, then home to Irish, Italian and Polish families that had moved from New York and Jersey City, was full of factories, where many of the residents worked by day, and union halls, where they gathered by night.
Mr. McGreevey's parents were not involved in politics, but they made a point of knowing all their neighbors on Stima Avenue and fellow parishioners at St. Joseph's, the largest Roman Catholic church in town. They lived down the street from Thomas Deverin, the longtime Democratic Mayor of Carteret, who became one of Mr. McGreevey's political champions.
By the early 1970's, Mr. McGreevey was heading down the turnpike every day to the more affluent town of Metuchen, where he attended St. Joseph's High School. Many of the teachers at St. Joseph's then were involved in the antiwar movement. At times, Mr. McGreevey said in an interview, their message contrasted with the values he had learned from his father, whose brother, Mr. McGreevey's namesake, had died at Iwo Jima. Although the Vietnam War had ended when he left high school in 1975, Mr. McGreevey said he would have joined the Marines if his father had not insisted he attend college.
"It was like, you know, America right or wrong," Mr. McGreevey said. "Particularly regarding Vietnam."
It was not clear then that Mr. McGreevey was destined for a career in politics, Mr. Bixel and other teachers said. But he studied hard, and while many of his classmates grew their hair and dressed sloppily, he kept his dark curls short and wore ties.
"It was a tough period in terms of the confrontational behavior from students who were questioning authority," said Jerry Rabadeau, Mr. McGreevey's economics teacher at St. Joseph's. "But he didn't see the institutions as being a threat to him. He saw himself as part of the institution."
Mr. Bixel remembered Mr. McGreevey as a student who constantly challenged his teachers' positions.
"Almost on a daily basis he would say to me, 'I feel like you're bombarding us with liberal Democratic politics,' " Mr. Bixel recalled. "As a 16-year-old young man, he was certainly following the beliefs of his parents."
As the oldest child -- he has two younger sisters, Carolyn and Sharon -- Mr. McGreevey was eager to please his parents, who called him "our lad of great expectations" from the time he could walk. He learned to swim at the Rahway Y.M.C.A. when he was in fifth grade, and later became a lifeguard and took charge of the weekend swimming program. At St. Joseph's, he joined the debate team, the school spirit committee, the German Club and the yearbook staff.
Jack McGreevey said that as a teen-ager, his son rebelled not by smoking cigarettes, but by insisting that his father stop smoking 10 cigars a day.
"We worked at raising that kid," the elder Mr. McGreevey said. "He never got into pot, he never got into anything. My point is, the kid was always very good."
In 1975, Mr. McGreevey enrolled at Columbia University, where he majored in political science and spent most of his time studying in the library. Asked what he liked best about his college years, Mr. McGreevey did not reminisce about friendships kindled in smoky bars, raucous fraternity parties or pranks played on roommates. Instead, he reeled off courses: Ancient Civilization. The American Presidency. Chinese History.
"All I did in college, literally, was just work," he said during an interview in his campaign van, absently eating french fries he had just bought. "Columbia was a blur of studying. Hard work. Always focused."
He finished college in three years to save money, then enrolled at Georgetown University Law School in 1978. As a law student, he worked at the National Institute for Trial Advocacy and in the civil tax division of the Justice Department. His schedule was so busy that rather than take his white shirts to the cleaners, he waited until holidays and lugged piles of them home for his mother to wash. But Charles Lizza, a classmate, said Mr. McGreevey was not too busy to be a regular at an Irish pub frequented by politicians on Capitol Hill, where he would drink Guinness and chat with the person next to him.
"He could be as comfortable in that environment, sitting at the bar, as he was talking to a law professor," said Mr. Lizza, now a lawyer in Newark. "He is forthcoming and earnest with people of every social stature."
Mr. McGreevey went on to get a master's degree in education from Harvard University before returning to New Jersey in 1982. He worked for the Middlesex County Prosecutor before Mayor Deverin of Carteret, his neighbor, recommended him for the job in the Assembly Speaker's office. Mr. Karcher, his boss there, recalled Mr. McGreevey as a "charming Irish kid" with an obsessive interest in government. Not yet 30, he was already working 14-hour days and occasionally sleeping in the office, Mr. Karcher said.
Mr. Karcher and others who have known Mr. McGreevey for years say his refusal to slow down and take notice of the world outside politics frustrates them. John J. Fay Jr., a former state senator from Woodbridge who is one of Mr. McGreevey's closest advisers, said he only occasionally convinces Mr. McGreevey to see a movie -- the last one they saw together was "Braveheart" -- or take a day off.
Mr. Karcher, too, said he wished Mr. McGreevey would take more advantage of cultural offerings. "Jim and I are different in one important way," Mr. Karcher said. "I tried my very best never to allow politics to become my whole life. This is the only thing I find disappointing. He said his favorite radio station was CBS News Radio. I mean, Jim, please, tune into WQXR."
But the people who might be expected to fret the most about Mr. McGreevey's workaholic tendencies, his parents, have no such concern. It is easy to see why. They travel the state as volunteers for his campaign, giving speeches to veterans and residents of retirement communities and rarely getting home before 10 P.M. When a reporter asked whether his son should learn to relax, Jack McGreevey narrowed his eyes.
"A little hard work never hurt anyone, my dear lady," he said.
 
Love and Loss
A Marriage Broken On Rocks of Politics
He rarely takes vacations, but once, in 1990, Mr. McGreevey spent a week on a cruise ship. Another passenger was Kari Schutz, a librarian from Vancouver with a soft voice and a shy smile. To hear him tell it, Mr. McGreevey was smitten. He married her a year later in a small ceremony near her home.
"I was in love with her from the moment I met her," Mr. McGreevey said, talking briefly about his wife after the second gubernatorial debate in Whippany. "She's the only woman I've ever wanted to marry."
Mr. McGreevey brought his bride home to his condominium in the Iselin section of Woodbridge, and as both were adjusting to married life, he dove into his mayoral campaign. Their daughter Morag -- her name is a Gaelic form of Mary -- was born in 1992, at the beginning of Mr. McGreevey's term. By the time she was 1, Mr. McGreevey was running for office again.
"When you're in politics as deeply as he is, you're out every night," said Mr. Gawroniak, the former Woodbridge Councilman. "I recall the girl coming into Council chambers during meetings, holding her baby. He would swoop over there and the cameras would follow. They were such an attractive couple. It seemed like she was in love."
But before long, Kari McGreevey decided she could not brook the political life. Friends of the couple say she was also homesick and worried about her mother, who was ill. She took Morag home to Vancouver in 1995 and never came back. In the divorce papers she filed that year, she accused Mr. McGreevey of being too politically ambitious to be a good husband and father.
He has said that the only significant other in his life these days is "the undecided voter."
Mr. McGreevey has been reluctant to talk about the breakup, saying only that politics played a role. Mrs. McGreevey has been even more tight-lipped, declining all requests for interviews.
But in the final weeks of the campaign, Mr. McGreevey had a change of heart. After the debate in Whippany, he dialed his wife's number on his cellular phone and asked her, coaxingly, to speak with a reporter. He supervised the three-minute conversation, whispering, "What's she saying?" and shouting, "Tell her what a good husband I am!"
Speaking softly, Mrs. McGreevey said her husband was "a good father" who was "very interested in Morag." When they lived together, she said, he cooked vegetables for dinner and scrubbed the kitchen floor. Asked which of Mr. McGreevey's qualities she most admired, Mrs. McGreevey paused.
"His honesty," she said. "He's extremely intelligent. He has a wonderful, warm personality, and he can handle so many situations so efficiently. He's able to delegate."
Asked why she abandoned the marriage, Mrs. McGreevey paused again.
"The life style," she said. "It's all-consuming. Very, very demanding. If you haven't lived it, you wouldn't even know. Jim thrives on it."
Both have denied that there was any reason other than politics for the breakup.
Mrs. McGreevey said she was especially disturbed by an incident during Mr. McGreevey's Senate campaign in 1993, when the Republican State Committee mailed out fliers with a picture of what appeared to be Mr. McGreevey's car parked in front of adult book and video shops near Times Square. "Mr. McGreevey was caught with his government-owned car enjoying himself in Manhattan," the flier read.
The Republicans later admitted the picture was a fake, but that was cold comfort to Kari McGreevey.
"I had a small child," she said. "Stressful isn't even the right word."
After allowing a few minutes of awkward conversation, Mr. McGreevey motioned that it was time to hang up. As his aides hovered, Mr. McGreevey himself reflected on the breakup.
"It was a rough life style for her," he said. "Kari was raised in a much more gentle, civil and polite environment."
Haltingly, Mr. McGreevey said he still loved his wife, calling her "a magnificent woman" who "loves me for who I am and not what position I hold." Asked if they might reconcile, he stared at the floor for several long moments.
"Time will tell," he said.
 
Political Workaholic
The Public Life Is a 24-Hour Job
To meet Mr. McGreevey is to think you know him well. He bestows nicknames on total strangers, throwing an arm around them as if he was their oldest chum. With elderly people he is a jokey Boy Scout, and with children, a sprightly coach. At a Pentecostal church in Irvington, he is "Brother McGreevey," rocking to the music and shouting, "Amen!" At a union meeting in Jersey City, he is pumping his fist and shouting, "Aaaaaaaaay!" In other settings, Italian, Spanish and Yiddish phrases roll easily off his tongue.
Yet few people have been allowed to know his innermost thoughts. In interviews and on the campaign trail, he gives summaries of his upbringing, interests and relationships, providing minimal detail. On a ride from Newark to Cherry Hill earlier this month, his answers to personal questions were predictably brief.
How did he like living in Washington during his law school years?
"Obviously, you know," Mr. McGreevey replied. "The Washington Post. Politics. It was a great opportunity."
When he calls his daughter on the phone, what do they talk about?
"School," he said. "She just won a slice of pizza because of how many books she's read."
His favorite books are political biographies and Tom Clancy novels. He runs and lifts weights at a health club in Woodbridge, listens to Andrew Lloyd Webber musicals on his tape deck and eats vegetables, soup and Italian food. Pictures of Robert F. Kennedy line his mayoral office, where the book collection includes Thomas Merton's "No Man Is an Island," Dale Carnegie's "How to Enjoy Your Life and Your Job" and Stephen Covey's "Seven Habits of Highly Effective People."
By most accounts, Mayor McGreevey cleaned up a mismanaged government and brought in a more businesslike approach. He imposed fees for some services and created an economic development corporation that he said has brought 1,800 jobs to town. He also borrowed $34.6 million to stabilize finances, but has held the property tax rate to a few cents above what it was in 1990.
As a state legislator, he sponsored the Pollution Prevention Act, which has helped reduce toxic emissions, as well as a law that requires insurance companies to provide coverage for mammograms. As an assemblyman, Mr. McGreevey voted for Governor Florio's $2.8 billion tax increase in 1991. But later, as a senator, he supported most of Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's income tax cuts.
Mr. McGreevey's employees describe him as a demanding, controlling boss who is good-humored until he catches someone shirking or making mistakes. He works late into the night at City Hall in Woodbridge, responds personally to citizen complaints and sends city officials to management seminars run by Mr. Covey, whose books Mr. McGreevey devours.
"Jim doesn't tolerate inefficient thinking," said Jody Massimino, Mr. McGreevey's legislative aide. "There's no lollygagging with Jim."
Mr. Gawroniak, the former Woodbridge Councilman, said Mr. McGreevey used to display his temper when other town officials challenged him in meetings. "He just goes ballistic," Mr. Gawroniak said. "He shouts and screams and jumps up and down."
But Mr. McGreevey's friends describe a warm, funny man who likes to dance, takes them on whirlwind trips to Washington and plays hide-and-seek with their children. Ms. Massimino said Mr. McGreevey shepherded her son through the college admissions process. Mr. Kennedy, who is the Mayor of Rahway, said Mr. McGreevey paid him a surprise visit one recent night, after a long day of campaigning, because he had heard his friend was "stressed out."
"It was 11 P.M. and there was Jim, giving me advice on how to relax," Mr. Kennedy said.
Late-night calls and visits to friends are Mr. McGreevey's way of countering stress and getting feedback on his campaign, which friends say he craves. "Last night he called at midnight, wanting to know how we thought the fund-raiser went," said Mr. Kennedy's wife, Lori. "He'll always ask, 'How do you like my commercials? How do you think I'm doing?' "
Even his closest friends acknowledge that most of the time, Mr. McGreevey acts like a man possessed. But to suggest there is something unseemly about the way he conducts his life is to hold him to a different standard from other dedicated politicians, they say. Is Governor Whitman so different, they ask? Is President Clinton?
"I'm not sure there's something wrong with a man who's going to be the governor not devoting 100 percent of his talent and time to being a politician," said Mr. Deverin, Mr. McGreevey's mentor from Carteret. "You've got to give 100 percent, in heart and in mind."

GRAPHIC: Photos: James E. McGreevey, the Democratic candidate for governor of New Jersey, working the crowd, left, during last month's Labor Day parade in South Plainfield. (Norman Y. Lono for The New York Times); Above, a family portrait of Jack and Veronica McGreevey with their children James and Carolyn, made about 1960. (pg. B1); James E. McGreevey in the 1974 St. Joseph's High School yearbook. Mr. McGreevey working out on a weight machine at the Club in Woodbridge this month. Co-workers describe him as a demanding, controlling but good-humored boss. LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Biography; Series

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (94%); 

STATE: NEW JERSEY, USA (94%);

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN WASHINGTON: THE IMPLICATIONS;
A Yield of Little More Than 'Normalization' of Abnormal Relations

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29

 BODY:
The Chinese hailed today's summit meeting as a "normalization of relations" between Washington and Beijing, but in fact it indicated how abnormal the relationship remains. Hot lines and reciprocal summitry, however useful, inevitably evoke memories of the cold war and United States-Soviet relations, which were anything but normal.
But managing United States relations with China -- arguably the most important relationship of the post-cold-war world -- will require a more subtle, less Manichean cast of mind than the cold war did. Then, most elements of American society were on the same page. Now they are not, with business pushing for freer trade, trade unionists complaining about unfair competition from cheap goods, and members of Congress and churchmen stressing human rights. 
 And all the while, more Americans, perhaps needing one, are coming to regard China as an adversary, if not in political at least in economic terms. In a new Gallup poll taken for CNN and USA Today, 36 percent said they regarded China as unfriendly or an outright enemy. In 1983, before Tiananmen Square, the figure was 21 percent.
In a news conference with President Jiang Zemin of China this afternoon, an event that lasted more than an hour, President Clinton never once described anything that had happened during the Chinese leader's visit to the United States this week as "historic."
For the usually ebullient Mr. Clinton, who often points with pride to landmarks and milestones and political breakthroughs, it was a telling omission that epitomized the difficulty of relations between Beijing and Washington. If he seemed muted, an American official said, it was because the negotiations before and during this summit conference, the first of its type in a decade, have been marked by "ask-no-quarter, give-no-quarter bargaining."
The official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said that "after days and days and days, we have found it difficult to have even the most basic kinds of discussions with China," except for an important agreement on the first export to China of advanced American nuclear technology.
On the crucial question of human rights, the two leaders might as well have been on different planets. Top American negotiators had tried to convince Mr. Jiang at least to express remorse for the deaths of demonstrators in Tiananmen Square in 1989, even if he was unwilling to say the decision to open fire was wrong.
When Mr. Jiang did not do so, and instead said at the news conference that the Chinese Government had "drawn the correct conclusion" and moved swiftly to insure stability, and when he said blandly that "it is just natural for our two countries to hold different views on some issues," Mr. Clinton had no choice, his aides said, but to respond bluntly. He did so, asserting that the shootings and "the continuing reluctance to tolerate political dissent" had kept China from developing a significant level of support in the world.
It was a stark admission of failure, unusual in summit annals.
The plain fact is that in Chinese-American relations many of the most important questions are not susceptible of solution by top political leaders, or they are susceptible of solution only by running greater risks than the politicians are willing to accept. Most of the progress that has been made, and it is limited, has been made by businessmen and only ratified later by governments, like the big deal under which Boeing will sell 50 jetliners to China.
"In many senses," Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin told American executives in Beijing last month, "you have invested in this relationship more fully than we have in Washington." And today Mr. Clinton gave a certain primacy to economics when he was asked why the United States did not try to broker an agreement between China and Taiwan, as it had sought to do in Bosnia and the Middle East.
"Since so much investment and contact has gone on in the last few years between Taiwan and China, I think the Chinese people know how to resolve this when the time is right," he said, taking the ball from the hands of the diplomats and putting it squarely in the hands of business.
Except in Washington, where such events always matter more than they do in the country at large, the spotlight has been stolen from the summit conference by the gyrations of Wall Street, gyrations that had their origin in Southeast Asia and in China's new special administrative zone, Hong Kong.
Only 15 years ago, Americans and their Government felt powerless to stop the march of the Asian economies, and they feared the loss of jobs and control of American financial markets. Now they feel powerless to halt the rot in the Asian economies, and they still fear the loss of jobs and control of American financial markets.
When cracks began to appear in the "tiger economies" of Southeast Asia some months ago, the Administration decided not to attempt any bailout of the type used successfully during the Mexican crisis of 1994-95. Mr. Rubin has said repeatedly that the United States must not allow itself to be seen as the world's banker of last resort, ready to step into every financial crisis everywhere. To do so, he has contended, would spawn more crises.
Even after Monday's plunge in stock prices on Wall Street, there was more talk than action in Washington. That brought criticism from some experts on the region, including a former ambassador, a Democrat, who described the failure to intervene as "a craven and ultimately damaging approach."
Ultimately, government has to try in some areas, no matter what the problems, because there are a number of things that business cannot or will not do. Human rights are one subject to which business executives are averse. Nor can they negotiate trade agreements, so the Clinton Administration has put a huge effort into finding some way to to integrate China into the world economy and into making it possible for Beijing to join the World Trade Organization.
But no headway at all was reported after this summit meeting on that difficult subject, either.
The best the two leaders and their associates could do was concentrate on process, agreeing to meet regularly and to set up a communications link. Mr. Clinton agreed to visit China next spring. Mr. Rubin and Zhu Rongji, China's economic czar, agreed to talk about instability in financial markets.
There was also talk of "a constructive strategic partnership," but precious little flesh was put onto those bare rhetorical bones, beyond some generalized talk about dealing with continued instability on the Korean peninsula and some significant progress in coping with the touchy problem of nuclear proliferation.

HEADLINE: Papers Link Donations to 2 On Senate Hearings Panel

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29

 BODY:
Documents released by Senate investigators today identified 20 donors to a private conservative organization that worked outside the normal political channels in ways that benefited conservative Republicans, including two members of the Senate committee investigating campaign finances.
One beneficiary was Senator Don Nickles, an Oklahoma Republican who as a member of the Governmental Affairs Committee has been trying to persuade the Senate leadership to end the hearings that have proceeded for almost four months under the direction of Senator Fred Thompson, Republican of Tennessee. 
 Another committee member who benefited from the organization's activities was Senator Sam Brownback, Republican of Kansas.
Senator Nickles appeared in marketing advertisements for the organization, Triad Management Services, a consulting group that helped conservative donors make contributions outside the purview of Federal election laws. Mr. Nickles's political action committee received tens of thousands of dollars in donations in 1996 from some of Triad's biggest donors.
In Mr. Brownback's 1996 Senate race, a last-minute $400,000 television advertising blitz was paid for by Triad donors. These advertisements appeared in the closing weeks of the election and attacked his Democratic opponent as an out-of-state liberal.
Besides raising money from conservative donors and funneling it to Republican candidates, Triad also raised money for two affiliated nonprofit groups that ran advertisements attacking Democratic candidates. Such groups have been criticized as thinly disguised fronts for partisan political activities, purporting to be issue oriented but often supporting individual candidates and their campaigns.
Triad has been highlighted repeatedly by advocates of campaign finance reform as an example of how loopholes in the law allow donors and candidates to exceed limits on donations and avoid having their names linked directly with specific candidates. Federal campaign law prohibits individuals from giving more than $2,000 in a campaign cycle. There is no such limit on donations to nonprofit groups like Triad.
Hearings had been scheduled for this week before the Governmental Affairs Committee into Triad's campaign activities, but Republicans on the committee canceled them after Democratic members of the committee obtained names earlier this week of Triad's donors.
The documents being circulated today also indicate that Mr. Brownback benefited beyond the advantage he received from the attack advertisements. His father- and mother-in-law, John and Ruth Stauffer, were able to donate more than $32,500 to him through several conservative political action committees that worked closely with Triad and steered the Stauffers' donations back to Mr. Brownback's campaign, according to Federal Election Commission records.
A spokesman for Mr. Nickles denied today that the Senator's desire to end the hearings was tied to his relationship with Triad.
"Senator Nickles has all along thought the hearings should not be a mile wide and an inch deep," said Brook Simmons, Mr. Nickles's spokesman. "With regard to Triad, this is just a desperate attempt by the Democratic National Committee to draw attention away from their own serious misdeeds."
The documents, obtained from Congressional investigators, show that the biggest Triad donor is the Cone family of Pennsylvania, which runs a company that manufacturers children's clothes. Robert Cone and his brother Edward, according to bank documents, donated around $1.1 million to Triad and two affiliated nonprofit groups that sponsored the attack advertisements for the Brownback campaign.
The family, which declined comment, also gave $10,500 to Mr. Nickles's political action committee, the Republican Majority Fund.
Another donor being examined by the committee is Koch Industries, an oil company in Wichita, Kan., and the nation's second-largest privately held company. The documents show that it gave $2,000 directly to Triad. But Senate investigators say they believe Koch Industries supports the Economic Education Trust, based in Twin Falls, Idaho, which gave $1.3 million to Triad in 1996.
Jay Rosser, a spokesman for Koch Industries, declined to comment on any relationship with Triad or the trust.
Mr. Nickles has received large campaign contributions from Koch Industries over the years. In 1989, Mr. Nickles defended the company in Congress against allegations that the oil refiner had been illegally taking oil from the Osage Indian reservation and from Federal property. A grand jury investigation cleared the company, although a Senate study concluded that Koch Industries had short-changed the tribe.
Other big Triad donors include Foster Friess, a Jackson, Wyo., money manager, who donated $25,000. Mr. Friess is a major Republican donor who gave $260,000 to two campaign committees headed by Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York.
Bruce Benson, the 1994 Republican candidate for Colorado governor, gave Triad $25,000. Mr. Benson said he believed the donation was for a good cause.
"These candidates needed our support and I trust the money went to do a good job," he said.
