HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN WASHINGTON: THE OVERVIEW;
U.S. and China Reach Trade Pacts but Clash on Rights

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29

 BODY:
President Clinton and the Chinese President, Jiang Zemin, engaged in a day of unexpectedly contentious talks today that produced several significant commercial agreements but appeared to broaden the gulf between the two powers on human rights.
China agreed to buy $3 billion worth of American civilian airplanes and to make concessions that clear the way for Americans to compete to sell nuclear reactors to China. 
 The concession, announced by President Clinton, was that China would abandon its nuclear cooperation program with Iran, which United States officials suspect was a cover for the development of nuclear weapons. China's assurances will permit American companies to bid on commercial nuclear power contracts in China that are potentially worth $60 billion.
The agreements came after Mr. Jiang, leading an aggressive Chinese delegation that refused to follow the script written for the summit meeting, tried but failed to win concessions on trade from the American side. Even though he did not get all he wanted, Mr. Jiang will leave Washington on Thursday with his stature as a global leader enhanced.
But when he goes to New York on Thursday, Mr. Jiang can expect a chilly reception instead of the warm official handshakes that have greeted him on the first three stops. Neither Governor George E. Pataki nor Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani plans to greet him on his arrival or to attend a dinner reception for him Friday at the Waldorf-Astoria. Page B1.
American officials hailed the business accords as the product of a successful policy of "constructive engagement" with Beijing.
But if the summit meeting was good for commerce, it did little to assuage American concerns about political and religious rights in China. Mr. Jiang stood beside Mr. Clinton at a joint news conference this afternoon and forcefully defended China's preference for order over personal freedom, even when the result is the abridgement of individual rights.
The Chinese President emphasized the mutual economic benefits of the relationship between the two countries and tried to minimize the "noises" he heard from rights protesters gathered in Lafayette Park, across from the White House.
"President Clinton and I share the view that China and the United States enjoy a high degree of complementarity and a huge potential for cooperation in the economic and trade fields," he said.
But Mr. Clinton insisted that the China could not expect to prosper while suppressing freedom. He said the United States and China had "profound disagreements" on Beijing's treatment of its citizens even as it sought to broaden the two countries' business ties.
"The American people greatly admire China's extraordinary economic transformation, and we understand the importance that your own experiences and your present challenges lead you to place upon maintaining stability," he said. "But we also believe that China will enjoy more growth and more stability as it embraces more fully the political as well as the economic aspirations of all your people."
Later, at a state dinner at the White House, the two Presidents kept their respective tones as they exchanged toasts. Acknowledging Mr. Jiang's interest in American history, President Clinton said: "Long before the United States was even born, China was a stronghold of creativity, knowledge and wealth." Many of China's earliest contributions, Mr. Clinton went on, "still enrich our lives today."
Mr. Jiang said, "Differences that cannot be resolved for the time being can be put aside while concentrating on seeking common ground." The countries' joint interests in peace, security and prosperity outweigh their differences, he said.
At the earlier press conference, Mr. Clinton offered an unusual defense of freedom of speech in the United States. "In our country I think it would amaze many of our Chinese guests to see some of the things that have been written and said about me -- my family -- our Government, our policies. And yet after all this time I'm still standing here, and our country is stronger than it was before those words were uttered six years ago."
Then Mr. Clinton turned and amended his statement: "Excuse me. Before those words began to be said six years ago. They're still being said every day."
Mr. Jiang, clearly relishing the international spotlight that the Washington summit meeting brought him, told a global television audience that a country of 1.2 billion could not progress toward economic reform and renewal without "social and political stability."
"The concepts on democracy, on human rights and on freedoms are relative and specific ones, and they are to be determined by the specific national situation of different countries," Mr. Jiang said.
He offered no apologies for the brutal suppression of pro-democracy demonstrators in Tiananmen Square in 1989 or for his country's continued jailing of dissidents today. And he warned Mr. Clinton against interfering in China's internal affairs.
Mr. Clinton, responding to Mr. Jiang in a moment of drama that defined the distance between the United States and China on the fundamental question of human rights, declared the Chinese Government to be "on the wrong side of history" in its response to the Tiananmen demonstrations and in its approach to personal liberties.
"I believe that what happened and the aftermath and the continuing reluctance to tolerate political dissent has kept China from politically developing the level of support in the rest of the world that otherwise would have been developed," Mr. Clinton said.
The exchange encapsulated a two-day meeting designed to move Washington and Beijing toward warmer relations and more regular contacts. But three-and-a-half hours of face-to-face talks between the two leaders did not appear to bring the two significantly closer.
At other times during the news conference, Mr. Clinton and Mr. Jiang appeared to be talking past each other, addressing skeptical domestic constituencies rather than each other.
Mr. Jiang was asked if he would release two prominent political prisoners, Wang Dan and Wei Jingsheng. Mr. Jiang replied peremptorily, "I am the president of the People's Republic of China, not the chief judge of the Supreme Court of China."
Samuel R. Berger, the White House national security adviser, called the news conference at the conclusion of the two leaders' meetings "an extraordinary event" that could never have occurred in China.
"I don't suspect that President Jiang has ever been subjected to a press conference like that," Mr. Berger said. "I think that's good and I think that's healthy."
Senior American officials said that the Chinese negotiated very aggressively over the last three days. Officials who attended the meetings said that while the Chinese were tough and at times intransigent, the summit talks brought a new level of candor to the relationship that had not been present in four previous meetings between Mr. Clinton and Mr. Jiang.
"There has been an evolution from their first, highly scripted meeting in Seattle in 1993," this official said. "Jiang is much more willing to leave his talking points to speak clearly and directly. There was a forthrightness about these discussion that allows us to do problem-solving at these meetings, rather than just reading notes at each other."
Although the leaders were not asked about allegations now being investigated in Congress that China funneled illegal campaign contributions into last year's election, Mr. Clinton did raise the issue in private, Mr. Berger said. He said that Mr. Jiang had repeated what he has said on the subject several times before, that China had not engaged in illegal activity but that he would cooperate with American investigators.
Despite the frost at the summit talks, there were propitious winds on trade and business development, although they come at a price of tolerating China's present tariff structure and its human rights record.
Mr. Clinton said he would lift a 12-year ban the sale of American nuclear technology to China, an action long sought by American corporations avidly eyeing the estimated $60 billion Chinese market for civilian nuclear power plants. The move, which has fostered protests in Congress, requires Mr. Clinton to certify that China has ceased supplying technology that could be used for nuclear weapons development to Iran and other countries.
Officials said that China has provided written assurances that it will engage in no further nuclear cooperation with Iran, and will end two existing contracts. The Administration said it will make the classified agreement with China available to members of Congress.
Mr. Clinton, anticipating criticism on the nuclear deal, called the agreement a "win-win-win" for the United States. "It serves America's national security, environmental and economic interests," he said.
Mr. Jiang announced that China would accede to the Information Technology Agreement signed last winter, which will eliminate China's steep tariffs on imported computer and telecommunications equipment.
The leaders also announced a contract for the sale to China of 50 Boeing jetliners worth $3 billion.
But Mr. Clinton rejected one Chinese request -- that the United States make a firm commitment to helping China join the World Trade Organization by the end of 1998. Chinese officials pointed out that the United States made a similar agreement with Russia for its entry into the trade organziation. Mr. Clinton said he would do "everything possible" to bring China into the organization, but he would not ask the organization to bend its rules on tariffs and trade barriers to ease China's entry.
The summit meeting produced a number of lesser accords, including a commitment to high-level visits on economic, security, environmental and law-enforcement issues. The United States will open an office of the Drug Enforcement Agency in Beijing and send lawyers and jurists to China to consult on development of civil and criminal justice systems.
Mr. Clinton announced that he would visit China in the second half of next year, the first American President to do so since President George Bush's trip in 1989 before the Tiananmen Square bloodbath.
China and the United States -- the world's two largest producers of greenhouse gases -- agreed to cooperate on finding a workable solution to the problem of global warming. American companies will be given access to Chinese markets to build cleaner power plants, more efficient cars and rural power stations.
The Administration's hope had been that the summit talks would be marked by significant advances in the economic arena, where the United States and China have historically made the greatest progress. But today's results, officials conceded, were disappointing.
"The general tone was intransigence," one senior Administration official said. "Friendly, cooperative-sounding intransigence."
There were some areas the two sides could boast about. The order for Boeing was significantly larger than most officials here anticipated: 50 planes for $3 billion instead of 30 planes for $2 billion. And China abandoned its opposition to joining the Information Technology Agreement, which reduces tariffs on computer and other information-technology products to zero within the next seven years. That affects about $1.8 billion in American exports to China, and is a fast-growing sector of trade.
Mr. Clinton and Mr. Jiang twice touched on the financial turmoil in Asia, and Mr. Jiang went to some lengths to argue that the underlying condition of Hong Kong is solid. At Mr. Clinton's suggestion, the two men agreed that Mr. Rubin and Zhu Rongji, China's chief economic official, should work together to "promote financial stability in Asia." But Treasury officials said that there was not yet a concrete plan for accomplishing that goal.

HEADLINE: For China's Visiting President, Forecast in New York Is Chilly

BYLINE: By JANE H. LII 

 BODY:
Instead of the 21-gun salutes and warm official handshakes that have greeted him so far on his state visit, President Jiang Zemin of China can expect a chilly reception in New York this evening. Neither Governor George E. Pataki nor Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani plans to greet him on his arrival or to attend a reception for him at the Waldorf-Astoria tomorrow evening.
And to the dismay of some local Chinese leaders, Mr. Jiang is offering what some see as a slight of his own: he plans to avoid any visits to the Chinese communities in the city, among the largest Chinese outposts in the country. Although the Chinese have established other communities on the West Coast, Chinatown, in lower Manhattan, is still considered by many to be the political and economic center for new immigrants. 
 The situation reflects the sensitive political geography of New York's diverse Chinese community. While the old, predominantly Cantonese power structure of Chinatown has been overwhelmingly pro-Taiwan, a flood of newcomers from Fujian province in southern China has profoundly altered both the balance of power and the sentiment toward the mainland. While many of the Fujianese ask for political asylum on arrival, they nonetheless remain loyal to China and champion Chinese causes.
Although business interest is the primary reason for Mr. Jiang's visit, human rights seem to be at the core of both scheduling issues. Aides to the Governor and the Mayor say they wish to avoid any appearance that they condone China's imprisonment of political dissidents. And even a warm welcome for the Chinese leader in Chinatown would give human rights protesters another opportunity to embarrass him. Protests have been staged in Washington and human rights activists have vowed to follow him in New York and in Boston.
For weeks, Mr. Jiang's visit has dominated conversation and news coverage in the Chinese-language media. For some Fujianese leaders, Mr. Jiang's decision to avoid Chinatown has undermined their decadelong struggle to win recognition and acceptance from the city's power structure, which has traditionally allied itself with Taiwan and the old guard of Chinatown.
At the same time, even those who are disappointed are reluctant to criticize Mr. Jiang openly and speak with pride about China's economic accomplishments.
"We understand he has to meet with big businesses during his short stay and he doesn't want to face the demonstrators," said a Fujianese community leader who spoke on condition of anonymity. "But it would have meant so much to us if he could just squeeze Chinatown in."
During his two-night stay, Mr. Jiang is scheduled to tour the New York Stock Exchange and offices of IBM, AT&T and Lucent Technologies; at the Waldorf, he will dine with top executives of major American corporations. He also plans to meet with representatives from the city's Chinese community, either at the Chinese Consulate or at his hotel.
There are no rules governing the itineraries of visiting international figures. Some, like Sandro Pertini, the late former President of Italy, seek out those with a common heritage. When Mr. Pertini visited New York in 1982, he visited Staten Island, where there is a large Italian-American population.
Nelson Mandela of South Africa met with African-Americans in Harlem in 1990; Jean-Bertrand Aristide of Haiti met with Haitian students at Brooklyn College in 1992.
But Mr. Jiang is steering clear of Chinatown, Flushing, Queens, and Sunset Park, Brooklyn.
For Governor Pataki and Mayor Giuliani, the decision not to meet with Mr. Jiang is the most expedient solution to a delicate situation.
Zenia Mucha, a spokeswoman for the Governor, cited "scheduling conflicts" and "the upcoming election" as reasons for his absence. Mr. Pataki will be campaigning for Republican candidates across the state, she said. Besides, she added, the distance between Albany and New York would make a meeting difficult. "The Governor is in upstate New York," Ms. Mucha said.
 But privately, an aide to the Governor conceded that he was boycotting the events to protest China's persistent human rights abuses.
"Clearly the Governor has concerns on that issue, as do millions of Americans," said the aide, who insisted on anonymity.
A spokeswoman for Mr. Giuliani, Colleen Roche, said the Mayor was boycotting the event because of "grave concerns about China's human rights policies." In addition, she said, he will be busy with his campaign for re-election.
The two United States Senators from New York, Daniel Patrick Moynihan and Alfonse M. D'Amato, have also said they would not attend the events. To some political observers, the official snub says as much about Mr. Pataki's and Mr. Giuliani's lack of diplomacy as about China's human rights problems.
"It's a sign of remarkable rudeness," said Mitchell Moss, director of New York University's Taub Urban Research Center, "to ignore the leader of a nation of 1.2 billion people.
"But there is no outer limit to the rudeness that can be exhibited in New York," he said.
Indeed, some say that snubbing Mr. Jiang is the wrong approach to resolving human rights problems in China. Hank Morris, a Democratic political consultant, said the Governor and the Mayor were missing an opportunity to confront Mr. Jiang.
"To the extent New York is displeased with China's human rights policy, it is an opportunity to send China a message," said Mr. Morris, who is a consultant for Representative Charles E. Schumer of Brooklyn. But others say the Governor and the Mayor are doing the right thing.
"I'm not happy with the human rights violations," Mr. D'Amato said. "For us to look the other way is wrong."
This is not the first time Mr. Jiang has been slighted on his visit. On Tuesday, Gov. George F. Allen of Virginia backed out of an event, leaving his wife to read a letter with veiled criticisms of China's human rights record.
But Mr. Jiang is expected to be greeted by top state and city officials elsewhere. In Hawaii, he was greeted by Gov. Benjamin Cayetano, and he is expected to meet with the Mayors of Boston and Los Angeles and the Governors of Massachusetts and California.
Whatever the consequences of Mr. Jiang's itinerary for business ties between New York and China, his failure to tour Chinatown may leave some bruised feelings among the Fujianese, who have organized parades to celebrate the national day of China and the return of Hong Kong.
"This is like a slap on the face for them," said Robin Mui, the production manager of Sing Tao Daily, a Chinese-language newspaper that is neutral with regard to China and Taiwan.
The Chinese Embassy in Washington did not return phone calls seeking comment. The Chinese Consulate in New York hung up on a reporter in mid-sentence.
On the streets of Chinese communities throughout the city, many were critical over the official snub to Mr. Jiang. "China is changing," said Tsu Chun Kuo, a businessman in Flushing, Queens. "And it would be a shame for the United States not to be a part of this change."
But many in Chinatown say they are thrilled that he came to the city. A garment worker from Hong Kong, Zhu Ping, said she had not expected Mr. Jiang to visit Chinatown. "He is such an important person and we are so unimportant. I'm not offended at all that he should spend his time on more important issues."
She added: "Just to see his picture in the newspaper is good enough for me. I'm from Hong Kong, and now I'm Chinese. And I'm so proud to be a Chinese."
In other circles, the question of what to feed Mr. Jiang is as delicate as some political issues.
During a state visit by Deng Xiaoping in 1979, official hosts tried to avoid serving the Chinese delegation large portions of beef, believing it might offend their sensibilities, or chicken, which they feared would seem too inexpensive. As a result, meal after meal, Mr. Deng was served veal.
But one of the hosts of tomorrow evening's banquet, the U.S.-China Business Council, a trade organization representing U.S. companies doing businesses with China, says it has found a solution. While the council would not reveal the exact menu, its president, Robert A. Kapp, said the entree would be something that has the "prestige of a four-legged animal without the unappealing quality of red meat." Like chicken, but more upscale.

HEADLINE: People Can Claim One or More Races On Federal Forms

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration today adopted new rules for listing racial and ethnic makeup on Federal forms, allowing people for the first time to identify themselves as members of more than one race.
The change, which could affect Government policies like affirmative action and the drawing of legislative districts, is the first revision in the Government's definition of racial and ethnic groupings since 1977. It means that on Federal forms people can identify themselves in a single racial category or a combination. 
 The Administration rejected a "multiracial" classification that would have covered all people of mixed racial heritage.
"We're allowing people to express that multiracial heritage in whatever way they view themselves," said Franklin D. Raines, the director of the Office of Management and Budget, which issued the rules. "A multiracial category would simply say there is some combination that people believe they are but wouldn't tell you much more than that."
Three categories will remain the same: black, white and American Indian or Alaska Native. In addition, the category of Asian or Pacific Islander will be split into a classification for Asians and one for Native Hawaiians and Pacific Islanders. The black category will be known as black or African-American. The ethnic category of Hispanic will remain, known as Hispanic or Latino.
The first major official use of the new rules is to be in next year's dress rehearsal of the 2000 census. They will take effect on Thursday and were chosen after more than four years of study, debate and testing. They also reflect the growing segment of the nation's population that is of mixed racial parentage.
"It will have profound impact in places like California, which has a high percentage of people with mixed racial backgrounds, not just black and white," said Carlos Fernandez, who founded of the Association of Multiethnic Americans, a lobbying group. "I believe one of the reasons that the pressure built up and O.M.B. reacted was that they saw the numbers growing and the future trends."
But the Administration has yet to say how people who select this option will be counted in studies like the census. The Administration has not decided how to count someone who lists a racial makeup of black and white. More complicated is what to do with people listing themselves as black, white and Asian. Should such a person be counted as black, white or Asian or some combination?
The counting issue is important because Federal policy under measures like the Voting Rights Act, the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and aid for bilingual education is based on the percentage of certain racial groups in a given location. For example, legislative districts must be drawn in such a manner to insure that black residents are adequately represented, and block-by-block census counts are essential to the process.
The issues over how to list people of mixed race are a microcosm of the intricate racial issues confronting the nation as it moves into the next century. They are the outgrowth of group-identity politics that first emerged along racial lines with the black nationalist movement in the 1960's, and then infused other ethnic and racial groups, including the demands now by children of mixed-race marriages to be recognized in their own right.
The number of children in mixed-race families increased to 2 million in 1990 from 500,000 in 1970. The number of people who consider themselves of more than one race is still small. About 1 percent of people, mainly Asians and American Indians, listed themselves as being of more than one race in a 1996 test conducted by the Census Bureau. But the number appears to be growing, and the popularity of celebrities of mixed-race heritage like the golfer Tiger Woods could lead more people to identify themselves with more than one race.
For the most part, demographers, academics and groups representing multiracial people would prefer dividing people into as many subgroups as possible to better study economic, cultural and social trends. Civil rights groups, on the other hand, fear that the dilution of the number of people identified with a single group if the identification is spread over too many categories.
For example, lawyers in employment discrimination suits will at times try to prove that a company is racially biased by comparing the number of blacks in particular jobs with the proportion of African-Americans in the local population. Such litigation could be greatly affected if a significant number of blacks list themselves as being of more than one race, and the Government counts them as something other than black.
Officials at the Office of Management and Budget said they would meet with officials from other Federal agencies, interest groups, demographers, planners and social scientists to work out a policy for counting people who list themselves as members of more than one race. The officials said they hoped to put out recommendations on the issue by the fall of 1998.
The fight over how to count people will be arduous. The Association of Multiethnic Americans will argue that mixed-race residents be counted separately, Mr. Fernandez said.
Such a view is bound to raise concerns among some minority critics who have contended all along that the drive for a changing the racial categories was a way to attack affirmative action and other race-based government programs.
"I believe the same people who are against affirmative action are the same people who are pushing this," said Robert Hill, the director of the Institute of Urban Research at Morgan State University in Baltimore.
Mr. Hill is also the chairman of a Census 2000 Advisory Committee on the African-American Population.
The Administration's review of the official racial classifications began after lobbying by groups representing mixed-race people. In the debate over new categories since 1993, a myriad of groups has sought to gain official acceptance, many in the mistaken belief that recognition would lead to Federal financial aid.
A drive for a new category of Arab-American or Middle Eastern American foundered because groups from that volatile part of the world could not agree on whether such a classification would include both Arab-Americans and Jewish immigrants from Israel.

HEADLINE: Lesson for Thailand's Small Investors: What Goes Up . . .

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 29

 BODY:
"I'm afraid," the young investor said, staring at her brightly colored computer monitor on a small stock-trading floor. "I dare not buy. I'm afraid it will go down more tomorrow."
She was hesitating, like so many investors here and abroad this week, as stock markets around the world heaved and quaked in the latest reaction to an Asian economic crisis that began this summer here in Thailand. 
The investor, who would allow only her given name, Sukanya, to be used, has reason to be afraid. Like many Thai entrepreneurs, she entered the stock market during its recent boom years and now has lost big.
"My boyfriend told me I could use his money to buy anything, any stock," she said on Monday. "I started with 45 million baht" -- more than $1 million -- "three years ago. Now it's worth 4 million. That's why I drive this old car."
At a nearby monitor, Chansin Vongreeramit, a retired finance company executive, was bolder. While Sukanya waited for her chosen stock, Siam City Bank, to drop another tenth of a point, Mr. Chansin bought.
Half an hour later, the stock inched upward. He had earned $103. That modest amount made him the day's big winner here at the headquarters of the Thai Farmers Bank.
Burdened by the country's economic problems, the Stock Exchange of Thailand seemed impervious today to a rebound in New York and around Asia, with its index falling eight-tenths of 1 percent.
Instead of a central trading floor, small outlets like this one around Bangkok handle individual trades. Most people here, like Sukanya, did not play at all on Monday. They chatted over coffee and crullers, read newspapers and dozed in their seats as the room's big trading board flashed its depressing numbers.
Since the baht's effective devaluation in July, its value has tumbled more than 40 percent. The stock market, already weakening over recent months, tumbled too, falling from about 1,200 points when Sukanya began investing her boyfriend's money to well under 500 now.
The trading floors began to empty out. Some investors lingered only to sell off their remaining holdings.
"I realize it's better to quit," said a man who declined to give his name. "You know why? I cannot afford to lose any longer. Nobody gains. Nobody gains, believe me."
It is a feeling that is shared by many people in Thailand today who are looking back across the last decade of heady growth with sudden astonishment as if waking from a happy dream.
"It was so exciting," Sukanya said.
Thailand was the darling of foreign investors, and until market forces and currency exchange rates turned against the country, huge amounts of money rolled in.
Now the squeeze is on. The International Monetary Fund has promised a $17 billion credit line in return for fiscal austerity programs. Prices are rising, companies are closing and hundreds of thousands of people are beginning to lose their jobs.
Fifty-eight finance companies that overextended themselves in loans, particularly for property, have been forced to close.
One of these is the General Finance and Securities Company, where Sukanya used to do her trading. Now its trading floor is dark and padlocked, with only a special lounge for regular investors remaining open.
Only a handful of people sat quietly there on Monday in the glow of their computer screens. One of them was asleep.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Study Faults Connecticut

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
High taxes and high insurance costs are making Connecticut a hard place for manufacturers to do business, according to a new study.
The Manufacturing Alliance of Connecticut, a trade group, ranked the state 43d out of 50 based on 13 business categories, including taxes and the productivity of workers. 
 Connecticut was found to have an advantage in research and development spending, education spending and availability of loans.
Rhode Island and New Hampshire were other New England states in the bottom 10, the study found. It ranked Massachusetts 27th, and found Washington State to be friendliest to manufacturing.

HEADLINE: THE 1997 ELECTIONS: THE CANDIDATES;
Giuliani Shrugs Off Messinger's Attacks in Debate

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
Ruth W. Messinger used her final joint television appearance with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani last night to repeatedly bludgeon his first-term record, blaming him for a "crisis" in city schools and for high unemployment that she warned signaled dark times ahead.
For 60 minutes, Ms. Messinger, the Democratic mayoral candidate, took the offensive whenever she could in what was likely to be her last prolonged exposure to the public before Tuesday's vote. Mr. Giuliani responded with the occasional protest and jibe, asserting that the city's fortunes had vastly improved under his stewardship, and pledging to focus in a second term on areas Ms. Messinger singled out as lacking: schools and job creation. 
 But for the most part, the Republican Mayor shrugged off Ms. Messinger's attacks. He smiled, laughed dismissively as she crisply laid out her arguments and even -- to the evident surprise of Ms. Messinger and the small audience in the television studio -- complimented her as qualified to fill the position of Mayor. In sum, Mr. Giuliani acted like a candidate who, as several friends said yesterday, considers his victory a virtual certainty, and thus saw no reason to take many risks last night.
"Let me point out that we're certainly seeing the nice Rudy Giuliani tonight," Ms. Messinger said with a grin as their hourlong debate, broadcast on WABC, came to an end.
The debate, the candidates' second, was short on drama and suspense, with both Mr. Giuliani and Ms. Messinger repeating, for the most part, arguments that have become familiar to both of them. But while polls suggest that many voters think a Giuliani victory is all but assured, Ms. Messinger was as scrappy and combative as she has been at any point in this campaign. In her closing statement, when the moderator tried to cut her off, Ms. Messinger pushed on, saying she represented a view of New York City vastly different from Mr. Giuliani's. The Mayor, she said, "never talks about the poor at all," as she tried to emphasize their different political philosophies:
"Seeing that no child goes to bed hungry or homeless. Giving working families a fair shake. These issues are at the heart and soul of the Democratic Party. They've never been high on Rudy's list. And why they should they be? I'm a Democrat, he's a Republican. Fashionable or not, I've cared about these problems all my life."
Mr. Giuliani offered a far different view of the city. "I don't see a city in which all problems have been solved," he said, "and I don't see a city in which everyone has been included in the opportunity and access that many have had. But I do see a city that's made improvements. I see a city that's better off than it was four years ago. Crime is down dramatically. Jobs are coming back."
Viewers of last night's debate were afforded a fairly broad picture of the candidates' stylistic and ideological differences and similarities. Both candidates said they would accept, to a limited degree, the presence of police in schools to combat violence, and experimenting with year-round schools.
Ms. Messinger said she would push for legislation or contract provisions requiring police officers hired in the future to live in the city. Mr. Giuliani said he opposed that. Ms. Messinger said that the city should not build a stadium for the Yankees in Manhattan, even if the team threatens to move out of the state, without submitting the issue to voters for approval. Mr. Giuliani called such an initiative illegal.
And Mr. Giuliani said he did not consider school overcrowding as great a problem as Ms. Messinger did. He said he had attended schools with as many as 50 students in a class and asserted, in response to a question, that he would rather have his son Andrew attend a class that large, if it was safe and effective, than a small class that was not.
The two candidates took different tacks, as well, when asked whether they would pledge to serve out their terms. The question was addressed to both candidates, but reflected the fact that Mr. Giuliani's aides are pushing for a large margin of victory in the belief that it would position him to run for higher office.
Mr. Giuliani refused to say whether he would serve out his term. "I have no idea what the future is going to bring," he said. "It would be my intention to serve out four years, if my health remains, if everything remains O.K., but I can't rule out options in the future."
There has been no speculation that Ms. Messinger, if she wins, might turn around and seek another, higher office. She did nothing to encourage such discussion last night. She described Mr. Giuliani's position as "a real dodge," adding: "I promise you that I will serve as your Mayor every single minute of the next four years. I will not be out measuring the curtains in my next office."
The debate also produced a novel political exchange that seemed to capture the changing political calculus in New York: Mr. Giuliani, a Republican, attacked Ms. Messinger, a product of the city's liberal wing, for promising not to raise taxes if she is elected Mayor.
"How is it possible to make that pledge responsibly?" he asked. "You have no idea, I have no idea -- you saw what happened on Wall Street just a few days ago -- what kind of situation the city would be in a year from now."
Mr. Giuliani added, "Do you want to withdraw that pledge because it really isn't a responsible way to go into this campaign?"
Ms. Messinger said that she did not. "I believe it's extremely responsible and shows my respect for the heavy burdens on the taxpayers of this city to say that over the next four years I would not raise taxes."
Despite these exchanges, this debate did not approach the sometimes sharp tone of the one in September. When a questioner asked whether Ms. Messinger was qualified to be Mayor, Mr. Giuliani nodded yes.
"I don't agree with her ideas and I think she would take the city back to where it was four or five years ago, but I don't quarrel with her qualifications," he said. "She has had a distinguished career in public service."
Ms. Messinger quickly protested: "Let me be as clear as I can. It is my intention to move this city forward. Although there is nothing the matter, Mr. Mayor, with a city, in which the Mayor fought --"
Mr. Giuliani cut her off: "That was a compliment, Ruth." The audience laughed.
"Oh no, " Ms. Messinger said. "It's only a compliment if you think backwards is a good direction."
"We disagree on ideas," the Mayor said. "I think you have a long and distinguished public career."
"I thank you," Ms. Messinger said.

PUB-DATE: October 30, 1997

SECTION: Section F; Page 1; Column 1; House & Home/Style Desk

LENGTH: 1787 words

HEADLINE: At Home With;
A Hardy Perennial, Her Passions Still Blooming

BYLINE: By ALEX WITCHEL

 BODY:
WHEN Henry Kravis and Carolyne Roehm separated in 1993, her mother said, "Now you'll know who your friends are."
Ms. Roehm winces at the memory. "At the time, I asked, 'Do I want to know that much?' " 
 Sitting in the living room of her Sutton Place apartment last week, Ms. Roehm said, "There are people I never heard from again, but the people who have remained my friends are wonderful."
A group of them declared themselves last week by throwing a publication party at the Union League Club for Ms. Roehm's first book, "A Passion for Flowers" (HarperCollins, $45). The list read like a gossip column from the glory days of the 1980's, featuring Gayfryd Steinberg, Anne Bass and Blaine Trump.
But the appearance of one guest in particular moved Ms. Roehm: Kimberly Kravis, her former stepdaughter. "I hadn't seen her or Robbie, her brother, much," she said, "because I think you should let the dust settle with everything in life. They're great kids."
In the court of New York social crimes, Ms. Roehm committed an unthinkable offense: she let a billionaire husband get away. As a result, she lost her design business (which he financed), her cachet on the charity circuit and her must-have status at A-list parties. For all the women who secretly hated her for her money and because at 5 feet 10 inches she weighed 114 pounds, it became open season. Her dress designs were good, sure, but not as good as those of her mentor, Oscar de la Renta, who gave her her start.
In 1991, after her company folded, a casualty of both the recession and the unexpected death of her stepson Harrison, she regrouped and started a catalogue business. Yes, that was promising -- in its first year it exceeded projected sales of $500,000 and grossed $3 million -- but truly, catalogues are so democratic, and the retailing operation behind this one had inventory problems. Ms. Roehm always insisted on only the best materials, and that just wasn't practical. So, once the husband went, there went the catalogue. Next.
Ms. Roehm, 46, knows all this, of course. Nestled in her overstuffed couch, barricaded by brocade and taffeta pillows, she talked about her book on flowers and her meaning was not lost. "I don't want to sound hokey," she said, "but if you see a perennial garden out of season, you think it will never come back and it does. Flowers are forever. Yes, they die, but another one always sprouts." She blushed. "I'm not gifted enough to explain this."
For a visual person, as she repeatedly calls herself, it's not a bad explanation. The thing about Carolyne Roehm that her detractors underestimate is a very important one: she is smart enough to know what she doesn't know, and she never stops trying to learn. But it was her drive for perfection, she admits, that did her in, both in her career and in her marriage. She would regularly rise at 6 A.M., exercise, take piano lessons, study French, work at the office 10 to 12 hours a day, organize enormous black-tie benefits and keep up not only the Park Avenue duplex and the Connecticut house, but also two homes in Southampton, a villa in the Dominican Republic, a ski house and a ranch in Colorado. Don't cry for me, Argentina? Try it first and see how long it would take to fall over.
"One hates a marriage to fail," Ms. Roehm said carefully. "It's so painful. But in the end it probably saved my life. Why was I so driven? You could speak to an analyst, I guess, who would say, 'She was so insecure she just had to prove herself in everything.' " She sighed, and seemed relieved that her two maids appeared to serve tea -- on silver trays with starched linen napkins.
Ms. Roehm leaned forward to pour, all limbs. She was wearing brown stretch pants that betrayed not a trace of body fat, though she claims to have gained 14 pounds since her divorce. "I know I was a cadaver," she said. "Now, I'll ride horses, play tennis and ski, but I don't want to exercise."
Her long arms shine with moisturizer, her dark brown hair shines with conditioner and her skin is unlined peaches and cream. Sipping tea, with her pointy chin and her upturned nose, she seemed familiar somehow. If Mary Poppins had married a mogul in New York in the 1980's, she would look like Carolyne Roehm.
"I'd wanted to be a fashion designer all my life and I wanted to be successful at it," she said. "When I met Henry in 1980, there hadn't been the big deals. Life was different." The couple married in 1985. "When I started my business I went through the whole thing about 'What if our romance falls apart?' " She smiled wryly. "It was the right question.
"But women responded to my clothes. Henry started doing huge deals. I actually learned from him about doing work for charity, that giving your time to raise money is a responsibility when you're very lucky. So I plunged into that. I'm not the type that can let go. The couple of times I didn't follow through 100 percent I thought less of myself. I was a strung-out wreck. I admit it -- I got caught up in the 80's and lost track of what was important in my life. I was on that fast track to nowhere."
But did she have to lose her business in the process? She sighed. "One gets married with the idea it will last forever," she said. "These are the risks you take in life. And you know what? I was a big girl. Henry gave me an opportunity to do things I never would have been able to do."
In addition to publishing "A Passion for Flowers," Ms. Roehm is once again getting into the catalogue business, selling home accessories under the name Home by Carolyne Roehm. This time, though, she owns the business herself and she's starting out small, with only 20 items. "I don't want to be a dog wagged by its tail," she said. "I want to grow this steadily. Yes, I love extravagant things but I want to give people value. All the merchandise is from Portugal -- and it's in stock. There's something about the European artisan that intrigues me."
Maybe so, though this room doesn't show it. Oil portraits by Elisabeth Vigee-Lebrun, a friend and confidante of Marie Antoinette, hang everywhere and there are no fewer than five arrangements of roses. There are also gold candelabra, a marble bust mounted on a pedestal, a fireplace topped by a grand scrolled mirror and yards of art books. But for all its grandeur, it's still not enough to stop her eyes from filling when she talks about men ("I hope and pray I will be madly in love and want to be with someone all the time, but I don't know if that necessarily means marriage") and it doesn't stop her eyes from brimming when she recalls getting pregnant in vitro during her marriage and losing the baby.
"I'm thinking about adopting kids now," she said. "Strangely enough, while I might have missed my chance to do it, I don't think I would have been a very good mother. With the space I've had these last few years, I think now I would be O.K."
Can't she just hear people say: "And why not? You certainly can afford it." She nodded. "I think when people say nasty things it's not about you, it's about them. I am finally getting better about that. Not everyone is going to like me, not everyone is going to invite me, and there is nothing I can do about it. I make mistakes, like we all do. The people who work for me care for me. They are my extended family."
Her own family shrank with her father's death two years ago. Ms. Roehm was the only child of two educators, born in Kirksville, Mo., who had to suffer the indignity of a father who was her junior high school principal. Her mother, now retired, was a teacher and speech pathologist. Growing up in Missouri, Ms. Roehm, who was named Carolyne Jane Smith at birth and went by the name Janie, used to play dress-up with castoff gowns sent by relatives and dream of becoming a designer. The very first thing she ever bought herself was a rhinestone tiara -- from the Sears, Roebuck catalogue.
After graduating from Washington University in St. Louis, she moved to New York and worked for Kellwood, a company that manufactured sportswear for, appropriately enough, Sears. She then became, after much persistence, Oscar de la Renta's assistant and designed his Miss O collection. She took a yearlong intermission in 1978 to move to Darmstadt, Germany, and marry Axel Roehm, the heir to a chemical fortune, a union she has termed "disastrous."
When her own design business closed and her divorce from Mr. Kravis was finalized in 1994, she took off for Oxford University to study Shakespearean tragedy. "I used to say to Henry, 'How much money does one have to have in life before my fantasy of taking a year off and studying all the things I was too stupid to study in college would come true? Wouldn't it be fun?' " She smiled, though it was half grimace. "I don't think he thought it was so much fun." At Worcester College, she lived in a dorm room and loved it, before moving on to Paris and an apprenticeship with Henri Moulie, the grandmaster of flower arranging.
"Flowers are really what I love the most, in terms of things," she said. "Flowers so change the quality of your life, as does a good book or a piece of music. Nothing gives me greater pleasure."
After four months in Paris, she returned to Weatherstone, the Connecticut house, "back home to my garden," she said. "I'm lucky that a lot of people I really like are near my home in Connecticut and that everything I love is there -- my flowers, vegetables, six dogs, cats, horses. I just got two goats. There's a real spirit there. I laugh there, I cry there, I spend time alone there comfortably. I don't think I'm the flaky type in terms of spirituality, but home is my relationship with my animals and garden and house. All my senses are more finely tuned there. If I see my animals do something charming or find a huge dahlia that's a luscious red color, I physically feel that surge in my heart, like it's getting bigger. I have that there, not here."
Here, though, she sees friends for dinner, indulges her love for funny movies and white truffles and exults in the fact that she hasn't given one party in this apartment since last Christmas. Indeed, the only sounds that have punctuated the afternoon are the constant ringing of the phone and the fax in the next room. The sense of quiet anticipation, of new beginnings, is everywhere. What else could she want?
Again, her tireless radar for her own limitations goes up. "In my next life, I want to be funny," she said seriously. "Like Erma Bombeck. When other people are funny, I laugh, but I'd love to do it myself." She leaned back and sighed. "If nothing else, on my tombstone it will say: 'She was a very hard worker. She might not have been effective but, boy, she worked hard.' "

Nothing gives me greater pleasure." (Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times)(pg. F4)

PUB-DATE: October 31, 1997

SECTION: Section E; Part 1; Page 1; Column 1; Movies, Performing Arts/Weekend Desk 

LENGTH: 2908 words

HEADLINE: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;
Welcome To the Club: Jazz Swings In New Spots

BYLINE: By BEN RATLIFF 

 BODY:
New Yorkers like to mention casually, as if it were painfully evident, that we have the best jazz in the world. That's obviously true, at times. But the scene here has long been top-heavy and ruled by a vicious cycle. The B flat blues you hear from jazz musicians goes like this: The market for unknown jazz being what it is, few young musicians get to make records. Budgets in jazz being what they are, the records that are made can be misproduced and badly distributed. And competition being what it is, a jazz musician can only get a plum gig if he has a few good records easily available.
Top-quality jazz in Manhattan has historically come out of the music schools or the biggest clubs, of which we are now lucky to have five: the Village Vanguard, Birdland, Sweet Basil, the Blue Note and Iridium. But school-band concerts are chancy propositions, and the Big Five have supplied your image of a jazz club: pricey, uptight, full of tourists and the occasional pinstriped businessman who falls asleep on the table after yelling "Go, man, go!" for an hour. 
 But the scene is changing. Over the last year or so, jazz has spread across Manhattan to new clubs, restaurants and cafes that don't fit the stereotype. There is probably more jazz around on a given night than there has been in a decade, and some of it is very cheap. More young players are being showcased; more experimental jazz is available; a more casual atmosphere prevails. At the same time, jazz artists of the huge middle ground -- those between the neophyte and the big-timer, who have spent their lives working abroad, teaching or serving as eternal sidemen -- finally have places to play.
The success of Smalls, a three-year-old club on West 10th Street in Greenwich Village, is partly responsible for the sprouting of new places. Smalls proved that you don't have to go to the Big Five to hear exciting, straight-ahead jazz. With its nonthreatening air and workshop environment, Smalls has become a launching pad for young musicians schooled in the rigors of be-bop but stretching the idiom. Meanwhile, the downtown jazz scene that used to be nurtured at the Knitting Factory in TriBeCa has spread to newer places, since that club has recently tilted toward rock and dance music.
Trios and quartets can easily set up in a corner in places like the Izzy Bar, Detour or the Zinc Bar, where the saxophonist Ravi Coltrane, with a new quintet, created two fascinating evenings this month. But even a big band, the most impractical and economically unwieldy of jazz concepts, has a chance to grow in some small spaces. In one recent week, I heard two excellent and completely unrecognized big bands: one at the Neo Lounge in the West Village, led by Joey Sellers, and another at the Internet Cafe, led by Chuck Clark. Not much of this music has been written about or sniffed out for commercial potential.
The new spots range from the Jazz Standard, a bona fide jazz club with weeklong engagements, which opened on Tuesday and is attached to a chic restaurant; to Metronome, a restaurant where a different band sets up every night in a corner overlooking Broadway in the Flatiron district; to the East Village restaurant Opaline.
There's the Savoy Lounge, hard by the Port Authority Bus Terminal; the Minetta Lane Theater off the Avenue of the Americas in the Village; the Internet Cafe, a tiny, homey coffeehouse on East Third Street; the Bowery Bar, a hot downtown spot that will soon start a Monday night jazz series, and the Lenox Lounge, the Art Deco club in Harlem.
At some of these places, the musicians are creating their own opportunities to perform. The best news: Few of these clubs charge more than $10 for admission.
The jazz world tends to take itself very seriously, thriving on "its own marginalized status," said Samantha Black, who signs jazz artists for the record label Verve. "So we end up with these jazz-club environments that are like museums. That's not the way jazz used to be. You didn't just go to revere; there was an engagement.
"What's great about these new places is that young people aren't overwhelmed by the cost, so they aren't also overwhelmed by the threat that they might not understand the music, or the fear that they're in a too-rarefied crowd."
Here is a look at some of the new jazz clubs in Manhattan.
 
The Jazz Standard
On the soigne end of the scale, there's the newest in town, the Jazz Standard, in what used to be the Rosenblum Perfume factory, on 27th Street at Lexington Avenue. At street level, there's the restaurant, 27 Standard, with a full wine list and a contemporary American-style menu; the chef is Michael Smith, who used to work at the Rainbow Room and the Hudson River Club.
Downstairs, the Jazz Standard has room for 150 patrons, a size comparable to the Big Five, with its own menu, running from pizza to caviar. (Two layers of insulation have been installed so the diners upstairs won't be disturbed by the music.) The ducts of the former factory on the ceilings and walls have been kept intact as part of the decor.
Since Birdland opened on West 44th Street with its all-star schedules, what's needed now is a club that showcases musicians signed to smaller labels or those about to break the surface of media attention. Accordingly, the Jazz Standard's owner, James Polsky, a former jazz drummer, has booked the room through January with younger musicians like the saxophonist Don Braden, who plays there through this weekend; the vibraphonist Stefon Harris; the pianist Jonny King, and the saxophonist Mark Shim.
 
Minetta Lane Theater
Less bound to the financial vicissitudes of the food-and-drink business is the jazz series at the Minetta Lane Theater in Greenwich Village.
The theater has excellent sound and seats 350, twice as many people as the biggest club in New York. When the house empties on weekends (the Minetta Lane currently has a successful long-running play, "Gross Indecency"), the jazz begins. On Monday, when the theater is dark, the music starts earlier in the evening.
Drinks are sold at the concession stand in the lobby. Tickets run as low as $5, and though the first few concerts had small audiences, Roy Hargrove's big band nearly sold out for two shows on a recent Sunday night.
The philosophy here is simple: "We're trying to make jazz attractive to young people," said Mike Kolker, producer of the concerts. Indeed, you couldn't otherwise hear Mr. Hargrove in a theater or a club at this price. But Mr. Kolker is also bringing in young band leaders like Greg Tardy and Omer Avital, and he plans to adopt the rock-club practice of having lesser-known bands open for big names.
The positive effect of the $5 ticket in jazz is nearly incalculable. If you've spent $20 to cross the threshold of a club and another $10 for drinks, you might feel too guilty to cheer; you sit still and absorb, trying to get every penny's worth. And it goes without saying that struggling musicians can't afford to hear their heroes at high prices.
"When I want to see the Joe Lovano-Paul Motian-Bill Frisell Trio at a club, I literally have to save money for a month," said Tony Malaby, one of the best young tenor saxophonists in town, who just gave up his day job selling fly-fishing gear. But if it's cheaper than a movie, you tend to let yourself go. As at Smalls, the bands feed off the energy of the crowd.
 
Bell Caffe, Jules, Alt.Coffee
On the more experimental end of the spectrum, musicians are taking greater control of their work, creating new situations for themselves, even starting their own record companies.
"A lot of people are getting tired of waiting for calls," said the saxophonist Tim Berne, who has formed his own record label, Screw Gun, and who's just as likely now to perform at the Internet Cafe in the East Village as the Knitting Factory, where his free-ranging music was almost exclusively heard.
At restaurants like the Bell Caffe and Jules, groups led by the saxophonists Dan Willis and Michael Blake have been able to get regular engagements; this is how bands grow into maturity. The trumpeter Dave Douglas started a group out of a regular engagement at the Bell some years ago; it has grown into one of the more exciting trios in jazz, and it's called the Tiny Bell Trio, in the restaurant's honor.
Alt.Coffee, a cafe on Avenue A at St. Marks Place in the East Village, is another good example. It's a friendly joint where loners read books and students chat for hours: a captive audience. Ted Reichman, an accordionist and composer, saw the opportunity there. For a year, with the drummer John Hollenbeck and the vibraphonist Matt Moran, he's been booking experimental improvised music and jazz into the club every Monday night for free concerts; he plans to produce a mini-festival there in January.
Mr. Reichman said he was "inspired by how things work in San Francisco and Chicago," where the do-it-yourself ethos has resulted in thriving performance scenes.
A band playing at Alt.Coffee can stretch out across a whole evening, make more money than at an established club, with the help of a tip jar, and draw greater interest from the regular habitues. One recent night, the cafe was standing-room-only for a performance of Mr. Hollenbeck's quartet, with percussion, voice, saxophone and steel guitar.
By contrast, although playing at the Knitting Factory still has an element of prestige (European promoters hold the club in awe as an imprimatur for new music), as many as five bands may play there in one night. A band can sometimes get overlooked; it's hard to create a following with a few performances there in the course of a year.
 
Internet Cafe
The Internet Cafe is another grass-roots success story. Nearly two years ago, the cafe's owner, Arthur Perle, asked the saxophonist Hayes Greenfield to bring in music; now it's grown into a six-night-a-week schedule.
"They let musicians try out new things," said the saxophonist Sam Newsome, who has played there with his band, Global Unity. The club is starting to present musicians like Ellery Eskelin and Marty Ehrlich who once played most of their New York gigs at the Knitting Factory.
For the last year, Chuck Clark has led a dynamic 10-piece big band at the Internet, full of excellent players like the trombonist Chris Washburne and the alto saxophonist Matt Hong. Like many of the bookings there, the group's sound mixes swing with odd rhythmic structures, harmony with dissonance. It's a territory that Mr. Malaby, who has also played there with his own groups, describes in jazz terms as "too outside for Smalls, too inside for the Knitting Factory."
About 60 feet long and 12 feet wide, the club has a middle area where the musicians play; waiters walk right through the bandstand. It feels a bit like home: the magazine rack is full, and the manager's golden retreiver, Homer, sometimes takes naps in the bathroom.
 
Detour
Another hive for developing talent is Detour, a small no-cover jazz bar on East 13th Street in the East Village, which opened two years ago and now presents bands seven nights a week. Its owner, Art Zeidman, a working musician, was inspired by small jazz clubs in Amsterdam that had a casual atmosphere and vital music.
The bands are not paid, which prevents a lot of musicians from performing there on principle, but Mr. Zeidman has helped young players develop their craft, including Mr. Hong and the trombonist Mike Fahn.
One musician characterizes it as "Augie's downtown," a reference to the Morningside Heights bar Augie's, where students escaping homework go to chat loudly, occasionally noticing that someone a few feet away is pouring his heart out for tips. But Detour has a small upright piano, which Augie's does not, as well as a less beer-slinging atmosphere.
 
Homefront
Homefront, on the ground floor of a West 54th Street bed-and-breakfast, is modeling itself on the downtown lofts of a generation ago where disgruntled jazz musicians declared independence by producing their own concerts. A long, high-ceilinged room filled with sofas and comfortable chairs, it's a pleasant and relaxed post-dinner or post-theater hangout, with beer and wine for sale.
The style of the music booked there has varied dramatically, from the rhythm-and-blues gutbucket kick of James (Jabbo) Ware's Me, We and Them Orchestra, to Zusaan Kali Fasteau's wild and pancultural free jazz. As is the case with most of these places, it doesn't feel like a jazz club.
In the New York jazz scene, the Big Five shall remain and prosper, but perhaps only as one kind of jazz experience. It's time to take the old image, wipe it clean and start again.
 
Places Where the Price Is Low and the Musical Energy High
 
Here is what's playing this weekend at the Manhattan jazz clubs mentioned in the Critic's Notebook article, along with some November and December highlights.

HEADLINE: NYC;
Appearing In the Role Of Underdog

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN 

 BODY:
IF you think about Ruth W. Messinger's campaign in cinematic terms, just for the heck of it, a couple of film models suggest themselves. "Rocky" is always a possibility. You know the drill: an underdog, given no chance, slogs on against all odds, winning hearts if not the title.
Then there's "They Shoot Horses, Don't They?" 
 That may sound terribly unkind. But the "put her out of her misery" despair of that film is hard to shake off as the New York City mayoral race limps to the finish line. Could things be any worse for Ms. Messinger?
Polls show her getting clobbered on Tuesday. All the major New York dailies are endorsing Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. Her earnest campaign style, dripping with figures and facts, generates few sparks. She is trying to persuade voters that the city's glass is half empty, what with crumbling schools and homelessness, only to find herself caught out of sync in a glass-is-half-full era, with people feeling good about lowered crime and rising municipal revenues.
Whether it is her own fault or a case of editorial dereliction, she has suffered a virtual news brownout on television, with local stations skipping most of her public events in favor of really important stories like Marv Albert's incisors. Then, too, she has endured one defection after another by fellow Democrats, who as a group have proved about as faithful as Prince Charles.
Put all that together and you can understand why Mr. Giuliani's unexpected compliment on Wednesday night -- his reference in their debate to her "distinguished career in public service" -- sounded as though he were not praising her as much as administering last rites.
Given that pileup of adversities, the real question may be how she can keep up her 17- and 18-hour days so enthusiastically. At 7:30 A.M. yesterday, there she was yet again outside a subway station, this time the Parkchester stop on the No. 6 line in the Bronx, greeting riders and smiling broadly, looking for all the world like someone who had this election in the bag.
Maybe "Rocky" is a bit over the top as a reference. But a 60-something man watching her admired her doggedness, even as he confessed that he would vote for Mr. Giuliani.
"I can go out at night," he said. "Four years ago, I couldn't do that. The streets are cleaner, too." But as he watched the Democratic candidate, he added: "She has guts, I'll say that for her. I feel sorry for the woman. Her own party has deserted her, and I'm a Democrat myself."
Naturally, the general assumption that this race is over does take its toll, Ms. Messinger acknowledged the day before as she rode to the A. Philip Randolph Senior Center, on West 146th Street, where she was accompanied by former Mayor David N. Dinkins, and loosened up enough to share a brief dance with him.
"I promise you it hasn't been easy doing this every day," she said. "But I feel it's important to do it."
"Look, I entered this race for a reason," she said. "There are a set of things that are important to me and need to be addressed in this campaign. This has all been about a very consistent set of issues. I've been talking about these kinds of issues for 20 years."
SHE ticked off themes that have formed the core of her anti-Giuliani attacks: overcrowded schools and outdated textbooks, police brutality, an expanding homeless population and a local unemployment rate that is nearly twice the national average, for all the let-the-good-times-roll feelings.
"It's good that crime has gone down, and it's good that the economy has improved for some people," Ms. Messinger said. "But as a city, we have to say: What next? What are the problems looming out there that have to be addressed?" New York City's "genius" has been to see issues coming round the bend, she said, adding, "It takes a leader to say, 'Here's the next crisis.' "
Of course, even if she's correct about the issues that lie ahead, the polls suggest that voters do not consider her, absolutely no pun intended, the right messenger.
But it was interesting how Mr. Giuliani, who usually suggests that he has turned New York into the Emerald City all on his own, suddenly acknowledged in Wednesday's debate that every problem has not been solved, that not everyone has prospered from recent economic successes, that job growth has not been enough and -- mirabile dictu -- that Mr. Dinkins deserves to share credit for the drop in crime.
It may yet turn out that Ms. Messinger's biggest contribution, should the Mayor indeed win, was showing him where that half-empty glass was.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Gold Prices Post Sharp Rise; Crude Oil Up on Iraq Worries

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Gold prices rose sharply yesterday, buoyed by uncertainty over the Asian financial crisis and fears that tensions between the United States and Iraq would escalate.
On other markets, the Iraqi situation also bolstered energy futures, while coffee fell sharply. 
 Gold prices this week have staged a moderate recovery from the 12-year lows that came last week on expectations that central banks would sell their reserves. In recent days, investors have been seeking a haven for their money amid increasing instability in world markets.
Gold prices were further buoyed by fears of a new confrontation between Iraq and the United States after the Iraqi Government barred two Americans from entering the country yesterday. The two were part of a United Nations weapons inspections team.
Gold prices were further helped by comments from Finance Minister Kaspar Villiger of Switzerland, who said he was opposed to selling half of Switzerland's gold reserve, as was proposed by a Government panel last week.
Despite those comments, the market is likely to remain under pressure because of expectations that other central banks will sell much of their reserves.
Gold for December delivery rose $2.80, to $317.20 an ounce, after rising as high as $319.30 an ounce on the Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange; December silver rose 7.2 cents, to $4.867 an ounce.
Crude oil, heating oil and unleaded gasoline prices jumped for a second day on the New York Mercantile Exchange because of concerns over the Iraqi dispute.
December crude rose 51 cents, to $21.22 a barrel; November heating oil rose 0.93 cent, to 58.12 cents a gallon; November unleaded gasoline rose 0.58 cent, to 60.67 cents a gallon.
Coffee prices fell sharply on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York after the National Coffee Federation in Colombia denied reports that a virus had been found in northwestern growing regions, where the coffee trees provide much of the world's supply of gourmet arabica beans.
December coffee fell 2.45 cents, to $1.482 a pound.

HEADLINE: Sony Profit Up Sharply, Aided by Film Studio

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 30

 BODY:
The Sony Corporation said today that earnings rose sharply in the latest six months as demand for its digital electronic products soared and the film "Men in Black" helped lead a revival at its Hollywood studios.
The company raised its forecast for sales and earnings in the current fiscal year, citing rising global demand for products like its Playstation video-game system, video cameras and cellular telephones. 
 Sony's success in selling those items was matched in the six-month period by a strong performance from its film division, whose top management was replaced after a string of costly high-profile flops like "The Cable Guy" and "Striptease."
Summer hits including "Men in Black," "Air Force One" and "My Best Friend's Wedding" helped push revenue from the movie business up 59 percent from a year earlier, to 301 billion yen, or $2.5 billion. That accounted for about 10 percent of sales over all.
In the six months that ended Sept. 30, group pretax profit rose 84.6 percent, to 202.1 billion yen, or $1.7 billion, from 109.43 billion yen a year earlier. Net income gained 75.7 percent, to 90.93 billion yen from 51.74 billion. Sales rose 21 percent, to 3.069 trillion yen from 2.531 trillion.
The yen's decline against the dollar helped the results. As the Japanese currency weakens, the yen value of profits from overseas increases, allowing Japan's exporters to cut prices abroad without harming earnings.
Overseas sales accounted for almost 80 percent of total sales during the period. Sales in the United States rose 32 percent, to 958 billion yen.
Despite the weak Japanese economy -- consumer spending has been hurt by a tax increase imposed in April -- Sony's domestic sales rose 19 percent.
Sony said the recent plunge by Southeast Asian currencies would not hurt earnings because the company produced more goods in the region for export to other areas than it sold there.
The results were released after the close of stock trading today in Tokyo. Sony shares closed with a loss of 200 yen, to 9,900 yen, in a lower market. The shares are more than 43 percent higher than they were a year ago. Sony's American depository receipts rose 87.5 cents, to $83.24.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Rally as 30-Year Treasury's Yield Slips to 6.14%

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury bonds ended mostly higher yesterday, deriving strength from another decline in the wobbly stock market and diminished fears that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates anytime soon. It was the fourth time in five days that the bond market has rallied, reflecting the growing allure of stable fixed-income securities, compared with the seesaw behavior of stocks.
The Dow Jones industrial average, which plunged 554.26 points Monday, rebounded 337.17 points Tuesday and zigzagged to end 8.35 points higher Wednesday, dropped sharply in another gyration yesterday to end 125 points lower. 
 The price of the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond increased 27/32, to 103 7/32. Its yield, which moves inversely to price and can signal future interest rate trends, eased to 6.14 percent from 6.20 percent on Wednesday. Most shorter-term maturities also rose in price.
Bond investors largely brushed aside reports on the economy that suggested further strength and possible inflationary pressure, which typically tend to hurt bond prices.
The Commerce Department said new-home sales in September fell slightly but remained above an annual rate of 800,000 for a fourth consecutive month, the longest stretch in 19 years. The Labor Department reported an unexpected drop in weekly claims for unemployment insurance, suggesting demand for workers remains robust. The Conference Board's help-wanted index, a barometer of the supply of jobs, rose to 87 in September from 85 in August.
Despite this evidence of further economic vitality, many bond market investors apparently feel the Fed's policy-making committee will not seek to slow growth with a dose of higher interest rates when it meets Nov. 12.
Alan Greenspan, chairman of the central bank, broadly hinted in Congressional testimony Wednesday that the Fed would refrain from raising rates and suggested the stock market's turbulence would help slow the economy on its own, by making consumers less willing to spend.
A further hint of optimism about lower rates in the bond market was seen in when-issued trading ahead of next week's quarterly Treasury refunding, with yields noticeably lower yesterday. The new three-year note was offered at a price to yield 5.65 percent, down 4 basis points from the previous day. The 10-year note was priced to yield 5.85 percent, down 5 basis points, and the 30-year bond, 6.11 percent, down 6 basis points. A basis point is one hundredth of a percentage point.
Yesterday, the Treasury auctioned $21.12 billion of 80-day cash management bills at an average rate of 5.18 percent. Cash management bills are used to meet the Government's short-term cash needs outside the regular schedule of bills, notes and bonds.
The following are the results of that auction:

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Dudley Gambles On Knicks

BYLINE: By HARVEY ARATON 

 BODY:
HIS degree in economics from Yale notwithstanding, Chris Dudley rejected a guaranteed offer of $16 million over four years from the Detroit Pistons and accepted a shade over $1 million to play this season for the Knicks. No one has called yet from New Haven, demanding he return the diploma.
"Detroit was going to start me at $3 million this year and jack it up," Dudley said the other day, stretching out his 6-foot-11-inch frame in a folding chair after Knicks' practice in Purchase, N.Y. He shrugged his coat hanger shoulders. "I have to make up $2 million. It's a risk, but if I lose, I lose." 
 The party line is that Dudley can't lose, that the Knicks have promised to re-sign him next summer to a glorious new deal that will allow him to explore one of his potential post-playing careers: real estate, and at Manhattan prices.
"We heard they promised him $18 million for the next three years -- six, six and six," a Pistons official who did not want his name used said yesterday.
Salary cap circumvention is what the National Basketball Association screamed when it challenged the shifty three-way deal arranged by Portland, Toronto and New York. But that is a migraine-inducing subject that we want no part of on the day actual basketball games will be played.
The 13th installment of the Patrick Ewing era begins in Charlotte tonight, and somehow the notion of a Yalie economics major putting money he doesn't even have on the Knicks is an intriguing (some would say nutty) subplot to another climb up Mount St. Michael. Let's not be naive about this: Dudley was most likely assured he would be taken care of, but these are the Knicks we are talking about. Their best-laid plans could wander off the figurative bench, and drop into oblivion.
Dudley is always an injury risk, with his history of foot and back problems. And N.B.A. lawyers are massing at the bargaining table for another assault on the so-called soft cap, which allows teams to pay their own players whatever they want. Then Dudley must consider a third possibility of peril: the Knicks bomb out early in the playoffs again and someone in their multilayered corporate hierarchy starts measuring the team's results against its staggering payroll.
To the credit of the organization (and the customers who keep swallowing one retirement savings-gutting ticket price increase after another), no expense has been spared, in the continuing attempt to squeeze one championship out of the Ewing era.
An upgrade in talent two summers ago that cost $150 million in contracts? Done. Four years and $65 million for a sore-kneed, 35-year-old Ewing? No problem. Another $33 million guaranteed contract to fortify Jeff Van Gundy's bench? Chris Mills, come on down.
The Knicks' swelling annual payroll stands at $52 million, twice the salary cap, and about what it took for the Florida Marlins to compensate 25 players. Yes, it is less than Chicago's payroll, but the Bulls do have Michael Jordan, who makes roughly twice the gross national product of France.
At some point, if the Knicks do not ride the playoff train well beyond their second-round step-off station of the past three seasons, the hard-core personnel analysis will be done. It will ask why a $70 million player (Larry Johnson) was not good enough to carry the small forward position, necessitating the sacrifice of the promising (and low-paid) Walter McCarty and the acquisition of Mills. It will ask why a $24 million point guard (Chris Childs) is not good enough to start and why a $56 million shooting guard (Allan Houston) isn't averaging at least 20 points a game.
It will pose these questions to Ernie Grunfeld, the Knicks' president and general manager, and then wonder why another $18 million should be invested in a backup center.
That, of course, is negative thinking, unacceptable during preseason, unless Van Gundy was whining about his team's effort or Charles Oakley was mumbling what no one but the news media wanted to hear.
It's difficult to argue with the Knicks' strategy to go for it now, while Ewing can still produce, though it runs contrary to the teams positioning themselves to win when Jordan, like Joe DiMaggio, has gone away.
The goals of Dudley's previous teams, the Nets and Portland, were to mark everyone present for the start of practice. Commitment to winning has never been the Knicks' problem, but instead of them or us forecasting yes or no, let's settle back and see what happens. They begin tonight, and then Dudley's might-have-been teammate, Grant Hill, comes to town.
As Ewing would say, see you Sunday.
