HEADLINE: Home Sales and Job Data Show Some Economic Vigor

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30

 BODY:
Fresh evidence emerged today of strong new-home sales and declining unemployment that showed considerable vigor in the economy before the stock market's wild gyrations this week.
Sales of new single-family homes fell two-tenths of a percent in September to a still-strong seasonally adjusted annual rate of 800,000 a year, the Commerce Department said. 
 It was the second decline in a row. Yet September was the fourth consecutive month in which sales were at or above the 800,000 rate, the longest such stretch in 19 years.
In another sign of economic vitality, the Labor Department said new applications for unemployment insurance fell by 16,000 to a seasonally adjusted 297,000 last week, the lowest since late July. The four-week average, a less volatile measure of employment conditions, fell to 305,250 from 308,250 the previous week, the department said.
Many economists say the drop in the stock market will reduce consumers' accumulated wealth and dampen economic growth this year, and that eventually should cause companies to cut back hiring a bit.
Since the winter, the national unemployment rate has been at or below 5 percent, the lowest sustained joblessness in 24 years.
"We'll have tight labor markets for a while, but not tighter," said Elliott Platt, an economist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. "As we get into 1998, we'll have a significant slowing down."
The robust job market and the income gains that result have been key elements supporting housing this year, as have low mortgage rates.
The stock weakness, if sustained, could both help and hurt the housing market. It helps by reducing mortgage rates, a side effect of an investor migration into the relative safety of Treasury bonds, which serve as benchmarks for mortgage rates.
However, declining stock values reduce the resources that consumers can call upon to make housing down payments. That can diminish home buying, said David Seiders, an economist at the National Association of Home Builders.
During the first nine months of the year, new-home sales were running 5.7 percent ahead of the corresponding period in 1996. The supply of new homes for sale -- 286,000 in September and August -- was the slimmest in four years. That is in line with analyst expectations that sales will taper off next year.
Mr. Seiders said he was forecasting 798,000 new-home sales this year and 750,000 in 1998.
By region in September, sales of new homes plunged 12.2 percent in the Northeast, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 65,000, the lowest in 16 months. They also fell 3.7 percent in the South, but jumped 9 percent in the West and rose 2.1 percent in the Midwest.
Nationally, the median price of a new home, meaning that half sold for more and half for less, was $142,000 in September, up 2.2 percent from a year earlier.

HEADLINE: Senate Approves Fed Nominees

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30

 BODY:
The Senate confirmed President Clinton's two nominees to the Federal Reserve Board today. Both are mainstream economists who stress the importance of restraining inflation.
Edward Gramlich, 58, a University of Michigan economist with broad experience in budget policy and social welfare, and Roger Ferguson, 46, a banking and management specialist at the New York consulting firm McKinsey & Company, were confirmed by a voice vote. 
 Both are highly respected economists with views broadly similar to those of their colleagues on the Fed, who emphasize fighting inflation with the aim of promoting long-term sustainable growth.
The Fed board, which normally has seven members, has been operating with five governors since the start of the year, when Janet Yellen left to lead Mr. Clinton's Council of Economic Advisers and Lawrence Lindsey joined a Washington research organization.
The nominations sailed through after Senator Tom Harkin stopped blocking them. Senator Harkin, an Iowa Democrat, is a frequent critic of the Fed, which he says keeps interest rates too high and economic growth too low for America's small businesses and working families.
Mr. Gramlich fills Ms. Yellen's seat, and his term expires Jan. 31, 2008.
Mr. Ferguson fills the seat vacated by Mr. Lindsey, whose unexpired term runs until Jan. 31, 2000.

HEADLINE: Reconsidering A Trade Equation;
Why a Stronger Dollar Hasn't Brought a Drop in Exports

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
As the dollar strengthened this year, Ronald D. Bullock, president of the Bison Gear and Engineering Company near Chicago, raised his prices in francs and marks for the metal transmission gears that he exports to Europe. But his customers stuck with him, drawn by Bison Gear's new willingness to custom-design the gears -- similar in shape to bicycle sprockets -- for each factory machine whose speed they regulate. And Bison's exports have risen, despite the sticker shock.
"We hire a lot more engineers today than we ever have before to do this custom-designing," Mr. Bullock said. 
 Stories like these proliferate among the nation's manufacturers. Added together, they explain why a longstanding economic verity -- that a nation's exports begin to fall after its currency has risen in value for 18 months or so -- has failed to kick in during the current strengthening of the dollar, which began two years ago.
American business has responded much more than in the early 1980's, the last time the dollar moved up sharply. This time it cut costs, shaved prices and profit margins, developed products, sold harder. The unexpected export vigor has added significantly to the nation's sales, here and abroad, and has bolstered the economy, helping to prolong the expansion into its seventh year.
"American manufacturers have managed to export against the odds," said Wynne Godley, an economist at the Jerome Levy Institute, a research group.
At the same time, however, the robust dollar makes it easier and less costly for America's trading partners to export more to this country, and they are doing just that. Despite the growth in American exports, foreign companies are selling more in the United States than American business sells abroad. The turmoil in Southeast Asia, with its currencies falling in value, will only increase these sales to America.
The merchandise trade deficit, as a result, has widened considerably in recent years, even surpassing the record level reached a decade ago. But in contrast to the furor that the trade gap created then, it is greeted today almost with indifference.
"The difference is really in the perception," said C. Fred Bergsten, director of the Institute for International Economics. "People no longer think it is a reflection of some underlying weakness in American competitiveness."
Allied Signal Inc., of Morristown, N.J., offers one explanation for why exports are rising even while the dollar strengthens. Airline travel is booming everywhere, and Allied is a big exporter of engines and parts for commercial aircraft. Demand is driving sales. So are long-term contracts. Big customers like Dessault of France, maker of Falcon business jets equipped with Allied engines, cannot easily switch suppliers. "That's impractical," said Marc Greenberg, an Allied spokesman.
AMP Inc. of Harrisburg, Pa., provides another insight into the nation's export performance. AMP exports to itself, a growing American practice largely impervious to exchange rates. AMP is shipping connectors for Pentium chips to its plants in Asia, where they are installed in electronic equipment sold in the region. The company also sends computer cables and connectors to its Mexican plant, where they are attached to one another and imported back into the States for AMP to sell. Sixty percent of America's merchandise exports to Mexico fell into this category last year, according to one recent study. And Mexico is America's fastest-growing export market, after Canada.
"The question is, do we use intelligent, flexible Mexican labor for this assembly work," said William J. Hudson, AMP's chief executive, "or do we install an expensive piece of automated equipment in the United States? We prefer the flexible Mexican labor, particularly since models change so often."
No one knows how much stronger the dollar has to get for exports, even AMP's, to stop rising. The United States is not the first nation to experience a rising currency and, at the same time, rising exports. Japan, for one, is an old hand at this, and Americans are becoming more adept, too.
Thousands of small manufacturers, for example, have doubled and tripled their sales abroad in recent years, according to the National Association of Manufacturers. Like Bison Gear, which has $35 million a year in revenue, 10 percent of it from exports, they often find ways to offset the costs of a rising dollar.
The stronger dollar does not kick in everywhere, and that helps as well. The dollar has not strengthened in recent months against the currencies of America's two largest export markets, Canada and Mexico. Both have absorbed bigger shares of United States exports in the last year.
In Europe and Japan, where the dollar is much stronger, some American companies have resisted increasing their prices in francs, marks or yen, even though that has meant lower dollar revenue and lower profit margins for each item sold.
"You are getting falling dollar prices for American exports, more than you would expect," Mr. Godley said. "One wonders how long that can last."
Varian Associates Inc., a multinational based in Palo Alto, Calif., gambled on freezing the price in Europe and Japan for its chromatographs, industrial instruments that sell for upwards of $40,000 and identify invisible elements in a substance. The pricing gamble paid off.
"We found, to our surprise, that we sold more units, nearly 20 percent more," said J. Tracy O'Rourke, Varian's chairman. "And that kept our export revenue over the past year flat at $150 million. The demand is there for state-of-the-art capital equipment, if it is not too pricey."
Though each chromatograph is less profitable now, the greater number of units sold has maintained Varian's overall return for this piece of equipment, Mr. O'Rourke said. Cost-cutting, an increasingly important activity as the dollar rises, has also helped. Varian found a way to use one circuit board, costing $1,000, in each instrument, in place of five.
There is the downside, of course, to this export success story. A stronger dollar -- it has risen roughly 16 percent since mid-1995 when measured against the currencies of America's major trading partners -- means that more francs or marks or yen are needed to equal the same number of dollars in sales.
By the same token, though, foreigners who export to the United States need fewer dollars to make the same profits in their weakened currencies. So they can charge less for their products in the United States, encouraging Americans to buy more from abroad.
And for all the resilience of American exports, imports are rising even faster. That translates into a widening merchandise trade deficit, to a record $191 billion last year and a projected level of roughly the same size this year, compared with $173.6 billion in 1995. The previous high, before the 1990's, was a gap of $159 billion in 1987.
Remember the nationwide eruption of hand-wringing and attacks on Japan over that deficit? The public angst finally disappeared in the early 1990's as the trade deficit fell and as Japan's once-impregnable economy fell into decline. Now the deficit is rising again, even passing the old 1987 level, but the dogs that barked so loudly in the 1980's are just beginning to arouse themselves.
A broader measure of the nation's international transactions is also going deeper into deficit. The current-account balance, which covers not only trade but the nation's other overseas transactions -- tourism, investments, services, brokerage fees, international phone tolls, even dollars sent by immigrants to families back home -- reached $148 billion last year. And this year, it could exceed $150 billion.
That is close to the record current-account deficit of $168 billion, also set in 1987, although still much less as a percentage of the nation's annual income. Fortuitously for the American economy, the strong export performance this year -- totaling $447.5 billion through August in merchandise alone, or 11 percent ahead of last year -- acts as a brake on this rising deficit. Service-sector exports help, too. They are much smaller, but rising fast.
A decade ago, the national wail over the big deficit in the nation's international transactions held that Americans were, in effect, borrowing abroad to pay for a profligate life style, and that the next generation would have to repay the accumulating bill, reducing its own living standard to do so. Such talk is all but forgotten today. The bulging deficit is billed as more of a blessing than a curse.
The old profligacy issue -- that Americans were spending wastefully beyond what they could afford on their own -- has given way to a more hopeful view of how the money is being used. Now the foreign money flowing into the country is said to be stimulating investment in American factory operations and other productive facilities.
The Clinton Administration subscribes to this optimistic assessment, and there is evidence of it in Government statistics. "The earnings from these investments mean that going forward we will have the wherewithal to pay back the foreign debt," said Janet Yellen, who heads the President's Council of Economic Advisers.
A decade ago, the flood of imports meant, to many, that higher-paying manufacturing jobs were shifting abroad as imports replaced goods made here. That is still a popular view; the Economic Policy Institute, a Washington research group, for example, concluded in a new study that imports are shutting down some domestic production, forcing workers into lower-paying service jobs.
Many experts, however, argue optimistically that imports, far from crowding out domestic production, are a necessary and welcome supplement for an economy that is close to fully employed. The imports, in this view, make up the shortfall.
"At a time of full employment, it does not make sense to think of the trade deficit as costing jobs," Ms. Yellen said.
The Asian crisis could challenge this view, if those countries respond by flooding the United States with inexpensive goods, and by cutting back the demand for American exports of machinery and heavy equipment. Most of that is for public works projects that hard-pressed Asian governments might now postpone.
A downturn in the American economy would also eat away at the optimism. "People would look at the rising unemployment," Mr. Bergsten said, "and they would inevitably blame the trade deficit." The issue could easily work its way into the next Presidential election.
The one broad area where the rising dollar has hurt exports is in commodities -- Allied Signal's exports, for instance, of chemicals, fibers and plastics that can now be purchased for less overseas. For Allied, these exports have fallen this year, but not by enough to offset the overseas demand for the company's aircraft parts. So Allied's total exports rose to $1.23 billion in the first six months, from $1.14 billion in the corresponding period last year.
"We have a lot riding," Mr. Greenberg said, "on the growing demand for airline travel."

HEADLINE: U.S. IS SET TO LEND $3 BILLION TO HELP BOLSTER INDONESIA

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30

 BODY:
The United States will announce Friday that it is committing roughly $3 billion to what senior Administration officials describe as a "second line of defense" to aid Indonesia -- the first direct American financial contribution to restore financial stability in Southeast Asia.
The announcement will be made Friday morning, after the International Monetary Fund announces a $15 billion emergency aid package for the nation of 200 million people, the world's fourth-most-populous country. But this situation is the reverse of the bailout of Mexico in 1995, in which the United States took the lead and the I.M.F. provided backup financing. 
 The fund's loans come with a number of strings attached, including wide-ranging austerity measures that may prove painful for the family of Indonesia's authoritarian ruler, President Suharto.
"We don't expect that Indonesia will need to draw on our direct help," one senior Administration official said. "But what we need to address here is an atmosphere of contagion" that has spread in the form of extraordinary instability to currency and stock markets around the globe.
The strategy to be announced Friday was developed by Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin and his deputy, Lawrence H. Summers. And its intent is clearly to send a simultaneous message to governments and investors around the globe: That the United States, the world's largest economy, has decided that the risks to worldwide markets have grown enough in recent weeks that it must show a willingness to intervene.
Indeed, the American plan came together after another rough day on Wall Street. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 125 points, or 1.67 percent, and losses were particularly severe for several American banks that investors fear could be exposed to significant losses in emerging markets like Asia. Page D1.
But American officials said they had no fear that Asia's problems would create instability in the American banking system, as it has in Japan. Japanese banks were among the heaviest lenders in Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand and Hong Kong, where the market losses have been the heaviest.
As in the Mexico bailout, the American loans, if needed, will come from the Emergency Stabilization Fund, set up by the Roosevelt Administration more than half a century ago to stabilize the United States dollar on world markets. The fund is administered by the Federal Reserve and the Treasury, and funds can be lent without the approval of Congress. In Mexico's case, $12 billion in loans from the fund were repaid last summer.
Even though American funds will not be immediately dispersed, today's action represents a reversal of strategy for the Clinton Administration.
When the I.M.F. put together a $17.2 billion bailout package for Thailand in August, the United States helped draw up the conditions -- including sharp austerity requirements that have led to protests in Thailand -- but did not contribute funds. Treasury Department officials argued that a direct financial contribution from Washington was not called for in Thailand's case because it appeared at the time that there was little risk that the country's financial troubles -- fueled by speculative attacks on its currency -- would spread to other markets.
It did. And clearly American officials are concerned that unless the contagion is stopped in Indonesia -- a country with a history of much stronger economic performance than Thailand -- it could quickly envelop other emerging markets around the world. Brazil has been particularly hard hit in recent days.
There is a political calculation at work as well. Asian officials have complained that the United States has insisted on a major role, as the largest contributor to the I.M.F., in setting the conditions for the fund's bailout programs -- even though little American money was at risk.
"This became an untenable policy," one State Department official said this week. "If you want to deal the cards, you have to buy some chips."
The main announcement on Friday will come from the I.M.F., which has been negotiating with the Government of President Suharto for two weeks on the fiscal changes that Indonesia must make in return for the $15 billion aid package. Two billion dollars will come from the World Bank, and $3 billion from the Asian Development Bank, based in Manila.
Indonesia will have to agree to a number of conditions, including some that may threaten huge, Government-backed projects that have greatly enriched members of President Suharto's family and fueled Indonesia's reputation as one of the most corrupt nations in Asia.
In what may be a partial concession to the I.M.F., Indonesian officials have said this week that the company building Indonesia's national car, PT Timor Putra Nasional, is removing President Suharto's son, Hutomo Mandala Putra, as president of the company. But his replacement will be drawn from another, related company that is also controlled by the Suharto family.
The car project has become a symbol of how the aging Mr. Suharto has come to rule his country. Indonesia outraged Japan, the United States and the European Union last year when it exempted the company from the huge tariffs that are applied to the import of all cars and car parts entering the country, giving it a huge advantage over foreign car makers. A protest over that is pending at the World Trade Organization.
Asian diplomats said today that President Suharto, who is 76, had approved the austerity plan mandated by the I.M.F., even though he was concerned that it could add to the domestic unrest that has already popped up sporadically in several cities. Mr. Suharto recently warned his army to be prepared to quell disturbances.
The I.M.F. also has to proceed with care. President Mahathir Mohamad of Malaysia sharply criticized the fund today for imposing harsh austerity rules on Southeast Asian nations, while letting currency traders operate around the globe without regulation. He said his country would not seek assistance from the I.M.F., no matter how deep its woes.
"This way we will not be enslaved by anybody, otherwise we will return to colonialization," he said. Malaysia was once British Malaya, and Indonesia was a Dutch colony for 350 years until its independence in 1949.
American officials said that they would only agree to disperse funds from the "second line of defense" if Indonesia strictly followed the I.M.F.'s mandates and if the I.M.F. aid was not sufficient to stabilize the Indonesian markets.
And even then, they said, Indonesia could not draw on the money unless it had more currency reserves on hand than it was borrowing from the United States. Currently, those reserves total about $25 billion.
Washington is only one of several capitals offering to be part of that defensive line. Mr. Suharto declared earlier this week that Singapore, which is heavily dependent on trade with Indonesia, was offering $10 billion, though it is unclear under what conditions. Japan is also expected to offer some backup financing, along with Australia and Malaysia.

HEADLINE: THE 1997 ELECTIONS: THE MAYOR;
The Morning After a Contentious Debate, Giuliani Focuses Singularly on His Record

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

 BODY:
A day after the hand-to-hand combat of the campaign's final debate, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani once again adopted a strategy of extolling his own record and barely acknowledging Ruth W. Messinger yesterday, going so far as to refer to her not by name but merely as "a candidate."
Mr. Giuliani went before a business group in the morning to describe what he said were his achievements in turning around New York City's economy and revamping its budget. Accompanied by charts and ignoring his prepared text, he reprised for his sympathetic audience a list of his re-election campaign's greatest hits: cutting taxes, reducing the growth in city spending, helping to create 173,500 private-sector jobs, scaling back the municipal work force and trimming the welfare rolls. 
 "We changed the atmosphere of the city," Mr. Giuliani said in his speech before the New York City Partnership and Chamber of Commerce. "This city is no longer seen -- city government is no longer seen -- as being antibusiness."
He contended that when he entered office, the local economy was out of balance, with an unwieldy city government levying so many taxes and imposing so many regulations that businesses were stifled. He conceded that the city had not recovered all the jobs that it had lost in the recession, but he did not dwell upon other problems in the city's budget that independent monitors have cited, including large projected gaps in the coming years and heavy long-term debt. The city spends nearly 20 percent of its tax revenues on principal and interest from its borrowing.
The Mayor was introduced by Richard D. Parsons, the president of Time Warner, who was a staunch supporter until the two feuded last year over Mr. Giuliani's effort to get Time Warner's cable division to transmit Rupert Murdoch's 24-hour news channel in the city. Mr. Giuliani and Mr. Parsons hugged awkwardly, and there appeared to be little warmth between the two.
Mr. Giuliani later said that he would embark on a campaign tour across the city on Sunday, visiting as many neighborhoods as he could before Election Day. Mr. Giuliani also told reporters that he had decisively won the debate on Wednesday night with Ms. Messinger, the Manhattan borough president, whom he called "the opposition."
In his speech to the business group, the Mayor said: "Antibusiness politics was at the core of the way politics was practiced in New York City, from at least the late 1930's, right through 1993. You ran for office running against big business. You ran for office running against all the bad, terrible corporations. I even hear a candidate who says that now. I don't hear her right now, but I heard it a lot last night."
He then growled, as if mocking Ms. Messinger's repeated attacks on his record in the debate, and broke off into a chuckle.

HEADLINE: THE MARKET TURMOIL: THE RISKS;
Bank Stocks Fall On Fears About Overseas Losses

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY L. O'BRIEN 

 BODY:
Bank stocks plunged yesterday on fears about big banks' exposure to hair-raising drops in overseas markets, especially in Latin America. But traders and bankers say the Chase Manhattan Corporation, the nation's largest bank, may be facing significant losses, at least on paper, in a currently less-noticed part of the world -- Russia.
Bank stocks have been under pressure recently as investors' fears have mounted about the banks' exposure to weaknesses in the economies of Asian, Latin American and Eastern European countries. Many of the biggest United States banks are active traders in the currencies and securities issued in those countries and for many years enjoyed robust returns. But since the financial crisis began in Southeast Asia this summer, all emerging markets have been whipsawed. 
 Most banks have declined to discuss how well they are faring in those markets, particularly Brazil, where stocks fell 9.8 percent yesterday. And holders of Brady bonds issued by Brazil have seen the value of their holdings drop by about 17 percent since the middle of last week. Brady bonds are foreign debt whose principal is backed by United States Treasury bonds.
Many large banks with exposure to Latin America and other emerging markets helped lead the stock market lower yesterday. BankBoston Corporation's shares dropped 5.6 percent; BankAmerica Corporation fell 4.5 percent; Citicorp and J. P. Morgan both fell 3.4 percent. Chase's shares plummeted $4.50 yesterday, to $115.75, a drop of 3.7 percent.
The broad drop in bank stocks shows that Chase is not alone.
Still, traders and bankers say Chase has been badly burned in the last week trading the Russian equivalent of Treasury bills, known as GKO's, atop even larger paper losses from Latin American securities. It is not known exactly how big the combined losses are or whether they will be material to a bank that last year reported $2.5 billion in net profits. But the setback illustrates the financial dangers facing companies that trade in the unpredictable and often perilous world of emerging markets.
A Chase spokesman said it was company policy not to comment on any of the bank's market activities.
Donald Layton, Chase vice chairman for global markets, said the bank was comfortable with its financial position in emerging markets.
"We're one of the leading players in emerging market debt," Mr. Layton said. "We're used to the ups, and we're used to the downs."
Mr. Layton said also that the recent economic meltdown in Southeast Asia "created and kicked off a financial markets episode which to a large degree has taken on a life of its own, which is not directly related to economic fundamentals outside of Southeast Asia."
Banks technically do not realize losses in their trading portfolios until securities are actually sold. Until then, any market downturns are only reflected in a bank's daily trading ledger, not in its publicly reported bottom line. So a turnaround in the emerging markets by the end of the fourth quarter could erase any paper losses the banks now have.
Nonetheless, an individual close to Chase's trading operation said that the bank has been badly hurt "in the emerging markets and, despite having very robust foreign exchange gains, it won't balance out" by the end of the quarter.
This person said that Chase has suffered paper losses in Russia "in the tens of millions" of dollars in addition to much larger losses in Latin America.
Chase and Credit Suisse First Boston, an investment firm, are considered to be two of the largest concerns specializing in Russian securities. Credit Suisse said it had not booked any recent losses related to Russia, nor does it have paper losses there because it had effectively hedged all of its positions.
The Russian stock market has tripled in the last 18 months. But by this week, shares had fallen about 40 percent from their August highs. The price of GKO's -- dubbed gekkos in Wall Street parlance -- has plummeted in the last two weeks, though they are so thinly traded that quotes were hard to come by yesterday.
A Citicorp spokesman said the bank had "nothing in particular to report" regarding its exposure to emerging markets.
Indeed, analysts said some of the concern about banks' problems in emerging markets is overblown. "I haven't heard of anything that would make me think anything odd and unusual is going on in Brazil," said Diane B. Glossman, an analyst with Salomon Brothers Inc.
"All broker dealers have taken hits in particular countries over the last week," said Peter Allen, head of emerging markets research for BankBoston, which has a large banking operation in Brazil. "I'm sure a lot of banks have taken hits in Brazil, maybe in Argentina, too."
Trading in emerging market securities has been so feverish in the last few days that trading volume on Wednesday overwhelmed many broker-dealers that make markets in such instruments. Eurobrokers, one of the biggest firms processing emerging market debt trades for banks, closed early on Wednesday. And many other broker-dealers closed about half an hour early on the advice of the Emerging Markets Trading Association, an industry trade group. "Traders have been getting in at 5 A.M. over the last couple of days, and we thought we would give everybody a half-an-hour breather," said Mike Chamberlin, the group's executive director.
Trades were apparently processed more smoothly yesterday.
But banks are still casting a wary eye on Latin America. "The temperature is fragile," said the head of emerging markets at a major money center bank who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "People will see how Brazil pans out. We're still concerned about Asia. Russia is a smaller part of the story."

HEADLINE: M.J. Latsis, 70, Emma Lathen Writing Team Collaborator

BYLINE: By ROBERT McG. THOMAS Jr. 

 BODY:
Mary Jane Latsis, who helped make business the backdrop for murder as one half of the Emma Lathen writing team that produced two dozen John Putnam Thatcher mysteries, died on Monday at a hospital in Plymouth, N.H. She was 70 and maintained residences in Warren, N.H., and Brookline, Mass.
Her collaborator, Martha Henissart, said the cause was a heart attack and a stroke. 
 When the urbane New York banker John Putnam Thatcher made his first appearance on the mystery scene, in a 1961 book named "Banking on Death," it raised eyebrows in two cultures.
For one thing, Thatcher, the executive vice president and head of the trust department of Sloan Guaranty Trust, the world's third largest commercial bank, was the first fictional sleuth to spring from the world of business and finance, and he became an immediate hit on Wall Street.
For another, in a genre in which pseudonyms are common enough, nobody knew who Emma Lathen was, or even suspected that she was two shes, one a 34-year-old Harvard trained economist (Latsis) and the other a 32-year-old Harvard-trained lawyer (Henissart).
It was years before the trade tumbled to their secret, and years more before the writers would agree to be identified in interviews, to avoid embarrassing Miss Henissart's clients.
By the time the two women met as Harvard graduate students in 1952 and discovered a shared addiction to murder mysteries, Miss Latsis, a native of Chicago, had graduated from Wellesley, worked for a while for the Central Intelligence Agency and spent two years in Rome working for the United Nation's Food and Agricultural Organization.
At first they were merely friends and roommates who swapped mysteries and introduced each other to favorite authors before going their separate ways, Miss Latsis to teach economics at Wellesley, Miss Henissart to practice law in New York.
Then in 1960, Miss Henissart took a corporate legal position in Boston. While staying with Miss Latsis during a house hunt, she asked what good mysteries were around and was told there were not any.
"Then let's write one," said either Miss Latsis or Miss Henissart, who insists that neither woman had ever been able to recall which of them had uttered the magic words.
Almost immediately they began working out the details of an unconventional collaboration in which they would first agree on the basic structure and major characters, then write and exchange alternating chapters. Miss Latsis, composing in pen on yellow legal pads while sitting in a chair, always produced the first one, and Miss Henissart, using a manual typewriter, the last.
They would then get together for a final joint rewrite, ironing out inconsistencies and gradually synthesizing a distinctive composite style.
The collaboration was rocky at first, especially after Miss Latsis killed off one of Miss Henissart's favorite characters, but they soon found common ground and enough success to quit their jobs.
Although their books, which have sold hundreds of thousands of copies, have been praised for their wit and insights, what set them apart was the authentic, often intricate business deals that produced both the murders and the clues their banker hero used to solve them.
Under the name R.B. Dominic, they created another offbeat fictional detective, an Ohio congressman, but he was never as popular as the redoubtable John Putnam Thatcher. They abandoned the series after seven books.
They generally produced a book every year or so, but once, when Miss Latsis, the daughter of Greek immigrants, became agitated over the 1967 Greek colonel's coup, they interrupted the project they were working on and turned out "When In Greece" in six weeks.
Their latest book, "A Shark Out Of Water," is being published by St. Martin's Press this month, and another manuscript, using the Persian Gulf war as a backdrop, is about 80 percent complete. Miss Henissart said she planned to finish it, but did not know if John Putnam Thatcher would continue after that.
With their success, the women, two slender brunettes often taken as sisters, bought a house together in Warren and spent part of each year there, working and talking over plots during long hikes through the White Mountains, their collaborative solitude broken only by Miss Henissart's succession of suitors and Miss Latsis's ever faithful Walter Frank.
Mr. Frank, a Cambridge investment executive, was not the model for John Putnam Thatcher, but over the years he displayed a certain gallantry.
In a concession to an old-fashioned sense of propriety and Miss Latsis's aversion to marriage, she and Mr. Frank maintained a 40-year romance while maintaining separate residences.
He is her only survivor.

HEADLINE: THE 1997 ELECTIONS: THE VOTERS;
New Jersey Poll Finds Volatility Among Voters

BYLINE: By JENNIFER PRESTON 

 BODY:
Christine Todd Whitman continues to receive high marks as Governor of New Jersey, but she has been unable to convince voters that she would do a better job than her Democratic opponent, State Senator James E. McGreevey, in addressing their top concern, auto insurance, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.
Although those polled said they had more confidence in Mr. McGreevey's ability to lower auto insurance rates, 60 percent were unable to offer an opinion of him. Four years ago, a poll found Mrs. Whitman in a comparable position, with 46 percent saying they could offer no opinion of her. 
 With voters expressing such mixed sentiments -- and one in three saying they could change their minds before Tuesday -- the survey's findings underscored the volatility of New Jersey voters. Moreover, the poll found a significant variation in the support for each candidate, depending on how likely they were to vote on Election Day.
The race between Mrs. Whitman and Mr. McGreevey appeared to be a statistical dead heat among those voters judged by pollsters to be the most likely to vote, based on their voting history and their stated intentions. They represented 15 percent of the total registered voters in the poll.
In this group, the poll showed that 43 percent preferred Mrs. Whitman, while 39 percent said they favored Mr. McGreevey. Murray Sabrin, the Libertarian gubernatorial nominee, received 9 percent of support from this group, and 8 percent said they were undecided. This group had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 7 percentage points.
Mrs. Whitman's lead widened among a broader group of voters who were not as sure that they would vote next week. Forty-four percent of this group said they would support Mrs. Whitman, while 34 percent said they would vote for Mr. McGreevey. In this group, Mr. Sabrin was preferred by 8 percent and 13 percent were undecided.
Mrs. Whitman's biggest lead was among all registered voters surveyed. She led Mr. McGreevey 44 percent to 33 percent, while 8 percent said they preferred Mr. Sabrin and 12 percent said they were undecided. The findings are similar to lastmonth's Times/CBS News poll, in which 44 percent of registered voters said they preferred Mrs. Whitman compared with 35 percent who said that they preferred Mr. McGreevey.
Despite a strong economy, Mrs. Whitman finds herself locked in a close race because voters do not think that she has done enough during her first term to bring down the cost of auto insurance and property taxes, the highest in the nation.
Mrs. Whitman appears to need a large turnout among Republicans and independent voters. Turnout also seems to be crucial for Mr. McGreevey. But his first challenge over the next few days is to solidify his Democratic base and sway undecided voters who, experts say, historically tend to choose the challenger over the incumbent.
In the poll, Mr. McGreevey had the support of only 56 percent of those surveyed who described themselves as Democrats, giving him an opportunity to narrow Mrs. Whitman's lead by making a strong appeal to rally the Democratic Party.
Mrs. Whitman made inroads among those who described themselves as Democrats, winning 26 percent of their support, while Mr. Sabrin captured 6 percent from this group. Twelve percent of the Democrats said they were undecided. The Governor needs to draw support from both Democrats and independent voters because, the poll found, she had the support of only 7 of 10 self-described Republicans. Thirteen percent said they were supporting McGreevey and 7 percent said they were supporting Mr. Sabrin.
For those voters who described themselves as independents, Mrs. Whitman won the support of 36 percent; Mr. McGreevey, 29 percent, and Mr. Sabrin, 12 percent; 20 percent said they were undecided.
"It is still extremely close," said David P. Rebovich, a professor of political science at Rider University in Lawrenceville. "Democrats should not be especially discouraged. It is close enough and there are enough undecided voters out there for the McGreevey camp to attract. Late deciders usually break for the challenger, so there is some encouragement there."
The statewide poll, conducted Saturday through Wednesday, was based on interviews with 1,392 adults. Of these, 1,082 said they were registered to vote. The poll has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points, which means that statistically, each candidate's support at the time of polling could have been three points higher or three points lower than measured in the poll.
There were signs that the race was tightening during the week. Interviews that were begun Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday produced a somewhat smaller gap between Mrs. Whitman and Mr. McGreevey among registered voters than those conducted over last weekend.
"This is going to be a close race," said Tom Wilson, manager for Mrs. Whitman's re-election campaign. "This is the way that New Jersey behaves. You have a large amount of people who make sure that the candidates are listening to them."
But the McGreevey campaign was encouraged by the poll's finding that their steady barrage of criticism of Mrs. Whitman's handling of auto insurance was resonating with voters. And even though Mr. McGreevey may not be as well known as he hoped to be at this stage in the campaign, his advisers noted that most New Jersey voters traditionally do not begin to focus on statewide elections until just before Election Day.
"The voters know enough about Jim McGreevey to realize his commitment to reducing auto insurance rates, stabilizing property taxes and enhancing educational standards," said Richard McGrath, a spokesman for the McGreevey campaign.
The poll found that 54 percent of those surveyed approved of the way Mrs. Whitman was handling her job as governor, while 35 percent disapproved. Mrs. Whitman was also given high marks for her handling of the state's economy and environment.
But 76 percent of those polled said that they disapproved of the way that she had addressed the state's high auto insurance rates. And 63 percent said that they disapproved of the way she has handled property taxes.
Forty percent said they thought that Mr. McGreevey would be more likely than Mrs. Whitman to bring down the cost of auto insurance. Twenty-seven percent cited Mrs. Whitman and 18 percent said that neither candidate would reduce rates. When asked whether their opinions on auto insurance would influence their choice for governor, 26 percent said a great deal, 41 percent said somewhat, 19 percent said not much and 11 percent said not at all.
On the issue of property taxes, 50 percent said that they believed the taxes would increase in a second Whitman term, while 36 percent said the taxes would stay the same. Eight percent said they would decrease.
If Mr. McGreevey wins the election, property taxes will rise, 34 percent said in the poll. Another 34 percent said they would stay the same. Ten percent said they would fall and 17 percent said they did not know.
In the poll, 70 percent said that the tax cuts enacted during Governor Whitman's first term had made no difference to them personally, up from 66 percent in last month's poll.
The poll also showed that Mr. Sabrin, the first third-party candidate to qualify for public financing under the state program that provides matching taxpayer dollars to candidates, was pulling votes equally from Mrs. Whitman and Mr. McGreevey.
Most voters said they had seen at least one television commercial from the two major party candidates, but only 35 percent said that they saw or heard any of the three televised debates last week.
 
How the New Jersey Poll Was Conducted
 The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Saturday through Wednesday with 1,392 adult residents of New Jersey. Of these, 1,082 said they were registered to vote.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was selected by a computer from a complete list of New Jersey exchanges. The exchanges were chosen to assure that each area of the state was represented in proportion to its population. For each exchange, the telephone numbers were formed by random digits, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers. Within each household, one adult was designated by a random procedure to be the respondent for the survey, thus allowing access to all adult household members.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of telephone lines into the residence, and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to region, race, sex, and age.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20 the results based on such samples will differ by no more than three percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all adult residents of New Jersey.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll. Differences in the wording and order of questions, for instance, can lead to somewhat varying results.
Registered voters in the poll were classified as likely voters or most likely voters based on their answers to five questions dealing with past turnout, intention to vote this year, attention to the campaign and degree of mobility.

HEADLINE: THE 1997 ELECTIONS: THE CANDIDATES;
Campaigns Look for a Prop: Vice Presidents Are Willing

BYLINE: By BRETT PULLEY 

DATELINE: MORRISTOWN, N.J., Oct. 30

 BODY:
With lingering concern that the more conservative base of her party had not shown enough enthusiasm for her re-election bid, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman spent much of her time today in Republican-dominated regions of the state, trying to excite a wing of her party that has complained about her pro-choice stand on abortion and her fiscal policies.
To bolster her conservative credentials, Mrs. Whitman was joined by the former Vice President, Dan Quayle, who took to the stage in the town green here and wasted little time proclaiming why he was with the Governor. "I am here today as a conservative Republican enthusiastically saying we're going to re-elect Christie Whitman as Governor," Mr. Quayle said. 
 It was unofficially Vice Presidents' day in New Jersey, as Mrs. Whitman's Democratic opponent, James E. McGreevey, was joined by Vice President Al Gore, who traveled to the Camden County town of Pennsauken this morning to laud the county's $3 million program to provide at least one computer for each of the county's 5,800 classrooms by the year 2000.
The appearance with Mr. Gore at Pennsauken High School was the highlight of the day for Mr. McGreevey, who was praised by the Vice President for his pledge to enhance educational standards in the state. For Mr. McGreevey, Mayor of Woodbridge and a state senator, the event generated valuable news coverage and provided a forum for him to repeat his promise to abolish the curriculum standards that the Whitman administration adopted earlier this year and replace them with what he says will be tougher standards.
He told 2,000 students in the school's gymnasium that New Jersey's standards were the weakest and lowest in the country. "If I'm elected Governor, you're going to be working so much harder," Mr. McGreevey said, drawing jittery murmurs and muted clapping. "I want you to be able to achieve your fullest potential."
Later in the day, Mr. McGreevey campaigned in his home county, Middlesex, where he greeted workers at the 4 P.M. shift change at the Ford production plant in Edison. Mr. McGreevey, who has received endorsements from most major labor groups, was joined by John J. Sweeney, the president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O.
Mrs. Whitman spent the morning in Orange at the funeral of Scott M. Gonzalez, the state trooper killed last week in the line of duty. But by the afternoon, she had also made an academic visit, as she and Mr. Quayle talked with students at Randolph High School, one of the state's top schools, tucked in the woodsy suburbs of Morris County.
After the Governor delivered a message about personal responsibility to the students, she and her husband, John, and Mr. Quayle, hanging out the window of her campaign bus, tossed foam flying-discs emblazoned with her 10-day bus tour theme, "On the Road to a Brighter Future."
But there was one student -- far, far away -- who caused the most emotional moment of the day. At the Parsippany offices of Dialogic Corporation, a manufacturer of computer telecommunications components, Mrs. Whitman had just finished delivering her stump speech about job creation and the economy to 300 employees, when company officials told her they had a surprise for her.
With the flick of a switch, the voice of the Governor's 20-year-old daughter, Kate, came over a loudspeaker -- live from South Africa, where she is currently studying. "Hi, Mom," the voice said. The Governor began to cry. At that point, Mr. Whitman stepped on the stage, and spoke into the microphone to his daughter. "They're telling me this call isn't costing us," he joked. "You can talk as much as you want," Mrs. Whitman added.
Before they ended the call, Mrs. Whitman asked her daughter, a junior at Wesleyan University who is spending the semester in Cape Town, "Did you get your ballot in?"
At one point during the day, Mrs. Whitman's bus pulled into a shopping center parking lot, and with news media trailing behind, she went into a Kmart store to buy cold medicine and vitamins. As she greeted shoppers, one man asked her about the criticism of her in advertisements for the Libertarian Party candidate, Murray Sabrin. "They're just totally untrue," Mrs. Whitman said of the ads. The man said that the explanation was good enough for him, and that he would vote for the Governor.
But convincing people like Pat Sheils of Morristown is not as easy. A devoted Republican and staunch opponent of abortion, she stood and watched the Governor and Mr. Quayle deliver their speeches here in her hometown and then confided that she plans to vote for Mr. Sabrin. "New Jersey is the partial-birth abortion capital," Ms. Sheils said. "I don't want her as Governor. She is a Clinton Republican."

HEADLINE: THE 1997 ELECTIONS: THE CHALLENGER;
Touring 3 Boroughs, Messinger Focuses on Education

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN 

 BODY:
Just five days before next Tuesday's mayoral election, Ruth W. Messinger worked the Bronx yesterday, trying to energize voters in the only borough where polls show her to have a consistent edge over Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.
There and at other stops in Manhattan and Queens, she focused her message on education issues, including her desire to cap tuition for City University students and her support of the state's proposed $2.4 billion School Bond Act. 
 While Ms. Messinger sought to keep her campaign day focused on education, she found herself denying assertions that she once supported the use of one-officer patrol cars for the New York Police Department.
Both campaigns issued competing news releases yesterday on the patrol car issue, raised in the mayoral debate Wednesday night. In fact, both Mr. Giuliani, as Mayor, and Ms. Messinger, as Manhattan Borough President, have said at different times in recent years that the Police Department should consider experimenting with patrol cars operated by one officer under certain conditions. Neither candidate, however, expressed support for adopting such a policy.
Ms. Messinger began her day at 7:30 A.M. at the subway station at East 177th Street in the Parkchester section of the Bronx. She returned to the Bronx yesterday afternoon for a rally at Hostos Community College, where Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx Borough President, joined her on stage and the students applauded the parts of her speech that were delivered in Spanish.
"Necesito su apoyo, su ayuda y sus votas," Ms. Messinger told more than 300 cheering students in Hostos's repertory theater, asking for their support, their help and their votes. "You got it," one student shouted back in English. Another screamed, "Go Ruth! Go Ruth!"
Later in the morning, after she testified before the State Assembly's Committee on Higher Education about reducing tuition at the city's community colleges, she was asked why there seemed to be fewer reporters covering her campaign day.
"I believe that the press in this city owes it to the people of this city to cover all of the issues that I have been talking about in the campaign," she said. "The question is whether the people of this city know enough about a persistently high unemployment rate, about the dreadful, dilapidated and deteriorated condition of some of our schools, and I think they do not."
After she made her pitch for $2.4 billion School Bond Act at Public School 199 in Sunnyside, Queens, her private meeting with parents attracted about two dozen people.
Last night, Ms. Messinger attended a rally with female supporters at the West Park Presbyterian Church on the Upper West Side of Manhattan.
"I think that the city is ready for one tough mother," Ms. Messinger said. "You have five days left to win this election."

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN WASHINGTON: IN CHINA;
At Home, Rosy News for Jiang's Trip

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Oct. 30

 BODY:
Among the mandatory smiles and pageantry of Jiang Zemin's state visit to Washington this week, the impromptu debate on human rights between Mr. Jiang and President Clinton at their news conference Wednesday stood out as unusually frank. For American viewers at least, it was a reminder of the differences that remain despite a multitude of agreements and shared hopes.
But few Chinese are apt to learn about this telling moment because the pointed exchange was not mentioned at all in the news coverage here. All week the Government-controlled television and newspapers have extolled the happy moments of the trip and glossed over less pleasant tidings. 
 Viewers this evening of China's only national television newscast watched the Clintons and Gores meet Mr. Jiang and his wife, sat through nearly the entire American national anthem and watched the 21-gun salute. They heard a long summary of the leaders' joint statement, covering everything from environmental agreements to the desire for world peace.
The news conference itself was shown only briefly, and the crowd of protesters across the street from the White House was not mentioned at all. From the long and lively press conference, the Government-run China Central Television showed only a moment of each leader's statement about constructive cooperation, and a Chinese reporter lobbing Mr. Jiang a softball of a question.
The television networks and newspapers here -- all Government controlled -- have been remarkably consistent. The images given the Chinese people have been resolutely upbeat, with special emphasis on the pomp and symbols. The newspapers have sometimes mentioned, amid the long lists of achievements, that the two countries have differences on human rights, but then report only Mr. Jiang's justifications.
Mr. Jiang clearly wanted this trip to give him new stature as a leader, and China new stature as a world player. Each day's ceremonies have been featured atop page one of every major newspaper, crowding down news about the stock market chaos in Hong Kong, and they have filled the opening minutes of every news broadcast.
"The goverment sees this visit as a very big event, and they give the media very detailed directions about what to print," said Wu Guoguang, a former editorial writer of the People's Daily who left China in 1989 and now teaches at the Chinese University of Hong Kong.
Longtime China-watchers in the diplomatic community here are not surprised by the timid and uniform press coverage, a habit of Communism that has not waned in the new era of economic opening. The Chinese leaders need time to mull over the results of this American visit, said a Western diplomat, and in the meantime would find it risky to allow attention for anything so heated as Wednesday's Presidential retorts.
The trip has produced one mystery. Mr. Jiang's hourlong swim in Hawaii, a feat of stamina by any measure, would seem designed to impress the Chinese people and harked back to famous swims by Chairman Mao and Deng Xiaoping. Yet while the Western and the Hong Kong press gave wide coverage to the event, someone high in the Chinese government apparently decided that this would not strike the right tone at home: Chinese television and newspapers ignored it.
A possible answer was suggested by Mr. Wu, the former People's Daily editor. He recalled that several years ago Li Peng, the Prime Minister, took a swim in the Dead Sea during a visit to the Middle East. The publication of a picture of him lolling in the water coincided, unfortunately, with a period of disastrous flooding in southern China, and Mr. Li's public image took a dive.
"Maybe the papers learned a lesson from that," Mr. Wu said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

U.S. Commits $3 Billion To Indonesia Aid Package
The United States will announce today that it is committing roughly $3 billion in backup financing for an International Monetary Fund package to aid Indonesia. 
Though the I.M.F. is taking the lead, the commitment is clearly intended to send the message that the United States has decided that the risks to worldwide markets have grown intense enough that it must show a willingness to intervene in Southeast Asia, where the troubles began. Page A1.
 
Wellpoint Stock Falls Sharply
The downturn in the stocks of managed-care companies spread to Wellpoint Health Networks, whose shares fell 13 percent even though the company reported relatively strong quarterly financial results. D2.
 
Worldcom Shares Below Key Level
Worldcom, whose unsolicited bid for MCI Communications depends in part on the value of Worldcom stock, announced quarterly results that exceeded expectations, but they failed to lift the company's shares above a price it had set to help determine the value of its MCI bid. D10.
 
The original bidder for MCI -- British Telecommunications, which is now in complex negotiations with the other suitors, GTE and Worldcom -- insisted that it still wanted a partnership with MCI. It, too, announced operating earnings that exceeded expectations, though the bottom line was affected by one-time costs. D10.
 
$875 Million Bid in Long Distance
ACC, a provider of local and long-distance telephone service, said it had received an unsolicited $875 million offer from Tel-Save Holdings, a long-distance company. D10.

Signs of Economic Vibrance
The Government said new-home sales fell slightly but remained strong in September, and applications for unemployment insurance slid last week. The reports suggest that the economy had considerable stamina before the stock market's gyrations this week. D2.
 
Treasuries Ascend Again
Treasury bonds continued to gain from the uncertainty in the stock market and the diminished fears that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates soon. The yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond fell to 6.14 percent from 6.20 percent. D20.
 
The dollar was dragged lower by the drop in stocks, adding to a weeklong slump against the Swiss franc and the German mark while turning lower against the Japanese yen, against which the dollar had risen. D17.

The price of gold, a traditional safe haven for investors -- rose sharply, buoyed by uncertainty over the Asian financial crisis and fears that tensions between the United States and Iraq would escalate. D17.
 
Sony in Black
Earnings at Sony rose sharply, helped by rising demand for digital electronic products and the success of the Will Smith film "Men in Black," which helped the company fix its sights on a box-office revival for its Hollywood studios. D4.
 
Pharmacia Earnings Decline
Pharmacia & Upjohn said quarterly net income fell 20 percent as its older drugs faced strong competition and exchange-rate fluctuations ate into sales. D10.

A New Approach for Fila
Fila is refocusing its sales pitches centered on Grant Hill, the basketball star. An extensive campaign by Arnell Group Brand Consulting, to introduce the fourth version of the shoe named after him, seeks to concentrate more on the performance aspects of the product than its fashionability. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. D9.

HEADLINE: Pen in Hand, Raul Salinas Denies Murder and Theft

BYLINE: By JULIA PRESTON and PETER TRUELL 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 27

 BODY:
When his brother was President of Mexico, Raul Salinas de Gortari lived the high life, enjoying the thoroughbred horses, fast cars and luxurious houses readily available to someone who could deposit more than $100 million in Swiss bank accounts.
Now, after spending much of the last three years in a cramped, frigid cell in Mexico's harshest prison, Mr. Salinas says that he amassed his fortune legitimately, but acknowledges that he did it by seizing the "huge opportunities" for business deals afforded a sibling of Mexico's leader. 
 In his first extensive interview with a foreign publication since he was jailed in February, 1995, on suspicion of murder, Mr. Salinas vigorously denied the homicide charges as well as allegations that he was paid by Mexico's drug barons to protect their multi-billion dollar enterprises. He also provided new details of how two American financial institutions, Citibank and Bankers Trust, handled his money.
Mexican authorities do not allow Mr. Salinas to meet directly with reporters. And so one day last week, the man who has become a symbol to many Mexicans of the venal abuse of political power sat down with a ballpoint pen and white pad of paper -- the only writing materials he is allowed. He responded with 10 pages of replies to written questions from The New York Times, answering in occasionally awkward English that his lawyer later corrected.
"I always have had private business, and when you are the brother of the President of Mexico, many huge opportunities come to you, as happened to me," wrote Mr. Salinas, the eldest brother of Carlos Salinas de Gortari, whose term in office ended in late 1994. "There was no need for me, with the position I had, to get involved with drug dealers."
One such opportunity, he said, arose in 1993 when the Mexican Government sold a leading television network to private investors for $641 million. Raul Salinas confirmed that he loaned the lead investor $30 million around the time of the sale because he was certain he would make a profit and it would be "a good one." The interview was arranged by Stanley Arkin, Mr. Salinas's New York-based lawyer. Mr. Arkin also set up several hours of conversations with members of Mr. Salinas's immediate family who live in Mexico, including his father and three of his siblings.
The siblings -- Adriana, who is 47 and runs a publishing company; Enrique, 44, a civil engineer; and Sergio, a 43-year-old sociologist -- criticized their brother Raul for making "stupid mistakes" and misusing privileges that came to him as a result of his brother's Presidency.
But they adamantly denied that anyone in the Salinas family had any role in drug trafficking or theft of government money.
Defending Raul Salinas and protesting his imprisonment, the Salinas clan gathered in the wood-paneled library overlooking a garden at the elegant Mexico City home they have occupied for 45 years. They charged that overzealous authorities have demonized Raul and the rest of the family of the former President, who is widely blamed for a severe economic crisis that erupted just after he left office.
"When a wounded animal falls, the hyenas close in to finish it off," said Adriana Salinas. "The authorities are trying to finish us off from every side by attempting to show that we are thieves, drug-traffickers and amoral people."
Mr. Salinas's relatives said they were stunned to learn of the huge balances in his Swiss accounts and they called Raul Salinas's use of false documents and other financial subterfuges "indefensible."
"Raul was in a very influential position in my brother's administration in which he had many business opportunities," said Enrique Salinas, his brother. "We know that this is a common situation for someone who is in the President's family, but we feel that Raul overdid it. He was a show-off. He abused his possibilities."
"But we know, we are absolutely sure, that he is not guilty of drugs or taking money from the Government," Enrique Salinas said.
Former President Carlos Salinas, whose reputation was wrecked by his brother Raul's scandals, is living in forced exile in Dublin, Ireland, although he has not been charged with any crime in Mexico. He did not participate in the interviews.
Since 1995, Raul Salinas has been held without bond on murder charges at the Almoloya prison near Mexico City, a maximum security prison designed for dangerous convicted felons which, he noted pensively, was built on orders from his brother Carlos. Raul Salinas's visits from relatives and defense lawyers are limited and closely monitored by prison guards.
Disclosures two years ago that American banks helped Raul Salinas move more than $100 million to Swiss accounts touched off investigations in Mexico, Switzerland and the United States that are still unfolding.
Swiss investigators have said they believe the deposits resulted from drug payoffs, but have yet to present evidence publicly to support that assertion. In the United States, officials have been examining Citibank's handling of the money and why the bank accepted such large deposits from Mr. Salinas, a former bureaucrat who earned a modest salary for much of his career. No charges have been brought by either country.
The Swiss have interviewed several witnesses in the United States who link Raul Salinas to drug trafficking, but the Salinas family says there is no hard evidence to support those allegations. Under Swiss banking law, the Government can keep any money shown to be drug-tainted.
"My money in Switzerland is honest money, and by this time they should know it," Mr. Salinas wrote. "I have never taken a peso from a public budget or a drug dealer and I believe the charges against me are false and will be defeated."
He said, as he has in the past, that most of the money deposited in Switzerland was put up by private Mexican investors for an investment fund that he planned to begin using to finance international trade projects in Mexico after his brother's term was over.
"I was in charge of finding good investment opportunities and I was very well positioned for that," Mr. Salinas wrote, although he did not mention any specific project he was considering. "But my arrest on Feb. 28, 1995, stopped everything."
Mr. Salinas declined to specify how much of the money in the Swiss accounts belongs directly to him and exactly where he got it.
His comments left other questions unanswered. No contracts were signed to establish the fund, formalize the tranfers to Mr. Salinas or detail planned investments. The dollar transfers, made in the months just prior to a devastating peso devaluation in Mexico, passed through a web of off-shore front companies into Swiss accounts Mr. Salinas opened using a fake passport.
"They trusted me," Mr. Salinas said of his partners, in his only explanation for the secrecy and informality of the transactions.
One deal that did go forward, Mr. Salinas said, involved the Government's sale of a broadcast franchise which became TV Azteca, now Mexico's second largest television network. Mr. Salinas said he lent $30 million to Ricardo Salinas Pliego, an entrepreneur who is not a relative, just as the Mexican Government was awarding his group the sale.
"I was going to get the money back with a profit (a good one)," Raul Salinas wrote.
A spokesman for TV Azteca said today: "All the details on this subject are on the record. The loan is outstanding and the interest will be paid at maturity."
Mr. Salinas also described his relations with Amy G. Elliott, the Citibank vice-president who was his private banker beginning in 1992 and helped him to move tens of millions of dollars to Switzerland and set up companies in the Cayman Islands. Citibank, according to Mr. Salinas' account, looked him over carefully when it accepted him as a client.
The issue is an important one for the bank. American laws and regulations on money laundering require banks to make an effort to know both their customers and the source of their money.
"They were very strict," at first, Raul Salinas wrote of Citibank. "They asked a lot of questions about the origin of the money, they asked about my private businesses and public sector jobs; they visited my house, they met my family and some of my friends like Carlos Hank," the Mexican financier who introduced Mr. Salinas to Ms. Elliott.
But then things changed.
"After that," he said, "they didn't ask many questions. I trusted them and they trusted me."
Citibank said today through a spokesman, Richard Howe, that the bank continues to cooperate with investigators. "We constantly watch for possible violation of the laws by the bank or its employees, and in this case, we have found no reason to believe there have been any," Mr. Howe said. He added that Ms. Elliott remains a vice president "in good standing."
Mr. Salinas also described another important relationship with a New York bank: Bankers Trust New York Corporation, where he said he also had a personal banker whose name he could not remember. One account that Mr. Salinas held at the Zurich branch of Bankers Trust with his wife, Paulina Castanon, carried the title "Bonaparte" and held $10 million in April 1994, according to bank records provided by one of Mr. Salinas's business associates.
The Mexican Government's investigation of Raul Salinas for the 1994 murder of Jose Francisco Ruiz Massieu, a former state governor who had once been Adriana Salinas's husband, has been plagued with irregularities.
The former chief prosecutor on the case is now in jail, charged with conspiring to frame Mr. Salinas. Yet the Government is pressing forward and has refused to move Mr. Salinas to a less restrictive prison.
Mr. Arkin, Raul Salinas's lawyer, said that much of the testimony in the American investigations appeared to come from convicted drug criminals "who had an extraordinary interest" in helping themselves by accusing Mr. Salinas.
Mr. Arkin said, "I'd hope my government takes a very careful and sober look at what may very well be the same sort of fabrications that are taking place in Mexico in the homicide case."
The family patriarch, Raul Salinas Lozano, who is 80, spoke affectionately of Raul, Jr. as "a very, very good son." But he claimed he never talked business with him.
"I never thought he had money," Mr. Salinas Lozano said.
After the family's turmoil, Mr. Salinas Lozano said he was offering one piece of advice to his grandchildren:
"I ask them, 'Please don't go into politics.' "
