HEADLINE: THE 1997 ELECTIONS: THE RECORD;
Messinger Has Moved Right, But Not Sufficiently for Some

SERIES: RACE FOR CITY HALL: The Challenger's Record

BYLINE: By FRANK BRUNI 

 BODY:
Talk to the people best acquainted with Ruth W. Messinger's industrious tenure as a New York City Councilwoman and a myriad of issues get mentioned, from child welfare to campaign finance reform, American intervention in Nicaragua to gay rights. As the Council's resident firebrand from 1978 through 1989, Ms. Messinger was as rarely at a loss for causes as she was for words.
But the initiative that many of her colleagues remember best, invoking it alternately as an example of her grit and an emblem of her recklessness, is commercial rent control. 
 Commercial rent control has always been a controversial idea, deemed by many politicians to be too meddlesome in the economy, too perilous to investment and growth. But in the boom years of the 1980's, when merchants in Manhattan saw rents practically quadruple overnight, Ms. Messinger was a leading voice for some kind of regulation, pressing for binding arbitration between landlords and tenants who faced increases above a certain amount.
Ultimately, she failed. But along the way, she succeeded in defining and distilling her political identity as a champion of underdogs more dogged than most others, a true believer in the aggressive ministrations of government and a populist ready to challenge the corporate interests that other politicians were more reluctant to estrange.
These are traits that emerge repeatedly in an examination of Ms. Messinger's two-decade political career, which embraces not only her 12 years as a Councilwoman but her eight years as Manhattan Borough President, the elected office she has held since 1990.
Ms. Messinger is now running for mayor as the Democratic nominee, and while supporters look to her past and see evidence that she would institute a more compassionate city government, detractors see proof positive that she would usher in a less restrained and sensible one.
"She'd clearly be better on social issues," said City Councilman Stanley E. Michels, a Manhattan Democrat and an old friend, comparing Ms. Messinger with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. "I think she'd be much more sensitive to the underclass, to the less fortunate, to minorities."
But other politicians -- some Democrats as well as Republicans -- said that these proclivities, etched perhaps more clearly in her political record than in her current campaign, were too extreme.
"She represents a philosophy far to the left of what I believe is good for the city of New York," said former Mayor Edward I. Koch, a Democrat who sparred repeatedly with Ms. Messinger when he occupied Gracie Mansion and when she served, in his words, as "the intellectual leader of the left wing of the City Council." Mr. Koch said that he planned to cross party lines on Tuesday and vote for Mr. Giuliani, a man he personally dislikes.
In recent years, Ms. Messinger has tacked somewhat to the right, mellowing her rhetoric and -- perhaps most striking -- supporting the kinds of commercial and residential development she once opposed. She abandoned commercial rent control.
But the extent of her transformation is difficult to gauge. In her current campaign, Ms. Messinger has occasionally diverted attention from her past without making clear where she stands in the present on a broad range of issues.
Moreover, Ms. Messinger became Borough President just as the City Charter was being revised in ways that greatly diminished the post, and she has spent the better part of a decade in something of a political holding pattern.
When former Mayor David N. Dinkins, whom Ms. Messinger succeeded as Borough President, was asked repeatedly to pinpoint her accomplishments in that job, he talked vaguely about her priorities before finally conceding: "A borough president doesn't have any power."
 
On the Council
Leaning to the Left; Strong on Details
Ms. Messinger also had limited power on the Council. Representing the Upper West Side of Manhattan, she spoke for an unusually progressive district where her membership in the Democratic Socialists of America was a badge of honor, and she voted frequently in the Council's dissident minority.
Her influence on the Council, even by her own estimation, was often indirect, measured not so much in a long litany of legislation attributable to her as in the way she shaped debates. Colleagues said that Ms. Messinger did astonishingly thorough homework and came to discussions with reams of information and long lists of questions.
Ms. Messinger, a former social worker, demonstrated a consistent concern for the homeless and poor, battered children and bruised wives, victims of oppression and targets of bigotry. She fought against the displacement of residents of single-room occupancy hotels that were slated for gentrification, and her criticisms of the city's child welfare system helped trigger reforms.
But Ms. Messinger's specific remedies for social ills were not always the most widely accepted ones, at least at the time. For example, she was an early advocate of the distribution of condoms in schools. She was one of the most ardent proponents of a citywide gay rights bill, promoting it for eight years until it finally became law in 1986. The City Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, who voted against it, said that Ms. Messinger deserved as much credit as anyone else for its passage.
But critics say that in her steadfast support for minority groups and what she assumed they wanted, Ms. Messinger sometimes pandered to them. For example, in 1985, she opposed the closing of gay bathhouses, a position that echoed some of the loudest gay advocates, but not all of them, and that ignored the advice of most public health officials seeking to curb the spread of AIDS. Ms. Messinger argued at the time that bathhouses, where men met for anonymous sex, were not a major threat in the spread of the disease.
On this issue and others, Ms. Messinger seemed resistant to any abridging of civil liberties. She abstained from a Council vote to make the sale or possession of drug paraphernalia a crime, citing worries that it would disproportionately punish minorities.
At the same time, however, she supported some legislation that would have involved local government in citizens' lives in new ways, such as an unsuccessful resolution requiring permits for bicycles.
 
Legislative Record
Campaign Finance, Taxes and Broccoli
One of the most persistent raps against Ms. Messinger was that she embraced too many issues, wasting her passion on matters peripheral to city government and beyond its control. She supported a broccoli boycott in solidarity with exploited agricultural workers, introduced a Council resolution condemning United States interference in Central America and sponsored another that called on Congress to reopen the investigation of the spy case against Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, who were executed in 1953.
All of this distracted from more substantive achievements.
"She was part of an awful lot of landmark bills," said Mr. Vallone, identifying Ms. Messinger as one of the principal architects and advocates of the city's first recycling law in 1989; of a 1988 act banning smoking in many public places, and of a 1988 campaign finance measure that, for candidates who want to receive public funds, put ceilings on the individual contributions they could accept and on the amount they could spend.
Ms. Messinger was also a driving force behind a 1984 law that protected government whistleblowers from repercussions.
But she perhaps garnered the most attention during her Council years for her frequent attacks on the hefty tax abatements that the Koch administration routinely granted developers and corporations to spur the construction or rehabilitation of residential and commercial buildings.
Her success in exposing these practices and pressuring the city to modify them made her a hero among many neighborhood groups and tenants but a villain among many landowners and landlords. And it earned her a reputation as an archenemy of development. But in an interview, Ms. Messinger said that she was merely exerting common sense. Tax abatements, she argued, "were much too consistently done with a broad brush, with no balance of questions about what kind of development was good for the city, what kind was problematic."
She said that on the residential front, the city was often bankrolling the evictions of low and middle-income tenants to make way for new luxury apartments. And on the commercial front, corporate America was doing so well and the New York real estate market was so hot that the city did not need to forfeit tax revenue to insure building.
Nor could it afford to, she said, because the city was emerging from a fiscal crisis and strapped for cash. As chairwoman of the Council's Committee on Revenue Enhancement, Ms. Messinger made city taxation policies an area of expertise. While she suggested cutting taxes on small businesses, she advocated increases in other taxes, including those on hotel rooms and alcohol.
These days, she talks less about raising new revenue than pruning existing spending, a change in emphasis that has surprised some longtime supporters.
"She never said she was for taxes," remembered Gale A. Brewer, Ms. Messinger's chief of staff on the Council, "but I didn't realize she was this against them."
 
Borough President
Moving to Center, Within New Limits
During Ms. Messinger's campaign for Manhattan borough president in 1989, she not only reaped the fruits of the campaign finance law she had helped enact, but met accusations from some fellow politicians that she was being a glutton.
Under the law, she qualified for $600,000 in public money, and she took and spent all of it, on top of the even larger amount she had raised on her own, even though she was running against token opposition. She said she used the public and private money to help educate voters about important issues, to build name recognition among voters, to help Mr. Dinkins' mayoral campaign and to lobby for City Charter revisions.
In 1992, Ms. Messinger surprised many political colleagues by endorsing the construction plans for Riverside South, the complex of buildings that Donald Trump is raising along the Hudson River.
Opponents of the project say that Ms. Messinger, in anticipation of her own mayoral campaign, was simply trying to shed an anti-business image. But Ms. Messinger said that the land Riverside South occupies was inevitably going to be developed and that Mr. Trump's proposal included such public perks as a waterfront park and money for renovating the subway station at West 72nd Street and Broadway.
"This looked to me like the best opportunity we were going to have," she said.
As for her more receptive attitude toward development in general, Ms. Messinger said that, as Borough President, she no longer speaks only for the Upper West Side, a rather thoroughly developed patch of concrete, and that the New York economy is not quite as sunny as it was in the mid-1980's.
"I'm representing an entire island with potential development sites at a time when it's clear the city needs some ongoing investment, some additional building and the jobs that that brings," Ms. Messinger said. "Time and venue have changed."
She acknowledged that she has changed, too, but only, she said, in some of the particular measures she advocates, not in her fundamental convictions. Of the limited money that the Manhattan Borough President's office controls -- between $15 million and $20 million annually -- Ms. Messinger has funneled more into the generally poorer portion of Manhattan above 96th Street than into the wealthier swath below.
 
Mixed Reviews
Despite Changes, Still a Crusader
Her willingness to tread into politically turbulent waters followed her to the Borough Presidency. Both Ms. Messinger and her appointee to the citywide Board of Education, Luis O. Reyes, supported the Rainbow Curriculum, which, among other suggestions, proposed lessons on tolerance of homosexuality for elementary school children.
And, as always, Ms. Messinger has not confined her crusades to matters of local governance. In 1992, she appeared at a concert in Manhattan called the Ban the Dam Jam to speak out against a hydroelectric project that would flood land in Quebec used by Cree Indians.
Her performance as Borough President draws mixed reviews from Manhattan's representatives on the City Council -- Democrats as well as the lone Republican -- and from leaders of community boards, most of whom say she has been good, but not great.
They praise the blueprint that her office developed for turning the Manhattan waterfront into a continuous esplanade. They also laud the research and planning assistance that her office has provided to overlooked sectors of Manhattan's economy, most notably the diamond district on West 47th Street.
But they say that her effectiveness has been undercut, particularly in the last four years, by the distraction of preparing to run for higher office.
"She made her office into an anti-Giuliani publicity machine," said City Councilman Andrew S. Eristoff, a Republican who represents the Upper East Side. "Her annual budget documents and reviews have been nothing more than political manifestoes."
Ms. Messinger said that some of the real work done by a borough president is simply not visible to outsiders, and that she has been willing to use her extremely limited budget for projects that do not lead to fancy ribbon cuttings.
For example, she put up $1.8 million to remove asbestos at the Museum of Natural History and, she said, to dredge "the lead guck out of the plumbing." Ms. Messinger said that if the museum announces that it needs money for a gleaming new wing, "Lots of people want to do that. But they say the pipes are so corroded you can't turn on the water -- what donor cares?"
Ms. Messinger has always made it a point to care, even when she was one of the only ones.

HEADLINE: BASKETBALL;
Check That Playbill: It's Nearly Show Time

BYLINE: By MIKE WISE 

 BODY:
The Dynasty Farewell Tour begins tonight in Boston, where Michael and the Role Players will welcome Rick Pitino back to the National Basketball Association. On the West Coast, the Lakers want to send the Jazz a message even without Shaquille O'Neal. Larry Bird and Chuck Daly are off the golf course and on the sidelines. Charles Barkley, the superstar who cries wolf, is contemplating retirement again. And two women will obliterate another barrier in American sport.
Tempering the marquee matchups, legends and historical significance is the reality that not all is well as the N.B.A. begins its 51st season. 
 Several All-Stars are out with injuries until perhaps the first of the year. John Stockton, Scottie Pippen and Alonzo Mourning are expected to miss at least the first month of the season to rehabilitate from recent surgery. Michael Jordan will have to piggyback the aging Bulls until January. And Barkley, days after allegedly tossing a 5-foot-2-inch man through a window, has not decided whether he will grace the N.B.A. with his irascible presence this season.
Philadelphia's Allen Iverson will miss the opener and Portland's Isaiah Rider will miss the first two games because of league-imposed suspensions for spending part of their summer vacation in trouble with the law.
For now, the Bulls vs. the Celtics in Pitino's return to the league and the Lakers playing host to Utah in perhaps a Western Conference title preview will try to camouflage the blemishes.
Other games with intriguing sub-plots tonight include the Indiana Pacers at the Nets in Bird's return, and the deep and talented Knicks at Charlotte, where the Hornets were swept by New York in their first-round playoff series a year ago.
O'Neal will miss the opener with a pulled abdominal muscle. And Malone, who hasn't missed a start since 1991, is questionable after injuring his middle finger on his right hand during practice yesterday. He will make a game-time decision about playing. His streak of 467 straight games, the fourth-longest active streak in the N.B.A., is in jeopardy.
New York's Buck Williams needs 64 games to move ahead of Moses Malone (1,329) and into third place on the career list of games played behind Robert Parish (1,611) and Kareem Abdul-Jabbar (1,560).
Rules changes will go into effect tonight, including the lengthening of the 3-point line to its original distance of 23 feet 9 inches.
After Pat Riley, Pitino literally ushered in the coach-as-savior era. He leads a group of well-compensated gym teachers who have entered another economic stratosphere. Red Auerbach, the franchise patriarch, made $100,000 his last season as coach in 1966. The former Celtic great Dave Cowens, the league's lowest-paid coach, will make $500,000 in Charlotte this season.
Pitino's $7 million annual salary as president and coach of the Celtics doubles the $3.5 million salary of Dee Brown, Boston's highest-paid player. Pitino's best player, Antoine Walker, makes $1.9 million.
Daly in Orlando, Larry Brown in Philadelphia and Bird in Indiana also signed deals that pay them more than $4 million a season.
"It's kind of an interesting concept, but bottom line it's still the players' league," Daly said recently. "I don't care if your credentials stretch from here to 1930 and include everything in the book. If your players can't shoot, pass and dribble, it doesn't matter. You need talent."
History will indeed be made over the weekend when the referees Violet Palmer, 33, and Dee Kantner, 37, become the first women to officiate games in one of the nation's four major professional sports leagues. They were appointed by the N.B.A. earlier this week, creating a major stir among the players.
"You can't pat them on the butt," Jordan said facetiously.
Kantner laughed at the notion that she might pursue harassment charges for what remains a routine encounter between a player and an official. "I never thought I'd be answering questions like these at 37," she said. "As long as it's in the context of the game, I'm fine with it."
Finally, the league may be less than a year away from entering the post-Jordan era. Given all the concerns and absences on opening night, it is a sobering thought.
"I can give it up if I tell myself that's it," said Jordan, 35, who has hinted often of retiring again after this season. "I'm not afraid to walk away. Some people think I am. That's someone's perception of me who doesn't know me. I never think about the negative. I think about what's happening now. I'm still playing. We still got a chance to win a championship. That's how I look at it."
Said Commissioner David Stern: "If the most extraordinary athlete of our time is nearing the end of his active career, that has to be a concern to us. But we can't spend our time lamenting. We have to spend our time preparing for the post-Michael era. We are going to miss him. There's going to be a void. The question is, who's going to fill it, and the answer is, a lot of players."

HEADLINE: THE MARKET TURMOIL: THE TRADING;
Aftershocks From Asia Hit Wall St.

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
The worldwide drop in share prices resumed with waves of selling yesterday, dragging down stock market indexes on six continents and sending Wall Street into another retreat.
The currency and economic crisis engulfing Asia -- and reverberating through wobbly stock markets there -- is worrying investors elsewhere in the world who fear a contagious economic slowdown. That has meant jitters from Tokyo to Wall Street. 
 Yesterday, after prices dropped in Hong Kong, Japan and Europe, the selling pressure reached New York and then slammed into Brazil and Argentina, where fears are growing that a banking and currency crisis might be unfolding.
Early today, stocks rose slightly in Asia. In Tokyo, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 94 points, or almost six-tenths of 1 percent, at the close of trading. Hong Kong stocks were up 138.11 points, or about 1.33 percent at the mid-afternoon break today.
Yesterday, investors in the United States thwarted an early downturn, but a late selling spree sent the Dow Jones industrial average down 125 points, or 1.67 percent, to 7,381.67 -- about 10.6 percent off its record high set Aug. 6.
The losses appeared to send a signal to investors that the huge rebound that occurred after Monday's selloff, when the Dow plummeted 554 points, might mean the American stock market is not yet prepared to resume its historic ascent.
"I don't think the crisis is over," said David Shulman, a strategist at Salomon Brothers. "We're now getting a Latin American version of what happened in Asia, like the contagion has jumped the Pacific."
Although analysts have played down the economic threat to the United States economy -- which remains robust -- they say that investor faith in the stock market, and the idea that everything is perfect, has been breached in recent weeks.
"The prospect of unlimited growth was one of the underpinnings of the 90's bull market," Mr. Shulman said. "But that prospect is suspect for at least the next year."
Perhaps just as important, some analysts argue, is the psychological effect of seeing other bull markets topple. In Hong Kong, for instance, the main stock market index rode higher than almost any other, soaring 480 percent between late 1990 and its Sept. 7 peak this year. During the same period, the Dow was up as much as 250 percent at its peak.
Since then, the Hang Seng index has been battered, plunging 38 percent in two months, largely because of the economic and currency crisis that began in Thailand and swept across Malaysia, Singapore and Indonesia. In recent months, the old talk among Wall Street analysts of the great Asian Tigers has degenerated into caustic remarks about real estate bubbles and "golf course capitalism."
Trading volume was again heavy, as more than 712 million shares changed hands, making yesterday the third-busiest day in history on the New York Stock Exchange after Tuesday and Wednesday.
In fact, this has already been the busiest trading week in history on the Big Board, with more than 3.3 billion shares traded in four sessions, easily obliterating last week's record of a little more than 3 billion shares.
That kind of activity, analysts say, is a sign that investors are worried that the recent turmoil could fester and that a big portion of the spectacular gains of the last three years could be erased.
"The market was discounting perfection, and we've been slowly finding out that the world's not perfect," said Gail Dudack, the chief investment strategist at UBS Securities. "And so now the consensus has disappeared. And once you break confidence, in order to reinstill it, the market's going to have to demonstrate real value."
The day got off to a bad start, as investors woke and learned that heavy selling had resumed in Europe and Asia overnight.
In Chicago -- the epicenter of futures and options trading -- the indexes were all negative. In New York, the Dow fell 100 points at the opening. But as the day progressed, a seesaw bout took place as the index swung between negative and positive. Through much of the day, though, a broad array of smaller stocks got battered. The Russell 2000 index of smaller company issues closed down 1.4 percent.
Technology issues -- under pressure early after analysts downgraded the prospects of Dell Computer and Intel -- slid throughout the day, sending the technology-heavy Nasdaq down 32.34 points, or 2 percent, to 1,570.41.
Shares of Dell -- an issue that everyone thought was a winner -- have lost nearly 26 in the last two weeks and closed down 5 1/2 yesterday, to 78. Intel fell 4 1/2, to 75 3/4.
Banking issues also suffered over concerns that there could be large losses related to economic problems in Asia, Latin America and Eastern Europe. The Standard & Poor's bank index fell 3.2 percent yesterday, taking down all 28 of the issues listed, led by BankAmerica, which dropped 3 5/16, to 69 3/4.
The broader market was also battered. On the Big Board, 804 issues rose while 2,175 fell, and blue chips -- which showed some strength early -- suffered the worst at the close.
The S.& P. 500 fell 15.48 points, or 1.68 percent, to 903.68. And 26 of the 30 Dow stocks fell, led by J. P. Morgan, which dropped 3 7/8, to 110 3/8.
Analysts, however, insist that the United States economy is strong and that corporate earnings will not suffer greatly from the events in Asia.
Bruce Steinberg, the chief economist at Merrill Lynch, said that although economic growth in America would slow some because of the Asian turmoil, the economy might have been threatened by overheating anyway, which would have prompted the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates. "Next year, U.S. growth would have slowed no matter what," he said. "Now it's going to slow on its own because of these outside effects, away from the U.S."
While several analysts said damage to corporate earnings would be slight, others predicted that prominent stocks would suffer as investors downgrade their expectations of profits from sales to Asia.
"The idea that every U.S. company is growing and that we were going to sell more Cokes and Nikes to China -- that may still be true, but today, it's a little less so," said Frederick Taylor, chief investment officer at the U.S. Trust Company. "So this selloff is partly fundamentals based. It's not just psychological."

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Business Report Is Rosy

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Business activity in the New York metropolitan area rose in October from the previous month to the highest level in nearly a year, the National Association of Purchasing Management-New York said yesterday.
The New York purchasing managers index rose to 70 percent this month from September's 60.3 percent. This month's reading was the highest since last December, when the index stood at 72.9 percent. A reading above 50 percent signals growth. 
 However, looking at the next six months, New York purchasers weren't as upbeat this month as they were in September. The index of future conditions fell to 65.8 percent from 69.5 percent in September.
"Overall, the local economy continued to show solid growth in October, although the evaluation of future conditions six months hence slipped to its lowest reading since May," the report said. In May, the outlook index stood at 64.9 percent.
In addition, inflation picked up in the New York area this month, the purchasing managers said. The prices-paid index increased to 58 percent in October from 48 percent in September.

HEADLINE: Inside Art

BYLINE: By Carol Vogel 

 BODY:

Bulls, Bears And Auctions
Will the stock market's roller-coaster performance this week affect the important Impressionist, modern and contemporary art sales that begin in 10 days in Manhattan?
The experts, putting an obviously optimistic spin on the situation, don't think so. "Money always has to find a home," said Christopher Burge, chairman of Christie's in America. "An awful lot depends on the underlying economy. If the economy is weak, the art market will falter, but right now things are strong and I think our sales will grow as they have over the past few seasons." 
 When the stock market crashed in 1987, the art market went in the opposite direction. Just three weeks after Black Monday, Sotheby's Impressionist and modern art sale broke $100 million for the first time, a 45 percent increase from six months before.
"We are optimistic that history will repeat itself," said Kevin Bousquette, chief operating officer for Sotheby's worldwide.
Mr. Burge of Christie's recalled that after the 1987 crash, prices rose even more over the next two years.
Donald B. Marron, chairman of Paine Webber and himself a major art collector, said the quality of the pictures, not stock prices, fueled the market. "Quality pictures are always in demand," he said. "But because the price of paintings have become so high, if the stock market goes down before the sales, it may well free up money for the art world and be an alternative use of capital."
 
Selling Low
For years, Henry Kravis has been a serious buyer of 19th- and early 20th-century paintings. Now the financier hopes to become a major seller, and has chosen Sotheby's, where he is a major shareholder and board member, for several important sales. But his first three efforts have not done as well as the auction house expected.
While none of the paintings he has decided to sell are listed in the catalogues with his name, experts in the field who are familiar with his collection have identified them.
In a sale last week in Manhattan, Mr. Kravis offered Winterhalter's "Young Woman From L'Ariccia" (1838), which was featured on the cover of Sotheby's 19th-century paintings catalogue. The work was expected to bring $2 million to $2.5 million, but sold for $1.7 million.
He also sold two paintings by Delacroix: "An Arab Horse" (1840-1850), for which $1.4 million to $1.8 million was expected but $992,500 received, and "Greek Officer (1823-1824), which carried an estimate of $350,000 to $500,000 and sold for $343,500.
Prices include the auction house's commission, which is 15 percent of the first $50,000 and 10 percent of the rest. Estimates do not reflect commissions.
The results are not stopping Mr. Kravis from selling more. In December, four of his Sargents will be in Sotheby's American-paintings sale in Manhattan.
The most important is "In the Garden, Corfu" (1909), which experts say is likely to fetch $5 million to $7 million. The painting depicts two women reading in a garden, and is considered so important that it might break the record for an American painting sold at auction as well as the record for a Sargent. The Sargent record was set when "Cashmere" (1908) sold in December at Christie's for $11.1 million.
The three other Sargents Mr. Kravis is selling are "The Rialto" (circa 1909), which is expected to sell for $3 million to $5 million; "The Venetian Wine Shop" (1898), which is also estimated to bring $3 million to $5 million, and "A Gust of Wind" (circa 1886), expected to bring $700,000 to $900,000.
That would leave Mr. Kravis with two Sargents. The better, "A Morning Walk" (1888), shows a woman with a parasol; the other is a 1902 portrait of Charles Stuart, Sixth Marquess of Londonderry.
The financier is disposing of his paintings, experts say, because they are not in keeping with his new wife's taste. Marie-Josee Kravis, whom Mr. Kravis married three years ago, prefers fine French furniture and Old Master paintings, they said, while Mr. Kravis's former wife, Carolyne Roehm, liked 19th-century paintings.
Mr. Kravis did not return telephone calls. Officials at Sotheby's declined to comment on the sales.
 
Poussin to Los Angeles
Persistence has paid off. The J. Paul Getty Museum, whose history of trying to import paintings from England has been rocky, just received permission from the British authorities to bring Nicolas Poussin's "Landscape With Calm" (1650) to California, where it will become part of the Getty's permanent collection.
The painting, considered one of the 17th-century French painter's most important works, will hang in a big gallery of Italian and French paintings when the Getty opens its new $1 billion campus in the Brentwood section of Los Angeles in December.
The Getty bought the painting for a reported $25.6 million from the trustees of Sudeley Castle in Gloucestershire, who were selling it to raise money to save the castle.
But before the painting could leave England, the British Export Review Committee had to determine that no British institutions or private collectors were willing to match the Getty's price and keep the work in Britain.
The process is neither simple nor quick, as the Getty knows all too well. It waited five years before learning it could not export Canova's "Three Graces," for which it was willing to pay $12 million, because the Victoria and Albert Museum in London and the National Galleries of Scotland had raised enough money to match the price. While the Poussin purchase has a happy ending for the California museum, the painting was bought seven months ago and not until the end of last week was its export license granted.
Luckily for the Getty, there are already 20 Poussins in British museums and 19 more in private collections in England so no major British institution or collector tried to buy the painting.

CORRECTION-DATE: November 4, 1997, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
A brief report in the Inside Art column on Friday about Henry Kravis's sales of part of his art collection misidentified the New York auction house where John Singer Sargent's "Cashmere" (1908) was sold in December for $11.1 million, a record for the artist. It was Sotheby's, not Christie's.
